Governmeut Oriental Series –Class B, No. 6

HISTORY OF DHARMASƒÄSTRA

( ANCIENT AND MEDI√ÜVAL RELIGIOUS

AND CIVIL LAW IN INDIA )

PANDURANG VAMAN KANE National Professor of Indology

Volume 1 REVISED AND ENLARGED

Part 1

Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona 4

1968

Copies can be had direct from the Bhandarkar Oriental

Research Institute, Poona 4 ( India ) Price Rs. 50 per copy, exclusive of postage

Vol. 1: Second Edition

Part 1

Pages 1-112 printed by Shri D. V. Ambekar, at the

Aryabhusban Press, 915/1 Shivajinagar, Poona 4

and

Pages 113-684 printed at the Bbandarkar Institute

Pross, Poona 4

and

Published by Dr. R. N. Dandekar, M.A., Ph.D.,

Hon. Secretary, Bhandarkar Oriental

Resourol Institute, Poona 4

PREFACE

On November 17, 1962, the publication of the fifth and last Volume of Professor P. V. KANE’s History of Dharmasastra was formally announced by Dr. S. RADHAKRISIINAN, and a significant landmark in the history of Indological research in this country may be said to have been thereby established. The Histury of Dhramu≈õƒ´stru is a literary work which is. truly magnificent both in conception and execution. Its five Volumes, which together extend over nearly 6,500 pages, seek to present the most comprchensive treatment of the religious and civil law of ancient and medieval India. And, Professor KANE has accomplished this gigantic task single-handed incidentally, he has written down every word in the History in his own hand –and that too while he had been occupied with various other literary and public activities. As I have said on another occasion, for Professor KANE, the History of Dharma ≈õƒÅstra is the crowning glory of a life of great fulfilment, and, for the Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, it is a matter of signal pride and honour to have been closely associ ated with that work.

The first Volume of the History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra was published in 1930. When the last Volume was published in 1962, the Institute felt that a second edition of the first Volume was manifestly called for. And this, for two reasons. For one thing, that Volume bad almost gone out of print. The second reason was academic in character. The first Volume needed to be revised and enlarged. Perhaps it was the only Volume of the History of Dharmag≈´stra which could have needed any revision at all. Though that Volume opened with an exhaustive theoretical discussion of the concept and sources of Dharma, its major part was devoted to a detailed history of the literature relating to Hindu Dharma≈õƒÅstre. Since the time of its publication, more than thirty-five years ago, quite a considerable amount of material had been publish ed in India and abroad about Dharma≈õƒÅstra literature. Some new texts had been brought to light or some new light and been sought to be thrown on the already known texts oksame of KANE’s own bypotheses had been challenged. It had thug become necessary for the author to examine all this maleriet

FOUNDED

Preface critically and, on the basis of such examination, to modify or ratify or enlarge whatever he had already said on the subject.

However, when the last Volume of the History of DharmasƒÅstra was published in 1962, Professor Kane was already eighty-two years old, and the Institute was naturally hesitant to broach to him the subject of a revised edition of Volume I. But just a casual reference to it was more than enough - indeed, Professor KANE himself must have been thinking of such a revision – and he set out to work on a revised and enlarged edition of the first Volume with his usual assiduousness. In course of time, the printing was started in the Institute’s own Press, but I must confess that the printer could not keep pace with the author. The revision also had grown far beyond the original estimate. It was, therefore, decided to publish the Volume in two parts, and the first part, containing nearly 600 pages, is now being issued on the occasion of the Golden Jubilee of the Institute. As for the second part, I can only say that Professor KANE has almost completed the revision of the entire Volume and the printing of the remaining portion is making steady progress.

Bhandarkar Oriental 1 Research Institute, Poona, May 17, 1968.

R. N. Dandekar

Please note

des1

VOON

The Synopsis of Contents and the General Indeer for the whole Volume together with the necessary Appendite will be given in the Second Part of this Volume.

R. Gharpure ).

I

INS.

A

HISTORY OF DHARMASƒÄSTRA,

  1. Meaning of Dharma

Dharma is one of those Sanskrit words that defy all attempts at an exact rendering in English or any other tongue. That word has passed through several vicissitudes. The dictionaries set out various meanings of Dharma such as ‚Äúordinance, usage, duty, right, justice, morality, virtue, religion, good works, function or characteristic." Dharma is also personified as a doity, as in the well-known verse. AdityacandrƒÅvanilosnalasca… dharma≈õca jƒÅnƒÅti narasya v·πõttam'(MahƒÅbh√•rata, Adi., chap. 74.16) or as in Manusmrti VIII. 16 .v≈ôso hi bhagavƒÅn Dharmah' ( which also occurs in SƒÅntiparva 90.75 ). Vide H. of Dh. Vol. V (part 1) pp. 19-21 for the three words “vrata', ‘dharman’ and ‘rta’ and JBBRAS. Vol. 29 (1954) pp. 1-28. In the hymns of the Rgveda the word appears to be used either as an adjective or a noun (in the form dlarman, generally neuter) and occurs at least about sixty times by itself (i. e, not preceded by a particle like vi or some words like satya), and about eighteen times in combination with a particle ‘vi’ and with the words *sva' and ‘satya’ fifty-six times therein. It is very difficult to say what the exact meaning of the word dharma was in the most ancient period of the Vodic language. The word is clearly derived from root dh? (to uphold, to support, to nourish ). In a few passages, the word appears to be used in the sense of up holder or supporter or sustainer' as in Rg. I. 187.11 and X. 92.22. In these two passages and in Rg. X. 21.33 the word dharma is clearly masculine. In all other cases, the word is either obviously in the neuter or presents a form which may be either masculine or neuter, In most cases the meaning of dharman is religious ordinances or rites ‘as in Rg. I. 22. 18, V. 26. 6, VIII. 43. 24, IX. 64. 1 &c. The refrain’tani dharmƒÅni pratham√¢ny√•san’ occurs in Rg. I. 164. 43 and 50, X. 90. 16. Similarly, we have the words

prathamƒÉ dharmƒÅ' (the primeval or first ordinances) in Rg. III. 17. 1, and X. 56. 3 and the words ‘sanatƒÉ dharmƒÅni (ancient

i fog a Faia HET thu aralin i This occurs in 344 34.7. 2 ‡§á‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•É‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§§ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ 3 ‡§µ‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡§ú‡•Å‡§π‡•Ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡•§History of Dlurma≈õƒÅstra

"

U

ordinances ) occur in Rg. III. 3. 1. In some passages this sense of * religious rites’ would not suit the context, e. g. in IV. 53. 34, V. 63.75, VI. 70. 16, VII. 89. 57. In these passages the meaning seems to be ‘fixed principles or rules of conduct’. In the VƒÅja saneyasamhita the above senses of the word dharman are found, and in II. 3 and V. 27 we have the words ‘dhruvena dharma≈ÜƒÅ.’ In the same Samhita the form ‘dharma·∏•’ (from dharma) becomes frequent, e. g. X. 29, XX. 9. The word ‘Vidharman’is froquently employed in the Rgveda viz. in the instrumental (in X. 46. 6), in the dative (in VIII. 7.5), in the locative in eight passages (I. 164. 36, III. 2. 3, VI. 71. 1, IX. 4. 9, IX. 64. 9, and IX. 86. 29-30, IX. 100.7) probably meaning VidhƒÅra≈Üe) and in the vocative (in V. 17.2). It is difficult to assign a definite meaning to this word in all these passages. But from several passages where the word ‘vidhartr’ is employed (which is derived from the same root dh·ªá with ri) it follows that vidharman probably means the same thing as vidhart; (in Rg. II. 28. 4, VII.7.5, VII. 41. 2, VII. 56. 24) applied to different gods. “Svadharman’as an epithet of Agni occurs in Rg. III. 21.2 and the word Satyadharman is applied to different gods alone viz. to Savity, Vi≈õvedevƒÅh, Agni and to Mitra and Varuna in I. 12 7, V. 51.2, V. 63. 1, X. 34. 8, X. 121. 9, X. 139. 3. In the case of this word the meaning appears to be whose regulations do not fail’. The Atharvaveda contains many of those verses of the Rgveda in which the word dharman occurs, e. g. VI. 51.3 (acitty√§ —Åot tava dharmƒÅ yuyopima), VII, 5. 1 (Yaj√±ena yaj√±amayajanta), VII. 27.5 (trini pada vicakrame ). In XI. 7. 17 the word ‘dharma·∏•’ seems to be used in the sense of ‘merit acquired by the porformance of religious rites.’ In the Aitareya-brƒÅhmana, the word dharma seems to be used in an abstract sense‚Äù, viz. ‘the whole body of religious duties’. The

FOUNI

191

  1. Meaning of Dharma

B»ôhadaranyaka Up. (I. 14. 14) treats Dharma and Satya as equivalent. In the Chandogya-upani≈üadlo (2.23) there is an important passage boaring on the meaning of the word dharmut. ‘there are three branches of dluerna, ono is (constituted by sacrifice, study and charity (i. o. tho stago of house-holder ), the second ( is constitutod by ) austeritios (i. 0. the stage of being a hermit); the third is the brahmac≈´rin dwelling in the house of his teacher and making himself stay with the family of his teacher till the last; all these attain to the worlds of meritorious men; one who abides firmly in bruhman attains immortality.’ It will be seen that in this passage the word * dharmu' stands for the peculiar duties of the W≈õramas. As the word brahmac≈´ri itself occurs in this passage of the Chandogya, it is clearly indicated that this brief passage means to rofer only to the a≈õramas and their special duties. Prof. Hazra (in *Our Heritage' Vol. VII part I pp. 15-36, ‘on the early meaning and scope of the word dharma’) remarks (on p. 20 ) that the word Dharma as used in Vedic literature did not mean any act of vyavah√°ra is shown definitely by this Chandogya passage (II. 23. 1). This is a strange (to put it mildly ) argument as one passage from an Upanisad (relating to only one small aspect of dharma ) cannot control the meaning of the word

Dharma' occurring hundrods of times in Samhit√°s, BrƒÅhmanas and other Upanisads. Vide Br. Up. I. 4. 14, II, 5, 11 for the wide conception of Dharma (to cite only a fow Upanisad passages). The foregoing brief discussion establishes how the

ord dharma passed through several transitions of meaning nd how ultimately its most prominent significance came to be ‘the privileges, duties and obligations of a man, his standard of conduct as a member of the Aryan community, as a member of one of the castes, as a person in a particular stage of life.’ It is in this sense that the word seems to be used in the well known exhortation to the pupil contained in the Taittiriya‚Äú

( Continued from lust puge ) Hicra Hara ( 97. V. 4. 124 ). PƒÅ·πáini employs the word dharma in some of his s≈´tras as in an atia (II. 4.4, wbich derives the word ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï ), IV.4.92 (derives ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø from ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ), ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç IV. 2. 46 ( derives words like $15 ti, 59172177), ‘1tY ERIA’ (IV. 4. 47),

affresquicara (V. 2. 132, which explains Tlaquah or-pissi or-qui. 10 ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™ ‡§è‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§è‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ

upani≈üad (I. 11 ) ‘speak the truth, practise (your own) dharma &c.’ It is in the same sense that the BhagavadgitƒÅ uses the word dharma in the oft-quoted verse “svadharme nidhanam ≈õreyah' The word is employed in this sense in the dharma ≈†ƒÅstra literature. The Manusmrti (1.2) tells us that the sages requested Manu to impart instruction in the dluarmas of all the var≈Üas. The YƒÅj√±avalkya-smrti (I. 1) employs it in the same sense. In the Tantra-v√°rtikall also wo are told that all the dharmas≈´tras are concerned with imparting instruction in the dharmas of var·πáas and ≈´sramas. MedhƒÉtithi commenting on Manu says that the expounders of smrtis dilate upon dharma as five-fold, e. g. varnadhirma, ≈´≈õrama-ƒ±lharma, wrn≈´srama-dharma, naimittikadharma ( such as prƒÅya≈õcitta) and gunadharma (the duty of a crowned king, whether Ksatriya or not, to protect).12 It may be noted that the Mitaksara on Yaj. I. 1 after mentioning the fivefold dharmas and illustrating them adds a sixth category viz. “SidhƒÅrana-dharma'- duties common to all men (including even candƒÅlas) such as ahims√£ and quotes a vedic passage in support ‘na himsyƒÅt sarvƒÅ bh≈´tƒÅni’. Slightly differing enume rations of virtues to be cultivated by all men are found in Gaut. Dh. S. VIII. 23-25, MatsyapurƒÅna 52. 8-10 (8 in all), Manu X. 63 (five), YƒÅj. I. 1. 22 (nine). Vide H. D. Vol. II pp. 10-11 and vol. V pp. 1023‚Äì24, 1637 and 1648. It may be noted that the Artha≈õƒÅstra of Kautilya (1. 3. 13) proscribes for all men ahimsƒÅ, satya, ≈õauca, anas≈´yƒÅ, ƒÅn»õsamsya and k≈üamƒÅ. It is in this sense that the word dharma will be taken in this work. Numerous topics are comprehended under the title dharma≈õƒÅstra, but in this work prominence will be given to works on ƒÅcƒÅra and vyavah≈´ra (law and administration of justice ).

1917

  1. Meaning of Dharma

It would be interesting to recall a few other definitions of dharma. Jaimini13 defines dharma as a desirable goal or result that is indicated by injunctive (Vodic) passages.’ The word dharma would mean such rites as aro conducive to happiness and are onjoined by Vedic passages. The Vaisosikas√ºtral4 defines dharma as ‘that from which results happiness and final beatitude.’ The Manusin»ôti (in 11. 1) gives the following general definition of Dharma.14a ‘Know Dharma to be that which is practised by the learned that lead a moral life, that are free from hatred and partiality, and that is accepted by their hearts (i. e. conscience ).’ Another similar definition is given by the Nitisara of KƒÅmandaka VI. 7 ‘that is Dharma which when done is praised by √§ryas (respectable people) that are conversant with (the vedic) tradi tion and adharma is said to be that which such people consure’. This is a versified rendering of Ap. Dh. S. I. 7. 20 yat-tu ƒÅryƒÅ·∏• kriyamƒÅnam pra≈°amsanti sa dharmo yadgarhante sosdharma·∏•.' There are several other more or less one-sided definitions of dharma such as ‘ahimsƒÅ paramo dharma·∏•’(Anu≈°ƒÅ sanaparva 115. 1.), ‘ƒÅnr≈õamsyam paro dharma·∏•’ (Vanaparva 373. 76), “ƒÅcƒÅrah paramo dharmah' (Manu I. 108). HƒÅrƒ´ta defined dharma as srutipramƒÅnakals' (based on revelation). In the Buddhist sacred books the word dharina has several senses. It often means the whole teaching of Buddha ( S. B. E. Vol. X. p. XXXIII). Another meaning of dharma peculiar to the Buddhist system is an element of existence, i. e. of matter, mind and forces16.

This is not the place to discuss what Asoka’s Dhamma was, From tbe 4th Rock Edict it appears that 12 years after his coronation the Dhamma he wanted to spread or propagate comprised abstentio n injury to living creatures, courtesy for one’s relatives and for H umanid

(Continued on next page)

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

The present work will deal with the sources of dharma, their contents, their chronology and other kindred matters. As the material is vast and the number of works is extremely large, only a few selected works and some important authors will be taken up for detailod treatment. More space will he dovotod to comparatively early works.

  1. Sources of Dharma The Gautamadharmas≈´tra?? says ‘the Veda is the source of dharma and the tradition and practice of those that know it (the Veda ).’ So √Ñpastamba18 says the authority (for the dharmas ) is the consensus of those that know dharma and the Vedas.' Vide also the Vasisthadharma-s≈´tra 19 (I. 4-6). The Manusm·ªôti20 lays down five different sources of dhurmu ‚Äúthe whole Veda is (the foremost) source of dharma and (next) the tradition and the practice of those that know it (the Veda); and further the usages of virtuous men and self-satisfaction.' Y√°j√±a valkya21 declares the sources in a similar strain the Veda, traditional lore, the usages of good men, what is agreeable to one’s self and desire born of due deliberation-this is traditionally recognised as the source of dharma.' These passages make it clear that the principal sources of dharma were conceived to be the Vedas, the Smrtis, and customs. The Vedas do not contain

(Continued from last page) and Srama≈Üas, obeisance to mother, father and old persons'. In the beginning of this aedict Asoke mentions that for centuries before him

people indulged. in injuring or killing living beings. From the Mababbasya on VƒÅrtika 2 on Pa≈Üini 11. 4. 12 it appears that in Patanjali’s time there was permanent or aatural opposition or antipathy between Sramanas and brƒÅhma·πáas; ‘ye≈õƒÅm ca virodha ityasyƒÅvƒÅkƒÅ≈õa·∏• ≈õramanabrƒÅbmanam’; ‘Ye≈üim ca virodha·∏• ≈õƒÅ≈õvatikah’ is PƒÅ≈Üini II, 4, 9, Vide Rhys Davids ‚Äú Buddhist India” (ed. of 1950) pp. 192-194 for Asoka’s Dhamma to be gathered from his Rock Edicts I, III, VII, IX, XII, and Pillar Edicts 2 and 3.   1. Sources of Dharnu.

positive precepts (vidhis) on matters of dharma in a connected form; but they contain incidental references to various topics that fall under the domain of dharma≈õƒÅstra as conceived in later times. Such information to be gathered from the Vedic Litera ture is not quite as meagre as is commonly supposed. In another place22 I have brjught together about fifty Vedic passages that shed a flood of light on marriage, the forms of marriage, the different kinds of sons, adoption of a son, partition, inheritance, ≈õr≈´ddha, strƒ´dhana. To take only a few examples. That brotherless maidens found it difficult to secure husbands is made clear by several Vedic passages. ‚ÄúLike ( a woman) growing old in her parents' house, I pray to thee as Bhaga from the seat common to al123. Vide also Rgveda I. 124, 7, IV. 5. 5 and Atharvaveda I. 17. 1 and Nirukta III. 4-5. These passages constitute the basis of the rules of the Dharmas≈´tras and the YƒÅj√±avalkya smrti against marrying a brotherless maiden24. This bar against marrying a brotherless maiden seems to have been due to the fear that such a girl might be an appointed daughter (putrik≈´) and that a son born of such a girl would be affiliated to his mother’s father. This custom of putrik≈´ is an ancient one and is alluded to in the Rgveda, according to YƒÅska25. Rgveda X. 85 is a very interesting hymn as regards marriage ; verses from it are used oven to this day in the marriage ritual.26 It shows that in the remote Vedic age the marriage rite resem bled in essence the BrƒÅhma form as described in the Dharma s≈´tras and Manu.27 But the purchase of a bride (i. e. what is called Asura marriage in later literature ) was not unknown in the Vedic age. A passage of the MaitrƒÅyaniyasainhitƒÅ ((I. 10. 11) is referred to in the Vasisthadharmas≈´tra28 in this con nection, viz. “she who being purchased by the husband'. The

GƒÅndharva form is hinted at in the words29 .when a bride is fine looking and well adorned, she seeks by herself her friend among men'. The iniportance of the aurasa son was felteven in the remote Vedic ages. ‚ÄúAnother ( person ) born of another’s loins, though very pleasing, should not be taken, should not be even thought of (as to be taken in adoption30). The Taittiriya-samhita (VI. 3.10.5) propounds the well-known theory of the three debts31. The story of Suna·∏•sepa in the Aitareya-brƒÅhma·πáa (VII. 3) suggests that a son could be adopted oven when there was an aurasa son. The Taittiriya-samhita (VII. 1. 8. 1) tells the story of Atri who gavo an only son in adoption to Aurva. The K≈üetraja son of the Dharmas≈´tras is often referred to in the earliest Vedio literaturo. ‘What (sacrificer) invites you (Asvins) in his house to a bed as a widow does a brother-in-law or a young damsel her lover ‘32. The Taittiriya-samhitƒÅ makes it clear that a father could distri bute his wealth among his sons during his own life-time, Manu divided his property among his sons’ &c.33 Another passage of the same Sahit≈´ seems to suggest that the eldest son took the whole of the father’s wealth ‘therefore people establish their eldest son with wealth ‘34. Even in the Vedic ages the son excluded the daughter from inheritance’a son born of the body does not give the paternal wealth to (his ) sister ‘35. A passage of the Taitti riya-sa·πÅhitƒÅ is relied upon by ancient and modern writers on dharma≈õƒÅstra for the exclusion of women in general from inheri tance: therefore women being destitute of strength take no portion and speak more weakly than even a low person36.   1. Sources of Dharma

eulogises the stago of studenthood and the Satapathabrahmana speaks of the duties of the Brahmacarin such as not partaking of wine and offering every evening a samich to fire37. The Taittirlya-samhita (VI. 2. 8.5) relates38 how Indra consigned Yatis to wolves (or dogs) and how PrajƒÅpati prescribed a PrƒÅya scitta for him. The SatapathabrƒÅhmana speaks of the king and the learned brahmana as the upholders of the sacred ordinances.39 The TaittirlyasamhitƒÉ says ‘therefore the S≈´dra is not fit for sacrifice’.’ The Aitareya BrƒÅhma·πáa tells us that when a king or other worthy guest comes, people offer a bull or a cowti. The Satapatha-brƒÅhmana speaks of Vedic study as yaj√±a and the Taittiriya-aranyakata enumerates the five yajnas, which are a prominent feature of the Manusmrti. The Rgveda eulogises the gifts of a cow, horses, gold and clothes43. Another passage of the Rgveda44 (thou art like a prapƒ´ in a desert) is relied upon by Sabara on Jaimini (I. 3. 2) and by Visvarupa on Yajnavalkya as ordaining the maintenance of prap≈´s (places where water is distributed to travellers). The Rgveda condemns the selfish

man who only caters for himself 45.

The foregoing brief discussion will make it clear that the later rules contained in the charms≈´tras and other works on olurmu≈õƒÅstra had their roots deep down in the most ancient Vodic tradition and that the authors of the dharmas≈´tras were quite justified in looking up to the Vedas as a source of dharma.

‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡•• ‡§ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶ X. 107. 2. 44 ‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ë‡§ó‡•ç‡§® ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡•á’ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á’ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶ X. 4.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

But, as said above, the Vedas do not profess to be formal treatises on dharma; they contain only disconnected statements on the various aspects of dharma ; we have to turn to the smrtis for a formal and connected treatment of the topics of the dharma≈õƒÅstra. Vide Prof. S. C. Bannerjee’s ‘Dharmas≈´tras, a Study’ pp. 514 533 for Vedic passages cited in major Dharmas≈´tras and pp. 533-539 for references to them by name or by initial word or words.

Before proceeding further a few preliminary remarks must be made. Ancient Sanskrit writers and modern historians of Sanskrit Literature divide ancient Sanskrit works into three groups, viz. the Vedic SamhitƒÅs (Rgveda, Yajurveda, Sama voda and Atharvaveda ), the BrƒÅhma·πáas (including the early Upani≈üads like the B»ôhadƒÅra·πáyaka). and S≈´tras. The first two groups together constitute Veda or ≈öruti ( as Sabara says on P. M. S. II. 1. 33 ‘MantrƒÅs-ca BrƒÅhma·πáam ca Vedah ‘). S≈´tras are not Veda, but many of thom are connected with the Veda and contain numerous mantras. Kalpa is one of the six auxiliary lores (angas) of the Voda and this group is generally later in time than the BrƒÅhmanas, though some s≈´tra works appear to have been composed even in the times of the Tai. √Ñr. II. 10 and of the BrhadƒÅrangakopani≈üad (II. 4.10 and IV. 5. 11). A distinction is drawn between Kalpa and Kalpas≈´tra by tho TantravƒÅrtika.45a The word Kalpa (or rather Kalpasutra) is used in two senses, one comprehensive including tho aphoristic works on Vedic ritual, on the domestic ceremonies and also on law, government and administration of justice; the other sense covers only those aphoristic works that deal with Vedic sacrifices and matters related thereto. If the first sense is taken then Kalpas≈´tras are classified into three classes, viz. Srautas≈´tras that deal with solemn Vedic sacrifices, mentioned or discussed in the Vedas and BrƒÅhmanas; (2) Grhyas≈´tras that deal with domestic ceremonies such as Upanayana, marriage and with daily and periodical rites and employ mantras for them mostly from one SƒÅkhƒÅ of the Veda; (3) Dharmas≈´tras (also depending on the Vedas as the highest authority ) that treat of some of the topics dealt with in the G»ôhyas≈´tras but add provisions on matters .concerning economic life, politics, government, civil and criminal law. A complete Kalpa in the first sense should cover all the three divisions. It is highly doubtful whether gxth Veda

45 a on P. M. S. I, 3, 11 (for which vide H. of Dh. VOR Collor 1844 n.

2077).

1917

  1. Sources of Dhitrina

11

≈ö√•khƒÅ had originally a complete set of the three kinds of works covered under the word Kalpa. This will be briefly dealt with a little below.

Recently (1959) Dr. Ram Gopal has brought out a large work on ‘India of Vedic Kalpas≈´tras’ containing over five hundred closely printed pages. The title of the work is rather misleading. It does not deal with the Srautas≈´tras beyond very briefly stating what they contain and distinguishing their contents from those of the G»ôhya and Dharmas≈´tras. His work is concerned only with the details gathered from the G»ôhya and Dharƒ±nas≈´tras and he has nothing to say about the development of the several topics dealt with in these two classes during the long period of at least 2000 years after the s≈´tra period (which he places between 800 - 500 B. C. on p. 89). His work should have been entitled “Indian Life as depicted in G»ôhya and Dharmas≈´tras”. As far as it goes it is a tolerable thesis, though rather prolix, dogmatic and over-disputatious. Having confined himself to the Gphya and Dharmas√ºtras, it should have been his business to discuss all points concerning at least the principal Gƒºhya and Dharmas≈´tras. But he leaves important matters concerning several s≈´tras untouched. For example, on p. 54 he observes ‘many s√ºtras in the Gaut. Dh. S. appear to be of doubtful authenticity and it is an important task for future reseurchers to determine precisely the spurious s≈´tras interpolated in the original Dharmas≈´tra’. One feels that he should himself have tackled that task at least about some representative G»ôhya s≈´tras and the Gautama- dharma-s≈´tra ( which he places on p. 84 among the oldest class of Srauta, Grhya and Dharmas≈´tras and when on p. 82 he holds that Gautama is undoubtedly the oldest writer on SmƒÅrta Dharma) by a thorough examination of chapters and passages in them and should have pointed out the criteria why certain g≈´tras are held to be spurious and so forth. He need not have included in the thesis the description of the flora and fauna &c. (pp. 103-109) or if he wanted to include these subjects he should have devoted more space. Nor was there any need for him to discuss (as he does on pp. 100-103 ) the varying limits of Aryavarta, since that subject had been dealt with at length by me in H. of Dh. Vol. II pp. 11-16. Ho hardly adds anything substantial to what I stated on that topic twenty two years ago. He could have referred to Vol. II of H. Dh, pp. 11-16 and added bits of information that did not getur therein.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

  1. When Dharmasastra works were first composed

The important question is to find out when formal treatises on dharma began to be composed. It is not possible to give a definite answer to this question. The Nirukta (III. 4-5) shows that long before Yaska heated controversies had raged on various questions of inheritance, such as the exclusion of daughters by suns and the rights of the appointed daughter (putrikƒÅ ). It is very likely that these discussions had found their way in formal works and were not merely confined to the meetings of the learned. The manner in which Yaska writes suggests that he is referring to works in which certain Vedic verses had been cited in support of particular doctrines about inheritances. It is further a remarkable thing that in connection with the topic of inheritance YƒÅska quotes a verse, calls it a Sloka and distinguishes it from a ƒæk.47 This makes it probable that works dealing with topics of dharma existed either composed in the sloka metre or containing slokas. Scholars like Bichler would say that the verses were part of the floating mass of mnemonic verses, the existence of which he postulates without very convincing or cogent arguments in his Introduction to the Manusmrti (S. B. E. vol. 25 Intro.xc). If works dealing with topics of Tharmu oxisted before Y√°ska, a high

The first half of the verse ‘AigƒÅd-angat’ occurs in. Br. Up. VI. 4.9 and in Kau≈üitaki Up. 2. 11 (three p√§das) and the whole verse in Baud. Gs. and A·∫•v G¬ß. and in mantra-patha II. 11. 33. The MƒÅpavagrhyasutra (I. 18. 1) provides that the verse ‘angad-angat,’ quoted io n. 47, was to be muttered over the son’s head after the father returned from a journey. It may be noted that in the extant Manusmrti

Manuh SvƒÅyambhuvoSbravƒ´t’ occurs in IX. 158 and the words * ManurƒÅha PrajƒÅpatih’ occur in X. 78 and the words' tan-Manoranu. sasanam’occur in VIII. 139 and 279 and in IX. 239. This shows that the ≈õloka quoted by the Nirukta might have been contained in some Smrti work like the extant Manusmrti. Vide Manu IX. 133 and 139 for the underlying idea that there is no difference between the son’s son and the daughter’s son and therefore between sop and daughter.

As stated in Gautama, Manu, Yaj. and others, Srutt and Smrti are the most authoritative sources of Dharma and Manusmrti II. 10 states that Smsti Is Dbarmasastra. This last in a broad sense comprises the G»ôhya and Dharmas≈´tras, metrical smstis like those of Mann. Yaj, Brhaspati, ParƒÅ≈õara, commentaries on them and digests | pibandhas).

antiquity will have to be predicated for them. The high antiquity of works on dharma≈õƒÅstru follows from other weighty considerations. It will be seen later on that the extant dharma s≈´tras of Gautama, BauchƒÅyana and ƒÄpastamba certainly belong to the period between 600 to 300 B. C. Gautama 48 speaks of dharma≈õƒÅstras and the word dharma≈õƒÅstra occurs in BaudhƒÅyana also (IV. 5.9). BaudhƒÅyana speaks of a dharma p≈´thaka (I. i. 9.). Besides, Gautama quotes in numerous places the views of others in the words ‘ityeke’ (e. g. II. 15, II, 58, III. 1, IV. 21, VII. 23). He refers to Manu” in one place and to ' ƒÄcƒÅryas' in several places (III. 35, IV.18 ). BaudhƒÅyana mentions by name several writers on dharma, viz. Aupajanghani, KƒÅtya, KƒÅ≈õyapa, Gautama, Maudgalya and HƒÅrita. Apastamba also cites the views of numerous sages such as those of Eka, Kanva, Kautsa, H√§rita and others. I. p. 25). The words Damat gufa may also mean ' A king (ruler) does not command’ &c. The Gaut. Db. S. IX. 53 provides that a learned brƒÅhma·πáa may approach a ruler for his own ‘yogak≈üema’. Similarly. the MahƒÅbhƒÅ≈üya itself (Vol. III. p. 7) on VƒÅrtika 9 on PƒÉn. VI. 1.2 bas the words SEAT 37iig√≠a TAITATA149691 3 eraia,' where ‘Isvara’ can only mean ‘king or ruler.’ Panini in I, 4. 97 (adhir. i≈õvale) and in II. 3. 39 uses Isvara in the sense of ruler or owner. There is not much to choose between the two senses. If Isvara' is taken to mean ‘God’the meaning would be ‘God (i. e. Veda, the word of God ) does not order &c. Vide TR. 39. II. 4.10 TRI PERT Haki faizdiharaagaat oc: magistariefta:’ on which the VedƒÅntas≈´tra (1.1.3) magliaraia is based.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

verses and dogmas that have their counterparts in the dharma s≈´tras52. The foregoing discussion establishes that works on the dharma≈õƒÅstra existed prior to YƒÅska or et least prior to the period 600-300 B. C. and in the 2nd century B. C. they had attained a position of suprenie authority in regulating the conduct of men.

In this book the whole of the extant literature on dharma will be dealt with as follows :-First come the dharmas≈´tras, some of which like those of ƒÄpastamba, Hiranykesin and BaudhƒÅyana form part of a larger S≈´tra collection, while there are others like those of Gautama and Vasistha which do not form part of a larger collection; some dharmax≈´tras like that of Visnu are, in their extant from, comparatively later in date than other s≈´lra works; some s≈´tru works like those of Sankha-Likhita and Paithinasi are known only from quotations. Then early metrical sm·ªôtis like those of Manu and YƒÅj√±avalkya will be taken up for discussion; then later versified smrtis like that of N√§rada ; there are many sm·ªôti works like those of Brhaspati and KƒÅtyƒÅyana that are known only from quotations. The two epics, the Maha bhƒÅrata and the RƒÅmƒÅyana, and the PurƒÅnas also have played a great part in the development of the Dharma≈õƒÅstra. The commentaries on the sm·ªôtis, such as those of Vi≈õvar≈´pa, Medha tithi, Vij√±ƒÅe≈õvara, AparƒÅrka, Haradatta will be next passed in review and then the digests on alarmu such as the works of HemƒÅdri, Todaramalla, Nilakantha and others.

It is very difficult to settle the chronology of the works on dharma≈õƒÅstra, particularly of the earlier ones. The present writer

52a. A few passages from the MahƒÅbhƒÅgya having a striking identity or

similarity to Dharmas≈´tra texts may be cited bere. HASTUV

FOUNDED

1917

  1. When Dharma≈õƒÅstra works were first composed

15

does not subscribe to the view of Max M√ºller (H. A. S. L. P. 68) and others that works in continuous Anustubh metre followed s≈´tra works 53. Our knowledge of the works of that period is so meagre that such a generalisation is most unjustifiable. Some works in the continuous sloka metre like the Manusmrti are certainly older than the Visnudharmas≈´tra and probably as old as, if not older than, the Vasisthadharmas≈´tra. One of the earliest extant dharmas≈´tras, that of BaudhƒÅyana, contains long passages in the sloka metre, inany of which are quotations and even ƒÄpastamba has a considerable number of verses in the ≈õloka metre. This renders it highly probable that works in the ≈õloka metro existed before them. Besides, a large literature on dharma existed in the days of A pastamba and Baudhayana which has not come down to us. In the absence of that literature

it is futile to dogmatise on such a point.

In volumes II to V both Srautas≈´tras and G»ôhya-s≈´tras have been quoted and relied upon very frequently. In pp. 976-1255 of Volume II a comparatively full account was given of the Vedic sacrifices based on the Srautas≈´tras. But no account of the Grhyas≈´tras in general was given in any of the five volumes of the History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra. Therefore, a brief statement on the gƒºhyas≈´tras with references to some printed editions is set out below and no attempt will be made to settle their chronology. The chronology of the Dharma≈õƒÅstra given later on may be held applicable to the G»ôhyas≈´tras also with some unimportant modi fications. The G»ôhyas≈´tras often refer to the Srautas≈´tras of their schools e. g. the ƒÄ≈õv. Gr, begins’uktƒÅni vaitƒÅnikƒÅni gƒºhyƒÅni vƒÅksyƒÅmah’ (the Srauta sacrifices have been already expounded; we shall now expound the gƒºhya rites ). VitƒÅna means, acc. to Amarako≈õa, ‘kratu ‘(vedic sacrifice) and ‘vistƒÅra’. G»ôhya is derived from ‘gƒºha’ (which means ‘house or a shed’ or wife’ (‘gƒºhini g·∫∑hamucyate’ in SƒÅnti-parva 144:6 Ch ed.). The grhya fire was set up by a man at or after marriage or on partition of inheritance. Vide ƒÄ≈õv. G·ªã. S. I. 61 (P√§nigraha≈ÜƒÅd gphyam paricaret), H. of Dh. Vol. II p. 678 note 1615 for other texts; ƒÄp. Dh. S. II.7. 17. 16 ‘Sarvesu v»ôtte≈üu sarvata·∏• samava dƒÅya. pr√§≈õniyƒÅd-yƒÅdthoktam ' has in view An. Gr. S. VIII.2 1. (khanda ). 9. Similarly, Ap. Dh. S. I. 1. 14. 16, II. 2. 3.

17, II. 2.5.4. refer to provisions in ƒÄp. G»ô. S. 53 a Similarly, a gƒºhyas≈´tra has often in view the Dharmas≈´tra of its carana; e. g. ƒÄp. Gr. 8. 21. 1. (mƒÅsisraddhasy√§parapak≈üe yathopade≈õam kƒÅlƒÅ·∏• ) has in view ƒÄp. Dh. S. II. 7. 16. 4-21. It may be noted that ƒÄp. Gr. IV. 11. 16-17 ( PƒÅlƒÅso dando…upadi≈õƒÅnti ) occur as ƒÄp. Dh. S. I. 1. 2. 38. It may plausibly be argued that the extant Srauta, G»ôhya and Dharmas≈´tras of certain caranas like those of Apastamba and Baudhayana were composed either by one and the same person or at least by father and son or grandfather and grandson and so on. But this would not be correct in the case of several Dharmas≈´tras.

The grhyas≈´tras belong to the various recensions of the four vedas The gƒºhyas≈´tras translated in volumes XXIX and XXX of the Sacred Books of the East Series are in order S√§nkh√•yana, ƒÄ≈õvalƒÅyana, PƒÅraskara,:KhƒÉdira, Gobhila, Hiranyake≈°in, ƒÄpasta mba. The Dharmas≈´tras translated in Sacred Books of the East Vol. II, VII and XIV are those of ƒÄpastamba, Gautama, Vi≈ünu, Vasistha and BaudhƒÅyana. The gƒºhyas≈´tras belonging to the Rgveda are : (1) ƒÄ≈õvalƒÅyana gr. s., published with NƒÅrƒÅ yapa’s commentary by Nir. Press and in B. I. Series and with AnƒÅvilƒÅ of Haradatta in Tri. S. S. (1923). This Gr. S. belongs to the sƒÉkala S√§kh√£ and the last verse in the SƒÅkhƒÅ of the Rg. is * SamƒÅnƒ´va ƒÅk≈´ti·∏•’; (2) The SƒÅ≈àkhƒÅyana Gƒô. S. (in six adhyƒÅyas of which the last two appear to be later additions ) commented upon by NƒÅrƒÅyana and published in Indische Studion, Vol. XV. pp. 1-166, and by Dr. G. R. Sehgal with a learned Introduction (1960), New Delhi; (3) The Kau≈üitaka (often written as Kausitaki) Gr. S. edited by Mr. Ratna Gopal Bhatta (in the Benares S. Series, 1908 ) and by Dr. T. R. Chintamani, Madras, 1944 with the commentary of BhavatrƒÅta. These two belong to the BƒÅskala SƒÅkhƒÅ of the Rgveda, the last verse of which ‘is tac-cham yorƒÅvsnimahe.’

The Yajurveda has two recensions Krsna and Sukla. The former has come down to us in four schools viz. Taittiriya, MaitrƒÅyaniya, Kathaka and Kapisthala-katha. The number of Srauta and G»ôhya-s≈´tras belonging to the Krsnayajurveda is large. The more important of the Gr. Sutras are (1) Baudha

  1. The Grhya and Dharmas≈´tras

19

The gƒºhyas≈´tras belonging to the SƒÅmaveda are :

(1) Gobhilagphyas≈´tra, published in the B. I. series ; published in the Calcutta Sanskrit series with the com. of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, edited by Chintamani BhattƒÅcƒÅrya (1936). The mantras required in gƒºhya rites are collected in a Mantra brƒÅhma·πáa and the s≈´tra mentions only the opening words, but where the mantras are not contained in the MantrabrƒÅhmana they are quoted in full; this mantrapƒÅtha called Mantra brƒÅhma·πáa was most probably compiled before the Gobhila Gr. S.

(2) The KhƒÅdiraghya-s√∫tra, published in the Mysore Govt. Library Series with the com. of Rudraskanda, son of NƒÅrƒÅyana. This is based on the Gobhila G»ô. S. and is an abridgement of it;

(3) Jaiminiya-gƒºhya-s≈´tra, edited by Dr. Caland in the Punjab Oriental Series (1922);

(4) The DrƒÅhyƒÅya·πáa-gƒºhya-s√ºtra (published in Anan. series, Poona).

The Atharvaveda has the Kausika-s≈´tra as its Grhya. which was edited by Prof. Bloomfield. Vide Prof. Belvalkar Presentation Vol. pp. 28-33 for a paper by Mr. O. G. Kashikar for corrections in it and a paper Kausikas≈´tra and the Atharva veda' by Prof. Edgerton in F. W. Thomas Presentation Vol. pp. 78-81. There are several commentaries on it. It devotes a large part of it to utp≈´tas and s≈´ntis.

  1. The Dharmasutras It seems that originally many, though not all, of the dharma. siiras formed part of the Kalpas≈´tras and were studied in distinct s≈´trucaranas. Some of the extant dharmas≈´tras here and there show in unmistakable terms that they presuppose the Gshyas≈´tra of the cara≈Üa to which they belong. Compare ƒÄp. Dh. S. I, 1. 4. 16 with Ap. G»ô. S. I. 12 and II. 5; and Baud. Dh. S. II. 8. 20 with Baud. Gr. S. II. 11. 42 (and other s≈´tras ).54 The Dharmas≈´tras belonging to all s≈´tracara·πáas have not come down

Abandarka

20

1

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

to us. There is no dharmas≈´tra completing the ƒÄ≈õvalƒÅyana Srauta and G»ôhyas≈´tras; no MƒÅnavadharmas≈´tra has yet come to light, though the MƒÅnava Srauta and G»ôhya s≈´tras are extant; in the same way we have the SankhƒÅyana Srauta and Grhya s≈´tras, but no sƒÅnkhƒÅyanadharmas≈´tra. It is only in the case of the ƒÄpastamba, Hira·πáyake≈õin and BaudhƒÅyana S≈´tracara√±as that we have a complete kalpa tradition with its three components of Srauta, G»ôhya and Dharma s≈´tras. The TantravƒÅrtika of KumƒÅrila contains very interesting observations on this point. It tells us that Gautama (dharmas≈´tra) and Gobhila (gƒºhyas≈´tra) were studied by the Chandogas (SƒÅmavedins), Vasistha ( dharmas≈´tra ) by the Rgvedins, the dharmas≈´tra of Sankha Likhita by the followers of VƒÅjasaneya-samhitƒÅ and the sutras of ƒÄpastamba and BaudhƒÅyana by the followers of the Taittiriya ≈öƒÅkhƒÅ55, The TantravƒÅrtika (p. 179 ) establishes it as a sido dhƒÅnta (on Jaimini I. 3. 11 ) that all the dharina and grhyrƒ± sutras are authoritative for all Aryan people. From this it appears that, although originally all s≈´tracara√±as might not have possessed dharmas≈´tras composed by the founder of the carana or ascribed to him, yet gradually certain dharmas≈´tras were specially taken over or appropriated by certain cara√±as. As the dharmas√ºlras were mostly concerned with rules about the conduct of men as members of the Aryan community and did not deal with ritual of any kind, all dharmas≈´tras gradually became authoritative in all schools.

The dharmas≈´tras were closely connected with the grhyas≈´tras in subjects and topics. Most of the G»ôhyas≈´tras treat of the sacred domestic fire, the divisions of G·ªãhya sacrifices, the regular morning and evening oblations, sacrifices on now and full moon, sacrifices of cooked food, annual sacrifices, marriage, purnsavana, jƒÅtakarma, upanayana and other sarsk≈´ras, rules for students and snƒÅtuhas and holidays, ≈õrƒÅddha offerings, madhuparka. In most cases the G»ôhyas≈´tras confine then solves principally to the various events of domestic life; they rarely give rules about the conduct of men, their rights, duties and responsi

F. 7. 1. 3. 11). B i

  1. The Dluirmis√ºlras

bilities. The dharmas≈´tras also contain rules on some of the above topics such as marriage and the samsk√§ras, rules for Brahmacarya and sn√§takas and holidays, on ≈õrƒÅddha and madhuparka. It is therefore not to be wondered at that in the Apastamba-g»õhyas≈´tra the topics of the duties of the BrahmacƒÅrin and of the house-holder, of alithis and of ≈õr≈´ddha are meagrely treated as compared with the ƒÄpastamba-dharmas≈´tra. The dharmas≈´tras very rarely describe the ritual of domestic life; they merely touch upon it; their scopo is wider and more ambi tious; their principal purpose is to dilate upon the rules of conduct. law and custom. Some s≈´tras are common to both the ƒÄpast amba-grhya and the dharma sutra 56. Sometimes the grhyas≈´tra appears to refer to the dharmas≈´tra57. There are certain points which distinguish the dharmas≈´tras ( the more ancient of them at least ) from smrtis : (a) Many dharmas≈´tras are either parts of the Kalpa belonging to each s≈´tracarana or are intimately connected with the grhyas≈´tras. (b) The dharmas≈´tras some times betray some partiality in their Vedic quotations for the texts of that Veda to which they belong or in the caranas of which they are studied; (c) The authors of the older ) dharma s≈´tras do not claim to be inspired seers or superhuman being958. while the other smrtis such as those of Manu and YƒÅj√±avalkya are ascribed to Gods like BrahmƒÅ. (d) The dharmasutras are in prose or in mixed prose and verse; the other smrtis are in verse. (e) The language of the dharmas≈´tras is generally more archaic than that of the other sm·ªôtis. (f) The dharmas≈´tras do not proceed upon any orderly arrangement of topics, while tho other sirtis (even the oldest of them, viz. Manusm·ªôti ) arrange their contents and treat of the subjects under three principal heads viz. nc≈´ri, ryavahƒÅra and pr≈´ya≈õcitta; (g) Most of the dharmasi tras are older than most of the other sƒ±nstis.

Many of the technical terms used in the G»ôhyas≈´tras and Dharmasutras are derived from the SainhitƒÅs, BrƒÅhmanas and Srautas≈´tras e. g. the following few technical words which occur in the G»ôhya and Dharma s≈´tras' are so derived and references

The ƒÄp. Dh. S. (I. 4. 12. 10 ) makes the interesting statement “religious rites were declared in the BrƒÅhma·πáas, the texts of those rites have been lost, (but those texts ) can be inferred from the actual per formance (of the rites that are in vogue): “brƒÅhmanoktƒÅ vidhayas te≈üƒÅm utsannƒÅ·∏• pathƒÅ·∏• prayogƒÅd-anumiyanto'. This shows that an early writer like Apastamba (who flourished some centuries before the Christian era ) was aware that BrƒÅhma·πáa works had once described many of the gƒºhya rites, but that in his day such BrƒÅhma·πáa texts had been lost.

  1. The Dharmasutra of Gautama. This has been printed several times (there is Dr. Stenzler’s edition of 1876, the Calcutta edition of 1876, the ƒÄnanadƒÅ≈õrama edition with the commentary of Haradatta, and the Mysore Government edition with the bhƒÅsya of Maskarin ; it was trans lated by B√ºhler in S. B. E., Vol. II. with an introduction). The AnandƒÅ≈õrama edition of 1910 which is incorrect in a few places (e. g. 21.7 ) has been used in this work. This dharmas≈´tra is, as we shall see, the oldest of those we have. The Gautama dharmas≈´tra was specially studied by followers of the SƒÅmaveda ( see note 55 above). The commentary on the Caranavyuha tells us that Gautama was one of the nine sub-divisions of the RƒÅnƒÅvanƒ´ya school of the SƒÅmaveda. A teacher Gautama is mentioned frequently in the LƒÅtyƒÅyana≈õrautas≈´tra (. g. I. 3.3 and I. 4. 17 ) and in the Dr√§hyƒÅyana≈õrauta (e. g. I. 4. 17, IX. 3. 15 ) of the SƒÅmaveda. The Gobhilagphya (III. 10.6) which belongs to the SƒÅmaveda cites Gautama as an authority. There fore it is not improbable that a complete Gautamasutra embody ing Srauta, Grhya and Dharma doctrines once existed. There are other indications pointing to the close connection of the Gautamadharmas≈´tra with the SƒÅmaveda. Chapter 26 of the dharmas≈´tra about Krcchra penance is the same, almost word for word, as the SƒÅmavidhƒÅnas9 BrƒÅhma·πáa (I. 2, Burnell’s ed.). 59 There are, however, considerable divergences; e. g. tit. 17. 9. 26. 10-12

are ‘‡§Ü‡§™‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§õ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ RE:1 pictagon, 1 FATEHIY &c. while the Hina internet.

1917

  1. The Dharmasutra of Gautama

23

Among the purificatory texts (21 in number ) mentioned in Gau. Dh. S. (19.12 ) there are nine that are S√§mans. The mention of the five utterances (Vy√§hrtis ‘) ‘resembles the number in the VyƒÅh·ªãtisƒÅma60 though the order is different. It is, however, to be noted that Gautama is a generic name. In the Kathopani≈üad, both Naciketas (II. 4. 15, II. 5. 6 ) and his father (I. 1. 10 ) are styled Gautama. In the ChƒÅndogyopanisad there is a teacher H√§ridrumata Gautama (IV. 4.3).

Dr. Ram Gopal in his Ph. D. thesis ‚ÄòIndia of Vedic Kalpa sutras ‘(1959) charges me (on p. 53 ) with being inconsistent as regards the Gautama-dharmas≈´tra. This book is probably his first serious work on ancient Sanskrit literature and society and I am afraid that he is more dogmatic in several conclusions of his than the facts warrant. About Gautama Dharmas≈´tra I made ( in the first edition of the H. of Dh. Vol. I published so far back as 1930 ) two points viz. (1) that it was originally an independent work and not attached to any particular Vedic SƒÅkhƒÅ; (2) that it was subsequently adopted by SƒÅmavedins as their Dharmas≈´tra probably because it contained a few indi cations of leanings towards the SƒÅmaveda. I pointed out some of those indications, but also showed that Gautama’s name was connected with the Kathas of the Krsna Yajurveda also, as in the Kathopani≈üad both Naciketas and his father are referred to as Gautama and because the TantravƒÅrtika (about 650-700 A.D.) asserted that Gaut. Dh. S. was accepted or adopted by the SƒÅma vedins as their Dharmas≈´tra. I could have added many other matters in support of my theory but thought that it was unneces sary to do so. The duty of all scholars when dealing with ancient works or matters more than a thousand years old is to marshall the necessary or available facts with honesty and, if they do not all point to the same conclusion, to declare, if possible, one’s

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstrat

opinion in favour of one probability as against another. There is no inconsistency in doing this and it is always possible that different scholars may hold widely divergent views about the age and other matters relating to a writer or work (particularly an ancient one ). I need cite only one example. The Artha ≈õƒÅstra of Kautilya has been available in print for half a century. There are hundreds of papers and books on various aspects of the Artha≈õƒÅstra. Yet on the question of the age of the Artha≈õƒÅstra depending on the same materials there are at least two divergent views, some scholars assigning it to 300 B. C. (Jacobi, Sham Shastry and Jayaswal), while others like Jolly and Winternitz bring down the work to 300 A. D.

Now that the charge of inconsistency has been made against me, I should like to say something more here. Gotama is a famous rsi in the Rgvoda. The name occurs at least eighteon timos in the Rgveda mantras and is employed in almost all cases (from nominative to vocative ). Rahugana Gotama is the r≈üi of Rgveda I. 74-93 and the word Rab≈´ganƒÅh (plural) occurs in Rg. I. 78. 5. Nodha Gautama is the rsi of hymns 58-64 of Rgveda I and of hymn 88 of Rg. VIII. Nodhah (vocative ) occurs in Rg. I. 64. 1. NodhƒÅ·∏• Gotama occurs in Kg. I. 62.13 and NodhƒÅ·∏• (nom. sing.) in Rg. I. 61.14, I. 124. 4. VƒÅmadeva Gautama is the sage of almost all hymns in Rgveda-mandala IV (viz. hynins 1-41 and 45-48). In Rg. IV. 4. 11 VƒÅmadeva speaks of Gctama as his father. It is well-known that the verses of the SƒÅmaveda are taken from the Rgveda (except about 75). In the Index of the words in the SƒÅmaveda, prepared and published in the Nirnaya sagara Press by the Swamis Vishveshvarananda and Nityananda in 1908, the words Gotama, Gautama, Nodhas, VƒÅmadeva and Rah√ºgana do not occur at all. In the two Var≈°as attached to Br. Up. II. 6. 1 and IV, 6. %, the name of Gautama occurs thrice among the 60 generations or so from Brahman (n.) to PautimƒÅsya. It is rather renarkable that Svetaketu ƒÄru≈Üeya’s father is addressed as Gautama by PravƒÅbapa Jaivali in Br. Up. VI. 2. 4-13. It may further be noted that in the daily turpana (satiating with water) of gods, sages and pitrs, ( as required by Manu II. 176 also ), the ƒÄ≈õv. G»ô III. 1. 5. mentions several 60a

gages among whom Gautama is mentioned. But in the tarpana for Samavedins now followed the sages to whom water is offered are only thirteen viz. RƒÅ≈ÜƒÅyana, Satyamugra, Vy√°sa, BhƒÅguri, Aulundi, Gaulgulavi, BhƒÅnumƒÅnaupamanyava, KƒÅrƒÅti, Masaka GƒÅrgya, VƒÅrsaganya, Kuthuma, SƒÅlihotra, Jaimini; and it ends ‘trayodasaite me SƒÅmagƒÅcƒÅryƒÅ·∏• svasti kurvantu tarpitƒÅ·∏•’; vide Sanskrit Intro. to Shri Satavlekar’s edition of SƒÅmaveda Samhita p. 6. It would be noticed that, though Jaimini is mentioned in it, Gautama is not.

As compared with the number of Srautas≈´tras and G»ôhyas≈´tras of the Vedas there is a paucity of Dharmas≈´tras. It is well-known that at present there are only a few Vaidikas of the SƒÅmaveda in the whole of India and some large tracts of India, have no Vaidikas of SƒÅmaveda at all. Probably the SƒÅmavedin

Vaidikas must have been much less in numbers even in ancient and medieval times as compared with tha Vaidikas of the Rgveda and the Yajurveda. Even supposing that there was some Dharmas≈´tra of the SƒÅmaveda composed some centuries before Christ, gradually it inight have faded out and the small number of SƒÅmavedins that still existed in scattered parts of India adopted the Gautama Dharmas≈´tra which as shown above shows some SƒÅmaveda connections.

The Gautama Dharmas≈´tra appears to have been held in high esteem by KumƒÅrila, as in his TantravƒÅrtika he quotes or clearly refers to Gautama Dh. S. at least a dozen times, but quotes ƒÄp. Dh. S. and BaudhƒÅyana Dh. S. only a few times; vide the author’s paper on Tantra-vƒÅrtika and Dharma≈õƒÅstra Works’ in JBBRAS, New Series Vol. I. (1925) pp. 95-102. KumƒÅrila remarks that the two S≈´tras (P. M. MahƒÅbhƒÅrata) he starts with Gautama as the first in enumerating the Dharmas≈´tras and remarks that Gautamiya (Dharmas≈´tra ) and Gobhiliya (i. e. Gobhila

gƒºhyas≈´tra ) are accepted or adopted by the Chandogas (i. e. SƒÅmavedins). The word ‘parigrhita’ employed by KumƒÅrila is very suggestive. One is said to adopt or accept what was at one time not one’s own. Adoption of a son is called ‘Putraparigraha and marriage is called dƒÅraparigraha.’

Not only KumƒÅrila but an earlier famous writer on Logic and Philosophy viz. Dharmakirti in his NyƒÅyabindu appears to suggest that Gautama was chief among the exponents of Dharma≈õƒÅstra.60c

Dr. Ram Gopal relies ( on p. 52 ) mainly on two circumsta nces, viz (1) that chapter 26 of Gaut. Dh. S. dealing with expiations called K·ªácchras is identical with SƒÅmavidhƒÅna Br. I. % and argues that it is not unreasonable to assume that the Gautama-dharma-s≈´tra borrowed it from that BrƒÅhmana; (2) that the majority of the purificatory texts prescribed in Gaut. Dh. S. (19. 13 ) belong to the SƒÅmaveda. I shall discuss the second point first. The relevant s≈´tra is set out in the note in transliteration and with explanations in some cases,60s

Continued on next page)

  1. The Dharmasutra of Gautama

The most important matter about this passage is that the whole of Gaut. Dh. S. chap. 19 (not merely one s≈´tra or sentence beginning with the word ‘Upanisadah’) is identical with Baud. Dh. S. III. 4 (except a few variations ) and also with Vas. Dh. S., Chap. 22 (except a few items). It may be argued that all three borrow from a common source and that such borrowing of a whole chapter cannot alter the character of the three s≈´tra works. We have to find that sourcs-that is all; but even if we find it, the Baud. Dh. S. still belongs to tha Krsna Yajurveda and Vas. Dh. S. is the Dh. S. for Rgvedins according to KumƒÅ rila. In view of the fact that Baud. Dh. S. (I. 1.25 ) mentions Gautama’s views as set out a little later it is most likely that Baud. Dh. borrows from Gaut. Dh. 8. the passage about expiations.

Dr. Ram Gopal is rather inaccurate when he says (p. 52) that the majority of the purificatory texts are from the SƒÅma. veda. Restricting oneself only to the number of texts specified ( which are 21 ) there are only ten texts that are Samavedic ( essentially nine only as Rathantara and Brhat are two conse cutive verses of the SƒÅmaveda, P≈´rvƒÅroika). But there are other important details of this s≈´tra that deserve consideration. The first purificatory text is Upani≈üads, which are enormous in extent as compared with the Saman texts and all the Vedic SamhitƒÅs are several thousand times more extensive than all the specified S√§mans. Therefore, this argument comes practically to nothing as proof of the assertion that the Gaut. Dh, S. was from the first affiliated to the SƒÅmaveda. The other argument about one chapter (26) being borrowed from S√§mavidhƒÅna Br. leads nowhere. If the BaudhƒÅyana Dh. S. oven after borrowing a chapter from another source, does not cease to be a s≈´tra of the Kr. Yajurveda, there is no reason why the same reasoning cannot hold good as to the Gaut. Dh. S. Dr. Ram Gopal refers (on p. 53 ) to passages from LƒÅtyƒÅyana (I. 3. 3, I. 4.7) and

( Continued from last paye) Saman (sung on ‘PibƒÅ Somam ‘Rg. VII, 22. i and Samaveda, PurvƒÅr. cika 398): (16) MahƒÅdivƒÅkirtya ( sung on Rg. X. 170 1, Samaveda, Aranya 628): (17) One of the Jye≈üthasƒÅmans (various rk verses are put forward op which they are to be sung); (18) Babispavamaga (sung on Rg. IX. 11. 1, S√§maveda, UttarƒÅrcika 651);(19) Ku≈ümƒÅ≈ÜdƒÅai (mantras from Tai. Ar. II. 3-5); (20) PƒÅvanƒÅnya·∏• (verses from 9th Mandala of the Rgveda): (21) Savitri (Rg. III. 62. 10). further details about these 21 texts, vide H. of Dh. Vol. IV Pp:459 G note 107. Vas. Dh. S. 22 omits Nos. 11-18 and Baud. Dh, Somits No. 18.

TOUNDEO

1917

28

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Dr√§hyƒÅyana (II. 3.15) Srautas≈´tras that speak of Gautama and from Gobhila Gr. (in III. 10.6 r…ôfers to Gautama’s views on AstakƒÅ ≈örƒÅddhas ) and that certain s≈´tras of Gobhila Gr. agree closely with Gautama’s (p. 53 and notes p. 56 ).

From these two circumstances it does not follow at all that Gautama (of the Dharmas≈´tra ) belonged to the Simaveda. That would be begging the question. Gobhila’s is comparatively a rare name among ancient sages connected with Vedic Litera ture, while the name Gautamia is a very ancient one, has been closely connected with the Rgveda and the Krsna Yajurveda occurs in the tarpana for Rgvedins, is quoted by Ap. ≈ö. S. (I. 3. 33 ) and Baud. Dh. S. Therefore, one may say with good reason that Gobhila, L√§tyƒÅyana and others refer to or follow the views of Gautama, one of the most famous and ancient sages.

It should be noted that Gautama’s views are mentioned twice in the ƒÄs. S. S. The first passage refers to the controver sial question of ≈õr√§ddha in honour of three paternal ancestors of a person when one or two of the three are alive. This subject has been dealt with in H. of Dh. Vol. IV pp. 511 ff. The author of ƒÄ≈õ. ≈ör. S. in II. 6. 16-23 states the differing views of GƒÅ≈ÜagƒÅri, Taulvali and Gautama, and states his own conclusions, Similarly, ƒÄ≈õ. ≈ör. S. in V. 6. 22 refers to the view of Gautama that it is the hotr priest that first partakes of camasa oblations in the hott’s vasatkƒÅra. ƒÄp. ≈ör. s≈´tra (I. 3. 11 ) refers to the view of Gautama. These passages may lead one to conjecture that Gautama had composed a srautas≈´tra also, which is not now available. We have many such instances where out of the three classes of the s≈´tras of a Vedic carana (viz. Srauta, G»ôhya and Dharma ) often one or even two are wanting or not available. There is no LƒÅtyƒÅyana G»ôhya nor Dharma s≈´tra, though LƒÅtyƒÅ yana ≈ör. S. exists, there is the Gobhila G. S. and the KhƒÉdira Grhya sutra but no Gobhila or KhƒÉdira ≈ö. S. nor Dharmas≈´tra. We have ƒÄ≈õv. S. S. and G. S., MƒÅnava ≈ö. S. and G. S., DrƒÅhyƒÅ yana and Jaiminiya S. S. and Gr. S. but no Dharmas≈´tra belon ging to these caranas. In the case of Gautama, we may make several conjectures viz. that all three classes of s≈´tras composed by or attributed to Gautama once existed but two of them are now not available, or that Gautama Dharmas≈´tra was an inde pondent work or that the Gautama mentioned in some Srauta s≈´tras is different from the author of the Dharmas√∫tra One thing is clear that Gautama being a gotra name wa borne by

UTE

WS

POOKA

I FOUNDED //

≈†. The Dharmas≈´tra of Gautama

29

many persons from the times of the Rgveda and that some of such persons were Rgvedins. One solid fact is that Gautama’s is the earliest of the extant Dharmas≈´tras (though some s≈´tras may be of doubtful authenticity ) and the view in the present state of our knowledge that his was an independent Dharmas≈´tra has the greatest probability. This view would explain why the Gaut. Dh. S., though the oldest of Dharmas≈´tras conforms with Panini’s grammar far more than the Apastamba Dh. S. and Baud. Dh. S. do. The latter two, being a compact part of the Kalpas≈´tra and transmitted orally from one generation to another, retained many un-PƒÅ·πáinian forms while the Gaut. Dh. ≈ö. being originally unconnected with any definite school could be easily amended according to the requirements of those memorizing or reading it. Besides, there is no direct evidence before Kum√§rila that Gautama was adopted by the SƒÅmavedins and as to how many centuries befor…ô him.60 My view is that the author of ƒÄpastamba Dh. S. was a southerner and wrote either at a time when PƒÅ≈Üini’s work was not composed at all or before it spread throughout India

Writers of S≈´tras sometimes refer to or quote s≈´tras of other schools. For example, Gautama’s view ( stated in XI. 20) is mentioned in the BaudhƒÅyana Dh. S. I. 1, 25. Baud. Dh. 8. stated five differences in the usages of the peoples of the south and of the north, and states the view of some that a person (of one region ) if he followed the practice of another region would incur sin and that the custom in a country (southern or northern) would be authoritative in that country alone and notes that Gautama holds this latter view to be wrong. This establishes that Gautama Dh. S. came before Baud. Dh. S. (and before the earliest part of it. ). 631

60 e A grant renewed by king BhƒÅskaravarman of Kamar≈´pa originally

made by his great-great-grandfather is published in E. I. Vol. 19 pp. 248-250 where the donces are named and their gotras are mentioned such as Gautama, Kautilya, Maudgalya &c. The original grant must have been made in the 5tb or 6th century A. D. Io the same E. I. History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

According to Haradatta the dharmas≈´tra has 28 chapters. The Calcutta edition adds one chapter on Karmavip≈´ka after chapter 19. In many places Gautama unmistakably refers to his own previous dicta; e. g. Yathoktam v√£ (23. 16 ) refers to 23. 10; 23. 26 refers to 17. 8-26; 17. 18 refers to 15. 18. The following are briefly the contents of the Gautamadharmas≈´tra :-1. Sources of dharma, rules about interpretation of texts, time of Upanayana for the varnas, the appropriate girdle, deer skin, cloth and staff for each Varna, rules about sauca and ƒÅcamana, method of approaching the teacher; 2 rules about those not invested with sacred thread, rules for the brahmac≈´rin, control of pupils, period of study; 3 The four ƒÅ≈õramas, the duties of brahmac≈´rin, bhik·π£u, and vaikh≈´nasa; 4 rules about the house-holder, marriage, age at time of marriage. eight forms of marriage, sub-castes; 5 rules about sexual intercourse on marriage, the five great daily sacrifices, the rewards of gifts, inadhuparka, method of honouring guests of the several castes; 6 rules about showing respect to parents, relatives (male and female ) and teachers, rules of the road; 7 rules about the avocations of a brƒÅhma·πáa, avocations for him in distress, what articles a brƒÅhma·πáa could not sell or deal in; 8 the forty samsk√§ras and the eight spiritual qualities (such as day≈´, forbearance &c.); 9 the observances for √• snataka and householder; 10 the peculiar duties of the four castes, the responsi bilities of the king, taxation, sources of ownership, treasure-trove, guardianship of minor’s wealth; 11 RƒÅjadharma, the qualities of the king’s purohita ; 12 punishments for libel, abuse, assault, hurt, adultery and rape, theft in the case of the several varnas and rules about money-lending and usury and adverse possession, special privileges of brƒÅlmanas as to punishments; payment of debts, deposits; 13 rules about witnesses, falsehoods when excusable; 14 rules of impurity on birth and death; 15 Sr√§ddha of five kinds, persons not fit to be invited at ≈örƒÅddha; 16 UpƒÅkarma, period of Vedic study in the year. holidays and occasions for them;17 rules about food allowed and forbidden to brƒÅhma·πáas and other castes; 18 the duties of women, niyoga and its conditions, discussion about

  1. The Dharmas√ºre of Guuluma

the son born of niyoga; 19 the causes and occasions, of prƒÅya≈õcitta, five things that remove sin (japa, tapas, loma, fasting, gifts ), purifi catory Vedic prayers, holy food for one who practises japa, various kinds of lapas and gifts, appropriate times and places for japa&c.;20 abandoning a sinner who does not undergo prƒÅya≈õcitta and the way of doing it; 21 sinners of various grades, mahƒÅpƒÅtakas, upapƒÅtakas &c.; 22 pr√§ga≈õcittas for various sins such as brahmahaty≈´, adult ory, killing a Ksatriya, Vaisya, S≈´dra, cow and other animals &c.; 23 prƒÅyascitta for drinking wine and nasty things, for incest and un-natural offences, and for several transgressions by brahma cƒÅrin; 24 secret prƒÅya≈õcittas for mah≈´p√§takas and upap≈´lakas; 26 the penances called K·ªãcchra and Atikrochra: 27 the penance call ed CƒÅndrƒÅya·πáa; 28 partition, stridhana, ro-union, twelve kinds of sons, inheritance.

The Gautama-dharmas≈´tra is written entirely in prose and it contains no verses either quoted or composed by the author him self, as is the case with the other harmasutrus. Here and there occur sitras that look like portions of Anustubh verses e.g. 23.2761. The language of Gautama agrees far more closely with the standard set up by Panini than the dlarmas≈´tras of BaudhƒÅyana and ƒÄpastamba. It is not very easy to account for this differ ence. It is obvious that commentators and generations of students that were brought up in the tradition of the PƒÅ·πáinean grammar tampered with the text and improved it in accordance with their notions of correct Sanskrit. But why this process should not have been carried out to the same extent in the case of ƒÄpastamba it is difficult to say. A conjecture may be hazarded that the ƒÄp. Dh. S. being a well-knit component of the Ap. Kulp and being studied as such was less liable to being tampered with than the Gautama Dh. S., which probably did not in its origin belong to any particular kalpi. The same commentator, Haradatta, explained both Gautama and √Épastamba. Haradatta, who, as will be seen later on, was a great grammarian, shows in several places that the current reading was ungrammatical from the PƒÅ·πáintan stand-point and that he preferred readings that were in consonance with P√§nini’s rulesha Thero are still a few un-P√•ninean words, e. g. in 1. 14 (‘dvƒÅvinnsateh for dv√§vim

61 312ga Ait Baui qui a : 1 62 e. g. on ott. Et. 77. 16. 21 ( 722765 2 A17267 27797) he says ‘72

≈õƒÅt’) and 9. 52 (kulamkula). The TantravƒÅrtika (p. 99 ) appears to discuss the various readings in Gautama (I. 4563 ). A few s≈´tras quoted from Gautama in the MitƒÅk·π£arƒÅ (e. g. the s≈´tra ‘utpatyaiva arthsvƒÅnitvam labhante), the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ (dvyamsam vƒÅ p≈´rvajah syƒÅt) and other works aro not found in the extant text. This fact along with the fact of an interpola tion of one chapter makes it clear that the present text of Gautama is of somewhat doubtful authority.

The literature known to the Gautama-dharmas≈´tra was extensive. Besides the Vedic sainhitƒÅs and BrƒÅhma·πáas it mentions the following works; Upani≈üads (19. 13 ), the VedƒÅngas (8.5 and 11. 19), VƒÅkovƒÅkya63a and ItihƒÅsa (8.6.), PurƒÅ≈Üa (8.6 and 11.19),Up aveda (11.19), dharma≈õƒÅstra (11.19). That he borrows a chapter from the SƒÅmavidhƒÅna-brƒÅhma·πáa has been mentioned above. He borrows the first six s≈´tras of the 25th chapter from the Taittiriya Aranyaka ( 11. 18). The Sramanaka (in Gautama III. 26 ) is, according to Haradatta, the VaikhƒÅnasa-≈õƒÅstra (either composed by Vikhanas or treating of the dutios of hermits). Gautama refers to ƒÄnv√≠k≈üiki (11.3). The only teacher of dharma he quotes by name in Manu (in 21.7), who is cited for the proposition that there is no expiation for the three sins of brahmahatyƒÅ, drinking wine and violation of the bed of the yuru. Haradatta says that in the extant Manusmrti the same propo sitions are laid down about bra’mahatya and sur≈´pƒÅna (in Manu 11. 89 and 146 respectively ), but that as to violation of guru talpa a passage from the Manusmrti has to be searched out (i. e. such a passage is not found there ). From this B√ºhler drew the conclusion that Gautama refers to the dharmas≈´tra attributed to Manu (and not to any versified Manu-smrti). But B√ºhler is not right in drawing this inference. In the first place in spite of what Haradatta says there are verses in the extant Manusmrti (XI. 104-105 ) which say that death is the expiation for violation of the guru’s bed. In the second place, there is nothing to show, even if Haradatta were correct, that Gautama refers only to a dharnas≈´tra of Manu and not to a versified work. Besides Manu, Gautama frequently quotes certain views ascribed to the ‘AcƒÅryas’

  1. The Dharmasutra of Gautama

33

(0. g. III. 35, IV, 18). What teachers are meant by the word * ƒÄcƒÅryƒÅ·∏•’(which occurs in the Nirukta, in Kautilya and various other works ), it is difficult to say. Probably the word means ‘the general traditional view of most writers in that particular ≈õƒÅstra on a particular point.’ Vide the author’s paper on * The meaning of ƒÄcƒÅryƒÅ·∏•’in ABORI Vol 23 pp. 206-213. In numerous places Gautama refers to the views of his predecessors in the words .eke' (2. 15, 40 and 56, 3. 1, 4. 17, 7.23 &c.) and ‘okesƒÅm’ (28. 17 and 38 ). This proves that Gautama was preced-1 od by great literary activity in the sphere of dharma≈õƒÅstra. Gautama 11. 28 seems to be a reminiscence of the Nirukta (II. 3 )612

The earliest reference to Gautama as an author on dharma occurs in the BauchƒÅyanadharmas≈´tra. BaudhƒÅyana discusses the authoritativeness of usages peculiar to the north or the south and quotes Gautama as saying that it is wrong to hold that certain customs must be held authoritative in certain countries (even though opposed to Vodic tradition and smrti). This refers to G. Dh. S. 11. 20. In another place BaudhƒÅyana gives it as his view that a BrƒÅhmana, if he cannot make a living by teaching, officiat ing as a priest or hy gifts, should earn his livelihood as a Ksatriya and quotes the views of Gautama as opposed to this65. The extant Gautama on the other hand teaches the same view as that of BaudhƒÅyana66. B√ºhler made the plausible suggestion that the s√ºtra in the extant Gautama is an interpolation. Govindasv√§mni, the commentator of Baudhayana, suggests that another Gautama is referred to by BaudhƒÅyana. It is possible to suggest that in the Ms. of Gautama usod by BaudhƒÅyana the s≈´tra about living as a Ksatriya did not occur and the next s≈´tra about living as a Vaisya alone occurred. Chapter 19 of the Gautamadharmas≈´tra which forms an introduction to pr√ºyascittus in Gautama seems to have been borrowed wholesale by BaudhƒÅyana (III. 10 ) with slight changes. That BaudhƒÅyana borrows follows from the fact that the chapter in Baudhayana occurs in the middle of the discussion about prƒÅya≈õcittas and not as an introduction, which is the case in Gautama. BaudhƒÅyana treats of penances in several places (II. 1

History of Dharmu≈°ƒÅstra

III. 5. 10 and VI. 1.4). There are, besides, many s≈´tras in both Gautama and BaudhƒÅyana that exhibit a close correspondence, e.g. Gautama III. 25-34 and BaudhƒÅyana II. 6. 17 about VaikhƒÅnasa, Gaut. 3. 3 and 35 and Baud. II. 6. 29, Gaut. 15. 29 and Baud. II. 8. 2, Gaut. 23. 8-10 and Baud. II. I. 12-14, Gaut. 24.2 and Baud. II. 3. 8. The Ap. Dh. S. II. 6. 15. 25 speaks of Smrti as laying down that up to upunayana there is no adhik≈´ra for homa. This probably refers to Gautama II. 1-3. The Vasisthadharmas≈´tra also quotes the views of Gautama in two places ( 4. 35 and 37, impurity on death). The first refers to Gautama 14. 41 but the second cannot be traced in the extant Gautama. Chapter 22 of Vasistha is borrowed from the Gautamadharmas≈´tra, chapter 19. There are besides many s≈´tras that are the same or almost the same in Gautama and Vasistha, e. g. Gautama 3. 31-33 and Vas. 9. 1-3, Gaut. 3.26 and Vas. 9. 10, Gaut. 1, 44 and Vas.3. 37, Gaut. 1. 40 and Vas. 3. 38, Gaut. 1. 45-46 and Vas. 3. 48, Gaut. 1. 28 and Vas. 3. 49, Gaut. 14. 5-7 and Vas. 4. 24-26. Gautama is referred to in the Manusmrti (III. 16 ) as the son of Utathya. Gautama is one of the authors of dhurma≈õƒ´stras enumerated in YƒÅj√±avalkya (1.5). AparƒÅrka quotes a verse from the Bhavisya purƒÅna which speaks of Gautama’s prohibition about drinking 67 Similarly, Kull≈´ka (on Manu XI. 146 ) quotes a verse from the same PurƒÅna which refers to Gautama 23. 2. KumƒÅrila in his TantravƒÅrtika quotes over a dozen s≈´tras from Gautama which present the same text as we have68. Gautama 11. 29 and 12. 4 are quoted by Samkara in his bh√§≈üya on VedƒÅntas≈´tra III. 1. 8 and 1.3.38 respectively. Vi≈°var≈´pa in his commentary on YƒÅj√±avalkya quotes numerous s≈´tras from Gautama. In Medh√§tihi’s bh≈´syn on Manu the writer more frequently quoted than any other is Gautama (e. g. on Manu II. 6, VIII. 125 &c.).

The foregoing discussion about the literature known to the Gautama Dh. S. and the authors and works that mention Gautama or quote the dharmas≈´tra helps us in arriving at the approximate age of the dharmas≈´tra. He is separated by a long interval from the SƒÅmavidhƒÅna BrƒÅhmana. He is later than Yaska and wrote at a time when Panini’s system was either not in existonce or had not attained a pre-ominent position. The extant text was known to BaudhƒÅyana and Vasistha and was in the same state long before 700 A. D. The s≈´tra betrays no knowledge of the onslaught delivered on Brahma

  1. The Dharmas≈´tra of Gautama

35

nism by Buddha and his followers. He uses the term bhiksu (3. 10) instead of the term parivrƒÅjaka that occurs in BaudbƒÅ yana, Apastamba and other sutra works and lays down that a bhik·π£u is to stay in one place in the rains, which reminds one of the Buddhist ‘bhikkhu’ and ‘Vasso ‘. 68a Gautama cites the opinion of some that Yavana is the offspring of a Ksatriya male and a S≈´dra female (4. 17). It is supposed by many scholars that the Yavanas became known to the Indians only at the time of Alexander’s invasion and hence every work in which the word yavun occurs must be later than 320 B. C. B√ºhler (S. B. E. vol. II. Intro. LVI.) seems to suggest that the s≈´tra where the word Yavana occurs in Gautama may be an interpolation. This is not a satisfactory explanation.

Dr. Ram Gopal (on p. 54 ) finds fault with me for my criti cism of Dr. B√ºhler. Unfortunately, he appears to have not correctly grasped the situation. Gaut. Dh. S. 4. 17 (tebhya eva …para≈õava-yavana-karana-≈õ√ºdrƒÅ√±-s≈´dretyeke ) does not express Gautama’s view but only states the view of some writers that if a s≈´dra woman has union with a brƒÅhmana, a ksatriya, vaisya or a s≈´dra the child begotton would respectively be a PƒÅra≈õava, a Yavana, a Karana, a S≈´dra. B√ºhlor tried to show that this was an interpolation. At the time when B√ºhler first wrote his intro duction to Vol. II. of the S. B. E. almost all Western writers regarded the occurrence of the word ‚ÄúYavana’ in a Sanskrit work as enough ground for relegating it to 300 B. C. or to a later date. B√ºhler’s words on p. LVI of the edition of 1879 (SBE Vol. II) are ‚Äú As there is no historical evidence to show that the Indians became acquainted with the Greeks before the invasion of Alexander in the 4th century B.C, it has been held that works containing the word Yavana cannot have been composed before 300 B. C.” Then he refers to Gautama’s text not being trust worthy and then to Rudradaman’s inscription (vide E. I. Vol. VIII at p. 43 ) in which TushƒÅspa is described as YavanarƒÅja and asserts that TushƒÅspa was not a Greek but a Persian. Supposing TushƒÅspa had been a Persian there is no reason why he could not or might not have been called or described as YavanarƒÅja in Kathiawad in the 2nd century A. D. Vide H. of Dh. S. Vol. V. p. 516 note 743 where it is shown that Yavana is an exact reproduction of the word Ionian (from Ionia, which was originally

68 a The fact tbat Gautama quotes by name only one predecessor viz. Mag

while the Ap. Db. S. quotes many authors by name has a preat beariog on the date of Gautama.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

a strip of mountainous coast in Asia Minor in which Miletus was in the 6th century B. C. the richest city in the Greek world. Even the M. B. (Santiparva 207. 43, Ch. ed.) has. Yauna Kamboja-GandhƒÅrƒÅ·∏• KirƒÅta Barbaraih saha) and Asoka in his 5th Rock Edict has ‘Yona-KƒÅmboja-GandhƒÅrƒÅnam.’ If B√ºhler had even then held the view which he sets forth in his Introduction in the second edition, he could have easily said in the Introduction to his first edition that even if the S≈´tra in which the word ‘Yavana’ occurs was not an interpolation, the date of Gautama need not be affected by the mere occurrence of the word ‘Yavana ‘in a s√∫tra that embodies the view of others. B√ºhler avoided in the Introduction to his first edition being definite about the age of Gautama owing to the word ' Yavana ' in Gautama, because he had not the courage at that time to differ from the current of western opinion. Dr. Ram Gopal in a research thesis shirks the important task of determining which s≈´tras of Gautama are spurious and yet devotos nearly one page to this. I had only the first edition in the library I used. It would liave been onough if he had simply said that Dr. B√ºhler later expressed his views about the occurrence of the word ‘Yavana’ definitely in the Introduction to the 2nd edition, though he did not do so in the Introduction to the first edition.

One may ask, if B√ºhler bolieves that the Indians borrowed their alphabet centuries before Alexander from the neighbours of the Greeks, why it is improbable that the Indians may not have heard of the word Yavana centuries before Alexander and why Yavanas may not have resided in India long before that date. Taking all these things into consideration tho Gautama-dharmas≈´tra cannot be placed later than the period botwevn 600-400 B. C.

Haradatta wrote a learned commentary on the Gautama dharmas≈´tra called MitƒÅksarƒÅ. For an account vide sec. 87 below. In numerous places he quotes the explanations of other coin mentators of Gautama (e. g. 9. 53 ; 10. 12, 56, 66 ; 11. 17; 12. 32; 21, 9 &c.)

  1. The Dharmasutra of Gautama

mnentions in several pages the views of Maskarin on Gautama’s s≈´tras (vide pp. 23, 248, 257). In the G»ôhastharatnƒÅkara of Cande≈õvara (p. 330 ) ƒÅcƒÅrya Maskarin on Gaut. Dh. S. IX. 57 is mentioned. Therefore, it follows that the bhƒÅsya of Maskarin is certainly not later than 1100 A. D. and may be assigned to the period 900-1100 A. D. This bhƒÅsya is far more extensive than Haradatta’s cuinmentary, and it is not unlikely that being much earlier has been made use of by Haradatta. But, as there were other early bhƒÅsyas of Bhartryaj√±a and AsahƒÅya ( which are not yet available in print) it is difficult to say whether Haradatta borrows from the older ones or from Maskarin. For example, on Gaut. I. 6 (tulya-balavirodhe vikalpa·∏•) the bhƒÅsya extends to three printed pages. The same is the case with regard to Gaut.
