such usages of countries, castes and families are valid and authoritative as are not opposed to the Vedas; (3) Women are not independent as regards the performance of religious duties, that a woman is to be married before the appearances of menses, that a guardian who does not arrango for a girl’s marriage incurs sin and that a girl after waiting for three menstrual periods should herself choose her husband possessing the requisite qualities and when she does so she should return the ornaments given to her by her father’s family; (4) That an offender if a brƒÅhmana was not to receive bodily punishment (XII. 43 ); (5) he allowed niy gae if the husband died childless (XVIII. 4-8).

Jƒ´vƒÅnanda publishes a smrti of Vrddha Gautama in 22 chapters and about 1700 verses (part II, pp. 497 636 ), where it is said that Yudhisthira asked Krsna about the charias of the four castes.   1. The BaudhƒÅyana Dharmasutra This has been edited several times (text by Dr. Hultzsch at Leipzig in 1884, text in the AnandƒÅ≈õrama collection of smrtis and in the Mysore Government Oriental Series in 1907 with the commentary of GovindasvƒÅmin; translated in S. B. E., Vol. 14, with an Introduction). The Mysore edition has been used in this work. BaudhƒÅyana is a teacher of the Krsnayajurveda. A complete set of the BaudhƒÅyanas√±tras has not yet been recovered and has not been as carefully preserved as the s≈´tras of Apa stamba and Hiranyakesin. Dr. Burnell arranges BaudhƒÅyana’s s√ºtras into six s≈´tras, the Srautas√ºtra in 19 pra≈õnas (probably ); KarnƒÅntas≈´tra in 20 adhyƒÅyas ; Dvaidhas≈´tra in four pra≈°nas ; Grhyas≈´tra in four pra≈õnas ; Dharmas√∫tra in four pra≈õnas ; Sulvas≈´tra in three adhyƒÅyas. The commentators offer no indi cation as to the place originally assigned to the grhya, dhurma and sulva sutras in the whole collection. Dr. Caland in his mono graph ( A. D. 1903 ) ‘Uber das Rituelle s≈´tra des Bandhayana’ gives on p. 12 the contents of the BaudhƒÅyanas≈´tra as follow: Pra≈õnas I-XXI ≈örauta, XXII-XXV Dvaidha, XXVI XVIII

The G»ôhyas≈´tra cites the view of BaudhƒÅyana himself (1.7). The BaudhƒÅyana-dharma refers to the Grhya and presuppose it in several places (vide note 54 ). In the BaudhƒÅyanagƒºhya (III. 9. 6 ) we have a reference to pudak≈´ra ƒÄtroya, VrttikƒÅra Kaundinya, PravacanakƒÅra Kanva BodhƒÅyana, and S≈´trakƒÅra ƒÄpastamba. 68.8 A similar passsage occurs in the BlƒÅradvƒÅja G»ôhyas≈´tra. In the BaudhƒÅyana-dharma-sutra (II. 5.27 R≈üitarpana ) we have Kanva BodhƒÅyana, ƒÄpastamba s≈´trakƒÅra and SatyƒÅsƒÅdha Hiranyakosin one after another. These references show that Kanva BodhƒÅyana was an ancient sage when the BaudhƒÅyana-dharmas≈´tra was written and that he could not have been the author of the grhya or the dharma s≈´tras of BaudhƒÅyana. BaudhƒÅyana may have been a descen dant of this Kapva Bodh√£yana. This surmise is supported by GovindasvƒÅmin who explains BaudhƒÅyana occurring in BaudhƒÅ yanadharinas≈´tra 1. 3. 13 as KƒÅnvƒÅyana. In the dharƒ±nas≈´tra BaudhƒÅyana is hiinself cited as an authority several times ( 0. g. I. 4. 15 and 24, III, 5. 8, III. 6. 20). In all these places the

Mysore edition reads BodhƒÅyana, while the Anand√°≈õrama reads

BaudhƒÅyana. In one or two places he is styled ‘bhagavƒÅn ( III. 6. 20). Several explanations are offered by the commen tator GovindasvƒÅmin (on I. 3. 13). He says that it is the practice of the ƒÄcƒÅryas to refer to themselves in the third person (as MedhƒÅtithi says on Manu. 69 ) or that the author of the dharmas≈´tra is a pupil of BaudhƒÅyana as the Manusmrti is promulgated by Bhrgu, the pupil of Manu, or there was some other BaudhƒÅyana whose works have not come down to us.

Confusion results from the lists of sages in turpa≈Üa mention ed in several G»ôhyas≈´tras. The passage from BaudhƒÅyana gp is quoted in note 68a. In that passage KƒÅnva BodhƒÅyana is called ‘pravacanakƒÅra’ and ƒÄpastamba is called ‘s≈´trakƒÅra’, while SatyƒÅsƒÅdha, Hira·πáyake≈õa, VƒÅjasaneya, YƒÅj√±avalkya, Bhara dyƒÅja and Agnive≈õya are merely named without any addition, In the Baud. Dh. 8. quoted in the saine note Kanva BaudhƒÅyana (without the epithet ‘pravacanak√≥ra ‘), ƒÄpastamba s√ºtrakƒÅra and SatyƒÅsƒÅdha Hiranyake≈°in are named. Two questions arise about the three names viz. (1) aro the sages mentioned in the tarpana passages the authors of the s≈´tra works in which they occur; ( % ) what is the import of the words pravacanakƒÅra and s√ºtrakƒÅra applied to KƒÅ≈Üva BodhƒÅyana and Apastamba respe ctively and do those words suggest that KƒÅ≈Üva BodhƒÅyana is much earlier than ƒÄpastamba. The present writer thinks that the authors of the Grhyas≈´tras were different from Kanva BodhƒÅ yana and Apastamba to whom water is directed to be offered in the tarpa≈Üa part of those works. They might be descendants of KƒÅ≈Üva BodhƒÅyana and Apastamba who are included in the sages for turpana.

If KƒÅ≈Üva BodhƒÅyana and Apastamba mentioned in the tarpapa passage were also the authors of the BodhƒÅyana and ƒÄpastamba gphyas≈´tras it is very difficult to believe that they recommended to the generations that would come after them to offer water to them in tarpana. frequently in the Upanisads viz. Tai. Up. 9, Katha II. 23 and Mundaka III. 2.4 (nƒÅyam-ƒÅtmƒÅ pravacanena labhyah ). The Tai. Up. (I. 9), after setting out the opinions of two sages, mentions the view of NƒÅka Maudgalya that sv√§dhyƒÅya (study of the Veda ) and pravacana ( expounding or exposition i. e. teaching ) is tapas (i. e. they should be striven for). The Rgveda I. 162-1 employs the form ‘pravaksyƒÅma·∏• (we shall loudly proclaim in the sacrifices the valorous deeds of the swift horse born among Gods ). The Ap. Gr. while dilating upon the offering of Madhuparka once a year to one’s teacher, father-in-law, king &c. when they pay a visit, provides that one should offer only once and not overy year Madhuparka to a famous expounder of the Veda and its meaning ) acc. to Haradatta (on ƒÄp. Gr. V. 13. 20. (sakrit pravaktre citraya). In these words (pravacanakƒÅra and s≈´trak√§ra ) there is no suggestion of time or early or late in time. The only difference is that the expounder may compose his work in any way (which may be prolix or otherwise ), but a s≈´trak√§ra has to be brief and compose his work in an appropriate style.

The following are the contents of the BaudhƒÅyana-dharma sutra :- Pra≈õna I:-Sources of dharma, who are sistas, pari≈üad, different practices of northern and southern India, countries where ≈°istas reside and where mixed castes reside, prƒÅya≈õcitta for visiting countries of the latter type; 2 Studenthood for 48, 24 or 12 years, time of upanayana and the girdle, skin, staff appropriate to each caste, duties of brahmac√§rin, eulogy of brahmacarya;3. The duties of the snƒÅtaka who has completed his studies and observances but has not yet married ; 4. directions about carrying the earthen jar (in the case of the snƒÅlaka);5. bodily and mental≈õauca, purification of various substances, impurity on birth and death, meaning of sapinda and sakulya, rules of inheritance, purification on touching a corpse or a woman in her menses or on dog-bite, what flesh and food was allowed and forbidden; 6. Purification from the point of view of sacrifice, purification of clothes, ground, grass, fuel, vessels, and articles used in sacrifice; 7. Rules about the importance from the sacrificial point of view of sacrifice, of the sacrificial utensils, priests, the sacrificer and his wife, ghee, cooked offerings, the

speak with g’ and literally means ' declare loudly proclaim,’ N

victim, soma and fires; 8. The four rarnas and the sub-castes; 9, mixed castes; 10. the duties of kings, the five great sins and punishments for them, punishuments for killing birds; witnesses; 11. The eight forms of marriage, holidays; Pra≈°na II. 1 PrƒÅya ≈öcittas for bruhmahatya and other great sins, Prayascittas for a bramach≈´rin violating his vow of celibacy, for marrying a sagotra girl, for marrying before elder brother, sins lesser than the great ones, description of such penances as ParƒÅka, K·ªãcchra, Atikrc chra ; 2. Partition of heritage, larger share for the eldest, the several substitutes for an aurusa son, exclusion from inheritance, dependence of women, prƒÅya≈õcitta for adultery hy men and women, rules about niyoga, means of subsistence in distress, con tinuous duties of the house-holder such as Agnihotra &c.; 3. The daily duties of the householder such as bathing, ƒÅcamana, Vai≈õva deva, giving food; 4. SandhyƒÅ; 5. Rules about the manner of bathing, of ƒÄcamana, worship of the sun, and about the method of propitiating (‘tarpa≈üa’) gods, sages and pitrs; 6. The five great daily yaj√±as; the four castes and their duties; 7. regulations about dinner; 8. ≈örƒÅddha ; 9. eulogy of sons and spiritual benefit from sons; 10. rules about sanny≈´sa; .Pra≈õna III. 1 modes of sub sistence for the two kinds of householders, SƒÅlina and YƒÅyƒÅvara; 2. the means of subsistence called ‘Sannivartani’;3. the dutios of the forest hermit and his means of livelihood; 4. prƒÅya≈õcitta for not observing the vows of Irahmac≈´rin or householder; 5. method of reciting Aglamarxarur, the holiest of texts; 6. the ritual of prasytayƒÅvaka; 7. the purificatory homa called K≈´≈ümƒÅ≈Üda; 8. the penance called c≈´ndrƒÅyana ; 9 the recital of the Vedas without taking food; 10. theories about purification for sin, purifying things; Pra≈õna IV. 1. prƒÅya≈õcittas of various kinds viz. for tating forbidden food or drink &c.; 2. Pr≈´nƒÅyƒÅnus and Aghamar sana as purifiers in case of several sins; 3. secret prayascittas; 4. Various Vedic texts as prƒÅya≈õcittas; 5. Means of securing siddhi by means of japa, homa, i≈üti and yantra: the penances called K·ªãcchra, Ati-Krochra, S√§ntapana, ParƒÅka, CƒÅndrƒÅyana; 6. the muttering (japa ) of holy texts, the i≈ü√ßis; . praise of Yantras, various Vodic texts used in homa; 8 censure of those who enter on the means of siddhi out of great greed, permission to get these things done through another in certain circum stances,

The extant Dharmas≈´tra does not appear to have come down intact. The fourth pra≈õna is most probably an interpolation. Most of the eight chapters of that pra≈õna are full oft versorthe portion in prose being very small. The last three chapers (6-8)

The BaudhƒÅyana Dharmasutra

43

are entirely in verse. The style is quite different from that of the first two pra≈õnas. The first five chapters of the fourth pra≈õna dealing with prƒÅya≈õcittas are more or less superfluous, the same gubject having been dealt with in II. 1. and III. 4-10. Some of the s√ºtras in the earlier pra≈°nas are repeated verbatim in the fourth, e. g. II, I, 33-34 and IV. 2. 10-11 (avaklƒ±ni-prƒÅyascitta). The third pra≈õnn also is not free from doubt. The tenth chapter of the third pra≈õna is, as said above, taken from Gautama. The sixth chapter of the third pra≈õna agrees very closely in phraseology with the 48th chapter of the Visnudharmas≈´tra. But it is rather difficult to say which is the borrower. Dr. Jolly (S. B. E. Vol. VII. p. XIX) is inclined to think that both borrowed from a common source. It seems more probable that Visnu borrows fronƒ± Baudhiyana, as the Vi≈ünudharmas≈´tra uses the form punita’ in place of ‘punatha’ (in Baud.) and as the Vi≈ünudharmas≈´tra omits all reference to Rudra ( Baud. III. 6. 12.) and omits the words “ganƒÅn pa≈õyati, ganƒÅdhipatim pa≈õyati … bhagavƒÅn BodhƒÅyana·∏•” (Baud. III. 6. 20.). In the Mysore edition all the four pra≈õngs of the Dharmƒ±s≈´tra are divided into adhyƒÅyas, but the Mss used by B√ºhler appear to have divided the first two pra≈õnas into kandikƒÅs and the last two into adhyƒÅyas. There are many repetitions even in the first two pra≈õnas, which therefore make one rather doubtful about the authenticity of the first two pra≈õnas also in their entirety. For example II. 6. 11 and 31 have identical; parts in II, 7 22 and II. 10.53 the same verse (“astau grƒÅsƒÅ” &c.) is quoted. Such repetitions are frequent in the two last pra≈õnas e. g. III. 2. 16 and III, 3.23 ; III. 4. 5 and III.7. 12. Some of tho quotations ascribed to BaudhƒÅyana in the MitƒÅksarƒÅ and other works ara not taken from the tharmasƒ´lra, but from the Grhyas≈´tra or its supplements (e. g. the words ‘ekƒÅm sƒÅkhƒÅmadhite ≈°rotriyah” quoted in the Mit. on YƒÅj. III. 24 which are cited by Hultzsch (on p. 125), are taken from the G»ôhya (vide note 78 below).

Though the fourth pra≈õna appears to be interpolated, yet the interpolation must have taken place early enough. Vi≈°var≈´pa on YƒÅj. I. 64 quotes Baud. Dh. S. IV. 1. 15-16 (trƒ´ni var≈üƒÅnyr tumati ) expressly as Baudhayana’s and on YƒÅj. I. 72 quotes Baud. Dl. S. IV. 1. 22 (bhartuh pratinivesena &c.) by name. The Mit, on YƒÅj. III. 305 quotes (as BaudhƒÅyana’s) a long passage, Baudh. Dh. S. IV. 1, 5-11. SankarƒÅcƒÅrya on Br. Wo. IV.5. 15 quotes Baud. II. 10. % “brahmacaryavan praxmati as smrti. YƒÅj. I. 71 is almost the same as Baud. Dh. 152. 58 ( Soma·∏• saucam &c)

YSTITOR

FOUNDEO

1917

44

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

The Dharmas≈´tra of BaudhƒÅyana is somewhat loose in structure and is not concise. GovindasvƒÅmin remarks (on I. 2. 19) that BaudhƒÅyana does not aim at brevity.70 Several subjects are treated of in two places and often without any logical connection with what precedes or follows. Rules of inheritance (dƒÅya-bh√§ga ) occur in the midst of rules about prƒÅgascitta (in II. 2.); rules about holidays (anadhyƒÅya) occur immediately after the eight forms of marriage and the condemnation of the sale of a daugher (I. 11). Rules about snutaka occur in two places (1. 3 and II. 3. 10 ff.). BaudhƒÅyana quotes at least 90 Verses introduced by the words “athƒÅpyudƒÅharanti,” more than 80 being from the first two pra≈õnas alone. There are over two hundred other verses, about 80 of which occur in the first two pra≈õnas and about ten are Vedic. Some of the verses even in the first two pra≈õnas do not appear to be quotations e. g. I. 1. 16, II. 2. 1. II. 3. 50, II. 3. 52-54 and 56. A verse quoted is in the Vamsastha metre (IV. 3. 14); there are two verses in the UpajƒÅti metre taken as a quotation (II. 3. 18). There are some prose quota tions introduced with the words “athƒÅpyudƒÅharanti” (e. g. II. 4. 5 and II. 6. 30 which refers to the asura Kapila son of Prahlada ). The language of the Baud. Dh. 8. is archaic and often departs from the PƒÅ·πáinean standard. BaudhƒÅyana employs such un P√°ninean forms as ‚Äúgphya” (for gƒºhityƒÅ in II. 5. 1), p≈´jya (II. 9. 5.), “adhigacchƒÅna·∏•” (in II. 9.9.), ƒÅnayitvƒÅ (III. 3. 6), “punatha " (in III, 6. 5, probably a quotation,), “tebhi·∏•” (for tai·∏• in III. 2. 16, a quotation). In several places BaudhƒÅyana states opposite views and then gives his own opinion on the point, e. g. Baud. I. 5. 105-109 (about impurity on birth); II. 1. 49-51.

As regards the literature known to BaudhƒÅyana the following points may be noted. All the four Vedas are mentioned by name in II. 5. 27 ( tarpana ). He quotes very frequently the Taittiriya SamhitƒÅ, Tai. BrƒÅhmana and the Tai. ƒÄranyaka (in the Andhra recension). Well-known hymns of the Rgveda such as the Aghamar≈üa≈Üa, the Purusas≈´kta and also simple .rks’ are frequently referred to. In III. 10 ( which is almost the same as Gautama 19 ) there is a s≈´tra enumerating the Upani≈üads, the Samhitas of all the Vedas and several s≈´mans as purificatory texts. There are long quotations taken from the Satapatha brƒÅhma·πáa (XI. 3. 3.1 ff and XI. 5. 6.3) in Baud. (1. 2. 52 about

  1. The Baudh≈´yana Dharmas≈´tra

brahmac≈´ri and II. 6. 7-9 about brahmayaj≈àƒ±). It is noteworthy that in the tarpana there is an invocation of the Atharyaveda and immediately afterwards of the AtharvƒÅngirasah. The same is found in the BaudhƒÅyanagƒºhya also (III. 2.9 and 22 ). In the Upani≈üads (Brhadaranyaka II. 4. 10, 1V. 1. 2) it is the word AtharvƒÅngirasa·∏• that stands for the Atharvaveda. BaudhƒÅyana quotes a gƒÅthƒÅ of the BhƒÅllavins (I. 1. 29 ) about the geographical limits of Aryavarta. Vasistha adduces the same verso (I. 15 ) and says that it is taken froin the NidƒÅna work of the BhƒÅllavins. The Nirukta also mentions a school of Vedic interpretation called NaidƒÅnƒÅh. It is difficult to say what NidƒÅna works contained. Itih≈´sa and Purana occur in the tarpa≈Üu (II. 5. 27). The angas of the Vedas occur in I. 1.8 and the six anyas in 11. 8. 2. Whether the word “rahasya‚Äù in II. 8. 3 means the ƒÄranyakas (as GovindasvƒÅmin explains ) is doubtful. BaudhƒÅyana mentions a VaikhƒÅnasa-≈õƒÅstra in II. 6. 16, which appears to refer to the work of Vikhanas on hermits and speaks of SrƒÅmayaka (the rites prescribed by Vikhanas for initiation as hermit), just as Gautama does. Among the authors on dharma mentioned by name are : Aupajanghani ( II. 2. 33 for the view that only aurasa son was to be recognised and not the other kinds of sons71), KƒÅtya (1.2. 47), Ka≈õyapa (or KƒÅ≈õyapa in other editions, I. 11. 20 on the point that a woman bought cannot be a patnƒ´), Gautama (I. 1. 23 and II. 2. 70 ), Prajapati (II, 4. 15 about failure in SandhyopƒÅsana, and II. 10. 71 about sanny≈´sa), Manu (IV. 1. 14 and IV. 2. 16), Maudgalya (II. 2. 61, about observances of a widow being restricted only to six months after her husband’s death), Harita (II. 1. 50). Baud. I. 2.7 quotes a verse, which Vasistha ascribes to HƒÅrƒ´ta (Vas. II. 6). As to Gautama, vide p. 33 above. Manu is only mentioned in the fourth pra≈õna, the authenticity of which, as said above, is very doubtful. BaudhƒÅyana II. 2. 16 ( about the efficacy of Aglumar≈üa≈Üa) closely agrees with Manu XI. 260. The first reference to Manu’s teaching cannot be traced in the Manusmrti. PrajƒÅpati ( in III. 9. 21 ) seems to stand for god BrahmƒÅ and not for any real or mythical writor on dharma. One remarkable piece of information contained in BaudhƒÅyana (II. 6. 30 ) is that he quotes from a work (of the BrƒÅhmana class in language ) a prose passage wherein the division into four a≈õramas is ascribed to an asura Kapila, son of PralhƒÅda. daughter of U≈°anas and the king Vrsaparvan, which is nearly the same as MahƒÅbhƒÅrata I. 78. 10 and 34. Baud. quotes the view of ƒÄcƒÅryas (II. 6. 29 ) as Gautama does. In several places he refers to the views of his predecessors on dharma as ‚Äúothers” (eke, apare ) e. g. I. 4. 23, 1. 5. 16, I. 6. 105-106, II. 5. 2. In II, 3. 18 two verses in the UpajƒÅti metre are quoted as sung by “anna” (food). From the numerous quotations in verse cited by BaudhƒÅyana on topics of dharma, it follows that the Dharmas≈´tra was preceded by a considerable number of works on dharma in verse. B√ºhler (SBE vol. XIV, p. XLIII) says that Vij√±ƒÅne≈õvara was the first writer who quoted the Baud. D. S. But there are writers who flourished centuries before Vij√±ƒÅne≈õvara that regarded BaudhƒÅyana as a writer on dharma and either quoted his words or pointedly referred to them. Sabara in his bh≈´sya on Jaimini I. 3. 3 says that the rule in the Sm·ªôtis about the period of Vedic study being 48 years is opposed to the Vedic injunction “one who has begot sons and whose hair are dark should consecrate the sacrificial fires73.‚Äù This must be regarded as referring to the words of BaudhƒÅyana (I. 2.1). Sabara uses the same word ‚ÄúVedabrahmacarya” that Baud. employs. It is true that Gautama and ƒÄpastamba both refer to the rule about 48 years, but they do not employ the word “veda-brahmacarya.” The TantravƒÅrtika7 of KumƒÅrila says that the words of ƒÄpastamba (II. 6. 15. 1) which seem to accept the validity of local and family usages (even though opposed to Sm·ªôti tradition) stand refuted by the words of BaudhƒÅyana (I. 1. 19-24 ) who cites only such censured usages as are opposed to Snirti. Kum√§rila appears to think that BaudhƒÅyana attacks the extant work of √Ñpastamba, i. e, the present Baud. is later than the present ƒÄpastamba. It is not necessary to follow KumƒÅrila implicitly as regards chronological details, where he is speaking of writers that flourished over a thous and years before him. But his opinion deserves weight. The Tantra

6,

The BaulhƒÅyana Dharmas≈´tra

v√•rtika quotes a Smrti passage which bears a close resemblance to BaudhƒÅyana (II. 3. 28). In the commentary of Vi≈°var≈´pa (who as we shall see below flourished about 800 A. D.)on YƒÅj√±avalkya, BaudhƒÅyana is quoted at least nine times in the chapter on ƒ´c≈´ra alone. Vide Vi≈°var≈´pa on YƒÅj. I. 21, 26, 29,53, 64, 69, 72, 79, 195 (Trivandrum edition), where Baud. I. 5. 14, I. 2.30, , 5.5, 1. 1. 17, IV.1. 15, 1V. 1. 18, 1V. 1.22, IV. 1. 20 and I. 5. 47 are respecti vely quoted. There are very few variations from the present text and the only serious variation is as regards the last (1,5.47) which is in prose ( while Vi≈°var≈´pa quotes a verse ). It is remar kable that Visvar≈´pa quotes several verses from the fourth pra≈õruri, which shows that even if the fourth pra≈∫na be an interpolation, it is comparatively an ancient one. The Mit. also (on YƒÅj. III. 306 ) quotes a long passage from the fourth pra≈°na (IV.1.5-11 ). The words of the SƒÅkuntala76 that the first precept is that a girl is to be given away to a meritorious person are probably a reminiscence of Baud. IV. 1. 12. MedhƒÅtithi on Manu. V. 117 quotes BaudhƒÅyana I. 5. 47 and on IV. 36 quotes Baud. I. 4. 2 (which is mutilated as printed). On Manu. V, 114 he says that all the rules about purification of substances are contained in BaudhƒÅyana-smrti. On Manu. V. 118, he quotes Baud. I. 5. 50.

About the home of BaudhƒÅyana it is difficult to advance any positive conclusion. In modern times BaudhƒÅyaniyas are mostly confined to the south. We know that SƒÅyana, the great commentator of the Vedas, was a BaudhƒÅyaniya. A grant of Nandivarma, a Pallava, of the 9th century mentions BrƒÅhma·πáas of the pravacina-s≈´tra as recipients.77 As BaudhƒÅyana is called pravacanakƒÅra in the G·ªãhyas≈´tra B√ºhler thinks (8. B. E. vol. 14 p. XLII) that the BrƒÅhmanas belonged to the BaudhƒÅyanacarana. B√ºhler is probably right. In the grant most of the donees are students of the ƒÄpastamba S≈´tra. First the Gotra, then the S≈´tra and then the name of the donee are introduced in the grant. Therefore as some of the donees are said to be students of “pravacanas≈´tra,” it follows that “pravacana” stands for some s≈´tra school. It appears that s≈´tra and pravucunui are two different

FOUNDED

History of Dharmas√ºstra

things, whatever the latter term may mean. BaudhƒÅyana is called pravacanakƒÅra and Apastamba is styled s≈´trakƒÅra. We are toid by the BaudhƒÅyana-gphys≈´tra78 that a BrƒÅhma·πáa who studied s≈´tra and pravacana was styled ‚Äúbhr≈´na.” B√ºhler was inclined to hold that BaudhƒÅyana was a southern teacher for several reasons. BaudhƒÅyana mentions customs of the south and includes see-faring as a custom peculiar to the north (I. 1. 20 ), while in another place he places sea-faring at the head of sins (patanƒ´yas ) lesser than the mortal ones (II. 1. 41 ). Therefore it is said that he was not a northern teacher. But as against this we have to remember that BaudhƒÅyana (I. 1.29) quotes with approval a verse in which the countries of Avanti (Ujjain), Anga, Magadha, SurƒÅstra ( Kathiawar) and Dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅpatha are declared to be the home of mixed castes. Dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅpatha was generally supposed to be the whole peninsula south of the NarmadƒÅ. BaudhƒÅyana, if he was a native of the south, would not have spoken of his country as the home of mixed castes only, unless he put a restricted meaning on the word Daksi≈ÜƒÅpatha ( which sometimes meant in later days MahƒÅrƒÅstra). Vide J. B. B. R. A. S. for 1917 p. 620. Though as stated above, the question of the home of BaudhƒÅyana is a difficult one, yet if a definite inclination has to be shown, then I am disposed to agree with B√ºhler that the author of Baud. Dh. 8. was a southerner. It is important to note that Baud. wants to expound the dharmas declared in the Veda, in the Smrtis and those practised by ƒ£istas (I. 1.1-4) and defines sistas (1. 1.5-6) as those who possess certain moral qualities and who understand the Veda together with other supporting sastras. He sets out first the five peculiar usages of the southern part, two of which are the usages of marrying one’s maternal uncle’s or paternal aunt’s daughter, These two are even now in vogue in some parts of MahƒÅrƒÅstra and the South among certain sub-divisions of brƒÅhma·πáas and were not prevalent in the north. BaudhƒÅyana impartially sets forth five practices of the south and five of the north that were opposed to ancient ≈õƒÅstras and his own view appears to have been that in the case of all persons belonging to AryƒÅvarta ( whether they be in the northern or southern parts) both sets of five practices in s≈´tras ( 19 and 20 ) were not to be followed. In that connection he quotes several (three) views about AryƒÅvarta and two verses more, one of which

The Brullunyana Dharmƒ±s≈´tra.

uno

names the countries in which there is mixture of castes and the 2nd mentions some countries like ƒÄratta (Panjab), Sauvƒ´ra, Pu≈Üdra, Vanga, Kalinga, sojourn in which made a person liable to undergo an expiation. The countries mentioned in the first verse are all (except Dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅpatha ) to the north of the NarmadƒÅ. It is quite probable that he did not like the usage of marrying one’s maternaljunole’s or paternal aunt’s daughter even for southern people. It should be noted that almost all the countries in the 2nd verse are north of the NarmadƒÅ. Further, DaksinƒÅpatha appears to have meant a country roughly liko modern MahƒÅrƒÅstra long before the Christian era; vide ASWI. Vol. V. p. 60 which shows that in an inscription (No. 1) of Nanaghat (Poona District ) Vedisiri is mentioned as king of DaksinƒÅpatha. Vide ASWI Vol. IV. p. 110 and RudradƒÅman’s inscription (E. I. Vol. VIII at p. 44, where Satakarni is said to have been lord of Dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅpatha). The fact that ƒÄpastamblyas, Hira·πáyake≈õins and BaudhƒÅyaniyas have congregated much more in the suuth than in the north for centuries supports the above statement. The words UttarƒÅ patha and DaksimƒÅpatha were never strictly defined. For example, in the Sanjan plates ( supposed to be spurious ) of Buddhavarasa (E. I. Vol. 14 p. 144 at p. 149 about 700 A. D.) we meet with the words ‘UttarƒÅpa thƒÅdhipati-Sri-Har≈üadevaparƒÅjayopalabdhogra-pratƒÅpah’ i. e. king Harsa is said to have been lord of Uttarapatha. If we turn to the Harsacarita of BƒÅ≈Üa (first paragraph after two initial verses of the 5th UcchyƒÅsa ) we read ‘Atha kadƒÅcid-rajƒÅ Rajyavardhanam-ƒÅb≈´ya H√º≈ÜƒÅn hantum…cirantanairamƒÅtyaih… k≈ôtvƒÅ sƒÅbhisƒÅram-uttar≈´patham prƒÅhi≈Üot’. This shows that Sth√¢nvisvara (modern Thanesar) was not included in UttarƒÅpatha in BƒÅna’s days. UttarƒÅpatha occurs in the Hathigumpha Inscription of KhƒÅravela ( E.I. Vol. XX. p.71 at p. 79 and p. 88 ). PƒÅnini knows the word as in V. 1.77 ‘UttarƒÅpathen√§hrtam ca’ ( UttarƒÅpathen√§hrtam auttarƒÅpathikam, UttarƒÅpathena gaochati auttarapathikah). About Dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅpatha the MahƒÅbhƒÅsya says that large lakes are called ‘Sarasi’ in Dak·π£i·πáƒÅpatha (Kielhorn’s ed. Vol. I. p. 73). The word ‘Dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅpatha oocurs in the gana

dh√ºmƒÅdi’ (PƒÅn. IV. %. 127 ).

The extant BaudhƒÅyanadharmas≈´tra is certainly later than Gautama, as it mentions Gautama twice by name and as one quota. tion at least is found in the extant Gautama. Besides BaudhƒÅyana quotes by name several teachers on dharma, while Gautama quotes only one, Manu. BaudhƒÅyana is far removed from the times on the Upani≈üads. Baud. (II, 7, 15) quotes a verse which is itself an

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

adaptation of a passage from the ChƒÅndogya-upani≈üad. 79 He quotes Harƒ´ta. It is uncertain whether the H√§ritadharmas≈´tra, a manuscript of which was discovered by the late Vaman Sastri IslƒÅmpurkar at Nasik, is the one intended. B√ºhler thought that the work of BaudhƒÅyana was earlier than that of ƒÄpastamba by a century or two. His first reason was that KƒÅ≈Üva BaudhƒÅyana receives homage in the tarpa≈Üa before ƒÄpastamba and Hiranyakesin and that the same order is observed in the Baudhayana-grhyas≈´tra. But this reason is far from convincing. It may be conceded that BaudhƒÅyana was regarded as the oldest (or the most authoritative or respectable ) of the three schools of the Black Yajurveda. But from this it does not at all follow that the extant dharina-s≈´tra of the BaudhƒÅyaniyas is earlier than that of the ƒÄpastambiyas. For aught we know the s≈´tra compiled for the school of BaudhƒÅyana may be later than the s≈´tra manual of the ƒÄpastambiyas. We saw above that orthodox opinion, represented by KumƒÅrila, regards BaudhƒÅyana’s work as later than ƒÄpastamba’s. All the three founders of the three schools are mentioned in the BaudhƒÅyanagƒºhya and dharmas≈´tra. One may equally argue with good reason that both these works knew a s≈´tra work of Apastamba and that the extant dharmas≈´tra of ƒÄpastamba is that work. Another reason assigned for the priority of BaudhƒÅyana’s work over Apastamba’s is that, though both have numerous s≈´tras that agree almost word for word. a comparison of the views of the two writers shows that Apastamba lays down stricter and more puritanic (and therefore later) views on certain points than BaudhƒÅyana. Gautama, BaudhƒÅyana and Vasistha mention several secondary sons, while Apastamba is silent about them, Gautama, BaudhƒÅyana (II. 2. 17, 62 ), Vasistha and even Visnu approve of the practice of niyoga, while ƒÄpastamba condemns it (II. 6, 13.1-9). Gautama and BaudhƒÅyana (1. 11. 1) speak of eight forms of marriage, while ƒÄpastamba speaks of only six and omits PrƒÅjƒÅpatya and Pai≈°ƒÅca (II. 5. 11. 17-20 and II. 5. 12. 1-2). BaudhƒÅyana (II.2.4-6) allowed a larger share to the eldest son on a partition, while ƒÄpastamba condemns such a procedure (II. 6. 14. 10-14). The BaudhƒÅyana-gƒºhyas≈´tra (II. 4, 6) allows upanayana to rathak≈´ra, while ƒÄpastamba (gshya 4. 10. 1-4) does not do so (dharmas≈´tra I. 1. 1. 19). These points are hardly conclusive on the question of date. From

79 Baud. ‘Aigareta un protan sa saudi arealfor

909fat quad A ta: Il ‘; compare 9172121Thaty. 24.71 29” ‡§•‡•à‡§∑‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á’ &c.

FOUNDED

  1. The BiudhƒÅyana Dharmasutra

very ancient times there was great divergence of opinion among the doctors of the law on most, if not on all, of these points. There is no hard and fast rule that these doctrines were upheld by early writers and condeinned by later ones. BaudhƒÅyana himself quotes the views of an ancient writer, Aupajanghani, who condemned all secondary sons. The verses that BaudhƒÅyana quotes on this point (II. 2. 34-36 ) are quoted by ƒÄpastamba also but without the author’s name (Ap. II. 6. 13.6), there being variants only in the first verse. Niyoga was allowed by Manu (9. 56-63 ) and then condemned (9. 64-68) and B»ôhaspati refers to this attitude of Manu (vide Kull≈´ka on Manu 9. 68). Even 40 late a writer as YƒÅj√±avalkya (II. 131 ) approves of niyoga. About the rathak≈´ra being allowed to consecrate the sacred firos there is a discussion in the s≈´tras of Jaimini (VI. 1. 44 ff). Vedic passages supported both methods viz. equal division among sons and the bestowal of a larger share on the eldest. Even YƒÅj√±a valkya (II. 118) allows a larger share to the eldest son. Therefore, hardly anyone of the circumstances relied upon by B√ºhler as indicating a later age for ƒÄpastamba is conclusive or convincing. The third ground for placing BaudhƒÅyana before Apastamba is that the style of the former is simpler and older as compared with the latter’s. That BaudhƒÅyana is simpler than ƒÄpastamba may be admitted. But this may be due to the fact that BaudhƒÅyana has been tampered with more than √Ñpastamba. On the other hand ƒÄpastamba contains more un-PƒÅ·πáinean forms, more uncouth constructions, more words in an archaic sense than is the case with BandhƒÅyana. All that is almost certain about the age of the BaudhƒÅyana-dharmas≈´tra is that it is later than the work of Gautama, that its style, its doctrines and its general out-look on different subjeots do not compel us to assign it a later date than that of the other dharmas≈´tras. We have adduced evidence to show that long before the days of Sabara ( whose latest date cannot be later than 500 A. D.) the BaudhƒÅyana-dharmas√∫tra was an authoritative sm·ªôti; it follows that the dlarƒ±nas≈´tra must be placed somewhere between 500-200 B. C. Numerous s≈´tras are identical in BaudhƒÅyana and ƒÄpastamba e. g. Ap. I. 1. 2. 30 = Baud. I. 2. 40-41, ƒÄp. I. 2. 6. 8-9 = Baud. I. 2. 39, Ap. I. 5. 15.8 = Baud. I. 2. 31, Ap. I. 11. 31. 11 and 16 = Baud. II. 3. 39 and 32. There are several verses that occur in both e. (). Baud. II. 1. 4% = ƒÄp. I. 9. 27. 11, Baud. II. 2. 34-36 = ƒÄp. II. 6. 13. 6 (thtag verses condemning secondary sors), Baud. II. 10. 63 Ap 11. 9. 21. 10, Baud. II. 7. 22-23 = Ap. II. 4. 9. 13. (two verdes1

History of Dhurmu≈õustra

Baud. II. 6. 36 = ƒÄp. II. 9. 24. 8. Besides these there are numerous Vedic quotations that are common to both. All this, however, does not establish anything about their relative position. The Vasistha-dharmas≈´tra also has numerous quotations in common with Baud. Vide Vas. I. 15. = Baud. I. 1. 28, Vas. III. 5, 6, 11, 20, 56 = Baud. I. 1, 10, 12, 11, 8 and I. 5. 58. (respectively ); Vas. 6. 20-21 = Baud. II. 7. 22-23; Vas. VIII. 17 = Baud. II, 2, 1 ; Vas. XI. 27-28 = Baud. II. 8. 21-22; Vas. XVI. 34 = Baud. I. 10. 35, Vas. XVII. 73 = Baud. IV, 1. 17, Vas. XVII. 86 = Baud. I. 5. 102; Vas. XXII. 10 = Baud. I. 1. 33. It is to be noted that some of these quotations (Baud, II. 8. 21-22, I. 10. 35) occur in the extant Manusmrti (III. 125-126 and VIII, 98). There are a few prose s≈´tras in Vas that are transformed into verse in Baud. and vice versa e. g. Vas. III. 41 (prose) = Baud. 1. 5. 20 (quoted as a verse ), Vas. III. 57 ( quoted as a verse ) = Baud. I. 6. 19-20. It is not likely that one borrows from the other. There are two other possible explanations, viz. that both Baud. and Vas. (and Manu also) quote froin or adapt a common source or that the three works have been tampered with and interpolations introduced at every step. The latter alternative is too sweeping as the number of verses is very large and makes all the old s≈´tras except that of Gautama valueless for all chronological purposes. One cannot subscribe to the view that such extensive interpolations took place as the latter theory demands. The first alternative appears more reasonable. What that common source was, whether it was a regular work in verse or whether there was a floating mass of such popular verses as B√ºhler holds, are questions that present Very great difficulties. It is not easy to believe that there hundreds of floating verses on dharmu no body knew by whom composed, on which writers of the centuries preceding the Christian era drew for supporting their opinions. That does not sound as a very likely procedure. It is more probable that such verses were contained in a work or works now lost.

I tried on pp. 29-31 of the first edition to bring forward arguments on both sides of the question whether BaudhƒÅyana Dh. S. is earlier or later than Apastamba and on p. 30 stated that the Baud. Dh. 8. may be placed between 500 B. C. and 200 B. C. Dr. Ram Gopal (p. 76 of his work) trots out the plea that I am inconsistent. I have given above an answer to this charge in the case of my remarks about Gautama. So I do not want to rebut here the charge of inconsistency. I am prepared to place BaudhƒÅyana Dh. S. between 600 B. O, to 300 B. All these

The Banuelh√ºljatrict Dhurnius√ºlrit

datos are more or less tentative and there is n10 finality about them at least at present.

In the tarpana, Baud. (II. 5. 21 ) mentions several appellations of Ganesa, viz. Vighna, VirƒÅyaka, Sth√ºla, Varada, Hastimukha, Vakratunda, Ekadanta, Lambodara. But this affords no certain clue as to date. The worship of VinƒÅyaka is found in tho M√§navagƒºhya also. In the tarpeixe (II. 5. 23 ) we have the seven planets montioned in the order of the days of the week and also RƒÅhu and Ketu ; besidos the twelve names of Visnu occur in II. 5. 24. In II. 1. 44 Baud. speaks of tho profession of an actor or of a teacher of dramaturgy (NatyƒÅcƒÅrya) as an upapƒÉtaka. Soveral s≈´tras attributed to BaudhƒÅyana on the subject of adoption in the DattakamimƒÅmsƒÅ and other later works are taken from the BaudhƒÅyanagrlyaso»ôas≈´tra (11. 6), the g≈´tras agreeing very closely with Vasistha ( 15.1-9).

According to Burnell the oldest commentator on the BaudhƒÅyana≈õrauta-s≈´tra was BhavasvƒÅmin, whom he placed in the 8th century. The commentary of Govindasvamin on the Dharmas≈´tra is a learned one and is generally to the point. He appears to be a very late writer.

  1. Dharmasutra of ƒÄpastamba. This has been edited several times (viz. by B√ºhler in the Boinbay Sanskrit Series with large extracts from Haradatta’s commentary called UjjvalƒÅ and also at Kumbhakonam with the complete commentary of Haradatta and translated by B√ºhler with an introduction in S. B. E. vol. II). The Apastan bakalpas≈´tra of the Taittiriya SƒÅkhƒÅ of the black Yajurveda is divided into 30 pru≈õnas. According to B√ºhler, the first 24 pra≈õnas contain the treatment of Srauta sacrifices; the 25th contains paribh≈´·π£ƒÅs, pravarakhanda, and Hautraka prayers to be recited by Hotr priests ; 26th and 27th pra≈õnas constitute the G»ôhyas≈´tra, the 28th and 29th Dharmas≈´tra and the 30th pra≈õna is Sulvas√∫tra. B√ºhler seems to be slightly inaccurate here. According to Caundappa, who commented on the ƒÄpastambiya s≈´tras in the 14th century, the ƒÄpastambiyaman trapƒÅtha forms the 25th and 26th pra≈õnas of the Kalpas≈´tra and the G»ôhyas≈´tra forms 27th prasna.80 The Srauta-s≈´tra of 80 ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∑‡§á‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§• ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä

(Dr. Winternitz’s edition of ƒÄp. MaptrapƒÅtha p. IX ). The editor farthek states (p. IX n. 2) that ParibhƒÅ≈üƒÅs form part of the 24th pra≈õn a nu not of the 25th, as B√ºhler says.

Hlistory of Dharma≈õƒÅstrd

Apastamba was edited by Dr. Garbe in the B. I. series ; the G»ôhya and MantrapƒÅtha were edited by Dr. Winternitz. The G»ôhya with the commentary of SudarsanƒÅrya has been edited in the Mysore Govt. Oriental series by Pandit Mahadeva Sastri ( in 1893). It is divided into eight patalas and 23 khandas. According to the Caranavy≈´ha, ƒÄpastamba (or “bha” as written in many southern mss.) is one of the five sub-divisions of the KhƒÅndikiya school of the Taittiriya≈õƒÅkha of the Black Yajurveda. Whether the author of the ƒÄpastambiya Srauta, G»ôhya and Dharma s√ºtras is the same is difficult to detormine. One s≈´tra in the ƒÄpastambadharma (II. 2. 5. 17 ) is the same as Ap. Srauta (III. 17. 8 and VIII. 4. 6). Oldenberg (S. B. E. vol. 30, p. XXXII) does not subscribe to B√ºhler’s view (S. B. E. Vol. II, pp. XIII-XIV ) that the authors of the Ap. Srauta and Duerme were identical and gives it as his own view that another person of the same school might have imitated the style of the author of the Srauta. Whatever may be said of the identity of the authorship of the Srauta and Dharma s≈´tras, the G»ôhya and Dharma seem to be very closely related and both seem to be the compositions of the same author. The Ap. G»ôhya-s≈´tra, as compared with the ƒÄ≈õvalƒÅyana-gphya or Gobhilagphya, is extremely brief and leaves out many rules that are given in other Grhya works. For example, about the choice of a girl, the Ap. Gr. gives only one worthwhile rule (I. 3. 18 )81, the other rules (1. 3. 10-17 ) are of a trivial character such as that the girl that is sleepy or weeping or leaves the house when the bridegroom’s party comes to choose her or when the girl’s name is that of a river, naksatra or tree or she has a name in which the penultimate letter is r or 1 &c. but all those rules in the grhyas≈´tra (including the one in s≈´tra 18 ) are recommendatory and a marriage entered into against these rules would have been valid even in old times. The most important rule, breach of which would have made tho marriage void, is stated in ƒÄr. Dh. S. II. 5. 11. 15-16 ) viz. that the gotra of the bride’s father and of the bridegroom must not be the same and there must be no sapi≈Üda relationship between the two on the mother’s and father’s side.

Dr. Ram Gopal says on p. 57 (of his work ) that I am not accurate when I state about the choice of a girl that ƒÄp. Gr. S. gives only a single rule (I quoted that rule ). I added that it was the Ap. Dh. S. (II. 5. 11. 15-16 ) that provides that the girl must not be a sagotra or sapinda. Dr. Ram Gopalk awayed by

_81 ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§§ ‡•§

  1. Dharmasƒ´tra of Aprstamba

mere numbers. He points out that there are ten s≈´tras in Ap. G»õ, about the choice of a marriageable girl. What I wanted to emphasise was that only one rule of ƒÄp. Gr. was worth something and I quoted that rule. A marriage entered in defiance of all the ten rules in ƒÄp. Gƒæ, would have been quite valid even in those days. I wanted to illustrate how ƒÄp. Gr. S. was scrappy and omitted even vital matters. The rules (only two) forbidding a sagotra or sapinda girl for marriage were vital and breach of them would have made the marriage void. Ap. Gr. S. I. 3. 21 is not ƒÄpastamba’s opinion; it is the view of others (YasyƒÅm manascak≈üu≈üor-nibandhas-tƒÅsyƒÅm-rddhir-netaradƒÅdriyetetyeke ). Even this rule is recommendatory and not obligatory and a marriage in defiance of it would have been quite valid in those days and would be valid also in these days. That view occurs also in the KƒÅmas≈´tra III. 1, 14. Vide H. of Dh. vol. II, p. 432 note 1025 for further information. In the 2nd volume of H. of Dh, on pp. 437-38, I mentioned this prohibition of sagotra and sapravara marriages and recommended on pp. 498-99 that the legislature should intervene and loosen the absolute bar against sagotra and sapravara marriages. The Indian Parliament (by Act 25 of 1955, called the Hindu Marriage Act) has removed the bar against Sagotra and Sapi≈Üda marriages to a great extent. Vide sections 3 (f and g) and 5 of that Act. The ƒÄp. Grhya is silent about the forms of marriage, about holidays, about the duties of brahmac≈´rins and such other subjects which are generally treated of in other Grhyas≈´tras. These subjects are dealt with in the ƒÄp. Dh. S, and there are several places where the Dharma sutra presupposes the existence of the Grhya and refers to it, Compare ƒÄp. Dh. S. II. 1, 2. 10-1182 with Ap. Gr. S. III. 7 (particularly s≈´tras 1, 17, 23 ). Vide note 54 above. Some s≈´tras are identical in the Grhya and Dharma, e. g. ƒÄp. Dh. S. I. 1.2. 38 and G»ôhya IV. 11. 15-16 ( about the staff of BrahmacƒÅrin); ƒÄp. Dh. 8. II. 4. 8.7 and Grhya V. 13, 19. In some cases the Grhya s≈´tra itself seems to refer to the teachings of the Dharmas≈´tra,

llistory of Dhurmu≈õƒ´strou

e. g. G·ªáhya 8.21. 1 and Dharma II. 7. 16. 6-7. All these facts make it highly probable, if not certain, that the Grhya and Dharma s≈´tras were composed by the same author and that the details of certain topics were purposely omitted in the G»ôhya to avoid repetition. The Sm·ªãticandrikƒÅ (III. p. 458 ) distinctly asserts that the author of the Dharmas≈´tra and the Grhyas≈´tra was the same.

The contents of the ƒÄp. dharma-s≈´tra are :

  1. the authoritative sources of ilharm are the Vedas and the usages of those who know tharma; the four urnas, their precedence ; definition of ƒÅcƒÅrya and his greatness, time for upanayana according to the varnas and according to one’s desire ; prƒÅyascitta if proper time for upanayana is gone, he whose father, granc-father and great-grand-father had no upanayana performed becomes patita, but he can be purified by prƒÅya citta ; the duties of brahmac≈´rin, residence with teacher for 48 years, 36, 25 or 12 years ; rules of conduct for brahinac≈´rin, his staff girdle and garment, rules about begging for food, bringing fuel and offering to fire; the vows of a brahmacƒÅrin are his tapos; rules about saluting teacher and others according to varnas ; giving daksi≈ÜƒÅ to the teacher at the end of study; rules for enƒÅtaka ; rules about holidays and about the time and place for Vedic study; rules about holidays apply to study of the Veda and not to the use of mantras in Vedic rites; the five great daily yaj√±as to the bh≈´tas, men, gods, pitrs, and sages ; honouring men of higher castes, old men, parents, brothers and sisters and others; method of inquiring about one’s health &c. according to warnas; occasions of wearing yaj√±opavita; times and manner of ≈´camana; rules about forbidden and permitted food and drink; the avocation of a vanij not allowed to a brƒÅhmana except in distress; rules forbidding the sale or exchange of certain things; grave sins (pataniya ), such as theft, the murder of a brƒÅhmana or other man, causing abortion, incest, drinking wine etc; other sins are not so grave, though they make the perpetrator impure : discussion of some metaphysical questions such as the knowledge of the soul, Brahma, the moral faults that lead to perdition such as anger, avarice, hypocrisy &c; the virtues that lead to the highest goal, such as absence of anger or avarice &c. truthfulness. tranquility; compensation for killing a Ksatriya, Vai≈õya, or ≈ö≈´dra and women ; prƒÅya≈õcitta for killing a BrƒÅhmania and an Atreyi BrƒÅhma·πáa woman, for killing a guru oria Systriya ; prƒÅya≈õcitta for violating the bed of a guru, for drhiking wire

  2. Dharmas≈´tra of Apastamba

and for theft of gold; prƒÅya≈õcittas for killing several birds, cows and bulls, and for abusing those who should not be abused, for sexual intercourse with a S≈´dra woman, for taking forbidden food and drink &c.; rules about K·ªãcchra for twelve nights; what constitutes theft; how one should act towards a fallen (patita ) guru and mother; various opinions about prƒÅyascitta for viola ting guru’s bed; prƒÅya≈õcitta for a husband who has intercourse with another woman and for wife’s adultery ; prƒÅya≈õcitta for killing a bhr≈´na (a learned brƒÅhmana); brƒÅhma·πáa was not to wield arms, except in self-defence against hodily injury ; prƒÅya≈õcitta for abhi≈°asta ; prƒÅya≈õcittas for lesser sins; various views about snataka ( VidyƒÅsnƒÅtaka, VratasnƒÅtaka and VidyavratasnƒÅtaka); the observances (vratas ) of snƒÅtaka as regards garments, answe ring calls of nature, about scandalous talk, about not seeing the rising or setting Sun, avoiding moral faults such as anger ; 11 (pra≈õna) the householder’s observances commence on marriage (pƒÅnigrahana); Tules of conduct for a householder about taking food and fasting, about sexual intercourse ; all the varnas attain unmeasured bliss by performing their duties and are re-born in conditions appropriate to their actions and by means of evil deeds are re-born in evil surroundings e. g. a brƒÅhmana who is a thief or a murderer of a brƒÅhma·πáa becomes a CƒÅ≈ÜdƒÅla, a similarly guilty r≈´janya becomes a paulkasa; the three higher castes should after bathing perform Vai≈°vadeva ; S≈´dras may cook food for their masters of higher castes under the supervision of Aryas ; Offerings (bali) of cooked food; guests (atithi) should be first offered food, then children, old men, sick persons and pregnant women (and then the householder himself); no one should be refused food when he comes at the end of Vai≈°vadova; rules of receiving guests, such as unlearned brƒÅhamanas, ksatriyas, vaisyas and s≈´dras; an house holder should always wear an upper garment or his sacred thread may serve that purpose ; in the absence of a brƒÅhma·πáa teacher, a brƒÅhmana may learn from a ksatriya or vai≈õya teacher; duties of a married man when his teacher comes as a guest ; duty of house holder to teach and to observe the rules of conduct laid down for him ; in case of doubt as to a guest’s caste and character, how to proceed ; who is an atithi ; praise of honouring an atithi ; procedure in case an atithi comes to a king or to one who has consecrated fires ; to whom and when madhuparka is to be offered; the six nigas of Veda named ; all including dogs and candƒÅlas should be given food after Vai≈°vadeva ali gifts to be made with water ; one must not give at the expansiy

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

of servants and slaves ; one may subject himself, wife and sons to privations (but not servants); amount of food to be taken by brahmac≈´rin, householder, hermit &c.; occasions for begging are the teacher, marriage, sacrifice, maintenance of parents and avoidance of the cessation of some worthy observance (like (ugnihotra); the peculiar karmans of brƒÅhmanas and the other oastes; rules of war; the king to appoint a pirohila skilled in dharma and art of government, who is to carry out punishments and penances; punishments including death sentence according to the gravity of the offences, but a brƒÅhma·πáa was not to be killed or injured or to be made a slave; rule of the road; a man of the lower caste by practising his duties rises higher and higher when re-born and a man of the higher castes goes lower by audharma; one should not marry another wife, when the first has children and is helpful in the performance of dharma; rules about marriageable girl, i. e. she must not be sagotra and sapinda of the mother; six forms of marriage viz, brƒÅhma, ƒÅrsa, daiva, gƒÅndharva, ƒÅsura, raksasa; preference among the six; rules of conduct after marriage; sons born of wives of the same caste can perform the duties appropriate to the father’s caste and inherit parent’s property; the son of a woman who was once married or who is not married according to prescribed forms or who is not of the same caste is censured; whether the son belongs to the begetter (or to him on whose wife he is begotten); there can be no gift or sale of a child; partition during father’s lifetime a

equal division; exclusion from inheritance of the impotent, lunatics and sinners; the inheritance in the absence of son goes to nearest sapinda, then to the teacher and then to the pupil, or the daughter and ultimately to the king; the opinion of some that the largest share goes to the eldest son is opposed to the Vedas; no partition between husband and wife; usages of countries and families not to be followed if opposed to the Vedas; impurity on death of agnates, cognates &c; gifts to be made at proper time, place and to proper person; ≈õr≈´ddhas; times of ≈õr≈´ddha; materials required at ≈õrƒÅddha; food (including flesh) appropriate at ≈õrƒÅddhas; what brƒÅhma·πáas are to be called at sriddha; the four ƒ´≈õrumas; rules about parivrƒÅj i. e. sannyƒÅsin; the duties of forest hermit; praise of the meritorious and condem nation of evil-doers; special rules about kings; founding of his capital and palace; position of the sabhƒÅ; extirpation of thieves; gifts of land and wealth to brƒÅhma·πáas; protection people; persons exempt from taxation, such as ≈örotriyas, women of all pastes, students and ascetics; punishment of youngworten for

  1. Dharmas≈´tru of Apastamba

59

adultery; punishment varied according as the woman wronged was Arya or S√ºdra; punishments for abuse and for homicide ; punishments for various breaches of conduct; dispute between cowherd and master; the perpetrator, the abettor and one who approves of the act are all guilty; who are to docide disputes; in case of doubt decision by inference and by divine proof (ordeals ); punishment for perjury; all other dharmas should be learnt, according to some, from women and people of all castes.

Each of the two pra≈õnus of the √Ñpastamba-dharma-s√∫tra is divided into eleven patalas, there being 32 and 29 khandik≈´s in the two patalas respectively. The Dharmas≈´tra is written in a more concise and compact style than that of BaudhƒÅyana and has more archaio and un-PƒÅ·πáinean forms than any other extant Dharmas≈´tra. For example, the following are against the rules of PƒÅnini; AdhƒÅsana ( for adha ƒÅsana ) in I. 1. 2. 21, aglamsnu (1. 2. 3. 22 ), muh≈´nsca (I. 2. 8.22 ), agƒºhyamƒÅna (I. 4., 12. 8), sarvatopeta (for ‘sarvata upeta’) in 1.6.19.9, sakhim (for sakhim) in I. 7. 21. 9. Haradatta points out in many places that the current reading was un-PƒÅ·πáinean and therefore he read differently (0.g. in II. %. 5. 2 he reads ‚Ä¢ aviprakramana’, while the current reading was ‘aviprakramina !:)83. This makes it probable that in the original text there must have been many more un-PƒÅninean forms than in the one preserved by Haradatta. There are many unfamiliar or rare words used by Apastamba, i. e. ananiyoga (1. 6. 19. 12), anaiscƒÅrika (I. 8. 22. 1), kartapatya (I. 2.5.3), vyupatoda and vyupajƒÅva (-‘pa’) in I. 2. 8. 15, brahmaha sainstuta (I. 1. 1. 32). We meet with strange forms of certain words, such as paryƒÅnta (1. 3. 9. 21 ), pra≈õƒÅsta (II. 8. 19. 3), anatyaya (I. 1. 1. 21, for anatyaya ), brahmojjham (for-ojjliah ) in I. 7. 21. 8, ≈õvƒÅvit (1. 5. 17. 37), ≈üthevana (I. 11. 30. 19 for sthivana ), ƒÅcƒÅryadƒÅre (for-dƒÅre»ôu) in I. 2. 7. 27. Though the Ap. Dluarnas≈´tra is mainly in prose, there are versos here and there.Somo of the verses are expressly stated to be taken from other sources by being introduced with the word “udaharanti” or with ‚ÄúathƒÅpyudƒÅbaranti” e. g. I. 6. 19.13 (two ≈õlokas from a Purana), 1. 6. 19. 15 (compare Manu 8. 317 and Vas. 19. 44 ), I. 11. 31. 1, I. 11. 32. 24, II. 4. 9.13 (two verses, same as Baud. II. 7. 22-23), II. 7. 17.8, II. 6. 13.6 (three verses almost the same as in Baud. II. 2. 34-36 ), II. 9. 23. 4-5 (two ≈õlokas from a PurƒÅna ). Besides these, there are several isolated verses, most of which seem to be quotations, though not introduced with words liko “udƒÅharanti

They aro I. 4. 14. 25, 1. 6. 19.14 (the first pƒÅda of which is Manu 4.212 ), I. 9. 27. 10, I. 9. 27. 11 (same as Baud. II. 1. 42 ), II. %. 4. 14 (compare Manu III. 101 ). Some of these verses are defective in metre, there being nine syllables in one anustubh pƒÅda as in 1. 9. 27. 10, II. 9. 23. 4-5, II. 2. 4. 14. One of the verses is in tho classical UpajƒÅti metre (II. 7. 17. 18), while another closely approaches that metre (I. 9. 27. 11). Besides these, there are a few half-verses, II. 5. 11. 5-6 ( same as latter half of Vanaparva 133. 1), II. 9. 21 10 ( Manu 6. 43 has the first pƒÅda ). Thus in all there are about twenty verses, of which at least six occur in

BaudhƒÅyana. Some s≈´tras that are printed as prose are parts of vorses, e. g. I. 2. 5. 11. Besidese these, there are several verses in the patalas dealing with metaphysics (1.8. 22. 4-8 and I. 9.23. 1-3 ) that are pieced together largely from Upanisad passages. ƒÄpastamba in several places employs the first person plural about himself, e. g. I. 1. 1.27, I. 8. 23. 4. Haradatta points out that in his day there was difference in the text as handed down in Northern and in Southern India.85

ƒÄpastamba quotes, besides the Saihit≈´s, the BrƒÅlmanas very frequently (e. g., I. 1.1, 10-11, 1.1.3.9, I. 1. 3. 26, I. 2.7.7, 1. 2. 7. 11, I. 3. 10,8), He quotes the VƒÅjasaneyaka (1. 5. 17. 31 ) and the VƒÅjasaneyi-brƒÅhmana (I. 4. 12. 3 on sv√§dhyƒÅya), he speaks of the Upani≈üads (II. 2. 5. 1), his quotations (II. 2. 3. 16-11. 2. 4.1-9) from the Tai.   1. Dharmas≈´tra of √Ñpastamba

I pointed out the discrepancy relying on the two sutras is printed. I thought that the word Chandas was printed inadvor tontly (before ‚ÄòKalpa’). There is a further inelegance. If the reading Chandah-kalpa be accepted, then the word Chandas is used in the same sentence in two senses viz. Veda and metro, Besides, VedƒÅngas are all related to the Vedas and Kalpa in the context of the enumeration of VedƒÅngas would only mean ritual of Vedic sacrifices’ and in Chandah-kalpa the word Chandas’ then would be redundant. He speaks of the six reigns of the Veda ( II. 4. 8. 10 ) and in the next s≈´tra enumerates Chandas, Kalpa, grammar, Jyoti≈üa, Nirukta, Siksa, (phonetics ) und Chandoviciti (metrics ), which are soven (SiksƒÅ boing probably intended to boincluded in grammar). There are passages in Apastamba which agree with the Nirukta, e. g. the definition of ƒÅcƒÅrya 16. He quotes the views of ten writers on dhurmu by name, viz. Eka (I. 6. 19.7), Kanva (1.6.19.3 and I. 10. 28. 1), KƒÅpva (I. 6. 19.7 ), Ku≈Üika (1. 6. 19.7), Kutsa (I. 6. 19.7), Kautsa (I. 6. 9.4 and 7, 1. 10. 28. 1), PuskarasƒÅdi (I. 6. 19.7, 1. 10. 28. 1), VƒÅrsyƒÅyani (I. 6. 19, 5 and 8, 1. 10. 28.2), Svetaketu (I. 4. 13. 19 and 1.7, 5. 6), Harita (1. 4, 13, 11, 1, 6. 18. 2, 1. 6. 19. 12, 1. 10. 28,1, 5 and 16, 1. 10.29. 12 and 16). Some of the names (viz. Kautsa, V√§rsyƒÅyani, and PuskarasƒÅdi ) occur in the Nirukta. He quotes the view of Svetaketu in ≈õvetaketu’s own words ( in I. 4. 13. 20 ) that even a married man should every year stay with his teacher for two months to refresh his studies and gives it as his own opinion that Svetaketu’s view is opposed to the ≈†ƒÅstras (the Vedas). In another place (I. 1. 4. 5-6 ) le speaks of Svetaketu as an avara (a person belonging to later ages ) and as one who on account of the remnant of his merito rious actions done in it foriner life or lives was able to grasp the four Vedas in a short time. It is usual to see in this a reference to Svetaketu in the ChƒÅndogya Upani≈üad ( VI. 1. 1-2), where it is stated that Svetaketu mastered all the Vedas in twelve years. But this identification is somewhat of doubtful value. Apastamba: quotes Svetaketu as a teacher of dharma. The quotation from Svetaketu given by ƒÄpastamba has nothing corresponding to it in the Upani≈üad. Besides, the ChƒÅndogya Upanisad appears to Diake a distinction between two Svetaketus ( in VI. I and VI. 8). one being called ƒÄru≈Üeya and the other ƒÄrupi ( son of Arunak 3o Araiagaita 31714: ' 3719. 9. I. 1.1, 14 ; ‘31191g: AH

geri geta sirgarquiangala gira ET’ Ti 1.4 and TORTA THIE : ( quoted in the Fi II. 3.)History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

H√§rsta, whose views are cited:so frequently, is quoted by BaudhƒÅ yana (II. 1. 50 ) and also by Vasistha (II. 6.). From the two s≈´tras (1.6.19.3 and 7 ) it follows that Kanya and Kanva are two distinct writers. The Kumbhakonam edition reads KƒÅ≈Üva in I. 10. 28. 1, while B√ºhler reads Kanva there. KƒÅ≈Üva BodhƒÅyana is a teacher, whose name occurs in the r≈üitar pana in many works. The view ascribed to KƒÅnva by Apastamba in I.6.19.7 seems to bo the same as that of the BaudhƒÅyana-dharmas≈´tra (I. 2. 1987). It has been shown above that there are close parallels in thought and oxpression between BaudhƒÅyana and Apastamba. In several places Apastamba seems to be controverting the views of BaudhƒÅyana or similar views held by others. ƒÄpastamba condemns the view of giving the paternal wealth to the eldest son as opposed to the Vedas and explains the Vedic text (Tai. S. II. 5.2.7, quoted above ) about the eldest son being endowed with all wealth as a

nere anuvƒÅda and not a vidhi (vide Ap. Dh. S. II. 6. 14. 6-13). Baudhayana cites both the texts of the Tai. S. about equal division among sons and about the oldest son’s larger share and seems to favour the latter view by putting it last (11. 2. 2-7). Similarly, the discussion in Apastamba (I. 1. 4. 5-12 ) about it brahmac≈´rin eating the leavings (ucchi≈üta ) of his guru, provided the things are not directly forbidden by Sruti, soons to be directed against BaudhƒÅyana (II. 1. 25-26). Although ƒÄ.pastamba does not expressly quote Gautama, he appears to have had before him the Gautama-dharma-s√ºtra. He speaks of it smrti (II. 6. 15. 25) that lays down that upunayana confers rulhilcƒÅra on a man for sastric actions and that before upanayan ono is free to do any thing and to eat anything, This, as inter preted by Haradatta, refers to Gautama (II. 1). There are striking coincidences between Gautama and √Ñpastamba, 0, $. Gaut. I. 19. = Ap. I. 1. 1. 41 (about some teachers prescribing the yellow robe to a brahmacƒÅrin), Gaut. I. 3 = Ap. 11. 6. 13.7 ( about the violation of dharma by the great in fornier ages ), (Gaut. 9. 52 = Ap. I. 11. 31. 13, Gaut. 23. 9. = Ap. 1. 9. 25. 2; Gaut, 16. 19 = Ap. I. 3.9. 14-15 ). Apastamba frequently refers to the views of his predecessors in the words ‘eke’ (I. 1.2.

. Dhurmasƒ´tra of ƒÄpustandu.

37, 38, 41;1. 1. 4. 17; I. 2. 5. 20; I. 2. 6. 4. , I. 3. 9.3, I. 3. 11. 3 &c.) and aparam' (II. 6. 15. 22 ). It is somewhat remarkable that in many of these cases (where ‘eke’ occurs ), the views are those either held by Gautama or ascribed by him also to others, e. g. ƒÄp. I. 1. 2. 38 about the staff of a brahmac≈´rin refers to Gaut. I. 23; ƒÄp. I. 1. 2. 41 is almost same as Gant. I. 19, Ap. I. 2. 5. 20 seems to refer to Gaut. 1, 54-59, Ap. 1.3. 9. 3 (the view of some that Vedic study lasts for four months and a half) seems to refer to Gaut. 16. 2, and Ap. 1.3.11. 3 (about not studying after dining at a sacrifice for deities that are manusya-prakrti) pointedly refers to Gaut. 16. 34 which contains the word ‘manusyayaj√±abhojana’. Apastamba twice quotes verses from a PurƒÅ≈Üa (I. 6. 9. 13, II. 9. 23. 3) and in one place gives in prose the view of a Purana (1. 10. 29.7.)89. ƒÄpastamba (II. 9. 24. 6) speaks of the view of a Bhavisyat purƒÅna ( about creation of the world after a periodic dissolution). In one place Apastamba (II. 11. 29. 11-12 ) says that the knowledge that exists (traditionally ) among women and s≈´dras is the furthest limit of vidy≈´ and it is said to be a supplement of the Atharvaveda.' Here he probably refers to Artha≈õƒÅstra, which according to the caranavyuha, is the Upaveda of the Atharva veda. ƒÄpastamba refers (II. 7. 16. 1) to Manu as founder of the institution of ≈õrƒÅddha. But this appears to be a reference to Manu, the mythical progenitor of mankind, and not to the Manusmrti. It is noteworthy that ƒÄpastamba (II. 7. 17. 8) quotes a verse, which is the same as Anu≈°ƒÅsanaparva 90. 46 ( sambhojani n√§ma &c.).

The Apastambadharmas≈´tra stands in a peculiar relation to the P≈´rvamimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ. It is the only extant Dharmas√ºtra that contains many of the technical terms and doctrines of the MimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ. He says (I. 1. 4.8)' a positive Vedic text is more cogent than an usage which merely leads to an inforence (of its being based on a Vedic text now lost 90 ). This refers to Jaimini’s rule (I. 3. 3)” if there is a conflict between an express Vedic

. 1. 10. 29, 7; this seems to be a summary of a verse like the one in BaudhƒÅyana ( Dh. S. I. 10, 12 ) and Vasistha (III. 18) i nto

19.17

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

text and Smrti, the latter is to be disregarded : but if there be no confliot an inference (may be made that the Smrti is based upon some Sruti)”. In another place ƒÄpastamba says (1. 4. 12. 11 ) ‘where an action is done on account of finding pleasure therefrom (i. e. from a worldly motive ), there is no ( inference of its being based on ) Sastra’. This is the same as Jaimini’s teaching (IV. 1. 2 )’. He speaks of the convention (samy) of those who know NyƒÅya (i. e. MimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ ) that angas ( such as the Kalpas≈´tras are ) cannot be designated the Vedas ( which are the principal), which is clearly a reference to PurvamimƒÅlisa (1. 3. 11-14)‚Äù and he says that those who know NyƒÅya lay down that a mere unur≈´da (affirming or reciting) of what is well known to all is not a positive rule ( a vidhi ), which is similar to Jaimini’s rule93. The dictum of ƒÄpastamba that the word “sale” (kraya ) applied to a bride in some Vedic texts is merely figura tive closely resembles Jaimini’s94 remarks on the same point.

The remark of ƒÄpastamba that the rules of anadhyƒÅya only apply to Vedic study and not to the recital of mantras at sacri fices corresponds to a rule in Jaimini’s almost in the same words. These examples show that in ƒÄpastamba’s day MimƒÅ msƒÅ doctrines had been far advanced and that works existed that dealt with MimƒÅmsƒÅ topics (NyƒÅyas ). The correspondence in language with the P√ºrvamƒ´mƒÅmsƒÅs≈´tra is so close that one is tempted to advance the view that ƒÄpastamba knew the extant MimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ-s≈´tra or an earlier version of it that contained almost the same expressions. It cannot be said that all these passages are later interpolations. They have all been explained by Haradatta and one of the s√ºtras referring to MimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ topics ocours in so early a work as the commentary of Visvar≈´pa (on YƒÅj. 1. 7) who quotes ‚Äú BrƒÅhmanoktƒÅ vidhaya·∏•" &c. ( ƒÄp. I. 4. 12. 10). The last passage is quoted by MedhƒÅtithi also (on Manu II. 6).

  1. Dharmas≈´tra of Apastamba

65

The dharmas≈´tra of ƒÄpastamba has been quoted from very ancient times as authoritativo. Sabara in his bhƒÅsya on Jaimini VI. 8. 18 quotes one s≈´tra of ƒÄpastamba and a paraphrase of another. 96. The TantravƒÅrtika refers to the s≈´tras of Apa stamba about local and family usages, 97 about drinking wine and about the conflict between the views of BaudhƒÅyana and Apastamba (vide above page 46 also ). SankarƒÅcƒÅrya in his bhƒÅsya on Brahmag≈´tra IV. 2. 14 quotes ƒÄpastamba I. 7. 20. 3 (about the planting of trees for fruit as a meritorious act and the collateral benefits of shade and fragrance ). He also cites (on Brahmas≈´tra II. 1. 1. ) about the Supreme Soul a half verss from Apastamba (I. 8. 23. 2) 98. In his bhƒÅsya on Brhad aranyaka, he cites Ap. Dh. S. I. 5. 15. 1 (upƒÅsane gurunam &c.). Ap. Dh. S.. (II. 9. 23. 3-5) quotes from a Purana two verses which are very similar to two verses quoted by SankarƒÅcƒÅrya in his Bhasya on Chan. Up. V. 10. 1. Visvarupa on Yai. III. 252 refers to one verse and a half quoted by Apastamba (I.9.25. 11 Tri. ed.) and explains it. The two patalas of Apastamba (I.8. 22 and 23 ) dealing with adhyƒÅtma (philosophy ) were commented upon by SankarƒÅcƒÅrya, who, from the general style and method of the commentary (vide Trivandrum edition of the adhyat mapatala) seems to be the same as the great ƒÅcƒÅrya. Sure≈õvara in his VƒÅrtika (I. 1. 97) on Sankara’s bh≈´sya on the Brha dƒÅra·πáyakopani≈üad quotes the s≈´tra about the planting of mango ( ƒÄpastamba I. 7. 20. 399) troos. Vi≈õvar≈´pa, who according to Madhava, was the the same as Suresvara,100 quotes (Trivandrum edition) in his commentary on YƒÅj√±avalkya (ƒÅcƒÅra and vyavahƒÅra only) Apastamba’s s≈´tras about twenty times. The quotations show that the text of Apastamba was identical with the 96 " ‡§Ø‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‘‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ö ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø, ‘‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§®‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡•á

‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É.. 99 ‡§Ü‡§®‡•á ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§•‡•à ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§É‡•§ ‡§´‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®,

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

one printed, barring a few variations that are no more than mere slips on the part of the soribes of Mss. In his commentary on YƒÅj. III. 237 Visvar≈´pa quotes eighteen s≈´tras of ƒÄpagtamba (I. 9.24. 6-23) consecutively which are the same as those in the printed text. MedhƒÅtithi quotes ƒÄpastamba II. 5. 11. 2, II. 4. 7. 16, II. 8. 19, 20, 1. 4. 14. 30-31 on Manu II. 247, III. 102, III, 273 and VIII 357 respectively and appears to refer to ƒÄpastamba I. 4. 13. 6 (about “om”) on Manu II. 83. The MitƒÅk≈üarƒÅ has several quotations and AparƒÅrka contains about two hundred s≈´tras of ƒÄpastamba, though rather in a mutilated form. But it is not necessary to refer to these and other later works in detail, since Haradatta’s commentary, as will be shown later on, was written about the time of AparƒÅrka. Thus from the days of Sabara ( 400 A. D. at the latest) to 1100 A. D. we have a host of writers who youch for the authenticity of the extant text of ƒÄpastamba.

About the home and personal history of Apastamba little is known. Apastamba is not an ancient name. It does not occur in the Vedic texts. It occurs in the gana ‚ÄúBidƒÅdi" in PƒÅ·πáini IV.1. 104. Dr. Ram Gopal (on p. 75 of his work ) thinks rather naively that the occurrence of @pastamba’s name in the BidƒÅdigana iends some support to the view that ƒÄpastamba is earlier than PƒÅ·πáini. The Bidadi-gana has nothing to do with literary works, but is concerned only with the addition of a termination to the words in the gana in the sense of (gotrƒÅpatya) * a descendant from grandson downwards but not a son’. Bida’s

son would be Baidi, but his grandson would be Baida. Besides, this gana contains about fifty words in the GanapƒÅtha now available. ƒÄpastamba is the 14th in the list. Moreover, the ganas are liable to be added to as illustrated by what is said above on KambojƒÅdigana. Besides, the mere occurrence of the word Apastamba in the BidƒÅdi-gana does not convey that the person mentioned is the author of the Gphya or Dharma-s≈´tra known now as ƒÄpastamba’s. All that can be held to follow from the BidƒÅdi-gana is that a person named Apastamba and his descendants named after him were known at the time. He speaks of himself as belonging to later ages (avara). Vide ƒÄpastamba 101 I. 2. 5. 4. and II. 6. 13. 9. In the tarpana he is generally mentioned after BodhƒÅyana and before SatyƒÅsƒÅdha Hirapyake≈õin

(vide note 68a above). Therefore according to tradition his school was elder or more authoritative than that of Hipamyakesin In one place Apastamba refers to a peculiar ≈õrƒÅddha ustige of 101 Heralsang app THAT ARE ' and ‘prenatay and car: ‘.

POOM

. Dharmus≈´tra of Aprastambu

67

the udicyas (II. 7. 17. 17 ).102 Apastamba must be supposed to have embodied in his work tha usages of his own country. If he specially mentions the usages of a particular locality, it would follow that he did not hail from that looality. But the exact meaning of “Udicya” is doubtful. Haradatta quotes a verse of the grammarians, according to which the Country north of the Saravati was called “Udicya‚Äù. According to the MahƒÅr≈Üava quoted in the commentary on the Caranavy≈´hata the Apastambiyas were to be found to the south of the Narmada, in the south-east, that is, in Andhra and the territory about the mouth of the Godavari. Therefore it is natural to suppose that ƒÄpastamba’s school had its origin in the south and probably in

ƒÄndhra.

Now that rather puerile arguments have been advanced by Dr. Ram Gopal about the home of ƒÄpastamba, BaudhƒÅyana and Hiranyak…ôsin (on pp. 96-100), a more thorough reply is given here by reference to numerous grants and inscriptions,

Dr. Ram Gopal does not bother about inscriptions and copper plate grants. I had referred in the first edition (of 1930 ) to Pallava grants in general and mentioned a specific one in I. A. Vol. V, p. 155. In that grant five out of the eight donees

102

TTET Fanarti atitra 1991; on this GR reads a verse of the grammarians viz. druga fata : sfruta de Tui fait TATU #1 : Ta srcaret and adds moi vari camera congratai

harrari. Homidri in matracararo (III. 1. p. 1350 ) quotes the same Apastamba s≈´tra and the Verse arua &c but reads Forrit for it. Is strat the modern RƒÅpti, & tributary of the Saray≈´ or is it turi near Honavar in north Canara or any other rlver ? This verse occurs in the K√§sik√§ on Pan 1. 1. 75. PƒÅ·πáini in VI, 3, 120 explains the word SarƒÅvati as meaning abounding in reeds, which may be applicable to many rivers, Dr. Ram Gopal, after referring to the different Identifications, made by various scholars (pp. 95-96). finds that in the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa ( II. 68. 13-16) occurs a river called SaradandƒÅ and at once jumps to the conclusion that Saradanda’conveys

almost the same sense as Saravati’ (p. 96). Saravati is formed from sara with affix ‘matup. ' Has’ danda’ the same sense as matup’? I should like to know where it is so stated. The usual meanings “danda’ are a staff, army, punishment or fine., and one of the ffur upƒÅyas in RƒÅjaniti. One should like to know how Saradanda (willele is a compound word having two separate nouns) can have the sapien sense as SarƒÅvati (which is forined by a noun and an allis vetup. Stition a

(2) There is another grant earlier than the above (of 4th century A. D.) viz. the Gorantla plates of king Attivarman edited in I. A. vol. IX. pp. 102-3, in which the donee Kottisarman described as ' ƒÄpastambhas≈´tra- Ra-yajus-s√£mavide.

(7) Charter of Pallava king Narasimha - varman II (about 711 A. D.) in Sanskrit but in early Telugu, Kannada characters and the donge is described as a student of Apa stambas≈´tra, of Rathitara gotra named KumƒÅramanda≈õarƒ±nan.

All these are specially cited by me for ƒÄpastambhiyas as donees, Now about BodhƒÅyana ( BaudhƒÅyana). It has been seen above that BodhƒÅyana is called ‘pravacanakƒÅra’ in the passages on tarpana (vide note 68 a above) and hence in some early grants the donees are describod as students of Pravacana or Pravacana sutra or-carana or-Kalpa, though in the South Indian records from the 11th century A. D. and onwards the BaudhƒÅyana-s≈´tra does occur.

(1) Sringeri plates of Avinƒ´ta (circa 495-555 A. D.) in Mysore Arch. Rep. 1916 pp. 34-35, where two of three donees are students of Pravacana-kalpa ;

(2) Bangalore Residency Plates of Western Ganga king Avinita (c. 495-555 A, D.) in Mys. Arch. Rep. 1911;

(3) Uttan√ºr plates of Durvinita (Mys. Arch. Ron 1416), where 48 brƒÅhma·πáas of Taittiriya-oarana and Pravdane Ana stamba-g√ºtra are mentioned.
