1917

ht. Dharmas≈´tra of Apastamba

(4) and (5) Guminareddipura Plates of Durvinita (circae 555-605 A. D.) in Mys. Arch. Rep. 1912 pp. 31-32 ) and Nallala Grant of Durvinita (Mys. Arch. Rep. 1924 p. 70 ) where donees are of pravacana-kalpa.

(6) Al√ºr grant of Yuvaraja NƒÅrasimha (c. 800 A. D.), Mys. Arch, Rep. 1924 p. 75) where doneo is of Pravacana-Kalpa.

(7) UdƒÅyendiram grant of Pallava king Nandivarman, 8th century A. D. (E. I. Vol. III. pp. 145 ff) issued from KƒÅ√±ci-pura to the donee of Pravacanas√ºtra named Kula≈°arman.

(8) Raykota plates of Skandaƒ£isya (E. I. Vol. V. pp. 49 f (about 9th century A. D.). The donee is Madhava≈°arma of the Vatsagotra and of the Pravacanas≈´tra.

A comparative statement of the students of the sutras ( ƒÄpastamba, BodhƒÅyana, Hiranyakeƒüin ) from a few grants will be extremely instructive :

  1. In the Udayendiram plates (of 8th century A. D.) of Nandivarman Pallavamalla in S. I. I. Vol. II, pp. 361 f thoro are 39 donees of Ap. S≈´tra, 16 of Pravacanas≈´tra and 4 Babyr cas (Rgvedins). The number of donees actually named is 59, though on p. 368 it is stated that the donees were 108.

  2. In the Tandau≈£tottam Pallava plates of 8th century A. D. in $. I. I. Vol. II. pp. 517ff, among the 244 donoes, 139 are ƒÄpastambiyas, 24 of the Pravacanas≈´tra, 2 of ƒÄgnivesyas≈´tra, 1 of AsvalƒÅyana.

  3. In the grant of Eastern CƒÅlukya NarendramrgarƒÅja 9th century A. D. (8. I. I. Vol. I. pp. 31ff ), of the 24 donees, 18 are Apastamblyas, 6 are Hira·πáyake≈õins (but these latter are mention ed first ).

  4. In the unpublished Karandai plates of Chola King Rajendra I (1019-20 A. D.), out of 1080 donees, about 620 are ƒÄpastambiyas, 55 BaudhƒÅyaniyas, 42 SatyƒÅsƒÅdha (i. e. Hiranya kesins). Vide Annual Report on Indian Epigraphy for 1949-50 pp. 3 and 17 No. 57. The grant consists of 55 plates falling in three groups. The first group is of three plates entirely in Sanskrit written in grantha characters. It gives the king’s genean logy and records the gift of the village Tribhuvana-mahƒÅdex agrahƒÅra to a number of brƒÅhmanas. Second group of 52 platos lo in Tamil language, gives details of lands included in the villages the boundaries of the village and the officials connected with the

History of Dharma≈õ√ºstra grant. The third group of 30 plates also in Tamil merely contains the names of the brƒÅlima≈Üa donees of the village.

The age of the ƒÄpastamba-dharmas≈´tra can be settled within only approximate limits. It is probably later than the Gautaina Dharma-sutra and also the BaudhƒÅyayana dharmasutra and before 400 A. D. it was an authoritative smrti work according to Sabara. ƒÄpastamba is enumerated by YƒÅj√±avalkya as a writer on dharma (1. 5) and by Sankha-Likhita. Its grammar which often deviates from Panini leads one to infer that he flourished a little before or immediately after PƒÅnini. As he quotes the views of ten writers on Dharma ≈õƒÅstra he cannot be placed amongst the early writers on Dharma. It is doubtful whether the provision that one should not take food from a Sargha can be taken to refer to Buddhist sangha. PƒÅ·πáini employs the word sangha in several s≈´tras (IV. 3. 127, V. I. 58, V. 2.52 ), but in all these there is no clear indication of the ideas attached to the Buddhist Sangha. Ap. Dh. S. I. 6. 18. 31 (avidhinƒÉ ca pravrajita·∏•) provides that one should not take food from one who has become an ascetic without observing the rules about entering that order. This does not necessarily mean that he refers to Buddhist and Jain monks. As Sannyasa became popular many must have pretended to be sannyƒÅsins without first observing the rules for entering that order. The ƒÄp. Dh. 8. was probably composed at a time when the MimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ system had already been founded. Hence if a tolerably definite period is demanded, then the ƒÄp. Dh, 8. should have to be assigned to the period of 450-350 B, C, and not 600-300 B.C. (as in the first edition).

On p. 84 of the first edition I tried to explain why we have a complete set of srauta, gƒºhya and dharma s≈´tras for Baudhi yana and others (all belonging to the K»ôspa-yajurveda) and why an A≈õvalƒÅyana-dharmag≈´tra for Rgvedins and Gobhila dharmas≈´tra for sƒÅmavedins or PƒÅraskara (or KƒÅtiya ) Dharma. s≈´tra for Sukla Yajurveda had not coine down to us. Dr. Ram Gopal would not miss an opportunity to criticize the H. of Dh. as he does on pp. 51-52. I have had often to show in this edition the worth of his research.

But on the subject of ƒÄpastamba’s home which he holds to have been in North India his remarks display the tantastic nature of some of his researches. He relies on fom, pietas of internal evidence to corroborate his view that Apastakaba - home was in the North. First, he renarks ' a number of words which

POONA

190

  1. Dharmas≈´tra of Apastamba

71

aro of rare occurrence in Sanskrit and which are peculiar to the s≈´tras of ƒÄpastamba are current even now in the language which is spoken in Kuru-Pa√±cƒÅla and its neighbourhood.' He cites p. 96 only two words, viz. ghola (a horse ) and bhayedala (dangerous or furious ram), both from Ap. Srauta (XV. 3. 12 and XV. 19. 4 respectively) ‘ƒÅjyasthƒÅlim rauhi≈ÜakapƒÅle ca parima≈Üdale-ghota-prakƒÅre’ ƒÄp. ≈ör. XV. 3. 12 and ‘atha yadi grdhra·∏• salƒÅv≈ôki bhayedako dirgha-mukhyul≈´ko…sakunir ( Ap. XV. 19. 4). He cites no similar words from either the Grhyas≈´tra or Dharmas≈´tra of ƒÄp. He remarks ‚ÄòƒÄp. S.S. XV. 3. 12 employs the word Gho»õa to denoto a horse, and the word Tist is used in Hindi in the same sense’. His idea appears to be (though he does not make a very clear statement ) that as Hindi is now spoken in what was called Kuru-Pa√±cƒÅla in ancient times and Hindi-speaking people use the word ghodƒÅ (for horse ) now, the ancient Ap. ≈ö. S. which employs the word gho»õa in the same sense should be regarded as composed in north India. Research means careful endeavour and inquiries to discover facts by the scientific study of a subject. If Dr. Ram Gopal had inquired of non-Hindi people in Delhi such as Bengalis, Gujaratis and MahƒÅrƒÅstrians (of whom large numbers are now residents of Delhi) he would have found that all these groups of people employ the same word for a horse respectively in Bengali, Gujarati and Marathi. If he had referred to the Amarako≈õa 1026 he would have found that ghotaka is held by that comparatively early work as a synonym of a≈õva ( ghotake viti-turaga-turanga svaturangamƒÅ·∏•). If he had carried his inquiries further he would have found that the Kamasutra 1026 of VƒÅtsyƒÅyana (in I. 1.4) mentions a predecessor named Gho»õakamukha, who wrote . work on KanyƒÅsamprayuktakƒÅdhikarana and who was so called probably because he had a long neck like that of a horse. In the Artha≈õƒÅstra of Kautilya the name ‘Ghota-mukha’is cited in V.5.11 as that of a minister. Ghotaka or ghota therefore looks anoient enough as a purely Sanskrit word. An eminent epigra.

102 a The Amarakosa cannot be placed later than the 5th century A. D, and

may be a century or two earlier, Vide H. of Dh, Vol. V. p. 840 note 1367 for authorities,

102 b The Kamasutra is assigned to the 4th century A, D. by Winternitz in

History of Indian Literature, Vol. III ( 1922, Gernan) p. 540 and Mr. II. C. Chakladar in Asutosh Mookerji Silver Jubilee Vol. III IT holds that it should be placed in the middle of the 3rd cotton A.D.; so the author Ghotakamukba would liave to be placed Desi about the first century A, D., if not earlier.

MORA

FOUNDE

191772

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

phist who knows all the south Indian languages informs me that the linguists regard the word as Dravidian and connect it with Telugu gurramu and Kannada Kudire or kudure. If the word ghota be Dravidian, Dr. Ram Gopal’s argument would recoil on him like a boomerang. The same reasoning applies to the word ‘bhayedaka’( bhayahetubh≈´tah adakah, & dangerous ram). That word is compounded of bhaya ( danger) and edaku (ram ). The word ‘bhaya’ by itself occurs even in the Rgveda at least a dozen times and otaka means ‘ram’ according to Amarako≈õa 102 , Me≈üa is a synonym of ‘edaka’ and both these words occur in the present day Marathi. Edaka is one of the three unclean (amedhya ) animals acc. to Sat. Br. XII. 4. 1. 4. Edaka is the 2nd word in ‘ajƒÅdi-gana’ (‘ajƒÅdyata≈ütƒ±p’ PƒÅn. IV, 1.4). When PƒÅ·πáini mentions a gana with ƒÅdi it must be presumed that at least the first three of the words in the gana were known to him, though we know that in some ganas somo words were inserted later. Following the reasoning of Dr. Ram Gopal one may as well say that ƒÄpastamba’s home was in Mabarastra where both words (ghodƒÅ and edakƒÅ) are found in the people’s speech and the latter word at least was known before PƒÅ·πáini. Both these words were regarded as Sanskrit in the centuries before and after the Christian era by lexicogra phers and odaka was known many centuries before Christ, when there was no Hindi language in existence at all. This argument of Dr. Ram Gopal, it would be seen, is ridiculous and worthless.

On p. 97 Dr. Ram Gopal relies, for propping his hypothesis that Apastamba came from the north on certain phonetic tendencies that characterize modern Hindi. He instances only one word viz. Sik≈üƒÅ (in ƒÄp. Dh. S. II. 4. 8. 11) which is one of the six VedƒÅngas and compares it with Hindi ‘sikha’. This is on a par with his reliance on ghotaka and adaka referred to above. Sikha in Hindi means to learn or a pupil, while ≈öƒ´ksƒÅ or ≈öik·π£ƒÅ is a name for a Veƒë√£nga and ≈õikha in the sense to learn’ is derived from the root siksa (to learn, ‘Siksate ‘) and

sikba’ (pupil) is derived from ‘sisya’. I feel grave doubts whether Dr. Ram Gopal is aware of the real technical meaning of ‘SiksƒÅ’ or Sik≈üƒÅ’ occurring in the Upani≈üads and other ancient works. Vide note 85 a above where the Tai. Up. employs the dirgha’i in Sik≈üƒÅ and briefly enumerates the subjects of that vedƒÅnga and ƒÄp. belonging to the Kr≈°≈Üa Yajured, uses the word as ≈öik·π£ƒÅ but Mupdaka employ, ≈õik·π£ƒÅ. Vid the samo note.)

FOUNDED

1917

  1. Dharmas≈´tra of Apastamba

73

It was probably written at a time when Jaimini had founded his school. Hence we shall not be far wrong if we assign it to some period between 600-300 B. C. On several points his views are opposed to those of his predecessors, e.g. he rejects secondary sons, condemns niyoga, does not admit PaisƒÅca and PrƒÅjƒÅpatya as valid forms of marriage (vido above page 50). There aro other points also wherein ƒÄpastamha differs from Gautama and the other s≈´trakƒÅras. Gautama (IV. 14-17) and BaudhƒÅyana (I. 8. 7-12 ) give long lists of mixed castes and Gautama includes Yavana among them. ƒÄpastamba is silent on this point. But this has hardly any bearing on chronology. Even the Vedic works mention the Nisada and the P≈´rvainimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅs≈´tra has a special adhikarana (VI. 1. 51 ) devoted to him; the Br. Upani≈üad Inentions (IV.3. 22 and 37 ) such castes as C√§ndƒÅla, and the GitƒÅ mentions the ≈õvapƒÅka. The Ap. Srauta speaks of the Ni≈ü≈´da (9, 14. 12-13). The √Ñp. Dh. S. (11. 1. %. 6) mentions C√¢ndƒÅla, Paulkasa and Vai≈Üa. Gautama (17. 30 ) forbids the eating of the flesh of cows and bulls, while Ap. (I. 5. 7. 30-31 ) seems to allow it and cites the VƒÅjasaneyaka for support. In this connection it has to be noted that Vasistha also has a similar s≈´tra (14. 46). ƒÄp. (I. 9. 27. 10) prescribes a penance for one who practises usury and lays down that one should not eat at the usurer’s (I. 6. 18. 22 ), while Gautama appears to allow usury to a BrƒÅhmana as a calling if done through an agent (X. 6). BaudhƒÅyana, on the other hand, quotes verses that condemn usury in strong language as even worse than brahma hatyƒÅ, holds that a BrƒÅhma·πáa who is a usurer should be treated as a s√ºdra and allows the first two castes to practise usury only towards atleists, ≈°≈´dras and such like persons (I. 5. 79-81). So these differences of Ap. from others are hardly conclusive as to his chronological position.

Dr. Ram Gopal on p. 75 of his work refers to the fact that I place ƒÄpastamba between 600 B. O. and 300 B. O. (on p. 45 of H. Dh. vol. I), and then remarks that'(he) adduces no cogont arguments in support of his view' and then patronizingly adds * It is not possible in the present state of researches into Vedic literaturo, to assign precise dates to individual s≈´trakƒÅras and we at the most determine approximately the lower and uppor limits of the s≈´tra period. We are, therefore, not going to discuss here the possibility of assigning dates to individual authors'. I am going to show that he himself adduces hus.se cogent arguments' for the dates he assigns. In the first place,

H.D. - 10

1917

Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute

History of Dharƒ±natastra

period between 600 B. O. to 300 B, C. (to whioh I assigned Apastamba ) is not, I hope it will be admitted by most people, a precise date at all and is far more unprecise than what Dr. Ram Gopal would assign to him (as I am going to point out below from his own work). On p. 89 of his work Dr. Rani Gopal remarks ‘inost of the s≈´tras were composed betweon circa 800 B. C. and 500 B. C. From the general words employed by him on p. 90 it appears to be his view that not only the Srauta and G»ôhya s≈´tras but other s≈´tras also and Dharmas≈´tras were composed between 800 B. O. to 500 B. C. On p. 84 of his work he mentions four groups of s≈´tras ( srauta, gphya and dharma). He himself says that all the sitras belonging to the 4th group seem to be later than the beginning of the Christian era’. This group should be omitted from consi. deration. The first group contains 11 s≈´tra works (Srauta, Grhya and Dharma), the 2nd group contains 10 s≈´tra works (all except Ap. Dh. S. being either Srauta or Gphya). The third group contains eight works, all either Srauta or Grhya except Vasistha Dh. S., of which only the s≈´tra portion (and not verses) is included in this group. He regards all the s≈´tras in group one and most of those in group 2 as earlier than PƒÅ·πáini. The main prop of his dates for the three classes of s≈´tras is Papini’s date. On p. 86 he states that divergent views have been expressed by eminent scholars about PƒÅ·πáini’s date ranging from 7th century B. O. to 4th century B. C. In this welter of diffe ring views Dr. Ram Gopal fixes the dats of PƒÅnini at about 600 B.C-550 B.O (p. 88). What is the strony evidence on which he relies for this date? It is only this that he holds Pata√±jall'. date to be 150 B. C. and affirms that there is a near unanimity among scholars about this date. Then he conjectures (pp. 87-88) that a period of at least two centuries intervened between Pata√±jali and KatyƒÅyana (the author of the vƒÅrtikas on PƒÅ·πáini) and that another period of at least 200 years must be held to separate KƒÅtyƒÅyana and PƒÅ·πáini (pp. 87-88). My aim is only to show how large a part conjectures play in these dates of KatyƒÅyana and Panini. Taking, however, for the moment these conjectures as good arguments, three groups of s≈´tra works ( 29 in all) set out by Dr. Ram Gopal have to be squeezed into a period of three hundred years, the third group being later than the second and the 2nd group later than first. For all the three groups the total period allotted is 300 years (807 B to 500 B. C.). The first group is the largest and it would to be unjust to say that the largest group (viz. the first ) should be

1917

[

  1. Dharmas≈´tra of Apastamba

75

allotted 125 years (out of 300 ), that is, the first group flourished between 800 B. O. to 675 B. C. according to Dr. Ram Gopal, tbe 2nd group may be allotted 100 years (i. e. 675-575 B.C.) and the third group of only 8 works may be assigned 75 years i. e. from 575 B C to 500 B. O, The Srauta, Gphya and Dharma s√ºtras of Apastamba are placed in the 2nd group by Dr. Ram Gopal i. A. Apastamba himself is placed between 675 B.C.-575 B.C. by him. It would be noticed that this dating of the learned Doctor for Apastamba is far more precise than my date for √Ñpastamba (on p. 45 of vol. I of H. Dh.) viz. 600 B. O, to 300 B, C. While saying that it is impossible to assign precise dates to individual sutrakƒÅras and professing not to give precise dates to them, he puts the authors of ten s≈´tra works within the short span of about 100 years and assigns individual authors of the 2nd group of the B≈´tra works to the period from about 675 B. C. to 575 B.C. Scholars will note the great disparity that Dr. Ram Gopal exhibits between his precepts and his performance.

This is not the place to discuss at length the dates of Patanjali and PƒÅ·πáini. But a few words must be said on account of the importance attached to those dates by some scholars in settling the chronology of Dharmas≈´tra works. Dr. D. C. Siroar advances arguments for questioning the date 150 B: O. for Patanjali and himself holds that Patanjali flourished about 100 A. D. ( vide I. H. Q. Vol. 15 pp. 633-38). The date 150 B, C. for Pata√±jali is mainly based on MahƒÅbhƒÅsya reforences to Pu≈üyamitra (Sunga ruler between about 187 B. O. to 151 B. C.). On VƒÅrtika 7 to PƒÅ≈Üini I. 1.69 (svain r≈´pam etc.) the MahƒÅbh√§sya cites the instances of ‘Pusgamitrasabha’ and ‘Candraguptasabha;’ on VƒÅrtikas 3 and 4 on PƒÅ≈Ü. III. 1. 26 it cites (Pu≈üyamitro yajate yƒÅjakƒÅ pƒÅjayantiti tatra bhavitavyan Pusgamitro pƒÅjayate yƒÅjakƒÅ yajantiti…tam (tyƒÅgam ) ca Pusyamitrah karoti yajakƒÅ prayojayante). Again, on VƒÅrtika 1 on DƒÅn. III.2. 123 (vartam√°ne lag) the MahƒÅbbƒÅ≈üya says ‘iha Pu≈üyamitram yƒÅjayƒÅma·∏•’. There are several difficulties in the case of these passages. There are what are called in grammar ‘m≈´rdhƒÅbhi≈üikta’ exainples (i. e. stock examples ) not necessarily contemporaneous with the author but handed down traditionally. Patanjali himself speak’s of murdhabhi≈üiktam-udƒÅbara√±ain' (Kielhorn’s ed. Vol. 1. p. 144 on P√•n. I. 1. 57). In the very first passage ‘Candrannan tasabh√•’ is certainly such an example, since even if Patan att be assigned to 150 B.O., Candragupta flourished at least 1500 years before him and Pata√±jali could not have known it personal but

WOUNDED

History of Dharmu≈õ√§stra

only by tradition or hearsay. Then we have to keep in mind the vicissitudes through which, according to the V√°kyapadiya ( II. verses 484-490 ) of Bhartphari, the MalƒÅbhƒÅsya passed in the early centuries of the Christian era. It is narrated there that “Sangraha (a very extensive work on PƒÅ≈Üini’s grammar attributed to VyƒÅdi) was practically lost, that the great teacher Pata≈æƒ´jali composed a work called MahƒÅbhƒÅ≈üya containing the seeds of all nyƒÅyas, but persons with undeveloped intellects could not ascertain its import, that Baiji, Saubhava and Haryak≈üa flooded that work of the sage (viz. Pata√±jali) by following baseless reasonings. The traditional interpretation of (Sanskrit) grammar which slipped from the disciples of Pata√±jali remained in course of time among the southern people merely in the form of a work ( in Manuscripts). After securing the tradition from a mountain (in the south ) Caudr√£o√°rya and others following the essence of the bhƒÅ≈üya made it blossom forth in various ways.' 1026

The VƒÅkyapadiya is certainly not later than 600 A.D., though there are some scholars who place it not later than tho 3rd century A. D. (vide, for example, Shri Sadhu Ram in J. G. J. R. I. Vol. IX pp. 135-151). Whatever the date of the Vakya padiya, we cannot be certain that the present Mss. and editions of the MahƒÅbhƒÅsya represent an exact reproduction of wliat Pata√±jali composed. All that I want to emphasise is that we should not be cocksure about the date of the MahƒÅbh√§sya and not regard 150 B. C. as a certain date for Pata√±jali’s MahƒÅbhƒÅsya but should regard it only a possible or at the most a probable one.

Then as to the period of two centuries at least between Pata√±jali and K√§tyƒÅyana and between KatyƒÅyana and Panini suggested by Dr. Ram Gopal, I have to urge certain objections. PƒÅ·πáini’s family is said to have been living in Salatura in North West India (supposed to be mentioned in PƒÅ·πá. IV. 3. 94) and Panini is designated SalƒÅturlya by later classical writers like BhƒÅmaha ( in KavyƒÅlankƒÅra VI. 62-63). SalƒÅtura is identified by Cunningham in ‚ÄòAncient Geography of India' pp. 66-67 with Lahur, a small town north-west of Ohind in the angle

‡§™‡§§‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡•á ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•å‡§≠‡§µ ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§§‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§§‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡§∂‡§æ‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø II, verses 484-89.

1917

. Dharmas≈´tra of Apastamba

botween the Kabul river and the Indus. KƒÅtyƒÅyana (the author of VƒÅrtikas ) is supposed to have been a dƒÅk·π£i·πáƒÅtya on account of a rather jocular 112cl remark of the MahƒÅbhƒÅsya on the first VƒÅrtika. There were no printing presses in those days and works were propagated by means of oral transmission or by making inanuscripts and by the process of learned and ambitious writers visiting royal courts or rich men and pari≈üads or samitis. For example, in the Br. Up. Vi. 2 and ChƒÅndogya Up. (V. 3 )102e Svetaketu Aruneya is said to have repaired to the Pari≈üad or Samiti of the PancƒÅla people or country (between the foot of the HimƒÅlayas and the river YamunƒÅ) and a RƒÅjanya asked him five questions. Learned BrƒÅhmanas were a specially favoured class in ancient India. Learned works froin one part of BhƒÅrata spread quickly to even distant parts of the country in a short time on account of the visits of learned men to subhus patronized by kings, their ininisters and rich men. RƒÅjasekhara (about 900 A. D.) in his KƒÅvyaniinƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ (chap. XX pp. 54-55) gives valuable information. He says that the king should convenie asseinblios of poets and when the king is a poet all people becomo poets. The king should construct a hall for examining poems and that be should emulate 1021 (kings like ) VƒÅsudeva, SƒÅtavƒÅ hana, Sudraka, S√§hasƒÅnka and others (who presided over sabhƒÅs in their days ) by bestowing honours and gifts, that between itssemblies for discussions about poetic works he should order discussions in Sastras. The king should arrange meetings of brƒÅhma·πáas for exainining the worth of poetic and SƒÅstric works and quotes two verses, one referring to the examination of poets liko KƒÅlidƒÅsa and Bharavi in Ujjaiyini and the other referring to writers on S√§strus in P√§taliputra and uxpressly names Panini, VyƒÅ:li, Vararuci (KƒÅtyƒÅyana ) and Patanjali as having been examined. Thus there were even in ancient times means for rapid transmission of really valuable works to distant lands.

for his proposition that Katyayana is separated from Panini by at least two centuries (p. 87 ) Dr. Rain Gopal relias mainly

‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§§‡•á‡•§ 1020 Herist says " #371 TITEIT HATARRHEI 1026 ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§á‡§π ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏

History of Dharmastistra

on two circumstances viz. considerable change in Sanskrit idiom between PƒÅ·πáini’s time and KƒÅtyƒÅyana’s time and ( secondly ) much time must have passed before a grammar composed in Northwest India could become so popular as to induce an author from the South to compose VƒÅrtikas thereon. The first circums tance is worth little. Even in these days of the diffusion of primary education, daily newspapers, railways, radio progra mmes, a regional language like Marathi spoken in Berar and Khandesh varies in some details from the same language as spoken in Poona, Satara and the Konkan. The changos noted by KatyƒÅyana are not at all fundamental. P√§pini himnself refers to many differences and mentions by name ten predecos sors viz. Apisali (Vi. 1. 92), K√§syapa (1. 2. 25, VIII. 68). G√°rgya (VIII. 3. 20, VIII. 4. 67), GƒÅlava (VI. 3. 61, VIII. 4. 67). Cakravarma≈Üa (VI. I. 130), BhƒÅradvƒÅja (VII.2.63), SƒÅkatƒÅyana (III. 4. 111, VIII. 3. 18, VIII. 4. 50 ), Sakalya (1. 1. 16, VI. 1. 127, VIII. 37. 9, VIII. 4. 51 ), Senaka (V. 4. 112), SphotƒÅyana (VI. 1. 123). PƒÅ·πáini, moreover, refers to ‘ƒÄcƒÅryas’ in general in VII. 3, 49 and VIII. 4. 52. He also speaks of eastern ƒÅcƒÅryas in III. 4. 18 and northern ƒÅcƒÅryas in VI. 3. 32 (m√¢tara-pitara udicƒÅm ‘). This last citation shows that, though Panini cane himself from northwest India, Sanskrit was spoken even in tho Extreme north much beyond PƒÅ·πáini’s home and the people used the form ‘MƒÅtarapitarau ' instead of ‘MƒÅtƒÅpitarau’ as required by PƒÅ·πáini. This state of things existed even before PƒÅ·πáini in the time of YƒÅska, who states that the verbal forin Savati is used by the Kamboja people in the sense of ‘gati’, but only a derivative from it viz. saya·∏•’ is used by the Arya people (and not the verbal form ). This shows that in YƒÅsku’s time the Kambojas were not accepted as ƒÄryas, though their language was basically the same as that of the Aryas. 1028

Haradatta 102 he says what was not present to the mind of the S≈´trakƒÅra (Panini) or what was not noticed by him is clearly stated by the V√°kyakƒÅra (KatyƒÅyana ) and the Blasyak√°ra ( clearly states ) what was not noticed by the Vakyak√§ra. vƒÅrtika ‘Kamboja dibhyo lug-vacanam codƒÅdyartham’. Patan jali in his Bh√§sya specifies ‘Coda, Karlera and Kerala’ as the words included in KambojƒÅdi-gana but in the Ganapatha at the end of the Siddhantakaumudi (Nir, ed. of 1929 ) Saka and Yavana are further additions to the words of that gana. P√§nini dwelling in north-West India either forgot to include Cola (or Coda) and Kerala or did not know those names or it is possible that those nainos were first coined about the time of PƒÅ≈Üini or even after him but K√°tyƒÅyana coming later and being a southernor included Coun (or Cola) and Kerala. This shows how the Gana pƒÅtha ag now printed is not necossarily valid for PƒÅpini’s time,

The 2nd circumstance relied upon by Dr. Ram Gopal has been answered above by reference to the role of pari≈üads and by what kings should do and did in ancient India for the encoura gement and diffusion of Sanskrit literature,

Panini mentions ten predecessors by name, besides eastern und northern √£cƒÅryas. But KatyƒÅyana mentions only a few names such as Pau≈ükarasƒ´di (VƒÅrtika 3 on Pan. VIII, 4, 48 ), VƒÅjapyƒÅyana (VƒÅrtika 35 on PƒÅ·πá. I. 2. 64 ), VyƒÅdi (VƒÅrtika 45. on P√•n. I. 2. 64). I am aware that Pata√±jali notices different readings in the V√•rtikas (on which he comments) such as by the Saunigas (about 6 times) and by the BhiradvƒÅjiyas ( about ten times ). But considering the huge number 112i of VƒÅrtikas On the AstƒÅdbyƒÅyi this is a mere flea-bite. Similarly, it appears that a few VƒÅrtikas other than those of K√§tyƒÅyana existed in Patanjali’s day. Taking all these things into consideration, KƒÅtyƒÅyana may be said to have flourished one hundred years or at the most 150 years before Pata√±jali i. e. 300 B. C.-250 B. C., conceding for argument that Pata√±jali flourished about 150 B. C. But if Patanjali is held to have flourished in the first century A. D., KatyƒÅyana would have to be brought down to about 150 B.O. to 100 B.O.

If KƒÅtyƒÅyana is placed at about 300 B. C.-250 B, C. PƒÅniu should be placed at 450 B. C.-400 B. C.

PƒÅ·πáini’s s≈´tras themselves furnish some material to show that he did not flourish in the early phases of the s≈´tra period

but rather in the later phases of it. A few references to some of P√§nini’s s≈´tras on literary works and a few other matters will be helpful in arriving at a tentative date for PƒÅnini. PƒÅ·πáini says ‘PurƒÅ≈Üaprokte≈Üu brƒÅhmanakalpesu’ (IV. 3. 105), which means the affix nini is applied to BrƒÅhma·πáa works and Kalpa works, provided these are declared by ancient (inunis ). The oxamples are BhƒÅllavina·∏• and SƒÅtyƒÅyaninah from Bhallu and SatyƒÅyana. This clearly shows that in PƒÅ·πáini’s times there were sƒÅtra works both ancient and not ancient (i, e. composed nearer his time ).

According to PƒÅ·πáini IV. 3. 105 as it stands the termination nini would not apply to BrƒÅhmana works and Kalpas≈´tras that were not ancient. KƒÅtyƒÅyana adds a vƒÅrtika that ‘wini’ will not apply to YƒÅj√±avalkya’s and other BrƒÅhmanas though they are equally purƒÅ≈Üaprokta (and so we shall have ‘YajnavalkƒÅni’ and ‘SaulabhƒÅni’ BrƒÅhma·πáƒÅni. The KƒÅ≈õikƒÅ says that it is reported in the ƒÅkhyƒÅnas that YƒÅjavalkya and others do not belong to old times and the s≈´trakƒÅra acts on that. 1021 An example of an ancient Kalpa is Paingikalpa. the teaching of danoing (N√°tyƒÅcƒÅrya), these facts amount to this that before Panini and in his day also the profession of actors appears to have been not looked down upon in North-West India, while BaudhƒÅyana, an inhabitant of the southern parts of India ( as I noted ), looked down upon it.

Panini has the g≈´tra adhikrtya k≈ôte granthe' (IV. 3. 87) and then follows ‘Si≈õukranda-Yamasabha-dvandvendrajananƒÅ dibhyas-chah.'(IV. 3. 88 ), which means that the affix ‘cha’ (i. o. Iya) is added to denote a book composed with reference to children’s cries, the assoinbly of Yama, dvandva compounds and words in the Indra-jananƒÅdi-gana (0. g. Si≈õukrandiya, Yama sabhiya, KirƒÅtƒÅrjuniya, Indrajananiya etc.). This shows that much secular literature had already been produced in Panini’s days. A VƒÅrtika may be mentioned in connection with the date of P√°nini. The s√ºtra is ‘adhikstya krte granthe (P√°n. IV. 3.87) and the v√¢rtika is . LubƒÅkhyƒÅyikƒÅbhyo bahulam’. Tho. s≈´tra states as a general rule that works composed with reference to something have the affix ‘a≈Ü’(a) added to the word denoting the matter e. g. a work concerning SubhadrƒÅ would be called Saubhadra. KƒÅtyƒÅyana says that in the case of the literary genre called AkhyƒÅyikƒÅs this termination is in most cases not added. Pata√±jali cites the names of two literary works called AkhyƒÅyikƒÅs viz. Vasavadatta and SumanottarƒÅ, 102k where the termination is not found but also names an ƒÅkhyƒÅyikƒÅ oalled Bhaimarathi where the termination an’ was applied.

The above shows that in PƒÅ·πáini’s time ƒÅkhy√°yikƒÅs existed and they ended in the affix a·∫°, while K√§tyƒÅyana know many akhyƒÅyikƒÅs (mark the plural) which showed no termination.

‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§® ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§.

The two verses from thic Apastambiya-mantrapƒÅtha ( ed. by Wiaternitz) II. 11. 12-13 are : Frunia 7 Tr√§na rafmag: 1 fare inter ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡§µ ‡•§‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§§‡§ï‡•§ Vido H. of Dh. Vol. II. pp. 224-225 and note 519 for various readings in both verses, references to Yaugandhari, SƒÅlvas and SalvƒÅvayava in Panini, the K≈´≈°ika and in the parvans of MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. In the first verse, unless we uoderstand prajƒÅ·∏•' after salvi·∏•,' the meaning would be ‘women of S√§lva’ declared &c. The difficulty is what is the cxact reading of the third pada in both verses, free or for - as vocative, or fa i r or EST O. The word * vivftta' occurs even in the Rgveda (X.27.21), lo Yaj. Smsti 1.266 we have ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ rendered by the Mitaksara as ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§§‡§æ. If the reading is far :, then it would be an adjective of Fift: and would mean

E i. e. ‘on whom your wheel (i. e, power or dominion ) revolves’. Prof. Hazra objects to my rendering of the word ‘cakra as ‘dominion’ and in a matter of fact way asks how a river is to havo dominion and asserts ‘cakra’ should be taken to mean ‘army’. This is useless as it is not the army that is relevant in the work here but the people dwelling on the banks of the river. Rg. poets looked upon great rivers as goddesses, implored them to aceept their prayer (Rg. X.75. 5-6 ) and state that Sarasvati vanquishes their enemies (Rg. II.30.8). It should be noted that Vedic mantras are prescribed for some purposes not actually expressed in them, but even op the basis of a single word that has somo remote connection with the act for which it is prescribed. For example, the Mantra satyenotta bhita bh≈´mih’ &c., which is Ap. MantrapƒÅtha 1.6.1 and which occurs in Rg. X. 85. 1. and Atharvaveda XIV, 1, 1 (but not in Tai. S.) is recited (acc. to Ap. Gr. II.5.19 UttarƒÅ rathasyottambhani) at the time of supporting the chariot in which the powly married pair is to start for the husband’s home, simply because the word ‘attabhita’ occurs therein, though in the Rgveda verse what is said to be sup ported is the earth and the heaven. Even in modern lines at the time of a bath in any river old people repeat theyorso di Imam me Gange” etc. (Rg. X.75.5). Vido Dharmasindi paga/1375 for Snana-vidhi (Nir. ed. of 1926). Vide a long paper on Signaatonor yana by J. Gonda in East and West Journal (Rome) vol vit op 12-31.

  1. Dharmasƒ´tra of Apostambo

for Salva people and the other verse for brahmanas and referenos to river (in the vocative ) on which they reside is to be made. The author of Ap. Gr. found two verses in the MantrapƒÅtha of nearly the same import and having nearly the same words. He had to assign & proper viniyoga to each of the two verses. Straightforwardly construed, acc. to Ap. Gr. the first verse (in which ‘S√°lv√≠h’ are expressly mentioned ) should be sung in the case of all people of SƒÅlva country (whether brƒÅhmanas, ksatriyas or vaisyas ) and the 2nd verse was to be sung in the case of brƒÅhma·πáas (other than S√§lva brahmanas). This leaves a lacuna viz, what verse, if any, is to be sung for Ksatriyas and Vaiyyas who do not belong to the S√§lva country. It is possible that brƒÅhmanas are meant to be only illustrative (pradarsanar tham ) i. e. brƒÅhmanas and others not belonging to the Salva country should employ the 2nd verse. It would be seen how several interpretations are given by Haradatta and SudarsanƒÅ. carya on account of these difficulties. Among the first twelve verses in Ap. M. P. II. 11 five are common to both Rg. and Tai. S. and two (viz. verses 10-11 ) occur in Rg., Atharvaveda and Tai. S. That shows that the ƒÄp. M. P., though collected for Apastambiyas, could be drawn upon or referred to by others who were not Apastambiyas but studied soine other ≈õakh√≠. Siman tonnayana was a practice common to all persons (at loast of the three varnas ) in those days. It should be noted that anong the gphyas≈´tras there is great divergence about the details of Simantonnayana and about the verge to be sung. A≈°valayana. (I. 14. 6-7), Hira·πáyakeƒüin, Baud. Gr. (1. 10.9), BhƒÅradvƒÅja and Paraskara (I. 15. 7-8) prescribe in this sainskƒÅra only one verse and that too in honour of king Soma and no mention is made of sƒÅlvik' as in ƒÄp. Gr. S. These Gr. s≈´tras were not bound to follow strictly the Apastambiya MantrapƒÅtha, while √Ñp.Gr, was so bound. It is also remarkable that the Gr. g≈´tras of Gobhila, Khadira, Laugik»ôi and VaikhƒÅnasa are silent avon about the singing of a particular verse by lute players. Paras kara says that acc. to some the verse appointed (i. o. prescribed. niyukta,) must be sung. PƒÅraskara probably refers by this to the ƒÄp. Gr. simply because in the Ap. M. P. (which is a compil ation made by somebody who is not now definitely known) a verse occurs in which S√§lva people are mentioned and because that verse (one of two verses ) prescribed by Ap. Gr. was gung in Simantonnayana, it would be a wild conjecture on the part of anybody including Dr. Ram Gopal to say that the author of Gr. 8. came from the S√°lva country. Owing to the defectos

84

History of Dharmasriard

his outlook and methods, I propose not to refer to Dr. Ram Gopal’s work hereafter as far as possible. This volume would become very bulky if I were to reply to all his arguments, many of them baseless and inane.

I must say a few words about another recent work on Dharmas≈´tras. Dr. S. C. Banerji (of Maulana Azad College, Calcutta) recently published in 1962 ) a work on ‘Dharma sutras, a study in their origin and development’. He has summarised in the first 73 pages the contents of a portion of my History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra (published so far back as 1930 ) that dealt with the Dharnias≈´tras, quotes from them and refers to them dozens of times (sometimes four or five times on the same page). He is fond of adding sage remarks of which a few specimens are quoted below, though he admits on p. 7 (n. 1) ' for chronological questions relating to the works, we have taken Kane ( HDH Vol. I) as the chief authority. The work comprises several articles which Dr. Banerji contributed to some journals at different times. For example he contributed reconstruction of HƒÅrsta-dharmas≈´tra in J.O.I. (Baroda, 1958) pp. 14-37, which, with a few additions, appears in his work on pp. 257-287, re-construction of Atri, Cyavana, BhƒÅradvƒÅja and Devala in JOI. (Baroda) Vol. VI, now represented in Dharma gutras ‘etc. pp. 244-257; reconstruction of U≈°anas in ABORI vol. 39, pp. 85-100 ( 1953 ) now appears in Dharmasutras’ as pp. 340-44, ‘Flora and Fauna of Dharmas√ºtras ‘in J. O. I. ( Baroda ) vol. V, pp. 345-359 are set out now in ‘Dharnas≈´trasi pp. 206-228. He is more in collector than a scholar doing original and thorough research on his own account. He has given useful tables and appondices for workers on Sanskrit studies. He often writes rather pompously and does little arduous or valuable research himself. More than thirty-five years ago, 1 collected passages from Sankha-Lik hitas≈´tra (published in ABORI vol. VII-VIII) found in printed works. Since then & good many works on Dharnia-≈õƒÅstra have been printed. He does not make an effort to supplement what was not included by me and yet remarks (on p. 239 n. 1)‘P. V. Kane has collected, though not exhaustively, many passages ascribed to Sankha Likhita’, but he excludes my collection from his work nor does ho make the collection exhaustive by his own effort and research. On p. 73 he proposes to study the diversified contents of Dharma sotras under four main heads viz. (A) ƒÄcƒÅra, (BD Prayasoitta, (0) Vyavab√°ra, ‘(D) Rajadharma. Under A be makes four sube

  1. Dharmas≈´tra of √Ä pastamba

heads (1) Sampluribs, (s) Sraddha, (3) A≈õauca, (4) Dravya suddhi and some miscellaneous rules. Kane in his HDH Vol. II. briefly indicates the contents of this literature in tracing the evolution of a parti cular rite, custom or institution from the earliest times through different stages. But, as is usual in a work like his, there is no systematic, critical and comparative study of the contents of Dharmas≈´lras in it. The present attempt is made with a view to 52.pplying this need.’ Although he refers in the Bibiliography at the end of the book (on p. 54 ) to the History of Dharƒ±na≈°ƒÅstra ( Vol. 1-V ), it appears to me that he has either not read volumes III to V of that History or ignored them with what motives I cannot understand. Vol. III was published in 1946, Vol. IV in 1953 and Vol. V part I in 1958, at least several years before his present volume (published in 1962 ). There is not a single reference, so far as I could see, to those volumes in pp. 73-205. History of Dharmasastra

study of the contents of the Dharmas≈´tras ‘(to quote his own words ) in his book is for Sanskrit scholars to judge. I should like to say (begging his pardon) that he appears to me to be a conceited writer. I shall set out only one but an important instance. In the first vol. of H. of Dh. I devoted pp. 213-221 to KatyƒÅyana. I began by calling him one of a triumvirate in the realm of ancient Hindu Law and proceduro and based my remarks on quotations contained in a dozen works and authors. I stated (on p. 213 ) that KƒÅtyƒÅyana appears to have taken N√°rada and Bphaspati as his models in the treatment of VyavahƒÅra. I referred to a work called Karmapradipa of KatyƒÅyana in Jivananda’s collection of Sm·ªôtis and hold (on p. 221 ) that that author is different from KƒÅtyƒÅyana, the Jurist. In 1933 I published ‚ÄúKƒÅtyƒÅyana-sm·ªôtis√°roddhƒÅra’ in which I brought together 973 verses of KƒÅtyƒÅyana on VyavahƒÅra alone, extracted from twenty works, which work is mentioned by Dr. Banerji in his Bibliography on p. 542. Later on Prof. Ranga Swami Aiyangar collected over a hundred verses of Katyayana the jurist and published them in one of the papers presented to me on my 61st birthday (vide Kane Festschrift pp. 7‚Äì17). About K√§tyayana the jurist with whom I dealt on pp. 213-218 (in Vol. I. of H. of Dh.) I stated ‘All known quotations of Katyayana are in verse’ (p. 218 ). About this Dr. Banerji on p. 241 of his work remarks that Kane is not accurate when he asserts that * all known…… Verse’ and in connection with my remark about MedhƒÅtithi’s reference to a s≈´tra of KƒÅtyƒÅyana that we must either suppose that he ( Medh√§tithi) is referring to some other work of KƒÅtyƒÅyana than the one in verse from which hundreds of verges are cited by other writers or that KatyƒÅyana’s work on VyavahƒÅra also contained some prose passages’ (p. 218), Dr. Banerji remarks (pp. 241-42 ) that I am not right in drawing the inference and that ‘our collection of prose passages attributed to KatyƒÅyana by different writers proves conclusively that neither of the inferences of Kane is tenable’. My first inference based on MedhƒÅtithi quoting a s≈´tra of KatyƒÅyana was that Katyayana also wrote another work in s≈´tra style. Dr. Banerji says this inference is wrong. Then it follows that Katyayana did not write another work in prose. My second inference was that KƒÉtyƒÅyana’s work on VyavahƒÅra might have contained prose passages. This, he says, is wrong; if so, it follows that KƒÅtyƒÅyana’s VyavabƒÉra did not contain prose passages. He is inconsistent in this. On p. 53 (at the top left hand golumn No. 7 under the caption ‘minor writert on Dharmas≈´tot me

History of Dharmasastra

who was a jurist and whom I assigned to the period between the 4th and 6th century A. D. (p. 218 of vol. I, ed. of 1930 ). Dr. Banerjee appears to accept this date (p. 242 of his work). If the learned doctor had carefully read the prose passages attributed to KƒÅtyƒÅyana in medieval nibandhas set out by hini on pp. 295-296, he would have found that all of them refer to snƒÅna, ≈õrƒÅddha and none refers to law and judicial procedure at all. A cautious scholar would have paused before fathering those passages on KƒÅtyƒÅyana the jurist. The doctor’s reading is neither deep nor vast and, not being cautious, he gives free rein to his imagination. The doctor has probably not read or heard that there is a pari≈£ista in nine kandikƒÅs attributed to KatyƒÅyana and attached to the PƒÅraskaragrhyas≈´tra (which also is spoken of as KƒÅtiya).   1. Dharmasutra of Apastamba

89

these words of Kull≈´ka are an echo of KatyƒÅyana - srauta - g≈´tra VI. 10. 20-24 ‘pratinigadya homƒÅ·∏•…svƒÅbƒÅkƒÅrapradanah.’ The two passages (2,7) out of eleven are so brief that to find their source is like searching for & pin in a haystack. I had to spend hours in tracing the sources of these passages. All these passages, it is clear, do not refer to any juridical matter. Dr. Banerji has often stated as shown above that I had not proved conclusively my propositions. I hope that scholars will concede that I have conclusively proved at least one thing viz. what Dr. Banerji regarded (on p. 242, line 4) as con clusively proved by him has been conclusively proved to be wrong. After this exhibition of his carefulness and scholarship I do not want to expose his vanity and shallowness. He is very anxious to impress on his readers his cleverness and industry. On page 229 of H. of Dh. I, I briefly dealt with Pracetas and remarked that in both Mit. and AparƒÅrka we find prose passages and verses cited from Pracetas. At the end I said a few prose quota tions from Pr. are noted in the Smrtioandrika and by Haradatta. On p. 242 Dr. Banerji could not avoid saying in his usual manner

Kane is not absolutely accurate in holding that a few proge quotations etc.' He cites about 61 passages (prose) from Pracetas of which 34 are extracted from the Mit, AparƒÅrka and Smrtioan drikƒÅ to which works I had expressly referred. In order to reduce the bulk of the volume I did not set out any prose passages. That is all. I never said that only a few prose passages of Pracetas are known to nibandhas.

The commentary of Haradatta called Ujjvala-v≈ôtti is the only one so far recovered. For an account of Haradatta, vide sec. 86. The SmrticandrikƒÅ (I, page 25 ) quotes a passage from the bh≈´sya of Apastamba (11.6.15.19-20) and (II p.300) quotes the explana tion of the bhƒÅsyak√°ra on √Ñ pastamba II. 6, 14. 1. Both these passages are not found in the commentary of Haradatta, though in the latter case, Haradatta holds the same view as that of the BhƒÅsyakƒÅra. Similarly, the Viramitrodaya' (VyavahƒÅra, page 671) quotes the bh√¢syakƒÅra of ƒÄpastamba, but that quotation does not agree with Haradatta. Haradatta himself does not call his work bhƒÅsya, but vrtti. Besides, the Subodhini on the MitƒÅksarƒÅ (on Vai II. 132 ) quotes a passage from the Apastambadharma vrtti which is found in Haradatta on ƒÄp. II. 6. 14. 1. Haradara himself oites sometimes two or three other interpretations on the game s≈´tra (e. g. on Ap. I. 2. 5. 2; I. 3. 10. 6; I. 5. 15. 20:12 3 16). So the bhƒÅsyak≈´ra was probably one of his predecessore

In AparƒÅrka, Haradatta, Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ and other works there are numerous quotations in verse ascribed to ƒÄpastamba. These quotations are concerned with topics of ƒÄhnika, SrƒÅddha, and PrƒÅya≈õcitta. The Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ (III. pp. 423 and 426 ) quotes a StotrƒÅpastamba. Haradatta on Gautama (22. 18 ) quotes several verses on prƒÅya≈õcitta from ƒÄpastamba. Threo of these verses are found in the Apastamba-smrti in verse (Jivananda’s collection vol. I pp. 567-584 chap. I verses 16, 19, 31 ). The Smrti printed by Jivananda contains about 207 verses in ten chapters on prƒÅya≈õcitta and purifications. But the quota tions from the SmrticandrikƒÅ and AparƒÅrka show that the verse ƒÄpastamba was a much larger work and since they regarded the versified work as equally authoritative with the s≈´tra work, the versified smrti must have been comparatively an ancient work,

Shri. A. N. Krishna Aiyangar in Kunhan Raja Felicitation Volume (pp. 392‚Äì397 ) points out that there are some additional s≈´tras of ƒÄp. Dh. S. In the Rangaswami Aigangar Comh Korb (pp. 367-369 ) an account is given of an Apastambasmrti pagal Adyar Library in six patalas and 800 grantha.

27

  1. Hiranyake≈°i-Dharmas≈´tra

  2. Hiranyakosi-dharmas≈´tra. The Hira·ª•yake≈°i-dharmas≈´tra forms the 26th and 27th pra≈õnus of the Hiranyake≈õi-kalpa. The Srauta-g√ºtra has been published by the AnandƒÅ≈õrama Press (Poona ). The Hiranya ko≈°i-gƒºhya-sutra was edited with extracts from the cominentary of MƒÅtrdatta by Dr. Kirsto ( Vienna, 1889). The G»ôhya forms the 19th and 20th pra≈õnas of the Kalpa, each pra≈õna being divided into eight patalas. The Srauta-s≈´tra is largely based on the Srauta-s≈´tra of ƒÄpastamba Tho G»ôhya-s≈´tra is indebted to the Gƒºhya-sutra of Bh√§radvƒÅja. The Dharmasutra of Hiranyako≈õin can hardly be called an independent work. Hundrods of s≈´trus are borrowed word for word from the Apas tambil Dharƒ±nas≈´tra. The Dharnas≈´tra of Hirapyake≈°in ia therefore the oldest voucher for the authenticity of Apastamba’s text and is very valuable for checking the latter.

The Hiranyaka≈õins forni a s√ºtra-carana of the Kh√•ndikeya section of the Taittiriya≈õƒÅkhƒÅ and were formed later than the Apastambiya School. In a grant of the Kongu kings dated in 454 A. D. BrƒÅhma·πáas of the Hira·πáyakeƒüi School are mentioned (I. A. vol. V. page 136 ). According to the MahƒÅr≈Üava quoted in the commentary of the Caranavyuha, the Hiranyake≈õins were to be found in the south-west between the Sahya mountain and the ocean and near Parasurama (i. e, in the Konkan). There are at present many BrƒÅhma·πáas in the Ratnagiri District who call themselves Hiranyakeƒ£ins. The Dattaka-mlmƒÅmgƒÅ of Nanda-pandita twice quotes passages from the commentary of ≈öabarasyƒÅmin on the s≈´tra of SatyƒÅsƒÅdha. If he was identical with the great commentator of the P≈´rva-mimamsƒÅ (which is almost certain ), then we would have unimpeachable evidence for the existence of the works of the Hira·πáyako≈õins long before 200-400 A. D.

B√ºhler in his second edition of the ƒÄpastamba-dharmasutra (1893) gave (in appendix II) the various readings of the Hirapyakeƒ£i-dharmas≈´tra from two MSS. I secured a modern transcript of the Hiranyakeƒ£i-dharmas≈´tra from the Deccan College collection (No. 138 of 1881-82 ), which contains the text and also the commentray of MahƒÅdeva thereon. There are 18 folios for the s≈´tra and 101 for the commentary. That he is presents some readings which are not noticed by B√ºhler as foi in the two mss. consulted by him. For examplo, the us. reads “saptama ƒÅyu≈ükƒÅmama≈ütame brahmavarcasakƒÅƒ±nam (revorvidtHistory of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

the order of years in ƒÄp. I. 1. 1. 21-22 ), omits the words “yadi gnƒÅyƒÅt dandavat plavet” (from ƒÄp. I. 1. %. 30.), reads ‘vastrin yeva vasitobhaya &c.’ (Ap. I. 1. 3. 9 omits vasita), reads ‘gurave’ for ‘ƒÅcƒÅryƒÅya’ in Ap. I. 1. 3. 31. The ms. of the Hiranyake≈°i-dharmas≈´tra contains certain additions to the s≈´tras of Apastamba. For example, a s≈´tra ‘k≈üƒÅralavapa madhumƒÅms√§ni ca varjayet’ is added after Ap. II. 9. 22. 14, a s≈´tra ‘tesƒÅm p≈´jƒÅ ≈õroyasyƒÅtmana·∏• k√§ry√§’ occurs after Ap. II. 9. 25. 8, and the s≈´tra ‘sarva-dharmƒÅ≈ÜƒÅm svadharmƒÅnusthƒÅnƒÅ. niyame≈üu ca yuktah syat’ occurs after ƒÄp. II. 9.25. 13. The manuscript contains a few verses, that are not found in the Apastamba-dharmas≈´tra, introduced by the words ‘athƒÅpyu daharanti 103, (except in one case viz. putrena, &c.). The manuscript also omits certain s≈´tras found in √Ñp. 0. 8.

varpajyƒÅyasƒÅm cetarair yar≈Üaih’( ƒÄp. II. 5. 11.8), ‘anyatra rƒÅhudarganƒÅt’ (Ap. II. 7. 17. 25), ‘athopanayanam tata udakopaspar≈õanam’ (Ap. 1. 1. 1. 36.). In the case of some s√ºtras the readings of Hiranyake≈õin present a smoother and more classical Sanskrit than that of ƒÄpastamba and are mani. festly attempts to bring them in line with the requirements of the ≈°istas at the time when the Apastambas≈´tras were taken over into the Hirangakesi school. Hirapyake≈°isutra has

pƒÉdonam' and ‘ardhonam’ for ‘padunam’ and ‘ardhena’ of A pastamba (I. 1. %. 13-14), ‘asandarsane’ for ‘asandarse’ (Ap. I. 1. 2. 29), ‘aglanih’ for ‘aglƒÅrsnuh’ (Ap. I. 1. 3. 22 )

praksƒÅlayet' for ‘praksƒÅlayita’ (Ap. 1.1.3. 36), -kartrpatyam' for kartapatyam' (Ap. I. 2. 5. 3), yathƒÅ≈õakti' for ‘saktivisa yena’ (Ap. II. 5. 12. 1). Another noticeable feature is that the arrangement of the s≈´tras into sub-sections is a good deal diffe rent in the two works. B√ºhler notes that from the 13th khandika (6th patala ) of the second pra≈õpa both the manuscripts consulted by him do not indioate the patalas. The Deccan College manuscript does not number them from the second patala in the second pra≈õna. while Apastamba has eleven patalas in each of the iwo prasnas. The distribution of s≈´tras in the khavdikƒÅs is therefore different in the two works. Hirapyakesi has 31 khandik√§s in the first pra≈°na and 20 in the second. Besides, a few of the khandikƒÅs are diffo rently placed. The first khandikƒÅ of Hiranyakosi (first pra≈õna ) stops after ƒÄp. The com. of Mahadeva Dik≈üita called UjjvalƒÅ, is almost word iar word the samo as that of Haradatta’s Ujjvala. That one has borrowed from the other admits of no doubt and B√ºhler thinks that MahƒÅ deva is the borrower. But there is hardly anything to turn the scales in favour of Haradatta. Sometimes Mah√§deva’s commentary contains more matter than Haradatta’s (e. g. on the s≈´tras ‚ÄúSaptame brahmavaroasakƒÅmam &o’, ‘Upanayanam vidyƒÅrthasya ≈õrutita·∏•’, ‘dvƒÅda≈õƒÅvarardhyam’ and sometimes Haradatta contains more explanation (e. g. on ‘tasminsoa vidyƒÅkarnƒÅntain’ &c.; on ‘nƒÅpsu slƒÅghamƒÅna·∏• snƒ´yƒÅt’, on

pƒÅnisamk≈üubdhenodakenaika &c.’. MahƒÅdova differs from Haradatta’s explanation of the word ' atha', which the former takes in the sense of ‘ƒÅnantarya or adhikara’, while the latter takes it only in the sense of ‘ƒÅnantarya’. That Mahadeva also is an early writer follows from the fact ( noted by Buhler p. 117 m) that portions of his commentary are contained in the Munich Ms. of Haradatta dated Vikrama-Samvat 1668 (1611-12 A.D.). It is to be noted that Haradatta after saluting Gane≈°a at the beginning of bis UjjvalƒÅ does obeisance to MahƒÅdeva ( which may medier God Siva or the author MahƒÅdeva if he was the guru or fall of Haradatta ). Mahadeva often comments on the sutras found in Apastamba and not on the readings of them as existing

in the Hira·πáyake≈°i school; e. g. he comments on ‘pad≈´nam’, ou *adhasana≈°ƒÅyi' for ardhƒÅsana≈°ƒÅyi (the reading of the s≈´tra ), on ‘ƒÅtmasvastyayanƒÅrthena’ (Ap. One more circum stance that is worthy of note is that the UjjvalƒÅ of Haradatta does not contain many quotations from Sm·ªôtis as compared with his commentary on the Gautamadharmas≈´tra. Although ono may be inclined to hold that it is MahƒÅdova who borrows, it inust be clearly recognized that there is hardly any positivo evidence in support of such a view. There is a commentary called Vaijayanti on the Hiranyakesi-srauta-s≈´tra. This MalƒÅdeva is very likely identical with the Mahadeva who commented upon the dharmag≈´tra.

  1. Vasistha-dharmasutra. This dlurmusutra has been printed several times. The collec tion of Jivanada (part II, pp. 456-496 ) contains only 20 chapters and a portion of the 21st and so does the collection of Mr. M. N. Dutt (Calcutta 1908). The AnandƒÅ≈õrama collection of sinƒ´tis ( 1905, pp. 187-231 ) and the edition of Dr. F√ºhrer in the B. S. series (1916) contain thirty chapters. According to Dr. Jolly (R. u 8, p. 6 ) some mss. give only six or ten chapters, The Vasisthadharmas√ºtra with the commentary called Vidvan modini was printed at Benares. In the following Dr. F√ºhrer’s

edition has been used.

Kunj√§rila ( vide noto 55 above ) tells us that the dharma sutra of Vasistha was specially studied by the students of tho Rgveda, but that along with other dharmas≈´tras it is authori tative for all caranas. No srauta and gƒºhya s≈´tras of Vasi≈ütha, if they ever existed, have come down to us. We have therefore to fall back upon one of two hypotheses, viz. either the dharma s≈´tra of Vasistha is the solitary remnant of a school that might have once possessed a complete kalpa or that it was composed as an independent work on dharma and was subsequontly seized upon by the students of the Rgveda, who had only srauta and grhya s≈±tras of ƒÄ≈õvalƒÅyana. For reasons given olsayhero 1 incline to the latter viow. The dharmus≈´tra of Vasisthiam oftes

  1. Vasi≈ütha Dharmasutra

95

quotations from all Vedas and beyond the name Vasistha there is hardly anything special in the dharmas≈´tra to connect it with the Rgveda. It is true that in the 17th chap, several verses of the Rgveda (such as I. 21. 5, 1. 124. 7, V. 4. 10 which occur in g√¢tras 3, 16 and 4 respectively ) and several passages from the story of Sunah·∫•epa in the Aitareya-brƒÅhmana are quoted by the s≈´tra and that several hymns of the Rgveda, such as the (IsyavƒÅmiya (Rg. 1. 164 ), havispƒÅntiya (Rg. X. 88), Aghamarsann (X. 190 ), are referred to in the 26th chap. But there is nothing remarkable in this as some of the verses and s≈´ktas are mentioned in the BaudhƒÅyanadharmas≈´tra also. Besides, the Vas, Dh. S. quotes several passages from the Taittiriyasamhita (as in Vas. V. 7-9, which quote Tai. S. II. 5. 1-6 and Vas. XI. 48 which quotes Tai. S. VI. 3. 10.5), the Satapatha-brƒÅhmann, the MƒÅitrƒÅypiya-samhita (in Vas. I. 37).

The contents of the Vas. Dh. S. are:- I. Definition of Dharma, limits of ƒÄryƒÅvarta, who are sinners, the mortal sins, a brƒÅhmana can marry a girl of any of the three higher castes, six forms of marriage, the king was to regulate the conduct of people and to take the sixth part of wealth as a tax ; II. The four varnas, the greatness of ≈´cƒ´rya, before upanayana there is no authority for religious rites, the privileges and duties of the four castes, in distress a BrƒÅhmana could subsist hy resorting to the calling of a Ksatriya or Vaisya; a BrƒÅhmana was forbidden to sell certain things, usury condemned, rates of interost allowed; III. Censure of illiterate BrƒÅhma·πáa, rules on finding treasure-trove, who are utat≈´yins, when they could be killed in self-defence, who are parktipƒÅvanas, constitution of a pari≈üad, rules about ≈´camana, ≈õauca and purification of various substances;IV. The constitution of the four castes is based upon birth and the performance of samsk≈´ras, the duties common to all castes, honouring guests. madhuparka, impurity on birth and death; V. dependence women, rules of conduct for a rajasval≈´ ; VI. usage is transcen. dental dharma, praise of ƒÅc≈´ra, rules about answering calls of nature, moral characteristics of a brƒÅhmana and the peculiar characteristics of a s≈´dra, censure of partaking food at the houses of s≈´dras, rules of etiquette and good breeding ; VII the four ƒÅ≈õramas, and the duties of a student; VIII. Duties of art householder, honouring guests; IX. rules for forest hermits; X rules for sanny≈´sins; XI. six persons who deserve special honom viz. the priest at the sacrifice, son-in-law, king, paternal and maternal uncles and a snƒÅtaka; order of precedence in servisi

312222

96

History of Dharmasastra

food, guests, rules about ≈õrƒÅddha, times for it, the brƒÅhma·πáas to be invited at it, rules about agnihotra, upanayana, the proper time, staff, girdle &c. for it; method of begging for alms. prayascitta for those whose upanayana is not performed; XII; rules of conduct for a sn≈´taka ; XIII. rules about the beginning of Vedic study, rules about holidays for Vedic studies, rules about falling at the feet of guru and others, guiding principles in precedence as regards respect ( learning, wealth, age, relation ship, avocation, each prior deserving more consideration than each succeeding one ), rule of the road; XIV. rules about forbidden and permitted food, rules about the flesh of certain birds and animals; XV.rules of adoption, about excommunication of those who revile the Vedas or perform sacrifice for s≈´dras and for other sins; XVI, About administration of justice, king as guardian of minors, threefold pramƒÅnas, viz. documents, witnesses and possession; rules about adverse possession and about king’s advisers; qualifications of witnesses; perjury condoned in certain cases; XVII. praise of aurasa son; conflicting views about k≈üetraja son, viz. whether he belongs to the begetter or to him on whose wife he is begotten; twelve kinds of sons; partition between brothers, grounds of exolusion from partition, rules of niyoga, rules about grown-up unmarried girl, rules of inheri tanoe, king as ultimate heir; XVIII. pratiloma castes such as cƒ´≈ÜdƒÅla, no Vedic studies for s√ºdras or in their presence ; XIX. king’s duty to protect and to punish; importance of purohita , XX. about prƒÅyascittas for various acts unknowingly or knowingly done ; XXI. prƒÅya≈õcitta for adultery by S≈´dra and others with wonien of the BrƒÅhma·πáa caste or for cow-killing; XXII. prƒÅya≈õcitta for eating forbidden food, sacred texts that purify in case of sins ; XXIII. ponances for Brahmac≈´rin having sexual intercourse, for drinking wine &o.; XXIV. Krcchra and Atik·πõcchra; XXV. secret penanoes and penances for lesser sins ; XXVI-VII, virtues of prƒÅ≈ÜƒÅyƒÅma, Vedic hymns and Gayatri as purifiers ; XXVIII. praise of women, eulogy on Vedic mantras like Aghamar≈üana and of gifts; XXIX. rowards of gifts, brahmacarya, tapas &c. ; XXX, eulogy of dharma, truth and br√ºhmana.

The Vas. Dh. S. resembles in several respects the other dharmas≈´tras described above. It contains almost the same subjects and is similarly composed in prose intersemed with verses. The Vas. Dh. S. is in style like the Gautamadkarm Asutra and has many s√ªtras identical with or closely resembling those

  1. Vasi≈ütha Dharmas≈´tra

gory

of the latter. Vide. p. 18 above. It has also several g≈´tras closely corresponding with the s≈´tras of BaudhƒÅyana. Grave doubts have been entertained about the authenticity of the whole of the text of the Vas. Dh. S. as the mss. contain varying numbers of chapters from 6 to 30, and as the text is hopelessly corrupt in several places (e. g. vide note 108 below). The Vas. Dh. S. contains many verses which hear the impress of a comparatively late age. Chapters 25-28 are entirely in verse, while there are other chapters (like llI. 2-12, VI. 1-13, XI. 20-42 ) which contain many verses interposed between prose passages. In this respect Vasi≈ütha’s work is on a par with BaudhƒÅyana’s, in the fourth pra≈õna of which there are chapters entirely consisting of verses. It has therefore been argued that the text of Vasistha was tampered with freely, particularly as regards the chapters at the end. But as shown below it will have to be admitted that the interpolations, whatever they may be, were made at a very early period. The MitƒÅk·π£arƒÅ quotes Vas. by name about 80 times and the quotations are taken from almost every chapter from the first to the last. For example, Mit. quotes Vas. 27. 1 on YƒÅj. III, 310, Vas. 27. 21 on YƒÅj. III. 323, Vas. 28. ng on Y√°j. III. 297, Vas. 28. 18, 19 and 22 on YƒÅj. III. 309. Even MedhƒÅtithi quotes Vasistha over twenty times. The quotations are mostly taken from the first chapter to the 21st. Only one quotation from the last few chapters (viz. 27. 16 ) has been found in MedhƒÅtithi (on Manu XI. 211 ) and that too is not quoted as Vasistha’s, but is ascribed to others. ‘Vi≈°var≈´pa, who flourished about the first quarter of the 9th century quotes Vas. about thirty times in his commentary on the √ºc≈´ra and vyavah≈´ra sections of YƒÅj. These quotations hardly differ in any respect from the text of Dr. F√ºhrer’s edition and are scattered over almost all chapters from the 1st to the 17th, six quotations being taken from chapters 3 and 17 each. In the prayasoitta section Vi≈°var≈´pa quotes Vas. even more frequently. Besides several sutras from the 1st, 4th, 10th and 11th chapters, he quotes here no less than 22 s≈´tras of the 20th chap. and 9 of the 21st. More over, s≈´tras 37 and 39 of the 23rd chap. are quoted (on Y√§j. lII 281-282). What is more remarkable is that two verses (2-3) of the 28th chapter are ascribed to Vasistha and explained in detail ( on YƒÅj. III. 256 ), while Vas. 28. 4 is quoted without the author’s name. These facts make it certain that the Vas. D√•. 8. contained in Vi≈°var≈´pa’s day all the chapters from the fing to the 23rd and also the 28th. ≈öankara in his bh√•sya in Br. Onlar ni≈üad (III. 5. 1 ) quotes Vas. X. 4 and on B·ªâ, Up. IV. 5. 15 he

  1. Vasistha Dharmas√ºtra

tyƒÅhu·∏•). Vas. has many sutras on several topics very similar in language to Gautama. Compare Vas. XI. 16 and 14 with Gaut. 15. 3 and 5 (on ≈õr√§ddha ); Vas. XI. 49-51, 71-73 with Gaut. But the relation between Vas, and the Manusmrti is most important; at least 61 verses of the extant Manusmrti are identical with Vasistha’s (except for a word or a letter or tro in a few cases ). Of these some expressly mention the quotation as “MƒÅnavam 104b, or ‚ÄúMƒÅnayam ≈õlokam’ (vide above ), or use the word ‘udƒÅharanti’ about seventeen times, leaving no doubt as to whether they are quotations. Vas. IV. 5 and XVI. 30 are in prose but use the very words of the Manu sm·ªôti viz. Manu 5. 22, 32, 42 and Manu 8. 68 respectively. Some of the verses quoted in Vas, contain the word (Manu) as in IV. 6. There are at least five verses in Vas. three p≈´das of which are the same as in the verses of the extant Manu (compare Vas. 3. 59 and M. 5. 123, Vas. 6. 43 and M. 12.109, Vas. 26. 14 and M. 4. 146, Vas. 30.7 and Manu 7. 84 and six passages that contain half verses that are common to Vas. and Manu (Vas. 3. 8 and M. III. 128. Vas. 6. 11 and M. 4. 52, Vas. 8. 8 and M. 3. 103 and Vas. 10.5 and M. 2. 83, Vas. 13. 16 ( M√§nava sloka) and Manu 4, 117, Vas. 18. 10 (PƒÅrasayo… lyƒÅhuh) and M. 9. 178. Several verses occur without these words being prefixed, but most of them seem to be quotations (e. g. Vas. II. 3 which cornbines Manu. II. 169 and 170, IV. 6 which is Manu 5. 41, VI. 6 and 8 which are Manu IV. 157 and 158 ). Some of these verses introduced with the words ‘athƒÅpi’ &c. as well as some of those not so introduced are in the regular classical UpajƒÅti, UpendravajrƒÅ or IndravajrƒÅ (vide. I. 38, X. 20 for verses with athƒÅpi &c. and VI. 9 and 25, X, 17, XVI. 36 for verses without them). Some of the verses are in the ancient Tristubh form (e. g. VI. 3 and 30, VIII. 17, XVII. 71). In one verse (VI. 5) there are twelve letters in the first pƒÅda and eleven in the rest. One quotation with words “athƒÅpi” &c. is in prose ( II. 5). There are a few un-PƒÅ·πáinean forms like Vivadanti :

in XIV. 47 (vide PƒÅnini I. 3. 47). It looks as if the dharma sutra once ended with the 24th chapter, where we have an injunction (in g≈´tra 6 ) against imparting the dharmas≈´tra to one who is not a son or pupil. The same s≈´tra occurs in BaudhƒÅyana Dh. S. IV. 4. 9 and the succeeding s≈´tra is the same in both. But the words' prƒÅya≈õcitta has been described in the rahasya sections for playing false to the husband' (in Vas. V. 4): apparently refer either to chapters 25-28 (which contain rahasya penances ) or to some prototype of those chapters now lost.

The Vas. Dh. 8. quotes largely from the Rgveda and other Vedic SamhitƒÅs. Among the BrƒÅhma·πáas, the Aitareya and Satapatha are frequently cited. The VƒÅjasaneyaka ( Vas. 12. 31 and 23. 13 ) and the Kathaka ( Vas. 12. 24 and 30.5) are menti oned by name. The Tai. Aranyaka is quoted in Vas. 23. 23. The Upanisads and VedƒÅnta occur in 22. 9. Vasistha quotes a g≈´th≈´ of the Bhallavins from their NidƒÅna work about the extent of the home of Brahmanismn, which is quoted by BaudhƒÅ yana also ( Dh. S. I. 1. 27). He speaks of the argas of the Veda (3.23 and 13.7) and gives their number as six (3.19). Itihasa and PurƒÅna are mentioned in 27. 6. The science of words (grammar), of omens and portents, and of astrology and astronomy (NaksatravidyƒÅ ) are referred to in 10. 20-21. He prohibits the learning of the language of the Mlecchas (in 6.41). Vas. quotes a verse that states that the view holding the apr≈´m≈´nya of the Vedas leads to perdition (12. 41). In Vas, II. 8-11 occurs the VidyƒÅs≈´kta in four verses that we meet with in the Nirukta (II. 4). Vasistha calls his own work dharma≈õƒÅstra (in 24. 6) and probably refers to other works on dharma in the words ‘one who studies dharmas’ (in 3. 19). The study of dharma≈õƒÅstra as a penance for even mortal sins is spoken of in 27. 19. Vas. quotes several authors on dharma≈õƒÅstra. He quotes √† verse from HƒÅrita (in II. 6 ) which occurs in BaudhƒÅyana also with slight variations (Baud. Dh. S. I. 2.7), though without the author’s name. The two halves of this verse are almost the same as the latter halves of Manu. 2. 171-172. B√ºhler is there fore not quite accurate when he says without qualification that the verse attributed to HƒÅrsta occurs in Manu (p. XX, S, B. E. vol. XIV). Vas. quotes Gautama twice (in 4. 35 and 37 about impurity on death, the first corresponding to Gautama fit 41), while there is nothing in Gautama to correspond to the end. Vas. quotes a verse (11, 20 ) which mentions Yama by nemo

FOUNDED

  1. Vasi≈ütha Dharmas√ºtra

101

and embodies the latter’s views. Vas. (18. 13-15 ) quotes three slokas sung by Yama, one of which (14) is the same as Manu 4. 80 and another (15) is very similar to Manu 4. 81. Another sloka of Yama is quoted by Vas. (19.48 ) which is almost the same as Manu 5. 93. From these facts and others B√ºhler draws the conclusion (S. B. E. vol. XIV, p. XX ) that these verses were taken from the MƒÅnavadharmas≈´tra, which occupied the same position in Vasi≈ütha’s day as the Manusmrti does at present. I demur to this conclusion, which will be discussed later on in detail (under Manusmrti). Vas. (14. 30-32 ) quotes slokas of PrajƒÅpati, the first of which mentions Yama by name 1040, Vas. 14. 16-19 and 24-27 are quoted as slokas of PrajƒÅpati, three of which (14. 16, 18 and 24 ) are practically the same as Manu. 4. 248, 249 and 5.127. Vas. 14. 19 contains a p≈´da which occurs in Manu 4. 212. It is remarkable that the Vas. Dh. S. cites Vasistha himself with great reverence (as bhagavƒÅn) in 2. 50 (about the rate of interest), 24. 5 (about Krochra penance ), 30. 11. In numerous places the Vas. Dh. S. either refers to Manu by naine or quotes the views of Manu (under the form

iti MƒÅnavam') or a sloka of Manu (with words' M√°navam ≈õlokam). All these passages have an important bearing on the age of the Manusmrti and on the supposed existence of a M√§navadharmas≈´tra. They therefore deserve to be carefully examined. Vas. I. 17 is in prose ( about local, family or caste usages) and summaries the views of Manu. The absence of the word ‘iti’ before abravin Manuh' and the form of the s≈´tra itself clearly establish that Vas. is not directly quoting a

104 c Vasistha 14.16-19 and 24-27 are quoted as slokas of PrajƒÅpati. Several

of them arc quoted in different works and ascribed to other sources, For example, Vas, 14.16 and 18 are quoted from a Purana in Ap. Dh. S. I. 6. 19. 13, and these two are practically the same as Manu IV, 248-249 and Visnu Dh. S. 57. 11-12, Vas, 14. 19 is almost the same as Ap. Dh, S. I. 6. 19. 14 and a part of it is Manu IV. 212. Vas. 14. 24 is the same as Manu V. 127, Band. Dh. S. I. 5. 56, AnusƒÅsanaparva 104. 40, Visnu 23. 47,

It may be pointed out that AparƒÅrka (p. 1322 on raj. III. 311) quotes Vas, 28. 10-11 and a prose passage (of 6 lines) in which the Aghamarsana hyon, Rg. X. 189 (dyam gaul dic), Rg. IV. 40. 5 (Hanisah sucisad ) and the G≈Øyatri are prescribed as expiations. Vas. 28. 10-15 occur in Vi≈ünu Dh. IV, 3, 12th pƒÅda being different ) preceded by athƒÅpyudƒÅharanti'. Vas. 28. Talmontes are quoted as Vasistha’s in Sm. C. I. p. 187 (Gharpure’s edities L10%

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

s≈´tra of Manu. That s≈´tra is only a summary of our Manu I. 118. Vas. 3, 2 (which is preceded by the words ' MƒÅnavam slokam' is Manu II. 168. And so are Vas. 13. 16, 20. 18, which are Manu 4. 117 and 11. 151 ( with very slight variations). That the latter existed in Vasistha’s text is vouched for by AparƒÅrka (p. 1075). Vas. 4. 5 is in prose and cites the view of Manu that animals may be sacrificed only for worshipping and honouring the manos, deities and guests 105. There is hardly anything to show that it is a direct quotation from Manu and not a summary of Manu’s views. The s≈´tra briefly summaries the views that we find expressed in our Manu 5. 22, 32, 41 and 42 (the words of 42 ‘e≈üvarthesu pa≈°um himsan’ are interesting and bear a olose resemblance to ‘pa≈õum himsyƒÅd’ in Vas.). That sutra is followed by a verse which is the same as Manu 5. 41. It is to be noted that the same verse occurs in the dharwas≈´tra of Visnu (51. 64 ) which reads ‘n√§nyatreti kathamcana ' for ‘nƒÅnyathety bravin Manuh’. This change appears to have been purposely made to keep up the impression that the Visnu Dh. S. emanated from Visnu himself and so could not have borrowed from a human author. Vas. 4.7 is very similar to Manu 5. 48. B√ºhler (8. B. E. Vol. 25, P. XXXI) is wrong in taking Vas. 4. 8 as a quotation from the MƒÅnavadharmas≈´tra. There is nothing to show that it is so takon. It is more probably a quota tion from or a summary of a BrƒÅhamna passage (compare a quotation in AparƒÅrka on YƒÅj. 1. 109, which is similar). Vas. 23. 43 ( where Manu is referred to as prescribing an easy penance called Sisukrcchra for children and old men )corresponds more or less with Manu 11. 211 and 219 and Vas. 26. 8 has evidently Manu 11. 260 in view. There are only two places in Vasi≈ütha where the name of Manu occurs for which it is not possible to point out a corresponding verse in the Manusmrti. They are Vas. 12. 16 and 19. 37. The latter is cited as a M√§nava sloka and is in the UpajƒÅti metre. 106 Because this is not found in our Manu, B√ºhler and other Western scholars seem to think 105 pga ataug harada Toj rerni a Ala I ATAS 4.5; 918 4.8 is sponta

  1. Vasi≈ütha Dharmasutra

103

that the verse is taken from the MƒÅnavadharmas≈´tra which onde existed in mixed prose and verse and is now lost. But, as will be shown elsewhere, this hypothesis is based, to say the least, on very slender foundations. Besides these two that are not found in our Manu, there are about forty verses that are common to the Vas. Dh. S. and the Manusmrti and about a dozen verses which, though not strictly identical, are more or less similar. There are several prose s≈´tras of Vas. which correspond to the verses of Manu almost word for word.107 The hypothesis that commends itself to me is that Vas. contains borrowings from the Manusƒ±n»ôti or its purer ancient original in verse.

In the words ‘SrƒÅmanakenƒÅgnimƒÅdhƒÅya’ (Vas. 9. 10 ), the s≈´tra of Vikhanas seems to be referred to. Gautama (Dh. 8. 3. 26 ) contains the same words. Vasistha’s 22nd chap. is the same as Gautama’s 19th and BaudhƒÅyana’s tenth in the 3rd pra≈õna and seems to have been borrowed from Gautama. Vasistha refers to the views of others in the words ‘eke’ or ‘anye’ (Vas. 1. 12, 13, 25 ; 4. 10; 17. 66 ; 20.2). Dr. Jolly (S. B. E, vol. VII, P. XVIII ) thinks that Vag. 28. 10-15 and 18-22 are borrowed from the Vi≈ünudharmas≈´tra chap. LVI and LXXXVII or its original the Kathakadharmas≈´tra. Dr. Jolly is not right with regard to both the places. B√ºhler has already pointed out his mistake as to the second passage (S. B. E. vol. XIV p. XXII). The verses in Vas. 28. 10‚Äì15 occur in several sm·ªôtis ( vide Sankhasmrti, 10th chap. in Jivananda’s ed. part II. pp. 356-357 for the same verses ). Vasistha, chap. 28, verses 1-6 occur in Atrismrti VI. 1-6 (ƒÄnan. collection of Sm·ªôtis ) with slight variations of which the first five are quoted as Atri’s by the G»ôhastharatnƒÅkara p. 245 and verse 6 (‘agnerapatyam’occurs in PadmapurƒÅna, Vanaparva 200. 128 (Ch. ed.), Samyarta 1717) and in ‘Gupta Inscriptions’ No. 81 at p. 296 and in other Inscriptions. Vide H, of Dh. Vol. II. p. 1272, No.5 (in some cases the third pƒÅda of ‘Agner-apatym’ is different ). Verses 18-22 of Vas. 28 occur in the Atri Sm·ªôti VI. 7-11 and in Visnu Dh. S., chap. 87 (last two versos are the same as Vas. 28. 21-22)

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

and Visnu Dh. S. 90.10 (in prose ) is nearly the same as Vas. 28. 18-19. Besides Vas. 28. 11 occurs in Baud. Dh. S. IV. 3.7. Hence it is hardly proper for any scholar to make the dogmatio assertion that one particular smrti must have borrowed from any other. The rather very corrupt passage in Vasi≈ütha (16.21-23 108) very closely resembles a passage of Sankha, which is cited by Vi≈õvar√ºpa on YƒÅj. I, 305 and by the Krtya-kalpataru.

B√ºhler is of opinion that the home of the school to which the Vas. Dh. S. belonged lay to the north of the NarmadƒÅ and the Vindhya (S. B. E. vol. XIV p. XVI). When it is extremely problematical whether the Vas. Dh. S. was the product of a school, it is idle to speculate as to the home of the Vas. Dh. S. B√ºhler’s is no more than a mere conjecture and it is better to admit that we know nothing positive at present on the point.

The earliest work to refer to Vasistha as an authority on dharma is our Manu (8. 140), saying that Vas. allowed 1/80th of the principal as interest per month. This appears to refer to the rule in Vas, 2. 50. We saw above that Vas. borrows from the Manusmrti, which in its turn quotes a rule of Vasistha. The explanation of this is twofold. Both the Manusm·ªôti and Vas. have received later additions and further it is possible that the present Vas. Dh. S. is the work of some one who had received the teachings of Vas, through a succession of teachers and disciples. YƒÅj. mentions (1.4) Vasistha as a writer on dharma. The TantravƒÅrtika as seen above (note 55 ) remarks that the Vas. Dh. S. was studied by Rgvedins. The same work when speaking of works on dharma puts Manu, Gautama and Vasistha in the forefront. 1084 It appears that Sabara on P. M. S. VI. 1. 10 quotes or summarizes Vas. I.32 and 36 when he says ‘Vikrayospi ≈õr≈´yate, satamadhiratham duhitrmate dadyƒÅt, ƒÅrse gomithunam iti’. Vasistha I.32 and 36 are ‘gomithunena car≈üah tasmad duhit≈ômatesdhiratham ≈õatam deyam-itiha krayo vij√±ƒÅyate.’
