  1. Vasi≈ütha Dharmas≈´tra

105

The words ‘tasmad…deyam’ do ocour in Ap. Dh. S. II. 6. 13. 11 but not in the definitions of the forms of marriage as in Vas. The words ‘adhiratham satam dubitsmate’ occur in SƒÅn. Gr. I. 14. 16 and Kausi. Gr. I. 8. 36, but not in connection with any form of marriage (both do not enumerate the forms of marriage ). Vi≈°var≈´pa, MedhƒÅtithi and other early commentators largely quote from Vas. The verse’agnerapatyam’ (Vas. 28.16 ) occurs in the Ragim copp…ôrplate of Tivaradeva of the last quarter of the 8th century (Fleet’s Gupta Inscription No. 81.). Therefore the existence of a work of Vasistha on dharma at least in the first centuries of the Christian era is vouched for with certainty and the authenticity of its text is supported by eminent writers from the 7th century downwards. AparƒÅrka quotes passages from the BhavisyapurƒÅna which have in view the present text of Vas. 109 Some of the views held by Vasistha are very ancient. For example, he speaks of the twelve secondary sons, assigns a very inferior position to the Dattaka son (17th chapter), allows niyoga ( 17. 56 ff) and the remarriage of child widows (17.74 ). Like ƒÄpastamba he mentions only six forms of marriage (1.28-29 ), brƒÅhma, daiva, ƒÅr≈üa, g√ºndharva, k≈üƒÅtra and miinusa. In some respects his views are different from those of early writers like Gautama and BaudhƒÅyana, He prohibits the marriage of a BrƒÅhma·πáa with a s≈´dra woman (I. 25-26). Vide Baud. Dh. S. I. 8. 2 for the contrary view. He elaborates rules of adoption ( 15th chapter) which are not found in Gaut. or Baud. or ƒÄpastamba. Ho speaks of documents as one of the three means of proof (Vas. 16. 10-15 ), while Gautama, Apa stamba and BaudhƒÅyana are silent on the point, though in Gautama (13. 4) there appears to be a reference to documents. Taking all these things into consideration it may be said that Vasistha is later than Gautama, ƒÄpastamba and BaudhƒÅyana. but much earlier than the beginnings of the Christian era and may tentatively be assigned to the period between 300-100 B. C. It has been asserted by an eminent authority (Cambridge History of India vol. I, p. 249 ) that Vasistha 18. 4 (vai≈°yena brƒÅhma·πáyƒÅm-utpanno RƒÅmako bhavatityƒÅhuh) probably contains a reference to the Romans. This assumption is gratuitous and does not deserve serious consideration. The reading Romaka (on which the learned writer relies) is not supported by the best mss. and it is most hazardous to seize WiLL

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

avidity on a variant reading and to build an imposing structure of chronology thereon. The offspring of a Vai≈õya male from a BrƒÅhma·πáa woman is designated RƒÅmaka by Vasistha, while Gautama calls him Krta ( 4. 15 ) and Baud. Dh. 8. (I. 9.7) calls such an offspring Vaidehaka; so RƒÅmaka has as much to do with the Romans as with Rameses. In the nibandhas there are several quotations ascribed to Vasistha which are not found in the printed Dharmas≈´tra. For example, Haradatta on Gaut. (22. 18 ) quotes a verse in the UpajƒÅti metre which is not found in the present text 110

The author of the extant Vas. Dh. S. appears to have been eclectic. His s≈´tra contains dozens of verses that occur in the extant Manusm·ªôti. Similarly, many of the verses quoted by him in the words ‘athƒÅpyudƒÅbaranti’or the word ‘udƒÅharanti occur also in the Ap. Dh. S. and more often in Baudh. Dh. S. which latter just like Vas. employs the words. athƒÅpyudƒÅ haranti’ over forty times. Towards the end of the present text (edition of Vas., chap. 30. 9-10) occurs the verse ‘yƒÅ dustyajƒÅ’ &c., which is found in Vanaparva 2. 36, ≈õƒÅnti-parva 174, 55 and 276. 12 and Anu≈°ƒÅsana 7. 21. The last s≈±tra ( of Vasi≈ütha Dh. S.) contains an obeisance to Vasi≈ütha who is described as the son of MitrƒÅvaru≈Üa from Urvasi and as SatayƒÅtu ( who possessed hundred magic spells or against whom a hundred magic speels were employed ). Rg. VII. 33. 11 refers to the birth of Vasi≈ütha from Urvasi and calls him Maitr√§varupa and in Rg. VII. 18. 21 we have the half verse ‘Pra ye gshƒÅdama madus-tvƒÅyƒÅ ParƒÅ≈õara·∏• SatayƒÅtur-Vasi≈üthah’. SƒÅyana takes

‚Ä¢ ≈öatayƒÅtuh’ as meant for Sakti, son of Vasistha.

If we rely on the number of verses common to Manu and Vasistha or on r…ôferences to MƒÅnavam’ (Vas. IV.5.) or * MƒÅnava-≈õloka’ 13. 16, 20. 18 or simply ‘Manu’ (Vas. I. 17, IV. 6, XI. 23, XII. 16 ) and also consider the very large number of verses and passages common to the Manusmrti, Vas., Baud. and Ap. Dh., it would have to be held that the extant Vas. Dh. 8. is a re-hash of the Ap. Dh. 8., Baud. Dh. 8. and Manu ( as it oxisted before it was remodelled about the beginning of the Christian era or a century or two earlier).

  1. Vasi≈ütha Dharmas≈´tra

1

.. It would not be irrelevant, if most of the passages from Vasi≈ütha that are based on or refer to Vedic works are referred to here and examined. First, as to the Rgvedic Literature. Vas. IV. % mentions Purusas≈´kta (Rg. X. 90), Vas. 17. 3-4 quote portions of Rg. I. 21. 5 and Rg. V. 4. 10 (last pƒÅda, Vas. 17. 16. (praticinam gacchati putratyam ) refers to Rg. I. 124. 7 and Nirukta 3. 5; Vas. 15. 20 refers to making a person bathe with water from a holy lake or stream with the Vedic verses beginning with ' ƒÄpo hi sthƒÅ' ( Rg. X. 9. 1 ff); Vas. 17. 1-2 quote from Ait. Br. ( adhyƒÅya 33, 1) and Vas. 17. 31-35 refer to the story of Sunahsepa ( in Ait. Br. 33. 2-6 ). As to the Tai. S., Vas. 5.8 quotes a long passage from Tai. S. II. 5. 1. 1-6 (the transfer of Indra’s sin of killing Tv√§stra Vi≈°var≈´pa to women); Vas. 11.48 quotes Tai. S. VI. 3. 10. 5 (for the theory of three inherited obligations of brƒÅhma·πáas which is also mentioned in Satapatha Br.) ; Vas. I. 37 quotes Mai. S. I. 10. 11 (an≈£tam vƒÅ e≈üƒÅ karoti yƒÅ patyu·∏• krit√£ satyathƒÅnyai≈°-carati' &c) which also occurs in KƒÅthaka Sambiti, Sthanaka 36. 5. The Kathaka is mentioned by name twice by Vas. (iu 12. 24 and 30. 5) and the VƒÅjasano yaki (meaning Sat. Br.) is mentioned thrice (Vas. 12. 31, 14. 46 and 23. 13 ); 1104. Vas. 2. 34 quotes VƒÅj. Saibita (XII. 71 ): Vas. 18. 17 quotes the words ‘nƒÅgnim citvƒÅ rƒÅmƒÅm upoy√•t’ from the Kathaka and in 18, 18 explains the meaning of RƒÅmƒÅ, which appears to be taken from the Nirukta XII. 13. Among the BrƒÅhma·πáa works the Satapatha Br. is the one that is often quoted; Vas. I. 45 quotes Sat. Br. V. 4.2.3 (‘brƒÅbmano vedam adhyam’ &o), Vas. 14, 46 refers to Sat. Br. III. 1. 2. 21; Vas. 19. 4 ( vij√±ƒÅyate brahmapurohitam rƒÅ≈ütram-rdhnotiti), which is similar to Gaut. Dh, S. XI. 13-14 and is based on Sat. Br. V. 4. 4. 5; Vas. 30. 3. Agnir-vai brahmana iti ≈õruteh' (this is ≈öat. Br. I. 4.2.2); ' Vas. 23. 23 mentions the mantra beginning with ‘Agnisoa mƒÅ manyusoa ‘from Tai. ƒÄr. X. 24. 1; Vag. XI. 13 quotes Kathopanisad I. 7 ( ‘Vai≈°vƒÅnara·∏• pravi≈°atyatithir brƒÅhma·πáo gƒºhƒÅn’).

I might have omitted through oversight a few vedio passages. But those examined above show that passages from the SarbitƒÅs and BrƒÅhma·πáas of Vedas other than the Rgveda

1108 ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§¶‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†

NDED

108

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

and its BrƒÅhma·πáas outnumber those from the Rgveda and its BrƒÅhmanas. Then the question naturally arises, why was it adopted by Rgvedins as their Dharmas≈´tra ( as stated by KumƒÅrila). The answer is obvious. Vasistha is mentioned by name in the Dharmas≈´tra several times (vide above). The s≈´tra does rely on the Rgveda and its BrƒÅhma·πáa in a few passages. Vasi≈ütha’s is the greatest and most famous name among the ancient sages of the Rgveda. The whole of the 7th mandala contains 104 siktas out of 1028 in the whole of the Rgveda, is ascribed to Vasistha (MaitrƒÅvaru≈Üi). Mandalas I, IX and X have more s≈´ktas than mandala VII, but every one of the three manlalas is held to have been composed by several sages (and not by one for each of them). One aspect of the Vasistha Dh. S. viz. that different mss. of it state that it ends with different adhyƒÅyas is very significant. If it had been from the beginning a s≈´tra of the Rgveda, then its text would have been at least as well preserved as the text of such gƒºhya or dharma s≈´tras, as those of ƒÄ≈õvalƒÅyana and Apa stamba. Besides, there is one remarkable circumstance. The ƒÄ≈†v. gr. (II. 6) which is affiliated to the Rg. names and briefly defines eight forms of marriage viz. BrƒÅhma, Daiva, PrƒÅjƒÅpatya, Ar≈üa, GƒÅndharva, Asura, Pai≈°ƒÅca and RƒÅk≈üasa. The SankhƒÅyana-gƒºhya (I. 12-14) only describes the religious part of the marriage ceremony and altogether omits the mention of eight forms of marriage and their definitions. So does the Kausitaka-gphya (1. 8). The Gaut. Dh. S. IV. 4-11, Baud. Dh. S. I. 11. 1-9, Manu III 21 and 27-34, Kautilya III, 2. 1-9 name and define the same eight forms of marriage, as ƒÄ≈õv. Gr. does. But Vasistha (I. 28-36 ) mentions and defines only six forms of marriage viz. BrƒÅhma, Daiva, ƒÄrsa, GƒÅndharva, k≈üƒÅtra and M≈´nu≈üa. In this he seems to follow Ap. Dh. S. II. 5. 11, 17-20-II. 5. 12. 1-2). If Vas. Dh. S. had been from the first affiliated to the Rgveda it should have either treated the subject in the same way as ƒÄ≈õvalƒÅyana or followed the ƒÄ≈õv. gr. and enumerated eight forms or should have been silent about the several forms of marriage (as S√£ok. and Kaus. g·ªô. are ). This circumstance very much strengthens the theory that Vas. Dh. S. is eclestic and therefore followed Ap. Dh. 8. in the number of forms of marriage. There is a further circumstance. Vas. Dh. S. differs from Asv. G»ô, not only in the numberly of the forms of marriage but also in the nomenclature. His Klatra. the same as RƒÅk≈üasa and his MƒÅnusa is the same as Acuta, These two terms were probably borrowed by Vasistha from

FOON

yre 1917

  1. Vasi≈ütha Dharmas≈´tra

109

H√§rlta-Dharmas≈´tra (vide Viramitrodaya, SamskƒÅra prakƒÅ≈°a. p. 84). As Manu says (III. 34 ), tho PaisƒÅca form (in which a man has sexual intercourse secretly while the woman is asleep or intoxicated or unconscious, is the worst and most sinful form. Vasistha omitted it and PrƒÅjƒÅpatya was probably going out of vogue. Therefore, these two were omitted by Vasistha. The Asura and the Raksasa are declared by Baud. Dh. 8. I 11. 12 to be in accordance with the characterstic conduct of Ksatriyas viz. they rely principally on force either of wealth or of arms (‘atrƒÅpi ≈üa≈üthasaptamau K≈üƒÅtra-dharmƒÅnugatau tat-pratya yatvƒÅt-ksatrasya). Therefore, the RƒÅksasa form which consists mainly of carrying away a girl by force ( Manu 3. 33 prasahy kanyƒÅ-haranam ) is called k≈üƒÅtra by Vas. Vasi≈ütha might have been moved by such sentiments as are expressed by DavapƒÅla on KƒÅzhakagƒºhya XV ‘prasahy√§pahƒÅrƒÅd-rƒÅksaso vivƒÅhah, tatra kim prakarƒÅbhidhƒÅnona, evamasa·πÅvijnƒÅtopagamƒÅt Paisacopi prakƒÅravacanam n√§rhati pƒÅpatvƒÅt’. Manu ( in 8. 165, 168 declares that all transactions brought about by force or fraud should be held invalid (akrtu). There are also other points on wbich Vas. differs from all three grhyas≈´tras of the Rgveda or from SƒÅn. G»ô. and Kau≈ü. G·ªã. On even such a simple matter as the age of a BrƒÅhmana boy at Upanayana, Vas, differs from all three. They all agree that the Upanayana of a BrƒÅhmana boy may be performed from the 8th year to the 16th (Vas. XI. 49 and 71, ƒÄ≈õv. G»ô. I. 19. 1-2 and 5, San. G»ô. II. I. 1, 3 and 6, Kau≈ü. Gr. II. 1. %, 5), they differ on the most commendable year for it. Vas. (XI. 49 ) commends the eighth year from conception, ƒÄ≈õv. the eighth year from birth or conception (I. 19. 1,2), ≈õƒÅn. Gr. (II. 1. 1 and 3 ) commends either the 8th year or 10th year from conception and the Kaus. Gr. does the same. So far as I know no other Gr. or Dh. S. gives an option between the 8th or 10th year as the most commendable year for Upa nayana. Gaut. (I. 6, 8 ), ƒÄp. Dh. (I. 1. 19), Baud. Dh. (I. 2.8) Manu (II. 36 ) proscribe as most favoured the 8th year from conception. It follows that Vas. did not agree with any of the three schools of Rgvedins, viz. A≈°valƒÅyana, S√§nkhƒÅyana and Kau≈üitaka and struck an independent course and his work on Dharma was later on affiliated to the Rgveda, when it became a fashion to have a complete set of Kalpas≈´tras (in three pattet. for each Voda or its recensions.

The above mentioned parallelisms and quotations and that extent are more than enough to lead to the conclusion that

1:10

History of Dharma≈õƒÅs!ra

Vasistha’s Dh. S. was originally an eclectic work of an indepen dent character and that it did not at first attach itself to the Rgveda.

Dr. Ram Gopal in his work (on pp. 59-60 ) does not agree with my conclusion and, though he has to admit (p. 59 ) that Vasistha Dh. S. is not known to have formed part of a Rgvedio Kalpa, he holds (p. 60 ) on the ground of close agreement of Vas. with the three grhyas≈´tras of SƒÅn., ƒÄ≈†v. and Kaus. on the topics of upunayana, anadhy≈´rin, sn≈´take and five Mah≈´yaj√±as that Vasi≈ütha’s work was from the first affiliated to the Rgveda. In support of his theory he draws attention on p. 67 (note 31 ) to twelve passages from ≈ö√£nk. Gr., five from ƒÄ≈õv. Gr. and five from Kau≈ü. Gr. (in all 22 ). I do not want to enter upon a lengthy discussion. If about 75 passages quoted from Manu and numerous passages quoted with ‘udƒÅharanti,’ the presence of chapters on adoption, vyavahƒÅra, inheritance, partition, r√§jadharma and prayascittas, which are not shown to have been included in a Vedic Kalpa of the Rgveda do not induce a writer to admit the independent origin of Vas. there is no use in arguing with him. It is, however, necessary to show clearly what value should be attached to his arguments. His contention briefly put is that the 22 passages he cites from San. A≈õv. and Kau≈ü. gphya very closely agree with Vas. Dh. passages and therefore Vas. must be held to be affiliated to the Rgveda from the beginning. He cites Vas. IV. 6 as equal to $ab. G. S. II. 16.1 (viz. the verse ‘madhuparke ca etc.). But this verse is Manu V. 41 and both Vas. and SƒÅn, might have borrowed it from Manu (and what is most important Manu’s name occurs in the verse itself). Dr. Ram Gopal cites Vas.VI.:21 (ƒÅhitƒÅgniranad vƒÅm≈õca &c ) as equal to SƒÅn. II. 16. 5. Therefore he concludes that Vas. is indebted to ≈õƒÅn. It is very fine research indeed. There are two verses Astau grƒÉsƒÉ’ &c. and ‘ƒÅhitƒÅgairanadv√§sinca &c’in Vas. VI. 20-21. Both of these are cited in Baud. Dh. 8. II. 7. 22-23 and ƒÄp. Dh. S. II. 4. 9. 13 (in both those verses occur with the caption athƒÅpyudƒÅharanti’). It is noteworthy that the Kalpataru ( BrahmacƒÅrikƒÅnda p. 124 )cites ‘aparimitam brahmacƒÅri≈Üah (part of the verse ‘a≈ütau grƒÅsƒÅ’) and the verse Canadv√§n brahmac√£ri ca ƒÅhitƒÅgni≈õca &c as from Vasistha, ƒÄpastamba, HƒÅrita and Yama. San. Gr. II. 16 cites on a one of these two verses and that too in a modified form (as Anadian agnihotram ca’ (this is a bad reading and the verso lecomes ungrammatical). Therefore, this proves that S√•n. gr burrans

one of two ancient verses quoted by both ƒÄp. and Baud. and Vas. borrows both. SƒÅn. Gr. II. 16 has six verses, of which the first (‘madhuparke’ &c ) is Manu V. 41 (reads ‘yaj√±e’ for ‘some’). II. 16. 5 has been dealt with above. 1100 UpƒÅkarma is a very common rite even up to this day. So the provisions in the texts on this rite agree. Dr. Ram Gopal cites Vas. 13. 5 as agreeing with SƒÅn. Gs. IV. 6.7-8. There is not much verbal agreement between the two as the note will show 110c but there is at least as much or more verbal agreement with Gaut. and Manu. A thorough examination of all the twenty-two equations in Dr. Ram Gopal’s work (p. 67) would cover about a dozen pages. The domestio rites and their subsidiary matters being common to dvijas, there is a good deal of uniforinity as well as some difference in details in the s≈´tras connected with different Vedio SƒÅkhas. For example, compare Baud. Dh. 8. I. 2. 14-16 with ƒÄp. Db. S. I. 2. 33-38, also with Gaut. I. 15-23. Mere agreement of a few s≈´tras with others on simple and common matters relating to Upanayana, AnadhyƒÅya and the like hardly proves anything about their affiliation with any particular Veda or Vedic carand. I regret to say that Dr. Ram’s remarks on the passages of Vas. and the three G»ô. s≈´tras attached to the Rgveda ara misleading and also incapable of proving his thesis.

  1. Visnudharmasutra. The Vi≈ünudharmas≈´tra has been printed several times in India, viz. by Jivananda in his Dharmasastrasangraha (1876 part I pp. 70-176 ) by the Bengal Asiatic Society (1881, ed. by Dr. Jolly with extracts from the commentary Vaijayanti ), by M. N. Dutt (Dharma≈õƒÅstra texts, vol. II pp. 541-666, Calcutta, 1909) and translated by Dr. Jolly (in the S. B. E. vol. VII with an Introduction). In the present work Dr. Jolly’s edition has been used. The g≈´tra contƒÅins one hundred chapters. Though the number of chapters is so large, the s≈´tra is not very extensive. There are several chapters such as 40, 42 and 76 that contain only one s≈´tra and one verse. The first chapter and the last two are entirely in verse; the remaining chapters are in mixed prose and verse, the versified portion being generally at the end of each chapter. As pointed out by the Vaijayanti the s≈´tra is in close relation to one of the oldest schools of the Yajurveda, viz. Katha. It also stands in a peculiar relation to the extant Manusm·ªôti. According to the Caranavy≈´ha, Kathmand

  1. Vinnudharmas√∫tra

118

OdrƒÅyaniya are two of the twelve sub-divisions of Caraka sƒÅkhƒÉ of the Yajurveda. Dr. Jolly ( S. B. E. VII, p. XII ) gays that the Visnudharmasutra has four chapters (21, 67, 73 and 86 ) and that both drew from a common source. B√ºhler points out( West apd B√ºhler’s digest, 3rd ed. p. 35 ) that the Kathakagƒºhya found in Kashmir agrees closely with the Dharmas≈´tra of Visnu and the mantras in the latter agree with the KƒÅthaka recension of the Yajurveda. But the Visun. dharmas√∫tra is not the work of the same author that com posed the Kathaka Srauta or Grhya s≈´tras, nor does it appear that it formed part of the Kathaka Kalpa. Dr. Jolly ( R. u. S. p. 7 ) says that GovindarƒÅjƒÅ ( 12th century ) in his Smrti ma√±jarƒ´ cites a passage in prose from a Kathas≈´trakrt on the penance for BrƒÅhmana murder which is wanting is our Vis≈Üusmrti ( vide S. B. E. Vol. 25, p. xxl n for the passage ).

The contents of the Vi≈ünu-dharma-s≈´tra are :- The earth, being listed out of the surging ocean by the great Boar, went to Ka≈õyapa to inquire as to who would support her thereafter, and was sent by him to Vis≈Üu who told her that those who would follow the duties of varnms and a≈õramis would be her support, whereupon the earth pressed the great God to impart to her their duties ; 2. the four varnas and their dharmas ; 3. the duties of kings ( rajadharmal ); 4. the KƒÅrsƒÅpa≈Üa and smaller measures ; 5. punishments for various offences; 6. debtors and creditors, rates of interest, sureties; 7. three kinds of documents ; 8. witnesses ; 9. general rules about ordeals ; 10-14. ordeals of balance, fire, water, poison and holy water ( lcosa ); 15. the twelve kinds of sons, exclusion from inheritance; eulogy of sons; 16. offspring of mixed marriages, and mixed castes ; 17. partition, joint family and rules of inheritance to one dying sonless, re-union, stridhana; 18. partition among sons of a man from wives of different castes ; 19, carrying the dead body for cremation, impurity on death, praise of BrƒÅhmanas; 20. the duration of the four Yugas, Manvantara, Kalpa, MalƒÅkalpa, passages inculcating that one should not grieve too much for the departed ; 21. the rites for the dead after period of mourning, monthly frƒÅddha, sa pindikarana ; 22. periods of impurity on death for sapindas, rules of conduct in mourning, impurity on th and rules about impurity on touching various persons and objects ; 23. purification of one’s body and of various auhi stances ; 24. marriage, forms of marriage, inter-marriages

114

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

guardians for marriage; 25. the dharmas of women ; 26. precedence among wives of different castes; 27. the saƒ´skƒÅras, garbhƒÅdhƒÅna and others ; 28. the rules for brahmacƒÅrins ; 29. eulogy of ƒÅcƒÅrya ; 30. time for the starting of Vedic study and holidays; 31. father, mother and ƒÅcƒÅrya deserve the highest reverence ; 32. other persons deserving of respect; 33. the three sources of sin, viz. passion, anger, greed ; 34. kinds of atipƒÅtakas, deadliest sins; 35. five mahƒÅpƒÅtukas ; 36. anu patakas, that are as deadly as the mahƒÅpƒÅtakas; 37. numerous upapƒÅtakas; 38‚Äì42. other lesser sins ; 43. the twenty-one hells and the duration of hell torments for various sinners; 44. the various low births to which sinners are consigned for various sins ; 45. the various diseases suffered by sinners and the low pursuits they have to follow by way of retribution ; 46-48. various kinds of krcchras (penances ), sƒÅntapana, cƒÅndrƒÅyana. prasrtivƒÅvaka; 49. actions prescribed for a devotee of Vasudeva and the rewards thereof; 50. prƒÅyascitta for killing a brƒÅhmana and other human beings, for killing cows and other animals; 51-53. prƒÅya≈õcittas for drinking wine and other forbidden substances, for theft of gold and other articles, for incest and sexual intercourse of other kinds; 54. prƒÅya≈õcittas for miscellaneous acts; 55. secret penances ; 56. holy hymns like Aghamarsu≈Üu that purge sin ; 57. whose society should be avoided, VrƒÅtyas, unrepentant sinners, avoiding gifts ; 58. the pure, variegated (mixed ) and dark kinds of wealth ; 59. The duties of house-holders, pƒÅkayaj√±as, the five daily mahƒÅyaj√±as, honouring guests; 60. the daily conduct of a householder and good breeding ; 61-62. rules about brushing the teeth, ƒÅcamana; 63. means of livelihood for a house-holder, rules for guidance, good and evil omens on starting on journey, rule of the road ; 64. bathing and tar. pana of gods and Manes ; 65-67. worship of Vasudeva ; flowers and other materials of worship, offering of food to deities and pindas to ancestors and giving food to guests ; 68. rules about time and manner of taking food ; 69-70, sexual inter course with wife and about sleep; 71. general rules of conduct for & snƒÅtaka; 72. value of self-restraint; 73-86. srƒÅddhas, the procedure of sraddhas, astakƒÅ frƒÅddha, the ancestors to whom srƒÅddha is to be offered, times of sraddha, fruits of brƒÅddha on the several week days and the 27 naksakruerend the tithis, materials for sraddha, brƒÅhma·πáas unfit to be invited at $rƒÅddha, brƒÅhma·πáas who are parktipƒÅvana ; countnega fit for sraddha, tirthas, letting loose of a bull; 87-88. gitts of

.

911

10, Vi≈ünudharmas≈´tra

116

antelope skin, or a cow ; 89. kƒÅrtika-spƒÅna ; 90 eulogy of gifts of various sorts ; 91-93. works of public utility such as wells, lakes, planting gardens, embankments, gifts of food, flowers &c.; difference in merit according to the recipient; 94-95 rules about forest hermit ( vƒÅnaprastha ); 96-97. about sannyƒÅsa, anatomy of the bones, muscles, veins, arteries &c.; concentration in various ways; 98-99. praise of Vasudev& by the Earth and of Laksmi; 100. rewards of studying this Dharma≈õƒÅstra.

The Visuudharma-s≈´tra somewhat resembles the Dharma s≈´tra of Vasistha. Like the latter it is full of verses. But one feature which is peculiar to the Visnu-dharmas≈´tra is that it professes to be a revelation by the Supreme Being. None of the other dharmas√∫tras so far described assumes this role. The style of the Vi≈ünudharmas≈´tra is easy and somewhat diffuse. It presents hardly any ungrammatical forms. The printed text is corrupt only in a few cases ; the verses occur generally at the end of chapters. Sometimes the number of verses in a chapter is very large e. g., in chapter 20 there are 21 s≈´tras and 32 verses, in chapter 23 there are 24 verses, in chap. 43 there are 14, in chap. 51 there are 20 verses. Some of the verses are in the classical IndravajrƒÅ (19. 23-24 ) and the UpajƒÉti metres ( 23.61 and 59. 30 ) and a few are Tristubhs (29. 9-10, 30. 47, 72. 77). The three Tristubhs ( 29. 9-10, 30. 41 ) are three out of four verses of the VidyƒÅ B√ºkta occurring in the Nirukta (II. 4). Chap. 72.77 is BhagavadgitƒÅ 11. 70. Chapters 1, 99, 100 are entirely in verse. Chap). 98 contains praise of V√§sudeva by the Earth in about 91 names, some of which like Lekhya, Sapta, Kapila. SankhyƒÅcƒÅrya are rather surprising. The revelation by God Visnu is contained in 96 chapters (2 to 97 ). The nares of Visuu are only 94 bat 98.6 ( on nainas-te ) and 98.101 (namo nama iti ) are added to 94 and thus the names of Vi≈ünu are squared up with 96 chapters. The word uthu does not occur at the beginning of the first two chapters and in Dr. Jolly’s edition at the beginning of some other chapters also ( viz. 4, 16-20, 22-23, 26-27, 29-32 &c.). The chapters vary greatly in extent. In Chap. 34, 39 and 40 there is only one s≈´tra followed by one verse. There are other chapters bolso that are short, that is they have three or four s≈´tras andma. verso vix. 41, 84, 88, 89, while some chapters occupy mort

POONA

A

1917

H0

History of Dharmasastra

than three printed pages such as 3, 20, 22, 23, 51, 54, 96. Chap. 5th is the longest, containing 178 s≈´tras and 14 verses at the end. Here and there Visnu Dh. S. gives etymologies such as of the word putrue in 15. 44 ( = Manu 9. 138 ), of MƒÅmsa ( in 51.78 = Mapu V.55 ), of purusa ( from puri sete ) in 97.15, which is also given in Br. Up. II. 4.18 and Nir. I. 13), At the end of Chap. 78 there are two gathƒÅs (52-53) sung by pitrs which are quoted by Kull≈´ka on Manu III. 274 as Vi≈ünu’s and which are similar to Manu III. 273-74 and VƒÅyu-pur√§na 82.11 and Matsya-purana 204.5 ( matsya Chap. 204 has GƒÅthƒÅs 3-17 sung by the pitrs, 10 of which begin with api syƒÅt sa kulessm√§kam etc. ). Vide Anu≈°ƒÅsane parva 88. 12-17 (Ch. ed.). There is one verge ( 72.6 ) which has eleven letters in the first p√º√ºda and twelve in the remaining three,

In determining the age of the Visnudharmas≈´tra one is confronted with a difficult problem. Some of the chapters undoubtedly contain material which is comparatively old and on a level with the ancient Dharmus√±tras of Gautama and Apastamba. Such are the chapters about rƒÅjadharma and punishments (3 and 5), the rules about twelve sons and the mixed custes ( 15-16 , funeral rites and mourning (21 and 22 ). But there are very large portions of the work that bear a clear impress of a later date. The Visnudharma. s≈´tra apd the Manusinrti have at least 160 identical verses. But this is not all. There are hundreds of s≈´tras which are merely the prose equivalents of verses from the Mapusinrti. For example, Vi≈ünu 2.3 and Manu 2.16, Vinnu 3.4 and 6 and

an 7. 69 70, Vionu 3, 7-10 and Manu 7. 115, Visnu 3. -15 and Manu 7. 116-117, Visnu 4.1-13 and Manu 8, 132-137, Visnu 5. 4-7, and Manu 9. 237, Vi≈ünu 20. 1-21, and Manu I. 67-73, Visyu 51. 7-10 and Manu 4. 209-212, Visuu 59. 21-25 and Manu 3. 70, Vinnu 62. 224 and Manu 2. 59, Visnu 71. 48-52 and Manu 4. 80, and Visnu 96. 14-17 and Manu 6. 46 agree almost word for word. The verses that are identical in both are found in all the chapters of the Manusmrti from the second to the last, the largest number ( about 47 ) occurring in the 5th and chapters eleven, two, and three respectively contributing 25, 24, and 19 verses

Therefore the question whether the extant Vi≈ünudharmasutra borrows from Mavu or vice versu or whether both borrow Hom the common original assumes very great importance, As thorax

Manu 7.69 70,

  1. Vi≈ünudharmasutra

respondence extends over several hundred verses of the Manu sm·ªôti, the last hypothesis of borrowing from a compion original does not recommend itself to me. No such common source is known to have existed and to say that there were hundreds of floating popular verses whose authorship was unknown and which were drawn upon by both works appears to me to be au extremely gratuitous and unsatisfactory assumption. In my opinion it is the extant Vinnudharmas≈´tra that borrowed the verses ac hoc or adapted them from the Manusmrti, There are several lines of reasoniug that strengthen this hypothesis. There are some verses that are identical in both, in which the name of Manu occurs, which the Vismudharmas≈´tra omits by making slight verbal changes. For example, Vi≈ünu 23. 50 substitutes’tat parikƒ´rtitam’ for ‘Manur-abravit’ in Manu 7. 131 ; and Vis≈Üu 51. 64 reads ‘n√ºnyatreti kuthamcaua’ for Manu 5. 41’n√ºnyatretyabravin-Manu·∏•’ ( this last occurs in

Vas. 4. 6). The reason for these changes is obvious. The Vi≈ünu-dharmas≈´tra professes to be a direct revelation from Visuu and it is in keeping with this assumed role tbat not one human author is mentioned by name in the sutra. Therefore where the nume of Manu occurred in any verse, it was pur. posely omitted. Another reason why the s≈´trit must be presumed to be the borrower is the character of the extant work itself. It is a kind of hotchpotch and contains verses that are identical with those of other works. For example, several verses of the Bhagavadyit√† occur in the Vishudharma s≈´tra. Visnu 20. 48-49 and 51-52 are the same as Gƒ´tƒÅ 2. 13; 23, 24, 28 ; Visnu 72. 7 and GitƒÉ 2-70 are almost identical. Visnu 96. 97 and the first half of 93 are the same as Gƒ´tƒÅ 13. 1-2, except that in keeping with its character of a revelation to the Earth, the Vishudharmas≈´tra substitutes ‘vasudhe for’ kaunteya’ and ¬∑ bhƒÅvipi ‘for bhƒÅrata.’ Several verses of the Y√°j≈°avalkya-smrti are identical with those of the Visuudharmas≈´tra. For example, Vistu 6. 41 and Y√°j, 2. 53, Visnu 8. 38 and YƒÅj. II. 79, Vis≈Üu 9. 33 and YƒÅj. 2. 97, Visnu 17. 17 and YƒÅj. 2. 138, Vi≈ünu 17. 23 ( first half) and YƒÅj, 2, 210 ( latter half ), Visnu 62. 9 and Y≈´j. 1. 21, Vi. 63. 51 and YƒÅj. 1. 117 are identical. Besides these, there are hundreds of prose s≈´tras that are identical with passages of YƒÅj√±avalkya. For example, Vi. 3. 72-74 = Y√ºj. II. 1-4; Vi. 3. 82=YASI 318-320 ( rules about land grants.); Vi. 5. 65-69=Ya n. 217-220, Vi. 5. 73=YƒÅj. II. 221; Vi. 45. 3-12 =YƒÅj. 3. 2002141 ( about diseases suffered by singers ); Vi, 60.24 = YƒÇj.

ARSAN

ul

1917

118

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Vi. 96. 55-79=YƒÅj. 3. 84-90 ( about 360 bones of the body ); Vi. 96. 80-88=YƒÅj, 3. 100-102 ( about the number of arteries, veins, muscles etc. ); Vi, 96. 89-92=YƒÅj. 3. 93-99. Dr. Jolly thinks that YƒÅj√±valkya borrows from Visnu the whole of the anatomical section ( vide S. B. E. vol. VII, p. XX ). With great respect I differ from this opinion. There is nothing to show that the anatomical details were first given to the world by Vi≈ü≈Üu. They must have first been embodied in works on medicine such as those of Caraka and Susrutall and were probably copied by Dharmas≈´tra writers. But, if there is any borrowing between Vis≈Üu and YƒÅj√±avalkya, I think from the character of the Visnudharmas≈´tra that it is the s≈´tra that must be regarded as borrowing from YƒÅj√±avalkya. There are Beveral matters in the extant Visnudbarmas√∫tra which are wanting in YƒÅj√±avalkya and which induce one to place the extant s≈´tra later than YƒÅj≈°avalkya, viz. the uame .Jaiva' for Thursday ( Vi. 78. 5 ), the long list of tirthas ( Vi. chap. 85 ) which include Sriparvata and the five rivers of the south called southern Pa√Æcanada, the importance of the conjunction of the moon and Jupiter on a full moon day (Vi. 49. 9.10 ), the vague definition of Aryavarta 1a ( Vi. 84. 4). The verse in Vi≈ünu 54, 33 ( about half prayascitta for boys and old men ) is ascribed to Angiras by the MitƒÅk·π£arƒÅ (op Y√°j. III. 243 ).

Therefore, the most probable conclusion is that the extant Visnudharmasutra burrows from the Manusmrti, Yajnavalkya and other authors. It would be too much to assume that tbe Manusmrti, the BhagavadgitƒÅ aud Y√°j≈°avalkya borrow from such a comparatively unimportant work as the Vishudharma sutra.

The above conclusion is further strengthened by certain other considerations. The Manusmrti has been quoted with utmost reverence by a host of writers from at least the 4th cen tury downwards, such as Sabara, Kum√§rila and SankarƒÅcirya.

  1. Vi≈ünudharmashtra

119

Yaj√±avakya was commented upon by Visvar≈´pa in the first half of the 9th century. Visvar≈´pa in his com mentary quotes scores of s≈´tras from Gautama, Apastamba, BaudhƒÅyana, Vasistha, Sarkha and HƒÅrƒ´ta. But it is significant that Visvar≈´pa in his commentary on Yaj√±a valkya does not quote even a single g≈´tra of Visnu by name. It is true that Visvarupa ( on Yaj. III. 66 ) says that the four forms of asceticism ( pƒÅrivrƒÅjya ) should be under stood from the other smrtis like those of Visnu. 113 This probably refers to chap. 97 of the extant Visnudharmas≈´tra. Medhatithi (on Manu 3. 248) quotes Visnu (21. 12 ) and on Manu 9. 76 quotes a s≈´tra of Visnu which I could not trace in the printed Visnu. 114 The MitƒÅk·π£arƒÅ mentions Visnu about thirty times. The quotations are taken from chapters 19, 21, 22, 35-42, 50, 51, 52, 75 and 79 of the Visnudharma s√∫tra, 18 s≈´tras of chap. 22 ( on ƒÅ≈õauca and kindred topics ) being quoted on YƒÅj. III. 23, 24, 27, 29-30. But it is a remarkable fact that not one of the verses in the extant Vi≈ünudharmas≈´tra is cited as Visnu’s in the MitƒÅksarƒÅ. The only exception is a verse cited as Visnu’s on Yaj. III, 265, which has the same purport as Visnu 52. 14 (a verse) and the first p≈´du of which is identical with that of the verse in the Visnudharmas≈´tra 116 A few verses that are quoted as Vi≈ünu’s in the MitƒÅksarƒÅ could not be traced in the extant dharmas≈´tra.16 It is not unlikely that the s≈´tra

History of Dharmasastra

first contained mostly prose sutras based on Manu and the Kathakagrhya and verses were tacked on later.

Quotations from the Visuudharmas≈´tra in the Krtya. kalpataru (no part of which had been published at the time this volume was published in 1930, but now eleven parts of which have been published in the GOS. edited by my friend the late Prof. Rangaswami Aiyangar) are made hundreds of times e. g. 132 times on VyavahƒÅrakƒÅnda, 39 times on SrƒÅddha, 38 times in NiyatakƒÅla, 35 times in G»ôhasthakƒÅnda, 30 times in Brahmac√°rikƒÅnda, 10 times on Rajadharma, 15 times ou D√°nakƒÅnda ( the DƒÅnakinda quotes on pp. 231-33 the whole of chap. 90 except the last five s≈´tras and a verse). One great advantage is that the Kalpataru often states that the same verse or passage occurs in Visnu and other ancient writers e. g. in VyavahƒÉrakƒÅnda on pp. 270, 613, 627, 652, 676, 678 &c. verses are cited as Manu-Visnu and cited as Visnu and YƒÅj√±avalkya on pp. 150, 213, 289. YƒÅj. II. 120 ( second half ) is Visnu 17. 23 (first half ). The whole of Visnu Chap. 49 ( on Dvadasivrata ) and Vismu Chap. 89 are quoted by VratakƒÅnda of Kalpataru on pp. 310, 418 respectively. Among later writers of nibandhas Apararka quotes Visnu most profusely and the SmrticandrikƒÅ also quotes Visna about 225 times. Many of the verses found in Vi. are quoted by AparƒÉrka as Vinnu’s e. g. Vi. 84. 4 on YƒÅj. 1. 2; 68. 46 47 on YƒÅj. 1, 106 ; 67. 33 on Y√°j. 1. 107; 5. 183 on Y√°j. 2. 60 ; 10. 9-11 on Y√°j. 2. 102. But there are numerous verses quoted as Visnu’s by Apararka which are not found in the sutra, e. g. on YƒÅj. I. 21, 53, 89, 100. Sometimes. AparƒÉrka quotes almost whole chapters of Visuu, e. g. Vi. 68 on Yaj. I. 106 and 90 on YƒÅj. I. 208, 70 on Y√§j. 1. 114. It is to be noted that Vi. 70. 17 (a verse) is quoted by Apar√°rku as a prose sutra (on 1. 114 ) with slight verbal changes. All these facts make one feel naturally sceptial about the anthenticity of most of the verses in the extant Visnudharmas√∫tra. They probably formed no part of the sutra at the time when the MitƒÅk·π£arƒÅ

STATUR

ODHA

FOURDED

1917 OD

. TT

  1. Pippudharmas≈´tra.

121

was composed. At all events it cannot be gainsaid that the verses are a very late part of the s≈´tra.

The Visuudhamas≈´tra contains quotations from all the Vedic sarhitƒÅs and from the Aitareya-brƒÅhmana (as in Vi. 15.45 ). It mentions the Ved√§ngas very frequently (30.3 and 38, 28. 35, 83. 6 ), it speaks of Vyakarana (83,7 ), of itih√§sa ( 3. 70, 30, 38, 83. 7), of Dharma≈õƒÅstras (3. 70, 30. 38, 73. 16, 83. 8), of Pur≈´na ( 3. 70, 30. 38 &c ). About the close correspondence between Baud. III, 6 and Visnu. 48 and between Vas. 28. 10-15 and 18-22 and Visuu, chap. 56 and 87, vide remarks made above pp. 43 and 103. The sutra quotes several verses ( called g≈´th≈´s ) and says they were sung by pit≈ôs; vide 78. 52-53, 80. 14, 83. 21, 85. 65-67. They bear close resemblance to the gƒÉthƒÅs sung by the pit≈ôs quoted in the Apu≈°ƒÅsana-parva 88. 11-15 and a half verse estavya bahava·∏• putra yadyekopi GayƒÅm vrajet’ is the same in Vi. 85. 67 and Anu. 88. 14. The Vinnusmrti enumerates twenty one hells ( 43. 1-22 ), which are almost the same as YƒÅj√±a valkya’s (3.222-224 ). It mentions the names of the seven days of the week (78. 1-7-), Thursday being called Jaiva, while YƒÅj√±avalkya mentions only the seven planets (with RƒÅbu and Ketu ) in the same order ( I. 296 ). It recommends the practice of sutƒ´ ( 25. 14 ), speaks of pustakas (18, 44, 23. 56 ), a word which is not used by the other dharmasutras 80 far described. It gives a long list of good and evil omeus at the time of startivg on a journey (63. 33-39 ). Among evil omens it includes the sight of yellow-robed ascetics (i. e. Buddhists probably ) and KƒÅp√•likas ( 63. 36 ). It prohibits speech with Mlecchas, Antyajas ( 71. 59 ) and journeys to Mleccha countries ( 84. 2 ). It contains special directions about the worship of VƒÅsudeva in chap. 49 and speaks of Svetadvipa as the reward of devotion to V√°sudeva ( 49. 4). Here and there, there are eulogies of Vasudeva ( 1. 50-57, 65. 1, 97, 10, 98 which ( last ) gives one hundred names of Vis≈≥u ). It speaks of the four vy≈´has of V√°sudeva ( 67.2 ) and of the VarƒÅhƒÅ incarnation. It gives a vague location of AryƒÅvarta us a country where the four varnas exist ( 84. 4 ). It enumerates numerous sacred places ( 85. 1-52 ), among which Sriparvata, Sapt√°rsa ( modern Satayo GodƒÅvari and southern Pancanada deserve to be spabadiy noted. Though it does not specifically enumerate the eighboro122

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

titles of law just as YƒÅj≈àavalkya does not, yet it contains rules ( in chapters 5-6 ) on almost all of them.

As YƒÅjiavalkya enumerates Vis≈Üu among the pro pounders of dharma≈õƒÅstras, it follows that a work of Visuu existed in comparatively early times. What matters that work embraced it is difficult to say. It probably contained the topics found in the works of Gautama, Apastamba and others. It may have included portions borrowed from the

Kathakagrhya.

An important question is whether the Visnudharmasutra is related to the Kathaka school ( of the Caraka sƒÅkhƒÅ of the Kranayajurveda ). I do not propose to deal with it at great length. Nanda Pandita in his Com. on Visnu Dh. S. 67.3 (where twelve deities are named) expressly states that the deg cription of Vaisvadeva in that chapter follows the procedure adopted in the KƒÅthaka≈õƒÅkh√£ ‘KƒÅthaka-≈õnk hƒÅnusƒÅrena Vaisvadevam-ƒÅha …… AgnyƒÅdibhyo dvƒÅda≈õƒÅlutirjuhuyƒÅt’. Important evidence is furnished by the Krtyakalpataru, an extensive digest composed in the first half of the 12th century A. D. on Sriddha (GOS. Ed.). Vishu Dh. S. chap. 73 provides about ƒÅma≈°rƒÅddhas (≈õrƒÅddhas with uncooked grains) and KamyusrƒÅddhas ( srƒÅddhas performed on certain tithis, naksatras and weekdays for securing certain desired objects specified in Visnu Dh. S. Chap. 78) a certain procedure (the original is quoted in the note ) 1186 ‘in these srƒÅddhas

The above makes it clear that the Visnudharmas≈´tra took the KƒÅthaka-samhita and the Kathaka-grhya (or LaugƒÅk≈üi ) as its basis. The words

prathama-pa≈´cakena, madhyamapancakena' are vague and could have been understood only by those who know their relation to K√•thakgrhya and K√§tha kasambiti. It follows that at least some chapters (like 21, 64, 65, 67, 78 Svc.) were certainly based on the K≈´ƒ∑haka grbya (if not all ). and the Visuu Dh. 124

History of Dharmasastra

It may be stated that on Visnu Dh. S. 21. 17 also Nanda paudita mentions the KƒÅthakgrhya, that Visnu Dh. S. 64. 21 (DrupadƒÉm S√£vitrƒ´m vƒÅ) refers to KƒÅthaka S. 38. 63 (Drupa dƒÅdivonmumucƒÅnah etc. ). Similarly, Vi≈ünu 65. 2 (Asvinoh prƒÅnastau te iti jivudƒÅnam dattva) mentions Kathaka-sam. 11. 17; on Vi. Dh. S. 65. 7 Nandapandita remarks that the four mantras (KƒÅthaka-sa·πÅ. 36. 29-32) are to be recited; Visnu 65. 11 (tejosi sukramiti dipam ) mentions a mantra from KƒÅthaka-sam. I. 33.

Dr. Jolly in his learned and long introduction to the translation of Visuu Dh. S. (SBE. Vol. VII, pp. IX-XXXVII) deals with several problems, some of which have been discussed already. His remarks on some problems will be briefly mentioned here. On p. XXIV (in order to establishi the priority of Vi≈ü≈Üu to the Manusmrti ) he says that the

¬∑ Visnus≈´tra nowhere refers to South Indian nations such as the Dravidas and Andhras or to the Yavanas'. That non mention does not lead to positive conclusions is well illus. trated here. The Andhras are mentioned even in the Aitareya BrƒÅhmana ( 33. 6), where Vi≈õv≈´mitra curses his dis: obedient sons that their offspring will be Audbras, Sabaras and Pundras' &c, ). Asoka in his 13th Rock edict mentions Andhras. On p. XXI Dr. Jolly refers to YƒÅj. II. 240-41 where n≈´naka is mentioned and punishment is provided for one turning out a false nanaka or for fabricating a royal grant, wbile Visnu V. I refers only to royal grants but not to nƒÅnakas. This is put forward by Dr. Jolly as a ground for regarding Vishu as more ancient than YƒÅj. (p. XXI). It has been shown that the Vishudharmasutra professes to be a direct revelation by God Vi≈ü≈Üu to the Earth Goddess and therefore the redactor of Visnu knowing that the DƒÅyaka is of foreign origin omitted that word. Lastly, his view ( Intro. pp. XXV, 1f), following the lead of B√ºhler, that the extunt Manusmrti is an improved metrical edition of the MƒÉnava-dharmas≈´tra (not now available ) will be dealt with later under section 13 ( M√§navadharmas√∫tra: did it exist ?). I agree with Dr. Jolly that some devotee of Vi≈Ü≈Üu recast the original Dharmas√∫tra ( Intro. pp. XXVIII ff). I am in agreement with the view which Dr. Jolly holds that the original Visuudharmas≈´tra was closely connected with the Kathaka SamhitƒÉ. Not only Nanda pandita, but the Krtya kalpataru ( of the first half of 12th century ) relies on the tradition that Vi≈ü≈Üu Dh. S. accorda with LaugƒÅk≈üi-g≈Çby

TITU

  1. Visnudharinaaatta.
125

Dr. Jolly (on pp. XXIX-XXXI of his Introduction) puts forward several considerations as to how and why the chapters were raised to 100, what portions may be regarded 28 old and what were added by the Vi≈ünuite redactor later. I do not agree with everything he says but on the whole his treatment is judicious. He observes that the Vi≈ünuite editor (pp. XXXII ) cannot be placed earlier than 3rd or 4th century A. D. I agree with this.

The original Vinnu Dh, S. ( mostly in prose ) may have to be placed about 300 B. C. to 100 A. D. and the present inflated text about 400 to 600 A. D. Vide two papers of Prof. L. Renou of Paris on Visnu in Journal Asiatique ( 1961) pp. 163-172 ( in French ) and in Bulletin of the D. C. R. I. Vol. 20 parts 1-4 ( in English ) pp. 319-323.

When Dr. Jolly ways that certain chapters of Vi≈ü≈Üu Agree closely with the K√§thakagrhya, all that is meant is that some of the sutras of Visnu are the same or almost the same as those of the Kathakayshya (e. g. compare Visuu 21, 73 and 86 with K√§thakagshya V. 12, V. 9, and V. 3 respectively ). But in all these places Vinnu contains more details than the Kathakagrhya. It may, however, be noted that in a few cases tbe views of the Kathakagshya differ from those of Visnu. For example, Vi≈ünu ( 30.1) speaks of Vedic studies for 44 months only in the year when once they are started on the full-moon day of SrƒÅvana or Bhadrapada, while the KƒÅ»õhakagrhya ( I. 9. 10), gives three alternatives, viz. 442, 5 or 543 months ; Vis≈Üu prescribes that the proper year for the upanayana of a ksatriya is the 11th from conception ( 27.10 ), while the K√§thaka prescribes the 9th, without specifying whether it is to be from conception or birth (IV. 1.2); Vi≈ünu enumerates eight forms of inarriage ( 24. 18), while the K≈´≈£haka (II. 3 and 4 ) speaks of only two, BrƒÅhma and Asura, and is silent about the rest: Visnin ( 46. 19-20 ) defines SƒÅnta pana and Mah√º sauta pana differently from the K≈´thaka (1. 7. 3-4), but agrees with YƒÅj√±a valkya (III. 315-816 ). Here the recent Lahore edition of the K≈´thakagƒºhya by Dr. Caland has been used. As it used Kathaka mantras and borrowed from the KƒÅ»õbakagƒºhya, the dharmas≈´tra may have been ext. book of the KƒÅ»õbaka school and probably originated in Kashmir and Punjab which is the home of the Kath.

12B

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstro

The date of the older portion of Vinnu may be placed between 300 B. C. to 100 B. C. But this is no more than a mere conjecture. It is to be noted that Kum√§rila does not mention the Visnudharmas≈´tra among the s≈´tras studied by particular schools. Then several centuries later on the whole of the s≈´tra was recast from the Vaisnavite point of view and received large additions both in prose and verse. When these additions were made we have no exact means of determining. It is probable that they were not made very long before Visvar≈´pa. At all events the additions were made long after the YƒÅj≈àavalkyasmrti and after the 3rd century. The mention of the week days makes the s≈´tra comparatively a late work. The earliest epigraphic mention of a week-day is in the Eran inscriptiou of 484 A. D. ( vide Fleet’s Gupta inscriptious pp. 88-89 ) and Varahamihira (6th century ) knew the week days well. The Brahmapurana (28. 55) mentions Sunday and the Padmapurƒ´na mentions Thursday ( Brahmakhanda chap. 11. 34 ). The S√ºrya-siddhanta (XII. 6 and 78 ) speaks of the lords of days. Thus ulthough the extant Vi≈ünu–dharmasutra is a late recast, it contains a few doctrines that were held in ancient times. For example, it allows a Brahmana to marry a girl of anyone of the four varnas ( 24. 1 ) and does not inveigh against niyoga as Manu does.

A few of the s√∫tras agree closely with N√§rada. Vide Vi. 7. 10-11 and N√§rada ( RuƒÅdƒÅta verses 136-137 ).

The MitƒÅk≈üarƒ´ quotes all the prose passages of chapters 85-42 and ascribes them to B»ôhadvisnu (on Yaj. 3. 242 ). Similarly, on Yaj. 3. 261 it ascribes Vi. 35. 3-5 to Brhad. visuu. Similarly, the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ (II. p. 298 ) ascribes Vi. 17. 4 ff to B·ªähad-Vi≈ünu. The MitƒÅksarƒÅ (on YƒÅj. 3. 267 ) quotes a verse of Vrddha-Vi≈ünu which summarises some sutras of Vi≈Ü≈Üu”? (50.6 and 12-14).

In the AnandƒÅ≈õrama collection of smytis there is a Laghu-Vinnusm·∫∑ti in five chapters and 114 verses dealing with the duties of the varras and the four asramas. AparƒÅrka in his commentary on YƒÅj. 3. 238 quotes four

  1. The Dharmas√§tra of Harita

127

verses from Laghu-Vi≈ünu, which are not found in the Anand√°srama text. So AparƒÅrka used some other work or perhaps a larger work. The ParƒÅsara-M√ºdhaviya often quotes gadya-Visnu and padya-Vis≈Üu. The former from a quotation in vol. I. part 2, p. 234 seems to be the Vis≈Üu dharma sutra itself. In the SarasvativilƒÅsa numerous s≈´tras of Visnu with the explanations of Bharuci thereon are quoted, which are not found in the printed Vi≈ünu.118

The Visnu-dharmas≈´tra was commented upon by Nanda pandita, author of several works on dharma≈õƒÅstra, who wrote at Benares the commentary called Vaijayanti (accord ing to certain m8s.) in 1679 (i. e. 1622-23 A. D.) of the Vikrama era. Dr. Jolly publishes extracts from this commen tary in his edition of the sutra.

From the fact that the Sarasvativilisa quotes several times the sutras of Visnu with BhƒÅruci’s explanation, it looks probable that Bharuci commented upon the Visnudharma sutra. For further information on Bharuci vide sec. 61.

So far only the printer and well-known Jharmas≈´tras have been passed under review. But there were numerous other dharmas≈´tras which are either noir extant in rare m88. or are not yet discovered but are only to be reconstructed from quotations. It is now time to discuss them.

  1. The Dharmasutra of Harita That HƒÅrƒ´ta was an ancient s≈´trakƒÅra on dharma is quite patent from the fact that the dhurmasitras of Baudh√•. yana, Apastamba and Vasi≈ütha quote him as an authority.

History of Dharmasastra

Harita’s view is quoted by Baud. Dh. S. II. 1. 50, which differs from the view propounded in Baud. Dh. S. II. 1. 49; Ap. Dh. S. refers to HƒÅrita in I. 13. 11, I. 18. 2, I. 19. 12, I. 28 1, 5 and 16, I. 29. 12 (which is the same as quoted in Baud. Dh. S. II. 1. 49 ). Vasistha quotes Harita in II. 6 ( a verse the first half of which is in Manu 2. -71 and the 2nd balf in Manu II, 172 and in Vapaparva 180. 35). Vide also Baud. Dh. S. I. 2. 7 ( whieb is almost the same verse as in Vas. II. 6 and seems to be a quotation as ‘iti’ is added at the end. Apagtamba quotes Harita more frequently than any other author. From this it may be concluded that they belonged to the same Veda. The TantravƒÅrtika (vide note 55 above) mentions H√§rita along with Gautama and other s≈´trakƒÅras on dharma. From Visvar√ºpa down to the latest writers on dharma≈õƒÅstra HƒÅrita is most profusely quoted. From the quotations it appears that his dharmas≈´tra was perhaps the most extensive of all dharmas√∫tras.

Dr. S. C. Banerjee contributed to the Journal of Oriental Institute’ Baroda Vol. VIII, No. 1 (1958) pp. 14-37 & reconstruction of Harita-dharmas√∫tra and in his recent publication on Dharmas≈´tras' devotes pp. 257-289 to prose passages alone from HƒÅrƒ´ta quoted in several nibandhas on all topics of Dharma≈õƒÅstra arranged in Sankrit alphabeti cal order but transliterated in English characters. In pp. 239-244 he mentions twentyfour authors as writers of Dharmas≈´tras with brief notes on each and in pp. 244-344 he sets out transliterated prose sutras from these 24 writers and omits passages from Sankha-likhita because I collected passages from them in ABORI. Vol. VII-VIII ( vide p. 84 above) and onnits B»ôhaspati also since the late Prof. Ranga swami Aiyangar extracted passages of B·ªãhaspati quoted in nibandhas, arranged them under different topics and publish ed them in the G. O.S., Baroda (1941 ).

The late Pandit Vamansastri Islampurkar discovered at Nasik a ms. of the Harita-dharmasitra. It was not possible for me to make use of it for the present work. Dr. Jolly (in R. und S. pp. 8-9) gives an account of the mg. from which I give a summary. It is so faulty that an edition based on it alone cannot be thought of. The ms. contains thirty chapters. So far as the language and content are concerned the work impresses one as ancient, but the materia) citations ascribed to H√§rita in later digests or court

POONS

TIT

  1. The Dharmas≈´tra of HƒÅrƒ´ta

1

129

procedure and the law of crimes &c. are not found in the m8. The prose is mixed up with verses in Anustubh and Tristubh metres, which are often introduced with the characteristic words “athƒÅpyudƒÅharanti” as in other dharmas≈´tras. The m8. quotes ‘bhagavƒÅn MaitrƒÅyani’ and the verse " SatadƒÅyo viro‚Äù which is Maitriyaniya SamhitƒÉ 1. 7. 5. Dr. Caland points out remarkable correspondence between the citations of HƒÅrƒ´ta and the MaitrƒÅyaniya Parisista and M√§nava. Sraddhakalpa. All this tends to show that he was a s√ºtra kƒÅra of the Black Yajurveda. The numerous quotaticns from HƒÅrƒ´ta in Apastamba and BandhƒÅyana are not, however, found in the ms. The ms. was found at Nasik, which is also the source of two mss. of the MaitrƒÅyaniya SamhitƒÅ. The Kashmirian word kaphella' is cited in Harita and 80 the H√§rita-dharmas√∫tra probably originated there. HemƒÅdri ( Caturvarga III. 1. p. 559 ) mentions a commentator (bhƒÉ»ôyak√°ra 118 ) of HƒÅrƒ´ta.

From the numerous quotations from HƒÅrita in the nibandhas it appears that the dharmas√ºtra dealt exhaus. tively with the same topics as are dealt with in other dharma s≈´tras, viz. sources of dharma, brahmac√°rin of two kinds ( upakurvƒÅna and naisthika ), anataka, the householder, the forest hermit, prohibitions about food, impurity on birth and death, ≈õr√•ddha, the parktipƒÅvana, geueral rules of con duct, the five yaj√±as, Vedic study and holidays, duties of kings, rules of statecraft, court procedure, the various titles of law, duties of husband and wife, various kinds of sins, prƒÅyascittas, expiatory prayers &c.

According to Kull≈´ka (on Manu 2. 1) the HƒÉrita-dharma sutra opened with the words ‘now then we shall explain dharma; dharma is based upon revealed texts ( fruti); revealed texts are of two kinds, the Vedic and the T√¢ntric’.126

119 The s≈´tra of HƒÅrita is ‘q -oppia atar-fra 4-aralan

976277: ‘. 120 ‘‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§¨‡•à‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã

FOUNDED

180

History of Dharmasastra

Sruti is of two kinds viz. Vaidiki (consisting of the Veda ) and TƒÅntriki (consisting of Tantra )’. I did not explain this last word. Now I realise that the word is liable to be misunderstood. A veteran scholar like Dr. R. C. Hazra went so far as to suggest (in I. H. Q. Vol. 36 pp. 141-150 ) that by T√¢ntriki' I meant the system of Tantras (developed several centuries later than the Dharmas≈´tras ) dealing with Mantras, secret practices and esoteric teachings of gurus and that HƒÅrita did not know the tautras that were & later development altogether. I agree that the Haritadharmasutra did not use the word TƒÅntriki in the sense in which the word

Tantra is used in much later times. But as the text of Harita was not available, I could not dilate on that point and did not state what he must have meant by T√¢ntriki sruti.

I was then concerned only with the contents of the HƒÅrƒ´tadharmas≈´tra available from quotations in late works on Dharma≈õƒÅstra. H√§rita gave a wider meaning to Sruti than what other ancient s≈´tras and smrtis give to the word. In Gaut. Dh. S. I. 1-2 it is stated that the Veda is the source of dharma and also the sm·ªôtis and usages of those who know the Veda. Manu (II. 6) says the same thing and in 11. 10 asserts that Sruti means Veda and Smrti means Dharma sƒÅstra. H√§rita as quoted by Kull≈´ka widens the meaning of Sruti, as including Veda and also something more. But as that point has been now raised I shall try to explain briefly what he probably meant by TƒÅntriki (Sruti). The word Tantra is a Vedic one. It occurs in √¶g. X. 71. 9 ( siris-tantram tanvate aprajaj√±aya·∏•). Tantra here appears to mean ‘loom’ and the word is derived from the root ‘tan’ to spread or stretch. PƒÅ·πáini in VII. 2. 9 derives the word from the root ‘tan’ with affix ‘tra’ and in another s≈´tra (V. 2. 70 ) states that ‘tantraka’ means cloth recently taken off from a loom. The Amara kosa gives four meanings of tantra', one of which is ‘siddhƒÅnta’ (a system of thought or philosophy ). HƒÉrita’s idea appears to have been that a work dealing with the formulation of principles based on the Veda ( and hence called

‚Ä¢ T√¢ntriki' from the word tantra meaning siddhanta ) might be designated Sruti. It would be clear from the NyƒÅyas≈´tra ( I. 1. 27-31 ) that SƒÅnkhya and Yoga may be called ‘samda tantra’ though they differ on certain points. Similarly the ArthasƒÅstra may be called SamƒÅna-tantra with the Manak smrti, es both have certain principles in common, though

FOUNDEA 7

  1. The Dharmas√∫tra of Harita

131

they differ in other matters. It may be noted in this conneo tion that the word ‘tantra’ is applied to the SƒÅrkhya system by SƒÅnkarƒÅcƒÅrya (in his blƒÅsya on VedƒÅntas≈´tra II. 2. 1) and the PurvamimamsƒÉ system is styled by him as prathama tantra' in his bhƒÅsya on VedƒÅnta-s≈´tra III. 3. 53. The SƒÅ≈àkhya-kƒÅrikƒÅ refers to itself as ‘tantra’ in K√§rikƒÅ 70 ‘tena ca bahudh√§ k·ªátam tantram’. B»ôhaspati as quoted by A parƒÅrka p. 740 says that a wife is called half of a man in AmnƒÅya' (Veda ) and Smrtitantra'. So HƒÅrƒ´ta Dharma. sutra understands the word ‘tantra’ as meaning a b√§stra based on Veda'. The ArthasƒÅstra of Kautilya sets out in the 15th adhikaranu ‘tantra-yuktis’. Vide for further details on the meaning oftantra‚ÄôH. of Dh. Vol. V. pp. 1031-3.

The quotations show that this style ( as in n. 120 ) was pursued in the body of the work. AparƒÅrka (on YƒÅj. III. 322) quotes a s≈´tralal in a similar style about a penance TulƒÅ puru≈üa' said to have been promulgated by Siva himself. H√§rita-s≈´tra often introduces verses as quotations with the words “an author says thus” (evam hyƒÅha ; vide Apar≈´rka on YƒÅj. I. 83, I. 154, 1II. 135, VivƒÅda-ratnƒÅkarƒÉ pp. 443, 626 ). Numerous passages quoted as HƒÅrita’s are identical with passages from other dharma≈õƒÅstra works. The sutra ‘JƒÅyƒÅ patyor-na vibhƒÅgo vidyate’ is quoted as from H√§rƒ´ta by the SmrticandrikƒÅ (II. p. 268 ), which is the same as Ap. Dh. S. II. 6. 14. 16. The same work quotes ‘pratyak≈üavidhƒÅnƒÅd g√§rhasthyasya’ as from HƒÅrita which is part of Gautama. 3. 35. A verse about the enormity of usury quoted in the Smsticandrik√§ (1. p. 177 ) as HƒÅrƒ´ta’s is almost the same as BaudhƒÅyana ( I. 5. 79 ) and Vasi≈ütha( 2. 42). A verse about atipƒÅtakins (quoted by AparƒÅrka on YƒÅj. III. 231 ) is the game as Vishu 34. 2. Manu is mentioned by name in several verses (vide Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ III. p. 436, VivƒÅda-ratnƒÅkare p. 552-553). Two verses are cited in the VyavahƒÅratattve of Ragbunandana as found in HƒÅrƒ´ta, BaudhƒÅyana (I. 10. 30 ) and Manu (8. 18-19). A verse quoted by the Sm≈üticandrika ( II. p. 21 ) is almost the same as Manu 8. 95. Several times

Some of the doctrines of HƒÅrƒ´ta are worth noting.   1. The Dharmasutra of Harita

188

He speaks of the twelve kiuds of sops ( vide Haradatta on Gautama 28. 32). He looks down upon the profession of an actor and forbids the employment of a BrƒÅhmana actor in any ≈õrƒÅddha or rite for gods.128 A HƒÅrƒ´tabhƒÅsyakƒÅra is mention ed by the Kalpataru ( ≈õrƒÅddha ) on p. 51 in explaining a prose passage. Apararka (on Yaj. II. 332 ) quotes from HƒÅrita a lengthy passage in mixed prose and verse, where the worship of Ganesa comes in.128

A very interesting question is the relatiou of the verse quotations from Harita with the prose quotations from Harita The dharmas≈´tra was probably interspersed with verses as is the case more or less with all dharmas≈´tras except that of Gautama. But there are numerous verses ascribed to Harita in the nibandhus, which are manifestly modern. Both the MitƒÅk≈üarƒ´ and AparƒÅrka (on YƒÅj. I. 86 ) quote HƒÅrƒ´ta’s verses eulogisivg the satƒ´. The SmrticandrikƒÅ ( III. p. 344 ) quotes his verses that refer to the signs of the Zodiac. There are numerous verses coutaining elaborate rules of procedure, ascribed to H≈´rƒ´ta, which are quite foreigo to the general atmosphere of the ancient dharmas≈´tras. All such verses must be escribed to a comparatively later date. In the Suddhima y√ºkha it is said that certain verses quoted from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata by H√§rita are not found in several copies of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata.

The Dharmas≈´tra of HƒÅrƒ´ta appears to have been a very extensive one and was iu mixed prose and verse. AparƒÅrk& quotes both prose and verse passages over 110 times, one remarkable matter being that the quotations on VyavahƒÅra are only a few (both iu verse and prose ). The Kalpataru contains a very large number of prose and verse quotations from HƒÉrita. It would be a great service if some scholar collected all the quotations ( prose and verse ) cited in the Kalpataru with notes. They are profuse and some are very interesting. In the BrahmacƒÉrikƒÅnda he is quoted over .50 times and there are very large prose passages on pp. 198, 268, 271, 277 (on three kinds of spƒÅtakas ). The

The latter is professedly a Vaisnavite work, said to have been proclaimed by HƒÅrƒ´ta to Ambarisa; it is divided into eight chapters and contains about 2600 verses, dealing with the nityu and nuinittiku rites of the vurnus and asramas, the nature of the individual and Supreme Self and the means of attaining hvok≈ü%.   1. The Dharmas√∫tra of Harita

186

described as Manu. and Vrddha-Manu, Yajnavalkya and VrddhayƒÅj√±avalkya and the like were not entirely different individuals, but they were the same authors at different stages of their lives. Vide AparƒÅrka (pp. 7-8) on Vrddha

Manu and the Kalpataru (BrahmacƒÅri¬∞ ) quoted below.120b

That the Vrddha-Hirita in verse is comparatively a late work follows from the fact that it distinctly recites that the smrtis of Manu, YƒÅj√±avalkya, NƒÅrada and KƒÅtyƒÅyana were known to it as authorities on raja-dharma.130 Some of the quotations ascribed to Laghu-HƒÅrƒ´ta in Apar√§rka and other works are found in the Laghu-Harita, e. g. the verse ‚Äîvina yajiiopavitena ' (Laghu-Hirita, Anandisrama, verse 23 ) is quoted by AparƒÅrka on Yij. III. 289. Some verses that are ascribed to HƒÅrƒ´ta are found in the Laghu-HƒÅrƒ´ta; for example, the verge ‘snƒÅnam k·πõtvƒÅ tu ye,’ cited by the Smrticandrika (I. p. 203), occurs in the Laghu-Harita ( AnandƒÅ≈°raina, verse 41 ). It appears that several compila tions were made at different times, embracing different topics of dharma and ascribed to HƒÅrƒ´ta, probably because they were based more or less on the HƒÅrƒ´tadharmas√∫tra.

That some of the verses ascribed to HƒÅrita are very anci ent follows from several considerations. For example, Visva r≈´pa quotes (on YƒÅj. III. 246 ) a verse from HƒÅrƒ´ta. The

(‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡•¶ p. 24 ). Vido KrtyaratnƒÅkara pp. 29-30 for similar words. 130 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®

History of DharmajƒÅstra

SarasvativilƒÅsa quotes from Harita a brief passage which appears to be a portion of a verse and Katyayana’s explana tion thereon.131 It follows that long before the sixth century A. D. HƒÅrƒ´ta’s Dh. S. contained verses.

For HƒÅrita on VyavahƒÅra, vide sec. below.

Dr. S. C. Banerjee in J. O. I. ( Baroda ) vol. VIII pp. 14-37 ( 1958 ) published a collection of passages of HƒÅrita dharina-sutra ( transliterated ) from 21 works ( holding the different parts of the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ as separate works ), but without any translation or notes.

If all passages of HƒÅrƒ´ta quoted in the several nibandhas were collected and carefully studied it would be found that several verses are common to it and Manu and other sm·ªôti kƒÅras. For example, Kalpataru (op Grhastha ) p. 43, noted that the verse Vrsalƒ´phenapƒ´tasya' is common to Manu, Yama and H≈´rƒ´ta (it is Manu IV. 19). The same k√§nda on p. 310 quotes with the word (‘evam hyƒÅha’) three verses one of which ( pa√±ca pa≈õvanyte hanti) is the same as Manu VIII. 98.

  1. The Dharmasutra of Sankha-Likhita From the TantravƒÅrtika we learn (note 55 above ) that the Dharmas≈´tra of Sankha-Likhita was specially studied by the VƒÅjasaneyins ( the followers of the white Yajurveda ). The TantravƒÅrtika also quotes a few words from thnt Dhar. mas≈´tra which constitute an Anustubh pada.138 The Mah√° bhƒÅrata ( in S√§ntiparvan, chap. 23. 18-43 ) narrates the story of the two brothers, Sankha and Likhita, who resided in sepa rate dwellings surrounded by trees. Once Likhita came to the √°brama ( hermitage ) of Sankha in his absence. He took some ripe fruits from some of the trees of Sarkba’s a≈õrama and ate them. While he was eating, Saikha came and asked him where he got the fruits. Likhita smiled and told his brother that he took them from his trees. Then Sarkha got angry and told his brother that he was guilty of theft and asked

him to go to the king Sudyumna for punishment. Likhits went to the king who would not punish him as he was a man of pure character and learned ; wheu he persisted the king ordered his hands to be cut off. His arms were restored when he plunged into the river BƒÅhud√£. In Santi ( 130.29 ) 132a it is said It is not possible to live if one adopts Sankhalikhita mode of life, particularly when one intends to secure the pro tection of the subjects.' In another place (Santiparvan 132. 15-16 ) it is said ‘Some hold that conduct or practice is the best characteristic of dharma, others to whom Sankha-Likbita are dear do not like them.’ Vide SabhƒÅparva 7. 11 where among the holy sages who graced Iudra’s sabhii are included Saijkha and Likhita.

In the PƒÅli DighanikƒÅya II. 40-41 we have the words “Sakhalikhita - brahmacariyam caritum'. Prof. Bapat in the Silver Jubilee Vol. of BORI. ( 1942 pp. 61-66 ) tries hard to prove that the words Nayidam sukaram agƒÅramajjhi vasatƒÅ ekƒÅntaparipumpam ek√§ntaparisuddham Sankha likhitam-brahmacariyam caritum' occurring in the Dighani. kƒÅya (2nd sutta, 40-41 ) have nothing to do with the Dharmas≈´trakƒÅras. The word ‘brahmacariyam’ does not mean in Pali books the life of a Vedic student, but only a pure moral life here (that was to be led by a student in brahmanical society ). But the words quoted from the Digha are just like the words quoted by me above from the MahƒÅbharata (Santi 130. 29 ). My own idea is ( whatever the date of Sakha-likhita as writers may be ) that the Pali story is based on the story in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. It is not unlikely that the two had led or emphasized an excellent moral life. Thereafter, the redactors of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata included them in a story in the Santiparva and the Pali

198

History of Dharmasastra

!

writers included the gist of that story in their works. Just as it is difficult to assign a definite date to the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata, so also it is impossible or at least as difficult to say (there being no reliable evidence) that all the NikƒÅyas existed in writing before Asoka. YƒÅj≈àavalkya ( I. 5) mentions Sankha Likhita among the writers on dharma≈õƒÅstra. The ParƒÅsara smrti says (I. 24 ) that in the four ages of K·ªáta, TretƒÅ, Dv√§para and Kali, the ordinances of Manu, Gautama, Sarkha-Likhita and ParƒÅ≈õara are respectively of paramount authurity in matters of dharma. Visvar≈´pa (on YƒÅj. III. 248 ) quotes a verse from an ancient author which says that Sankha and Likhita pondered deeply over the dharma promulgated to the sages by Manu and drew upon the Veda188 also. From the gist of the passages of Sarkha Likbita quoted by Vi≈õvar≈´pa and the words ‚ÄòPratij√±ƒÅtƒÅrtha virodhah syƒÅt' it appears to have been the view of Visvar≈´pa that the verse quoted was the first verse (or one of several verses at the beginning) of the s≈´tra of Sarkha-Likhita. The word Manu-bhƒÅsitam’in note 133 was either introduced by some redactor at a later date or the word does not refer to the extant Mapu, but to some earlier version of it. Commenta tors and nibandhakaras from Visvar≈´pa downwards profusely quote Sarkha-Likhita. A considerable portion of these quota tions is in prose. Hence it is quite clear that the dharma s≈´tra of Sankha–Likhita is an ancient one, that it was largely if not entirely in prose and that it was once easily accessible though it has not yet been discovered. In the Annals of the Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute (vol. VII-VIII) I made an attempt at a reconstruction of Sanka-Likhita.

Jivananda (collection of smrtis, part II, pp. 343-374 ) prints in 18 chapters and about 330 verses a smrti of Sankha and a smrti of Likhita in about 93 verses ( part II., pp. 375‚Äì 382 ). The AnandƒÅ≈õrama collection also prints the same text of the two smrtis. The latter also contains a Laghu-Sarkha smrti in 71 verses and a Sarkha-Likhita-smrti in 32 verses. All these, except perhaps the Sankha-smrti in 18 chapters, are late compilations. The smrti in 18 chapters seems to have been compiled very early. About fifty verses from it are quo

  1. The Dharmas≈´tra of sarkha-Likhita

139

ted by the MitƒÅksarƒ´. In the 11th and 12th chapters occur a few prose passages, one of which is quoted even by Medha tithi. The numerous prose quotations ascribed to Sankha Likhita do not however occur in these sm·ªôtis. One point deserves special notice. Comparatively early writers some times ascribe the same text to Sankha-Likhita or to Sankha simply. The well-known s≈´tra about succession to a son less man ( athƒÅputrasya svaryƒÅtasya bhrƒÅtrgƒÅmi dravyam &c. ) is ascribed to Sankha by Vi≈õvar≈´pa and the M·ªãtƒÅk·π£arƒÅ, but to Sankha-Likhita by AparƒÅrka (on YƒÄj. II. 135-136 ). Similarly, the s≈´tra ‘pitaryasakte kutumbavyavahƒÅrƒÅn jyes tha·∏• ‘&c. is ascribed to Saikha by AparƒÅrka and to Sankha Likhita by the VivƒÅda-ratnƒÅkara, DƒÅyatattva and Madana parijata. Quotations ascribed to Likhita are few and far bet ween. Some passages are ascribed by some writers to Sankha and by others to Likhita. For example, a prose passage

Uddhrtya pariksitƒÅbhi·∏•’ &c. is ascribed to Likhita by Apa r√•rka ( on YƒÅj. I. 18 ) and to Sankha by Visvar≈´pa (on Y√°j. I. 20 . and by the Viramitrodaya ( ƒÄhnika prakƒÅ≈õa p. 68). Similarly, the sutra ‘ubh√°bhyamapi hastƒÅbhyƒÅm prƒÅnmukho devatirthena kuryƒÅt’ is ascribed to Sankha–Likhita- by the PƒÅrƒÅ≈õaramadhaviya : I. 1. p. 352 ) and to Likhita by A parƒÅrka (on YƒÅj. I. 101). The relation of the Sankha-smrti in verse to the dharmas≈´tra of Sankha seems to be this. The former is based upon the latter and is a versified paraphrase or adaptation of portions of the dharmas√∫tra. 134

The versified Sarkha shows a tendency towards greater strictness. The dhormus≈´tra allows a BrƒÅhmana to marry a woman of any of the four castes, while the verse Sankha resti icts him to the first three custes. 136 It is not unlikely that the dharmas≈´tra contained a few verses as is the case with BaudhƒÅyana, Apastamba and Vasi≈ütha. writer as Visvar≈´pa looked upon the prose and verse portions as the composition of the same author (vide his comment on YƒÅj. III 237, and AparƒÅrka pp. 1149, 1154, 1161 ).

The dharmasutra of Sankha-Likbita was commented upon early. Laksmidhara in his Kalpataru (Ghose’s Hindu Law vol. II. p. 504 ) draws attention to the fact that the bhƒÅsya kƒÅra of Sarkha read a well-known s≈´tra as ‘sa yadyeka·∏• syat’ instead of ‘sa yadyekaputra·∏• syƒÅt. ' Vide Kalpataru ( vyavahƒÅrakƒÅnda ) p. 654 (sa yadyekaputra·∏• syƒÅt ) and f. n. 6. Lak≈ümidhara flourished between 1100-1160 A. D. as he was a minister of Govindacandra of Kanauj. The VivƒÅda ratnƒÅkara ( 1314 A. D.) also cites the bh√¢syak√§ra of Sankha… Likbita. The VivƒÅdacintƒ´ma≈Üi (p. 67 ) quotes from the bba≈üyakƒÅra of Sarkha-Likhita.

The dharnas≈´tra of Sankha-Likhita would appear, from the quotations in the nibundhus, to have closely resembled the other extant s≈´tras on dharma in style and contents. It embraced almost all the topics treated of in Gautama or Apastamba. It agrees very closely with the words of Gau tama and BaudbƒÅyana in several places.138 It is curious to note that a quotation from Sankha containing the names of writers of smrtis cites Sarkha-Likhita as authority. 137

The dharmas≈´tra seems to have permitted niyoga, speaks of twelve secondary sons, and did not favour (like Apastamba ) the claims of females to succeed to males. On certain points the dharmas≈´tra of Sarkha marks a more advanced state of opinion than is the case with Gautama or Apastamba. Sarkha speaks of several kinds of ordeals and appears to have contained elaborate prose rules about thern (vide AparƒÅrka on YƒÅj. II, 95; Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ II, p. 112, Viramitrodaya, p. 270). As regards partition and inheritance, 136 Compare anunfalanteriet’ ( quotud in otco, 1f670, p. 452 )

with tit. 9. q. 1. 39‚Äì42 ; ' ATS√ÄI' (quoted by 3921 on

TET. I. 195 ) with it. 7. . I. 41-43 ; ' faget gaat AETATE'

( angetto III. 1, p. 977 ) with ott. 17. . 1. . 15. 137 ‘‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∂‡§®‡§Ü‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨.

‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞ 24:1 quoted in agat. I. p. 527; Eto RA1910 pood waa, ( 3114 Do 1).

ISTITUV

<

NDEN

  1. The Dharnas≈´tra of Sarkha-Likhita 141 Sakha-Likhita gives more detailed information than Apastamba or BaudhƒÅyana. The limits of Ary√§varta188 stretched over wide areas according to Sankha (i. e. to the east of Sindhu-Sauvƒ´ra and to the west of KƒÅmpilya ) than is the case with BaudhƒÅyana ( I. 1. 25 ) or Vasistha ( I. 8-9). The style of Sarkha reminds one of Kautilya rather than of Gautama. The quotations hardly exhibit any upgrammatical forms. It is noteworthy that YƒÅj√±avalkya is included among the authors of smitis by Sarkha ( vide note 137 ). If it is the extant Yajnavalkya-smrti that is meant to be referred to, then the dharmasutra of Sankha will have to be assigned to u late date. But this does not seem to be likely. From the fact that the YƒÅj√µuvalkya-smrti itself enumerates Sankha Likhita anong ancient authors on dharna, from the general style of the work, from the development of the legal concep tions it presents and from its doctrines about the rights of women, it appears almost certain that the extant YƒÅj√±a vulkya-smrti is much later than the dharmas≈´tra of Sankhu. There are close correspondences between Sarkha and YƒÅjfia valkyu.138 Saikha is quoted 99 times and Sajjkha-Likhita 63 times by Apararka. Ou Y√ºj. 111. 289-90 (p. 1154 ) Apa rƒÅrka first quotes Sarkha as ‘AgnyutgƒÅdi samvatsarum CƒÅndrƒÅya·πáam cared-gam ca dadyat’ and five lines after wards quotes Saikha-likhita with the words ‘AgnyutsƒÅdi mithyƒÅdhiti ca sarivatsarain br√§bmanagrhesu bhaiksyam caretƒÅm’. Kalpataru (Brahmac√°ri) quotes Sankha-Likhita 36 times, and Sarkha 19 times. From the fact that Sankha Likhita is quoted as including Sankha-Likhita among writers on Dbarma≈õƒÅstras it may be inferred that the original text was tampered with by some redactor. Kalpataru on Vyavah√°ra (pp. 830-31 ) cites a long prose passage of Sankha-Likhita on the proper avocations of the men of eleven mixed castes viz.

S≈´ta, K≈üats, MƒÅgadha, Ambastha, Vaidehaka, Ugra, Vena, Kukkuta, Ayogava, Pulkaya and Ni≈üƒÅda (compare Vi≈ünu dharmas≈´tra 16. 7-13 and Manu X. 47-50 ) and on p. 833 cites the avocations of CandƒÅla, ≈övapaca, dasyu and mleccha ganas.

The prose quotations from Sankha-Likhita refer to the VedƒÅngas, S√§nkhya, Yoga, Dharma≈õƒÅstra. Sankha recogni sed eight forms of marriage. The views of Sankha about the status of the offspring of mixed marriages differed from those of BaudhƒÅyana (1. 8. 6 ) and Manu (X. 6) and were inter mediate between the latter two.140 The tarparu141 ( which resembles the one in Baudhayana, though it is more elaborate) refers to the six VedƒÅngas, BhƒÅrata ( but not MahƒÅ-bhƒÅrata ), to twenty writers on dharma and contains numerous details about geography, mythology, and cosmogony which are gene rally found in the PurƒÅnas. The dharmasutra frequently cites the opinions of others. It mentious by name the views of PrajƒÅpati, Angirasa and Usanas ( Viv√•daratnƒÅkara p. 537 ), PrƒÅcetasa (VivƒÅdarat. p. 557-560 ), V·ªäddha-Gautama ( Mada na-pƒÅrijƒÅta pp. 701-2). The verse quotations ascribed to Sankha further mention Yama, K√°ty√°yava and Sankha him self. But in drawing chronological conclusions it is better to leave the verse quotations out of account. The saine verses are ascribed to Manu and Sankha242 and a few s≈´tras closely resemble the Manusinfti.143 Six identical verses occur in the Vasistha-dharmas≈´tra (21. 10-15) and in the Sankha smrti ( 10th chap. ).

All these circumstances lead to the conclusion that the dharmas√∫tra of Sankha is probably later than Gautama and Apastamba but earlier than the YƒÅj≈àavalkya-smrti and 80 must be assigned to some date between 300 B.C. to 100 A. D.
