  1. MƒÅnavadharmasutra-Did it exist?

143

  1. MƒÅnavadharmasutra-Did it exist ? Following the orthodox view of Western Sanskrit scho lars that most of the dharinas≈´tras are older than almost all, if not all, the metrical smrtis, I gave the first place of honour to the dharmasutras of Gautama and others. But my own views differ to a great exteut from those of the orthodox school of Sanskritists represented by Max M√ºller and B√ºbler. It is high time to state here my views about the existence of a M√§nava-dharma-s≈´tra supposed to be the original of our extant Manu.

Some western scholars, particularly Max M√ºller and Weber, started the ingenious theory that the extant Manu. smrti was a recast or remodelling of an ancient M√§navadhar mas≈´tra. Max M√ºller went so far as to enunciate the bold generalisation ‚ÄúThere can be no doubt, however, that all the genuine dharma-s√°stras which we possess now, are without any exception, nothing but more modern texts of earlier s≈´tra works on kuladharmas belonging originally to certain Vedic caranas” (H. A. S. L. pp. 134-135). For this sweeping gene ralisation there were very few data when it was made, as is admitted by Bihler. This theory of Max M√ºller was as hasty, as unfounded and as uncritical as several other theo. ries of his such as that about the renaissance of Sanskrit Lite rature in the early centuries of the Christian era, about the absence of the art of writing in India before PƒÅnini and about the uniform employment of the sloka for literary purposes in his so-called s≈´tra period and earlier. Western Scholars had to give up such theories before the stern logic of facts, but they have tenaciously clung to the theory about the Manu smrti being a recast of the M√§navadharmas≈´tra. One of the main planks of Max M√ºller’s edifice was the now exploded theory about the non-employment of the anustubh during the s≈´tra period ( which he tentatively placed between 600 B. C.-200 B. C. ) for continuous composition. In spite of the fact that one of the main planks has totally collapsed B√ºhler makes strenuous efforts to rehabilitate Max M√ºller’s theory by additional a priori arguments (S. B. E. vol. 25, PPA XVIII-XXIII and xxxI-XXXIX). The main points brought forward by B√ºhler are:-(I) The Vasistha Dh. S. (IV. 5 contains four s≈´tras, the first of which is The M√§nava sayan that one may kill an animal only in honouring the Mones, gode

144

History of Dharmasastra

and guests'. There follow two verses and a passage in prose with iti at the end. Buhler argues that all the four s√ªtras are quotations and as the extant Manusmrti is in verse, they must be regarded as taken from the M√§navadharma s≈´tra. (II) There are other quotations in Vasintha attributed to Manu which either contradict the present Manusmrti or have no counterpart in the latter. B√ºhler draws special attention to the fact that Vasistha (19, 37) quotes & M√§nava Sloka which is not in the anustubh metre and which has nothing corresponding to it in the extant Manusmrti. (III) A fragment of Uganas quotes an opinion of Manu about impurity, which is in prose.144 B√ºbler himself points out that here one ins. reads ‘Sumantu·∏•’ for ‘Manuh’. Therefore, this argument is of very little use in establi shing the existence of a M√§navadharmas≈´tra. Besides, it is possible that the mutilated passage is not a quotation at all, but a mere summary of Manu’s views. There is no ‘iti’ at the end to show that it is a quotation. (IV) KƒÅmanda kiya.nƒ´tisƒÅra (II. 3) says that according to the MƒÅnavas the villyas to be studied by a king are three, viz. the three Vedas, VƒÅrtƒÅ, and Dandaniti and that what is called Anviksiki is but a branch of trayƒ´; while the Manusmrti ( 7. 43 ) appear to reyard the four as distinct vidyas,148 Kimandaka (XI. 67 ) says that Manu prescribed that the council of ministers should consist of twelve ;146 while Manu (7. 54 ) says that the * 8ucivas' should be seven or eight. Biihler therefore argues that Kimandaka has in mind the Minavadharmas≈´tra and

145

not the Manusmrti and on the word ‘MƒÅnavah’ makes the following observations ‘It is a very common practice of Indian authors to refer in this manner to the books restricted to special schools. But I know of no case where the doctrines of the MƒÅnavadharma≈õƒÅstra or of any other work, which is destined for all Aryans and acknowledged as authoritative by all, are cited in the same or similar way’ (S. B. E. vol. 25, p. XXXVIII). In the first place it has to be noted that K≈´man daka is only paraphrasing the words of Kautilya in the above two places.147 Further, it is noteworthy that KƒÅmandaka employs the word ‘Manuh’ while Kautilya uses the word

MƒÅnavƒÅ·∏•’ (about the number of ministers). Therefore, acco rding to the KƒÅmandakiyanƒ´tisƒÅra there was no difference between the two. viz. the words “Manuli' and ‘MƒÅna v√§h’ denoted the same thing, a work. What B√ºhler means by his emphasis on the word “MƒÅnav√§h' is not quite clear. Early writers like KumƒÅrila and Visvar≈´pa employ the word ‘M√§na vam’ with reference to the Manusmrti just as they use the word V√•sigtham to denote the V√ºsisthadharmas≈´tra (vide Tantra-vƒÅrtika pp. 167, 194 and Visvar≈´pa on YƒÅj. III. 245 and 257). Sankara in his bhƒÅsya on Br. Upanisad I. 4. 17 applies the word . M√§nava' to the Manusmrti MƒÅnave ca sarvƒÅ pravrttih k≈´mahetukyeveti' ( referring to Manu 11. 4). Besides, there is hardly any conflict between the views of the M√°navas and the Manusmrti on the point of the number of the vidyƒÅs. The M√§navas knew that Anviksiki was counted as a fourth vidyƒÅ but said that it was really comprehended in the study of the Vedas. The Manusm»ôti only lays down from whom the vidyƒÅs were to be learnt. As regards the number of ministers, we cannot afford to forget that the Manusmrti (7.60 ) allows more ministers than seven or eight. Another explanation also is possible. In the final remodelling of the Manusmrti from its original in verse it is not unlikely that a few changes were made. (V) On the strength of the preser vation of the complete set of the s≈´tra works of Apastamba on srauta, grbya and dharma (also of BaudhƒÅyana and Hira ·ª•yakesin ), it is urged that the MƒÅnava carana had a s≈´tia on dharma. and the MƒÅnava-grlyas≈´tra (edited by Dr. Knauer in 1897 and recently in the Gaikwad Oriental Series) are extant. B√ºhler admits (S. B. E. vol. 25, p. XXXVIII) that the main pillars of his arguments are the quotations ascribed to Manu in the Vasi≈üthadharmas≈´tra.

The four s≈´tras of Vasistha (IV. 5-8 ) which are the sheet anchor of B√ºhler’s argument have been dealt with above under Vasi≈ütha (pp. 102 ff). If, as B√ºhler says, the four s≈´tras are one quotation, since iti’ occurs at the end of the 8th sutra, then we have here a quotation within a quotation, as iti' occurs also in s≈´tra 5. But this would be absurd. Besides, sutra 8 is really summarised from some BrƒÅhmana passage as indicated above. The proper construction of the four s≈´tras is as follows:- The fifth s≈´tra merely summarises the views of the Manusmrti to be gathered from Mann V. 41 and 48. The word ‚ÄúMƒÅnavam' stands for the Manusmrti just as it does in the Tantravartika and in Vi≈õvar≈´pa. Then the two verses of Manu are quoted. In the 8th s√∫tra a BrƒÅhma·πáa passage is cited in support of the position that sacrificing an animal is not ‚Äòkilling' (that leads to sin ).

As regards the few quotations which cannot be found in the extant Manusmrti the following points deserve consideration. The Vasisthadharmas≈´tra contains numerous verses identical with those of the Manusmrti. Most of the quotations attributed to Mapu are found in the Manusm·ªôti. Hence even if a few quotations are not found in our Manu, we cannot at once jump to the conclusion that Vasistha had before him not the Manusmrti, but the MƒÅna vadharma s≈´tra. Besides, B√ºhler is not right in saying that Vasi≈ütha 11. 23, 12. 16 and 23. 43 either contradict or find no counterpart in our Manu (S. B. E. vol. 25, p. XXXIV ). Vasistha 11. 23 corresponds with Manu 3. 245-246.148 None

147

of the three contradicts anything contained in the Manusmrti. Vasistha 23. 43 (about Sisukrcchra ) has nothing correspond ing to it word for word in our Manu, but it seerns to be an echo of Manu 11.211.149 In Vasistha 12. 16 ( paryagnikaranam hy-etan-manurƒÅha PrajƒÅpati·∏• ) there is nothing that contra dicts our Manu; that half and the preceding verses bear a close correspondence to BaudhƒÅyana Dh. S. I. 4. 2. Similarly, B√ºhler’s argument abont Manava sloka in the Tristubh metre is not quite sound. The text of Vasistha is far from satisfa ctory. On the non-occurrence of that verse or a correspond ing sloka in our Mapu no superstructure can be built. Vasi stha quotes ( 4. 37 ) a s≈´tra or opinion of Gautama which is not found in the extant Gautamadharmas≈´tra. Verses ascri bed to Vasistha in the nibandhas are not found in the printed text of Vasistha.

The analogy of the works of the schools of Apastamb·∫° and others can furnish no proof. Tbere are on the other hand weighty groupds for discarding that analogy altogether. It is a remarkable fact that excepting the three carunas (of the Black Yajurveda ) of Apustamba, BaudhƒÅyana and Hiranya kesin that arose and tourished in the southern portion of India, no carana of any of the other Vedas has an extant dhar masutra ascribed to the founder of the s≈´tra-curandƒ±. An explanation is suggested in the following lives. The BrƒÉbina nas in southern India were in the very early days of their colonisation surrounded by an alien culture and by alien customs. It was necessary therefore to formulate distinctly the rules of general conduct for the Aryan community in.

149 afh8 ( 23. 43 ) ‘31*: STARTER THE BATT IST: RVA JE TO

‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§π‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡•å ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å megtarea ll; AT 11. 245’ 54ƒñ TITET√ã Api HUTCAI FATTI ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§á‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§∞‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡••. FATTUT ( 2. 11. 218 ) is a milder edition of the 777879. The Spritet for minors and women was one-half or one-third of that for adult males (vide at. .. II. 1.61. and Bistria 38 ): m. 47. 4. 148

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

southern India, that studied the Black Yajurveda. The same necessity did not exist in northern India, where the members of the s≈´tracaranas knew their ordinary every day duties very well, and were more or less a homogeneous community with the same ideals and culture. Therefore, in the beggining when manuals of Srauta and G»ôhya ceremonies were first com posed, it was not thought necessary to compose set treatises on dlarƒ±na for each carana. Some of the rules of conduct were embodied in the gƒºhya s≈´tras because they were germane to the subjects treated of in them (such as the duties of brah macƒÅrins and householders, holidays etc.). Works, however, dealing with the general usages prevalent among the Aryan community in various parts of northern India must have been composed early enough. When the knowledge of the existe nce of the complete set of the sutra works in the Apastamba and other carunas of the Yajurveda in southern India perme ated to northern and central India, the leaders of the caranas cast about for works that would complete the works of their curanus and bring them in a line with those of Apastamba and others. Therefore the various cara≈Üas seized upon seve ral dbarmas≈´tras and adopted them in their schools for study. This must have occurred at a comparatively early date. For Kum√§rila, as we saw above, enlightens us as to what dharma s≈´tras were specially studied in which Vedic schools. The fact that, though Gautama and Vasistha are said to have been specially studied by the students of the SƒÅmaveda and the Rgveda respectively, there is hardly anything in these dharma s≈´tras that specially connects them with the two Vedas affo rds some corroboration of the above hypothesis. This assimi lation of independent dharmas≈´tras into individual s≈´tracara ≈Üas probably took place before or in the first centuries of the Christian era. Sabara (on Jaimini I. 3. 4 ) seems to make fun of the dharmas≈´tras when he says that the direction to observe brahmucarya for forty-eight years was a device of those who wanted to hide their impotence (Gautama 2. 52, Ap. Dh. S. I. 1. 2. 11-12, Baud. Dh. S. I. 2. 1 speak of brah.. macarya for 48 years ). This shows that these dharmasutras could not have been regarded as very authoritative by all early writers. Jaimini I. 3. 11 (according to Sabara ) denies

the independent authority of Kalpas≈´tras. It appears that ..the M√§nava school, which according to the Caraya vyuhanson sub-division of the Maitr√°ya·ª•iya, dwindled in numbers very

  1. M√§navadharmas≈´tra-Did it exist ?

149

early. KumƒÉrila, who was a most learned and profound stu dent of the various branches of Sanskrit literature, nowhere mentioned the M√§navadharmas≈´tra as studied by followers of the Black Yajurveda, though he mentions BaudhƒÅyana and Apastamba as studied by them. He places the Manusmrti even higher than the Gautamadharmas≈´tra and betrays no knowledge of the existence of the MƒÅnavadharmas≈´tra. Vi√üva r≈´pa who is generally identified with Sure≈õvara, the pupil of Sankara, remarks that the M√§navacarana is not existent (or found ) 160

The foregoing discussion will, it is hoped, induce every impartial critic to endorse the conclusion that, on the materials so far available, the theory that the MƒÅnavadharmas≈´tra once existed and that the extant Manusmrti is a recast of that B≈´tra must be held not proved.

  1. The Arthasastra of Kautilya

There are three words in ancient Sanskrit Literature that are used very often in the same sepse viz. Arthasastra, Dandaniti and Rajas√§stra or RƒÅjaniti or RƒÅjanitis√§stra or simply Nitis√§stra. The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata descants on RƒÅja dharma in several parvans, as in SabhƒÅ 5 ( the chapter called kaccit-pra≈°na), Vanaparva 150, Uddyoga (chap. 33-34). In Sabb√° 5 one hundred verses occur on RƒÅjaniti; for example, ( verse 41 refers to 18 tirthas (state dignitaries) tested by spies (as in Kaut. I. 12. 20), verse 47 refers to amƒÅtyas beyond the reach of upadhƒÅs (cf. Kau≈£. I. 10. 1ff). The Santiparva devotes more than 100 chapters to RƒÅja dharma from chap. 56. SƒÅnti, chap. 58 (1-4) names160s the

1602 aralaruites Portret p. 18 of faget’s comment on BTK

section. 150a ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§∞ ‡•§ ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡••

( Continued on the next page)

150

History of Dharmasastra

expounders of RƒÅja≈õƒÅstra (RƒÅja≈õ√§straplanetƒÅra·∏•), viz. Bphas pati, Vi≈õƒÅlƒÅk≈üa, Kavya, Indra, PrƒÅcetasa Manu, BharadvƒÅja, Gaura≈õiras. RƒÅjaniti is called ‚ÄúR≈´jyatantra‚Äù in the Malila plate of king Dhruvasena II of the year 323 of Valabhi Gupta era (i. e. 641-42 A. D.) in JOI. (Baroda ), vol. X. No. 2 at p. 127. R≈´janiti or Niti≈õ√§stra is described as the nectar or quintessence of the ocean of Arthas√ºstra in Kama nadakƒ±ya NitisƒÅra (1. 6). Kautilya himself employs the word RƒÅjaniti in V. 4. 3. RƒÅjaniti (Government and Politics ) is dealt with in Dharmas≈´tras and smrtis also (briefly or at length ) as in Gaut. Dh. S. (X-XIII), Manu (VII-VIII ), YƒÅjsa valkya (I. 309-68 and II. 1-307 ). Dharma≈õƒÅstras deal with all aspects of society and therefore they deal with RƒÅjadharma also. Dandaniti is another name for the S√§stra which has to be considered. Daula literally means ‘a stick or staff of a tree for driving cattle (vide Rg. VII. 33. 6) but it came to mean also the power of control and punishment’ i. e. it conveys the power of the king or supreme ruler called ‚ÄúDandadhara' or ‘DundadhƒÅra’ to dispense justice and to punish wrong-doers. The Gaut. 1000 Dh. S. (XI. 28 ) states that the word “Danda' conveys the idea of controlling (or suppressing) and (the king should keep under control (or suppress ) those who do not control themselves i. e. Dandaniti is the science of Government. Kautilya refers to it in the Artha≈õƒÅstra 1. 3-4. The SƒÅnti

( Continued from the previous page) ( verse 82 ). FOUNDED A 1917

  1. The ArthasƒÅstra of Kautilya

161

parva (in 59.78 ) gives the derivation of the word ‘Danda niti’ (as ‘Dandena niyate cedam dandam nayati vƒÅ puna·∏•ƒ± Da≈Üdnitir-iti khyƒÅtƒÅ trin lok√°n -abhivartate Il ) and advises the king to be always ready with the rod of punishment. Manu has a grand apotheosis of Danƒ±la’ (in VII. 14-31 ), some of the verses occurring in the Matsyapurana chap. 225. The DasakumƒÅracarita (VIII ) narrates that king Ananta varm√£, though endowed with all good qualities, did not feel much interest in Dandaniti and states that ƒÅcƒÅrya Vinnugupta prepared a compendium of it for the Maurya ( King). Here the Artha≈õƒÅstra of Kan»õilya is called Dandaniti. The Niti sƒÅra of KƒÅmandaka also follows (in II. 15) Gaut. Dh. S. in deriving the word dandu, says that the power of punish ment is vested in the king and that the rules that guide the king are called Dandaniti! 1506 This means that the main purpose and province of Dandaniti is to set out the functions of the State and deal with the administration of its different organs.

Artha≈õƒÅstra literally means the scince of artha. Artha is one of the four purusƒÅrthas (Dharina, Artha, KƒÅma and Moksa ). Manu (II. 224 ) refers to different views on the respective eminence of these. The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and the Smrtis were well aware of the great part that artha ( material well-being, wealth ) played in men’s lives. Wealth depended on land and labour. The MahƒÅbhanya remarks “a country is called ' arthavan' which has cows and crops” (arthavƒÅn ayam desa ucyate yasmin yavah sasy√¢ni ca vartante ) on VƒÅrtika 4 in P√°n. V. 2. 135 (Kielhorn’s ed. Vol. II. p. 40). The Drona parva (7.1) speaks of Minari ArthavidyƒÅ ano Vanaparva ( 35.21 ) states that Manu declared RƒÅjadharmas. Unless there existed some authority that regulated the people and their doings there would have been chaos and no security. Hence the ruler or the king was the most important institution in society and rules for the king’s guidance were called RƒÅjadharma or Rajaniti. Artha≈õƒÅstra therefore came to be identified with Rajausti≈õƒÅstra ( or simply Nƒ´ti≈õƒÅstra ). A special vame (viz. V√§rta ) was viven to the three viz. agriculture, rearing cattle, trade and commerce (vƒÅnijyuy. including various arts. Vide SabhƒÅparva 5. 83, Vanapambe

Bhanda162

History of Dharmatdatra

160, 30-31, S√§ntiparva 59. 33, 68, 35, 268. 3. The epic says * VƒÅrtƒÅm√ºlo hyayam lokastraiyyƒÅ vai dhƒÅryate sada' ( Santi 68. 35 ). The RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa also (II. 100. 47 ) says ‘this world when it resorts to VƒÅrtƒÅ prospers happily (vƒÅrtƒÅyƒÅm samsritastƒÅta lokoyam sukham-edhate )’. Kautilya makes it clear that Artha≈õƒÅstra and VƒÅrtƒÅ were distinct and yet VƒÅrtƒÅ was a subject of study for the king; it was one of the three or four RajavidyƒÅs (vide Artha≈õƒÅstra I. 4. 4, Manu VII. 43).

ArthasƒÅstra ju its technical sense is somewhat wider in meaning than Dandapƒ´ti and includes politics, economics, law and justice, but was narrower in scope than Dharma sastra. It was said to be an Upaveda of the Atharvaveda, according to the Vi≈ünupurƒÅna 180d III. 6. 28, VƒÅyu 61. 79 and BrahmƒÅnda 35. 88-89. It is therefore stated by YƒÅj. ( II. 21 ) that in case of conflict between Dharma≈õƒÅstra and Artha≈õƒÅstra the former is stronger. The Mit, on Y√ºj. makes this clear ( vide note below ). 1606

Mr. Ramakrishna Kavi first contributed a paper to J. V. O. I. ( Tirupati ) Vol. I. pp. 79-89 on CƒÅksusiya Artha s√§stra and in Vol. III. (pp. 99-116 ) published the text of that work in four patalas. In J. V. 0. I. Vol. IV he con tributed an Introduction (pp. 123-128 ) and notes on the sutras (pp. 129-140 and in Vol. VI. pp. 129-140). The text of CƒÅk≈üusiya begins with a verse saying that it is possible for a single man (or in one birth ) following the path of Niti≈õƒÅstra to conquer the earth provided he has the necessary effort (or determination ). The first s≈´tra is ‘Now then I shall expound ArthasƒÅstra which is the means of accomplishing the goals of human existence’. Then in 67 sutras it enumerates the topics of Artha≈õƒÅstra and covers almost the same topics as are found in Kautilya’s Artha. sƒÅstra. A few s≈´tras (which are all brief ) may be set out here by way of sample. (1) Sapta prakrtaya·∏•; ( 2 ) Sapta vidh√• pravrttih; (3) Sapta vyasanƒÅni; (5) tisro vidyƒÅ·∏•;

150d ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ã ‡§ß‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ã ‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•à‡§µ

1.1. The Arthu≈õtƒ´stra of Kuntil ya

153

( 9 ) »òat-trimsatguno rƒÅjƒÅ ; (10) Pa√±cavim≈õatigunosmƒÅtya·∏•; ( 11 ) »òadvim≈õatigunah senƒÅpatiriti; and so on. The last sutra is Dvividha ƒÅcƒÅra iti tadyathƒÅ-daivo mƒÅnusasceti'. The 2nd patala begins ; ‘atha s≈´trƒÅrtham vartayisyƒÅmah’ ( we shall comment on the meaning of the s≈´tras ).

Mr. Kavi (Vol. I. pr. 84ff'), relying on the name CƒÅksusƒ´ya (Caksusa was one of the first seven Manus acc. to Manusmrti I. 62.) and the close correspondence of certain sutras of the CƒÅk≈üusiya with the s≈´tras in Artha≈õƒÅstra, holds that Kautilya borrows from the CƒÅksusiya (p. 82 of J. V. 0. I. Vol. I). This is quite wrong. The reality is just the opposite of this. It is ridiculuous to hold that the erudite author of the Artha≈õƒÅstra had to borrow from a small beginner’s primer for his work of vast extent. Besides, the extant Kautiliya quotes several individual predecessors such as Kaunapadanta, Pisuna, BƒÅhudantiputra, BhƒÅradvƒÅja (and once Kaninka Bh.), VatavyƒÅdhi and Vi≈õƒÅlƒÅk·π£a and a few schools such as the Ambhiyas, Au≈°anasas, PƒÅrƒÅ≈õaras, B√°rhas patyas and MƒÅpavas, but nowhere mentions the Caksusiya. Moreover, while the Artha≈õƒÅstra of Kautilya or Canakya or Vi≈ünugupta is expressly named or quoted or referred to by numerous writers and works from at least the 3rd century A. I)., such as the TantrƒÅkhyƒÅyikƒ´, the KƒÅmas≈´tra, Kima ndakiyanitisƒÅra, the Pa√±catantra, B≈´na, Dandin, the Mudra rƒÅk≈üasa, hardly any writer or work of the centuries from the 3rd to the 8th has been shown to have mentioned the CƒÅk·π£usiya. Some verges are quoted from the C≈´ksusƒ´ya Artha ≈õrstra in an anthology called S√ºktiratnakara ( vide J. B. O. R. S. Vol. XI. pp. 81-84). Mr. Ramkrishna Kavi (in J. V. 0. I. Vol. IV. p. 123 ) says that thirteen verses are quoted from CƒÅksusiya in S≈´ktiratnƒÅkara, of which only eight are found in the mss. used by him.

This short primer for beginners in Artha≈õƒÅstra quotes a verse, a prose passage and sometimes several verses on most of the stras (except on s≈´tras 36, 38, 43, 45, 51, 52, 55-64). The verses are often preceded by such words as ‘atra slokƒÅh’, thereby intimating that they are quotations from some other work or works, for example, on II. 2 it quotes nine versek which either closely agree with Mann or state the same ideas in similar words viz. Manu IX. 303-11; on II. 3 it TEK ‘atra slokƒÅ·∏•,’ which closely agree with the extant Manu V!! 50-51. On II, 21 the CƒÅk·π£u√üƒ´ya sets out A prose passagerantlind

1, D.–20

FOON PED

OLE

Bhandarkar Oriental Aesearch Institute

154

History of Dhurmu≈õcistruo

then a verse which is the same as Manu, ( VIII. 26 ‘√§kƒÅrair ingitair-gatyƒÅ … … … mana·∏•’). On II. 4 it quotes four verses, one of which has the half verse ‘yadenam k≈üamayƒÅ yuktam–asaktam manyate janah’ (which is Udyoga parva 33. 48 and Santi. 160. 34 ). It is remarkable that at the end of the 2nd patala (on s≈´tra 24 ) it has a verse in Sragdhara metre. Mr. Kavi states that only one verse in the CƒÅksusiya (IV. 64, that has nine verses in it ) occurs in Manu (VII. 105 ) but, as shown above, the CƒÅksusiya quotes (on II. 21 ) Manu VIII. 26 and adapts several other verses of the Manu smrti with slight changes.

The publication of the Artha√≠√±stra of Kautilya was a great event and this work will have an abiding interest and value for all time. Dr. Jolly in his Introduction to his edition of the work described it as ‘perhaps the most precious work in the whole range of Sanskrit Literature’ (p. 1).

It was first published in 1909 by Dr. R. Shama Sastri in the Mysore Sanskrit Series. In 1915 he published an English translation of the whole with an Introductory note by Dr. J. F. Fleet and a Preface dealing with its authenticity and age. Revised editions of the text were published by him in 1919 and 1924 and his son published an edition of the text and translation in 1951. Another edition (in two parts ) by Dr. Jolly and Dr. R. Schmidt was published in 1923 by Messrs Motilal Banarasidas of Lahore with an English Intro duction of 47 pages and (Vol. II) with notes and a Sanskrit commentary called Nayacandrika by Madhavayajvan on a large part of the text (i. e. from adhikarana VII to XII). M. M. T. Ganapati Sastri published the Artha≈õƒÅstra with his own commentary called Srim√ºla in 1924 in three parts. Recently Prof. R. P. Kangle edited the text prepared from all the available mss. material and the University of Bombay published it as the first volume of the text with a glossary (in 1960) and a second volume with an English translation and explanatory notes was published in 1963 and a third volume containing a study of the Artha≈õnstra will soon follow. In this revised edition of the first volume of the H. of Dh. Prof. R. P. Kangle’s edition of the text published in 1960 has been used.

No complete commentary on the ArthasƒÅstra of Kautilya has yet been discovered. The commentaries so far discovered ere fragmentary. They are as follows: (1) The Com. called

T

PratipadapancikƒÅ of Bhatta-svƒÅmin on the 2nd Aubikarana from the 8th AidhyƒÅya to the 36th Adhy√¢ya published in J. B. O. R. S. Vol. XI and XII, in all 214 pages. (2) The Nayacandrik√• of Madhava–yajvan published in Dr. Jolly’s edition of the Arthas√§stra (19233 ), with an Introduction (pp. 1-47) in English ; it begins in chapter 7th of the seventh adhikarana ( on s√•dgunya ) and breaks off in the 4th adlyayu of the 12th allhikurie nuo ; (3) The com. (Mad. ) Vol. XXII. pp. 29-44 on chapters 9-14 of the first Albikarana. The author is pro bably the same as the anthor of the JayamangalƒÅ on the KƒÅmasutra. ( 4 ) Nitinirriti of Youthama ; a small fragment discovered along with i naguri ms. of the text, by Muni Jina vijayaji at Patan, concerned with II, 1, 1 to II. 3 and opening of II. 4 and published by him in the Singhi Jain–grantham√§lt series (Bombay, 1959 ); 150F ( 5 ) BhƒÅni-vyƒÅkhyƒÅna in Maluya lam. The commentary extends up to the 7th adhikurana only. The com, on the first two adhikaranay was edited and published in 1930 (1st adhikarana) and in 1938 (on zod adhikarana ) by Sambusiva Sastri and the com. ou the 3rd adhikarana was edited and published in 1945 by V. A. Rama swami Sastri, all at Trivandrum. The Com. ou udhikaranas 4-7 was edited by Shri K. N. Ezhuthachau and published by the University of Madras in 1960; (6) CƒÅnak ya≈£ikƒÅ by Bhikyu Prabhamati, a fracƒ±nent, being edited by Mr. G. Huribara Sastri and published in the volumes of the Journal of Oriental Research, Madras, upto pp. 1-188; (7) Commentary called Sriin≈´la on the whole of the Kuu≈£iliya by M. M. Ganapati Sastri, in which he utilizes the material afl’orded by all the commentaries available to him.

The first commentary, if it dealt with the whole of the ArthasƒÅstra, must have been very extensive, since the availa ble com. on a portion of the 2nd Adhikarana alone covers 214

History of DharnuciscƒÅstru

printed pages. That commentary quotes explanations of previ ous commentators in the words ‘anye’ and ‘apare‚Äôand quotes several slokas of Brhaspati on the blemishes of diamonds and on ‘prakƒÅ≈õa-taskaras.’ The NayacandrikƒÅ also refers to the views of predecessors ( vide pp. 35. 61, 62, 104, 115, 137, 191 ) and discusses various l’eadings also (vide pp. 136, 183, 188, 193 &c). Yogyhana’s com. (at least of about the 12th century A. D.; cites the views of Ambhiyas in a vers…ô on p. 2.

Besides the English trauslations of the Artha≈õƒÅstra by Dr. Shama Shastri and Prof. Kangle, there is J. J. Meyer’s German translation Das Altindische Buch von welt-und staatsleken das Artha≈õ√§stra des Kautilya’( Leipzig, 1925-26 ) and there is a Russian translation edited by Prof. V. I, Kalya. nov (Leningrad, 1959). The Artha≈õƒÅstra has been translated into Hindi by several authors and there are translations in Bengali, Gujarati, the four south Indian languages and in Marathi (this last by Messrs. J. S. Karandikar and B. R. Hivargaonkar, 1927–29 ).

This work bas given rise to frequent and furious coutro versies about its authorship, its authenticity and its age and it cannot be said that we have heard the last of this din of controversy. Moreover, this work has inspired, besides nume. rous articles in journals, several monographs, some of which have somewhat high sounding titles, such as Narendranath Law’s Studies in Ancient Indiau Polity,’ Dr. P. Banerji’s

Public Administration in Ancient India,' Ghosal’s History of Hindu Political Theories, ' Majumdar’s Corporate Life in Ancient India,' Benoy Kumar Sarkar’s' Political Iostitutions and Theories of the Hindus,' Jayasval’s ‘Hindu Polity,’ Prof. S. V. Visvanathan’s International Law in Ancient India' (1925). It is not possible to discuss at great length all the problems about Kautilya here. Only a brief statement can be attempted. For fuller study reference may be made to the following works and papers :- Hillebrandt’s ‚Äò√ºber das Kauti lya≈õƒÅstra und Verwandtes' (Breslau 1908 ), Z D M G. vol. 67, pp. 49–96 (Dr. Jolly ), Z DMG vol. 68, pp. 345-359 and vol. 69, p. 369 ff'; JR AS 1910, pp. 130-137 (Prof. Keith I. A. for 1918, pp. 157-161 and pp. 187-195 ( Dr. Jugobi translated by Dr. Sukthankar); Dr. Kalidas Nag’s Web Th√©ories Diplomatiques de l’Inde ancienne et l’Arthasasthouse

1.1. The Arthu≈õ√ºstic of Kautilya

157

( Paris 1923 ) and its translation in ‘Journal of Indian His. tory’ vol. V ; Dr. Otto Stein’s ‘Megasthenes und Kautilya’ ( Vienna 1922 ), K. V. Rangasvami Ayyangar’s lectures on Ancient Indian Polity ( Madras 1916), Dr. Winternitz in Cal cutta Review 1924 and in his history of Indian Literature (vol. III, 1D. 509-524 ), I. Meyer’s Das altindische Buch vom Welt-und Staatsleben das Artha≈°ƒÅstra des Kautilya' ( Leipzig, 1925) and Prof. N. C. Bandopadhyaya’s exposition of the social ideal and political theory of Kautilya. The Indian Antiquary for 1925 ( pp. 175 und 201 ) gives an exhaustive bibliography on the date of Kantilya.

While the author was engaged in collecting materials and after the 1st volume of the H. of D. was published in 1930 a very large number of studies of the Kuu»õiliya and numerous articles ou various matters connected with the Kau≈£iliya have been published. The present author has to confess that he has not read a good many of them. A short list of some of those studies and articles that he has lead or consulted is set out here:

Among studies may be mentioned the following :-Kauta liya Studien ‘by B. Breloer, three volumes (1927‚Äì1934) (in German); D. R. Bhandarkar’s ‘Some aspects of ancient Hindu Polity’( Benares 1929 ); Prof. Radhakumnd Mookerji’s ‘Chan dragupta Maurya and his times’ (Madras, 1943 ); “Kautalya Studies’ by Sten Konow (Oslo, 1945 ); Prof. K. V. Ranga swami Aiyangar’s ‘Indian Cameralism’ (Madras 1949);' Age of Imperial Unity’hy Dr. R. C. Majumdar Bombay, 1951);

Age of the Nandas and Mauryas' ed. by Prof. K. A. Nila kanta Sastri (Benares 1952, particularly pp. 132‚Äì169 and Pp. 190-201); ‘L. Altekar ( Benares, 1955); ' A History of Indian Political Ideas’ by Prof. U. N. Ghoshal (3rd ed. Bombay, 1959); Studies in Kautilya' by M. V. Krishnarao (2nd ed. 1958);. Studies in Hindu Political thous ght and its metaphysical foundations' by V. P. Varalan ( Benares ).

Among articles and papers may be mentioned the follo wing; ‘On the authenticity of the Kautiliya’ in I. A. vol 47

History of Dhurmu≈õcstra

(1918) pp. 157-161 and 187–195 (Jacobi’s remarks translated by Dr. Sukthankar ), I. A. Vol. 53 pp. 128-136 ( tr. by Prof. Utgikar); Date of Kautilya' by Prof. D. R. the king in the Kau≈£ilian State ' by the same author in game journal pp. 277-308; India Antiqua (studies presented to Dr. J. P. Vogel ) pp. 136 -145; Prof. U. N. Ghoshal on System of interstate relations and foreign policy in the early Artha ≈õƒÅstra State ); Kingship and community' in ‘Early India’ by Charles Drekmeier ( Oxford University Press, Bombay 1962, particularly chapters 11-13 pr. 189-244 ).

The Kautiliya is the oldest extuut work on Arthusastra. Though Artha≈õƒÅstra and Dharma≈õƒÅstra are often contradisti nguished on accouut of the difference of the two ≈õƒÅstras in ideals and in the methods adopted to reach them, Arthashstra is really a branch of Dharma≈õƒÅstra as the former deals with the responsibilities of kings for whom rules are laid down in many treatises on dlocrna. 181 For this reason and the fur ther reason that the Kau≈£iliya contains two sections (called dharmasthiya and kantakasodhana ) on the administration of justice, the Artha≈õƒÅstra of Kautilyu deserves careful conside ration in this work. According to the Caranavyuha of Sau naka, Artha≈õƒÅstra is an Upaveda of Atharvaveda. The pur pose of this ≈†ƒÅstra as stated in the Kau»õiliya itself is ‘to pre scribe means for securing and preserving (power over ) the earth. ‘152 YƒÅj√±avalkya distinctly states (II. 21) that in 151 TETTE FON√ÄT Tratfattat fatia iti Parapente fino on

  1. The Arthu≈õtƒ´stru of Kautilya,

159

case of conflict between Dharma≈õƒÅstra and Artha≈õƒÅstra, the rule is that the former prevails. 153 NƒÅrada also ( I. 39 ) says the same thing 154

That there was in India a great deal of thinking on roli tics, economics, law and administration of justice several cen turies before Christ is clear from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and the early Dharmas≈´tras like those of Gautama, BaudhƒÅyana and Apastamba. In the S√§ntiparva the word Niti≈õƒÅstra is frequ ently used in the sense of political science. For example, SƒÅnti 138. 196 states that ‘avisvƒÅsa’ (not putting trust in anybody) is briefly the essence of all Niti≈õƒ´stras.1548 Vide also SƒÅnti 111. 73, 138. 39 and 43. It has already been shown that the Santiparva names several expounders of Niti≈õƒÅstra. Brhaspatimata is frequently quoted in the great Epic on poli tics and connected matters. Bphaspati is said to be the son of Angiras ( Adiparva 76. 19). The SabhƒÅparva ( 55. 6) men tions as the opinion of Brhaspati that the conduct or life of kings is different from the (rules of conduct of common men.1646 The Udyoga Parva states that Bphaspati declared that one should give battle to an (enemical) army which is smaller by one-third than one’s own army.1640 Bhisina parva quotes the dictum of Brhaspati that one who has a sinall army should present a compact front, while one who has a large army should spread it out1649 and then a reference is made to a ‘vy≈´ha’ called Vajra (19. 7). The same parva speaks of a vyuha called Krau√±cƒ´runa (in 50. 40 ) which was suggested to Indra by Brhaspati; a vy≈´ha called Krau≈Ñca is mentioned in Drona-parvan (7.25). It is noteworthy that Kautilya deals with vyvhus in X. O and in the first s≈´tra refers to the arrangement of a vy√∫ha according to U≈°anas and

acc. to B»ôhaspati. It is remarkable that the Vajra array referred to above is mentioned in K. X. 6. 35, that a syena array is mentioned by Kautilya (X. 6. 12), though not Krau√±ca and that an array called Sakata is mentioned in the Dronaparva 7. 24, which occurs in Kau»õiliya also (at X. 6. 26 ).

SƒÅnti ( 69. 23-24 ) states that Bilaspati advises a wise king desirous of securing his kingdom to avoid war and to accomplish his object by the three upayas, appeasement, offer of gift, or bheila ( sowing discord ) and to be satisfied with what he would be able to secure by the first three. 154‚Ç¨ Santiparvan ( 59. 59 ) states that, according to the AcƒÅryas, the vices ( vyorsunas) of kings are ten in all, either due to Kopa (anger ) or to kƒÅm ( lust ).14f The first category consists of six vices, viz. v√§kp√§rusya (harshness of speech ), danda pƒÅrusya (harshness due to physical punishment ), arthadisana (violation of property ) and three others; the vices due to lust are four, vix, hunting, gambling, women and drinking. The Manusmrti (in VII. 47-8 ) speaks of ten vices due to lust and eight vices due to anger. The Kautiliya (VIII. 3 ) reduces the vices lue to lust to four and the vices due to anger to three only and holds a long discussion abont the comparative harm caused by these. The word Kantaka sodhana (suppression of criminals ) occurs in SƒÅnti 59. 5:3. History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

of a king as having studied the whole of Bphaspatimata and Au≈°anasa≈õƒÅstra. SƒÅnti 59. 51 refers to ‘SaptƒÅngarƒÅjya’; Manu IX. 294 and Kautilya ( VI. 1. 1 ) also mention the seven constituent elements.

SƒÅntiparva states that Brhaspati prescribed UtthƒÅna ( effort, endeavour ) for kings and as the basis of rƒÅjadharma and recites verses thereon.1547 Kautilya also says that a king should bring about the acquisition of what is not gained (Yoga) and protection of what is obtained by effort (Uttha nena YogaksemasƒÅdhanam, J. 7.1 ). Vide H. of Dh. Vol. II pp. 914-15, Vol. II pp. 588–589, Vol. V. pp. 1385-6 for a dis. cussion of the meaning of yogaksema.

The passages quoted above from different parvans of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata (not only from S√§ntiparva ) show that the author of the Mahabharata had before him a treatise of B»ôhaspati on Artha≈õƒÅstra, that it was extensive, contained verses and that it was divided into parts or chapters called ' AdhikƒÅra ' like ‘adhikarana’ in Kautilya.

It may be noted that A≈õvaghosa in his Buddhacarita ( I. 46 ) mentions the RƒÅja≈õƒÅstras produced by Sukra, son of Bhrgu and Brhaspati, son of Aigiras.154m Kalidasa in KumƒÅrasambhava ( III. 6 ) mentions the Niti of Usanas.

Brhaspati’s Artha Sastrn appears to have contained a legendary beginning that what Bphaspati, the preceptor of the Gods, taught Inilra is contained in the treatise of B»ôhaspati.

1541 ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§§ ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞

‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß ‡§Æ‡•á ‡•• ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§π ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§á‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø 58. 18-18; compare ‡§ï‡•å‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø ‘‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡•§ … ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø

‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ I. 19. 1-5 and 33-35. 154m ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•É‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§§‡•å‡•§ ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•å ‡§§‡•ã

‡§∏‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡•• ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ I. 46. ‡§∏‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§§‡•Å: Homlila literally mean crentod ( or proluced )

  1. The Arthuo≈õƒÅstru of Kuutilya

163

The present Manusmrti contains a similar assertion that BrahmƒÅ taught Mapu and the latter taught it to Marici, Bhrgu and others ( Manu I. 35-36 and 58 ) and Bhigu at the order of Manu transmitted the SƒÅstra to the sages ( I. 60 and 119 ). Such fabulous accounts were introduced in ancient works to heighten the authority of the teaching. The Birhas patyas mentioned in the Arthas√§stra were probably those who relied on the treatise of Brhaspati, and Kautilya differed from their teaching in I. 2. 4-5, V. 15. 48 (they required that 16 persons constituted a council of Ministers ), II. 7. 13 ( those superintendents who caused loss of revenue should be fined ten times the loss ), in III. 11. 40 (punishment for witnesses who lead to a wrong judgment), III. 17. 13 (on fine for him who instigated another to commit an oflence ).

Usa≈Üas is another ancient sage who appears to have composed a treatise on Arthasastra. That K√§vya Usauas was √† sage of hoary antiquity even in Rgvedic times would be indicated below (under U≈õanas). Several passages from U≈õanas mentioned in the great Epic would be cited there. The AsramavƒÅsikaparva states that the Vy≈´has called Sakata, Padma and Vajra have been declared in the SƒÅstra of Usanas. 154n The Vy√ºha called Sakata is mentioned in the ArthasƒÅstra X. 6. 26 and Vajra in X. 6. 35. The Manusmrti in VII. 187 mentions six Vy≈´las viz. Dandu, Saka»õa, VarƒÅha, Makara, Suci, Garuda, and in VII. 188 mentious Padmavyuha and Vajra in VII. 191.

It is clear that the author of the Mahabharata had before him a treatise by Usanas on RƒÅjaniti, which went into such details as the names of certain Vy≈´has. Manu (VII. 146 and 151 ) provides that the king should hold in a secret place a meeting of the councillors and sets out the subjects on which the king has to hold counsel with thein (mantrins ) and one verse (VII. 154 )1640 refers to the eightfold actions of the king 1540 372119979T TH√ã 957 (751 ) HRT I 3771 OF TESTET

The same story of king Nrga, who donated & BrƒÅhmana’s cow by mistake and became a chome leon because he did not speedily deal with the dispute, is nar rated in AnusƒÅsana parva 6. 38 und Asramedbika-parva 90. 99-100 and in the RƒÅmƒÅyana, UttarakƒÅnda, chap. 53. 6-26. Not only in the epics, but in some of the PurƒÅnas also RƒÅjadharma is treated at some length. For example, the Matsya Purana devotes severel chapters (225-229 ) to RƒÅjadharma that deal with the suhƒÅyas of the king, the conduct of the king’s servants, fortress and its equipments. From very early times, Visnugupta alias Canakya or Kau»õilya has been credited with the composition of a work on ArthasƒÅstra. The Kamandakiya-viti-sƒÅra285 pays a glowing tribute of praise to Visnugupta, who single-handed brought about the downfall of the Nandas and bestowed the earth on Candragupta by the force of his political strategy and who distilled from the ocean of Artha≈õƒÅstra the quintessence of (his work on ) Nƒ´ti≈õƒÅstra. KƒÅmandaka tells us further that he looked upon Vi≈ünugupta as Guru.158 The Tantr√°khyƒÅ.

  1. The Arthasustack of Kautilya

yikƒÅ ( the earliest version of the Pa√±catantra ), which, accord ing to Hertel ( H.O.S.), is not later than 300 A. V. 4, verses 13-14. ( one half of each ); (4) ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ … ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•ã … ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡§≤‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ otc.; vide ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•. VL 2. 33 (‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É), VI. 2. 28 (‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡§É); VII. 1. 2 (‡§∑‡§æ‡§ó‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø); (5) ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø … ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ( vide ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ I. 10. 1-4); (Gon p. 54 ) ‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§∂‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑-‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞-‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç . ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞ and ‡§Ü‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏ are respectively ‡§â‡§∂‡§®‡§∏‡•ç and ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø.

History of Dhurmu≈õcƒ´stra

Let us now turn to the MudrƒÅrƒÅksasa,159 from which a few passages are quoted below. It refers to Kautilya as ‘Kutila muti’ (of crooked intellect) in 1. 7 .Kautilya·∏• Kutilamatih su esa yena krodhƒÅynan prasabham-adƒÅhi Nandavamsah’, and again in Act IV. 2 there is a reference to the crooked intellect of Kautilya (api ca ku»õilim Kautilyasya prucintayato matim ). Again, in CƒÅnakya’s speech in MudrƒÅrƒÅ k≈üasa before 1. 22 anyac-ca-Nandam-iva Visnuguptah &c.’ it is clearly showu that Vi≈ünugupta and Canakya ure identical, according to the author of the MudrƒÅrƒÅksasa. Malayaketu boasts (V. 22)

I am able to uproot Vinnugupta and Maurya even if they come ( together ) with you ( RƒÅksasa )'. Here the author clearly shows that Vi≈ünugupta is identical with CƒÅ≈Üakya and Kautilya. There is a striking passage towards the end of the play after VII. 9, where CƒÉ≈ãakya addresses Raksasa (whom the former has won over to the side of Candragupta ) I, Visnugupta, otter salutatiou to you' (Vi≈ünuguptoham abhivƒÅdaye ) and Raksasa responds by saying ‘Bho Vir≈Üu. gupta’ when a little before (i. e. before VII. 6) RƒÅksasa had said (nivedyatam duritmaue C√•nakyƒÅya.' These passages establish beyond doubt that, according to Visakhadatta, Kau ≈£ilya, CƒÅ≈Üakya and Vi≈ünugupta were the names of the same persou and, from the way in which abhivadunc was perfor med, it appears that the dramatist believed that Visnugupta was the original name given at the time of N√§makarana. Manu (II. 121 ) prescribes that a brƒÅlimana making abhiva dana to a person older (than himself) should pronounce his own name with the words ‘here do I bow, so and so by name’. Vide H. of Dh. Vol. II, pp. 330-337 for discussion on abhivƒÅdana.

ACT

  1. Artha≈õƒÅstra of Kautilya

167

There was a great divergence of views about the time when a child was given a name. Vide I. H. Q. (1938) Vol. 14 pp. 24 44 (the author’s paper on giving a name to a child ) and H. of Dh. Vol. II pp. 238 ft. Several authorities prescribed that NƒÅmakarana should primarily be performed on the 10th or 12th day after birth ( Baud. Gr. II. 1. 23, PƒÅr. Gr. I. 17 and Manu 11. 30). There were various rules at different times about what name should be given. One of the rules was that the name may be derived from that of a sage or of a deity or may be the same as the name of an ancestor (Baud. Gr. II. 1. 28-29 and M√§navagrhya I. 18). The name Vi≈ünugupta would* be in accordance with these rules, but not Canakya necessari ly. Kautilya would only be a gotra name or a nickname. The wame Canakya may have been due to the place whence the author’s family came or where he was born, just as P√°nini is called SalƒÅturiya from Sal≈´tura occurring in PƒÅ. IV. 3. 93 ). In the Parisistaparva of Hemacandra (ed. by Jacobi, Calcutta 1883 ) on p. 55 of the Introduction it is stated that Canaka was a village in Colla District and Canakya was born of a BrƒÅhmana called Canin who resided there. Verse VIII. 339 states that Candragnpta became king 155 years after MahƒÅvƒ´ra passed away. His paternal grandfather or some more remote ancestor might have borne the name Canaka and so he was called Canakya (according to ‘Gaig√±dibhyo yan’ (PƒÅn. IV. 1. 105 ), Canaka being one of the numerous words under GargƒÅdi-yana.' We have CƒÅrƒÅyana and KatyƒÅyana (in Artha. V. 5. 11), Cara being included in the Nadadi-gana ( P√§in. IV. I. 99) as the 2nd word. Vide the Nidhanapur plates of Bhaskara-varman (of Kamar≈´pa) in E. I. Vol. 19 pp. 115-117 and pp. 248-250, where two hundred and five donees are named together with their gotras (about 25), among which are KƒÅtyƒÅyana, Kautilya (four donees of that gotra), Gautama, JƒÅt≈´ karna &. Vide J. I. H. Vol. XXXI. pp. 111-119 where several views are mentioned about the date of the Nidhanpur plates, S. Bhattacarya assigning them to about 647 A, D). The Ilarsacarita (VII) inentions several ancestors of Bhaskaravarmun, who, according to the Harta carita, was a contemporary of Emperor Harna. There is no

doubt that, whatever the exact date of the Nidhanpur grant may be, BhƒÅskara varman flourished in the first half of the 7th century.

Dandin flourished not later than 700 A. D.; vide the author’s History of Sanskrit Poetics ( ed. of 1961 ) pp. 119-120 and the discussion that precedes. The date of MudrƒÅrƒÅk≈üasa is rather debatable. It depends upon what is the correct rea ding of the last pƒÅda in the BharatavƒÅkya.100 The Bharata. vƒÅkya in the MudrƒÅrƒÅk≈üa≈°a is put in the mouth of Raksasa in some mss. and in that of Canakya in others. The word * BharatavƒÅkya' literally means the speech of the Bharata or of Bharatas' (‘BharatƒÅ ityapi na≈£ƒÅ·∏•’ says Amarako≈õa ). The NƒÅtya≈õƒÅstra does not define the word. Therefore, we have to rely upon the practice of early and great Sanskrit dramatists to find what the word exactly implies. In some of the great Sanskrit dramas, BharatavƒÅk yas are general in tone, asking for the welfare and happiness of the people (particularly of good men), long and healthy life, good government, good rains, good crops, fame and prosperity to poets &c., as in the Vikra morvasiya, MahƒÅviracarita, MƒÅlatimƒÅdhava, RatnƒÅvali, Veni samhƒÅra, Mrcchakatika. In the MƒÅlavikƒÅ¬∞ the last rerse requests the queen always to bestow her favours on him and adds that as long as Agnimitra is the protector of the subje cts, it is not necessary to invoke such blessings as the absence of floods, drought, locusts, invasions &c. The SƒÅkuntala ends on two notes. The first half says ‘may the king be assiduous in bringing about welfare to the people and may the literary efforts of those whose learning is great become famous.’ The second half is ‘may the self-existent Siva eliminate re-birth in my case.’ It is difficult to hold thut this refers to an indi

  1. The Arthu≈°ƒÅstra of Kautilya

169

vidual actor (the word ‘mama’ being there ). It must refer to Dugyanta, who is the last to speak (before the benediction) and possibly there is another suggested meaning that expres ses the yearning of the poet K√°lidƒÅsa himself. Therefore, it is not quite accurate to say that the BharatavƒÅkya is no part of the drama or that it is a chorus by all the actors ; in that case ‘mama’in the SƒÅkuntala would be inappropriate. The dramatist was to write the BharatavƒÅkya and it is possible that several dramas though they contained Bharatav√§kya were not or could not be put on the stage at all. The Bharata vakya, thought not an essential part of the action of the play, is still said by one of the prominent characters in the play. Avantivarman has nothing to do with the drama or the chara cters therein. The proper reading is therefore ‘pƒÄrthivas candraguptah.’ It is proper to hold that Canakya, who is the dominant character of the story of the drama, recites that benediction. The poet Visakhadatta was the grandson of a sƒÅmanta (feudatory chief) Va»õe≈õvaradatta and the son of MahƒÅrƒÅja (king) Bhaskaradatta and therefore it would be a fine piece of flattery if there be an oblique or indirect refere nce to Emperor ( MahƒÅrƒÅjƒÅdhiraja ) Candragupta in the words of the drama. The Gupta Emperor Candragupta II ruled till 414 A. D. Vide Fleet’s Gupta Inscriptions (1888) p. 15 and JBORS Vol. 30 pp, 1-46. If the poet flourished under him the drama was composed about 400 A. D. Taking Avanti varman as the king meant in the BharatavƒÅkya (which is very unlikely ), the draina must have been composed in the latter half of the 6th century, as Avantivarman took a great part in vanquishing the H≈´nas about 582 A. D. Vide 1. H. Q. Vol. 30 (1930) pp. 175-178 and pp. 485-6 for a discussion on Bharata vƒÅkya.

The K√°mandakiyanitisara highly praises Vinnugupta as shown above. The date of Kimanduka is also debatable. I showed so far back as 1911 ( in I. A. for 1911 p. 236 ) that VƒÅmana in his K√§vy≈°lankƒÅras≈´tra quoted from some work not available now a half verse KƒÅmam Kimandaki nitirasyƒÅ rasyƒÅ divƒÅnisam’ as an example of one variety of Yamaka. Dr. Jolly in his haste to dispose of evidence against his part theory treats this in a slipshod manner and gives a note on p. 8 (of Introduction) that the 8th century seems to be the most likely date of the Nitis≈´ra of K≈´mandaka. I shoes that Vimana quotes a half verge not from the Nitis√£g but

STITUDE

UNDED

170

History of Dharma≈õcƒ´stra

from some work in which occurs the statement the dhi (intellect of some person ) indeed day and night enjoys (the reading of ) Kamandaki-niti'. VƒÅmana in his own v·ªãtti on IV. 6. 2 states that Yamakas are treated at length in a work called Hariprabodha. That work is now not available. VƒÅmana elsewhere expressly says that the examples he gives are mostly from others (parakiyaisca puskalaih). It would have been a long time before the NitisƒÅra became famous. A work now unknown refers to it and a half verse from that work is quoted as an example of a figure of speech by the rhetorician VƒÅmana ( from Kashmir ). This might take centuries. The NitisƒÅra may be centuries earlier than 800 A. D. for all we know. KƒÅmandaka further tells us that he looked upon Visnugupta as his Guru. In the SƒÅntiparva (chap. 123 ) there is a dialogue between KƒÅmandaka and Angarista, king of Anga. The name Kamandaka is thus comparatively ancient.

There is nothing to prevent us from holding that the Nƒ´tisƒÅra of KƒÄmandaka may belong even to the third century A. D. I am here concerned only with showing that Dr. Jolly did not carefully consider the matter and is wrong in putting the K≈´mandakiyanitisƒÅra in the 8th century A. D. when he agreed to put VƒÅmana about 800 A. D. It is surprising that Winternitz also refers the Artha≈õƒÅstra to the 3rd century A.D. (p. 28 of Cal. Review, April-June, 1924). Dr. Jolly un. necessarily parades patent facts e. g. he remarks (on p. 11 ) that the B»ôhatsamlitƒÉ (chap. 78.1 ) contains nearly the same list of princes killed in their harem as the ArthasƒÅstra (I. 20. 15-17). In the first place, the list is not quite the same. But, apart from that, one would like to know what conclusion he draws from the fact that the BrhatsarhitƒÅ contains some or most cases of treachery mentioned by Kautilya is not clear. As he holds that A. belongs to the 3rd century A. D. it is clear that if there is a borrowing it is Varahamihira who borrows (as the latter flourished in the first-half of the Gth century A. D.). The Harsacarita (VI) mentions these cases and several more. The NitisƒÅra (VII. 51-54 ) also mentious these cases of treachery.

The KathƒÅsaritsagara of Somadeva (in the Kath√•pitha. lambaka chap. 5 verses 108–124 ) refers to the story of Canakya having brought about the death of Yogananda and placed Candragupta ( p≈´rvanandasuta ) on the Magadhat throne. That work purports to give successfully the context

  1. The ArthugƒÉstrou of Kuulilya

171

of the Brhatkatha ( 1. 1. 3), avers that it closely follows the original, does not depart even slightly from it and that only the language differs and there is abridgment in it and some detail (I. 1. 10). The BrhatkathƒÉ of GupƒÅdhya is supposed to have been composed in the Pai≈õnci dialect about the first century A. D. It is mentioned by Bina in Harsacarita ( Intro. verse 17 ) and in Dandin’s Kavyadar≈õa ( I. 38 ). The Brhat kathƒÅma√±jari of Ksemendra ( II. 216 ) refers to the story that C√°nakya brought about the death of Yogananda (by magic ) and placed Candragupta ( described as ‘p≈´rvanandasutah’) on the throne.

So far I have dealt with works that name Visugupta, CƒÉnakya and Kautilya singly or collectively and the dates of which though not very certain can be fixed within narrow limits. Now I shall refer to some PurƒÅnas which mention Candragupta and his minister Kautilya. There are five Puranas that have chiefly to be considered viz. V√°yu 199. 326-332, Brahmandu III. 74, Visnu (IV. 24, 25-33 in prose), BhƒÅgavata (XII. 17 ) und Mats yn ( 272. 19-26). The Matsya account is rather defective; Viyu aud Brahmanda agree, Vi≈°≈Üu and Bhagavata agree. All tive say in a prophetic vein that Nandas will rule for 100 years, that Kautilya would uproot the Nandas and place Candragupta on the throne, the latter will rule for 24 years, his son BindusƒÅra ( BhadragƒÅra in V√§yu ) for 25 years and Asoka (grandson ) will rule for 36 years. Some mention niue Maurya kings and others men tion ten kings, but all agree that the dynasty will rule for 137 years, though there is difference in the number and sequence of kings. Four Puranas (except the Matsya ) appear to refer to Guptavanisa but do not nume even the great conqueror Samudragupta. Therefore, it may be argued with great probability that they took their present form about 320-335 A. D. It is not necessary to enter into details here. Those interested in the PurƒÅna historcial traditions may refer to pages 842-861 of the fifth volume of the H. of Dh, and to & paper by Mr. H. G. Sustri in JOI ( Baroda ) Vol. IX pp. 387-392. The Dipavariisa, of the 5th ceutury A. 1), and a Ceylonese Chronicle, supports the Paurinic account so far that Candragupta’s son was BindusƒÅra, whose son Piyadassi (or Asoka or Piyadassana ) and that Asoka Tan crowned king 218 years after the passing away of Buddhaper ( VI. 14-15) and that Candragupita ruled for twenty-four172

¬∑ llistory of Dhurmu≈õcƒ´stra

years (Dipavam≈õa V. 73 and 100 ), as the Prir√µras say. The MahƒÅvamsa (Geiger’s ed, of 1908, I. 5. 10-20 ) states that Canakya, after killing the 9th Nanda, will anoint as king Candragupta Maurya (a Ksatriya), that he will rule 24 years, his son BindusƒÅra will rule for 28 years, then Asoka, after killing his brothers will be anointed king.

It is known from Greek, Buddhist and Jain sources and Indian inscriptions that Candragupta, Bindusara and Asoka were historic persons. We know from Greek sources that Candragupta and Seleucus, the successor of Alexander the Great in the East, formed an alliance and that Seleucus ceded to Candragupta parts of Gedrosia ( Baluchistan ), Arachosia ( KandƒÅbƒÅra ) and Paropamisadae (i. e. Kabul ), all of which stretched up to the Indus ), vide Tarn on the Greeks in Bact ria and India ‘, 1938, p. 100 and Cambridge Ancient History, Vol. VI. pp. 413-14 ( which gives a brief note on what Erato sthenes says about this treaty ). Similarly, the accounts in Matsya (272. 18-23 ), VƒÅyu chap. 99. 326-337 and other PurƒÅnas about Pusyamitra and his descendants and about the SƒÅtavƒÅhanas have been found to be substantially correct from the Sunga Inscription from AyodhyƒÅ (E. I. Vol. 20 p. 54 ), Nanaghat, Nasik and other Inscriptions. There is no reason, except unreusonable 828 picion and prejudice, why the conne ction of Kautilya or Canakya with Candragupta mentioned in the PurƒÅnas ( as in Matsya 272. 22 and V√§yu 99. 330-1), and the MahƒÅvansa anƒ±l other early literature should not be held to be at least probable. The embellishments and fabulous trappings of the story may not be taken seriously. But the core of the story should be accepted as quite probable and should not be rejected unceremoniously. Alexander’s was not a conquest of India in the ordinary sense of the word, the sense in which Alexander conquered Persia (see Tarn in the work cited p. 131 ). Tarn states (ibid, p. 174 notes 2 and 3) that some writers have put forward the theory that in the treaties between Candragupta and Seleucus there was a grant by the Iudian king to the Greeks of the right to intermarry in the Ksatriya-varna and Taru appears to hold that Candragupta’s marriage with a daughter of Seleucus might have taken place ( note 3 ). The Cambridge H. of India ( Vol. I. p. 472 ) observes . for Seleucus the task of meeting Candragupta in war proved too great. Seleucus was content to secure a safe retirement and a gift of 500 elephants by the surrender of all the Grecker

  1. The Arthu≈õƒ´stre of Kautilyo

173

dominions as far as the Kabul valley’. This shows that Candragupta was a very capable man and therefore his cause was espoused by CƒÉnakya who hailerl from GƒÅndhƒÅra. Dr. Chhabra ( in the Woolner Commemoration Voluine pp. 51-52) suggests that in the story in the RƒÅmƒÅyana (UttarakƒÅnda 100-101 ) about the war between Bharata and his sons Taksa and Puskala on the one hand and Sail≈´sa on the other, Sail≈´ga stands for Seleucus. At present there is nothing but the phonetic resemblance of the two words in favour of this idea.

It is knowu that l’orns first fought with Alexander but later on he became reconciled to him ( Tarn’s work p. 169 ); however, other people in North-West India fought despera tely with Alexander (ibil!. Alexander died in 323 B. C. It is highly probable that Parvataka mentioned as the father of Malayaketu in the Mudr√ºr≈´knasa is the king Porus who (after first opposing Alexander) had become an ally of the Greeks in Alexander’s days ( Tarn pr. 46, 169 ). Some Jaina sources put the accession of Caudragupta at 312 or 313 B. C. (vide Cambridge History of India vol. I, 1922 p. 698 and Bhattasali in J. R. A. S. 1932 pp. 273, 284 ). Tarn suggests that Candragupta seized Magudha in 321 B. C. and completad the conquest of the whole of Northern Iudia (including the countries in the Northwest) by 312 B. C. (vide Tarn’s work p. 47 n. 3). Much of this history is conjectural. One thing is quite clear that Candragupta got possession of some territory to the West of the Indus and secured some parts in the Panjab and also the crowu of Magadha. But the sequence of the several events is not clear and not beyond debate. From the MudrƒÅrƒÅksasa it appears that Candragupta first secured Panjab (probably with the help of Canakya and his suppor ters) in addition to what he got ceded by Seleucus, that C√°nakya was most probably from Gandh≈´ra, as in his treat ment of VƒÅk pƒÅr≈´sya (damage or injury by words ) be says (A. III. 18. 8 ) by that ( what precedes) are explained the defamation concerning the learning of professional story tellers and libel of the country of those who come from the country of Prajjunaka und Gaudhara'. As GandhƒÅra is specially mentioned here from among the dozens of countries in the continent of Iudia, it follows with great probability that he was born there or had lived there long. The story of Mudr√°raksasa shows that in the times of that author it wako believeil that Parvataki was killed by foul meuus, that oration

174

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

ments worn by Parvataka had fallen into the hands of Candra gupta (Act I just before verse 19 ) and verse 19 refers to five chiefs of North-West India as the most prominent among Mleccha chiefs. According to Greek sources, Porns was killed before B. C. 318 (Tarn’s work p. 46). The MudrƒÅrƒÅksasa opens when Candragupta had recently occupied the Magadha throne. In Act II of the MudrƒÅrƒÅksasa we read ( before verse 14 ) that Kusumapura ( the capital of Magadha ) had been invested by the army of Candragupta and Parvate≈õvara which consisted mostly of Sakas, Yavanas, KirƒÅtas, Kambojas, PƒÅrasikas and BƒÅhlikas and supported by the counsels of CƒÅ≈Üakya. This means that for securing the capital of Magadha soldiers from the Northwest of India had been brought by Candragupta and Parvataka and CƒÅ≈Üakya had the leading part in that. In Act III after verse 24 CƒÅnakya says to Candragupta, ‘we have recently secured the kingdom of the Nandas’ and in Act IV, 14 RƒÅk≈üasa himself tells Malayaketu that the Maurya has recently become king. It seems that Candragupta first gained provinces in Northwest India and then secured Magadha. Besides, in Act IV ( before verse five ) Malayaketu says that it was the tenth month after his father’s death. That shows that within a few months of Parvataka’s death, Candragupta had recovered the throne of Magadha and then engaged in a feigned quarrel with C√°nakya about Kaumudimahotsava in the capital. A short time before the false quarrel Malayaketu had left the capital. Hence, according to the MudrƒÅrƒÅksasa, Candragupta came to the throne about 317 B. C. if we accept the identity of Parvataka and Porus ( who died in 318 B. C. according to Tarn. ). The Cambridge History of India (vol. I, p. 470 ) holds that the MudrƒÅrƒÅksasa dates probably from the 7th century A. D., and that we need not question its evidence'.

In the KƒÅdambari of Bana ( first half of 7th century) we have a striking reference to Kautilya’s work as a cruel161 work because it mostly contains advice that is ‘very wicked’. This shows how Kautilya’s work had already become unpopular in North India ( before the first half of the 7th century ) on acco unt of its vigorous advocacy of the doctrine that the end justi. fies the means. This explains to some extent the paucity of

161 ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡•É‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§®‡§ø‡§ò‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•å‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§

EATINDER

1.4. The Arthu≈õƒÅstra of Kautilya

175

the mss. of the Artha≈õƒÅstra in the whole of India, particularly in North India, from where so far only a fragment of a ms. of the work has been recovered. The MatsyapurƒÅna (7. 63) contains a story in which the speaker (Indra ), who is suppo sed to have interfered with the womb of Diti that contained 49 foetuses and then made them Maruts, is made to say that he commited a wicked deed following the precepts of Artha sastra.102 This is probably a reference to the Kau≈£iliya by the author of the Matsya-PurƒÅna in the present state of our knowledge. If this be accepted the Artha≈õƒÅstra would have to be pushed back at least some centuries before 250-300 A.D., the probable date of the Matsya, as deinonstrated in H, of Dh. S. Vol. V. pp. 852, 854.

The extant Artha≈õƒÅstra itself claims that it is a work of Kautilya. (1) This SƒÅstra ( book ), that is easy to learn and to understand, that is definite as regards its essence, meaning and words, that is free from prolixity in matter has been com posed by Kautilya; (2) Having gone through all ≈õƒÅstras one after another and having secured (knowledge of) the practice (in such matters ), Kautilya composed these rules about edicts for the sake of kings (II. 10. 63). In the very first sentence of his work he states' this one text-book on the science of polity has been composed mostly by collecting toge ther (the teachings ) of as many treatises as have been establi shed by ancient teachers for securing the acquisition and pro tection of the earth ( realm ); (3) This SƒÅstra ( text-book ) has been composed by him who, in resentment quickly raised (re-arranged or regenerated ) the science of Politics, the wea pon (to strike down enemies ) and the earth that had fallen into the hands of the Nanda kings. eighty times and the testimony of comparatively early works and authors like the MudrƒÅrƒÅksasa (5th or 6th century A. D. probably ), BƒÅna (first half of 7th century A. D. ), the Dasa kumƒÅracarita make a very strong case for holding Kautilya as the author of the work on Artha≈õƒÅstra.

At the end of the whole work we find a verse which means ‘on seeing the numerous divergent views of the com mentators on the SƒÅstras (other text-books on politics ), Vi≈ünugupta himself composed (a work ) containing both sutra and bhƒÅsya ‘.16 This verse is not composed by Visnu gupta but by some one else. It does not mean that the Artha≈õƒÅstra has s≈´tras and bhƒÅsya thereon. It means that the work includes the form and merits of both s≈´tras and bhƒÅsyas thereon i.e. it is very brief when that quality is requ ired and it contains detailed expositions when they are requi red. He knew that svƒ´tras must above all be alpƒÅk≈üara’ (concise ) and a bhƒÅsya. must explain the meaning of the words of the sutra and add expository material. Vide H. of Dh. Vol. V. p. 1182, notes 1926-27 about the characteristics of s≈´tra and bhƒÅsya. The aphoristic style (in K. A. ) may be seen in such passages as ). 2. 1-10, 1. 3. 1-15, II. 10. 13-20, III. I. 6-11; the expository style may be seen in VII. 1. 32, V. 5.7 and long sentences in I. 21. 7, VII. 15. 12. etc. Johnston in his

two studies in the Artha≈õƒÅstra of Kautilya’in JRAS for 1929 (pp. 77-102 ) states that the Larik√°vatƒÅras≈´tra was translated into Chinese in 443 A. 1.1. The Arthu≈õƒÅstra of Kautilya

177

to centuries preceding the Christian era and therefore the name of Kautilya, it seems, was known some centuries before Christ and as most of the names are those of authors, Kauti lya should also lie regarded as an author in this passage.

The Tantr√•khyƒÅyika ( the earliest extant version of the Pa√±catantra ) which, acc. to Prof. Hertel ( the editor in HOS ), is certainly not later than 300 A.D., pays homage to Canakya the great as one of the expounders of Rƒ´ja≈õƒÅstra ( verse 2). Dr. Jolly (Intro. p. 8 ) wants to put the date of TantrƒÅkhyƒÅ yikƒÅ one century later (in order to be able to say that Artha ≈õƒÅstra might have been composed about 300 A. D. ) simply on the ground that the collection of tales was not translated into Pahlavi till about 570 A. D. and since the collection of tales agrees closely with the Pahlavi translation. This is not a tenable argument at all. The Pa√±catantra had several versions. We do not know what version the Persian translator had before him. He may have translated from a version older than other versions available in India at that time.

Dr. Jolly remarks (on p. 10 of Intro.) that the exhorta tion to soldiers contained in A. (x. 3 ) are quite ‘misleading. There are two verses in the exhortation ( quoted below).104a The first occurs in the extant ParƒÅ≈õarasmrti III. 44, which is comparatively a late smrti as shown below (under ParƒÅ≈õara smrti ). Therefore, the first verse ( if it is a genuine part of the original Artha≈õƒÅstra ) might have been borrowed by both A. and ParƒÅ≈õarasƒ±n»ôti from some other earlier work. The 2nd verse occurs in the Pratij√¨ƒÅ-Yaugaudharayana IV. 3 (one of the so-called Bh≈´sa plays). There is a sharp cleavage of opinion among Sanskrit scholars as to whether all the numerous plays published as BhƒÅsa’s are the works of the ancient Bhasa who is praised even by KƒÅlidƒÅsa. The pre sent author holds that almost all the published plays attri

buted to BhƒÅsa are not the works of the ancient BhƒÅsa. Besi des, the verses yƒÅn yaj√±asanghaih’ and ‘navam sarƒÅvam’ are preceded by the words ‘≈õrnvantu atrabhavantah’ in the speech of the gƒÅtrasevaka in the play. So, he appears to be quoting from another source. Further, the Pratij√±ƒÅ shows acquaintance with Artha≈õƒÅstra.165 Besides, the king’s exhor tation has iti’ at the end of X. 3. 27. The passage' vedesva pyanusr√ºyate … … hantavyah' has iti at the end and there is iti at the end of the two verses also. The passages ( x. 3 29-31 ) seem to be later additions and there are three itis instead of one in the supposed exhortation of the king. Therefore, if the two verses occur in the A. they are both quotations and further they may have been taken over by the ParƒÅ≈õara Smrti and the Pratij√±ƒÅ from the Artha≈õƒÅstra. Sten Konow in ‘Kautilya Studies’ (Oslo, 1945, pp. 1-71 )' sees no serious objection to the theory of BhƒÅsa borrowing from Kautilya' (p. 6). Dr. B. M. Barua in BliƒÅrata-Kaumudi vol. I. pp. 85-119 ( paper styled ‘Artha≈õƒÅstra, a blend of old and new’) seems to hold that both verses in A. X. 3 are traceable in the plays of Bh≈´sa (p. 99 ) but he does not condescend to tell his readers in what drama of BhƒÅsa the first verse ‚ÄúYan yaj√±asanghaih' occurs. Dr. Jolly also (Intro. p. 10 ) is vague about these two verses. He does not state from what play the verse ¬∑ Yan yaj√±ao' is taken. The first verse ‘Yan yaj√±asanghaih’ with slight variations is quoted from Visuudharma by Hein√§dri on Vrata -k√µnda vol. II p. 971 ( and as stated above it occurs in ParƒÅ≈õara Smrti also ). It is remarkable that even Keith on r. 491 (in B. C. Law Felicita tion Volume Part I ), vaguely says ‘In A. (X.3) are to be found two verses which apparently are taken from BhƒÅsa’, He never bothered to tell his readers in what play the first verse occurs, just as Dr. Barua and Dr. Jolly do. This is a good example of how sweeping assertions are made by even experienced scholars.

Among the circumstances for rejecting the thirteen Trivan drum plays as the works of the famous BhƒÅsa, a predecessor of KƒÅlidƒÅsa, may be mentioned the following: (1) the plays

1917

1.). The Arthu≈õƒÅstra of Kuutilyo

179

have come down anonymously; ( 2 ) verses ascribed to Bhasa in several anthologies are not found in the thirteen plays; (3) even verses quoted from a play called SvapnavƒÅsavadattƒÅ are not found in the SvapnavƒÅsavadattƒÉ ( of Trivandrum ); ( 4 ) that out of thirteen plays five are only one act plays not fit to be called NƒÅtakas at all. Vide a paper in Calcutta Review for 1924 (October-December ) pp. 339-349. Several scholars have placed Bhisa at the end of the 2nd century A.D. e. g. Sten Konow (in E. Kuhu Presentation vol. 106 ff. and Losny in J. O. I., Baroda ) vol. XIII No. 1 p. 48. This does not affect those who hold that A. belongs to about 300 B. C.

One question about Candragupta may be briefly mention ed here. Puranas vive confused accounts, Matsya ( 272. 26 ) and VƒÅyu ( 99. 326-27 ) state that the kings after MahƒÅpadma will be born of S≈´dra women. But VƒÅyu states that MabƒÉ nandi’s son from a S√ºdra wife will be MahƒÅpadma. That means that Caudrayupta was deemed at the time of the PurƒÉ plas to be the son of a Ksatriya from a S≈´dra wife. The author of the MudrƒÅrƒÅksasa ( whether he belonged to the 5th century A. D. or 6th or later) came long after the Puranas, was per meated by PaurƒÅnic lure and therefore he generally uses the word ‘vrsala’ (which means ≈ö≈´dra in medieval Sanskrit works ) with reference to Candragupta when speaking of him personally, but in his absence he several times employs merely the word ‘Candragupta’ (as after 1. 12. 14 ) or Vrsala (just before I. 10). In II. 18 just before approaching king Candra gupta occupying the throne C√¢nak ya speaks of him as Vrsa lena Vr≈üe≈Üa rƒÅjuam’ (Vrsala, the best of kings ). There is absolutely no evidence to hold that the kingmaker C√°nakya called hiin Vrsala'. It is the dramatist saturated thro ugh and through with laurƒÅ≈Üika ideas that Ksatriyas ceased to exist after the Nandas, who applies the word Vrsala to king Candragupta. But it must be emphasized that the MudrƒÅrƒÅk≈üasa also shows that Nandakula was the pit≈ôkula of Candragupta, acc. to RƒÅk≈üasa ; vide the words ‘Nandakulu manena pitrkulabh≈´tam gh≈´titam’ (after IV. 12 ) and V. 19

‚Ä¢ Mauryossau Sv≈´miputrah.' It is to be noted that in the MudrƒÅrƒÅksasa CƒÉnakya refers to Caudragupta as Vakogu also (just before I. 19). Frantic efforts have been made by some writers (e. g. by Mr. Goviud Pai in Gode com. vokamos part III pp. 141-150, particularly p. 146, by Mr. K. CASH in I. II. O. Vol. 13, pp. 641-653, and by H. K. Deb in I. Eldorferie

OONA

1917

A

Research Instit

180

llistory of Dhurmu≈õcistru.

Vol. 8, pp. 466-479) to explain away the word ‘Vroala ‘in certain ways such as holding Vrsala as the Sanskrit equiva lent of the word Basileos (Basileus ) occurring on the obverse of the coins of Menander and Demetrius ( who became king in 190 B. C. ; vide Cambridge History of India, Vol. I. pp. 586, 588). But this is a vain etfort and has not been accepted by many scholars. The Chamberlain’s words on the simple fur nishings of CƒÅnukya’s abode (Act III before verse 16 ) ‘to him His Majesty Candragupta is a mere Vrsala and rightly so’ indicate in what sense the word Vrsala was applied to Candragupta by Visakhadatta in the Madriraksasa or was understood by the Chamberlain. It should be noted, however, that the word Vrsala occurs in Rg. X. 34. 11 and is applied to the gambler (‘so aguer-ante Vrsalah papƒÅda’). Here Vrsala seems to mean ‘a miserable or unhappy person’. In the Rgveda ‘la’ is a flixed to some words as indicating endearmentor sympathy e.g. the word sis√∫la’ in Rg. X. 78. 6. Several papers have been written on the origin of Candravuptr such as in B.C. Law presentation Vol. pp. 590-610, by Dr. A. Ghosh in I. H. Q. Vol. VI pp. 271-283 ( which rebuts S√ºlra origin), and by Dr. R. K. Mukerjee in Woolner Commemoration Vol. pp. 93 99. Rƒ´ksasa speaks of Candragupta as Mauryaputra in the draina ( Act 11. 7) but Kulahina’ and in VI. 6 he calls him Vrsala which word in the context means nothing else but S≈´dra (his words being gatƒÉ sighrena srirvisalam-aviniteva vrgali). The difficulty is that we have no contemporary record about the status of Candragupta ( i. e. about 320 B.C.). The views of ancient sages differeil. Vasistha (I. 25) expressly states that some allowed even a dviju to marry a S≈´dra woman but without the use of Vedic mantras. Manu III. 13 (latter half) who allowed a Ksatriya to marry a woman of his own varna or a vai≈õya or a s√ºdra woman condemns in III. 14 such marri ages. It is possible that in the 4th century B. C. a Ksatriya could validly marry a S≈´dra woman. Kautilya provides (Artha≈õƒÅstra III. 6. 22 ) that in the case of BrƒÅhmunas the ≈üon born of a ≈õ≈´dra wife should receive one-third of the decea sed father’s property as his share and u Sapinda as heir shall receive two-thirds' for the purpose of offering the oblations to the deceased.

The Anusasunupurva says ‘tisro bh√§ry√§ brƒÅhmanisya dve bhƒÅrye ksatriyasya tu i ratyarthamapi sadrƒ´ syƒÅn-nabyna burapare janƒÅ·∏•’( 44. 11-12).
