previous commentators in the words ‘‘anye’, ‘apare’. It quotes several slokas of Brhaspati on the blemishes of dia monds and on prakc≈õc-taskuras. The commentary Naya candrik√° contained in Dr. Jolly’s edition (Lahore ) also is incomplete and begins with the 7th adhyƒÅya of the 7th adhi karana and breaks off in the 4th adhyƒÅya of 12th adhikarana. It also refers to the views of its predecessors in the words. ‘kecit’ &c. ( vide pp. 35, 61, 62, 104, 115, 131, 191 ). It discusses various readings (pp. 136, 183, 188, 193 &c. ).

Dr. Shamasastri includes in his edition 571 s√∫tras attri buted to Canakya. Their relation to the Kautiliya is a subject which requires careful investigation. In my own opinion they are later than the Kautiliya. It would be beyond the scope of this work to enter into details. Vide Dr. Jacobi’s article in Indian Historical Quarterly, rol. III., pp. 669-676.

There are several niti collections attributed to Canakya and published several times in different parts of India. All. of them are later than the Kau≈£iliya and are compilations of maxims and fine sayings. One of them the Canak ya–rƒÅjaniti ≈õƒÅstra ( publisherl in Calcutta Oriental series, 1921, 2nd edi tion ) contains 660 verses and was compiled under BhojarƒÅja. Several other compilations pass under the names Vpadha C√¢makya, Laghu-CƒÅvakya &c. All these are passed over here from considerations of space and utility.

Dr. Sternbach has devoted much labour and time to the several works published under the name of Canakya. Those interested may read the following: J., A. 0. S. Vol. 76. pp. 115-130 ( CƒÉnakya’s aphorisms in the Hitopade≈õa pussa ges ), J. A. O. S. Vol. 77 pp. 26-31, 107-115, 166-183 ), J. A. 0. S. Vol. 79, pp. 233-254 ( MƒÅpavadharmasastra verses in Canakya’s compendia ), JAOS. Vol. 83, pp. 30-66 ( MahƒÉ bhƒÅrata verses in C√¢nakya’s compendia ), ABORI Vol. 37, pp. 58-110, ABORI Vol. 42, pp. 99-122 ( Tibetan RƒÅjaviti ≈†ƒÅstra ), Vishreshvaranada Indological Journal I. pp. 66-77. ( verses from three anthologies examined ).

A few matters may be emphasized here that make the K. A. unique in some respects.

Even in the Vedic age there were high functionaries and officers of state and their names slightly differed in different

History of Dhuruts√§stra

functions, since Artha’ X. 33. 332 provides that the king should make the mantrin and purohita to accompany him in battle and to eucourage the soldiers by lwelling upon the excellence of the array ( vy≈´ha ) of troops in battle (and in X. 3. 44 ) the assistants of the purohita should speak ( to the soldiers ) about the acts of sorcery and black magic ( undertaken by them ). The Senapati ( commander-in-chief) held a purely secular office and in II. 3. 33-34 K. states his qualifications, duties and functions, and in X. 3. 45 provides that the SenƒÅ pati should acƒ±dress the soldiers of the army after they are made well-disposed by the payment of money and the besto wal of honours and should offer to pay one hundred thousand panus to him who would kill the enemy king, 50 thousand for killing ( in battle ) the SenƒÅpati or prince of the opposing army and lastly by offering double wages and gift of whatever il soldier may seize from the opposing army. It may be noted that K. provides ( in V. 3. 28-29 ) that of those that die on duty the sous and wives shall receive food and wages and their minor children, olid men and sick persons should be shown favour ( should be helped ).

The king’s priine duty was to offer security and pro tection to the subjects. Ap. Dh. S. (II. 10. 26. 4-8 ) pro vides that the king should appoint for the protection of the subjects in villages and cities jersons of the first three varnas, pure as to money and truth-loving and the assistants (purusas ) of those also should be possessed of the same virtues and that the king should arrange to guard a city against thieves for one yojan in all directions and a village for a kroza and they should re-imburse what is stolen with. in those limits Kilutilya makes an approach to the welfare state in IV. 3. 1–2, where he calls upon the king to protect the country from eight great calamities viz, fire, foods, disease (epidemic), famine, rats, wild elephants (and similar animals ), serpents and evil spirits (or demons) and he provides reme dies for these and arlds that in all such cases the king should favour the afflicted (people ) like a father (sarvatra copa hat√°n pitevƒÅnugƒºhniyat ). & brƒÅhmana learned in the Veda, the women of all the four Vulnas, boys that have not moustaches, even grown-up per sons as long as they stay with their teachers for instruction, persons performing austerities for religions purposes, a sidra washing the feet of persons of the other three varnas i. e. ser ving them, persons blind, dezafundonub and diseased, ascetics who have no money because they are not allowed by ≈õƒ´stra to possess money. The Dhurmus≈´tras further say that it is the duty of the king to see that none in his realƒ±n perishes through hunger, disease, extreme heat or cold or of set, purpose.

Another striking matter is K’s references to confederacies of oligarchic or republican Slates ( in the 11th Adhikarana about sanghus, which covers less than three printed pages ). He states ( XI. 1. 1-3) securing an oligarchy on one’s side is better than securing an ariny or an ally; for sanghas being well-kuit become unassailable by enemies. Those ( sanghas.) that are friendly should be won over by ( a policy of) con ciliation and gifts, while those that are hostile ( should be dealt with ) by ( sowing ) disseusions (among them ) and by force. Then K. inentions two clusses of oligarchies (X1. 1. 4-5 ).224 One class of Sanghas existed in the countries of Kamboja and SurƒÉstra and there were corporations of Ksatri yas also; all these maintained themselves ordinarily by igri. culture, trade and the profession of arms, while there were other sanghas vix. Licchavikas, Vijis, Mallakas, Mudrakus,

History of Dhurna≈õrƒ´stru.

Kukuras, Kurus and Panc≈´las, that maintained themselves on the title of rƒ´jun applied to them ( i. e. they were not culti vators of the soil aud mere soldiers, but they were chiefs or nobles ). K. A. in VIII. 3. 62-64 ) remarks that of the vices of gambliny and drinkiny, gambling is worse and that particularly, in the case of sigla and royal families, that the characteristics of a saigha viz. dissensions are caused by Gambling that lead to destructions; bence gambling is the greatest amony vices since it leads to weakness in governing

It is noteworthy that in the passage quoted in the foot. note about sanghas ( oligarchies ), K. I. separately mentions the Licchavikas and Vrjikas as saigh13, while some modern writers such as Dr. U. N. Ghoshal (p. 1 of his address in 1983 as President of the Asiatic Society of Bengal ) treut them as identical. Rhys Davids in ‘Buddhist Iudia’ (pp.19-26) suininarises the data about Indian Republics derived froin Buddhist works and points out that the Vajjians ( Vrjikas of K. A.) had eight confeilerite clans of which the Licchavis and the Videhas were inost important. The word ≈õreni ( found in K. A. ) is very ancient, occurring as it does frequently in the sense of gronp, row, Hock’even in the Ryverla (e. g. in 1. 163. 10, III. 8.9) and gana' occurs dozens of times in the Rg. The word saigla' is mentioned frequently by Panini (in III. 3. 86 in the sense of gana'), V. 2. 52, V. 3. 114 ( referring to Ayudhajivi.-5a ghas' among V√§hikas ). In V. 3. 115-117 P√•nini inentions several Ayudha-jivisanghas such as V√§rkenyah or VrkƒÅ·∏•, Pira≈õavah ( singular ) or Par≈õavah (plural), Yandheyah (or YaudheyƒÅh in V. 3. 117 ). In I. 6. 10 K. A. reports that the saigha of the Vranis perished by their foolhardiness in trying to assail Drai pƒÅyaua. The Mal√§bhƒÅrata does not mention the attack on DyaipƒÅyana. The Mahabharata states that the Y√•davas included Vrouis, Andhakas, Bhojas ( Mausala parva I. 14 ) and also Kukuras ( Mausala 5. 2), Mausala (chap. 3 ) shows that Y√ºdavas fought ainong themselves and perished. In S√ºnti 81. 25 Kinna is said to be the chief ( President ) of the Sangha of Vrsnis and in the Bhagavad-gita Kina is identi fied with V√§sudeva of the Vrsnis. In Santi 107 there is an interesting discussion as to the causes of the destruction of the Sanglas and Ganas. It is quite possible that K. me tlone Licchavikas and Vijikis separately on the analogy oMttre,

.

  1. The Arthesestru of Kautilya

253

ny√ºyas called ‘yo-balivarda’ or brƒÅhmana-parivr√§jaka' for which see H. of Dh. Vol. V. p. 1347. For the Licchavis of VaisƒÅli, vide I. H. Q. XIX p. 98 und Jayaswal’s History p. 112. For the Mallas, vide ¬∑ Buddhist India' p. 26, D. R. Bhandarkar’s Ancient India' pp. 51, 79. Kukura is associ. ated with Apar√§nta in the Nasik cave Inscription of Vasisthi putra Pulumivi and in the Junagad Inscription of Rudra. d√°m” (E. I. VIII. pp. 44, 60 ). The Yaudheyas are said to have been routeil by Rudradiman ( E. I. VIII. at p. 44 ). On Yuudheyas, vide Quarterly Journal of Mythic Society ( Vol. Silver Jubilee No. pp. 114-116 ) and Dr. Altekar’s paper on ‘Yaudheyas’ in U. P. Historical Society’s Journal Vol. 16 pp. 52-57 and Panini IV. 1. 178 119 pr√°cyn-Bharg≈´di yau.beyƒÅilibhyuh'. The Bylint-surbita (IV. 25, XIV. 28, XVI. 21 ) reiers to Yuudheyas and Arjunayanas. Vide Karna Jarvan 5. 48 and Subhisi 52. 14-15 for Yuuilheyas. .

Another distinctive feature of K’s work is the division of the urdministration into two branches, viz. the rural area (junc pullie ) and the Duryi ( cepitil or urban area ) each with distinct officers and duties. The tirst was in charge of the Sunshartr and the Pradestr ( K. A. II. 6 and 35, IV.1.1) and the urbau area ( Durm) under the N√§yuriku335 (city Superintendent ) as stated in K. A. II. 36. 1 ( samƒÅhurtrvan. nigariko pagaram cintiyet ), the last having to look after the city (or capital ). The city or Cipital was divided into four wards, each under an officer called Sthanika: un officer called Ciopa was to look after ten families or twenty or forty families and was to find out the total nunber of persons, men and women (described ) according to caste, gotra ( family name ) and occupation and also their income and expenditure. Numer ous details about regulations and fines to be imposed by the Nagarika are provided, which are passed over here. As regards the rural area the Sameharty was to form it into four divisions, (place euch division under an officer called sthƒÅnika and officers called yopas under the directions of sthƒÅnikas, were to look after groups of five or ten villages, prepare registers fixing the boundaries of villages, l’egisters of the

225

houses and fields that were to pay (or were not to pay ) taxes, to record tlie number of persons belonging to the four varuas, the number of persons that were farmers, cowherds, traders, labourers or slaves, the number of two-fonted or four footed animals and the extent of money or forced labour, of duties (tolls &c.) and fines to be levied, the number of males and females among the families, the number of children and old persons, their occupations, their ( peculiar ) customs ( caritri) and their incoine and expenditure. It would be noticed how elaborate were the provisions prescribed by K. for the preparation of a complete census of the capital as well as of the rural area.

*In the B. I. edition (1884) of the K√§mundakiya-uitis√°ra by Rajendrala! Mitra with a com. compiled by three Pandits the word Kautalya is explained as follows: ‘Kutu’ means ‘ghata’: ( with affix lic) Kitala’ means one who stores only as much coru as fills a jar and Kautalya would mean a descendant of such a person.386 The learned editor of the ArthasƒÅstra in the Trivandrum series, N. M. Ganapati Sastri accepts this (Intro. p. 4 ) and the only authority he cites for Kuutaly’u as a gotra naine is that of a very late lexicon called N√ºn√ºrth√•rnavasa iksepa of Kesavasv√§mnin. It is remarkable that the learned Mabamahopadhyaya prints the wame of the work as Kau≈£iliyam and in the opening verse of his commentary also keeps the word Kau≈£iliya and in the first sentence ( of the coin). also prints the author’s name as Kautilya, on p. 23 in the last verse of the first chapter he reads “Kautilyena krtam ≈õƒÅstram', again on p. 27 he prints' catasra eva vidya iti Kautilyah', on p. 33.neti Kautilyah' and on p. 39' Artha eve pradhƒÅna iti Kautilyah'. It is difficult to believe that the great Mahama. hopadhyaya, who had till then editel 80 works and who bad two mss. of the work in Tamil characters and one in Telugu characters, printed the author’s name as Kautilya by sheer carelessness (unuvudhand, as he states in his Sanskrit In troduction ). STITUT

FOUNDEI

1917

1.4. The Arthrostro of Kautilya

255

careless aud writes the word as Kautilya many times instead of Kautalya (which his three mss. supported as he says ) it is easy to believe that some later scribes purposely changed the word or carelessly wrote it as Kautalya. The form Kautalya makes its appearance in some works and inscriptions after the Ilth or 12th century A. D. This was probably due to later writers' unwillingness to hold that the great Canakya who helped Candragupta to drive away the Greeks from India and wrote an excellent work on Politics should have borne such an opprobrious name as Kautilya. But the word Kautalya makes hardly any sense. Manu (IV. 7-8) recommends that BrƒÅhma·πáas should not amass wealth, should not have more corn than what is contained in a granary of bricks or that they should be kumbhidhanya or possess only as much grain as would suffice for three days ( for the family and servants ) or only for one day. YƒÅj. ( I. 124 and 128 ) provides that a good brƒÅhmana shonld have only as much stock of grains as would suffice for one year ( for family &c) and should not go in for a Soma sacrifice if he has less or should have as much grain as would be contained in a granary or contained in a Kumbhi or as would last for three days or one day. These ancient smytis (Manu IV. 8, YƒÇj. I. 128) provide that the more penurious a brƒÅhmaya is the more lie becomes praiseworthy or should be more honoured. The commentators differ about the meaning of Kus√ºladh√¢nya and Kumbhi-dhanya (vide Kull≈´ka on Manu IV. 7). Kumbhidh·∫£nya means either one who has in store as much corn as would last for six months (MedhƒÉtithi ) or as would last for six days (GovindarƒÅja ). But no ove uses the word kutadhanvah or chatadh√¢nyah. Kumbhi is a technical word in Manu and Y√Çj. Therefore, to take lutule as Kumbhidh√°nya is not only far-fetched but unwarranted. Besides, the Puranas ( e. g. Matsya and V√°yu), B√•na bhatta, MudrƒÅrƒÅksusa, and Bhavabh≈´ti ( who employs' the words- Kutila-Daya-nisnƒÉta manasƒÅm') point to Kautilya as the name and no one has shown that Kautalya occurs in early Inscriptions (though Kautilya occurs as a gotra in early inscriptions from the 7th century A. D. ). Vide Danda viveka of VardhamƒÅna Pp. 134-135 for a discussion of the meaning of Kumbha ( it winds up by saying ‘n√°n√§rtha em Kumbha≈õabda·∏•)’.

In the S√§ntiparva ( 243. 2-3 ) it is stated that there are four ways of mainteuance for i br√ºhmana householder, via

POORA

256

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstri

may be Kus√ºladh√¢nya or KumbhadhƒÅnya or he may be a

Asvastana’i. e. storing only as much corn as would suffice for a day or he may follow the way of Kapota birds and that each one of these ways is superior to each preceding one. The Manusmrti (IV. 7-8) mentions four ways of living for a brƒÅhmana viz. Kus√ºladhƒÅnya, Kumbhidh√¢nya, Tryahaihiku (one storing only as much corn as would suffice for three days for the family and servants) or he may be asvastanika' (not storiny even for the next day ). The Manu-smrti (in IV. 4-6, states that a brƒÅhmana householder may follow for his livelihood the method of rta (i. e. collecting with his fingers grains that have fallen down in a field or on a public way or collecting the fallen pods of grain ) or the method amrtƒ± ( grain yot without asking ) or of mito ( collecting alms by begging) or of premrta, ( method of agriculture ) or by sutyan rton (i.e. traile); but a brahmana should not follow Svavrtti ( doy’s way i. e. serving or labouring for another). Visvar≈´pa on Y√¢j. I. 127 ( where also the words Kusuladhanya and KumbhidhƒÅnya are used ) explains that” kus√ºla means Kosthaka and is a measure for corn equal to twenty drons and Kumbhi is half of that and quotes a half verse ( Da≈õadroni smrtƒÅ Kumbhi Kus≈´lo dvi gunastata·∏•, ityabhiyuktopade≈õƒÅt ). (In VIII. 3-20) Manu provides the punishment of vudha (either whipping, cutting of a limb or death ) as the punishment for a thief who steals more corn than ten Kumbhis. Vi≈õvar≈´pia on Yaj. I. 127 (Vol. 1 p. 104 of T. S. S.) explains that Kusula is Kosthaka and is a measure of corn equal to twenty dronas and Kumbhi is half of that and quotes a verse ( Da≈õa dron√§h sm·ªôt√° Kumbbi Kus≈´lo dvigunastatah ). KsirasvƒÅmin on Amarakosa men tions Kudava, Prastha, ƒÄ≈Öhaka, Dro∆∞a and KhƒÅri as measures, parimƒÅras ), quotes a verse, stating four Palas are equal to Kudava, four Kudavas are equal to prastha, four prasthas are equal to ≈´dhaka, cight ƒÅdhakas are equal to dro≈Üa and the quantities of these measures differ in different countries i. e. in some countries four ƒÅdhakus are equal to drona and twenty dronas inake a Kumbha. The Mit. on YƒÅj. III. 265 quotes Manu VIII. 320 and remarks that Kumbha is equal to five thousand pular. A Kumbha or Kumbhi was a large measure in any case and not a mere jar, as M. M. Ganapatisastri says without any autlalarity Therefore, from ku»õa (a jar), one cannot jump to the condinsion that kutala would mean Kumbhidhinya or Kumbhadham

  1. VaikhƒÅnasa-dharma-prasna The work has been published in the Trivandrum Sanskrit Series by Pandit T. Gunapati Sastri (1913) and also edited by Dr. Caland in B. I. Series (1927) and translated into English ( 1929 ) with a learned Introiluction.

Mahadeva in his commentary called Vaijayanti ( AnandƒÅ srama ed.) on the SatyasƒÅdha Franta s≈´tra speaks of six Srauta Sutras of the Black Yajurveda viz. BaudhƒÅyana, BharadvƒÅja , ƒÄpastamba, Hiranyake≈°in, V√§dh≈´la and VaikhƒÅ nasa, and frequently cites passages from the VaikhƒÅnasa srautas≈´tra. In the Carana vy≈´lia of Saunaka, V√†dh≈´la and Vaikhanasa are not mentioned. But that VaikhƒÅnasa was a very ancient writer follows from the references contained in the ancient dharma works. In Gautaina the word Vaikha nasa' occurs (Dh. S. III. 2) as the name for the order of forest hermits ( Vivaprastha ) and in another S≈´tra (III. 26 ) he lays down that fire was to be consecrated according to the SrƒÅma≈Üaka,227 which latter is explained by Haradatta as VaiklƒÅnasa SƒÅstra. Baudhayana (Dh. S. II. 6. 17 ) has the same S≈´tra228 and defines a Vaikhanaga as one who follows the rules of conduct laid down in ViikhƒÅnasa sastra (Dh. S. II. 6. 16 ). The Vasistha Dh. S. (9. 10 ) also has the same s≈´tra as Gautama (Dh. S. III. 26). The Manusmrti (VI. 21) speaks of the V√§najrastha as one who abiiles by the views of VaikhƒÅnasa ( VaikhƒÅnasamate sthital ). Gau. III. 25-34 and Vas. IX. 1-11 deal with Vaikhannsa. Printed Gaut. III. 26 reads ‘≈õravanaken√§gnim√±dhƒÅya’ while Vas. IX. 10 hus' sra manakenƒÉgnim≈´dhƒÅyƒÅhitƒÅgnili syƒÅt'.

He is then above and beyond all the ordinary relations of life, such as, if he was a sramana before, he becomes a≈õramana or if he was a tiposu he becomes devoid of that state &c. Vide Tai. Ar. The VaikhƒÅnasadharmapra≈õna is divided into three pras nas, each pra≈õna being subdivided into khandas. There are in all 41 khandas. The work is a small one. The contents of the work are :-). the four wrnols and their privileges, and the four ƒÅ≈õrumas ; duties of brahmacarin; four kinds of brah mac≈´rins ; duties of the householder; four kinds of grhastha, vƒÅrtƒÅvrtti ( subsisting by agriculture ), sƒÅliva, yƒÅyƒÅvara and ghorƒÅcƒÅrika; forest anchorites; vƒÅnaprasthas are either sapat nika ( accompanied by their wives ) or apatnika (not so acco mpanied ); Saputnika are of four sorts, Audumbara, Vairi√±ca, V√°lakhilya and Phenapa; apatnƒ´ka VƒÅna prasthas; four kinds of bhiksus, viz. kuticaka, bah≈´daka, hamsa and parama hamsa; sakƒÅma (performed with desire of wordly gain ) and ni≈ükƒÅma (not so performed ) kurma; pravrtti and niv»ôtti; three kinds of Yogins and their sub-divisions ; II. the details of the grƒÅmanaka rites of the vƒÅnaprastha ( khandas 1-4); duties of the forest hermit; details of joining the order of sa·πÅnyƒÅsins ( khandas 6-8); age for samnyƒÅsa ( above seventy or when childless or widower); every day duties and obiger vances of samnyƒÅsins; about ƒÅcumana and sandhyƒÅ; sa Mare

ing ( abhivƒÅdana ) of all relatives, male and female; holidays from study (anadhyƒÅya); bath and Brahmayaj√±a ; rules about taking food; forbidden and permitted food; III. rules of con duct for gphastha ( khandas 1-3); rules of the road; purifica tion of golden and other metallic things ; purification of other things; about vanaprastha; bhiksu; burial of a sannyƒÅsin ; NƒÅrƒÅyanabali on the death of a sanny≈´sin, tarpana in the case of sann y√∞sins with twelve names of Visnu, Ke≈õava &c. and with water; anuloma and praciloma; the intermediate castes; Vrutyus, their origin; name, and means of subsistence (khandas 11-15).

The Vaikbinasadharmapra≈õna appears by its style and its contents to be a work of comparatively later date than the dharmas≈´tras of Gautama and BaudbƒÅyana. It is probably a recast of older materials. It contains the names of more mixed castes than the dharmas√∫tras and than even some of the later smrtis. The present work seems to have been either written or retouched by u devotee of Vis≈≥u. Faith in and devotion to Vis≈Üu or NirƒÅyana looms very large here (I. 5. 5 vƒÅrƒÅyana parƒÅya·πáƒÅh, I. 7.6 and 9; II. 4-5 bhakty≈± Visnum dhyƒÅyan, III. 7.3; N√°rayanaparam brahmeti brutah, (IIH 9.3 Visno rƒÉlayapƒÅrsve). It speaks of the eight angas of Yoga ( I. 10. 9 ), of the Ayurveda with its eight anges and of some treatise on evil spirits ( bh≈´tatantra III. 12. 7). It refers to the views of some in the word ‘eke’ (1. 7. 4. and II. 9. 10). It speaks of the SrƒÅmanaka fire (in I. 6.2 and I. 7. 3-4). It does not allow sauny≈´sue to Ksatriyas ( I. 1. 11 ). Vikhauas is cited as an authority (11. 5 9 and III. 15. 14 ).

B√ºhler found it ms. of the VaikhƒÅnasas≈´tra consisting of a grlƒ±ya in seven pra≈õnas, three pra≈õnas of dharma (the same as described above) and a fourth on pravurus. In the grhya a reference to Budhav√°ra occurs. " It is worthy of notice that the Vaikhanaga-gshya (II. 12. 1-2, Caland’s ed. p. 30 ) men tions BudhavƒÅra in ‘AthƒÅsƒÅdhop√°karma kury≈´t lƒÅpuryamƒÅna Pakse rikti-parvari varjayitvƒÉ BudhavƒÅre tithim gƒºh·ª•ƒÅti ‘, and that fifty ≈´butis are offered to Agni, the Earth, the four Vedas &c. and among others to Savitri, PrajƒÅpati, Usanas, Cyavana, B»ôhaspati, Angiras, Saikha, Likhita.

Besides, the Vaik. Gr. in IV. 10. 1. and 3 provides that after the daily homa in fire Vi≈ünu should be worshipped, at such worship becomes the worship of all gods and that up

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra -

image of Vinnu should be established in the house and wor ship should be offered to it in the morning and evening every day after homa. Further, the Grhya in IV. 13 provides for gruhusƒÅrti, since the proper functioning of the world depends on gruhus. They are mentioned in the same order as in YƒÅj. I. 295 and the procedure, though similar to that in YƒÅj. I. 295-308, is more elaborate on some points. For example, it refers (IV. 14 ) to the classification of naksatras into janma, karma, s√°rghƒÅtika, s√§mudƒÅyika and vainasika, which is not found in YƒÅj. but occurs in YogayatrƒÉ of Varaha mihira. Vide H. of Dh. Vol. V. part 1 p. 529, notes 762-63.

Dr. Caland in his paper on Vaikhanasas≈´tra holds that the Manusmrti borrows from VaikhƒÅnasagrhya and that the author of the latter was saturated with the idiom of Dravi :dian languages ( vide Prof. Keith’s review in Bulletin of tbe School of Oriental Studies, 1927, p. 623 ). Dr. Caland’s view about Manu is entirely wrong as will appear froin the section on Manu. Vide Th. Bloch in √ºber das Grhya-und Dharma s≈´tra der Vaikh≈´nasa’( Leipzig, 1896). … Dr. √áaland ( Intro. pp. XVI-XIX) put forward certain parallelisms between the Manusmrti and the Vaikhinasa smƒÅrta-s√∫tra. They are so flimsy that no serious notice need be taken of them and no acceptable conclusions can be based on them. Dr. Ergers published in 1929 ( at Gottingen ) his work Das Dharmas≈´tra des VaikhƒÅnasa’, which was reviewed in J. R. A. S. for 1929 pp. 916-918. Looking to all that has been stated above the extant Vaik. Grhya-s≈´tra and Dharma-s≈´tra are later than Y√ºj. and may be assigned to about 300 to 100 A. D. Vide Dr. Caland’s Intro. to the translation of the SmƒÅrtas≈´tra pp. XV ff.

Other Sutra Works on Dharma It will be proper to say a few words about some other s≈´tra works on dharma that are only available in mss. or are to be reconstructed from quotations in the digests. It is by no means to be supposed that these works that will be spoken of here were composed as early as those of Gautama, Anasta mba and others or’were composed before the extant Manu and Yaj≈àavalkya. But as the chronology of all ancient works on dharma is somewhat in a nebulous state, it is best to Weat here of all works, written in the s≈´tra style, even though

16, Atri

261

individual cases they inay really belong to a later age than the works composed entirely in verse. They will be taken up in alphabetical order (Sanskrit ).

  1. Atri That Atri was an ancient writer on hurma follows from & reference to him in Manu (III. 16 ) as holding the view that a crijati taking as wife a s√ºdra woman became fallen (patita). In the Deccan College collection there are several mss. ( Nos. 185-187 of A 1881-82 ) of the Atreyadharma≈õƒÅstra in nine adhyayas. They trent of gifts, prayers (japya ) and tupus by which men are free from all sins. Some of the chapters are in mixed prose and verse. The first three chapters are entirely in verse and some of the verses (such as ekƒÅksaram param brabma) occur in the Manusm»ôti. The fourth opens with a long s≈´tra, which, in style, resembles later bbƒÅsyas and com mentaries, 320 The 5th also is in verse and contains several verses found in Viisistha ( Dh. S. 28. 1, 4, 6). The sixth speaks of the specially boly hymns and verses of the Veda. Some of the verses here are the same as Vasistha ( 28. 10‚Äì11). “The seventh refers to secret prayascittas and the very first s≈´tra after the opening words sj.eaks of several non-Aryan tribes 230 such as the Sakas, Yavanas, kambhojus, Balbikas, Khusus, Vangus aud P√§rasu ( Persians ? ) &c. It is to be noted that the saine sutra ( with slight variations ) is quoted as Atri’s by Apariirka (on Ynj. III. 266 p. 1123). The 7th aud 8th chapters are in inixed prose and verse. The 9th is in verse and speaks of Yoya and its unyus. It refers to the fact that Sisup≈´lu, son of Damaghosa, because in his hatred of Govinda he always thought of the latter, went to heaven. The same sutra work is noticed in I. O. Cat., pp. 380-81, Nos. 1305 and 1306.

‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•à‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ

FirAZTOTT9-7-197-471H-TET Fat-ala 3-a1-are ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•Ä (?) ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§π‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡•á ‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§262

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

There are several works styled Atri-smrti or samhitƒÉ in the mss. One of them is in six chapters on secret prƒÅy≈õcittas, gifts, pit≈ômedha and ƒÅcƒÅra ( vide I. O. Cat., p. 381, No. 1308). There is another work styled Atrisa·πÅhitƒÉ printed in Jivanau da’s collection (part I. pp. 13-46). It contains about 400 verses and deals with the following topics :- importance of honouring guru; duties of four castes; purifications of seveaal mnulus ; virtues of BrƒÅhmanas such as saucu, anusƒ´yƒÅ; defini tion of i≈üta and p≈´rta, ten yamas and niyamas; importance of sons; adopted sons; prƒÅya≈õcittas for taking forbidden food or drink and for other transgressions ; impurity on birth and death; cƒÉndrƒÅyana, K≈Çchra, SƒÅnta pana ; gifts ; purifications from avoidable contacts with rajasvalƒÅ &c. ; SrƒÅddha and the brƒÅbma≈Üas to be invited for it.

In this work Atri is himself cited as an authority. Other authors and works quoted are: Apastam ba ( p. 30), Yama (p. 41 ), VyƒÅsa ( p. 24 ), Sankha ( pp. 22, 35), S√§t√§tapa (p. 35). The VedƒÅnta, S√§rikhya, Yoga, Pura·ª•as, BhagavatƒÅ·∏• (p. 45 ) are mentioned. It contains (on p. 14) the verse ‘sadya·∏• patati mƒÅnsena’ which is found in Vasistha Dh. S. (2.27) with the words ‘athƒÅpyudƒÅbaranti’. There are other verses also which occur elsewhere e. g.‘atha cen-mantravid’ occurs in Vasistha 11. 20, ‘tryaham prƒÅtah’ (p.23 ) is ulso Manu XI. 211. On p. 26 occur the words ‘utrƒÅpyudƒÅharanti‚Äôand so what follows is a quotation. On p. 32 there are three verses in another metre.

Atri‚Äôs verse about adoption 31 is quoted as the first autho rity on adoption in the Dattakamim√§insa. He mentions the seven urtyajas to be the washerman, the shoemaker, natu, buruda, kaivarta (fisherman ), meda and bhilla (p. 29). He further says232 that there is no question of untouchability in fairs, marriage seasons, in Vedic sacrifices and in all festivals. He says that BrƒÅhma·πáas from Magadha, MathurƒÅ and three other places are not honoured ( at a ≈õrƒÉddha) though as lear ned as B·ªãhaspati.283 231 zgatal adem: gaasaiara: Ti frost. ETHITH Ra: 11

√Ä p. 17. ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§‡•§

p. 33. 233 ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§ß‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞ ‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§ü‡§É ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•å ‡•§ ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§® ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ

FOUNDED

11771

May

  1. Atopi

208

The work mentions the signs of the Zodiac, Kany√• and the Scorpiou (1"43 ), and hence was not composed before the first centuries of the Christian era.

In Jivananda there is a Laghu-Atri (part I, pp. 1-12 ) in 6 chapters and about 120 verses, dealing with the means of being freed from gins (such as prƒÅnƒ´yƒÅma, sucred formula, gifts &c. ), with purifications from impurity on death and birth, with gifts. It mentions Manu. In the fourth chapter there are about ten lines in proge. There are numerous verses that occur also in the Vasistha-dharmas√∫tra, e. g. Vas. 26. 8-9 and 16-18 occur on p. 3 ; Vas. 28. 11.16 occur on pp. 4-5. It is difficult to say who the borrower is.

There is a Vrddhatreyasmrti in Jivananda (part I. pp. 47-59 ) in five chapters and about 140 verses. This closely resembles the Laghu-Atri-smrti described above. In the commencement both have the same six verses beginning with

bhagavan kena dƒÅnena’ and the works have many verses in common. In the fourth chapter of both the same prose passa ges occur.

Visvar≈´pa on YƒÅj. (III. 257 ) quotes two verses from Atri on prƒÅya≈õcitta which are found in none of the three works described above. 234

In the Mahabharata (Anu≈°ƒÅsana 65. 1 ) Atri is credited with the view that those who make a gift of gold give (prac tically) all objects. This bears a close resemblance to two verses that occur in Laghvatri (Jivananda part I. p. 5) and V»õddhƒÅtri (part I. p. 51 ).235

  1. Usanas KƒÅvya U≈õanas is an ancient sage in the Rgveda ; vide √¶g. I. 83. 5, where Kavya U≈õanas is said to have been an helper of Indra and brought out the cows (carried away and concealed by the Panis). In Rg. VIII. 23. 17 that sage is said to have established Agni for Manu and in Rg IX. 87. 3 U≈°anas is called a ≈ôsi and vipra and one who knew the hidden place where cows were concealed.

That U≈°anas wrote a work on politics follows from seve ral circumstances. The Kau≈£iliya quotes the Au≈õanasƒÅƒºƒ± seven times. It is almost certainly referring to a work. That work contained directions on the administration of justice also, as Kautilya speaks of Au≈°anasa method of partition (in allowing a tenth additional share to the eldest son, III. 6 ), as Au≈õana sƒÉ·∏• prescribed fines in cases where witnesses proved stupid &c. (III. 11,44 ). The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata, Santiparva 236 (chap. 56,

In the Deccan College collection there are two mss. of an Au≈°anasa-dharma≈õƒÅstra in prose with a few verses, viz. No. 644 of Vi≈õrƒÅm bƒÅg (i) and No. 191 of A 1881-82. These verses have application in these times also. :238 ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ

‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•å ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∂‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö HETTO 69: Afect agata 11 It is further said that Skanda, Iodra, Pracetasa Manu, Brhaspati, Sukra, BihiradvƒÅja, Gaurafiras and Veda-Vy√°sa abridged respectively to 25000, 10000, 6000, 3000, 1000, 700, 500 and 300 adhy·∫£yas and that Janamejaya abridged over the

last. 239 ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á ‡••

Daraurch Inctit11

  1. U≈°anas

267

The work is a brief one ( 8 folios ) in seven adhyƒÅyas. Their contents are:- II. impurity on birth and death; purification of certain things in certain ways such as with water, ashies &c. III. the four varvas and the mixed castes such as RathakƒÅra, Ambastha, S≈´ta, Ugra, MƒÅgalha &c., the VrƒÅtyas ; IV. no bodily injury to be done to brahmana; prƒÅyascittas for killing a brƒÅhma·πáa or a man of the other varnas and for other MahƒÅ pƒÅtakas, prƒÅya≈õcitta for eating the flesh of certain animals and for eating plants like garlic, prƒÅya≈õcitta for adultery ; discussion whether a BrƒÅhmana could marry a ≈õ≈´dra woman; prƒÅya≈õcittas for killing various beasts and birds ; fourteen vidyƒÅs; V. ≈°r≈´ddhrakalpa; what BrƒÅhma·πáas are punkti pƒÅvuna; details of ≈õrƒÅddha; food and flesh at ≈õrƒÅddha; who are unfit to be invited at ≈õrƒÅddha; VI. what things a BrƒÅhma·πáa could not sell; VII. punishments for the Maha pƒÅtakas; what are pure things at all times. Some of the views of the Au≈õanasa-dharma≈õƒÅstra are worth special notice. The son of a BrƒÅhmana, Ksatriya or Vaisya from a wife, of the var·ª•a immediately next to it belonged to the caste of the father.340 No sin or punishment attached to ope if one killed an atatƒÅyi (armed) BrƒÅhmana. The fourteen vidyƒÅs are said to be the six ungas and the four Vedas, Mimi≈ÜsƒÅ, NyƒÅya, Dharma≈õƒÅstra and Purana.241

The work very often quotes the views of others with the words ‘eke’; for example it says ‘the impurity on birth is ten nights for the parents of the child, but according to sume only for the mother.’ 242 The son of a BrƒÅhmana from a s≈´dra woman is called pƒÅrasava, but according to some he is nisƒÅda. The whole of the portion in the ms. about the mixed castes bears a very close resemblance to BaudhƒÅyana (Dh. S. 1. 9)

240 Ema farat Fiat TEVU Ta : 1 chap. Ill folio 3 A. 241 ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§∑‡§°‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ

History of Dharmasastra

except in a few particulars.343 At the end of all chapters from the second (except the third ) there are verses and also in the midst. There are verses introduced with the words

there is a sloka on this point' ( bhavati cƒÉtra sloka·∏•) or with the words ‘api codƒ´haranti’.

There are about 45 verses in the work, the 7th and last chapter being almost entirely in verse. As the mss. are corrupt and full of gaps, it is often difficult to find out whether a particular passage is prose or verse. In several verses the words Manur abravid' occur and in one place ‘tan manor anusƒÅsanam : 214 The latter closely agrees with Manu. Several verses are common to Manu and Usanas. The verse ‘gurutalpe bhaga·∏• kƒÅrya·∏•’ (Manu 9. 237) occurs in the ms. So also the verse “yena yena cidangena’ occurs in both.245 The words of Manu (V.78 ) ‘bƒÅle de≈õƒÅntarasthe’ are expressly quoted with the words ‘Manur-ƒÅha’. There are many other verses which, though not cited expressly as from a particular author, are found in other ancient works. For example, the verse ‘ƒÅpa·∏• ≈õuddhƒÅ bh≈´miyat√§h’ is Manu 5. 128 and Baud. Db. $. I. 5, 57. The half versekƒÅruhasta·∏• sucir nityam' is Manu 5. 126 and Baud. Dh. S. 1. 5. 48. The verse ‘yadekarƒÅtrena karoti pƒÅpam’ occurs in Ap. Dh. S. ( I. 9. 27. 11 ) and Baud. Dh. S II. 1. 42. The verse ‘tryaham prƒÅtas tryaham naktam ‘is Manu XI. 211. It is a remarkable fact that some of the verses in this dharmas≈´tra agree closely with the verses in the U≈õanas–smrti in verse, published by Jivananda ; e. g. the verse ‘dattv√• tu VedƒÅnatyartham’occurs on p. 525 and the verse ‘nimantritustu yo vipro adhyƒÅnam samprapadyate’ on p. 527. close resemblance to the versified smrti on many points, e. g. the prose passages about the duration of the satisfaction of the Manes by the offerings of the flesh of various animals occur almost in the same words in the versified smrti of USanas (Jivananda, part I, p. 522 ).

The Au≈õanasa-dharmas≈´tra contains several passages in prose which are the same as some verses in Manu.246 The s≈´tra quotes in one place the divergent views of Vasistha,247 Harita, Saunaka, and Gautama on the question whether a brƒÅhmana could marry a ≈õ≈´dra woman. The view of Vasi≈ütha (as quoted in the ms.) is that a BrƒÅhma·πáa could take to wife girls of all the four castes, but in the printed text of Vasistha ( I. 24 ) a BrƒÅhmana is allowed to marry girls of three higher castes only. It is possible that the ancient reading of Vasistha’s text was ‘catasral’ (as quoted in the Au≈õ√•nasa ) which was changed into ‘tisrah’. The passage reminds us of Manu III. 16 (SudrƒÅvedi patatyatreh ), but the views ascribed to Suunaka and Gautama in the ms. differ from those ascribed to thein in Manu. In another passage Vasistha’s views seem to be quoted.48

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

dharma viz. ƒÅcƒÅra, vyavahƒÅra and prayascitta. For example, the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ quotes prose passages of U≈õanas on anadhyƒÅya (1, p. 59), on duntadhavana (1. p. 106 ) and Haradatta quotes a prose passage on anadhyƒÅya (on Ap. Dh. S. I. 3. 10. I) and a prose passage on the fine for a K≈üatriya abusing a s≈´dra (on Gau. Dh. S. 12. 10) and on Niyoga ) on Gau. Dh. S. 18. 5). These passages are not found in the ms. But there are others that are found. For example, the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ quotes two passages, which occur in the mss.249 It appears therefore that the mss. either contain a portion only of the complete Au≈õanasa-dharma-s≈´tra or an independent s≈´tra work. The former alternative looks more probable. The foregoing discussion has shown that the sutra work is later than the dharmas≈´tras of Gautaina and Vasistha and also than the Manusmrti, which it probably knew in a very ancient version slightly differing from the extant one.

In Jivananda’s collection of sm·ªôtis there is an Au≈°anasa dharma≈õƒÅstra in 51 verses (part I. pp. 497-501 ). It deals with mixed castes and their avocations, such as s≈´ta, mƒÅgadha: dƒÅp≈ÜƒÅla, $vapaca, pulinda-&c. The same work occurs in the AnandƒÅ≈õrama collection, pp. 46-48. The Mit. (on Yaj. 1. 94 ) remarks that the means of livelihood for the mixed custes should be sought for in the works of Usanas and Manu.280 It is probably this sm·ªôti that is meant. Kull≈´ka on Manu. X. 49 says that the sale of hides and working on hides were means of livelihood for Dhigva≈Üas according to the Au≈°anasa.

In the same collection (part I. pp. 501-544 ) there is another sm·ªôti ascribed to Usapas in 9 chapters and about 600 verses. It treats of Upanayana, daily observances like ƒÅcamuna, Vedic study, occasions of unadhyƒÅya, the dharmas of snƒÅtuka ; ≈õrƒÅddha, proper BrƒÅhma·πáas for brƒÅddha, impurity on birth and death, rites after death, prayascittas for the mortal sins and lesser sins.

249 The passages are ‘79 ATC AHISTAHOERTRI Gala’(chap. V.

about SrƒÅddha ) and safa ET TEATAR FETA SITT FRA ORIENTACT

FOUN

  1. U≈°anas

271

This smrti quotes Usanas himself, also Manu, Bhrgu (Bhrguputra III ), Prajapati and speaks of dharma≈õƒÅstras, Puranas, MimƒÅrsƒÅ, Vedanta, PƒÅ√±carƒÉtras, KƒÅpƒÅlikas and PƒÅ≈õupatas. Numerous verses from the Manusm·ªôti are found in it (e. g. Manu II. 42, 49, 50, 125 ) and occur in the first chapter alone. There is a brief prose passage towards the end of the 9th chapter. It speaks of KƒÅpƒÅlikas, PƒÅ≈õupatas and atheists together ( 1). 525 ).

None of these sm·ªôtis in verse contains the passages in verse on vyavahƒÅra ascribel to U≈°auas that occur in the MitƒÅk·π£arƒÅ, SmrticandrikƒÅ and other works.

The Mit. (on YƒÅj. III. 260 ) and AparƒÅrka (e. g. p. 158, 192, 255 ) contain prose passages ascribed to Usanas and the same works contain numerous verses ascribed to Usanas, most of which are not found in the two smrtis in Jivananda. Some of the verses in Apararka ascribed to U≈°anas are found in the Au≈°anasasmrti (e. g. Apar≈´rka p. 418 ‘kuryƒÅd-abara·∏• ≈õrƒÅd dham‚Äôis Jivananda I. p. 521 ).

In other cases the verses quoted from U≈°anas in AparƒÅ rka, though not quite identical, bear a very close resemblance (e. g. the four verses in AparƒÉrka on p. 450 closely resemble Jivananda I, p. 525 and have some verses in common ).

Among the views on VyavahƒÉra quoted from Ugapas are some interesting ones. It was he who said that a son was not bound to pay his father’s debt, if it was a fine or unpaid toll or what is not vyƒÅvahƒÅrika.261 He holds that even blind, deaf or old men, women, minors could be witnesses in charges of sƒÅkasa ( AparƒÅrka p. 671). He is quoted also on ordeals, on svƒÅmipƒÅla vivƒÅda and on steya.

U≈°anas is quoted in Kalpataru (Grhastha kƒÅ≈Üda ) 8 times, in SrƒÅddha 13 times (8 times in prose ), in VyavahƒÅra eleven times (all verses, except one proge passage on p. 814 on anuloma unions ), 6 times in NiyatakƒÅla.

It is interesting to note that he states that the son of a brƒÅbmana from a ksatriya wife is a br√•hmana and the son of

History of Dharmasastra

a ksatriya from a vaibya wife is a k≈üatriya (p. 814 on Vyava hƒÅra ). AparƒÅrka quotes U≈°anas dozens of times, about nine quotations being in prose ( most of them on prƒÅya≈õcitta ).

The MaskaribhƒÅsya on Gautama Dh. S. quotes prose pag sages from U≈°anas in many cases e. g. on I. 64, 66, II. 17 (long), 18, 48; V. 9, X. 27 ( about principles of taxation ), 31. 36, 52; XII. 6, 10, 36, 42; XIX. 14 (long prose followed by six verses ) and also some verses as on XII. 19 M√§so vimsati bhƒÅgastu j√±eyah KƒÅrsƒÅpa≈Üasya tu ! KƒÅkani tu caturbhƒÅgo mƒÅsasyaiva prakirtitahtiSm·ªôticandrikƒÅ quotes Usanas 45

times on ƒÅhnika, vyavahƒÅra and ≈õrƒÅddha; vide Mit. on YƒÅj. II. 159 quoting NƒÅrada.

A work styled SukranitisƒÅra was edited by Oppert (Madras 1882 ) and by Jivananda (Cal. 1892 ) and translated by Benoy Kumar Sarkar in S. B. H. Series. That work is a very interesting one, but is comparatively of a late date.

It is probable that at least some parts of Sukranitisira edited by Oppert in 1882 are not older than about 1800 A. D. (viz, such as IV. 5. II prescribing fees for lawyers ). Vide Mr. Lallanji Gopal’s paper in the Bulletin of the London School of Oriental and African Studies, Vol. 25 for 1962 pp. 524-556, in which it is strenously urged that it is a fabrica tion of the 19th century). I do not agree that the whole work is later than 1800 A. D. The SukranitisƒÅra provides on p. 157 ( of Oppert’s ed. ). Farafrani fa ferargra girsui ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ

tar fattet III

Such passages may be interpolations made in the first quarter of the 19th century. In the year 1793 the Governer General–in-Council enacted Regulation VII of 1793 in order to induce men of education and character to take up the practice of law as a distinct profession. That Regulation applied only to the provinces of Bengal, Bihar and Orissa. In 1802 Regu lation XIV of 1802 was enacted in Bombay which consisted of 33 sections providing among other matters for the appo intment of pleaders, for the issue of sanads to them, for remuneration payable to them and for penalties in cases of misconduct or negligence.

Vide S√¢ntiparva 57. 40-11 for a famous verse of BhƒÅrgak ( i. e. U≈°anas ); TTATA sterte pare not relf acht Tag I 77891 ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡••

SITO

11 FOUNDED

  1. Karva and K√§nva

273

  1. Kanya and K√§nva From the Ap. Dh. S. it appears that Kanva and KƒÅ·ª•va were two distinct writers on dharma. In I. 6. 19. 2 ƒÄpastamba starts the question as to the persons, food at whose house was permitted. He states various views on that point and says that Kanya was of opinion that food may be taken at anybody’s house provided the latter offered it with a request (I. 6. 19. 3) and that the opinion of Eka, Ku≈Üika, KƒÅnva, Kutsa and Puskaras√§ili (1. 6. 19. 7) was that only that food that was offered by a pure and religious man should be partaken. In another place ( L. 10. 28. 1) Apastamb√© gives it as the opinion of Kautsa, H√§rƒ´ta, Kajƒ±va and Puskara sƒÅdi that a man became a thief if in any case whatever he appropriates another’s belongings. The Kumbhakonam edition of Pandit Halasyanatha reads KƒÅ≈Üva for Kanva.

Kanva is quoted a few times in the Smyticandrika on Ahnika ( daily duties ) and ≈õrƒÅddha. One of these quotations is in prose ( I. p. 97 ).252 Haradatta in his commentary on Gautama cites verses of Kanva in several places (e. g. Guu tama Dh. S, 21. 3, 23. 3 and 11 ).253 The first verse bears & close resemblance to Manu XI. 180 and Baud. Dh. S. II. 1. 62. Kanva is quoted in the Acaramayukha and the SrƒÅddha may≈´kha.

The Mit. (on YƒÅj. III. 58 ) quotes a verse of K≈´≈Üva on the length of the stay of a saimyƒÅsin in a village or town. On YƒÅj. I11. 260 the Mit. quotes a verse of Kanva stating the prƒÅyascitta for a brƒÅlimana having intercourse with the k»ôatriya wise of his teacher.

In the Madras Govt. Oriental Library there is a mo. of Kanva (vol. V, p. 1929 No. 2624 ).

Maskarin on Gaut. Dh. S. frequently quotes passages from Kanva (in prose and verse); vide on I. 33 and 39 ( both prose), V. 21 (prose definition of VedapƒÅraga ), IX. 1 (prose), X. 53 (verse on five kinds of br√§ddhas, nitya, naimittika,

I. 11. 20) cites a verse which con tains the view of Ka≈õyapa that a woman who is bought can. not be a patnƒ´ and that she is not authorised to take part in religious ( daiva ) rites or rites for the Manes.254 This verse is ascribed to Katyayana in the Smrticandrika ( I. p. 87 ). The Vanaparva quotes gƒÅthcs of KƒÅ≈õyapa on forbearance ( 29. 35-40). Whether Ka≈õyapa and KƒÅ≈õyapa are two different writers of dharmas√∫tras it is rather difficult to say. Probably they are identical. It appears that the dharmas√∫tra of KƒÅ≈õyapa comprised all the usual topics of dharmas≈´tras, such as daily duties, sraddha, asauca, prayascitta. This sutra has been quoted by all eminent writers from Visvar≈´pa down wards. VisvarƒÅpa quotes Kasyapa (in prose ) on the priya scitta for contact with candila 8866 and for killing a cow when the sinner is a brƒÅhmana or a member of another caste. 288 The Mit. (on Yaj. In the Deccan College collection there are two mss. (No. 200 of 1884-87 and No. 122 of A. 1881-82) which contain a KƒÅ≈õyapa≈üm·ªôti in prose (4. folios having 8 lines on each side ). It deals with the duties of householders, with prƒÅya ≈öcittas for doing mischief to wells, dikes, ponds, temples and houses of Brahmanas, for killing a cow and other beasts and birds, with rules on mourning after death and impurity on birth, with prƒÅya≈õcittas for eating garlic and other similar things, with the five mortal sins, with priya≈õcittas when such portents as earthquakes, lightning flashes occur, or for such accidental occurrences as the breaking of the milk pot, with purification of vessels of wood and inetals, with the visible physical sins and sing committed in previous lives, with the seven punarbh≈´s.

In this work some of the s≈´tras quoted as KƒÅ≈üyapa’s in the cominenturies are found (e. q. the quotation No. 259 “lasuna’ &c. above ). So also the verses about punarbh√∫s of seven kinds quoted by Haradatta are found in the mss. In this sinti, Kii≈õyapa is frequently cited as an authority.

Maskarin on Gaut. 23. 19 quotes a verse of KƒÅ≈õyapa providing priya≈õcitta for homo-sexuality and masturbation.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Prof. T. R. Chintamani contributed a paper (in which he edited a Dharma–≈õƒÅstra based on four mss. ) to the J. O. R. (Madras) vol. XIII. pp. 267-282 with an appendix containing passages and verses attributed to KƒÅ≈õyapa (pp. 283-292 ) by Vi≈õvar≈´pa, Vij√±ƒÅne≈õvara, AparƒÅrka and others not found in those mss. AparƒÅrka mentions KƒÅ≈õyapa 13 times ( almost all verses except on p. 922 which is in prose) and Ka≈õyapa six times.

It is to be noted that K√§≈õyapa is not mentioned by Y√°j. as one of the dharma≈õƒÅstraprayojakas, though ParƒÅ≈õara (chap. I. 13) mentions KƒÅ≈õyapƒÉ dharmƒÅ·∏•. The Sm·ªôticandrikƒÉ (I. p. 1) and the SarasvativilƒÅsa (p. 13 ) speak of 18 Upasmrtis in which KƒÅ≈õyapa’s is included.

  1. GƒÅrgya Vi≈°var≈´pa (on Yaj. I. 4-5) quotes a verse of Vƒõddha Y√°j√±avalkya in which G√§rgya is enumerated among the expo unders of Dharma ( dharmavakt≈´ra·∏•). He quotes two s≈´tras, one from G√°rgya ( on YƒÅj. I. 72260 ) and the other from V»õddha GƒÅrgya361 (on Y√¢j. I. 195). Therefore it seems that a sutra work of G√°rgya on dharma did exist. The Mit. (e. g. on YƒÅj. III. 326 ), AparƒÅrka and the Sin»ôticandrika quote several verses of GƒÅrgya on √µhnika, ≈õr√§ddha and pr√°yascitta. ParƒÅ sara (I. 13) mentious G√°rgya among writers on dharma. Apa rƒÅrka contains (pp. 124, 190, 368, 544 ) verses from G√°rgya on topics of dharina. It seeins that the two writers are identical. AparƒÅrka also quotes several verses from GƒÅrgya of astrono mical import (e. g. p. 5:17 on the nomenclature of the months as Caitiu in connection with the signs of the zodiac). This was probably an independent work. Fragments of a G√§rgi samhiti on astronomy and astrology have been recovered and it contains valuable historical information ( vide Kern’s pre face. to Brhat-samhitƒÉ pp. 33-40 and Mr. Jayasval in JBORS. vol. 14, p. 397 (F). A Jyotir-G√§rgya and a Brhad-GƒÅrgya are quoted in the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ. The NityƒÅcƒÅrapradipa (p. 20, B.I.S.) mentions Garga and GƒÅrgya separately as sm»ôtikƒÅras.

280 gfaar: fra FUIFFT Wararaarent al zer ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡•§ .

FOUNDE

1917

  1. Cyavana

277

The Anu≈õnsanaparva ( 18.38 ) states that Garga acquired on the banks of the Sarasvati astronomy with its 64 angas. In the same parure it is said that vrddha-GƒÅrgya inquired about vrgotsarga ( 125. 77 ff). Salya parva ( 37. 14-15 ) narra tes that oli Garya by his tapis acquired on the sacred Sara svatƒ´ knowledge of KƒÅla, movements of the planets, of evil and good ut pƒÅtas and that the place is therefore called Gargasrotas. This astronomer Garva is probably different from the Dharma s√§stra writer Garga. Vide H. of Dh. Vol. V. pp. 591-92, 741 42, 765 for Garga, the astronomer. Visvar≈´pa on YƒÅj: 1. 25 quotes a verse of G√§rgya on the proper times for morning SundhyƒÅ and evening Sandhya and a prose passage of Vrddha G√§rgya on Yij. I. 195 (p. 136 ).

  1. Cyavana Cyavana is a famous name in the Rgveda. The Asvins are often praised as having endowed the old and aging Cya vana with youth (vide Rg. 1. 117. 13, 1. 118. 6, VII. 71. 5, X. 39. 4). The Mahabharata spins certain stories on Cyavana in Adiparva, chap. 6 and 8, Vanaparva chap. 122-124, ƒÄ√Ωva medhika 10. 32. He married Sukanya, daughter of king SaryƒÅti, and the Asvins made him young and handsome. He theu helpeil the Asvips to get a share in Soma offerings after paralysing the arm of Indra who at first opposed this.

The Mit., AparƒÉrka and other works cite several s≈´tres and some verses from Cyavana. AparƒÉrka quotes a very long prose passage from Cyavana (on Yaj. Aparirka on YƒÅj. I. 207, with reference to the great rewards of the gift of a cow when she is about to deliver, sete out on pp. 299-30% from Cyarana.a long prose passage with ten

  1. Jatukarnya

  1. Devala The name Devala as that of a sage frequently occurs in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and is closely connected with Asita. Vide Sabh√§parva 59. 9-11, Salya 50 and S√§ntiparva 230. In SubhƒÅ ( 72. 5) it is stated that Devala declared that a man has three lights viz. son, actions and correct knowledge. It may be stated here that early extant commentators like Visvar≈´pa and MedhƒÉtithi do not quote prose passages from the Devala Dharmas≈´tra relating to S√§nkhya and Yoga. History of Dharmasastra

n√•rinƒÉm d√°sƒÅnƒÅm svƒÉmini sthite i tadvan-niyatam–asvimyam sarv√¢rthes vabravin Manuh’. Compare Adiparva 83.21, Udyo gaparva 33.64 and Manu VIII. 416.

The Sm. C.quotes Devala 86 times on Ahnika, 71 times on SrƒÅddha, 26 times on VyavahƒÅra. On p. 22 of Kalpataru on SrƒÅddha occurs the verse ¬∑ M√°nava! Sr√°idhakalpoyam ManunƒÅ samudƒÅh·∫°ta·∏•’. On pp. 272-273 of the Brahmac√°ri-kƒÅnda there is a long prose passage on ‘brahmac√°ridharma’, while on pp. 208-210 of SrƒÅddha-kƒÅnda twenty-two verses are quoted from Devala on pindavidhƒÅna’. On pp. 811-12 of VyavahƒÅra-kƒÅnda there is a prose passage on four anulomas and 6 prutilomas and four verses explaining them and stating that the son of a brƒÅbmana from a ksatriya wife and the son of a ksatriya from a vaisya wife are assimilataid to the father ; on p. 7 of MoksakƒÅnda there is a blending of the SƒÅrkhya with advaita doctrines; on p. 100-101 of the same kanda the Sankhya doctrine of M≈´lapraksti’, seven prak≈ôtivik≈ütis, 16 vikƒÅras is set out at length,

In the Mit., in Haradatta, AparƒÉrka and the Sm·ªôtican drikƒÅ there are numerous quotations in verse from Devala on ƒÅcƒÅra, vyavahƒÅra, ≈õr√§ddha, prƒÅya≈õcitta and other topics. That seems to have been an independent work. In the Anan dƒÅ≈õrama collection of sm·ªôtis there is a Devalasm·ªôti in 90 verses dealing with purification and praya≈õcittas for contact with Mlecchas. This appears to be a late compilation. Some of the verses contained therein are ascribed to other authors, e. g. verses 17-22 are ascribed to Apastamba by AparƒÉrk& (on YƒÅj. III. p. 1200) and verses 30-31 are ascribed by the Mit. (on YƒÅj. III. 290 ) and Apar√°rka to Visuu.

It is to be noted that verses 82-90 at the end of this Devalasm·ªôti are the same as YƒÅj. III. 315-324 (with slight variations ). Devala himself is named in verses 25 and 72 and VyƒÅsa in verse 68.

The Dharmas≈´tra of Devala, to judge from the quotations in the K≈ôtyakalpataru, AparƒÅrka, Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ and other early digests, appears to have been an extensive one and to have dealt with most of the topics that are discussed in the Dharmasutras of Gautama, Ajiastamba, Baudhiyana, Harita and others and also some matters in detail such 48 S√•rby and Yoga. The above works contain large prose extracts from

1:

:$$. Devala

it on topics of Dharma≈õƒÅstra. A few examples may be cited here. In the Brahmac√°ri-kƒÅnda of the Kalpataru on pp. 30 and 100 there are prose passages on the VedƒÅngas and itihƒÅsa and on pp. 272-73 a long prose passage on the duties and other observances of a brahmacƒÅrin; in the Sraddlia-k√§nda there is a very long prose passage ( covering one page ) on the persons to be avoided in SrƒÅddha ( pp. 78‚Äì79), but most of the other quotations are in verse; in the Gphastha-kƒÅnda (p. 119) occurs a long prose passage on the seven pƒÅkayajias, seven haviry jails and seven somu-yujnus; on pp. 254-255 a long prose passage on KsƒÉtradharma and on pp. 304, 309, 312 prose passage on hindƒÅ, anrta ( falsehood ) and steya (theft ) respectively. In the NiyatakƒÅla section (p. 142 ), the setting up of sacred sm√§rta fire after marriage is provided in & prose passage; in the VyavahƒÅrakƒÅnda (pp. 811-812 ) there is a prose passage naming four kinds of anuloma castes, six pratiloma castes and 6 anturƒÅlis castes and on p. 834 of the same k√§nda are set out in prose the duties binding on all men including c√¢udalas. It is clear that the Devala Dharmasutra was not all in prose; it contained numerous verses also; for example, on pp. 387-393 of the Grhastha-kƒÅnda in a prose passage referring to sinful taints of three kinds (viz, mental, vocal and bodily ) several verses are quoted describing separately the dosas of these three kinds. Therefore, the Devala Dharmas√∫tra contained verses also. But the present author is not prepared to hold that the several hundred verses ascribed to or quoted from Devala in several works (e.g. Apa r√§rka quotes about 120 verses from Devala ) and in other digests are part of the Devala Dharmas≈´tra ; many of them are very probably taken from a Devalasm·ªôti in verse. Hardly any other Dharmas√∫tra deals with Yoga and its technical terms ike prƒÅnƒÅyƒÅma, pratyah√°ra, dharan√° at such length as Devala does (vide H. of Dh. Vol. V. pp. 1380-81, notes 2263-64 ) for Sankhya technique, p. 1409 n. 2314 on definition of Yoga, p. 1435 note 2356 ( on prƒÅna and apƒÅna ), p. 1439 note 2363 on prƒÅƒ∑ƒÅyƒÅrna, p 1445 n. 2375 on pratyƒÅhƒÅra ), p. 1447 n. 2380 (on DharanƒÉ ), 1453 (n. 2390 on Siddhis), p. 1458 n. 2398 (on ahark√§ru and mamatva ). It may be noted that prose quotes, tions from Devala are only a few (namely those un YƒÅj. HA 26, III. 58 and 256 ), while about two dozen verses of Devat arg. quoted on several other verses of Yij.

POON

1917

384

History of Dharmasastra

. It would be a great service if some scholar put togeo ther in one volume all the passages of Devala occurring in Kalpataru, AparƒÅrka, and other early nibandhas with notes aboutparallel passages &c.

The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata ascribes the view to Devala tbat in man there are three jyoti8, viz. offspring, karma, and learning. 270

AparƒÅrka and the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ cite verses from Devala on partition, inheritance, on woman’s power over stridhana. These show that Devala, the jurist, flourished about the same time as the great jurists B»ôhaspati and K√§tyƒÅyana.

  1. Paithinasi Though not enumerated in YƒÅjsavalkya, Paithinasi seems to have been a comparatively ancient s≈´trakƒÅra on Dharma. On YƒÅj. III. 262 Vi≈õvar≈´pa quotes a sutra of Paithinasi on the prƒÅya≈õcitta for kiling a cow. Dr. Jolly (R. und $. p. 12 ) following Dr. Caland (“Ahnencult &c.' pp. 99, 109) thinks that Paithinasi belenys to the Atharvaveda as the prose quotations on frƒÉddha agree with the ritual of the Atharvans. The Mit. (on YƒÅj. I. 53 ) quotes a sutra of Paithinasi to the effect that di person should marry a girl who is beyond the third degree on the mother’s side and beyond the fifth on the father’s side. 271 On YƒÅj. III. 17 the Mit. quotes two s≈´tras relating to impurity on death.272 The Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ, A par√°rka, Hara datta and other writers quote numerous s≈´tras of Paithinasi. The Smyticandrika has a prose quotation on the duties of women.273 In another place the Sm·ªôticandrik√° (II. p. 263 ) cites a s≈´tra on partition.274 Apar≈´rka (p. 112 ) quotes two verses of Paithinasi recommending the practice of sati to women of all castes except Br√ºhmana women. Apar√§rka (p. 239 ) quotes a s≈´tra saying that the food of astrologers;

  1. Paithinasi

bell-makers and grƒÅmak≈´tas is poison.978 AparƒÉrka quotes (on p. 744 ) a s≈´tra of Sankha-Likhita and Paithinasi about inheritance to a deceased sonless man.376 A parƒÅrka quotes another important prose passage277 “the wealth of (a heirless) grotriya goes to the parisad and not to the king, the king should not appropriate the wealth of temples and guilds, depo sits and the wealth of minors and women”. Then the sutra quotes a verse on the same topic, which seems to refer to Manu 9. 194 in the word of sixfold origin' (gadƒÅgama ). Another s≈´tra quoted by AparƒÅrka (p. 754 ) says ‘when an appointed daughter dies, her husband does not take her wealth; if she be issueless, her mother or mother-in-law should receive it’. AparƒÅrka quotes a verse of Paithinasi (p. 921 ) at the time of marriage, famines, sacrifices, fairs and pilgrimages there is no impurity due to birth or death'.

Fragments of Paithinusi Dharmas≈´tra were edited by Prof. T. R. Chintamani ( 1939 ) and published in Annals of Oriental Research ( University of Madrus ). The Mit. on YƒÅj. I. 53 quotes a prose passage of P. limiting sapi≈Üda relationship to five degrees on the father’s side and to three on the mother’s side. Ou YƒÅj. I. 254 the Mit. quotes a verse about the sa pi≈Üƒ∑ƒ´. karala of a childless woman by her husband along with her mother-in-law. Mit. quotes prose passages as well as verses from Paithinasi. .

observed by a son being far away are ten from the day be hears of the death of his parents. P. in VyavahƒÅra-kalpataru p. 627 provides ‘womenima are the presiding deities of the house, no rules of saucil (purification) or vrata or fasting are obliga tory for them; they reach the highest worlds by merely look ing after their husbands’. This is not to be understood literally but what it conveys is the great worth of pati susrisa.'; compare Manu V. 155 and Yaj. I. 87. Kalpa¬∞ on Vyava¬∞ p. 742 quotes a verse as occurring in both Sankha likhita and Paithinasi. Visvarupa ( on Yaj. III. 262 p. 147) provides (in prose) a prƒÅya≈õcitta for √† goghna ( one who causes a cow’s death ). Paithioasi appears to have held the same view that is ascribed to Aupajanghani in Baud. Dh. S. II. 2. 39-41 (these verses being also quoted by Ap. Dh. II, 6. 13. 6 and also in Vas. 17. 9 without name in both ). Vide H. of Dh. Vol. II. p. 602 on 1417.   1. Brhaspati

.

earliest writers and works to mention him. In the Deccani College Collection there are two mss. of a Budha-dharma Sastra in prose ( No. 507 of 1881-82 and No. 145 of 1895-1902, 2 folios ). The work is very brief 279 and speaks of upa mayana. marriage, eight forms of marriage, the samskƒÅras from garbhadhƒÅna to ujana yana, the five daily great yaj√±as, Sraddha, pikayajinas, haviryajnas, somayaga, the means of subsistence for a BrƒÅhmana, the duties of Vai≈õyas and S≈´dras, the orders of forest hermits and sunnyƒÅxins, removal of thorns by the king, administration of justice, king’s duties.

The work does not produce the impression of being early. It is in the nature of a summary of larger works on dharma. All quotatious in Hem≈´dri cited from Budha are not found in the mss.

  1. Brhaspati

That Bphaspati was an ancient teacher of Artha≈õƒÅstra follows from the Kau≈£iliya, wherein the BƒÅrhasratyas are cited six times. In the Mahabharata (Sinti. chap. 59. 80-85) Brhaspati is said to have compressed into 3000 chapters the work on dharma, artha and kƒÅma composed by Brahma. The Vanaparva ( 32. 61) speaks of Brhaspati-niti. The Maha bhƒÅrata several times cites verses (yrithas or slokas ) said to have been sung by Brhaspatia80 ( vide Sinti. 23. 15, 56. 38-39,

‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§®‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•á ‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ñ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ï‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡•Ç‡§™‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç &c. ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø ( ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤, p. 309) quotes this as

Budha’s from ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ. 280 ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•å ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≤‡§∂‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ

‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. 23. 15. This verse ( with the reading ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•å ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã &0.) in ascribed by ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ 5. 3 to Usanas ; vide note 236. abore : ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡•§… ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç, ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ö‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ó‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø 56. 38-39 ; ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§É ‡§≤‡•ã: ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§® ‡§µ‡•É‡§π‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡•• ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§•‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¨‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‚Ä¢ 67.6-7.

  1. 6-7). Vide also santi. 58. 13-16, 69. 23-24. The Anu sƒÅsana ( 39. 10-11) speaks of the Artha≈õƒÅstra composed by Brbaspati and others. In some of these places there are dist inct references to a ≈õƒÅstra or mata of B»ôhaspati and sections of his work are referred to (as e. g. rƒÅjƒÅdhikƒÅra ). The SƒÅnti parva (170. 12) describes how a king could, according to Bphaspati’s views, secure his goal in four ways.281 In the Vanaparva ( 150. 29 ) men are said to be upheld by the nayas proclaimed by B»ôhaspati and Usanas. Vide also SabhƒÅ 50. 9, 55. 6, 73. 7-8, Udyogu 33. 71-72, 55. 66. The Kamasutra repeats the tradition that Brahm√£ composed a work in one bundred thousand chapters on dharma, artha and kama and that Bphaspati dealt with a portion of that work, viz. on artha.383 Vide note 238 above. A≈°vaghofa (Buddhacarita I. 46 ) speaks of the rƒÅja≈õƒÅstra of Sukra and B·ªähaspati. Accor ding to the Artha≈õƒÅstra of Kautilya some of the special views of B»ôhaspati’s school were that there were only two vidyƒÅs for kings viz. vƒÅrtƒÉ and dandaniti and that the council of ministers should comprise 16 members. According to K√•man. daka and the Pancatantra ( II. 41 ).avi≈õvƒÅsa ' was the sheet anchor of royal policy according to B»ôhaspati. The Yasasti laka ( p. 13 ) says that the niti of Bphaspati had no place for Gods.283 The commentary on the NitivƒÅky√§mrta gives the first verse of B·ªähaspati.384 Visvar≈´pa contains several prose quotations (which from their context must have been taken from Brhaspati ) about the qualifications of a sen√°pati, prati hƒÅra, duta &c. It is somewhat strange that in this quotation the mantrin is required to be deeply conversaut with the b√§stras of Manu, B»ôhaspati and Ufanas. For similar prose quotations, vide Visvar≈´pa on YƒÅj. I. 323, II. 154. That B»ôhaspati also wrote a s≈´tra work on VyavahƒÅra and other topics of dharma follows from the quotations contained in

  1. Brhaspath

289

Visvarupa and Haradatta. For example, Visvarupa cites a prose passage from Brhaspati (on Yaj. II. 38 ) about the duty. of the king to restore property stolen from his subjects if he could not recover it from the thief, about the rising scale of the rates of interest according to the castes; about the debts of a deceased man being payable by those who took his wealth, by his wife or by his son ; about a surety being made to pay when the principal died; about the illegitimate son of a s≈´dra getting a share on his father’s death and about his taking the whole estate with the king’s permission if there were no legitimate issue of the s≈´dra.285 Haradatta on Gau tama. 22. 18 quotes a prose passage from Brhaspati on the prƒÅya≈õcitta for killing a cow. These quotations establish that Bphaspati wrote a s≈´tra work on dharma also (i. e, at least on vyavahira and prayascitta). Visvarupa also quotes a few verses from Brhaspati on vyavahƒÅra and prƒÅya≈õcitta and in one place at least indicates that the verse he attributes to B»ôhaspati occurred in the same work in which a prose passage quoted by him occurred. 288 From this it follows that the s≈´tra work of Rphagpati on dharma contained verses also in VisvarƒÅpa’s time. Whether the two works on arthasƒÅstra and dharma were composed by the same Brhaspati cannot be determined. It looks probable that they were composed by different authors. Yaj. (I. 4-5) mentions Brhaspati among the expounders of dharma. He is probably referring to the s≈´tra work an dharma disclosed by quotations from Visvarupa. 285 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‘‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡•§

‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§∞‡§¶‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡••’ ; ‡§§‡§•‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‘‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞ &0. ( two verses)’ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‘‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ó‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∑‡§°‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ó‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•á ‡§µ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ … ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The words ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ó‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§É are attributed sty ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø by ‡§π‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ also.

990

History of Dharmasastra

In the Mit. and other commentaries and nibandhas over seven hundred verses on vyavahƒÅra and a few hundred more on ƒÅcƒÅra und prayascitta are cited from B·ªôlaspati. That seems to have been an independent work composed between 300 and 500 A. D., which will be discussed later on (vide sec. 37).

In Jivananda’s collection (part I. pp. 644-651 ) and in the AnandƒÅ≈õrama collection there is a B»ôhaspatism·ªôti in 80 verses in which Brhagpati is represented as instructing Indra about gifts. Several mss. in the Deccan College Collection contain this smrti, but in an abridged form in 70 and 49 verses (No. 130 of 1884-86 and No. 147 of 1895-1902). Vide also I. O. cat. p. 386 No. 1324, 1325-1328. Apararka quotes (p. 1225 ) verse 7 of this smrti (in verse ) and the D√§naratna kara quotes verses 6 and 7 as from Dana-Brhaspati.

The Barhaspatya Artha≈õƒÅstra edited by Dr. F. W. Thomas (Lahore, 1921 ) is a later work and does not deserve more than a passing notice. In six chapters it deals with the con duct, duties, studies of kings, omens, rules of policy &c.

27 BharadvƒÅja and BhƒÅradvaja Dr. S. C. Banerjee in his work ( Dharmasƒ´tras, a study in their origin and development) published in 1962 at Calcutta quotes only three prose passage of Bharadv√°ja. Although he publishes his work thirty years after the first vol. of the H. of Dh. he does not mention two prose passages which had been cited on pp. 126, 127, of that volume.

There is a Srauta s≈´tra and a Grhya s≈´tra attributed to BhƒÅradvƒÅja. The Ms. of the sranta in Bombay University Library contains nine pra≈õnas and a portion of the 10th and begins’ dar≈õapaur≈ÜamƒÅsau vyakhyƒÅxyƒÅmah.' It quotes Ale khana and ƒÄ≈õmarathya frequently. The Gyhya has been edited by J. W. Salomons. It appears from quotations iu Vi≈°var≈´pa and other early commentators that a s≈´tra work on dharma attributed to BharadvƒÅja or BharadvƒÅja was in existence. The forms Bharadv√°ja and Bh√§radvƒÅja probably refer to the same work. On Yaj. ( 1. 15 ) Visvar≈´pa quotes a prose passage from BhƒÅradvƒÅja prohibiting the learning of mlecchu tongues and calling upon the preceptor to teach his pupil pure words

su110

  1. BharadvƒÅja and Bharadvaja

291

observance of SandhyƒÅ and the kindling of fire ;38? on YƒÅj. 1. 32 BharadvƒÅja is quoted as prescribing a penance for even thinking of causing harm to beings ; 388 on YƒÅj. I. 185 a lengthy sutra of Bharadvaja on the purification of certain things is quoted, wherein is cited the view of soine that boys are purified by a mere bath when touched by antyajas ; 289 on Yaj I. 236 & prose passage of BharadvƒÅja forbids in ≈õrƒÉddhas the use of certain cereals as food. 200 AparƒÉrka quotes a long prose passage (p. 1155 ) from Bharadv√§ja in connection with the prƒÅya≈õcitta for cessiou of gƒºhya fires for various periods. .

‘In the Sm·ªôticandrika, in Haradatta and in several other works verses of Bh√§radvƒÅja are quoted, which appear to be taken from a smrti in verse.

That BhƒÉradv√°ja was an ancient writer op artha≈õƒÅstre follows from the Kautiliya, where in the views of BbƒÅradvƒÅja are cited seven times and of Kanika BharadvƒÅja once. Some of the views of Bh√•ra iv√§ja as described in the Kau≈£iliya are that a kinj should choose his ministers from amongst bis fellow-students, that the king should consider his line of policy alone in secret, that the princes should be punished secretly when they manifest po love for the king their father, that the minister should set one priuce against another when the kinu is on his dentli-bed, that when calamities befall the king and the minister, the former is the lesser of two evils, that one should bow down before the strong. This last view occurs in the Mahabhirata in the same words.201 The Santi parva (chap. 140 ) contains a dialogue between BhƒÅradvƒÅja and king Sutrunjaya of Sauvira in which danda is said to be the most pre-emieut among the expedients. The same parva ( chap. 58. 3) mentions Bharadviju in a list of writers on

‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§É- ‘‡§® ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§ï‡§ü‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ó ‡§°‡•á‡§™‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§∂‡§ø‡§™‡•Å. ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§≤‡§ï‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§´‡§≤‡§ï‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•ã‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•É‡§£ ‡§™‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡•á’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§

‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§¢‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§® ‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç-‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡•§‡•§ 201 TTEC sayo ( 12.1) FERT PE Goara walah malala

FOI192

History of Dharmasastra

rƒÅja≈õƒÅstra. The Ya≈õastilaka299 ( 4th ƒÄ≈õvƒÅsa p. 100, Nir≈Üaya. sƒÅgara ed. ) quotes two verses of BhƒÅradv√§ja from his treatise on the topic of the six guras. This shows that BhƒÅradvƒÅja’s work on politics was available in the 10th century and contai ned verses ( probably intermixed with prose).

BharadvƒÅja ( BƒÅrhaspatya ) is the sage of the whole of the sixth Mandala of the Rgveda. The form BharadvƒÅja occurs (in the singular ) in several verses (e. g. Rg. VI. 16. 5 and 33, VI. 31. 4) and in the plural also (in Rg. VI. 25. 9 and VI. 50. 15). The form Bharadvaja occurs in Rg. VI. 51. 12 and in VII. 2. 63. PƒÅ·πáini mentions BhƒÅradvƒÅja as a predecessor. The MahƒÅbhƒÅsya notes at least in nine cases that the Bh√§rad vƒÅjƒ´yas read the VƒÅrtikas differently (e. y. VƒÅrtika 9 on Pay. I. 1. 56, VƒÅrtika 3 on I. 2. 22, V√°rtika 4 on IV. 1. 79). Tbat is, the BhƒÅradvƒÅjiyas were a school of grammarians. BhƒÅradvƒÅja is said to be the eldest son of Brhaspati in Anu≈°ƒÅsana parva 30. 24 ff.. In Santiparvasan chap. 140 there are two verses that state: the king should have the rod of punishment ready (or raised up), that he should always exhibit his prowess, he should have no weak points, but should find out the weak points (of others) and should pursue the holes ( weaknesses) of others; that people are afraid of him whose Rod is raised √§nd that out of the four upƒÅyur Danda is the supreme one. These occur in BharadvƒÅja’s dialogue in Santi 140. Mapu (VII. 102-103 ) has almost the same verses. Kautilya differs

  1. Bharadvaja and Bharadvaja

from these views. He states ‚ÄúThe ƒÅcƒÅryas say “a king desiring the orderly maintenance of people’s life should always have the Rod of punishment lifted up (for striking when necessary ); for, there is no such means for keeping beings under one’s control as Danda'; ‘No’ says Kautilya ; for, the king that wields the Rod of punishment with severity becomes an object of disgust to beings; a king who is mild in punishing is treated with contempt, while a king that metes out the proper punishment is honoured; for the Rod of punishment used after proper consideration endows the people with Dharma, Artha and KƒÅma‚Äù.

It appears to the present author that Kautilya instead of separately mentioning BharadvƒÅja reported in the Santiparva and Manu, probably lumps the three (viz. BharadvƒÅja, Vy√§sa who quoted BharadvƒÅja’s views and Manu) and refers to the three as ‘ƒÅcƒÅryƒÅ·∏•’ here. It is remarkable that Kautilya no where expressly mentions VyƒÅsa’s name or the name MahƒÅ. bhƒÅrata either for supporting his own views or for differing from him or it. In I. 3. 1-2 the Kautiliya first mention’s S√°maveda, Rgveda, Yajurveda as Trays, then adds Atharva veda and Itihagaveda and thus makes the Vedas to be five. In the Chandogyopanigad (VII. 1.2, VII, 1. 4, VII. 7. 1) ItibƒÅsa-PurƒÅna is said to be the 5th Veda and it seems that the Kau≈£iliya follows it. So the ItihƒÅsaveda was entitled to great res ect as Veda. It is probable, therefore, that he does not expressly state anywhere that he differs from the Mah√§bharata or from VyƒÅsa. In the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata itself ‘AkhyƒÅna’ is frequently mentioned as the 5th Veda, as in Vanaparva 58. 9, Udyoga 43. 41-42, Karnaparva 87. 42, Salya 6. 14. The Arthas√∫stra 1. 5 14 ( Purauam-itivrttam-ƒÅkhya yikƒÅ-udƒÅbaranam-dharma≈õƒÅstram-artha≈õƒÅstram cetibƒÅsa·∏•) produces a jarring note, including, as it does, even Dharma b√§stra and Arthasastra under Itih√§ga. This does not stand to reason and tradition and is probably an interpolation or a marginal note, which later came to be embodied in the original work.

The Par√¢sara-Madhaviya (vol III, p. 231 ) quotes a verse of Bharudvaja which divides a pledge into four varie eties. A few quotations from BharadvƒÅja ou matters of vyavahƒÅra are cited in other works. For example, the Hra svati-vil√°sa cites a verse of BharadvƒÅja that a compromise the exchange and a partition, if fair and squel, could be annulled
