S√•t√•tapa on III. 243, 254, 263-64. In the Mit., the Smirtis candrikƒÅ and other works numerous verses of SƒÅtƒÅtapa are quoted on ƒÅcƒÅra and ≈õrƒÅddha. This work of SƒÅtƒÅtapa in verse is most probably a different one from the s≈´tra work. It appears that there are several smitis ascribed to S√£tƒÅtapa. In Jivananda’s collection there is a smrti of SƒÅtƒÅtapa called Karmavip√§ka in six chapters and about 231 verses. Its contents are: certain diseases are concomitants of certain sins; gifts of land, cows &c.; eulogy of BrƒÅhmanas; penances for killing a brahmana, a cow &c., penances for drinking wine, for incest and forbidden sexual intercourse of various sorts, for thefts; rites for those who meet with violent and accidental death. The last verse declares that the Smrti was promulgated by SƒÅtƒÅtapa to his pupil Sarabharga. It is a late production. It prescribes the reading of the Harivassa ( II. 30 ) as a penance for infanticide. Vide below under MadanapƒÅla.

No. 1362 of the I. O. catalogue (and cat. of Madras Govt. msg. vol. V. pp. 1994. 96 ) is a S√£t√£tapa–empti in twelve chap ters dealing with prƒÅya≈õcittas for mahƒÅpƒÅtakas, prƒÅya≈õcittas for injuries to various beings, marriage, vaisvadeva, sr√•ddha, pitstarpana, rules about taking one’s dinner, prƒÅya≈õcitta for dogbites and similar mitters; impurity on hirth and death, rules of conduct ( ƒÄcƒÅra ).

No. 1361 of the I. O. catalogue is a treatise in mixed pross and verse on prƒÅya≈õcittas for the MahƒÅpƒÅtakas and Upapa takas. Several verses of Manu ( such as III, 8, 11, 171 ) occur therein. It contains 139 verses. In Mitra’s Notices ( II. p. 41) there is a ms. called KarmavipƒÅka in 87 chapters and 2376 verses, of which the work in Jivananda’s collection seems to be a part or abridgment.

AparƒÅrka in several places quotes the views of S√§tƒÅtapa immediately followed by quotations from V√≠ddha-SƒÅtƒÅtapa or vice versa (e. g. on YƒÅj. I. 190, on III. 292 p. 1195 and p. 1201 ).

No. 205 of A. 1882-83 of the Deccan College Collection is a Vrdilha-SiitƒÅtepa smrti in 64 verses on prƒÅya≈õcittas for doing various things, on ≈õrƒÅddha, on washing the teeth. Her Cat. atatƒÅyin, except cows and brƒÅhma·πáas ‘. 398 A parƒÅrka quotes s≈´tras from Sumantu condemping marriage with maternal uncle’s or paternal aunt’s daughter and recommending the abandonment of a young wife in certain circumstances.200 In the Sarasvativil√°sa a prose passage of Sumantu is cited on the seven constituents of rƒÅjya 300

Paithinasi includes Sumantu among the thirty-six sages, expounders of Dharma≈õƒÅstra. Kalpataru (Br. K. p. 22) enumerates the means of settling (doubts on) points of Dharma viz. Veda, VedƒÅnga, ItibƒÅsa-purƒÅna, Tarka, Mima·πÅsƒÅ and Dharma-istras and also the practices of families, gana, country, caste and varna, and also the usages of heretical sects, of the ƒÅ≈õramas and of those learned in the Vedas. On p. 76 of the Br. k√§nda Sumantu provides that all BrƒÅlmanas, Ksatriyas and Vaisyas have to undergo the surixkƒÅrƒ±ls from GarbhƒÅdhana to Viv√•ha and Yaj√±as. The VratakƒÅnda ( Kal pao) quotes froin Sunautu numerous verses on K»ôirapratipad Vrata (pp. 36-38 ) and on A≈õ√ºnyasayana-vrata (pp. 41-44). It is possible that some of the verses ascribed to Sumantu in these cases are the compositions of some Sumantu other than the author of the prose sutras. e. y. the verse ‘a householder that does not offer sraddha, when the sun is in Virgo, how can he have wealth and sons’ &c. (q. by AparƒÉrka on YƒÅj. L. 217 p. 424). Kalpataru (on sraddha) pp. 90-91 quotes a long prose passage from Sumantu on persons that are (pƒÅrktcya (not fit to dine in the same row with others invited at SrƒÅd dha ). AparƒÅrka quotes numerous prose passages of Suma ntu on prƒÅyascitta. A much discussed dictum of Sumantu

(q. by Mit. on Yƒ´j. II. 21 and by AparƒÅrka on p. 1043 on Y√°j. III. 227 ) is there is no blame ( or sin ) in killing an atrƒ±tayin, except in the case of a cow or a brƒÅhmana that is ƒÅta tƒÅyin ). For a discussion of this dictum vide H. of Dh. Vol. II. pp. 148 151 and III. pp. 517-18, and the paper “ƒÄtatƒÅyivadha’ by Prof. Rangasvami Aiyangar in C. K. Raja presentation vol. pp. 197-232. The Mit. quotes several prose passages of Suma ntu on YƒÅj. II. 21, III. 6, 37, 250, 258, 260.

These quotations from Visvar≈´pa and others establish that a prose work on dharma by Sumantu existed early enough. It appears, however, that the work was not a very ancient one. Neither YƒÅj√ºavalkya nor ParƒÅ≈õara mentions Sumantu among the propounders of ilharma. On the other hand the name of Sumantu is an ancient one. In the Bhaga vatapurƒÅna (XII. 6. 75 and 7.1) Sumantu is said to have been a pupil of Jaimini and a promulgator of the Atharvaveda. Vide Sintiparva 341. 19 for Sumantu and other pupils of VyƒÅsa and SabhƒÅ 4. 11. In the daily turpu≈Üƒ∑u the name of Sumantu occurs along with Jaimini, Vai≈°ampƒÅyana, Paila.

Numerous verses on dharma are also cited from Sumantu by AparƒÅrka, the Sm·ªãticandrik√° and other works. This may probably be a different work from the s≈´tra work of Sumantu. In one verse of Sumantu ( AparƒÉrka on YƒÅj. I. 223 ) occur the words. Saikhasya vacanam yath√£’ and in another (Apar√°rka on Yaj. I. 217‚Äì218 ) the KanyƒÅ sign of the zodiac is refer red to.

It is remarkable that the Mit. and AparƒÉrka contain po verses of Sumantu on vyaval√°ra. The Sarasvati-vil√°sa is rich in quotations from Sumuntu on vyavah√°ra.   1. The Smrtis

299

fine for selling and purchasing land without the consent of the neighbouriny members of the family and says that in case of pre-emption the neighbours on the east are preferred to all and those on the south come last. :02 Sunintu defines a mort gage by conditional sale (callel uktilihhakraya’) and a sale for arrears of revenue by the king’s orders (called ajna kraya ).303

  1. The Smrtis The word sm»ôti is used in two senses. It is applied to all ancient orthodox non-Vedic works such as Panini’s gram mar, to the srauta, grhya and dharma sutras, to the Mahabha. rata, to Manu, Yijnavalkya and others. In a narrower sense smrti and dharmasƒÅstra are synonyms, as Manu says.304. The word smrti occurs in Taittiriya Aranyaka (I. 2). Gautama (Dh. S. I. 2) and Vasistha (Dh. S. I. 4) speak of smrti as one of the sources of Dharma. Ap. Dh. S. (II. 6. 15. 25) employs the word smrti and has in view Gautama’s Dharma sutra according to Haradatta. In the PurvamimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ-sutra the word smrti occurs ( vide VI. 8. 23 and XII. 4. 42 ).306 lu the Vedrutusutrus the word smrti is employed in a wide seuse, in one place as relerring even to the sankhya system.308

In that work the word is used, according to Sankara, with reference to the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata or the Manusmrti ( VedƒÅnta sutra II. 3. 47, III. 1. 14, IV. 2. 14 ).

Manu applies the word Smƒõti also to works that are opposed to and beyond the pale of the Veda (on XII. 95 ).307 But the word is used in this work in a narrower sense viz. Smrti means a work that is not opposed to the Veda or that does not treat the Veda as not authoritative and treats of varna, j√§ti, ƒÅ≈õramas and cognate topics. The word Sm»ôti occurs in the Mah√¢bharata (Santiparva 85. 10). But the more frequent word is Dharma≈õƒÅstra, though Manu (II. 10) says . Smiti is Dharma≈õƒÅstra.’ On P√•n.   1. The Smrtis

301

jali had before him a large smrti literature. Vide I. H. Q. vol. II. pp. 67 ff; I. A. vol. 14. pp. 326-27 ( Kielhorn), I. H. Q. vol. XI. pp. 79-90; Dr. F. W. Thomas Presentation Volume pp. 128-133 on ‘Mahabharata verses and very ancient Dharma s≈´tras and other works’ (by the present author). The Maha bhƒÅrata is spoken of as Dharmasastra, Artha≈õƒÅstra and Kama sƒÅstra (in Adi. 2. 383). The word Dharƒ±na≈õƒÅstresu or Dhar ma≈õƒÅstrƒÅ≈Üi (in the plural) occurs frequently in the great epic ( vide Vanaparva 207. 83, 293. 34, 313. 5; SƒÅnti. 24. 13, 297. 40, Anu≈°ƒÅsana 90. 34). The extant Manusmrti also (in III 232) mentions ‚ÄúDharma≈õƒÅstrƒÅni.” Dharma≈õƒÅstra is a much wider term than Dharmas≈´tra. The Dharmas≈´tras are only a few while there are dozens of Dharma≈õƒÅstras. Vide p. 21 above for points of difference between Dharnas≈´tras and Dharnars√°stras.

It may be stated that Inscriptions from comparatively early times refer to Sm·ªôtis, particularly to the Smrti of Manu. The Valabhi grant of Dhruvasena of Valabhi year 207 (i. e. 525 -6 A. D.) published in 1. A. vol. II. p. 205 qualifies the king as *ManvƒÅdi-pranƒ´ta-vidhi vidhƒÉnƒÅ-dharmƒÅ.' The Palitana platea of Simhadeva in the year 255 of the Valabhi era (i. e. 574 A. D. in E. I. Vol. XI. pr 16-20 of the Samanta-MahƒÅrƒÅja-SimhƒÉ ditya speaks of Varihausa (the father of the ruling chief) as ‘one whose intellect was puritieil by plunging into the, waters of the several Sirtis composed by Manu and others. Similarly, in the Paltana plates of Dharasena Il of (Gupta Samviat) 2.32 (i, e. 571 A, D.) in E. I. Vol. XI. pp. 80 at p. 82, we have the striking description of Guhasena ( father of Dharasena as oue in whose case the title ‘raju’ was significant because he pleased the hearts of his subjects by properly observing the path laid down by all Sinitis (sakala-smrti pranƒ´ta-marya-samyak-parip√°lnna-piraji-hrdaya - ranjanƒÅd auvartha-raja -≈õabilu!). In the Pulibumra pates of the Estern C·∫£luky: king Jayasimha ! ( 632-663 A. D. ) occur the words

Bphaspatiriva nayaj√£o Manuriva vinayaj√±a·∏•, Yudhisthira iva dharmapar√°yunalƒ±’(E. I. vol. 15 at p. 256 ). : The same words (i. e. those in E. I. FOUT302

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

the study of ItihƒÅsa-PurƒÅna-RƒÅmiyana Bh√§rata-pada-vƒÅkya YƒÅj≈àavalkya-K√§tyƒÅyana-Bhrgu Algiro-M√§rkaydeya - Bhat tadar≈õanƒÅdi-sa»õ≈õƒÅstrƒÅbhiratasya’ (on p. 311). Here the Smrti uuthors Yaj≈àavalkya, K√§tyƒÅyana, Bhrgu ( meaning probably ¬∑Manu'), Argiras and M√ºrkandeya are specially mentionel, besides the six Philosophical systems of Bhatta

(i.e. Kumirila) and others.

Smrtis mirrored the beliefs and practices of people and also influenced writers and ordinary people. For example, Dr. Sterubach in Journal of Bharatiya-VidyƒÄ, Vol. XI. ( 1961 pp. 221 309), shows how the Pancatantra stories are often based on or relate to separate judicial problems of civil aud criminal law as well as procedure, although it does not solve any of the problems raised. The Raghuvamsa (I. 17 ) states that the subjects of Dilipa did not swerve in the least from the beaten path laid down from the days of Manu. In Raghu yamsa XIV. 67 KƒÅlidƒÅsa says that Munu laid down that the Dharma of a king was to safeguard varnas and √§≈õramus ( vide Manusmrti VII. 35). The drama Micchaka≈£ika (Act IX) shows that a BrƒÅhmana guilty of murder was not to be senten ced to death and the judge refers to the dictum of Manu (pro bably Manusmrti VIII. 380 ) to that effect.

In ancient times the number of smrtis (i. e. works on dharmasastra ) must have been very small. Gautama men tions by name no smrtƒ±k√•ra except Mauu, though he speks of dharƒ±na≈õ√∫stras (XI. 19). Baudhiyana names seven (besides himself) authors on dharma, viz. Au pujanghani, Katya, K√°≈õyapa, Gautama, Prajapati, Mandgalya and Hirita. Vasi stha uaines only tive authors, Gautama, Praj√°pati, Manu, Yama and H√§rita. ƒÄpastumba meutions a large number, viz. ten, some of whom like Eka, Ku≈Üika and PuskurasƒÉdi are no more than mere names to us. Manu speaks of only six ( besi. des himself) viz. Atri, the son of Utathya, Bhrgu, Vasistua, Vaikh√•vaga (or ruther Vikhamas ) and Suunaka. But in all these works the writers are mentioned only casually aud there is no regular enumeration or list of writers ou dharma in one place. A parƒÅrku quotes (p. 7) a sutra of Gautama (not found in the priuted G. Dh. S.) in which sixteen authors of dharma≈õ√°stras including himself are enumerated. 308 The 309 ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§®,

‡§Ü‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§™ ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§

  1. The Smrtis

803

same s≈´tra with slight variations is ascribed to Sankha-Lik hita in the Viramitrodaya ( Paribhasa-prakƒÅsa p. 16). Yaj fiavalkya is probably the earliest writer who enumerated in one place ( I. 4-5) twenty expounders of dharma (including himself and counting Sankba and Likhita as two distinct persons ). It will be noticed that YƒÅj. omits BaudhƒÅyana. ParƒÅ≈õara also gives a list of 19 expounders of dharma (exclu ding himself), but his list differs slightly from that of YƒÅj. Parƒ´≈°ara omits Brhaspati, Yama and VyƒÅsa and adds KƒÅs. yapa, GƒÅrgya and Pracetas. The Tantra-v√¢rtika (p. 125 ) of Kum√§rila 81 enks of eighteen dharmasamhitƒÅs. Visvar≈´pa quotes a verse of Vrddha-YƒÅj√±avalkya, who adds ten names to the list of YƒÅj≈àavalkya (vide note 262 a bove).310 The Catur vi≈Üsatimata is a work which professes to give the views of 24 sages on dharma≈õƒÅstra, viz. all those listed by YƒÅj. (except K√§tyƒÅyana and Likhita ) and six more, viz. GƒÅrgya, Narada, BaudhƒÅyana, Vatsa, Vi≈õvamitra, Sarkha ( SƒÅnkhyƒÅyana ? ). Aigiras as quoted in the Smaticandrika (I. p. 1), Hemadri ( Danak handu p. 528 ), the Sarasvativilisa (p. 13) and other works mention Upasƒ±nrtis,311 There is a smrti called Sattrim sanmata quoted by the Mit., Aparirka and other works. History of Dharmasastra

his enumeration of them is slightly different from that of Paithinasi.13 The Vrddhagautamasmrti ( Jivananda part II. pp. 498-499 ) gives a list of 57 dharma-≈õƒÅstras. The Prayo ga-pƒÅrijƒÅta as quoted in the Viramitrodaya enumerates 18 principal smrtis, 18 upasmrtis and 21 other smrtikƒÅras.s14 If all the smrtis cited in the later nibundhas such as the Nirnayasindhu, the May≈´khas of Nilakantha and the Vira mitrodaya be taken into account, the number of sm·ªôtis will be found to be about 100.

The sin≈°tis thus relied upon are the products of different and widely separated ages. Some of them are entirely in prose or in mixed prose and verse, while the large majority are in verse. A few of them are very ancient and were com posed centuries before the Christian era. Such are the dhar

masutras of Gautama, Apastamba, BaudhƒÅyana, and the Manusm·ªôti. Some were composed in the first centuries of the Christian era such as the sm·ªôtis of YƒÅj√±avalkya, Parisara, NƒÅraila. Most of the sm·ªôtis other than the above fall between the period from 400 A. D. to 1000 A. D. The chronology of all these sm·ªôtis presents perplexing problems. Some of the metrical sm·ªôtis are remodellings of older s≈´tras as in the case of Sankha. There are sometimes as many as two or three

  1. The Sortie

305

different sm·ªôtis going under the same name, e. g. SƒÅtƒÅtapa, HƒÅrƒ´ta, Atri. Then the confusion is worse confounded by the fabrications of sectarian zeal, such as the HƒÅrƒ´tasm·ªôti which is full of Vai≈ü≈Üa vite teachings. There are several works going under the naines of well-known sm·ªôtikƒÅras with the prefixes Vrddha, B»ôhat, Laghu. In many cases the works going under these names are different from the smrtis that are without these prefixes and this differentiation took place at a very early date in certain cases; for example, so early a writer as Visvar√ºpa distinguishes between YƒÅjsavalkya and Vpildha-YƒÅjuavalkya, GƒÅrgya and V»õddha-GƒÅrgya. Similarly, Visvar≈´pa quotes (on YƒÅj. I. 69 ) Vrddha-Manu and (on YƒÅj. I. 19 ) Vrddha-Vasistha, which latter probably was different from the Vasisthadharmas≈´tra, as the latter does not contain the details given by Visvar≈´pa.815 In some cases the works designated Vrddha or B·ªãhat are larger and in all cases later than the works without those prefixes. For exam. Ple, vide Parisara aud Brhat-ParƒÅ≈õara (Jivananda part II. pp. 53-309), Glutaina and Viddha-Gautana (Jivananda Part II. pp. 497-038). Some of the works with the prefix V≈°ddha are versified compilations of prose works e. g. Mit. on Y√•j. III. 267 quotes a verse from Vrddha-Visnu which is merely the versified equivalent of Visuu-dharmas√∫tra chap. 50. 6, 12-14. It appears that sometimes the same work is cited with the prefix Vrddha or B»ôhat, e. g. the Mit. on YƒÅj. II. 135 quotes a passage from Brhad-visnu which is the same as the Vi≈ünudharmas≈´tra 17. 4-7.

As most of the writers quote from memory and had recou rse to mss. and not to standard editions, even well-known verses are ascribed to different authors in different works. The verses ‘bhrƒÅtrn√°m-aprajƒÅh’ &c. which are quoted as NƒÅrada’s (N√§rada 16. 25-26 ) in the VyavahƒÅramayukha are attributed to Sarkha in the Madana pƒÅrijƒÅta (p. 680). The three verses about bundhus are ascribed to BaudhƒÅyana by Madhava and to V·ªäddha≈õƒÅt√§ta pa by the MadanapƒÅrijƒÅta (p. 674 ).

In spite of all these drawbacks, an attempt will be made in the following pages to arrange some of the leading versified sm·ªôtis in chronological order beginning from the Manusm·ªôtit.

818' allegativa pret sariata g fakta:. Vide farge. Th. In ..*84-68 for the five-pito on one’s hand,

306

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

All these sm·ªôtis are not equal in authority. Most of them are obscure and are only rarely cited by ancient commenta tors. Exclusive of the dharmasutras hardly a dozen emptis have found commentators. If we are to judge of the authority of a smrti by the commentaries thereon, then the Manusmrti stands pre-eminent. Next to it is the YƒÅjsavalkyasmrti.

  1. The Manusmrti So many editions of this work have been published in India since 1813 ( when the Manusmrti was first published at Calcutta ), that it is not possible to name them. In this work the NirnayasƒÅgara edition with the commentary of Kulluka has been used throughout. Another edition of Manu well known on this side of India is that of the late V. N. Mandlik, who published several commentaries such as those of Medha tithi, Govindaraja and others. The Manusmrti has been tran slated into English several times. The best known transla tion is that of Dr. B√ºhler in the S. B. E. series (vol. 25). Dr. B√ºhler also added an exhuustive and very scholarly intro duction to his translation and dealt with numerous problems connected with the Manusmrti.

In the Rgveda the rgis often speak of Manu as ‘father’ (in Rg. I. 80. 16, I. 114. 2, VIII. 63. 1 ) without expressly saying

of whom.' But in Rg. II. 33. 13 the sage speaks of Manu 88 ‘our father’ (Y√¢ni Mavur-avrnitƒÅ pitƒÉ nah). The word Manu in several cases (from the nominative to the locative) and in componnd words like Manu-jƒÅta,' ‘Manu-pritƒÅsah’ and Manur-hita' occur hundreds of times. In Rg. VIII. 30. 3 the prayer is ‘O Gods! May you protect us, help us, speak in our favour, may you not lead us far from the ancestral path of Manu.’ In Rg. I. 36. 19 the poet says ‘0’ Agnil Manu established you as a light for the people.' The gods are often referred to as those to whom Manu offered sacrifices (as in √¶g. V. 35. 15, VIII. 30. 2, X. 36. 10, X. 65. 14). In √¶g. VIII. 23. 17 it is said . KƒÅvya U≈°anas is said to have established Agni for Manu.' In √¶g. VIII. 98. 6 Indra is spoken of as the sha tterer of many cities of the asuras ), as the killer of dasyu and as bringing prosperity to Manu and as the lord of Heaven. The two s≈´ktas (Rg. X. 61 and 62 are ascribed in the Anivkra ma·ª•i to NƒÅbhƒÅnedistha, son of Manu, the refrain in the first four verses being ‘O’ intelligent (Angirases ) Hecept

  1. The Manusmrti

307

me, the son of Manu, as officiating priest). It may be noted that NƒÅbhƒÅnedistha is mentioned in Rg. X. 61. 18 and descri bed as desirous (of securing cows ) and as praying loudly ( NƒÅbhƒÅnedistho rapati pra venan). In Ry. X. 62.4 be is referred to as “ayam NƒÅbhƒÅ' and in X. 62 SƒÉvarnya or SƒÉvarni is said to be Manu ( verse 11). In many of the verses of the √¶g. in which the word Manu occurs, commentators and translators often hold that the word Manu stands for ‘Manusya’ (and not merely for Manu as an individual ). But it is clear that in some Rgveda verses at least Manu must be taken as an individual sage ; e. g. in Rg. I. 112. 16 a prayer is made to the Advins to come with help as they did in the past ages (purƒÅ ) in the case of Sayu, Atri and Manu. Simi. larly, in 1. 80. 16 reference is made to the sacrifice offered and the sacred verses recited by Atharvan, father Manu and sage Dadhyan in past ages (p≈´rvatha ). The r»ôi of S≈´ktas 27-81 of Rg. VIII is said in the Anukramani to be Manu Vairagvata and Manu is mentioned in VIII. 27. 4 and 14, in VIII. 80. 2 ( thirty-three gods ure said to have been offered worship by Manu). On the two hymns (Rg. X. 61 and 62) the Ait. Br. ( 22. 9) tells the story of NƒÅbhƒÅnedistha, son of Manu, who was excluded from a share in the paternal wealth by his brothers and explains the refrain ‘pratigrbh·∫°ita m√§navam sumedhasa·∏•’ (in X. 62 ) as relating to that story.

It is impossible in the short space that can be spared to dilate at length on Manu as delineated in Sanskrit literature from the early Vedic times onwards. He is regarded in the early literature sometimes as the father of the human race ( so far at least as India is concerned ), as one of the very ancient sages, as having brought (or established ) Fire, as a semi-divine being who received from God himself the laws and regulations, as a king in the Krta yuga (Asvamedhika parva 4. 2 ), as the author of a work on Arthas√ºstra ( Drona parva 7.1). The Manusm»ôti (VII. 42 ) itself states that Mana became king by his disciplined behaviour (vinaya).

In the Taittiriya Samhita and the T√°ndya-mab√•-brƒÅh. mana it is said whatever Manu said is medicine ‘.816 Taitti riya-Samhita (II. 1. 5. 6 ) also says that mankind is Manu’s

816f* 49 1 8. 8. II. 2. 10. 2; ‘HET

7954 Tart’ arst. 28. 16. 17.

FOUNDED

308

History of Dharmasastra

( Manavyo hi prajƒÅ·∏•). In the Taittiriya SamhitƒÅ (IIL. 1. 9. 4-5 ) and the Aitareya BrƒÅhmana ( V, 14 ) we have the story of Manu dividing his wealth among his sons and of the exclu sion of his son NƒÅbhƒÅnedistha. The Satapatha-brahmana (S. B. E. vol. 12 p. 216 ) gives us the story of Manu and the deluge. In the Nirukta (chap. III ) there is a discussion about the rights of sons and daughters. One of the views there propounded is that children of both sexes take their father’s wealth and a rk and sloka are cited in support of that position.317 The sloka refers to the opinion of Manu SvƒÅyam bhuva. It is noteworthy that that sloka is opposed to a rik, which means that the sloka is not Sruti but.is Smrti. $o before YƒÅska wrote tbere were smrti texts in verse in which Manu was spoken of as a lawgiver. We have seen how.Ganta ma and Vasistha quote the views of Manu and how. Apasta mba connects Manu with the promulgation of frƒÅddhas ( 11.7. 16.1). The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata in numerous places speaks of Mapa, sometimes as Manu simply, sometimes as SvƒÅyambhuva Manu (Santi 21. 12.) and also as PrƒÅcetasa Madu (Santi, 57:48:). In the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata (SƒÅnti. chap. 336. 38-46) we are told how the Supreme Being composed a hundred thousand Slokas on dharing, how Manu SvƒÅyambhuv.& promulgated thosa dharmas and how Ubanas and Bfhaspati composed sdotros based on the work of Manu Sv√°yambbuva.318 In another place the account is slightly different and Manu does not figure thereiu. SƒÅnti-parva (chap. 59. 80‚Äì85 ) describes how the original work of Brubm√£ on the three, Dhurma, Artha, and K‚ÄôƒÅma, in 100000 cbapters was successively reduced to 10000, 5000, 3000 and 1000 chap, respectively by Visalaksa, Indra, BƒÅhudantaka, B»ôhaspati and K≈´vya (Usanas). The prose introduction to the NƒÅrada-smrti says that Manu com posed in 100000 slokas, 1080 chap. and 24 prukara≈Üas a Dha

rma≈õƒÅstra and imparted it to NƒÅrada, who abridged it into 12000 verses and taught it to MƒÅrkandeya, who in his turn .compressed it into 8000 slokas and passed it on to Sumati Bhargava, who again reduced it to 4000 slokas. The N√§rada smrti then gives the first verse319 of that work which is a combination of the extant Manu I. 5-6 and says that vyava bƒÉra was the 9th prakarana out of 24 in the original work of Manu. and Argiras.821 So early a writer as Visvar≈´pa cites verses from Manusmrti as those of Svayambh≈´ (vide com. on YƒÅj. II. 73, 74, 83, 85, where Manu 8. 68, 70-71, 380 and 105-6 are respectively quoted as Svayambhu’s ), while quotations from Bhrgu cited by Visvar≈´pa (on YƒÅj. I. 187 and 252 ) are not found in the Mapusmrti. In the same way most of the verses quoted from Bh·ªâgu by AparƒÉrka are not found in the Madu smrti. One verse which AparƒÅrka quotes from Bhrgu (on YƒÅj. II. 96 ) speaks of the view contained therein as that of Manu.322

It is almost impossible to say who composed the Mapu smrti. It goes without saying that the mythical Manu, proge mitor of mankind even in the Rgveda, could not have composed it. What motives could have induced the upknown author to palm it off in the name of the mythical Mapy and to suppress his identity it is difficult to say. One motive may have been to invest the work with a halo of antiquity and authoritative ness. B√ºbler following Max M√ºller says (SBE vol. 25 p. XVIII) that the Manusmrti is based on or is a recast of an ancient dharmas≈´tra, viz. that of the M√§navacarana. The ques tion whether the MƒÅnavadharmas√∫tra existed has been disco Boed above ( sec. 13, pp. 141-149 ). Buhler bimself candidly admits (SBE vol. 25, p. XXIII) that the recovery of the writings of the MƒÅnavas has not only not furnished any facto in support of the alleged relation between the MƒÅnavadharma sutra and the Manusmrti, but on the contrary has raised difficulties, as the doctrines of the M√§navagƒºhyas√∫tra (edited by Dr. Knauer) differ very considerably from those of the Maqusmrti. To take only a few examples : MƒÅnava Gr. S. II. 12. 1-2 are opposed to Manu 3.1; M≈´nava Gr. $. I. 4. 7 to Manu 4.95; M√§nava Gr. S. I. 20.1 to Manu 2.34 ; M√§nava Gr. 8. I. 21. 1 to Manu 2.35; MƒÅnava Gr. $. I. 22. 1 to Manu 2. 36 ; M√§nava Gr. S. II. 12. 1-2 to Manu 3. 84-86. Besides, there is nothing in our Manu corresponding to the VinƒÅyaka≈õƒÅnti in the M√§navagƒºhya (II. 14 ) nor to the tests for selecting . bride prescribed in MƒÉnava Gr. S. I. 7.9, which corresponds to

  1. l’ho Manuemyh

811

AsvalƒÅyana Gƒô. S. I. 5. 5-6. Dr. Caland points out (R. und S. p. 17 ) that, though single verses of the Manusmrti tally with the SrƒÅddhakalpa of the M√§nava School, yet the descrip tions of funeral rites widely differ in the two works. There are no doubt some parallels as pointed out by Bradke (in ZDMG, vol. 36, pp. 417-477). There is one circumstance about the authorship of the Manusmrti that deserves to be noted. The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata 323 seems to distinguish between SvƒÅyambhuva Manu and Pr√°cetasa Manu. The former is said to be the pro mulgator of dharma≈õƒÅstra and the latter of artha≈õƒÅstra (or politics ). For example, Santi 21. 12 speaks of SvƒÅyambhuva Manu and Santi 57. 43 and 58. 2 speak of pr√°cetasa as an author on rƒÅju≈°ƒÅstra or rƒÅjadharma. In some places Manu alone without any epithet is associated with rƒÅjadharma or ArthavidyƒÅ. It is not unlikely that originally there were two distinct works, one on dharma and the other on arthasƒÅstra, attributed to Manu. When the Kautiliya speaks of tbe MƒÅne Vas, it probably refers to the work on politics attributed to PrƒÅcetasa Manu. It is extremely doubtful whether RƒÅja. sekhara, when he mentions the several views on the number of vidyƒÅs (including that of the MƒÅnavas, that they were three), had the ArthasƒÅstra of the M√§navas before him or only copied a passage from Kautilya (vide KƒÄvyamimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ p. 4). It is not unlikely that the work on dharma attributed to Menu may have contained general directions on the duties of kings. It is therefore (i. e. because there were two different works on dharma and arthagƒÅstra attributed to Manu ) that the views ascribed to the M√§navas hy the Kau≈£iliya are not found word for word in the extant Manusmrti. One may hazard the conjecture that the author of the Manusmrti, wbo ever he might have been, combined in his work the informa tion contained in the two works on dharma and arthasƒÅstra and supplanted both the earlier works and that this result had not been either accomplished at the time when the Kauti liya was composed or was then quite recent. In the extant Manusmrti, the work is ascribed to Sv√§ymbhuva Manu and then six other Manus, of whom PrƒÅcetasa is not one, are enu merated ( I. 62).

TE

History of Dharmagdstra

The extant Manusmrti is divided into twelve adhyƒÅyas and contains 2694 slokas. Dr. Jolly’s edition (published in 1895 ) prepared after collating numerous mss. and printed editions contains only one sloka more. The Manusm·ªôti is written in a simple and flowing style. It generally agrees with Panini’s system, though it contains some deviations from it as in the verse ‘s√§ksinah santi metyuktv√§’ ( 8. 57). The foregoing pages have sufficiently shown how it agrees closely with the doctrines contained in the Dharmas√∫tras of Gautama, BaudhƒÅyana, Anastamba. We have also seen how numerous verses are common to the dharmas√∫tras of Vagistha and Visnu and the Manuemrti. The Kautilƒ´ya also exhibits remarkable agreement with the Manusmrti in phraseology and doctri Des.824 : What conclusions are to be drawn from this will be discussed later on. Some verses are repeated, e. g. V. 164 165 are the same as IX. 30 and 29. The contents of the Manu: smrti may be briefly summarised as follows: (I) Sages ap proach Manu for instruction in the dharmas of the varnas; Manu describes the creation of the world from the self-existent God more or les in the Sankhya manner; the creation of VirƒÅj, of Manu from Viraj, of ten sages from Manu ; creation of various beings, men, beasts, birds etc.; BrahimƒÉ imparts Dharma≈õƒÅstra to Manu, who teaches the sages; Manu bids Bhrgu to instruct the sages in dharƒ±nƒ± ; six other Manus sprang from SvƒÅyambhuva Manu; units of time from nimesa to year, the four yugas and their twilights; one thousand yugas equal a day of BrahmƒÉ; extent of manvantara; pra laya; successive decline of dharma in the four yugas; diffe rent dharmas and goals in the four yugas; the special privi leges and duties of the four varnas; eulogy of BrƒÅhma·πáas and of the ≈õƒÅstra of Manu; ƒÅcƒÅra is the highest dharma; table of contents of the whole sƒÅstra ; (II) definition of dharmo, sour 324 Compare p oate TouthTerut tearaava tanto alten

sfatuat al Real (I. 4) with HI 7. 101 BSTETTAR√ãTEU≈†A JELI ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡••; ‘‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï grateff fraueatis: RITA’ CT ( 1. 4) with #] 7. 162 facit. qa√ßus: Fort; 38H Ranes: ht√†’arma (III, 1) with HF 8. 55 STARTET HATTE a far√† 49:'; PETAR H49.41 TECH (III. 17 ) with HI 8.332 Fakat crayaa tax * p q 84.

  1. The Manusmrti

315

jiva ; tortures of hell; the three gu≈Üas, suttva, rajas and tamas; what brings about nihsrcyusu; knowledge of the Self is the highest means of bliss ; prioritu and nivrtta karma; the latter is karma done without an eye to reward ; eulogy of Vedas; place of turku ; sisters anii preri≈üud; reward of studying the MƒÅnava s√ºstra.

The extent of the literature known to Manu was con siderable. He mentions the three Vedas and the Atharva veda is spoken of as the Atharva girasi Sruti ( XI. 33). He refers to Aranyaka (IV. 123 ). The VedƒÅrgas are said to be six (III. 185 ) and they are often referred to without stating the number ( II. 141, IV. 98 ). He speaks of dharma ≈õƒÅstra (II. 10) and also knew many dharma≈õƒÅstras (III. 232). By dharmapƒÅthaka (XII. 111 ) he probably means one who has studied dharma≈õƒÅstras. He mentions several authors on dharma≈õƒÅstra, viz. Atri, the son of Utathya (i. e. Gautama according to commentators ), Bhrgu and Saunaka (all these in III. 16), Vasistha (on the rate of interest in VIII. 140 which agres with Vasisthadharmas≈´tra II. 50), VaikhƒÅnasa. mata (in VI. 1). He mentions ƒÄkhyƒÅnas, ItihƒÅsa, PurƒÅnas and Khilas (III. 232 ). He speaks of bruhna as described in the VedƒÅnta (in IV. 83 and 94 ) and is probably thinking of the Upani≈üads. That he knew some generally accepted works opposed to the teaching of the Vedas is quite clear from his reference to Veda b√•hyƒÅ·∏• sm≈ütaya·∏•’ (XII. 95). He is probably referring to the writings of the Bauddbas, Jainas and others. He speaks of heretics and their guilds (IV. 30 and 61 ). He refers to atheism and calumny of the Vedas (IV. 163 ) and of various tongues spoken among men (IV. 332 ). He frequently refers to the views of others in the words “kecit‚Äù in III, 53, 261, IX. 32, ‘eke’ in X. 10, XI. 45, ‘apare’ and ‘anye’in III. 261. In IX. 49 Manu refers to GƒÅthƒÅs of VƒÅyu and it appears that at least verses IX. 43-45 are quotations. Yoga had been well developed at the time of the Manu-smrti. In Manu VI. 70 it is laid dowu that even three PranayƒÅmas when accompanied by Omk√°ras and the VyƒÅbstis constitute the highest tu pas and that by prƒÅnƒÅyƒÅma all the aberrations of the senses (including the mind ) are destroyed. In VI. 72 are briefly indicated the results of PrƒÅ·π£ƒÅyƒÅma, Praty√§b√§ra ( withdrawal of the sepse organsdrom the objects of sense ), DhƒÅra·πáƒÅ (the holding of the minetto certain spot or a certain point such as the tip of one’s nose

1917

316

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

and DhyƒÅna (contemplation) i. e. one-pointedness of the apprehension of the object contempluted upon. Vide H. of Dh. Vol. V. pp. 1444-49 for explanation of PratyƒÅbƒÅra, DbƒÅ ranƒÅ, DhyƒÅna. The word DhyƒÅnayoga occurs in Manu VI. 73 and 79 and it is stated that by dhyƒÅnayoga, one realizes brahman. The words ‘DhyƒÅnayoga,’ ‘DhƒÅra·∏•ƒÅ’ and others occur in some of the Upanisads as illustrated in the note325 below. The Yogas≈´tra is not later than the 2nd or 3rd century A. D. ; vide H. of Dh. vol. V, pp. 1395-98, but the Upani≈üads had developed much of the yoga technique centuries before the Yogas≈´tras and the Manusmrti is based on the Upani≈üads and not on the Yogas≈´tra.

Numerous interesting and difficult problems are conne cted with the Manusmrti. B√ºhler in his elaborate introduc tion (S. B. E. vol. 25) exhaustively deals with these problems. It is not possible to go at great length into those questions here. A separate volume would be required to deal with the problems raised by Biihler and to examine the arguments of B√ºhler, Hopkins and others who have written on them. Only a brief discussion of some of these problems can be attempted.

B√ºhler takes considerable pains to refute the claims of Manu to be regarded as the first legislator (S. B. E. vol. 25 pp. XXIII-XXX). But no serious refutation of the claim is really needed. The very extent of the literature known to the Manusmrti and the mention of several writers on dharma sƒÅstra by name are sufficient to negative that claim.

B√ºhler devotes a great deal of space to the consideration of the question as to what circumstances led to the substitu tion of a universally binding M√§nava-dharma≈õƒÅstra for the manuals of the Vedic schools (8. B. E. vol. 25 pr. XLVI-LVI)

arquit Upani≈üad ( VI. 18 ) rogards Yoga as ≈üadauga ‘91011978: ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§∑‡§°‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É‡•§; ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§†‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡•ç VI.   1. The Manusmrti

317

and as to why the special law schools selected just the M≈´na vadharmas≈´tra among the large number of similar works for the basis of their studies (ibid. pp. LVII-LXV ). B√ºhler then considers the question how the M√°navadharmas√∫tra was con verted into the present Manusirti. B√ºhler concedes that the last is a problein of great difficulty and admits of an approxi mate solution only. The discussion of all these questions by B√ºhler is extremely thought-provoking and brilliant in many places, though it must be said with great respect that the arguments are often a priori and gavour more or less of speci al pleading. As I question the very foundation of B√ºhler’s edifice ( viz, the actual existence of a M√§nava-dharmas≈´tra ), it would be futile for me to enter into a discussion of the pro blems referred to above.

Jolly in Introduction to the Vishudharinas≈´tra (p. XXYII n. 3) admits that Manu has little in common with the M√§nava grhya, both in mantras and otherwise, Manu is recognised as an ancient writer on Dharmasastra in the Dharmas≈´tras. Gaut. Dh. S. 21. 7 refers to Manu’s view that three out of the five mortal sins ( Mah√°p√§takus ) could uot be wiped out except by death ( this has a counterpart in the extant Manu smrti in XI. 89, 90, 103-4). The Ap. Dh. S. II. 6. 13. 11 refers to the tradition that Manu divided family property among his sons and also to the tradition (in II. 7. 16. 1 ) that Manu was the founder of the institution of SrƒÅddha rites. Manu is called SrƒÅddhadeva’ in Bralƒ±mƒÅnila-purƒÅna III. 59. 38. The Baud. Dh. S. also pientions Manu’s division of pro perty among his sons, refers to Maru’s opinion that the father is a sinner if he does not arrange a marriage for his daughter within three years after her first monthly illness (IV.1.14) and further that the Aghamarsana hymn (Rg. X. 190. 1-3) is declared by Manu as a penance for all sing ( Baud. Dh. S. IV. 2. 19 20). This reflects Madu XI. 260. The Vas. Dh. S. in numerous places mentions. MƒÅnaram slokam’ or simply “MƒÅnavam', besides verses containing words like Manuh prƒÅha' (in XI. 23 ) or Mannr-ƒÅha prajƒÅpatili' (in Vas. XII. 16 ), ‘abravin-manuh (in Manusmrti V.41 and in Vas. IV. 6). This question of the relation of the Manusmrti and Vas. Dh. S. has been dealt with at some length above (pp. 99-103/

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

mƒÅ≈Üda II. 36. 3-5 name twelve Manus. VƒÅyu ( 100.53 ) derive the word Maru as ‘Mananan-mƒÅnanƒÅc-caiva tasm√§t te Manava·∏• sm·ªôtƒÅ·∏•’. It is interesting to note that Kum√§rila (650-700 A.D.) asserts that there are 14 Manus.326

An extensive literature327 has accumulated in modern times about Manu and the Manusmrti, about the relation of the Manusinfti to the Dharmas≈´tras, to the Mahabharata, to the Artha≈õƒÅstra of Kautilya and about the development and spread of his doctrines to countries in South-East Asia. The present author has read some of it, but he cannot expatiate on all the topics about Manu in one volume of the History of Dharmu≈õƒÅstra.

In ancient times it was held to be the king’s duty328 to protect the kingdom and the people, to see that the rules of var nus and ƒÅ≈õrumas were carried out by them, to make them conform to the dictates of S√ºstra if they swerved from them, to punish the wicked and to dispense justice. The Artha≈õƒÅstru says ‘people of the four vurnals and in the ( different ) di≈°ramas protected by the king with the Rod (of punishment ) and attached to the actions prescribed as their respective) duties keep to the paths appropriate to them.’ Kautilya (in Artha s√§stra III. 1. 38 ) calls the king Dharƒ±na pravartaka’ (pro pounder or promulgator of Dharma ). Many works (parti. cularly the Mahabharata ) hold that all dharmas and all vidyƒÅs

1917

  1. The Manusmrti

319

abide in RƒÅjadharma, that the welfare of the people depends on the king (Santiparva 141. 9 ). Though the general tendency was to say that Dharma progressively declines in each of the four yuzas, yet this idea 32' was not universal. The Mahabharata and the Manusmrti state (in IX. 301) that conditions described about the four yugas are not immutably fixed parts of Time, but it is the ruler (who by conducting himself properly ) can create the conditions of even Krtayuga in what common people call Kaliyuga. There is a great difference between ancient societies (like those in India ) and some modern western societies. In several modern societies there are legislatures that lay down many laws to be observed by the people. In ancient times (in India ), the legislative activity of the ruler was extremely limited. Besides, India was divided into many kingdoms and great conflict of laws might have arisen. Moreover, there was no single ruler who could have legislated for the whole of India, even if the task of legislation was attemp ted. Manu ( in VIII. 3 ) and Katyayana330 provide that causes ( law-suits) were to be looked into (i. e. decided ) by the king according to the SƒÉstras and in the absence of SƒÅstric dicta, by

mina

..

vie

w

‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å 1X.301 ; ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§≠ ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø 141. 10; ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§æ‡§°‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•å ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡•• ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á

II. 1 (p. 599) ; ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•å ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§∞ I. 24 q, by ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ ( ‡§Ü‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ï p. 11).

11

320

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

the usages of the country and that if the king decides causes by his fiat when there is in existence a S√ºstric text, it leads him away from heaveu, it brings danger to him from enemies and reduces the span of his life. Manu (VII. 13 ) laid down that since the ruler has in him the glory of eight deities (Indra, VƒÅyu, the Sun, Yama, Agni, Varuna, the Moon and Kubera ) whatever rules as regards desirable matters he (the king) established, whatever rules he makes about undesirable actions should not be transgressed by the people. Medha tithi and other commentators expressly state that the ruler could not inake a rule opposed to the SƒÉstras and the long standing usages of the people. Therefore, changes in the practices of the people could be provided only by resorting to such devices as the Kalivarjya topics (indicated in H. of Dh. III. pp. 885‚Äì968 ) or by composing fresh sastras acceptable to the learned and the leaders of people or by saying that in the four different yugas four different smrtis were predominant as stated in ParƒÅ≈õara-smrti (I. 24). Manu (IV. 176 ) says ‘One381 should abandon what was once) Dharma, if it ends in unha ppiness or it has become hateful to the people’ and YƒÅj. (I. 156 ) also remarks ‘what was once ) allowed to be Dharma should not be practised, if people have come to hate it and it does not lead to Heaven.’ The Vi≈ünu-Purina (III. 11. 7 says the same thing. It is very rare to find one SmrtikƒÅra expressly stating that he dissents from the views of other named smrtikƒÅras. Yaj. (I. 56 ) remarks ‘what is said (by some) that persons of the twice-born classes can marry a s≈´dra woman is not my view,’ Manu (in III. 13) allows a brƒÅhmana to marry a sudra woman, but in the following ver ses (III. 14‚Äì19) he severely condemns such marriages. That means he condemned the practices of a former age. Similarly, the practice of niyoga ( appointment of a brother-in law to procreate a son on the widow of a sonless person ) was set out at some length by Manu in IX. 53-62, but immediately

  1. The Manusmrti

321

afterwards he condemns it (in IX. 64-68)337 as beastly (pa≈°u dharma' in IX. 66 ) and waters down the whole idea by say ing (IX. 69 ) that, when after the betrothal of a girl, the selected bridegroom dies (before actual marriage), then the brother of the deceased should marry that gir). B»ôhaspati refers to these passages of Manu by saying that Manu descri. bed the procedure of niyoga but ultimately he himself for bade it ( vide B»ôhaspati quoted by AparƒÅrka p. 97 (on YƒÅj. I.

68-69 ).

Confusion is caused by the fact that ancient texts refer to Svayambhuva Manu, PrƒÅcetasa Manu and Manu simply. To take first the Manusmrti itself. The views of SvƒÅyam bhuva Manu are mentioned in Manu VI. 54 ( on the vessels to be used by ascetics ), VIII. 124 (the parts of the body where corporal punishment was to be administered in the case of all offenders except brƒÅhmanas ), IX. 158 (on the twelve varieties of sons such as arrasa, ksctraja &c.). In the first two cases the verb abravit' is used and in the 3rd ƒÅha'. No Manu is cited in chapters II and VII. In Manu IX. 138 the etymo. logy of the word ‘putra’ is attributed to Svayambhuva (Manu not being added ). The words ‘tan-manor anu≈°ƒÅsanam occur in VIII. 139, 279 and IX, 239. The words ‘Manur abravƒ´t’ occur many times, as in III. 150 and 222, IV, 103, V.

vorge322

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

TV

41 and 131, VIII. 168, 242, 339, IX. 182 and X. 63. In Manu smrti IX, 17 Manu is said to have consigned certain special matters to women in general (Manur-akalpayat). Manu PrajƒÅpati is mentioned in X. 78 and in XII. 123 it is stated that the highest Purusa is called by some as Manu PrajƒÅpati. I have not been able to find in the Manusmrti any mention of PrƒÅcetasa Manu as having said something, but in I. 35 among the ten PrajƒÅpatis that primeval Manu (son of VirƒÅj) created Pracetas is one. Therefore, it boils down to this that in the 2684 verses of the Manusmrti (in the Nir. edition ) Manu (whether simply as Manu or as SvƒÅyambhuva or as PrajƒÅ pati ) is mentioned only about twenty times. In many of these cases the words MapurƒÅha’ or Manur-abravit' or Manor-anu≈õƒÅsanam’are' padap≈´rana'. The earliest ex tant commentator ( Medhatithi ) on Manu IV. 103333 expressly says ‘Manugrahanam slokap≈´ra≈ÜƒÅrtham, vikalpƒÅrtham-anye.’ This shows that there was at least among those who could read and understand the Manusmrti, no idea about deceiving anybody and that learned people at least did not understand the words as meaning that the primeval Manu had said so. The general tendency in the Manusmrti is to have a complete proposition or idea (and not more or less ) in one verse of 32 syllables. In several cases where that seemed difficult these words were added as ‘padding.’ In the few cases where great conflict of views is expressed in the extant Manusmrti, the words. Manurabravƒ´t’or Manur√§ha ‘or ¬∑ Manor-anu≈°ƒÅsanam do not occur. For example, as to the propriety of a brƒÅbma ·ª•a marrying a woman of the s≈´dra class the opinions of four sages are mentioned (in Manu III. 16 ). But no words like

‚Ä¢ Manu svƒÅyambhuva’ or Manur-abravit' occur there. The opinion of the extant Manusmrti is that by marrying a s√ºdra woman a brƒÅhmana falls into naraka (hell) and by procre ating a son from her he loses his status as a brƒÅhmana ( Manu III. 17 ), while Bh»ôgu’s view seems to be that a brƒÅbmana be comes a condemned sinner by having a child (son or daugh ter ) from her. If the entire extant Manusmrti proceeds from Bhrgu, pupil of the primeval Manu, the Bhrgu (in III. 16 ) seems to be a different person altogether. It may be noted that AparƒÅrka on YƒÅj. II. 96 (p. 696 ) quotes a verse of Brgy

333 ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§®‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§ú‡•Ä‡§§ ‡•§‡•§

$1. The Manusmrti

323

on ordeals in which the view of Manu is stated.334 That means that there was a work of Bhrgu before AparƒÅrka in which Manu was cited. There are only two cases (in the present author’s opinion ) where Manu’s views are set out and where he may be said to assert his views as against those of others. One is connected with the question of the ≈õrƒÅddha to be offered to three ancestors, when the performer’s father and great grand-father are dead, but the grand-father is alive. In this Case Manu gives two alternatives in III. 221-222. The Kalpa taru on SrƒÅddha (p. 240 ) states three views about this ma tter. The other case is about eating the flesh of animals ( dis cussed at length in the Manusm·ªôti in V. 26-56 ). The general tenor of the extant Manusmrti is against flesh-eating, but there was Vedic authority for offering flesh on certain occa sions; therefore, Manu allows the killing of animals only on four occasions (in Madhuparka, in Yaj√±a, in SrƒÅddhas and rites in honour of gods ) and forbids it in other cases ( in V. 41. )

E. W. Hopkins, in his paper on ¬∑ Professed quotations from Manu found in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata' in J. A. O. S. Vol. XI. pp. 239-275 indulges in some very strongly worded and unca lled-for criticism of the extant Manusmrti and of the views attributed to Manu in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and in later legal and other works. A volume would be required to refute the one sided remarks of Hopkins. But a few samples must be given. On p. 268 he observes ‘the SƒÅstram was in great part collated between the time when the bulk of the epic was composed and its final completion, that previous to its collation there had existed a vast number of sententious remarks, proverbial wisdom, rules of morality etc. which were ascribed, not to this treatise of Manu at all, but to the ancient hero Manu as a type of godly wisdom. These I conceive to have floated about in the mouths of the people, not brought together but all loosely quoted as laws or sayings of Manu and these sayings were afterwards welded into one with the laws of a particular text (? sect) called the M√§navas. … … I fancy this sect built up their ƒÅcƒÅra ( usages ) and Kuladharma ( family law ) out of their own heads, not ascribing them to Manu

334

79: 1g arag faanila sfargia ( v. 1. afaite la 4a: 171*** pastataifa arfasteci HT: | 34921* p. 696.

324

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Hopkins is obsessed by the occurrence of words like Manura bravit’ in the Manusm·ªôti and asks ‚Äúif Manu says all, why emphasize a few ? According to my theory these Manu verses found in the Manu treatise were simply caught up and drawn from the hearsay of the whole Brahmana worlds. Doctrines utterly at variance with the MƒÅnava treatise are palmed off upon us with ‚ÄúManu said " doctrines”. It has been shown above that there are less than two dozen Manu said ‘(to use Hopkin’s phrase ) verses in about 2700 verses of the extant Manu and most of them do not at all teach doctri nes at variance with the M√§nava treatise. This is a specimen of what some Western Scholars on account of preconceived base less notions write about Indian works and Indian people. On p. 270 he winds up his diatribe in the following words ‘in my opinion the devotees of the legal SƒÅstra were more knaves than fools.’ There is no need to criticize these baseless and purely subjective remarks and wild theories about thousands of floating Sanskrit verses among people thousands of years ago, their being welded into one ≈õƒÅstra and new customs star ted on the basis of these verses by a sect like the MƒÅnavas. Apart from the Manusmrti (in which phrases like ‘Manur abravit occur a number of times ) such references do not occur at all in YƒÅj., there are only a few places in NƒÅrada where such phrases occur and in other early sm·ªôtis also there are only a few such references. Some later sm·ªôtis do mention Manu in some cases. The reason is obvious. Manu was famed as the great law-giver of ancient times. Some practices and rules had changed in the course of centuries. Later writers wanted changes according to their lights to be recognised, but, if they bad stated them in their own names, little weight would have been attached to them, therefore they probably hit upon the plan of saying in some cases that the view propounded by them had the authority of Manu. Hammurabi professed to have received laws from the Sun. Prophets of several religions profess that what they say is inspired by God Himself. Luther, who rebelled against the authority of the Pope, denou nced Copernicus as a fool and relied upon the Bible for prov ing that it was the Sun that had motion and not the earth. One should like to know whether Hopkins would have been jyrepared to dub as knaves ancient prophets who claimed to have received directly from God what they preached. top kins (in JRAS Vol. XI. pp. 243‚Äì246 ) collects some impreca

History of Dharmasastra

Manu is not at fault. And such people are certainly not as blamable as men claiming to have direct messages from God in this matter.

There is a rather involved account in the extant Manu smrti about the creation of the world by ParamƒÅtman. Sages ask Manu to expound the Dharmas of Varnas and intermediate castes; the evolution is briefly described in the summary of the first chapter above. Towards the end of the first chap ter the Manusmrti winds up by stating the appropriate acti ons for the four varnas, the pre-eminence of the brƒÅbmana and by proclaiming that the highest Dharma is ƒÅcƒÅra as propoun ded by the Vedas and the Smrtis and that the Sm»ôti declares the Dharmas of countries, castes, families, heretical sects and of ganas (guilds and oligarchies ).

The description of Manu as the son of Brahm√¢ and the primeval promulgator of laws is a mere camouflage or disgu ise. The extant Manusmrti mentions such human authors as Atri, Utathyatanaya, Saunaka, Bh·ªâgu (all in III. 16 ), Vasi stha ( as laying down the proper rate of interest in VIII. 140); also mentions Sm·ªôtis beyond the pale of the Veda ( XII. 95) and above all refers to dusyus who speak mlecchu languages and Arya languages such as Paundrakas, Odras, Kambojas, Yavanas, PƒÅradas, Pahlavas, Cinas, Sakas, KirƒÅtas, Daradas and Khasas (X. 44-45). Similarly, the ≈õƒÅntiparva ( in chap. 65 )388 mentions in a dialogue between Indra and MƒÅndhƒÅtp ( verses 13-14 quoted below) sixteen dasyu-like peoples and in verses 17-21 sets out the Dharmas that should be practised by those people described as living like dasyus. We know from the 13th Rock Edict of Asoka that he tried to propagate dhamma among Yona-kambojas, NabhƒÅka, NƒÅbhapanti, the Andhras and PƒÅradas, Bhoja-pitenikas and in the 5th Rock Edict also he mentions Yona-Kambhojas, people of GandhƒÅra, the Rittikas, Pitenikas and other Western people. These references to people to the West of AryƒÅvarta would indicate that the extant Manusmrti is not older than about 200 B. C.

PRONA

FOUNDED

  1. The Manusmrti

327

I shall now address myself to the discussion of the age of the Manusmrti from external and internal evidence. That ques tion is bound up with other problems, viz. whether there are earlier and later strata in the extant Manusmrti, whether the Manusm·ªôti was recast several times or once only, what relation exists between the Manusmrti and the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata.

First the external evidence may be taken up. The bhƒÅ kya of MedhƒÉtithi is the earliest extant commentary on the Manusmrti and was composed about 900 A. D. as will be shown later on. The text commented upon by MedhƒÅ tithi was the same (barring a few various readings ) as the one we now posses 8. Therefore, long before 900 A. D. the Manusm·ªôti was the same as now. Visvar≈´pa in his commentary on YƒÅj. quotes over two hundred verses of the Manusmrti either wholly or in part from all the twelve chapters beginn ing with the very first verse. The text that Visvar≈´pa had before him was the same as the present Manusmrti and the verses were arranged in the game order as at present. Visva r≈´pa quotes eight verses ( Manu XI. 108-115 ) from Manu (on Y√¢j. III. 262 ). SankarƒÅcƒÅrya in his VedƒÅntas≈´tra-bhƒÅgya quotes the Manusm»ôti very frequently. For example, he quo tes Manu I. 5 and 21 (on V. S. I. 3. 28 ), I. 27 (on V. S. IV. 2. 6), II. 87 ( on V. S. III. 4. 38), X. 4 and 126 ( on V. S. I. 3. 36 ), XII. 91 and 105-6 (on V. S. II. 1 and 11 ). In his bhƒÉ sya on the Br. U. he quotes Manu dozens of times and calls the Manusmrti. M√°navam'337 (on B·ªâ. U. I. 4. 17). He looks upon the Manusmrti as one of the authorities on which the author of the VedƒÅntas≈´tra relies.338 The Tantra vƒÅrtika of KumƒÅrila stands in a special relation to the. Manusmrti. Vide J BBRA S for 1925 pp. 98-100. He places Manu at the head of all sm≈°tis, even higher than the dharmas≈´tra of Gautama. He cites numerous quotations from the first chap ter of the Manusmrti to the last. He looks upon all parts of the extant Manusmrti as equally authoritative and regards the Manuem·ªôti as the highest authority on matters of dhar

st17. POONA

‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡••. History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

another place Brhagpati says ‚ÄúBurgu spoke of sale without ownership after deposit; listen to it attentively, I shall speak of it with more details”.340_This keeps in view Manu VIII. 4 and clearly shows that Brhaspati was well aware of Bhrgu’s connection with the extant Mapusmrti. Angiras as quoted in the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ (I. p. 7) speaks of the dharma≈õƒÅstra of Manu. In the VajrasƒÅci of Asvaghosa (ed. by Weber ) several verges are quoted as from the MƒÅnavadharma’ which occur in the extant Manusmrti,850 though it must be admitted that there are others that do not occur. In the RƒÅmƒÅyana also there are verses cited as from Manu which occur in the extant Manusmrti; vide Kiskindha 18. 30-32 ( Gujarati Press, 1915 1920), where two verses are quoted as ‘sung by Manu’ which correspond to Manusmrti VIII. 318 and 316 respectively.

The foregoing discussion of the external evidence shows that writers from the 2nd century onwards (if not earlier ) looked upon the extant Manusmrti as the most authoritative smrti. This position it could not have attained unless several centuries intervened between it and these writers. Therefore it must be presumed that the Manusmrti had attained its present form at least before the 2nd century A. D. Even the MahƒÅbhƒÅsya contains a verse which is Manu II.

‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§. 350 8.g. ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á-‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§§‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§® ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≤‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡•§

‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ( this is ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å X. 92); ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‘‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§≤‡•Ä‡§´‡•á‡§®‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§π‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø!‡§™‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡••’ (this is ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å III. 19.); ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‘‡§Ö‡§ß‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ñ‡§∞‡§É ‡•• ‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç ‡••’ ( this cannot be traced in the extant Manusmrti); ‡§á‡§π ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§≠‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§†‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• This is followed by several verses citing instances of ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†, ‡§ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶ and otherho, though born of women of low olass, became sages.   1. The Manusmrti

331

120.861 But as the verse occurs also in the Anu≈°ƒÅsana (104. 64-65 ) no chronological conclusion can be drawn therefrom. The PratimƒÅnƒÅtaka (after V. S.) speaks of Manaviyadharma b√§stra’ and Pracetasa-srƒÅddhakalpa’ but as it is in con troversy whether that work can be ascribed to the ancient Bh√£sa this reference will serve no useful purpose.

The next question is whether the Manusmrti contains earlier and later strata. There can be no doubt on this point. On numerous points the Manusmrti contains conflicting doctrines. In Manu III. 12-13 a BrƒÅhmana is allowed to have a s≈´dra woman as wife, while in III. 14-19 it is emphati cally asserted that a s≈´dra woman cannot be the wife of a brƒÅhmana and heavy disabilities are prescribed for him who breaks the injunction. In III. 23-26 there are contradictory statements about the appropriate forms of marriage for the several castes. In one breath Manu seems to permit niyoga (‘9. 59-63 ) and immediately afterwards he strongly reproba tes it (9. 64-69). The lengthy discussion on flesh-eating in Manu V. 27–56 discloses different mentalities. At several places the work seems even to recommend flesh-eating in sacri fices, ≈õrviddhas and madhuparku (V. 31-32, 35, 39, 41 ), while elsewhere it recommends total abstinence from meat on all occasions whatever ( V. 48-50). In one sloka ( Manu II. 145) the father is said to be equal to a hundred ƒÅcƒÅryas, while in the next verse the ƒÅcƒÅrya is said to be superior to the father. In V. 1 Bhrgu is said to have sprung from fire, while in I. 35 he is said to be one of the ten sons of Manu SvƒÅyambhuva. Vide also IX. 32-56.

B√ºhler devotes considerable space to this question (S. B. E. vol. 25. pp. LXVI-LXXIII). He arrives at the conclusion that the cosmological and philosophical portions in the first and 12th books, the philosophical disquisition in II. 89-100, the classifications of pitarah in III. 193-201, the means of sub sistence for BrƒÉbmana in IV. 1-24, verses 1-4 of the fifth book. the rule about mixed castes (X. 1-7 ) and the duties of castes that are repeated in X. 101-131 were put in when the work was versified from the M√§navadharmasutra. Though

351 ‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ [‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®

Farma Tac | HET4164 vol. III. p. 58. This verse occurs also imbo salita ( 38, 1).

FOUNDED

1917332

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

one may not agree with all the details of B√ºhler’s examina tion and with his theory about the versification of the MƒÅnava. dharmas√∫tra, it may be admitted that most of the passages pointed out by him have rather the flavour of comparative modernity about them. My own position is that the original Manusmrti in verse had certain additions made in order to bring it in a line with the change in the general attitude of people on several points such as those of flesh-eating, niyoga &c. But all these additions must have been made long before the 3rd century A. D. as the quotations from Brhaspati and others show.

In this connection it is pertinent to note that the text of the Manusmrti has been the saine with very few exceptions at least from the 6th century onwards (as the quotations in the TantravƒÅrtika and in the SƒÉrikara bh√¢sya on the VedƒÅntas≈´tra and as the commentaries of MedhƒÅtithi and others show ), while the text of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata differs greatly in the diffe rent editions published in our country.

To cite a few examples; SankarƒÅcƒÅrya on V. S. I. 2. 19 quotes the latter half of Manu I. 5, on V. S. I. 3. 28 refers to Manu I. 21 in slightly different words, on V. S. IV. 2. 6 quotes Manu I. 28 (anvyo’ &c.), on V. S. I. 3. 36 refers to Manu X. 4 ( about S√ºdra) and quotes the first half of Manu X. 126; on V. S. II. 1. I quotes the whole of Manu XII. 91 and on V. S. II. 1. 11 he quotes Manu XII. 105-6. From this it is clear that he had before him the extant Manusmrti (from its first to the last chapter ) and treated it as an authoritative Sm·ªôti. Similarly, KumƒÅrila ( who, according to the present author, wrote his TantravƒÅrtika between 650-700 A. D. (as shown on pp. 1191, 1198 and notes 1946 and 1952 of H. of Dh. Vol. V.) quotes many verses of Manu ( sometimes as M√§navam ).

The TantravƒÅrtika stands in a special relation to the Manusmrti. Whenever the author speaks of Sm·ªôtis, that of Manu is the first to come to his mind and KumƒÅrila refers to him even before the Gautamadharmas≈´tra. A few examples may be cited. After finishing the discourse on the importance of Veda (consisting of Vidhis, ArthavƒÅdas, Mantras and nƒÅmadheyas ), KumƒÅrila starts his discourse on the Stortis and mentions Manu as the representative of or foremost maong Smrtis. On p. 105 he quotes Manu II. 6-7, though he emphy

POONA

FOUNDED

1917

  1. The Manusmrti

333

the plural.smart≈ôbhi·∏•’i. e. smrtikƒÅrai·∏•). On the question of the duration of the stage of student-hood ( brahmacarya) for various periods, he first quotes Manu (III. 2) and then Gau tama Dh. S. II. 51-52 (on p. 192). The TantravƒÅrtika states that authors of Sm·ªôtis are generally prepared to accept as authoritative the usages of countries, castes and families, that are not opposed to the Vedas and first quotes Manu II. 6 and then Gaut. Dh. S. XI. 20.

Another problem is whether the Manusmrti has under gone several recasts. This does not seem likely and the evi. dence adduced in support of the theory that the Mauusmrti suffered several recasts is quite inadequate for the purpose. The occurrence of several conflicting passages can as well be explained on the theory of a single recast and it has also to be borne in mind, as B√ºbler points out, that Sanskrit writers down to the most recent times are in the habit of placing side by side conflicting opinions without actually preferring a particular view to others. The tradition of the Naradasmrti that the sƒÅstra of Manu was successively abridged by NƒÅrada, M√§rkandeya and Sumati BhƒÅryava is, as has been observed above, not worth much, since it is merely intended to glorify NƒÅrada’s work. The other traditions given above either ignore NƒÅrada altogether or assign him a secondary position. The present Manusm·ªôti is put into the mouth of Bh·ªâgu. NƒÅrada’s sm·ªôti is clearly based upon Manu, though the former diverges from the latter on many points. B»ôhaspati generally takes Manu as his text and amplifies the dicta of the Manusmrti (as the verses quoted above in notes 345-348 show ) and so his work may by analogy be regarded as a VƒÅrtika on Manu, as Dr. Jolly puts it. Angiras also looks upon Manusmrti as most authoritative. It is therefore that the PaurƒÅnic account ( note 321 above ) regards Bhrgu and other works as the redactions of the original Manusm≈üti. The quotations cited from V·ªäddha-Manu and Brhan-Manu do not establish that the original Manusmrti underwent many recasts. Quotations cited under these names are later than the Manusmrti. Vi≈°var≈´pa (on YƒÅj. I. 69 ) quotes the views of V·ªäddha-Manu on niyoga, who allows it only to s≈´dral. The MitƒÅk≈üarƒ´ quotes a verse from Vrddha-Manu about the widow of a sonless man being entitled to all her husband’

.

334

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

wealth while Manu is silent on that point.369 The Mit. on Yaj. II. 135-136 and Madhava (in ParƒÅsuramadhaviya ) quote a verse and a half from Brhan-Manu, which are expansions of Manu (V. 60 ).353 The fact that many quotations ascribed to Manu in several works are not found in the extant Manu smrti is explicable in several ways and not only by the theory of several recasts. For one thing the authors quoting from memory may be found tripping. For example, in an inscrip tion of the Badami CƒÅlukyas of the 7th century two verses that occur in most grants of lands are ascribed to Manu, but are not found in the extant Manusm»ôti.354 No one can for a moment doubt that the extant Manusmrti was an authorita tive work in the 7th century. Therefore, there is hardly any reliable evidence to support the theory that the Mauusmrti suffered several recasts.

Turning now to the internal evidence, the extant Manu smrti seems to be much older than YƒÅj√±avalkya, since the rules of judicial procedure are incomplete and awkward in Manu as compared with YƒÅj., since there is no reference to documents as evidence in Manu, as ordeals are not treated of in Manu, as legal definitions are almost absent in Manu, while frequent in YƒÅj. and as Manu is silent about the widow’s rights, while YƒÅj. gives her the first place among the heirs of a sonless man. So the Manusm·ªôti will have to be placed some centuries earlier than the third century A. D., the latest date to which the YƒÅj≈àavalkya sm»ôti can be assigned with any show of reason. In X. 44 Manu mentions the Yavanas, KƒÅmbojas, Sakas, Pahlavas and Cinag365 and in X. 48 Medas

aufwar. on ITF. II. 135. 353 ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡§æ-‡§∏‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡§ï‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å

  1. The Manusmrti

335

and Andhras. This shows that the extant Manusmrti could not be much earlier than the 3rd century B. C. The Yona, Kamboja and GƒÅndhƒÅra people are mentioned in the 5th rock edict of Asoka. Manu forbids BrƒÅhma·πáas to dwell in the kingdom of a ≈õ√ºdra ( IV. 61 ) and condemns the appointment of a s≈´dra as a judge ( VIII. 20-21 ). The late Mr. Jayaswal in his work ‘Manu and YƒÅj√±avalkya’ p. 32 refers to Manu smrti XII. 100350 (among other matters) which states ‘a person who knows the science of the Veda deserves the post of the commander-in-chief, the kingdom itself, the leadership in Government and the overlordship of all the world’. He thinks that this is a sample of the aggressive brƒÅhmana spirit that aroge when Pusyamitra Sunga became king. Pu»ôyamitra was a SevƒÅpati before he became king. Mr. Jayaswal cites other examples of this spirit (such as Manu VIII. 20 which states that even a brƒÅhmana in name only who maintains himself out of the superiority of his caste may be a judge but a s≈´dra never.’ This was nothing new. Centuries before the extant Manusmrti, the Tai. S. ( I. 7.3. 1 ) states that BrƒÅbmanas are gods that are directly seen. Gaut. VIII. 1 placed the learned brƒÅhmana on the same level as the king. The extant Manu smrti in its arrangement and doctrines is much in advance of the ancient dharmas≈´tras such as those of Gautama, BaudhƒÅ yana and Apastamba. Taking all these things into considera tion B√ºhler ( S B E vol. 25 p. CXVII ) was certainly right in saying that the extant Manusmrti was composed between the second century B. C and 2nd century A. D. But the question of the date when the original Manusmrti to which additions were made between the 2nd century B. C. and 2nd century A. D. was composed presents very great difficulties. That question is largely bound up with the relation of the Maha bhƒÉrata to the Manusmrti.

This question is an extremely intricate one. The late V. N. Mandlik ( Intro. to the VyavabƒÅramayukha XLVII ) held that the Manusmrti borrowed from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. B√ºhler after an elaborate examination of the question (SBE vol. 25, pp. LXXIV-XCVIII) came to the conclusion that it was indisputable that the 12th and 13th parvans of the MahƒÅ, bhƒÅrata knew a MƒÅnavadharma≈õƒÅstra which was closely.

858 ‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡•§

HIGH·ªÜ XII, 100. ; B. . L 7.3 v√† 4 : 44 4G HI·ªÜUII: 1L

836

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

connected with but not identical with the present Manusmrti. B√ºhler expresses himself very cautiously and it seems to me that the great scholar was unduly prepossessed in favour of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata as against the Manusmrti. B√ºhler some what contradicts himself when he says that the author of the epic only knew the dharmas≈´tras (SBE vol. 25, p. XCVIII). Hopkins ( Great Epic of India p. 21-22 ) seems inclined to hold that the 13th book which alone, according to him, reco gnises the sƒÅstra declared by Manu, knew the present Manu smrti, though the earlier books cannot be held to have known a sƒÅstra of Manu even when they employ such expressions as ‚ÄúManu said.” He thinks that there was a floating mass of verses containing philosophical and other lore attributed to the mythical Manu on which the earlier books of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and the Manusmrti both drew and that the matter that is common to both works was not borrowed from any systematic treatise. B√ºhler accepts this view with the slight modification that the floating mass of verses was not all attributed to Manu ( S B E vol. 25 p. XC). Before giving my individual views on this vexed question as against the array of such eminent scholars as B√ºhler and Hopkins some facts must be clearly set forth. The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata is nowhere men tioned by name in the Manusmrti, though the word “itihƒÅsa” (in the plural ) occurs in Manu (III. 232 ). The Manusmrti mentions many historical and legendary personages, about most of whom the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata contains similar stories. The following are the persons so mentioned in the Manus Angirasa (in II. 151‚Äì152, addressing his elders as ‘putrakƒÅ·∏•’); Agastya (V. 22, in connection with sacrificing animals); Vena, Nahusa, SudƒÅs Paijavana and Nimi (all in VII. 41 ); coming to grief through insolence ); P»ôthu, Manu, Kubera and the son of GƒÅdhi (VII. 42), benefiting by their good conduct ); Vasistha (in VIII. 110, taking an oath before king Paijavana ), Vatsa (in VIII. 116, undergoing fire ordeal ); Ak≈üamƒÅlƒÅ and SƒÅrangi (in IX. 23, though of low birth, respectively were united to Vasistha and MandapƒÅla ); Daksa (in IX. 128-129 ) gave his daughters to Dharma, KƒÅ≈õyapa and Soma ); Ajigarta (in X, 105, who was ready to sacrifice his own son ); VƒÅmadeva (in X, 106, desired dog’s flesh to save his life ); BharadvƒÅja (in X. 107, who accepted the gift of mans cows ); Vi≈õvƒÅmitra (in X. 108, who took from a CandƒÅla’s hand a dog’s tes P»ôthu is also mentioned (in IX. 44 ) as the husband of the earth and in IX. 314 BrƒÅhmanas are credited with HD rips

  1. The Manusmrti

337

made fire all-devourer, the ocean undrinkable and the waning (phthisical) moon to wax. Most of the names mentioned here go far back into Vedic antiquities. For example, Vasistha’s oath occurs in Rgveda (VII. 104. 15367) and the B»ôhaddevatƒÉ (VI. 32-34 ), Ajigarta figures in the Aitareya brƒÅhmana (VII. 16 ) and Angirasa’s story occurs in the Tandyamaha brƒÅhmana ( 13. 3. 24 ). Besides, the Manusmrti does not say that the stories are taken from the great epic. The MahƒÅ bhƒÅrata also was not the first to originate these stories but is only a storehouse and encyclopaedia of the numerous popular traditions that were current in ancient India. When our Manu ( 9. 227 ) says that gambling was seen to have produced in former ages deep-rooted enmities, it is unnecessary to suppose that there is a reference to the MahƒÅbh√§rata, for, from Vedic times the evil effects of gambling were known ( vide Rgveda X. 34 ) and even the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata contains the same verse ( Udyoga 37. 19), though this fact was not noticed by B√ºhler. On the other hand, there are numerous passages in the Mahabharata scattered over almost all the poorvans, where occur such expressions as, ' Manur.abravid, ‘the rƒÅjadharmas of Manu’, ‘the ≈õƒÅstra of Manu’ etc. Some of these passages agree with the extant Manusmrti, while some do not. Besides, there are hundreds of verses in the Mahabharata that are identical with the verses of the Manusmrti, though they are not expressly attributed to Manu. Dr. B√ºhler says that in the Vana, S√§nti and Anusasana parviens alone he could identify either wholly or partly 260 verses with those of our Manu. What then is the conclusion ? Prima facie it should be, on account of all these abovementioned facts, against the MahƒÉ bhƒÅrata and in favour of the Manusmrti being the earlier of the two. Hopkins at all events holds that the Avu≈°ƒÅsana parva knew a Manusmrti essentially the same as we have now. B√ºhler expresses himself more cautiously and says that the Santi and AnusƒÅsana parvane knew a MƒÅnava-dharma≈õƒÅstra closely connected with the extant one, though not identical. Both are agreed that the earlier books when they speak of Menu are either referring to the MƒÅnava-dharmas≈´tra or 16 the flouting mass of popular verses, but not to our Manu.

___ We must now closely examine the data. The AnusƒÅsana parva distinctly speaks of ‘a sistra declared by Manu’.358 In the S√§ntiparva are quoted two ≈õlokas sung by Manu in his own dharmas,’ one of which is identical with Manu369 (9. 321 ). In another place the S√§ntiparva speaks of the ‘rƒÅjadharmas of Pracetasa Manu ‘and quotes two verses therefrom.360 In the Dronaparva (7.1) MƒÅnari arthavidyƒÅ’ is referred to and in Vanaparva the rƒÅjadharmas as proclaimed by Manu are referred to ( Vanaparva 35. 2. 21 ). In other places, the words Manu SvƒÅyambhuva said’ occur (e. g. Santi 21. 12, Anushsana 114. 12, Vanaparva 180. 34-35, Adiparva 73. 9, 110. 32-36, Udyoga 37. 1-6). In most cases the words ‘Manu said‚Äôoccur without the appellation

‚Ä¢ Svayambhuva’ or ‘PrƒÅcetasa’ (e. g. Santi 78. 31, 88. 14-16, 121. 10-12, 152. 14, 152. 30, 266.5; Anusisana 44. 18 and 23, 65. 1 and 3, 67. 19, 68. 31, 88. 4, 115.52-53 ; Vanaparva 32. 39, Udyogaparva 40. 9-10, Adiparva 41. 31, 74. 39 ). The words
