‡§∑‡§°‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§ú‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§∏‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. 57. 43-45. ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§Æ‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å. 61. 34-35. Here ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ is supposed to address ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§∞. Compare ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø 8.18 ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§Æ‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§¶‡§É ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ã‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å. 20. 14 and ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•å‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡•• ‡§≠‡§®‡•Å. 20. 21. ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å 9. 3 is almost the same.

  1. The Manusmrti

339

subjects are not guarded by the king, he shares in the 4th part of whatever sins they commit. Then some say that the whole sin is the king’s,' while again some say he certainly shares in balf of them (the sins ); but on hearing the ordinance of Manu our view is that he shares in the 4th part of the sing. Here the author of the Anu≈°ƒÅsana expressly says that he puts forward his own opinion after hearing Manu’s ordinance. There is no doubt that the AnusƒÅsana parva clearly refers in several places to the extant Manusmrti. In Anu. 19. 88-89 reference is made to those who know Dharma≈õƒÅstras about adultery. In Anu. 45. 17-20 reference is made to the GathƒÅs declared by Yama and set down in Dharma≈õƒÅstras and one verse ¬∑ Arse gomithunam ‘is nentioned there, which is the game as Manu III. 53. In Anu. 20. 14 it is said that it is the view of Prajapati that women do not deserve independence and 20. 21 is almost the same as extant Manu 9. 3. Jayaswal arrives at this conclusion ( on p. 50 ): ‘the main date may be regarded to be circa 150 B. C., the final revision and the present form would have been fixed by 100-150 A. C., not later.’ He seizes upon the word ‘SenƒÅpatya’ in Manu XII. 100. The word was placed first for preserving the regularity of the Sloka metre (in which the 5th letter in each pƒÅdu is required to be short ) as the wording Rajye ca Senapatye ca’ would have the fifth letter long. Further, Manu had already stated in several places the greatness and worth of brƒÅhmanas e. g. Manu in I. 93 says “BrƒÅhmana is the lord of this whole creation, because be sprang from the mouth of the Creator as stuted in Rg. X. 90. 12), as he is the senior (among the four varnas ), as he preserves the Veda (by memorizing it) and since he propounds Dharma'. Vide also 1. 99-101 (which

( Continued from the previous page) ‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡•ä‡§£‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•à‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§É ger: ll slutet 7.6. ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§™‡§ö‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞ Brent are 79: 1 HE VIII, 169; JEG 9 Jangat arqfACT ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§ 67. 44-46, J≈´TT 33. 79-80 ; 34miteter TFUHT418 atat qa4a 35, 21.

11211

340

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

occur also in Santi 72. 6, 10,11 first half ), also Manu VIII. 37, IX. 317, 319, X. 3. Further, there was the tradition of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata war that after Bhƒ´≈üma was mortally wounded, Drona, a brƒÅhmana teacher, was made commander-in-chief of the Kaurava army. The Drona parva expressly refers to the ceremony of abhiselca in the case of Drona as commander-in chief. Although, the Ap. Dh. S. (I. 10. 29. 7) states that a brƒÅhmana should not take in his hand a weapon even for test ing it, that was an extreme view ; other Dharmas≈´tras (like Gautama VII.25, Baud. II.2.80, Vasistha III. 24 ) allowed a brƒÅhmana to use arms in danger to life, for protecting cows and brƒÅhmanas &c. We learn from PƒÅnini (V. 2. 71 ) that there were before his time brƒÅhmanas as professional soldiers and he teaches that the word “brƒÅhmanaka' means a country in which brƒÅhmanas follow the profession of arms. Kautilya (in A. IX. 2. 21-24 ) refers to armies of BrƒÅhmanas, Ksatriyas, Vaisyas and S≈´dras. Therefore, Jayaswal’s remarks on Manu XII. 100 are worthless for settling the date of the Manusmrti. Jayaswal’s ‘Manu and YƒÅjsavalkya’ is full of information, but it is sometimes marred by specious assumptions about ancient times for which there is hardly any solid basis. It would be impossible to deal with many such matters here for want of space. One matter, however, may be briefly men tioned here. Ou p. 288 of that work he propounds the somewhat startling proposition that Manu VIII. 169 shows that professional lawyers were already in existence in the time of the MƒÅuava Code'. The verse is quoted below. It literally means ‘three persons have to undergo trouble (in litigation ) for others viz. witnesses, sureties, kula (family members ); while four persons prosper or benefit (in litiga tion ) viz. the brƒÅbmana, the rich (i.e. the creditor who supplies money to the litigants ), the trader and the king. No word in this verse can mean a lawyer by itself. Vipra ordinarily means brƒÅhma·πáa. Gaut. Dh. S. 13. 26, Manu VIII. 9 and YƒÅj. 11.3 expressly provide that when the king cannot himself look into the causes of his subjects, he may appoint as judge & brƒÅhma·πáa learned in the Dharma≈õƒÅstra, along with sabhyas. The Mit. quotes Katyayana to the effect that if a brƒÅhma·πáa learned in the Dharma≈õƒÅstras cannot be found then & Ksat. riya or Vaisya learned in Dharma≈õƒÅstras may be appointeca So the general rule was that a brƒÅhmana was to be the presiding judge. He benefitted by litigation in the sense that he was paid his salury whatever the result of the litigation

  1. The Manusmrti

341

might be. The king benefitted by the receipt of the fines paid by the losing parties in litigations. The commentators do not say a word about a class of lawyers helping litigants for fees. Sarvaj√±a NƒÅrƒÅyana and Ramacandra paraphrase “vipra’ as pr√°dvivƒÅku; Kull≈´ka und GovindarƒÅja simply paraphrase ‘vipra’ as brƒÅhmana. MedhƒÅtithi’s' text as printed is not clear, yet he commented that this verse has to be connected with the preceding verse that condemns the use of force and that’vipru' should not be forced to accept a gift. So it is clear, that Manu and his commentators do not speak of a pro. fession of lawyers at all. Jayaswal refers to the Burmese code as giving a scale of fees (p. 288 n. 3). That may have been the law in ancient Burma and the Burmese might have grafted it on Manu, when they adopted Manu. He should have inentioned, if he wanted to place the matter on a sound footing, a Sanskrit Smrti setting out a scale of fees for law. yers. Hopkins says that the words ‘the sƒÅstra of Manu’ occur only in the Anusasana-parva and so only that parvan knew the Manusm»ôti, while in the other parvuna we have the expression ¬∑ Manu said,' and therefore these other books did not know the Manusmrti but are only referring to floating verses attributed to the mythical Manu. This, however, is not a reasonable conclusion. The words ‘shstra of Manu’ occur only once even in the Anus≈´sana while in about ten places in the same parvien we come across only the words ‘Manu said.’ If the words ¬∑ Manu said' in the Anusagana indicate in the Anus√£oana a reference to the extant Manusmrti, there is no cogent reason why the same words in other parvans should not be regarded as referring to the Manusinfti. Besides, in the SƒÉntiparva also we meet with the words ‘Dharmar or raja. dharmas of Manu’ and in Adiparva the word ‘dharma-darsane’ ( 120. 32 ). There are some important references to PrƒÅcetasa Manu in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata, though in the Manusmrti no text or view is ascribed to him. The SƒÅntiparva (in chap. 58. 1-3 ) names seven propounders of Rajadharma viz. Brhagpati, Vis√•lƒÅksa, K√§vya (Usanas ), SahasrƒÅksa, Mahendra, Pr√°cetasa Manu, Bh√§radv√§ja and Gaura≈õiras, all of whom speak highly of protection (of subjects ) as, the (one) Dharma for kings. The great epic quotes the views of Pracetasa Manu in Santi ( 57.44-45 ) that Pr√°cetas Manu set forth two verses in his work on Rajadharmas.) A reference to Pracetasn’s dictumn in Anusisana 46. 1-2 to the842

History of Dharma≈õ√°stra

effect that what the relations of a girl receive from the bride groom’s side is not a sale but that it is really meant as honour to the girl and as to be paid over to the girl. This is almost the same as Manu III. 54. In Vana parva 35. 21 we have the words . you have heard the RƒÅjadharmas that were declared by Manu.' This Manu must be PrƒÅcetasa since in Santi 58. 1-3 PrƒÅcetasa Manu is said to have been one of the expounders of R≈´ja≈õƒÅstra.

A remarkable reference to Vi≈õƒÅlƒÅksƒÖ as a writer on Niti (RƒÅjanƒ´ti) is found in an inscription from Cambodia (No. 64 in ‘Inscriptions of Kambuja’ edited by Dr. R. C. Majumdar ) in praise of Yasovarman, king of Kambuja, about 889 A. D. in a highly paronomastic verse.368 That is obviously a reference to some work of Manu. Hopkins further says ( Great Epic of India, p. 21 ) that all the express citations of Manu in the Anu≈°ƒÅsana except one agree very closely with our Manu, while in the other parruns the citations agree only up to one-third or one-half. In the first place I demur to the latter statement. The agreements of the citations in the other books are as close and almost as frequent as in the Anu≈°ƒÅsana, e. g. excepting SƒÅnti 21. 12 and 57. 43-45 all citations of Manu therein, referred to above, agree closely with Manu 7. 89, 9. 225-26, 9. 17-19 and 27, 6. 33 and 81, 11. 259-60, 5. 43 and 45 and 48-49. The same is the case with the few citations of Manu in the Vanaparva. B√ºhler says that the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata knew only of the dharmas≈´tras. But there is positively uot one express citation attributed by nane to the well-known writers of dharmasutras, such as Gautanna, BaudhƒÅyana, Apastamba, Vasistha or Sarkha-Likbita. That the Mahabharata knew several dharmaƒ£istras is clear from over a dozen references to dharmasastras, often in the plural (e. g. SƒÅnti 167. 4, 298. 40, 341. 74; Anu≈°ƒÅsana 19. 89, 45. 17-20; Vanaparva 207. 83, 293. 35, 313. 105; Adiparva 3. 32 and 77 etc.) The only place where a s≈´trakƒÅra is cited on matters of dhurma is Anu. 19.6; but no name is mentioned. 388 382 ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§¢‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É ‡§∂‡§∞‡•ã

  1. The Manusmrti

343

Hastis√∫tra, and Asvas≈´tra are mentioned in Sabh≈´ 5. 20, but no Dharmas≈´tra or Nitis≈´tra occurs anywhere. On the other hand B√ºhler is not prepared to admit that the views expressly attributed to Manu in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata are taken from a treatise and refers them to a floating mass of verses the authorship of which was unknown and was fathered upon the mythical Mapu. Distrust of ancient Indian authors could gono further. A volume would have to be written to expose the mis takes, underlying the assumptions and fallacies in the writings of Hopkins, B√ºhler and soine other Western scholars. The former collects two groups of passages from the Manusmrti; group A containing 9 passages, 8 of which he admits to be ancient and holds Manu VI. 54 ( uhout YatipƒÅtras including ‘alƒÅbu’) to be doubtful and group B with 13 passages ( 3 he holds ancient, 5 doubtful and 5 others suspicious ). It is impossible to agree with Hopkins in many cases which he treats as doubtful. For example, he cites Manu VIII. 59 as contradictiny VIII. 139 and therefore be suspects that VIII. 139 is not genuine Manu. It has been shown above that Manu makes contradictory statements on some matters such es the practice of niyoga and the validity of the marriage of & brƒÅhmana with a s≈´dra woman. Besides, the apparent con tradiction is easily resolved, if we hold that VIII. 59 lays down a general rule for fines and VIII. 139 contains grecial rules about debts only viz. if the defendant admits in court his indebtedness but has not paid the debt, then the fine for him is five panas for each hundred of debt, but if he denies the debt he should be fined ten panas for each hundred of debt (proved ). Besides, Hopkins has inisunderstood words like Manur-abravit or-ƒÅla. Those words have not a single meaning, but are capable of several explanations; firstly, a quotation may be meant; secondly, ouly the gist of Manu’s words ( but not his exact words ) may be intended; thirdly, the quotation may be only what the writer remembers of the original text of Manu and fourthly, he may think that what he states is the proper rule and enhances its authority by escribing it to Manu. B√ºhler’s assumptions are, to say the

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

least, gratuitous and are prompted by his unwillingness to assign an early date to a versified smrti of Manu. Not only are there identical verses in Manu and the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata, but some verses of the latter (e. g. Udyoga 35. 31 and S√§nti 111. 66 ) occur in the NƒÅradasmrti (pp. 103 and 26 respecti vely ). In my humble opinion the following seems to be the relation of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and the Manusmrti. I must state frankly that it is a mere theory, a conjecture which may be taken for what it is worth. Long before the 4th century B. C., there was a work on Dharma≈õƒÅstra composed by or attributed to SvƒÅyambhuva Manu. This work was most probably in verse. There was also another work on Raja dharma attributed to PrƒÅcetasa Manu, which also was prior to the 4th century B. C. It is not unlikely that instead of there being two works there was one comprehensive work embody ing rules on dharma as well as on politics. There is one circumstance that points in this direction. The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata quotes a saying (vacana ) of Pracetasa which is almost the same as our Manu 364 ( 3. 54 ). It is to these ( works or work) that YƒÅska, Gautama, BaudhƒÅyana, and Kautilya refer whenever they cite the opinions of Manu or the MƒÅnavas. The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata also (particularly in the earlier portions ) probably refers to the same. This work was the original kernel of the present Manusmrti. Then between 2nd century

B. C. and 2nd century A. D. the Manusmrti was finally recast probably by Bhrgu That work must have compressed the older works in some cases and expanded it in others. This

hypothesis would explain why some of the verses and views quoted as Manu’s occur in the extant Manusmrti and why some do not.365 In my opinion the extant MahƒÅbhƒÅrata is later than the extant Manusmrti. When N√§rada mentions the tradition that Sumati BhƒÅrgava coinpressed the vest work of Manu into 4000 verses, he is somewhat obscurely hinting at the truth. The extant Manusmrti contains only about 2700 verses. Narada probably arrives at the larger figure by including the verses attributed to V»õddha-Manu and Brhan-Manu. If Vrddha-Manu was a separate work it must have been composed before at least the 7th century A. D. at the latest. Visvar≈´pa on YƒÅj. I. 69 (p. 75, Trivandrum ed. of 1922 ) quotes two verses on niyoga. The Mit. on YƒÅj. II. 270 (first half) and 272, III, 5, 20 (latter half), 260 quotes a few verses of Vrddha-Manu, while Apararka quotes him twenty times and on p. 908 quotes Manu II. 67 and immediately afterwards quotes a verse of V»ôddha-Manu. Kalpataru on Vya. quotes Vrddha-Manu eight times, but in one case (on p. 402) one half of the verse is the same as Manu VIII. 157 (first hall). The Sm»ôticandrikƒÅ quotes Vrddha-Manu verses 23 times on ƒÅcƒÅra, 6 times on VyavahƒÅra and 12 times on SrƒÅddha.

Brhan-Manu is cited by the MitƒÅksarƒÉ only a few times i.e. on YƒÄj. II.135-36 (11 verses on limits of sapinda and tamƒÅnodaka relationship ), on Y√Éj. III. 20 (latter half) two verses on ƒÅ≈õauca. AparƒÅrka cites Brhau-Manu only once (on p. 910 ) on Asauca. The influence of the Manusmrti spread even beyond the confines of India. In A. with Manu (II. 136 ) and the other is a summary of Madu (III. 77-80). The Burmese are governed in modern times by the chanmathat, which are based on Manu. Vide Dr. For chhammer’s essay on the sources and development of Burmese Law (1885, Rangoon). Dr. E. C. G. Jonker ( Leyden 1885) wrote a dissertation on an old Javanese law book compared with Indian sources of law like the Manusmrti ( which is still used as a law book in the island of Bali).

Vide the paper of Louis Finot in I. H. Q. Vol. I (1925) pp. 599-622 on Hindu Kingdoms in Indo-China' (who re marks that India has laid her mark on all the great Far Eastern countries, some of them received from her a substan tial part of their religious and artistic culture and others are indebted to her for their very existence as civilized, Indo Chipa being the foremost among the latter ). Vide an article by R. Lingat in A. B. 0. R. I. Vol. XXX, pp. 284-297 on * Buddhist Manu or the propagation of Hindu Law in HinayƒÅnist Indo-China' and Dr. R. C. Majumdar in S. Krishnaswamy Aiyangar Presentation Volume pp. 445-461 on ‘Hindu Law in Java and Bali ‘.

Manu had numerous commentators. As to MedhƒÉtithi GovindarƒÅja and Kull≈´ka, vide below sections 63, 76, 88. (1st ed.). Besides these, NƒÅrƒÅyana, RaghavƒÅnanda, Nandana and RƒÅmacandra also wrote commentaries on Manu. Mr. Mandlik published all these commentaries. Dr. Jolly publish ed ( in 1885 for the Bengal Asiatic Society ) extracts from all these commentaries (except Kull≈´ka’s and Ramacandra’s ) and from an anonymous Kashmirian commentary on the first three chapters. AsahƒÅya seems to have written a commentary on Manu (vide below section on him). The VivƒÅdaratnƒÅkara quotes a commentary on Manu by Udayakara ( pp. 455, 560, 583, 590). The same work seems to sugyest that Bhaguri wrota a commentary on Manu.367 For the predecessors of Medha

3.1. The Manusmrti

tithi, vide sec. on him. Kulltika on Manu 8. 184 tells us that Bhojadeva. arranged the four verses of Manu 8. 181-184 in a particular manner and therefore suggests that Bhojadeva probably commented on Mapu. He also names a commen tator Dharanidhara on Mamu 2.83 and says that he was later than Medhatithi. He is also referred to elsewhere by Kull≈´ka ( on Manu 4.50 ).

The commentator NƒÅrƒÅyana is certainly earlier than 1550 A. D. as his commentary is cited by Bhattoji in his commen tary on the Caturvimsutimata (vide p. 61 of the Benares Sans krit Series edition, 1907). A ins. of Narayana’s commentary was written in 1497 A. D. and he appears to have been quoted by Riyamukuta in 1431 A.D. (Jolly in R. und. S. p. 31 ). He cites the explanation of Govindaraja on Manu VIII. 123. He appears to have composed a work called KamadhenudipikƒÅ in which he dealt exhaustively with the prƒÅyascittas for various sins (as said on Mauu XI. 71 ) and on the topic of flesh-eating at some length (as stated on Manu V. 56 ). He also wrote e work called Suddhidipika in which he wrote at some length on ƒÄsauca ( as stated on Manu V. 79 and 104 ) and on the

Bhandar

348

History of Dharmasastra

prƒÅya≈õcittas for MahƒÅpƒÅtakas (as stated on Manu XI. 209). He also refers to a MƒÅlƒÅkƒÅra (probably the author of a lexi con ) on Manu V. 81. He does not comment on some verses such 48 on Manu III. 174 and 278 (Mandlik’s ed.). He is generally brief in his comments but he has longer notes than MedhƒÅtithi or Kull≈´ka on Manu V. 16, 31, 56, VI. 34-35, 67, X. 42, XI. 130. He is later than GovindarƒÅja and Aouri shed betweon 1100 and 1300 A. D. Raghavananda men tions by name Medhatithi, GovindarƒÅja, NƒÅrƒÅyana, and Kull≈´ka and so is later than about 1400 A. D. When Nandana flourished it is difficult to say. But he is a late writer. There are several other commentators mentioned in the catalogues of mss. who may be passed over for want of space.

The TantravƒÅrtika (p. 159) after dealing with the use fulness of the Veda ( which is constituted by Vidhi, ArthavƒÅda, Mantra and NƒÅmadheya ) for understanding what Dharma is, comes to the consideration of Smrtis such as those of Manu and others that have human authors. It further quotes the words Vedoskhilo Dharmam≈´lam’ (Manu 2. 6 and 7 ) and concludes from the words of these passages that the Smart≈ôs (i. e. SmrtikƒÅras ) have bound themselves by stating that Veda is the source of Dharma. The Tantra vƒÅrtika further says that the Smrtik√°ras ( v. 205 ) accept th.

ess of usages that are not opposed to the Ved. in such passages as are quoted above. Similarly, MƒÅnavam (i.e. Manusmrti) states in 12. 105, 106 that one who desires to find out the pure Dharma has to rely upon Prutyak≈üu and Anu mƒÅna, and that man really knows Veda who makes use of logic in interpreting Veda. The TantravƒÅrtika (p. 191 ) further quotes a passage as of Manu which does not occur in the present Manu but occurs in the MBH, Santiparva 140.38, which states that a man should first extricate himself from distress by any action, soft or hard, and then when he becomes able, should practise what Dharma requires. Similarly, Sabara on P. M. S. VI. 1. 12 quotes a verge as Smrti which is almost the same as the extant Manu (8. 416 ) and which is also similar to Udyogapurva, ch. 33.64. For further referepet to Manu, vide the present author’s paper in JBBRAS NEW Series, 1925 ) Vol. I pp. 98-102. In one or two caso it appears that KumƒÅrila had before hinn a text of Manu slightly

CE

FOUNDED

  1. The Manusmrti

349

different from the extant Manu. For example, on p. 191 he quotes & verse as Manu’s which does not occur in the extant Smrti.

The above discussion shows that the extant Manusmrti was practically the same long before the 7th century A. D.

It may be noted that SabaragvƒÅmin on PMS. VI. 1. 12 quotes a verse as Sm·ªôti which is practically the same as extant Manu VIII. 116. Sabara has to be placed between 200 and 400 A. D. (nearer the former date); vide H. of Dh. Vol. V. p. 1197. Hence the extant Manusmrti cannot be placed later than 2nd century A. D. Vide the present author’s paper on ‘Gleanings from Sabara and the Tantrav√§rtika’ in JBBRAS (old series ) Vol. 26 ( 1924 ) pp. 83-98.

Vi≈°var≈´pa ( on Yrij. I. 69 ), the MitƒÅk·π£arƒÅ, the Sm·ªôtica ndrikƒÅ, the ParƒÅ≈õarainadhaviya and other works quote dozens of verses from Vrddha–Manu on √ºhnika, vyavahƒÅra and prƒÅyuscittu. The Mit≈´ksarƒÉ (on YƒÅj. II. 135-6, III. 20 ), AparƒÅrka p. 910 and other works cite a few verses from Brhan Manu. No independent works going under these names have yet been unearthed. Those works, if they ever existed independently, appear to have been later than our Manu. For example, our Manu is silent about the widow’s right to inherit to her husband, but V·ªáddha-Manu recognises the right of a chaste widow to take the entire wealth of her husband (Mit. on Y√§j. II. 136); similarly, B»ôhan-Manu ( according to the Mit. ) seems to refer to Manu’s view about the meaning of ‘gamƒÅnodaka’ (Manu 5. 60 ) and modifies it. It is not unlikely that those verses which were not recognised 28 Manu’s by ancient commentators like Medhatithi and were yet found in the msg. of the Manusmrti were regarded as Vrddha-or Bphan-Manu.

  1. The Two Epics The two great Epics of India, the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa, contain ( particularly the first) numerous passa ges bearing on meny topics of Dharma≈õ√§stra and are relied upon as authorities in medieval and later works. The Mabu bhƒÅrata itself claims (in Adiparva, 2. 83) that VyDS composed the work as a great Dharma≈õƒÅstra, as Arthasastra ( treatise on politics and Government), Moksasistra and also

POONA

1917

350

History of Dharma≈õƒ´stra

KƒÅma≈õƒÅstra.868 In the last parvan it claims that whatever is said in it would be found elsewhere and what is not con tained in it would not be found anywhere else i.e. it claims to be encyclopoedic and hence there was a great incentive to later scholars to add to it fresh matter. In the Udyoga parva (130. 18 ) and in Adi, 62. 20 the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata is spoken of as Jaya (jayo n√°metih√§soyam ≈õrotavyo vijigƒ´sunƒÅ ) and in the last pwrvan ( 5.51 ) the epic is also called sumlitƒÉ (1. 16, 63. 90), Purina ( 1. 17), akhyina (2. 388-389 ), itihisa ( 1. 19 and 26 and 2.36, 41 and 62. 18), itihisottama (in 2.385), Kavya (1. 61 and 73, 2. 390 ), Karsnaveda ( 1. 268 and 62. 18). It further states ( Adi. 1. 52 ) that different beginnings of the epic existed. In the last parvan ( svargarohana ) it states that the epic is so called because of its greatness360 ( great extent) and the weightiness (of its contents ) and that the epic is equal (in importance ) to the 18 PurƒÅnas, all the Dharma ≈†ƒÅstras and the Vedas with their subsidiary lores (chap. 5 45-46 ). Adi (1.81) states 310 that there are 8800 ≈õlokus in the whole work, the import of which only Vy≈´su and Suka know and Sanjaya might know or not.371 It is further stated that

MASTIPUR

DONA

. 1917

  1. The Two Epics

351

BhƒÅrata means the epic without the upƒÅkhyƒÅnas ( tales ) and contaius 24000 verses and the work MahƒÅbh≈´rata consists of one hundred thousand verses inclusive of the upƒÅkhyƒÅnas ( Adi. 1.101-2). The Adiparva (63.89-90) states that VyƒÅsa 37a taught the four Vedas together with the MahƒÅbh≈´ruta as the fifth to four pupils viz. Sumantu, Jaimini, Paila, Vai≈°ampƒÅ. yana and to Suka his own son and these five promulyated separate five versions of the story. The S√§ntiparva (chap. 327. 26-33 and 349. 10-12 ) repeats the same story about the five pupils of VyƒÅsa. The extant Mahabharata is supposed to be the one that Vai≈°ampƒÅyana narrated to Janamejaya, son of Parik»ôit, the latter being the grand-son of Arjuna and son of Abhimanyu. It is said in Adi ( 1.9-10 ) that Sauti heard the story narrated to Janamejaya and told it to Saunaka and other sages. Thus there are (acc. to the epic itself) three stages, viz. (1) Vyasa first transmitted the epic to five pupils ; (2) these five including Vai≈õumpƒÅyana composed separate works and Vaisampayana narrated it to Janamejaya, and (3) Sakti who heard the recital by Vai≈°ampƒÅyana narra

( Continued from the previous page) examples of K≈´ta rergos in Appondix, Note III pp. 190.193. One of these may be quoted hore from the Ulyognparva ; okny√° dvo vini. scitya trin oaturbhir vnsam kuru i pnica jitvi :nd-viditvƒÅ snpta hitvƒÅ sukhi bhava 113 :44. For the last, compare MaitrƒÅyapi Upanisnd VI. 30 ( Ynda pancivatishanto j√±ƒÅnini inanusƒÉ suba Buddhi·∫øca na vioestate t√¢mƒÅhu·∏• paramim yutiin 11). ‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•à‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•à‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡§¶‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö ‡•• ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç WITHFT TARAT: 1 311 83. 89-90.

ted it to Saunaka and others. Therefore, the author for the extant MahƒÅbhƒÅrata is Sauti and VyƒÅsa is only connected with it mediately. In this respect it differs from the RƒÅmƒÅ yana, the author of which is Valmiki according to all. Janamejaya PƒÉriksita is a famous name in Indian Antiquity. In the Ait. Br. (VIII. 21 ) it is stated that Tura KƒÅvaseya performed the Aindra MahƒÅbhi≈üeka for Janamejaya P√§riksita, who conquered the whole earth and performed the Afvamedha sacrifice and there is recited a Yaj√±a-gƒÉthƒÅ with regard to te it. He is mentioned also in the Satapatha Br. XIII. 5.4.1). What became of the other SamhitƒÅs said to have been com posed by the other disciples of VyƒÅsa is not known.

In the daily tarpana as prescribed in the A√©valƒÅyana grbya-s≈´tra 374 (III. 4 ) we find an echo of what we learn from the Adiparva about the four pupils (excluding Suke ) of VyƒÅsa viz. Sumantu - Jaimini - Vai≈°ampƒÅyana - Paila - S≈´tra - bhƒÅsya - BhƒÅrata - MahƒÅbhƒÅrata - DharmƒÅcƒÅryas - trpyaptu. AsvalƒÅyana was probably aware of the difference made bet ween BhƒÅrata and MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. The ≈öƒÉnkhƒÅyanag·∫∑hya omits the words ' BhƒÅrata……DharmƒÅcƒÅryƒÅ·∏•'.

In the present edition (of the H. of Dh.) the ChitrasalƒÅ edition of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata with the commentary, BhƒÅrata bhƒÅvadƒ´pa of NilƒÅkantha Caturdhara, has been used. It generally agrees with the Bombay oblong edition ; sometimes, however, there is a difference of one adhyƒÅya or a sloka or two. The Bhandarkar 0. Institute’s edition is not referred to, be cause when I collected my materials it had been only recently begun and even now it is not yet complete, though nearing completion.* But, as that edition gives in the margin of each page, references to the text of three editions of the epic, it is easy to find out a passage from the text of that edition also.

Many difficult questions arise about the two epics ( which have come down to us in different recensions ), such as the origin and development of the two epics, the inter-relation of the two, the dates of the two epics; the strata, if any, in the two epics; the literature known to them, their versification ; their influence on the early and later Dharma≈õƒÅstra works ; their influence in comparatively early times on peoples beyond India. A great deal has been written on these topics by Western and Indian writers for over a century. Considerations of space make it impossible to enter upon the detailed discu ssion of the questions stated above. Yet a few remarks must, be made on some of the topics discussed by scholars. The following works and papers will give some idea of the prob lems connected with these two heirlooms of Indian antiquitaine " Zur Geschichte and Critik des MahƒÅbhƒÅrata " by Holtzmit (Kiel, 1892-94 );' Das RƒÅmƒÅyana, Geschichte und Inhalt ‘Apa YUMO Dr. Jacobi ( Bonn, 1893 ), ‘The Great Epic of India’ by Premiere E. W. Hopkins (1901); Das MahƒÅbhƒÅrata &c. by Dahlmann

POON:

WUND

on√°ndorkar

354

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

(Berlin, 1895 ), ‘Mahabharata, a criticism’ by C. V. Vaidya ( 1903 ); The riddle of the RƒÅmƒÅyana,’ by C. V. Vaidya (1906); ‘Das MahƒÅbhƒÅrata, seina Eustehung, Sein Inhalt, seine Form’ by Oldenberg (Gottingen, 1922 ); M. Winter nitz’s History of Indian Literature' vol. I (Calcutta, 1927 ) pp. 475-517; Dr. V. S. Sukhthankar published several Epic Studies in JBBRAS (New Series ) Vol. IV, pp. 185‚Äì202, Vol. XI pp. 165-191, 259-283, Vol. XVI. pp. 70-113, Vol. XVII, pp 185-202, vol. XVIII pp. 1-76, Vol. XIX pp. 20-262 and in Kane Festschrift pp. 472-487 on “RƒÅmo pƒÅkhyƒÅna and the RƒÅmƒÅyana,‚Äù in which he details 86 verbal agreements between the two; Dr. V. S. Sukhthankar’s four lectures on ‘The meaning of the Mah√¢bhƒÅrata’ (1942), three of which were delivered and he passed away suddenly before the 4th could be delivered; this last is monograph No. 4 of the Bombay Asiatic Society ; State and Government in ancient India' by Prof. A. S. Altekar ( Benaras ); ‚Ä¢ History of Indian Political Ideas' by Dr. U. N. Ghoshal (1959); Political Theory of Ancient India ' by I. W. Spellman (Oxford 1964 ); Rev. C. Bulcke’s. RƒÅmakathƒÅ, Utpatti aur VikƒÅna,' Allaha bad, 1950; and a paper on the RainƒÅyana its history and character' in Poona Orientalist Vol. XXV pp. 36-60 and “Three RƒÅmƒÅyana Recensions " in J. O. R. ( Madras ) vol. 17 pp. 1-32.

It would not be proper to say nothing in this work about some of the vexed and important questions concerning the two epics, such as the approximate dates of the two, the inter-relation of the two and the question of the existence of different strata in them. These questions are inseparably intermixed and cannot be dealt with separately. Some points will first be brought out and briefly discussed and then the present author will state his own conclusions for whatever they may be worth. Winternitz (in History of Indian Litera ture' Calcutta, 1927, p. 469 ) went so far as to say that each stanza of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata must be judged on its own merits' and Sukthankar remarks that this is so ‘when we want to use the stanza for historical and comparative purposes’ and he points out (on p. 475 of Kane Festschrift ) that even a pont scholar like Oldenberg commits abysmal mistakes in the esti mate of the age and character of the passages of the Maha bhƒÅrata,

  1. The Two Epics

.

.

It is clear that the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata had become, long before the 7th century A. D., a work for popular education and was being recited before general audiences of men and women in India as in the 19th century. For example, on p. 61 of Peterson’s edition of the Kadambari, 376 it is said that the queen VilƒÅgavati learnt when the epic was being recited that the son saves his father from Put hell. Similarly, it is stated in the KƒÅdambari (p. 71 ) that the one thousand names of NƒÅrƒÅyana used to be recited continuously. The KƒÅdambari (p. 90) refers to the famous Gita dleclared by Krsua, one of whose names is ‚Ä¢ Ananta'. Going further backwards, we find in the famous Besnagara376 Columu Inscription (set out in JRAS for 1909 p. 1055 ) of the 2nd century B. C. of Helio dorus, a devotee of Vasudeva and a Yona ( yavana ) ambas sador from the Greek king Antalikita to the court of king Bhaga-bhadra. The last portion in Prakrit words is ‘dama, cƒÅga, appamƒÅda ' ( dama, tyƒÅga and apranada), which occur in Udyogaparva 43.22 and Striparva 7. 23. 376 ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡•Ä, p. 81

para 14. History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

It has been shown above that the Asv. gr. s≈´tra, which represents the last phase of Vedic literature, includes the ƒÅcƒÅryas of Bharata, MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and Dharma among the sages in the daily tarpu≈Üa. The M√§rkandeya-purana starts by saying that it has four doubts as to Bharata (vide H. of Dh. Vol. V, p. 901 for the four questions and p. 903 for the date ). The Mrcchakatika (III. 12 ) refers to the Sauptika parva ( mƒÅrgo hyesa narendra-Sauptikavadhe p≈´rvam k·∫∑to DrauninƒÅ). In several places where the VedƒÅntas≈´tra relies on Smrti for support SarkarƒÅcƒÅrya quotes only verses from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata.377 For example, on V. S. II. 3. 47 ( smaranti ca ) he quotes only two verses of the Mahabharata. Vide note below. This establishes that SarkarƒÅcƒÅrya held that the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata including the SƒÅntiparva ( which modern critics regard as interpolated later ) was earlier than the VedƒÅnta sutra. The present author has attempted to establish that when the GitƒÉ ( in 13.4 ) speaks of Brahmasutrapadas it does not refer to the Brahmas≈´tra of B≈´larƒÅyana but to several Brahmasutras such as those of BƒÅdari, Audulomi and Asma rathya ( vide H. of Dh. Vol. V. pp. 1173-74). Sabara in his bh√¢sya on the P≈´rvamimumsi-s≈´tra quotes passages from the present MahƒÅbhƒÅratza text; vide a paper in Sukthankar volume pp. 221-229 by Prof. V. M. Apte and D. V. Garge.

Before proceeding further it must first be emphasized that the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata claims to be itihƒÅsa (history ) as stated above, while the Ramayana is a kavya as expressly stated in the RƒÅmƒÅyana itself several times and as comparatively early

The words G≈´tha and ≈õloka occur in the Rgveda. GathƒÅ ( derived from the root gai' to sing) means a song or verse. Vide Rg. VIII.32.1, VIII. 71.14, VIII.98.9, X.99.4, IX.85.6 for g√•tha. The word Sloka occurs more frequently in the Rgveda than the word gathƒÅ and means a verse. In the MahƒÅ bhƒÅrata Gathas sung by the Pitrs ( AnusƒÅsana, 88.11-14), by Yama (Anu. 45.17 and 104.72 ) or by Janaka (Sinti 17.18-20), by Ka≈õyapa ( about Ksami, Vana parva 29.35-44), GƒÅthƒÅ about Paurava in Drona (57. 11 ) and about Bhagiratha (in Drona 60.8), of Yayati (in S√•nti 26.13 and in Drona 63.8-9 ), gƒÅthƒÅs sung by Ambarisa and by Alarka (in Asvamedhika 31. 12ff and 30. 30-31 respectively), by Brhaspati (Santi 23.14–15),by Brahman (Santi 136, about king’s treasury ), gƒÅthƒÅs sung by Usanas on distrust (Santi 138.192 ) and many more occur. (2) ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ. ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•á. ‡§∏‡•Ç. IV. 2. 14 ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø explaing : ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É-‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§¶‡•à‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§É ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø…‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Ä‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ó‡§É‡•§ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ó‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The verses are Santi.

parva 282. 32 { and also 260. 22 and 333. 19-20 ). 378 ‡§® ‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§®‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•á

parva (199. 13-15); Slokas by one who ponders over dharma as in Sauptika ( 1.53-55). Then many slokas and gƒÅthƒÅs are quoted as Anuvassa or simply as Anuvassam (meaning genealogies handed down in families ) e. g. Vanaparva 129. 8 says’atrƒÅnuvamsam pathatah ≈õru≈Üu me kurunandana' and then quotes two verses. For ' Anuvamsam,' vide also Vana parva 87. 16-17 (yatrƒÅnuvainsam bhagavƒÅn JƒÅmadagnyag tathƒÅ jagau). For Anuva·πÅsa slokas, vide Adiparva 95.8 ( for song878 of Devayani and Sarmi≈ütha ).

For other Anuvamsa Slokas, vide Adi. 95. 27, 95. 30-31, 95.46 ( about Santanu ). In Vana parva 88.5 there is an anu va·πÅsya gƒÅthƒÅ about Nrga. Sometimes, even itihƒÅsa is spoken of as sung i.e. recited (gƒ´ta ). The word itihƒÅsa is ancient. It occurs in the Atharvaveda, 380 in the Sata patha-BrƒÅhmana (XI. 1. 6.9), in the B»ôhadƒÅra·πáyaka and Chandogya Upanigads (III. 4. 2, VII. 2. 1 respectively).

The above brief statement is quite enough to show that before the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata was composed there were numerous verses landed down in families and that the Mahabharata utilizes and incorporates a large mass of ballads and bardic verses preserved in many prominent families. The RƒÅmƒÅyana, on the other hand, is a K√§vya and not an itihara and is con fined to the life of RƒÅma, his brothers and their vicissitudes.

asidvitiyosnusasƒÅra PƒÅndavam' (he, armed only with a sword, followed the Pandu hero ) and ‘Sarkarsana-dvitiyasya balam K»ôsnasya vardhatim’ (in this both Krona and his brother Sankarsana are mentioned ). from Nakula, Sahadeva and Bhimasena respectively. Vide also PƒÅ·πá. VI. 2. 34 RƒÅjanyabahuvacana-dvandvesndhaka vrsnisu ‘, which refers to several rƒÅjanyas among Andhe kavrsnis.

From the above brief references in PƒÅ·πáini and Pata√±jali one may affirm that the central story of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata is certainly older by centuries than the story of the RƒÅmƒÅyana. Reference has been made to the fact that there is a RƒÅmopƒÅ khyƒÅna in Vanaparva (chap. 273-292 containing about 750 verses ). It does not completely agree with the present RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa text. In this Kumbhakar≈Üa is said to have been killed by R√°ma ( Yuddha. 67. 180-181 ), while in the Ramop√• khyƒÅna it is Laksmana who does 80 ( Vanaparva 287.18-19 ). Besides, in the Santiparva (chap. 29 ) there is a brief reference to RƒÅma’s rule for 11000 years and the ideal happiness of the people under his rule. In the Dronaparva also RƒÅma is briefly referred to in the Sodasa -rƒÅjakiya section (chap. 55-71, that relating to RƒÅma being chap. 59). Stray references to a few other incidents of the RƒÅma story may be made here. For example, RƒÅma being led to pursue the gold-coloured deer ; the SƒÅntiparva refers briefly to the story of Samb≈´ka. The Salyaparva mentions that Rama cut off the head of a r√§ksasa and the Santi refers to the killing of RƒÅvana by RƒÅma through anger (361. 15 ).884

Hopkins refers to certain passages where VƒÅlmiki is mentioned in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and divides them into two classes. In the first class he puts certain references to Val miki as meant for a mere saint (a p·ªôi), as in SabhƒÅ 7. 16, Vanaparva 85. 119, Udyoya 93. 27, ≈õƒÅnti 207. 4 (along with Asita, Devala and many others ). In my opinion AnusƒÅsana 13.8 ( where VƒÅlmƒ´ki is styled bhagavƒÅn) belongs to this first category. Then Hopkins mentions ‘four passages as referring’ directly to the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa (vide the great Epic of India’) pp. 61 ff).

‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï‡•á ‡§∂‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§π‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§Æ‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§ ‡•§‡•§

FOU

19

11

m862

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Before proceeding to examine these four passages relied upon by Hopkins a few words must be said about the present text of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. There are three elements in it, viz. the bare story of the Pandava - brothers and their cousins (usually referred to as Kauravas ), the upƒÅkhyƒÅnas ( abound ing in the Vanaparva and scattered about in other parvans also ) concerning gods, sages, brƒÅhmanas, kings and others and didactic matter insisting on doing one’s duties and the role of dharma as in Udyoga 148. 16 ‘yato dharmastato jaya·∏•’ and in Kunti’s last message to Yudhisthira in AsramavƒÅsika parva 17.21 Dharme te dhiytƒÅm budhir-manastu mahad-astu ca' and philosophy (Sankhya, Yoga, VedƒÅnta ). There was, therefore, great scope at all times for adding stories and didactic matters. Thus the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata became very much inflated by additions made at different times. Anyone could add a story by saying ‘atrƒÅpyudƒÅharantimam itihƒÉsam purƒÅtanam’. In the AnusƒÅsana parvan alone in 25 chapters stories are introduced with these words, apart from several stories introduced in a different manner. Chap. 98 of that parvan is remarkable. There Bhisma introduces ( in the words ‘atrƒÅpyudƒ´haranti’) the story of a dialogue between Manu PrajƒÅpati and one Suvarna who asks how the practice of the worship of deities with flowers originated and what the rewards of such worship are. Then Manu cites the story (again with the words ‘atrƒÅpyu’ etc.) of the dialogue between Sukra and Bali Vairocana. Two examples may be cited about RƒÅma story being interpolated by devotees and enthusiasts. In chap. 74 of the Anu≈õ√±sana, apart from the evil results of the killing of a cow, the merit issuing from the gifts of cows or gold is praised and the chapter is wound up (verses 11-14) by Bhƒ´≈üma who says that he learnt all this from bis UpƒÅ dhyƒÅya to whom it came from the sages, to whom Laksmana imparted the story in the forest which RƒÅma had heard from his father Da≈õaratha who learnt it from Indra. Another similar example occurs in chap. 137 of the same parvan, which names numerous great men of the past that achieved highest worlds hy making gifts of various kinds, among whom RƒÅma (in verse 14), son of Dasaratha, is mentioned as having reached inexhaustible worlds by offerings in yaj√±as.

Not only were tales interpolated but there are everal repetitions in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. A few examples may be noted. There is in SƒÅnti ( chap. 227 ) an enlarged version of

SITUT

FOUNDED

  1. The Tuo Epice

363

the brief dialogue between Indra and Bali in chap. 223; chap. 175 ( dialogue between father and son ) is practically the same as chap. 277. Salya 38. 39-45 are the same as Vanaparva 83. 116-121. The SodasarƒÅjakiya occurs twice, once in the Dro≈Üa parva (chap. 55‚Äì71) and again in the Kantiparva chap. 29. The story of ƒÄstika occurs twice, iu Adi 13ff and in chap. 48ff again.

The literature known to the Mahabharata furnishes some data for making a statement about the probable date of the extant text of the epic. But as the present text is very much inflated owing to additions made at different times, it would be impossible to assign definite dates, and references to Vedas and BrƒÅhmana works need not be cited. The six Angas are mentioned in Adi. 170. 75. In S√§uti 312. 38 the Naighantu ka-padas are mentioned and the word Vrsa therein. The Nirukta of Yaska and its explanation of the word ' sipivista ' ( which occurs in Rg. VII. 100. 65-7) is mentioned in the S√§ntiparva.386 The Nirukta (V.8) gives the explanation of the word provided by Aupamanyava which is derogatory ( to Vi≈ünu), wbile YƒÅska appears to prefer a laudatory sense and applies the word to Vi≈ünu (as Surya), meaning ‘in which rays enter on all sides )’. The S√§nti (310. 21-22 ) mentious that Bphaspati knew (composed ? ) the VedƒÅngas, Bhargava Niti sƒÅstra ( politics ), N√°rada music ( G√°ndharva ), BhƒÅradvƒÅja archery, GƒÅrgya the doings of Devull, KronƒÅtreya medicine, and some disputants ( composed ) several sidehƒÅntas based on logic (such as T√§rkika, Vaise≈üika and K√°pila ). It will be stat ed in the section on Manusmrti how hundreds of verses are common to the MabƒÅbhƒÅrata and the Manusmrti. In the Anu≈°ƒÅsana we have (in 47.35 ) mention of the SƒÅstra declared by Manu. Itihasa and PurƒÅna are called the fifth Veda as early as the Ch√°ndogya Up. VII. 1. 2-4 and the Satapatha BrƒÅhmana requires that in the PƒÅriplava some Purana and ItihƒÅsa passages were to be recited on the 8th and 9th days respectively. Therefore, the numerous references to PurƒÅna in the Great Epic are not here set out. It is important to note that a PurƒÅna declared by V√§yu is mentioned in Vana Parva (191. 16). The Svargarohanaparva ( 5. 46-47 ) states that there are 18 Puranas composed by Krsna DvaipƒÅyana.

.

385 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ø‡§™‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï ‡§ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ß‡•Ä: ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§ß‡•ã ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É

THETET II TF 342‚Äì73.

364

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Upavedas are mentioned in Drona parva 202. 75. Dhanur. veda is mentioned in Santi 49. 32, 50. 233 and 167. 31.

The word ‘Dharma≈õƒÅstresu’ occurs frequently as shown above (vide pp. 13, 300-1 ). Individual writers on Dharma sƒÅstra ( apart from Manu ) are also quoted e. g. Yama in Santi 82. 31, Aigiras ( two verses ) in Santi 69. 71-73; Usanas on slaying an atatƒÅyin386 ( a desperado like an incendiary or a

poisoner ) may be killed outright in self-defence.

In AnusƒÅsana 18. 38 Garga is said to have obtained the knowledge of the sixty-four Kalas (arts) and in Salya-parva 37. 145 Garga is said to have gained on the banks of Sarasvati knowledge of kƒÅla and about the movements of heavenly bodies. Astronomer Garga is assigned to 50 B. C. by Kern ( vide Preface to Brhat-samhita p. 50)and H. of Dh. Vol. V pp. 79 and 592 n 878.

It appears that by the time the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata assumed its present form Buddhist and Jain ideas had acquired influence among the people. For example, the Vanaparva387 ( 181.42-43) says ‘truthfulness, self-restraint, tapas, charity, ahimsa, constant adherence to dharma, these are the means (of higher life ) ainong men, not caste nor family.’ Santiparva says

(188. 10 ) ‘there is no difference among the (four) var·πáas; this world is BrƒÅhma (belongs to BrahmƒÉ ), because it was formerly created by BrahmƒÅ and was, (later) reduced to differ ent var·πáas by their (diverse) actions’. The Santiparva annou nces Truthfulness, charity, freedom from hatred and wickedness, humility, kindness and tapas,-where these are seen, he is known as brƒÅhmana. If these characteristics are found in a s√ºdra and these do not exist in a twice-born person then the S≈´dra is not a s√ºdra and the so-called brƒÅhma·πáa is not a brƒÅhma·πáa. This approaches the teaching of the Dha mmapada verses 383, 393 (yamhi satyam ca dhammo ca 80 sukhi 80 ca brƒÅhmanah). Similiarly, in Anu≈°ƒÅsana 115 Yudhisthira asked Bhisma ‘you have often declared that ahime√¢ is the highest dharma and you also said that in ≈õrƒÅddhas the pitre desire to have flesh offered’. A naked Ksapanaka ( Digambara Jain) is mentioned in Adi 3. 126; in Santi 232. 21388 the Jain posi tion seems to have been alluded to and also in Afvamedhika 49. 2. In Adiparva 70. 46 it is stated that in Kanva’s hermi tage there were leaders of LokƒÅyatika views along with students of Vedas and Moksadharma.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Kamsa by Kƒôs·ª•a. That some verses quoted by the Maha bhƒÅsya are found in the Mahabharata is shown in the note below. 380

The date of the MahƒÅbhƒÅsya is generally accepted to be about 150 B, C.; vide (pp. 75-79 above). It quotes a quarter of a verse stating that some person followed the Pandava hero with only a sword in his hand and PƒÅ·πáini knows the central figures of the great Epic viz. Yudhisthira and Arjuna. It has been shown above (p. 75 ) that Panini flourished about 450 to 400 B.C. Therefore, it follows that there were poems about Pandava heroes and about Krsna killing Kamsa some time before 400 B. C. Scholars would have to assign 500 B. C. as the latest date for the core of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata.

Another circumstance pointing to the same conclusion is that the Asv. G»ô. mentions " BhƒÅrata-MahƒÅbhƒÅrata dharmƒÉ cƒÅryƒÅ·∏•'. The G»ôhyag≈´tras belong to the latest phase of the Vedic literature. The mention of BhƒÅrati and MahƒÅbhƒÅrata as preceding the ƒÄ≈õv. G»ô. would make it very probable that the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata was in existence at least just before the end of the Vedic period.

One warning already given by Winternitz in ' History of Indian Literature' (Calcutta, 1927 p. 469) and accepted by the late Dr. V. S. Sukthankar (in ‘Epic Studies’ VIII in Kane Festschrift p. 474 ) with an addition is that when we want to use a stanza for historical and comparative purposes each

such stanza must be judged on its own merits'. But life being short, this would be an almost impossible task for one scholar for the one hundred thousand stanzas of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata.

But if we turn to the RƒÅmƒÅyana, none of the great per sonages depicted in that epic such as Da≈õaratha, RƒÅma, Laks mana, Bharata (Rama’s brother ), HanƒÅmat, Sugriva, Bibhisana is inentioned by PƒÅ≈Üini or in quotations cited in the MahƒÅbhƒÅsya. Those who want to argue that the present RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa was known to Pata√±jali rely on a few matters, such as the reference to Kiskindhi and two verses891 about VƒÅnarasainyu in the MahƒÅbhƒÅsya. These two verses do not occur in the RƒÅmƒÅyana at all; besides, here “V√§narasainya' does not necessarily mean an ‘army of monkeys’; it may play. fully be applied to a crowd or number of monkeys; and moreover such verses illustrating the use of the same root in the Parasmaipada and ƒÄtmanepada might have been com posed by a teacher of grammar for the benefit of his pupils. As there is a parody of Dasaratha, RƒÅma and SitƒÉ in the Dasarathaj√§taka, it is probable that some decades before 250 B. C. there existed a popular story about these three. Some further remarks will be made in the section on RƒÅmƒÅ yana.

368

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

yat-syƒÅt kartavyam eva tat' (Dronaparva 14.67-68 ).32 The criticisms against this citation are several. One is that what is quoted is not a Sloka at all, but only a pƒÅda (quarter) at the most; secondly, the Sloka in the RƒÅmƒÅyana does not amount to an absolute rule, but there is a counterpoise in the latter half of the ≈õloka ; another criticism is that the Maha bhƒÅrata itself had already stated in the Adiparva and Vana parva the same rule against killing a woman. So it is proba ble that some interpolator mentioned it in the Dronaparva to show off his knowledge of the other epic. As regards the 2nd citation I am sorry to say that Hopkins is carried away by his enthusiasm to prove direct quotations from the RƒÅmƒÅ yana in the other epic. In the RƒÅmƒÅyana, the verse ‘rƒÉjƒÅpam prathamam vindet’ does not occurses at all. Hopkins is obliged to say that it agrees closely enough in sense and words with the verse in AyodhyƒÅ 67. 11. The verge from AyodhyƒÅ is not ipsissima verba'. There is another gratuitous assumption made by him. He thinks that Bhargava is VƒÅlmiki. Bhargava

means Usanas. Vide Amarakosass quoted below. Hopkins, in spite of his learning and industry, here forgets that the SƒÅntiparva ( 210. 20 ) ascribes # NitisƒÅstra to Bhargava and among the expounders of RƒÅja≈õ√§stra385 the Santiparva mentions

392 ‡§® ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§Æ ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§ö ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§

‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§° 81. 29-30 ; Compare ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø 158. 31 ; ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§É ‡•§

‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø 217. ' ; vide also ‡§µ‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ 208. 48. 398 ‡§Ü‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§ ‡•• ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ

‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø 67. 40-41; ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§° 67. 11 is ‘‡§Ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•á ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•á ‡•§ ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•á ‡••'; ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡§§‡§ø

‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‚Ä¢ 320. 59. 394 ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§â‡§∂‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂. 395 ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡•ã ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ 210.20. ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á

‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§∞ ‡•§ ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§É‡•§ … ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‚Ä¢ 58, 1-3.

1917

  1. The Two Epics

369

KƒÅvya (i.e. U≈°anas ) and Bhargava 306 as identical. VƒÅlmƒ´ki’s name has nowhere been mentioned as that of an expounder of RƒÅja≈õƒÅstra. The RƒÅmƒÅyana itself regards Usanas ( Sukra ) and Bhargava as identical when it describes the auspicious appearances on RƒÅma’s invasion of R√§vana’s capital ( Yuddha 4.49 ). Vide above under Kautilya’s Artha≈õƒÅstra where pa88a ges from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata on the RƒÅja≈õƒÅstra of Uganas have been quoted. Hopkins misunderstands the verse. What it means is: the life of RƒÅma was recited to some king by a court poet or possibly by Bhargava U≈õanas himself the expounder of Rajas√µstra, who thereon recited the famous verse ‘rƒÅjƒÅnam prathamam vindet &c,’ because the underlying idea of that expounder was ‘no king, no dharma nor security’. It is quite possible that both (i, e. MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and RƒÅmƒÅyana ) quote from a common source viz, the RƒÅja≈õƒÅstra of Kavya U≈õanas which once existed but has not yet been recovered.

The third passage occurs in the Vana parva, where Bhima is said to have met Hanumat on the GandhamƒÅdana but did not recognize him and took him to be a mere ordinary monkey (chapters 146 ff). There he speaks of Hanumat as his brother and very famous 397 in the RƒÅmƒÅyana (147. 11). VƒÅlmƒ´ki’s name is not mentioned in those chapters and this story was proba bly interpolated later. The Vanaparva is in extent next to the Santiparva. These two and the Anusasana parva cover about two-fifths of the whole of the extant Mahabharata. The 4th passage ( quoted in the note below )308 on which Hopkins relies occurs in the last chapter of the Harivamsa (which is a khila) and not at all in the text of the MahƒÅ. bhƒÅrata in the Chitrashala edition and others.

The above discussion shows that out of the four passages relied upon by Hopkins one is wrongly interpreted, two are not in the MabƒÅbhƒÅrata at all and the remaining one is pro bably interpolated.

HASTITUTE

1917

370

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

The most puzzling question concerning the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata is how the members of a polyandrous family became the heroes of the great national epic. Even in the extant epic attempts are made to explain the matter in a supernatural way. In the AsramavƒÅsikaparva it is stated that after the carnage in the great war, Dh·ªãtarƒÉstra, Vidura, Kunti ( the mother of five Pandavas ), GƒÅndhƒÅri, Draupadi, SubbadrƒÅ met together and sages like VyƒÅsa, NƒÅrada, Parvata and others also came when Dh·ªãtarƒÉstra complained that he had no sleep and no peace of mind and G√°ndh√•rƒ´ requested VyƒÅsa to vouch safe to DhrtarƒÉstra the sight of his fallen sons. Kunti told VyƒÅsa (AsramavƒÅsikaparva chap. 30 ) how DurvƒÅsas ( an irate sage ) came to her father (a king ) for alms when she was yet a maiden and as she pleased the sage by her assidu ous hospitality, he gave her five mantras on repeating any one of which the god addressed in that mantra would come to her. She proceeded to say that when she saw from her father’s palace the rising sun, she called him to come by reciting the appropriate mantra, the sun came and she duly requested him to grant her a son, when the Sun’s refulgence entered her and she secretly gave birth to a son (later ) called Karna, whom she let down in a river. She wanted to see that son whom she abandoned. Then VyƒÅsa consoled her that she was not to be blamed, that deities enter human bodies, that human limi tations do not apply to deities and he recited a verse that everything is pure and wholesome to the strong. 808

In the Adiparva (chap. 169 ) a similar story is repeated almost in the same words that a maiden requested God Sankara five times to bestow on her a husband and so he ble ssed her that she would have five husbands ( pati ) and she became later Draupadi, daughter of king Drupada. Adiparva (197, 35-36 and 44 ff) states the same kind of story, but it is Laksmi (in Svarga ) who asks five times for a husband.

In Adiparva the question how a polyandrous marriage was allowed in the case of the five Pandava heroes has been raised and dealt with in chapter 195, verses 27-31. Drupada (father of Draupadi) urges that five brothers should have one wife is adharma, it is opposed to the Veda and the use

  1. The Two Epics

371

of the people. The reply of Yudhisthira is: ‘Dharma is subtle; we only follow the path of our predecessors. I never told a lie nor am I bent on adharma. But my mother says that we five should have the same woman as wife.400 If one may speculate on the origin of the Pandavas, it is possible that they hailed from the hilly regions in the Himalayas where polyandry prevailed up to recent times, that they were formidable warriors and made their way in the countries of Kuru and Pa√±cƒÅla and married a PƒÅ√±c√¢la princess. The desceudants of the Pandava heroes viz. Pariksit and Janame jaya are well-known in the Vedic age. The Sat. Br. XIII. 4.5 and Ait. Br. 35. 1 mention P√§riksita Janamejaya as a performer of Afvamedha. Dasaratha, Rama and their descendants are not spoken of in these ancient works.

In Anushgana (115. 68-75 ) about fifty ancient kings are named that gave up flesh-eating in Kaumuda (K√•rtika) month and therefore they went to heaven. These passages of the great epic would have to be assigned at the most to √† century or two before the Christian era.

The RainƒÅyana ( AyodhyƒÅ 109.34 ) contains a down-right condemnnation of Buddha401 as nƒÉstika (atheist ) and 88 & thief and in chap. 108 of the same epic JƒÅbƒÅli is introduced as an atheist who condemns in the presence of RƒÅma tbe finer virtues of respect for parents and other relatives, the institu tion of SrƒÅddha, condemns those who talk of the other world and asks RƒÅma not to leave the kingdom in favour of Bharata.

The two epics have in common many striking verses. For example, in the story of the Kapota bird and the lubdhaka (hunter) where the Kapota burnt itself in order to offer food to the hungry hunter and the female bird, on the death of the male bird, entered fire and killed herself, a fine verse is put in

Another famous verse of the propriety of punishing even a guru when he becomes conceited, fails to distinguish between what ought to be done or not to be done and who pursues the wrong path 403 occurs in both. The S√§ntiparva (in 57.6 ) says that in former times king Marutta recited an ancient bloka in Brhaspati’s treatise in the section on kings (RƒÅjƒÅdhi kƒÅra ) and that it is 57.7. Another verse that occurs in both epics is : all collections end in dissolution, all tall things end in falling down, unions end in separation, life ends in death.404

The discussions so far beld make this clear that the main characters of the Mahabharata were known long before Panini and that tales relating to PƒÅ≈Üdava heroes had been embodied in a work or in works in verse long before Pata√±jali wrote i. e. that the core of the MahabhƒÅrata existed before 500 B. C. The same cannot be said about the RƒÅmƒÅyana. There is no evidence to show that the principal characters of the RƒÅm√• yana were known to PƒÅ·πáini or even to Pata√±jali. At the most one can say that the three names, Dasaratha, RƒÅma and Sit√§, were probably known about 250-200 B. C. but not described

  1. The Two Epics

978

as endowed with the qualities they bear in the extant RƒÅmƒÅ. yana. Therefore, one may conclude that there was a Bh√§rata epic long before there was a RƒÅma epic. From the way in which the VƒÅnaras led by Angada ( Ki≈ükindhƒÅ 41. 6ff) among whom were included such doughty fighters as Han√ªmat, Nila, J√°mbavat, were directed to go from Ki≈ükindhƒÅ towards the south in search of SitƒÅ carried away to LankƒÅ by RƒÅvana, one feels that the author did not correctly know the different countries that the VƒÅnaras would have had to traverse before reaching Lanka. Sugrƒ´va is said to have told them to go from Kiskindha to the south and one is surprised to read that Sugriva first mentions the Vindhya mountain with its thousand peaks and immediately afterwards NarmadƒÅ (chap. 41.8 ) and then mentions God√°varƒ´, Kronavenƒ´, VaradƒÅ ( 41.9), Mekala, Utkala, DasƒÅrna towns, Avanti ( 41.10 ), Vidarbha, Vanga, Kalinga ( 41.11 ). It is unnecessary to cite more. The present writer is constrained to hold that whoever wrote that chapter was an inhabitant of a place north of the NarmadƒÅ (which springs from Mekala )405 and knew only the names of towns, rivers and countries without knowing their exact loca tion. The author had probably never been to the island of Ceylon nor kuew anything about the distance between India and Ceylon nor haid he any idea about the extent of Ceylon. It was all a poetic fancy without any solid basis of known facts, even ancient. KiskindhƒÅ is now shown to be a village on the TungabhadrƒÅ river in the Bellary District. We know from the AranyakƒÅnda ( chap. 13 ) that Agastya directed RƒÅma to have a hut in Pa√±cava»õi near GodƒÅvari and from that place be later went to Royam≈´ka near PampƒÅ where dwelt Sugriva with four others ( Aranya. 72.11-12 ). 406

406 Vide Amarakosa which says ‘Tard TTT THAT √Ä* Print’. 406 Several scholars have writton about the location of LankƒÅ. Mr. M.

V. Kibe locates Lauka in contral India (vide ABORI Vol. XVII pp. 371-384; F. W. Thoinas prosentation Vol. pp. 144-5; J. C. Ghosh in ABORI vol, XIX pp. 84-86; Daniel John in ABORI vol. Vol. XIX at p. 8oront is pointed out that a portion of Orissa was known as LankƒÅmena M. 8. Anoy in his papor ‚ÄúThe Ramayana tradition in the PORARE

(Continued on the next page)

1917

374

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

It has been shown above that the RƒÅma story and chara cters are mentioned in the extant MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and the legends and some well-known characters in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata are noted in the extant Ramayana. Therefore, all that one can say is that both works have influenced each other. But As the core of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata is much older than that of the RƒÅmƒÅyana and as the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata is four times as bulky as the RƒÅmƒÅyana, it is the latter that most probably borrowed several matters from the great Epic. It has been demonstre ted above that the so-called four direct references in the MabƒÅbhƒÅrata to the RƒÅmƒÅyana put forward by Hopkins are not so and that only one remains, which appears to me to be a later interpolation.

Just as the story of Nala-Damayanti was set out in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata from a tale current in early days, so the RƒÅma story might have been only a popular tale in the beginning and was later turned into an epic, but the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata, if it had directly borrowed from the RƒÅmƒÅyana, would not have differed from the epic on such an important matter as the killer of Kumbhakarna. Therefore, it is very probable that the RƒÅma tale was included in the Vanaparva at a time when the RƒÅmƒÅyana in its present form did not exist. The present writer holds that the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata assumed its present form certainly before the Christian era, but how much earlier it is difficult to say.

( Continued from the previous page ) day Ceylon' in the Proceedings of the A. I. 0. Conference at Dar bhanga ( 1048 ), pp. 206-218 tries to show that LankƒÅ is the present Ceylon and supports his viow by referring to the SundarakƒÅnda, Mahavamsa, RƒÅjƒÅvali and some similar works. I regret that his arguments aro far from convincing. In tho SundarakƒÅnda Lanka is not an island but is described as tho capital of RƒÅvana situated beyond the sea on the slopes of Trik≈´ta and surrounded by a wall as the versos quoted below testify. The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata mentions Sinhala and Lank√° soparntoly (Vanaparva 01. 23 Sinhalan Barba. r√•n mlecchun ye ca Lankiniviisina·∏• ). The Dipavamsa is the ear: liest chroniolo (about Ceylon) and it is not oarlier than the 4th ceatury A. D. and the Mahavarisa is much later (6th century or later ). They are not reliable authorities for ovonts that aro guppo sed to have lapponou govoral couturies before Christ. ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¨‡§≤‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§ü‡•á ‡§≤‡§π‡•Å‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ATT T T II … TATATU 7 SEATAEt Trauen argia H49T: FIETOSTITEATH i rep a spus 2. 7–8; at which is Tarraga: 31ATH 1 97*To 3. 13,

1917

  1. The Two Epics

375

Hopking497 devotes pp. 386-403 of his work The Great Epic of India' to the date of the Epic and summarises his con clusions on pp. 397-398. On p. 398 he says there is no date of the Epic' which will cover all its parts (though handbook makers may safely assign it in general to the 2nd century B. C.). A sizable volume would be required to criticize his remarks on several matters and to expose the hollowness of his hasty and one-sided conclusions. To take only one exa mple at random. He relies (p. 387) on the occurrence of the word DinƒÅra in the Harivamsa which is only a supplement to the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and on the fact that in the present text of the Epic ( Adiparva chap. 2.82-83 ) reference is made to the Hariva·πÅsa as a Khila, in which are included the deeds of Visnu such as killing Kamsa and the Bhavisya parva, wbich is a large and wonderful one amony Khilas. 408 The DinƒÅra is not mentioned in the 18 parvans of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata (not even in Santiparva nor in Anu≈°ƒÅsa naparva ) as Hopkins admits on p. 387. Supposing for a moment that the mention of dinƒÅra in Hariva·πÅsa is not interpolated, still from the reference to Harivassa in Adi I. 2 in general it does not necessarily follow that the writer of Adi. 2 had before him a Harivamsa contai ning the word DinƒÅra. Besides, his dating about the Intro duction of DinƒÅras in India is not supported by satisfactory evidence. He states ( on p. 387 ) " for the Roman denarius is known to the Harivamsa and the Harivamsa is known to the first part of the first book and the last book; hence such parts of this book as recognize the Harivarsa must be later than

m

the Introduction of Roman coins into the country (100-200 A, D.)'. He does not mention the evidence on which he bases his conclusion about the exact period of the Introduction of the Denarius in India. For the date of early Denarius coins, vide Pro. of British Academy, Vol. XVIII for 1932 pp. 211-266.409

The Romakas are mentioned in SabhƒÅparva 51.17. One remarkable matter is as follows. The Apastamba Dh.S. II. 5. 11.5-6 are' RƒÅj√±a·∏• panthƒÅ brƒÅhmanevƒÅsametya' and ‘gamety. tu brƒÅhma·πáasyaiva panthah’. These two s≈´tras form the second half of the verse in Vana parva 133.1 (the first half being ‘And hasya panthƒÅ·∏•… bh≈´ra vƒÅhasya panthƒÅ·∏• &c ).

VyƒÅba or the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata has been mentioned in some early inscriptions.

For example, the Pardi plates of Dahra-sena of Samvat 207 (probably of the Kalacuri or Chedi era i. e. of 456 A. D.) ascribes the verse ‘≈üa≈ü»õim varsa sahasrƒÅ·∫°i’ &c. (in E. I. Vol. X. p. 53 ) to VyƒÅsa. Gupta Ing. No. 31 at p. 137 (the Khoh copper-plate of MahƒÅrƒÅja SarvanƒÅtha dated in 204 of the Gupta era i.e. 533 A. D. ) says ‘uktam ca MahƒÅbhƒÅrate VyƒÅsena’.410 This inscription establishes that long before 530 A. D. the Great Epic was deemed to have one hundred thousand verses composed by VyƒÅsa. It has been already shown how in Bana’s day the Epic was recited to an audience of men and women. Several hundred verses are commou to both the Manu≈üm·ªôti and the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. Commentators of Dharma≈õƒÅstra works from early times quote the MabƒÅ bhƒÅrata. MedhƒÅtithi on Manu II. 94 quotes one of YayƒÅti’s verses about KƒÅma (desire ) being insatiable. On Manu

409

That paper shows that formerly it wag believed that the Donarius was introducted in 269 B, C. But on a fresh appraisal it is stated (od p. 214 ) that we may rogard 190 B. C. as a close approximation to the true date. On. p. 254 it is shown that the first issue of the paper denaring was in 187 B. C. In plate III accompanying the vol. No. 32 is a donarius of 42 B. C. and No. 33 of 99, 94 B. C. Hence Dinarius could have been introduced in India in 150 B. C.

XI.93 he quotes ¬∑ Ubhau Madhv√µsavaksibau’(Udyoga 59.5); on IX.64 he quotes SƒÅnti 63.13411 that the S≈´dra is entit led to three ƒÅ≈õramas but not to that of parivrƒÅjaka. On Manu VII. 177 he quotes the well-known verse na kascit kasyacit’ ( quoted above). The Mit. quotes the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata or VyƒÅsa frequently (e. g. on YƒÅj. 1.72,86, 256, III. 6, 250, 258, 300 ). AparƒÅrka quotes from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata dozens of verges, but the quotations from VyƒÅsa include many verses on Vyava bƒÅra attributed to VyƒÅsa which do not occur in the MahƒÅ bhƒÅrata. The K≈ôtyakalpataru sparingly quotes the MahƒÅ bhƒÅrata. It is unnecessary to refer to other and later digests on the question of the, date and text of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata.

When ancient Indians came to Java they brought with them their sacred books. The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata soon became most popular among the Javanese. Portions of the MahƒÉ bhƒÅrata were renderad into old Javanese or Kavi poetry. This work is known as Brata Yuda (modern Javanese) i.e. BhƒÅrata Yuddha. The Kalasan Inscription of the suka year 700 ( 778 A. D. ) found in a temple in central Java is the earliest Javanese Inscription written in a North Indian script. It was published by Dr. R. G. Bhandarkar in JBBRAS Vol. VII part 2 from a photograjih copy sent to him from Batavia. It opens with a salutation to T√ºrƒÅ, Buddhist goddess. The temple was constructed by the RƒÅjaguru (king’s chaplain ) of a king of the Sailendra dynasty. It contains twelve verses one of which is quoted below.412 Sardar K. M. Panikkar’s

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

paper on ‘ManipravƒÅla in Java’in ‚ÄòKunhan Raja Presentation volume pp. 65-69’ shows how from the 12th century A. D. onwards poems were composed in Java in the local kavi language, employed different Sanskrit metres and took over stories from the Sanskrit kƒÅvyas of KƒÅlidƒÅsa, BhƒÅravi and the episodes in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and adopted Sanskrit theories of rhetoric and ala; kƒÅras (figures of speech ). Several European scholars have worked on this subject. Vide for example, Louis Finot’s learned paper in I. H. Q. vol. I pp. 599-622 ( on the geography and chronology of Indian civilization in Indo China’) in which he gives the names of several Dutch and French scholars ( as his predecessors in the same field ). He remarks India has laid her mark on all the great Eastern countries some of which received a substantial part of their religious and artistic culture from India and others are indebted to her for their very existence as civilized states'. For Srivijaya', vide ‘La Royamme de Srivijaya’ by G. Coedes mentioned by Finot’s paper (1). 619) and Prof. Nilakanta Sastri in ‘Bulletin of the ‘l’ecole de Extreme Orient’, Tome XV fasc. 2 pp. 239 ff ( Hanoi ).

The commentary called BhƒÅratabhƒÅvadƒ´pa of Nilakantha Caturdhara ( son of Govinda ) on the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata (printed in the Ch. ed. ) is a learned one. In the opening verses at the beginning of Adiparva he praises one Laksma≈ÜƒÅrya, then two ancestors of his viz. NƒÅrƒÅyana and Dhire≈õa who are again named with reverence in SabhƒÅ l.1 as Hamiranurya (i.e. residing in Hamirapur ). At the beginning of Udyoga parva he calls bimself Laksmana padinuga ( following in the footsteps of Laksmana ); again on Vanaparva 129. 9 he states that followers of Lak≈ümalla who was the ornament of a family of persons well-versed in knowledge of brahman explains that verse differently. At the beginning of Bhismaparva, chap. 25 ( i.e. the Bhagavadgiti ) he performs an obeisance to Sridhara and others as ‘sadgur≈´n’. This Sridhara is, it appears, the commentator of the Bhagavata purana. On

On Vana' 93.27 he explains * KathinƒÅnƒÉm as KƒÅthi iti Mah√ºr√ºstra prasiddhah'. Though a MahƒÅrƒÅstrian he knew YavanabhƒÅsƒÅ as on SabhƒÅ 4,2 he ex plains that’Jivantƒ´‚Äô is called ' viriji' in YavanabhƒÅ≈õƒÅ.

As he refers to the Medinikoga and the KƒÅlamadhava he is certainly later than the 14th century A. D. In ‘Indian Culture’ vol. I pp. 706-710 it is stated that Arjunamisra, a Varendra brƒÅbmana who flourished in the latter part of the 13th century is a better commentator than Nilakantha. Vimalabodha wrote a commentary on the Mahabharata called Vimalasloki or Durghat√°rthaprakƒÅ≈õini, a ms, of which is in possession of the Bhandarkar Oriental Institute ( Poona). Vide Gode’s paper

414 ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ã‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•-‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•á ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç

‡§´‡§£‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ã‡§≤‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡§• ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§ó‡§§‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ( at end of tifata); hari at foran tante ATENTES ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•á ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§´‡§£‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ã‡§≤‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ú‡§§ ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á FIATHIRII. M√• appears to bave been used for reasons of metro instead of the usual word ard. In the Kathopaniad Nagitan asks his father’AI TITTA' (1.4) and in the BOX 112, 3 ( Tere na f√∂r 1517299 HT ).
