  1. The Two Epics

381

in Silver Jubilee Vol. of the BORI pp. 146 ff. Vide Dr. Raghavan’s paper in Kane Festschrift (pp. 351-355 ) for some commentators of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata such as Varada, Yaj√±anƒÅrƒÅya·πáa and Anandapurna (about 1350 A. D. ), parts of whose commentaries are found in mss. collections.

The extant MahƒÅbhƒÅrata professes that it is removed from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata war only by two generations or 80. It was narrated by Vaisam pƒÅyana to Janamejaya who was the great-grandson of Arjuna. The topics regarding the beg inning of the Kaliyuga and the astronomical data in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata have been discussed at some length in the 3rd volume of the H. of Dh. pp. 896-923.

The probable date of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata war has been dis cussed by the present author in H. of Dh. Vol. III pp. 895 923 and Vol. V. p. 849. There are three dates put forward from comparatively early times, viz. 3101 B. C. (the tradi tional date );( 2 ) that of the Brhat-samhitƒÅ and RƒÅjatarangini (viz. about 653 of Kali age ); (3) that of the VƒÅyu, Matsya, Brabmanda and Bhagavata purƒÅ≈Üas which provide that bet ween the birth of Pariksit ( grandson of Arjuna, the outstand ing fighter among the Pandavas ) and the coronation of Nanda there is a period of 1500 (or 1050 or 1015 years, according to various readings in the mss of those PurƒÅnas ). Almost all modern scholars discard the idea that the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata was composed a short time after the war. Similarly, the matters in the SƒÅnti and Anusasana parvans containing over twenty thousand verses are stated to have been declared by Bhisma, who was mortally wounded but lay on death-bed till the sun turned northwards. This was a very helpful camouflage to insert into the Epic any matter deemed worthy of being put in. In the Parvasa nigrahaparva ( Adi. 2.325-331 ) it is stated that in the SƒÅntiparva there are 329 udhyƒÅyas ( chapters ) and 14732 verses and in Adi. 2.331-338 it is stated that in the Anu≈õƒÅsana parva there are 146 adhyƒÅyas and 8000 verses. In the Chitraslala edition there are 365 chapters in the Santi parya and 168 in the Anusasanaparva. Thus the chapters in the two parvans (in the present text ) exceed the number of chapters stated in Adiparva, chap. 2. It is possible that later redactors arranged the chapters differently for varidus reasons. In the Santiparva the longest adhyƒÅya ( 138 ) 221 verses, then comes chap. 284 with 208 verses. On the

INST

FOUN382

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

other hand the shortest chap. of Sintiparva is 363 (of six verses only ), chapters 353 and 365 have only nine verses each, while some chapters (such as 129, 136, 304, 352 ) have only eleven verses. A few chapters like 192, 338, 342 have a few verses and also long prose passages. I have calculated the verses in the Santiparva and they come to about 13200 or so in the Chitrashala edition, but if one takes into account the prose passages (and calculates them as versified with 32 letters in each verse ), then there would not be much divergence in the number of slokas. Vide C. V. Vaidya’s ‘MahƒÅbhƒÅrata: a criticism’, Appendix, note one, for the total of chapters and slokas in the 18 parvans and the kbila Hariva·πÅsa stated in the Parvasangrahaparva and in the Bombay edition. They are respectively 96836 and 95826 blokas. Therefore, the reputed extent of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata even in early inscriptions (the Khoh plate of 533 A. D. ) viz. one hundred thousand is only approximate; vide Dr. Sukhtankar’s paper in ABORI, Silver Jubilee Volume, (1943) pp. 549-558 for remarks on the figures mentioned in the Parvasangrahaparva.

The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata not only repeats tales but also single verses of its own e.g. S√§nti, chap, 231.31 repeats GitƒÉ 8.17 (sahasra yuga'), chap. 251.9 is the same as Gƒ´tƒÅ (11.70, ƒÅp≈´ryamƒÅnam ), chap. 312.14 ( sarvatah p√°rio) is same as Gƒ´tƒÅ 13.13; Vana parva 189.27 (yada yadƒÅ ca dharmasya ) is the same as GitƒÅ 1V. 7.

In the two epics genealogies of ancient kings occur fre quently and it is impossible to reconcile all of them. A few simple examples may be cited. The Manusmrti (in I. ) claims that BrahmƒÅ first ( 1.32 ) created Viraj who created him (Manu) and he (Manu) created (1.35 ) the great sages ( Marici, Atri, Angiras, Pulaha, Pulastya, Kratu, Pracetas Vasistha, Bhrgu and NƒÅrada ) and they created the seven Manus (1.36 ) and the world was created by them. If we turn to the Mahabharata, the Anu≈õasana (chap. 2.5 ft') tells us that Manu PrajƒÅpati’s son was IksvƒÅku, who had one hundred sons of whom Da≈õƒÅ≈õva was the 10th. But the Vana parva (iu chap. 201-202 ) speaks of IkyvƒÅku, his son Sasida ( who ruled in AyodhyƒÅ ), his son Kakusthu, bis son Anenas, whose son was P»ôthu-whose son was Visvaga≈õva, whose son was Adki wlinse son was YuvanƒÅ≈õva and so on. In the ƒÄsvamedljikapare (chap. 4 ) the genealogy is ( in Kytayugu ) Manu-son Krasan

Œü œÑŒøœÖNœÅŒµŒø

Œù

  1. The Two Epics

383

dhi-son Ksupa-son Ik≈üvƒÅku (chap. 4.3-14 ). If we now turn to the RƒÅmƒÅyana, chap. 110 of the AyodhyƒÅkƒÅnda furni. shes a long pedigree (in verses 5-34 ) as follows: BrahmƒÉ Marici-Ka≈õyapa-Vivasvat-Manu Vaivasvata PrajƒÅpati-Iks vƒÅku (the first king of AyodhyƒÅ )-Kuksi-Vikuk≈üi-Bana Anara·πáya-Pythu-Tri≈°ajku – DhundumƒÅra - YuvadƒÅ≈õva - MƒÅn dhƒÅtr-Susandhi-Dhruvasandhi– Bharata-Asita-SƒÅgara - A82 ma√±ja - A·πÅ≈õumƒÅn - Dilipa - Bhagiratha - Kakustha - Raghu Prav·ªáddha. KalmƒÅsarƒÅda -Sankhana - Sudarsana - Agnivarna Sighraga-Maru-Prasu≈õruva-Ambarisa-Nahusa-NƒÅbhƒÅga-Aja Da≈õaratha-RƒÅma. This pedigree contradicts the one in Manu smrti ( 1.34-35 ) set out a little above, where Marici is one of the ten sons of Manu. Let us now turn to the Raghuvamsa, where ( in 1.11-12 ) it is stated that Vaivasvata Manu was the first king, that among his descendants was king Dilipa, whose son was Raghu whose son was Aja whose son was Dasaratha. It should be noted that in the AyodhyƒÅkƒÅnda two kings inter vene between Dilipa and Raghu and between Raghu and Aja ten kings are named. Hence it follows that the AyodhyƒÅ. kƒÅnda pedigree is either an inflated one or that KƒÅlidasa had a different pedigree before him at least from Dilipa downwards or that K≈´lidasa was not aware of the longer pedigree. From the Raghuvamsa itself it appears that K≈´lidƒÅsa knew the story of Sagara as an ancestor of Rama and the story of his A≈õvamedha horse being carried to the bottom of the earth and the digging of the earth for finding it and the ocean being filled with the waters of Ganges ( Raghu. XIII. 31 ); he also knew the story of Bhagiratha taking the Ganges from the matted hair of ≈öiva (Raghu IV.32 ) to the earth and of Kaku stha being a descendant of IksvƒÅku ( Raglu VI. 71 ). It is not unlikely that a very long pedigree was manufactured for the glory of the family of Rama and Kalidasa was not pre pared to accept it in its entirety. It may be noted that BƒÅna in the Harsacarita ( 6th uc—ÅhvƒÄsa p. 38 of my edition ) holds that Raghu was the son of Dilipa.

Both the epics inspired many later writers to compose Sanskrit dramas based on the characters and the various stories contained in them. The Dasar≈´paka416 recommend

Pooh

416 ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•§

‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•É‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§ö‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§É ‡•• ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï I. OE

384

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

that intending dramatists should rely upon the RƒÅmƒÅyana and the B»ôhatkatbƒÅ for plots. Dr. V. Raghavan recently published a work on ‘Some old lost RƒÅma plays’ (Annamalai University, 1961).

It appears from Kautilya’s Artha≈õƒÅstra that it knew the central story of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and that of the RƒÅmƒÅyana. For example, on I. 6. 8 ( Artha≈õƒÅstra ) it is stated that RƒÅvana perished since he did not restore another’s wife owing to pride and Duryodhana perished because he on account of pride did not agree to give a portion of the kingdom. In Artha≈õƒÅstra VIII. 3. 41-43 reference is made to Jayatsena and Duryodhana winning in gambling because of expertness in it and Nala and Yudhisthira lost in gambling. In the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata, however, Nala’s opponent is said to have been Puskara ( and not Jayatsena). There is little to show that the ArthasƒÅstra refers to literary works like the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and the RƒÅmƒÅyana and not to tales current among people in its day.

The MahƒÅbbƒÅrata is predominently a Vaimna vite work and contains two of the five jewels of Vuisuavism viz. the Gƒ´tƒÅ and the one thousand names of Visnu (in Anu≈°ƒÅsana parva 149. 14-120).

But it is not at all so thorough going in its dogma as are some medieval South Indian works of the 11th and later centuries A. D. The Anu≈°ƒÅsana ( 17. 31‚Äì153 ) contains 1008 names of Siva also. In many places the identity of Siva and Vi≈°≈Üu is emphasized as in Vanaparva and Santiparva.416 There are grand eulogies of Siva in Dronaparva 80. 39-48 and Sau ptikaparva 17 ( this last by Krsna ). In Anu≈°ƒÅsana (16.8) Siva is identified with Bruhman.

418 ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•á ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•à ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡••

  1. The Two Epics

The Mausala parva417 ( chap. 7) varrates that, after Krona passed away, Arjuna went alone to DvƒÅrakƒÅ in order to bring his wives and the YƒÅdava women to the PƒÅrdava capi tal, that Arjuna was attacked by the Abhiras on his way and the Abhiras forcibly carried away many ladies and some went with them of their own free will. Moreover, in Salya Parva 61. 28 ff,418 where Duryodhana, being mortally wounded by a mace stroke on the thigh by Bhima, severely upbraided Vasudeva for the breaches of the rules such as putting up Sikhandip against Bhisma and Yudhisthira’s prevarication about the death of AsvatthƒÅmƒÅ. Then Vasudeva referred to Duryodhana’s evil deeds ( verses 42-47 ), such as not giving & share to Pandavas in the paternal estate, poisoning Bbima, trying to burn Pandavas together with their mother in

jatugƒºha', taking by force Draupadi to the SabbƒÅ when she was in her monthly period, assault on the very young Abhi manyu by many of Duryodhana’s partisans, and added that he Wag killed for all these misdeeds. The text says that the gods showered flowers on Duryodhana and Gandharvas played on musical instruments &c. (verses 55-58). If the great epic had been a thoroughgoing Vaishave work these incidents would not have been mentioned by it.

A few passages 419 common to two or more works with slight variations from among (Artha≈õƒÅstra of Kau≈£ily., MakƒÅbhƒÅrata, Manu, MahƒÅbhƒÅsya, and RƒÅmƒÅyana are here set out and some have already been mentioned above ).

DE ‡∏™‡πà‡∏á‡πÑ‡∏ß

386

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

THE RƒÄMƒÄYA≈ÖA It is remarkable that an Italian scholar G. Gorrecio, published the text of the RƒÅmƒÅyana in five volumes ( the first being published in 1843 A. D. with a long Introduction of 143 pages and the UttarakƒÅnda being omitted ) and five more volumes of translations, Prefaces and Indexes, the 10th volume being published in 1858 A. D. The RƒÅmƒÅyana has been edited in several places e. g. by the Gujarati Press of Bombay in seven volumes ( with three commentaries ) and by the Nirnaya sƒÅgara Press (text in two volumes ) in 1905. A critical edition of the RƒÅmƒÅyana on the lines of the Poona critical edi tion of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata was undertaken at Baroda and 80 far the first three kƒÅndas have been issued. In the present edition of the H. of Dh. the one volume edition of the text of the RƒÅmƒÅyana published by Mr. R. Narayanaswami Aiyar and edited by a committee of four scholars in 1933 and based on four palm-leaf mss. and several printed editions has been used.

There are several recensions of the RƒÅmƒÅyana, three being well-known, viz. the Southern represented by the Guja rati Press edition in seven parts and the Nir. edition in two parts, the Bengali recension (represented by Gorrecio’s edi tion ) and North-western recension represented by the edition of the RƒÅmƒÅyana published by the D. A. V. College, Lahore in 1923 ff. The Southern recension is the most widely spread of the three. Jacobi found differences in these recen sions and classified them and arrived at the following conclusions :- (1) Each recension differs from both or one of the other two in the common verses, the Southern recension

( Continued from the previous page ) ( 5 ) ‡§è‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶

Hotarafa il t. X. 6. 51, Jan. 33. 43. (6) SERT BE A quala 71 asteht thaila HIT&F: 1 . XII. 1-2 ;

  1. The Two Epics

387

having the more original text; ( 2 ) each recension has a good number of verses, longer pageages and sometimes whole can tos which are not found in one of the other two recensions or in both the other recensions ; (3) the sequence of the verses is often different in two or sometimes in all three recensions. Jacobi found that in the first 30 cantos of Ki≈ükindhƒÅ 749 ver ses were common out of a total of 1303 verses in Southern recension and 1228 in East Bengal recension. Prof. C. Bulcke finds that of the 4202, verses of the N. W. version of Sundara kƒÅnda, 31 percent are absent from the Bengal version and 28 percent from the Southern Recension and 13 percent exclu sively belong to the N. W. recension (vide Poona Orientalist, vol. 25 at p. 37) and adds that the narrative changes very little and that the additional verses are often due to repeti tion of laments, consolations and fuller descriptions of events already narrated. He advances the plausible theory that all three recensions were reduced to writing independently on the basis of a text which had been transmitted orally for several centuries by professional singers who had committed the poem to memory. Prof. C. Bulcke (of Allahabad Univer sity ) in his careful paper on the ( three RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa recensions) examines these divergences in the recensions (in J. O. R., Madras vol. 17 pp. 1-32 ) and arrives at the conclusion that, in spite of the divergeuces the subject matter of the RƒÅmƒÅ yana viz. the narrative itself has been changed very little. He examines 152 cases from the seven k√§ndas and shows, (A) how in some cases the subject matter occurring in the Southern recension is absent from one recension or from both of the other recensions ; (B) the subject matter not found in the Southeru recension is in some cases present in one or both of the other recensions; and lastly (C) there are other differen ces among the tbree recensions which cannot be classified under either A or B. He points out places where entire sar. gas or fairly long passages are not present in all the recen sions even if they do not contain any new subject matter.

A few striking illustrations of the divergence in the three recensions may be cited here :

1 In the BƒÉlakƒÅnda, the auspicious conjunctions of the planets in certain signs of the Zodiac ( R√°≈õis ) at the birth of RƒÅma and his brothers occur in the Southern recension but

888

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

i

are absent in the other two;420 (2) a long poetic description of the Ganges in Ayodhya ( 50. 13-24 ) is absent in the other two recensio

censions: 13 ) the condemnation of Buddha as n≈´stiku ( atheist ) and as resembling a thief occurs in AyodhyƒÅ ( chap. 109.34 ) in Southern recension but is absent in Gorrecio’s ed. aud the whole chap. is absent in N. W. recension; (4) Two sargas, 62 and 63, of AranyakƒÅ≈Üda (in S. recension ) are absent from both Bengal and N. W. recensions; (5) a group of six sargas (10-15 ) in Yuddha-kƒÅnda in S. recension is entirely absent from the Bengali recension and partly from N. W. recension.

Many of the quotations from the RƒÅmƒÅyana in medieval digests are not found in the current editions of the epic, e.g. the DƒÅnasagara of BallƒÅlasena, king of Bengal (composed in sake 1091 i.e. 1169-70 A.D.) quotes four verses from the RƒÅmƒÅyana of which only one is found in the Yuddhakanda (18.30), acc. to Mr. Bhabtosh Bhattacharya in his paper on

The RƒÅmƒÅyana and its influence on BallƒÅlasena and Raghu nandana' in J. O. I. ( Baroda ) vol. II (pp. 18-22). Vide Dr. Bhabatosh Bhattacharya’s' Studies in Dharma≈õƒÅstra' pub lished in ‘Indian Studies’ (past and present) in 1964, in which he gives a list of verses from RƒÅmƒÅyana in seven digests (from DanasƒÅgara and others) which can be identified (pp. 53-55) and

another list on pp. 55-56, where verses quoted as from RƒÅmƒÅyana in the same works cannot be identified. In another paper on the RƒÅmƒÅyana and its influence upon the medieval digests of Eastern India Dr. Bhabatosh Bhattacharya shows that the early medieval works like the HƒÅralatƒÉ of Aniruddha and the three RatnƒÅkaras of Candesvara on Krtya, Grhastha and VivƒÅda, quote the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa sparingly, e. g. Aniruddha quotes only five verses and the Ratnakaras quote only four verses and that it is only the later medieval works such as the three out of the four Kaumudis of Govindananda that quote fourteen verses from the RƒÅmƒÅyana, most of which are found in all recensions of the Ramayana and the Rajadharmakaus tubha of Anantadeva quotes in all 39 verses from the RƒÅmƒÅ. yana but many of these verses do not tally exactly with the three recensions of the RƒÅmƒÅyana.

It should be noted that the UttarakƒÅnda shows no diffe rence worth mentioning. Therefore, it may be assumed that that kƒÅnda is not only the work of later interpolators, but it must have been composed after the original poem was bifur. cated into the Southern recension and Northern recension. The Mahabharata narrates the Rama story in Vanaparva (chap. 273-292 ) in about 750 verses. It may be noticed that some of the incidents mentioned in the UttarakƒÅnda occur in the Raghuvamsa of KƒÅlidƒÅsa. For example, Rama’s spy called Bhadra was ordered by RƒÅma on his return to AyodhyƒÅ after the destruction of RƒÅvana and his forces to report what was talked in the capital and the kingdom by the citizens and other people about himself ( RƒÅma ), about SitƒÅ and about his brothers (Uttara. chap. 43. 4-6). Then, Bhadra, after repeating what people said about RƒÅma’s ex ploits, stated that people talked disparagingly about taking back SitƒÅ, whom RƒÅvana had placed on his lap when carrying her away and had imprisoned in the Asokavanikƒ´ and that the subjects remarked that they would have to endure, if similar incidents happened in the case of their wives.431 In the 421 ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ

‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∂‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§π‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø

‚Ä¢

Raghuvamsa (14.31 ) also the spy is called Bhadra. It is clear that Kalidasa knew the UttarakƒÅnda. The Raghuvamsa in chapter 15 closely follows the UttarakƒÅnda. A few inci dents may be set out. Raghuo. 15. 81-84 may be compared with UttarakƒÅnda 97. 15‚Äì17. Compare also Raghu. 15.87-90 with Uttarao chap. 100, Raghu 15. 89-90 with Uttarao chap. 101-102, Raghu, 15. 92-95 with Uttarao 103-5, Raghu 15. 97-98 with Uttarao 107. KƒÅlidƒÅsa in Raghu (14.70) echoes the very words of the RƒÅmƒÅyana ( BƒÅlakƒÅ≈Üda+38 2. 18 and 40).

It should be noted that at the end of the Yuddhakanda there is a long phalu≈õruti about the fruits of reading it and there is another at the end of the UttarakƒÅnda also.+23 Besides, the first canto of the BalakƒÅnda gives a synopsis of the whole of the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa up to RƒÅma’s becoming a king after return ing from his victory over R√•vana, in which there is no reference to the subject matter of the BƒÅla k√§nda or of the UttarakƒÅnda. Then, again, in the 3rd chap. of the B√•lakanda there is a summary of events from RƒÅma’s birth up to his abandonment of SitƒÅ. It follows that even at the time of this second table of contents the Uttarakinda had not come up to its present form. Dr. Bulcke is not right when he says (on p. 41 of his paper in Poona Orientalist Vol. XXV) that Laks mana was unmarried as RƒÅma gays in Aranya-kƒÅnda ( 18.3). The learned writer forgets that RƒÅma was making fun of S≈´rpa≈ÜakhƒÅ who wanted Rima to marry her and therefore he (RƒÅma who had Sitii with him) jocosely said that Lakomana (unaccompanied by a woman ) was unmarried and that she might approach him. But this was all spoken iu fun, as is made clear by the word ‘parihƒÅs≈´vicalc≈üanƒÅ’ applied to S√ºr panakh√£ (not clever enough to understand the ridicule and the joke). Balakanda, chap. 73 verses 30-33 specify the names of the wives of RƒÅma and his brothers and AyodbyƒÅ chap. 118.53 expressly says that Urmilƒ´ was married to Lak≈ümala.

  1. The Two Epics

391

The RƒÅma story is frequently alluded to in the extant MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. The story of the golden deer424 ( M√°rica ) whose beautiful skin SitƒÅ longed to have ( Ara·πáyakƒÅnda. chap. 43-44 ) is referred to in the Sabh√§arva 76.5. The Vana parva (chapters 147.31 to 148.19 ) summarizes the RƒÅma story and ends with the verse that RƒÅma ruled the kingdom for eleven thousand years. This verse occurs in the RƒÅmƒÅ ya≈Üa also ( Yuddha 131.106 ). The Dronaparva (chap. 59 ) describes the excellence of RƒÅmarƒÅjya. The Dronaparva (196. 36 ) compares the death of Drona to the death of VƒÅlin. A large volume would have to be written if one were to deal with all questions relating to the two epics. I hold that there is no doubt that there existed a BhƒÅrata Epic before there was a RƒÅmƒÅyana ( Vide’the Great Epic of India' by Hopkins, as he says on p. 61 ). Jacobi’s German work on the RƒÅmƒÅyana has been translated into English by Dr. Ghoshal piecemeal in the Volumes of the Journal of the Oriental Institute, Baroda, in vol. V onwards.

In the Salyaparva (39.9‚Äì10 ) reference is made to the cutting of the head of a raksasa by RƒÅma in Janasth√§na. In the Santiparva425 is mentioned the story of the return to life of a brƒÅhmana boy ( who had died prematurely ) when RƒÅma killed Samb≈´ka, a s√ºdra practising peuance. The SƒÅptiparva speaks of the death of RƒÅvana at the hands of RƒÅma who was angered by RƒÅvana. 426 The Drona parva compares the fight of Ghatotkaca and Alayudha with the fight of RƒÅma and Ravaya ( 96.27-28 ).

All verse quotations in the MahƒÅbhƒÅsya are collected in one place by Kielhorn in I. A. vol. 14 the pp. 326-327

‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡•• 4793 148.19 ; Torak 59. 21-22 ( 2nd half is a:7777 THT 1139441897 ); T2711A¬• ( p. 130 ) bas (796FERENTIAT Fig Tre valla el frauliai HEITIG TIA 1551 376150ita i verse 93. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ï‡•á ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§π‡§®‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø

PTIKATI 11 12a 163. 67. 428 ‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¶‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§π‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§£:

17”) 12892

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Another question much discussed by some Western scholars is the relation of the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa to the Dasarath√° jƒÅtaka. Reasons of space prevent any detailed discussion. The Dasarathaj√§taka ( No. 461 in Fausb√∂ll’s edition, vol. IV) is a travesty of the RƒÅma story. In it SitƒÅ is a sister of RƒÅna, Dasaratha is a king of Benares (and not of Ayodhya ) who is said to have had 16000 wives and Sƒ´tƒÅ ( a sister ) is made queen after RƒÅma’s return from the forest. There is nothing peculiarly Buddhist in it. The JƒÅtakas forma later part of the Pali literature. Rhys Davids in ‘Buddbist India ‘furnishes a chronological table of Buddhist litera ture from Buddha’s times to Asoka and divides it into ten groups of which the J√°takas and Dhammapadas form the 7th. The J√°takas are not earlier than 250 B. C. and may be later by a century or more. It is not unreasonable to suppose that the germs of most of the JƒÄtaka stories were derived from the folk-lore of India existing in those times. They are meant to glorify Buddha in his suppo sed previous existences and, while using well-known names, try (probably purposely ) to make these names (except that of the Bodhisattva) ridiculous. For example, the Kanha DipƒÅyana JƒÅtaka No. 444 ( its prose being in two distinct parts ) makes it clear that none of the traits of the most famous sage of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata can be traced in the JƒÅtaka called after him. The JƒÅtakas generally contain some G√§thƒÅs and some prose passages. In a number of JƒÅtakas the prose parts are in conflict with the gƒÉthƒÅs or have nothing to do with them. The prose parts in their present form belong to 5th cent. A. D. and arose in Ceylon. Jacobi (Das RƒÅm√• yana pp. 84 ff) and Keith (JRAS. 1915 p. 323 ) hold that the prose parts of JƒÅtakas are confused and belong to a later date. Two questions arise viz. (1) Does the Dasarathe jƒÅtaka present an older form of the R√§ma story? (2) Is the Dasaratha JƒÅtaka really older than the RƒÅmƒÅyana ? Accor ding to the present author the replies to these two questions are in the negative and he agrees with the conclusions of the late Mr. N. B. Utgikar (in JRAS. Centenary Supplement pp. 203-211 ). Vide also the same scholar’s paper in LABRAS ( New Series vol. 4 pp. 115‚Äì134 ). In most of the Patuks also the stories as told in the Epic differ greatly from the stories labelled under the same name in them.

Stilts

?4:117 11

1?

  1. The Two Epics

393

In the DasarathajƒÉtaka ( No. 461, p. 127 ) occurs a gƒÅtha (‘phalƒÅnam iva pakkƒÅnam nicca·πÅ papatanƒÅ bhayam I evam j√°tƒÅnƒÅm maccƒÅnam niccam maranato bhayamil’), which occurs in Gorrecio’s edition (vol. II p. 42, verse 4) and is quoted below*** (but does not occur in other editions ).

Just as in the extant MahƒÅbhƒÅrata references are some times made to the RƒÅma story, so in the extant RƒÅmƒÅyana occur references to the legends that occur in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. For example, the story of Savitri (daughter of Asva pati, king of the Madras, and wife of Satyavan, son of Dyumat sena, the blind king of S√§lva ) well-known to all Indian women as the paragon of wifely virtue, is described in Vana parva (chap. 293-299), is very briefly mentioned in the Ayodhyakanda, where+18 Rama first expressed his unwilling Dess to allow SitƒÅ to accompany him in his forest exile. It should be noted that the verse speaks of Savitri’s story as well-known and does not dilate on any of the incidents connected with that story. It is again referred to in Sun darakƒÅnda 24.11. In the SundarakƒÅnda (chap. 24 10-12 ) six pativratus are named among whom Damayanti is the last.458 The story of Nala, king of Ni≈üadha, and his devoted wife Damayanti is one of the longest ƒÅkhyƒÅnas in the MahƒÅbha rata and is a very charming one. It is set out in the Vana parva, chapters 52-79. Cyavana was a son of Bhrgu. Vana parva (chap. 122-124 ) narrates at some length how Suka nyƒÅ, daughter of king SaryƒÅti, had to marry the sage blinded by her through mistake. She stuck to the old and blinded Cyavana, although the Asvins sought her hand. It should be noticed that most of these stories occur in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata

427 ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞

HEUTSOURI 428 ‡§∂‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∏‡§®‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

and some (like those of SƒÅvitrƒ´, Damayanti and Sukanya ) at great length, while the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa employs them only for com parison and does not set them out at length. Sagara is referred to in the RƒÅmƒÅyana (AyodhyƒÅ 36.16 about Asama√±ja). But no reference is made to his wives. In Vana parva (chap. 106-7) it is stated that Sagara was a descendant of IksvƒÅku, had two wives, Vaidarbhi and SaibyƒÅ, had from SaibyƒÅ one son called Asama√±ja whom he banished because he indulged in the pastime of drowning the children of the subjects (Santi, chap. 57.8-9 ) and Sagara had sixty thousand sons from Vaidarbhi who were all reduced to ashes by Kapila’s wrath when they dug the earth, found A≈õvamedha horse near sage Kapila and wanted to apprehend Kapila as the thief. The story of Uttarka, a devoted pupil of Gautama, is narrated at length in Advamedhika parva chap. 55-58 and in Vanaparva chap. 132‚Äì33. He married the daughter of Gau tama and requested AhalyƒÅ, Gautama’s wife, to accept some present as Gurudaksi≈ÜƒÅ (fee). When Uttanka pressed her to accept something, she asked him to bring the jewelled ear rings of the wife of king Saud√°sa- man-eater ( 56.31 ). He went to SaudƒÅga and begged for the ear-rings of his wife Madayanti. SaudƒÅsa asked him to see his wife and give her his message. A long story is narrated about the ear-rings which she gave. King Janaka held assemblies of learned men for discussion. One bandin (i. e. s≈´ta at his court ) used to argue with learned men, defeated them and plunged them in water. Uddalaka had a pupil Kahoda, who married the daughter of his guru. She conceived and the child in the womb rebuked his father when he committed mistakes in re peating Veda. The father cursed the foetus that he would be defective in eight limbs. AstƒÅvakra defeated bandin and those who had been thrown into water (including Kahoda who had been defeated by Bandin ) were revived by Varuna and then Kahoda recited a verse set out in the note below.480 YayƒÅti is frequently mentioned for comparison or illustration as in AyodhyƒÅ 5. 10 ( same words in Ki≈ükindhƒÅ 17. 9, viz. ‘yayƒÅtim-iva punyƒÅnte devalokƒÅd-iba cyutam’, also Ara·πáyeo

  1. The Two Epics

395

    1. ‚ÄúJƒÅmadagnya RƒÅma killed his mother at his father’s order (AyodhyƒÅ 21. 33 ); Visnu taking three steps ( Ki≈ükindhƒÅ 67. 3 and 25 ).

The SundarkƒÅnda is regarded by scholars as part of the original epic. Therefore, it is probable that the part of Sun darkƒÅ≈Üda which mentions the names of six pativratas, the stories about whom occur at length in the Vanaparva and A≈°vamedhika-parva, is probably later than the parvan: (Vana and Asvamedhika ) which are held by several scholars to be later than earlier parvans of the great Epic.

Nalak≈´bara is said to have cursed RƒÅvana when the latter ravished apsaras RambhƒÅ (Vanaparva 280.59-60, Uttara kƒÅnda 26. 15 and 41 ff’) who had an assignment with Nalak≈´bara, son of Vaisravana, brother of RƒÅvana; on hearing about this he cursed RƒÅvana that his head would be shattered in seven pieces if he dared to ravish any woman. In the YuddbakƒÅnda ( 122. 16 ) it is stated that Dasaratha ( who had died and had gone to heaven ) came in a heavenly car to meet RƒÅma after his victory over RƒÅvana and said . You have saved me as the brƒÅhma·πáa Kabola was saved by AstƒÅvakra.’ The story of Ast√°vakra, son of Kahoda is narrated in Vana parva chap. 132-4. King Nrga while making gifts of cows to brƒÅhma·πáas, by mistake donated the cow belonging to a brƒÅh mana which had strayed among the cows belonging to the king and when the brƒÅhmana lodged a complaint against the recipient of his cow before the king, the latter did not look into the matter for many days and the two brƒÅhmanas cursed him to be a chameleon. That story is referred to in ApusƒÅ. sana 6. 38, Asvamedhika 90. 99-100 and AnusƒÅsana 70 (at length ) and 72. 2.

Taking the cue from the name SitƒÅ (the heroine of the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa ) several scholars have regarded the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa as an allegory, the word SitƒÅ being employed twice in the Rgveda (IV. 57.6 and 7) and apostrophized as a goddess.481 Three personages are known to our mythology as RƒÅma, viz. JƒÅme dagaya RƒÅma ( or Parasurama ), BalarƒÅma ( brother of Krsna )

‡§∏‡§∏‡§ø ‡•• ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ ‡•• ‡§ã. IV. 57. 8-7. ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ means tho furrow loft Parent plough.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

and DƒÅ≈õarathi Rama. It is unnecessary for the history of Dharmasastra to deal with this question when the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa is admitted by all scholars as separated from the Rgveda by at least a thousand years or more.

It has been stated above that the core of the RƒÅmƒÅyana story may be only as old as 300-250 B. C. at the most. Asva ghosa432 in his Buddhacarita refers to VƒÅlmƒ´ki as writing a poetical work when Cyavana ( his ancestor ) did not do 80. Besides, the Raghuvamsa closely follows the UttarakƒÅnda as shown above. If we accept the date of KƒÅlidƒÅga as between 350 to 450 A. D., then the Ramayana in its present form can not be placed later than about 200 A. D. and may be placed at least a century or two earlier. In the KiskiudhƒÅ-kƒÅnda two verses have been expressly quoted as recited by Manu which occur in the present Manu.433 In Ayodhya 107.11-13 two verses are stated to have been uttered by Gaya in Gaya with reference to pitrs.434

The RƒÅmƒÅyana being mainly a K√°vya is not frequently or profusely quoted by works on Dharma≈õƒÅstra, particularly by comparatively earlier ones. Among the early commentators, MedhƒÅtithi on Manu IV. 217 refers to the RƒÅmƒÅyana as pre scribing SrƒÅddha on the 4th, 8th, 9th and 10th days after the death of a person. On Manu V. 7 MedhƒÅtithi quotes without naming the RƒÅmƒÅyana a half verse from it (yadanna·∏• puruso

rƒÅjan-tadannƒÅstasya devatƒÅ·∏• ).436 It may be noted that the Dhvanyaloka ( a Kashmirian work on Poetics of the latter half of the 9th century A. D. ) quotes a verse from the Aranya-kanda ( 16. 18 ) as an example where the Vyaigya ( suggested ) sense pushes the literal sense ( vƒÅcya ) of the word ( undhu in that verse ) very much in the background (atyanta-tiraskxta-vacya ).438_ In spite of this writers on Sanskrit Poetics rarely quote or refer to it.

Even AparƒÉrka who quotes the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata dozens of times quotes the RainƒÅyana only twice. 437 On YƒÅj. I. 211 AparƒÅrka quotes & verse saying of one who being able to save a sarunƒÅgatu allows him to die in his presence all merit ( sukrta i.e. punya ) is taken away by the one who is not saved ). On offering water to one’s deceased relations AparƒÅrka ( on Yaj. III. 5) quotes a verse from Ayodhyakanda (102-27 ). The Smrticandrika ( I. p. 57 ) quotes Sundara kanda 59, 35-36 about cessation of study on the first tithi of a month (pratipat-phthasilasya vidyevu tanutam gata). The Krtyakalpataru ( on vrata, brahmacƒÅri, tƒ´rtha and naiyata kƒÅla has no verses froin R√§m≈´yana though Naiyata kƒÅlikƒÅ quotes about two dozen verses from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata). Both epics condemn the king who being engrossed in pleasures does not attend the court of justice when the parties approach him for justice. The Kalpataru on ‘grhastha.’ quotes only two verses from Ramayana, but it mentions the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata

‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§° 18. 30 . by ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï p. 385.

TOTU

POONA

PRINDE 1917

398

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

twenty times, one citation on pp 281-285 quoting 20 verses from AnusƒÅsana ( 11.6-21 ) on where Sri resides. The DƒÅnasƒÅgara composed by king BallƒÅlasena in saka 1091 (1169-70 A.D. ) quotes the Mahabharata over 200 times, but quotes from the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa only four verses.488

In the Rajanitiratnakara of Candesvara (ed. by K. P. Jayaswal ), verses about the right of the eldest son to succeed to his father are supported by quotations from the RƒÅmƒÅ yana.430

Indian culture penetrated to Borneo, Java, Bali and other Indonesian islands. In the RƒÅmƒÅyana, Sugrƒ´va is said to have sent his followers in search of SitƒÅ in the four quarters. He directs them to the countries in the East and names Yavadvƒ´pa (Java) as one of them (in KiskindhƒÅ 40.29-30 ).440 Ptolemy (in his Geography of India about 150 A.D.) refers to it as

‚Ä¢ Jabadien'. It is generally accepted that Java and Sumatra had been Hinduized before the 3rd century A.D. This is not the place to go into the question of the cultural migration from India to the Eastern Archipelago. Vide Dr. Bijan Raj Chatterjee’s ‘India and Java’ (Calcutta, 1933 ). The culture .of South-East Asia' by Reginald le May (pub. in 1954) with 216 illustrations at the end ; ‘South India and the Eastern Archipelago’, in the Krsnaswamy Aiyangar Vol. by C. S. Srinivasachari pp. 483-497 ; ‘Sanskrit Texts from Bali’ edited by Prof. Sylvain Levi ( G. O. S. 1933 ); - Indian influence on the Literature of Java and Bali' by H. B. Sarkar ( Calcutta, 1934 ); Stutterheim’s RƒÅma legenden' and

‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø' ‡•• 439 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡•á ‡§ú‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Ü‡§π ‡•§ ‡§á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§≤ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§

‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§≤ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§ó‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•Å | 440 ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§á‡§§‡§Æ ‡•§

‡§Ø‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡•§‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ 40. 29-30.

  1. The Two Epics

399

' Pictorial History of civilization in Java ;' History of Srivijaya' by Prof. K. A. Nilakanta Sastri (1949 ); ‘Hindu Law in Java and Bali’ by Dr. R. C. Majumdar in S. K. Aiyangar Memorial Volume pp. 445-461.

The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata became very popular in Java; the Javanese puppet shows called ‘wayang’ have preserved the old Hindu traditions even in these days, though Java has been * Moslem country for five centuries. Tantric doctrines also prevailed in Java and Sumatra. The RƒÅmƒÅyana exists in Bali in the Kavi language. There exist several recensions of the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa in Java, both in verse and probe.

Some incidents of the Rama story are represented in the Javanese ¬∑ Wayang' (shadow plays ). Dr. Bijan Raj Chatterjee in India and Java' p. 29 states ‚Äú In a 6th century inscription of Cambodia we find the following passage with the RƒÅmƒÅ yana and the Purana he (the Brahman Soma≈õarman ) gave the complete Mahabharata and arranged for a daily recitation without interruption'. About India’s influence on architecture in Indonesia Levi writes ‚ÄúIn Architecture it is in distant Cambodia and distant Java that we have to look for the two wonders produced by the Indian genius, Angkor and Boro Budur'( q. from Srivijaya ‘by Prof. Nilakanta Sastri p. 11 ).

Two interesting chapters in the two epics are known as Kaccit-pra≈õna’ chapters. They are SabhƒÅ-parva chap. 5 verses 17-110 and 114-125 (in all 106 verses ) where the sage NƒÅrada asks Yudhisthira certain questions about what an ideal king is expected to do in all that concerns the Govern ment of the State and the people, and AyodhyƒÅkƒÅnda chap.100 verses 76 ( of which the first five are introductory in which RƒÅma, who was staying on Citrak≈´ta along with Sit√£ and Lak≈ümala ), inquires of Bharata about the Government of Ayodhy√° after RƒÅma left.441 In verses 6-10 RƒÅma asks Bharata about Dasaratha, about the UpƒÅdhyƒÅya ( Vasistha ) of the family and about his mother and step-mother; so in the RƒÅmƒÅyana only 66 verses are properly concerned with the Government of the country, the king’s duties and actions and cognate matters, while in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata these matters are

The word ‘Kaccit’ is employed when the person asking the question desires to receive a favourable reply, as the Amarako≈õa says ‘Kaccit kƒÅmapravedane’. The RƒÅmƒÅyana, employs this word in other passages also as in BalakƒÅnda 52. 7-9. From this analysis it follows that out of 66 verses in which the word lcuccit occurs in the RƒÅmƒÅyana 29 are almost the same as in Sabh√•parva and there also a few half verses, pƒÅdas ( quarters of a verse ), which are the same but are not noted here. Another weighty criticism is that at the time when this kaccit chapter is supposed to have been addressed by him to Bharata, RƒÅma did not know that king Dasaratha was dead. It is after this chapter that Bharata tells RƒÅma (in chap. 101. 5-6 ) that after Rima left for the forest the king died, being overwhelmed by sorrow. Therefore, some of the questions put in the mouth of RƒÅma are inappropriate and irrelevant, such as the questions about the honour paid to UpƒÅdhyƒÅya, about Purohita, Mantrins, SenƒÅpati and duta. All these high functionaries had been appointed by Dasaratha himself. On the other hand, in the case of Yudhisthira, who was the eldest among the sons of Pandu and who performed the RƒÅjas≈´ya also ( also as described in SabhƒÅ 33 ff ), those questions were appropriate. I think the chapter ( 100 ) of the AyodhyƒÅkƒÅnda is based on chap. 5 of the SabhƒÅparva and about 29 verses were almost bodily taken from the sheet parva into the AyodhyƒÅkƒÅnda.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

popular and is relied upon as a source in digests on Dharma, though not so frequently and profusely as the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. Vide for example, Dr. Bhabatosh Bhattƒ´cƒÅrya’s paper on * RƒÅmƒÅyana and its influence on medieval digests of East India' in Gode com. volume pp. 19-26. The following table will give some idea of the different topics of Dharma≈õƒÅstra dwelt upon by the Ramayana. The references are to the Madras one volume edition referred to above (p. 399 n. 441 ).

Abhiseka-AyodhyƒÅ 15, Yuddha 131. ArƒÅjaka-AyodhyƒÅ 67. PƒÅtakas (sins )- KiskindhƒÅ 17-18. RƒÅjadharma-Balakanda 7, AyodhyƒÅ 100, Aranya 6, 9, 33,

40-41, Yuddha 17, 18, 63. SrƒÅddha-AyodhyƒÉ 76, 103. Satyapra≈°amsƒÉ-Ayodhyƒ´ 109. Strƒ´dharma-AyodhyƒÅ 24-27, 29, 39, 117-118.

It must be stated that whole cantos are unauthorizedly added in some cases in the RƒÅmƒÅyana e.g. in the UttarakƒÅnda after chap. 23 five surgas ( containing 296 verses ) are added. Five more are added after chap. 37 ( containing 244 verses ) and three cantos are added after chap. 59 ( containing 145 verses ).

Another matter to be noted is that not only are unautho rized verses added in the RƒÅmƒ´yana but here and there verses are repeated e.g. several verses in AyodhyƒÅ 105. 4-12 and Yuddha 131. 2-10. It has been already shown that about 29 verses ( with ‘kaccit’ in them ) have been borrowed from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. Moreover, several verses are common to both the epics (e. g. vide pp. 385-386 above).

The claim, put forward in the Balakanda (chap. 2, verses 3-31 ), that Valmiki, on seeing the Krau≈Ñca bird killed by a hunter, uttered a verse ( ≈õloka ) that was to be the pattern or model for all succeeding poets composing poems in that matters cannot be admitted as tenable. The RƒÅmƒÅyana as a K cannot be claimed on the available evidence as earlier things 300-200 B. C.

  1. The Two Epics

403

Quotations in the MahƒÅbh√¢sya lead to the conclusion that, centuries before Pata√±jali, works in the Sloka metre bad been composed. A few examples quoted below will bear out this.442

Verses in the SundarakƒÅndia*4.3 are of great significance on the date of the Ramiyana. Han≈´min is said to have pondered over the question whether he should address Sita in Sanskrit used by DvijƒÅtis ( brƒÅlimanas, ksatriyas and vaisyas ) or he should employ sentences used by common men ( vide note below). There is hardly anything to show that about 400 or 500 B. C. there was a vast difference between the languages spoken by higher classes and those spoken by lower classes. But a century or two before and after the Christian era great differences had arisen between the two as indicated by Inscrip tions aud literary works.

I cannot close this brief section on the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa without mentioning a work of outstanding merit viz. ‚Ä¢Thirty lectures

1917

404

History of Dharƒ±na≈õƒÅstra

on the RƒÅmƒÅyana' by ths late Right Honourable V. S Srinivasa Sastri ( publisheil by the Madras Sanskrit Academy in 1949). He does not real with the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa in the spirit of a critical scholar. Questions of the date of the RƒÅmƒÅyana, the authorship of it, of the indebtedness of VƒÅlmiki to others and of the authenticity of the present text are left out by him. He deals at great length with the principal characters of the epic and his language is moving, often charged with fervour and emotion and his exposition of the different incidents is masterly. He quotes a very large number of verses from the RƒÅmƒÅyana. In his exposition he is at his best when he deals with the attack by RƒÅma against V√§lin from behind trees and the incident of harsh words RƒÅma used when he abandoned SitƒÅ after killing RƒÅvana ( YuddhakƒÅnda, 118, verses 12-24) His words are most eloquent when in the 27th lecture on p. 432 he says ‘that is RƒÅma’s greatness that he did not mind sacrificing anything to preserve Dharma. Dharma has many pbases. What he ( RƒÅma ) thought was his highest Dbarma, that he fulfilled and to that end there was nothing that be would not sacrifice’. It may be pointed out that the Padma purƒÅ≈Üa (Ananda≈õram ed. IV. 66. 28-29 ,444 proclaims in two verses the virtues that the RƒÅmiyana emphasizes by delineat ing some paragons of virtue such as RƒÅma, SitƒÅ, Bharata, Laksmana and Han≈´mƒÅn.

Though the RƒÅmƒÅyana is full of poetic passages, it often departs from Panini’s grammar. A few examples may be cited; * Kurmi‚Äô ( for karomi ) in Ayodhya 12. 36, ‘ƒÅnayitum’ (for ‘ƒÅnetum’) in AyodhyƒÅ 19. 10 and ‘nayisyati ( for ' nesyati’) in AyodhyƒÅ 12. 87, ‘rusya’ Ayodhya 97. 12, Mantrimsca' in SundarakƒÅnda 51. 37 ( for Mantri≈Üasca ).

The Gujarati Press edition of the RƒÅmƒÅyana ( in seven parts, 1912-20 ) contains three commentaries. A brief statement on these may be made here. Of the three the earliest seems to be the one called Bh≈´sana composed by Govindar√°jan of Kausikagotra. He was a man of profound learning in the various branches of Sanskrit literature. Sometimes his commentary is very extensive ( as on the first verse of the Balakanda ), but sometimes it is the briefest of

POORA

44 ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§π‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§ï‡§∞

‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö ‡•• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡§µ‡§ï‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ò‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§‡•§ ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£.

  1. The Two Epics

405

the three commentaries ( as on I. 75. 4, 1. 76. 15 ). At the end of the BƒÉlakƒÅnda he states that he had acquired fame by his proficiency in the Vedas, SƒÉstras and learned discussions and he had a keen intellect in Sanskrit poems, AlwinkƒÅra ( Poetics ) and the dramatic art. This writer confers different names on his own commentaries on the different k√§ndas viz. Manimanjira, Pitambara, RatnamekhalƒÅ, MuktƒÅhƒÅra, Srng√§ra tilaka, Ratnakiri≈£a, Manimukuta. It appears that Satakopa of Vatsa-gotra was his guru and he was the son of Varada ( last verse in com. on Yuddhakanda ). At the end of his commentary on Sundarakanda, he states that he looked into several commentaries of former ƒÅcƒÅryas.

As he quotes the KƒÄvyaprakƒÅ≈õa, the AlankƒÅrasarvasva and the V»ôtta-ratnƒÅkura he is certainly later than the 12th century A.D. and most probably flourished in the last quarter of the 15th century. Vide an exhaustive paper on Govinda rƒÅja by the late Prof. K. V. Rangaswami Aiyangar in A.B.O.R.I. [ Silver Jubilee vol. (1943), pp. 30-54 ).

The 2nd commentary is called “RƒÅmƒÅyanusiromani'. The author’s name is not clearly stated in the beginning, though at the end of the 7th kƒÅnda the concluding verse clearly says ‘SivasalƒÅya-nirinitiresƒÅ’. So this commentary was written by Siva-sahƒÅya and he composed the commentary on the banks of the Triveni (Ganges at Allahabad ) with the help of a rich patron called Vamsidhura, sou of SitƒÅrƒÅma, son of Todirama. This commentary also is learned and very extensive on some verses. From the last verse ( 8 ) it appears that the commentary was completed in Sarvat 1921, Asvina sukla 10 (i, e. 1864 A. D.). Thus it is a very modern commentary.

The third commentary is called Tilaka.445 The concluding verses 448 of the commentary indicate that the commentary was

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

written by Sri NƒÅge≈õa under the patronage of RƒÅmavarman, The idea of those two verses appears to be that the import of the RƒÅmƒÅyana was made clearer by the clearing cloth in the form of the intellect of RƒÅmavarman. What part other than that of a patron ( who employed an eminent scholar like NƒÅge≈õabhatta ) RƒÅmavarman played is not quite clear. The opening verses of the commentary on the BƒÉlakƒÅnda mention only RƒÅma as the author.

The commentary is learned and to the point and does not make an exhibition of the author’s wide reading and scholar ship.

As would be shown later on NƒÅge≈õa (or NƒÅgojibhatta ) flourished between 1670-1750 A. D.

Vide Prof. P. P. S. Sastri’s paper on The commentators of the RƒÅrnƒ´yana in the 15th to 17th century A. D.‘in A. B. O. R. I. (Silver Jubilee vol. 1943, pp. 413-414 ). He mentions the commentators on the Ramayana mostly from South India, as the Vaisnavas in South India looked upon the RƒÅmƒÅyana as the most sacred work on Visnu wor ship.

In the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata-titparya-nirnaya of Anandatirtha (Sri MadhvƒÅcƒÅrya, 13th century A. D.), seven chapters (III-IX) are devoted to the Ramayana story. In the first chapter he sets out the authorities. In I. 30447 he refers to the four Vedas vin. Rgveda and others, the PancurƒÉtra system, the Bharata, the Mula-RƒÅmƒÅyana, and the Brahmas≈´tra these are regarded as self-sufficient authorities. What does be mean by M≈´la-RƒÅmƒÅyana ? It means nothing else than the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa of VƒÅlmƒ´ki. In Sanskrit and the popular langua

  1. The Two Epics

ges of India there are numerous works having the RƒÅmƒÅyaya as part of their names. At the end of chap. IX (verses 125-7)448 the great AcƒÅrya says ‘through the grace of Visnu he has declared this grand story, by reasoning and by the power of his intellect, after dispelling all contradictions and deciding the truth from all the PurƒÅnas, the works on PancarƒÅtra, from the BhƒÅrata, the Vedas and the great RƒÅmƒÅyana. So here the word MahƒÅrƒÅmƒÅyana is used in the same sense as Mula-RƒÅmƒÅyana, since in both places ( 1-30 ) and (IX. 125 127 ) it is the sources of the RƒÅma saya that are spoken of

Mr. S. N. Tadpatrikar (in ABORI vol. V. pp. 61-68 ) refers to the word ' M√ºlarƒÅmƒÅyana ' and starts a new theory that the M√ºlarƒÅmƒÅyana mentioned in I. 30 by Madh vƒÅcƒÅrya is different from the MahƒÅrƒÅmƒÅya·πáa mentioned by the AcƒÅrya himself in IX. 125. The only authority for this is his inter pretation of some words he quotes from the commentary Tilaka. The few words he quotes are not at all clear and do not support what Mr. Tadpatrikar mentions and further the commentator is no authority binding on modern scholars for the meaning of the words employed by the AcƒÅrya in the 13th century.

The RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa, being a K√°vya and an AkhyƒÅna ( as stated in DƒÅnasƒÅgara, Introductory verse, 15, p. 3), it is sparingly quoted in Dharma≈õƒÅstra works. Dr. Bhabatosh Bhattacharya in his paper on The R≈´mayana and its influence on Ball≈´lasena and Raghunavdana ‘449 published in J. O. I. ( Baroda ), vol II, pp. 18-22 points out that only one out of

the four verses quoted from the RƒÅmƒÅyana in the DƒÅnasƒÅgara could be traced in the YuddhakƒÅnda (chap. 18.30 ¬∑ vinasta·∏• … raksita·∏• ‘) in the Gujarati Press edition and that none of the four verses could be found in the Bengali editions. In another paper on the RƒÅmƒÅyana and its infiuence on the medieval digests of Eastern India’ in P. K. Gode Commemora tion Volume 1960, pp. 319-326, the same learned writer discus ses the quotations from the RƒÅmƒÅyana in the HƒÅralatƒÅ, the three RatnƒÅkaras of Cande≈õvara (on Krtya, Grhastha, and VivƒÅda), Kaumudis of GovindƒÅnanda ( on DƒÅna, SrƒÅddha ), and the RƒÅjadharma-kaustubha of Anantadeva. The Kalpa taru on Moksa (pp. 25-26 ) quotes some verses from the RƒÅm. AranyakƒÅnda (chap. 6.2 ff) with different readings. The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata offers a great contrast in this respect to the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa, as hundreds of verses are quoted from it even in the comparatively early commentaries and digests like the MitƒÅk·π£arƒÅ and the Kalpataru.

It is impossible to deal with the numerous writings on the RƒÅmƒÅyana. Jacobi’s German work on the RƒÅmƒÅyana has been translated into English by Dr. S. N. Ghoshal and published by driblets in several volumes of the Journal of Oriental Institute ( Baroda ). Numerous dates have been proposed for the RƒÅmƒÅyana e. g. the Department of Letters, Vol. 19 ( Calcutta University ) puts down 433 A. D. as its date. The RƒÅma story occurs frequently in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata e. g. vide SabhƒÅparva 50. 39, Vanaparva chap. 148-152 (31 verses ), chap. 274-293 ( verses about 769 ); several PurƒÅ·πáas such as Brahmao, chap. 123 and 154, PadmapurƒÅna ( several times in PƒÉtƒÉlakhanda and Uttarakhanda ), NƒÅrada purƒÅna, BhƒÅgavatapurƒÅna (IX. 10-11 about 82 verses ), Agni purƒÅna (chap. 5-12, verses 189 ). One writer in Prera≈ÜƒÅ ' monthly for October 1949 says that there are fourteen commentaries on the RƒÅmƒÅyana.

  1. The Puranas The YƒÅj≈àavalkyasm»ôti provides that PurƒÅna, NMAYA (Tarka≈õƒÅstra ), MimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ, Dharma≈õƒÅstra, the ( six, subsidiary lores of the Veda (angas ) and the Vedas (four )-these fourteen

  1. The PurƒÅnas

409

are the sources ( means) of Vidyo and of Dharma. It would be noticed that the 14 sources are arranged by YƒÅj√±avalkya in a rising scale of importance and authoritativene88.460 The word PurƒÅna ( a class of works ) occurs in the Atharvaveda (XI. 7. 24, XV. 6. 10-11). The Sat. Br. (XI. 5.6-8 ) includes

Itihasa puranam’ among ‘Sv√§dhyƒÅya’ and furtber states ( XIII. 4. 3. 13 ) that on the 9th day of the PƒÅriplava ( an item in the RƒÅjas√ªya sacrifice) the hotr priest narrates some PurƒÅ≈Üa. The Tai. ƒÄr. II. 10 mentions BrƒÅhma·πáas, ItihƒÅsas, PurƒÅnas, Kalpas etc. ( Br√ºhmannitihƒÉsƒÉn PurƒÅnƒÅni Kalpan, GƒÅthƒÅ NƒÅrƒÅ≈õamsih). In the Chandogya Upanisad ( VII. 2 and 4 ) ItihƒÅsa–PurƒÅna is spoken of as the fifth Veda and the BrbadƒÅranyaka Up. (IV. 1. 2 ) separately mentions Iti hƒÅna and Pur√°na. The ƒÄ≈õv. Gr. includes PurƒÅ·πáƒÅni under ‘svƒÅdhyƒÅya !.461

It is not unlikely that originally there was only a single work called Purana. The MahƒÅbhƒÅsya ( Kielhorn, vol. I p. 9) uses the word Puranam and the Matsya (chap. 53) states that ori. ginally the Purƒ´na was only one. But since the Tai. Ar. emp. loys the word ‘Purƒ´nƒÅni’ in the plural it appears likely that there were in the times of the Aranyaka at least three (if not more) works called Purana. A verse quoted below-PurƒÅnam M√°navo dharmah etc.-‘462 occurs in many copies of the Manus mrti after XII. 110 and is mentioned by the TantravƒÅrtika on MimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅs≈´tra 1.3.27 p. 286 ( Anan. ed., first half).

From early times the Puranas have been enumerated as eighteen ; vide H. of Dh. Vol. V pp. 831-836. The number of upa purƒÅnas varies from a few to several dozens.

FOUNT

IR

410

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

The PurƒÅnas, as a class of works, were looked upon us encyclopaedias for all men and women as to ancient and medi val Hindu religious practices, mythology, geography, his tory of persons, families, royal dynasties and literature.

The chronology of PurƒÅnas is, like that of the Epics, . subject full of perplexing problems and is not dealt with in this revised edition of the first volume of the H. of Dh, as it has been discussed at length in the H. of Dh. Vol. V. pp. 815 1002 and the views of Pargiter, Kirfel, Dikshitar and Hazra have been set out, discussed and criticized at length in pp. 831-853. Vide also the present author’s paper PaurƒÅ≈Üa dharma’in Gode commemoration volume pp. 70-82 for the changes in religious ideas and practices brought about by the PurƒÅnas or reflected in them.

It has to be mentioned here that in the first few centuries of the Christian era the idea prevailed that those rules or ordinances ( Dharmas ) that were understood from the Veda are the highest (in authority ), but the rules ( Dharmas ) stated in the PurƒÅnas ( and similar works ) were inferior.468 This posi tion assigned to the Puranas was changed a few centuries before 1000 A. D. and PurƒÅnas came to be far more relied upon by works on Dharma≈õƒÅstra. For example, the Krtyakalpa taru (about 1125-1160 A. D.) quotes the PurƒÅlas even on such a topic as Mokoa much more than the Upani≈üads or the VedƒÅntas≈´tra. AparƒÉrka quotes a half verse*** as from Menu ( not found in extant Manusmrti), saying that one should strengthen the Veda by ItibƒÅsa ( i. e. MahƒÅbhƒÅrata ) and Pura uas. It is significant that the extensive commentary of Vigvar≈´pa on YƒÅj. hardly ever mentions a PurƒÅƒºa by name, though he twice refers to PurƒÅnas in a general way on Yaj. III. 170 and 175. He flourished about 800-860 ƒÑ. D. Simi. 453 ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å

ftua: II T q. by Apar√§rka p. 9 and by Kalpataru (Brshow.

vƒÅrio p. 33). 464 ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§π‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø

ata ofera i 3771* p. 19 on HT. 1. 7. In some works the above half vorse is followed by the wordo faritu quarst ATA nereala; vide antena 1. 287-89, afhDH√âHL= 27.6, SAN 1. 201, qara chap. 3 p. 50 (Jivananda‚Äôs ed. of Freed ) the last reads sans for efropaFranta. (Gharpunom . p. 3 ) ascribos it to Brhaspati.

  1. The PurƒÅ≈Üas

larly, MedhƒÉtithi on Manu very rarely refers to PurƒÅnas and mentions none by name. Vide notes below.486

The main characteristics of the teachings of the extant Pur√§llas, some of which at least were composed in the first few centuries of the Christian era would be merely indicated here briefly. Those who want to go into greater details are requested to refer to Vol. V of the H. of Dh. pp. 928-980. North and Central India had been harassed by the invasions of foreign hordes such as the Sakas and H≈´nas. Besides, the performance of Vedic sacrifices had become rare; Buddhism, Jainism and other schisms had greatly affected the minds of all persons including religious and thoughtful men. The leaders of Hindu Society had to wean away common men from the new and attractive teachings of Buddhism and hence the writers of PurƒÅ≈Üas struck upon finding out new dogma. The first doctrine that was recommended was that great rewards ( spiritual and other-worldly ) would follow on a little

455 ‡§è‡§∑‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ. on ‡§Ø‡§æ.

III. 170 ; ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ. on ‡§Ø‡§æ. III. 175;

On Manu I. 55 Medhatithi quotes : ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•à ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡•§; on I. 69 ho states : ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡••; on I. 74 he says ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡§ø; on ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å I. 78 ho quotes 2} verses from ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‘‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§π ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡§≠‡•å‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§∂‡§§‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§’ ‡§∂‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å‡§™‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï-‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ú‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§°.‡§™‡•Å. . by ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•¶ on ‡§Ø‡§æ. III. 30 and by ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§µ. ( ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï p. 118 ). ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∂‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‘‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§’ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ. on ‡§Ø‡§æ. History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

trouble and effort.466

DƒÅna (charity and gifts) came to be regarded as conferring the highest rewards in the Mapusmrti ( 1.86 ‘tapah param… dƒÅnamekam kalau yuge’), in Santiparva, VƒÅyupurƒÅ≈Üa (6.65 66), ParƒÅ≈õarasm»ôti (1. 23). The gifts of food ( and particu larly to brƒÅhma·πáas ) were regarded as highest. When the invasions by foreigo hordes were frequent and when rulers of different kingdoms in India itself engaged in constant warfare this idea was good enough

Even the Rgveda (X. 117. 6 ) condemns one, wbo offers no food to Aryarnan (and other gods ) nor to a friend (guest etc.) and feeds himself alone, eating only sin. The same idea (almost in the same words ) occurs in Manu III. 18, Visnusmrti 67. 43 (aguam sa kevalam-bhunkte yah pacutyatmakƒÅrunƒÅt) and the Bhagavad-gitƒÅ (III. 13 ). But the Pur≈´nas carried this idea to extreme limits. Manu prescribed that in rites in honour of gods and pitrs, even a single learned brƒÅhmana may be fed to secure the full reward of the rite, but not many brƒÅhinnnas who do not know the mantri18. Again, in 111. 149 Manu says that in rites for gods no close examination about a brƒÅhmana should be indulged in, but that in rites for ances tors effort should be made to ascertain that the family and character of the brahmanas are both good. But gradually this idea was given up, particularly at Sraddhas in GayƒÅ. For example, the VƒÅyupurƒÅna states that the brƒÅhma·πáas of Gaya are supermen, that when they are gratitied (at a Sr√§ddba) the gods together with the pit≈ôs become gratified, that no question should be raised about their fainily, their character, learning or tupas and that by honouring them a man attaine liberation.

It may be pointed out that the Vanaparva (chap. 84. 82-104 ) speaks at length about Gaya and its holy places, most of which are quoted in the PadmapurƒÅya, Adik bauda, chap. 38 ( verses 2-19). Those interested may consult H. of Dh. Vol. 1 V for detailed statements about Gaya.

  1. The PurƒÅnas

413

heinous sing.467 For example, the AnusƒÅsana parva ( 25. 42) says-’ In Gay√† a man is purified even of the sin of three murders of brahmanan, if he visits Asmaprstha (PretasilƒÅ in GayƒÅ ), the hill called Niruvinda and the Kruu√±capadi. We find even the Vannparva stating that one does not secure those rewards even by performing solemn sacrifices in which fees paid to the priests are large, as one secures by pilgrima ges to holy places.

Another development for which PurƒÅnas are largely responsible is that of numerous observances called Vratas (described in vol. V part 1 pp. 81-462). It makes one sad to find that a great minister of State in the latter half of 13th century A. D., Heinsidri, deals with nearly 1000 vratas in about 2500 printed pages, instead of pondering over the great menace of invasions against India by foreigners from the 11th century onwards and does not take or even suggest methods or means to counteract that evil.

Another important aspect dealt with by soine PurƒÅnas is that of bhakti’ (devotion to God ) and Ninasmarana (repea ting inaudibly the names of God). The word Bhakti in its technical sense of loving faith in and surrender to God does not occur in the early Upanisaids, but only in the Svet√°svata ropanigad VI. 23 (yasya deve parƒ´ bhaktir-yathƒÅ deve tathƒÅ gurau ). It is developed in the BhagavadgitƒÉ (as in IX. 27 aud 34, XI. 55 ), and in the Bhagavata, Vis≈≥u and other PurƒÅ ≈ÖAs. The subject of bhakti has been treated at some length in H. of Db. vol. V pp. 950-980.

Prof. Hazra in ludiau Culture’ vol. I. pp. 587-614 con tributes a learned paper on ¬∑ PurƒÅnas in the History of Smrti’ and at the end of the paper sets out several nibandhu works on Dharma≈õƒÅstra in which Purana passages are quoted and relied upon.

His treatment of the subject is, however, not exbaustive. To take only one instance. As regards quotations from

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

PurƒÅuas in the Mit. he cites only one quotation from the Matsyapurana (chap. 94 ). But the Mit. quotes several PurƒÅnas on YƒÅj. For example, on YƒÅj. III. 30 it quotes a verse from BrahmƒÉuda purƒÅna which is also quoted by the SmrticandrikƒÅ. On YƒÅj. I. 297-98 the Mit. quotes two verses from Matsya purƒÅna ( 93.11-12) on the position of the planets on a diagram or painting of planets in Grahap≈´jƒÅ. Matsya ( 93.33-37) prescribes the same four Vedic mantras that Yaj. prescribes (in I. 300-301 ) for the worship of the Sun, Mars, Saturn and Ketu. The Mit. on YƒÅj. III. 6 prescribes the offering of NƒÅrƒÅ yanabali for those that commit suicide and states that the procedure is described in Vai≈ünava (purƒÅna ?). On YƒÅj. III. 6 the Mit. quotes from the Bhavisyat-pur√°na providing, for death on serpent bite, to a brahmana reciter of Pur·∫£nas the gift of a golden serpent made from one bhara of gold. The Mit. on YƒÅj. II. 290 refers to the view of the Skandapurana that there were very≈´s that belonged to a distinct caste. It appears to quote the M√§rkandeya purƒÅna several times on Yaj. 1.238, 254, III. 19, 287. Thus the Mit. mentions by name only six PurƒÅnas, while Apar√§rka naines twenty PurƒÅ·πáas and Smrti-candrikƒÅ 22.

In all about 40 Puranas and Upa purƒÅ·πáas are quoted in Nibandhas.

PurƒÅnas have been published by different individuals, presses and societies. A critical edition of at least the eighteen PurƒÅnas based on Mss. collected from all parts of our country had long been a desideratum. But only recently the work of re-editing PurƒÅnas in a critical manner by collecting and consulting Msg. from the whole of India has been under taken by the Purana PrakƒÅ≈õana Samiti of the All-India Kashiraj Trust, Benares. The work which is under the general guidance of Dr. V. Raghavan, Dr. V. S. Agrawala and PanditarƒÅja Sri Rajesvara Sastri has been going on for some time. With the help of the new Catalogus Catalogorum of Dr. V. Raghavan, a complete list of the Mss. of the PurƒÅ≈Üas and the UpapurƒÅnas has been prepared. The work of bring ing out a critical edition of the MatsyapurƒÅ·πáa has been going on in Madras under the guidance of Dr. Raghavan and the work of the critical edition of the V√°mana purana has been undertaken by Dr. V. S. Agrawala at Benares. The semiti mentioned above has been also bringing out a Bulletin Calle PurƒÅ·πáa, which publishes only PurƒÅ·πáic studies by different

  1. The PurƒÅnas

416

scholars aiming at the elucidation of the textual and other problems relating to the subject-matter embodied in the PurƒÅnas.

The preparation of a subjectwise encyclopaedia of PurƒÅ·πáic material, publication of popular expositions of Puranas in English or Hindi are among the lines of work that are includ ed among the objectives of the PurƒÅna PrakƒÅ≈õana Samiti. The subject-concordance of six Puranas viz. K≈´rma, Linga, Matsya, MƒÅrkandeya, Visnu and V√ºmuna is also ready (at the end of 1964).

For the critical edition of the MatsyapurƒÅna, Dr. Raghavan is relying on more than thirty mss., all printed edi tions and an old Tamil translation. Besides, as each indivi. dual PurƒÅna is closely connected with many other PurƒÅnas and is almost all PurƒÅnas have numerous common topics, Dr. Raghavan is using the other Puranas for parallel portions contained in them. As PurƒÅnas have been quoted in numerous DharmagƒÅstra works, Dr. Raghavan has collected all quote tions from the Matsya-purƒÅna in nibandha works on Dharmasastra. His plau of work on the Matsya has been set forth in his Presidential Address at the 21st session of the All India Oriental Conference held at Srinagar in 1961.

As the project of the critical editions of the PurƒÅnas is a long-term one, VyƒÅga Institute on a permanent basis at Benares is going to be established in the near future.

The constitution of the original text of the purƒÅnas is a Herculean task which has not yet been attempted. Not only is there difference of opinion among the purƒÅnas about the Dames of the 18 Maha-PurƒÅnas, but there is divergence as regards the extent of the several pur√§vas. For example, the commentator Visnucitta of the Vi≈ünupur√§na says (on III. 6. 20-22 ) that the extent of the VisnupurƒÅ·πáa is variously given at 8000, 9000, 10000, 22000, 24000, but that he comments on a text of 6000 slokas only. The AgnipurƒÅna ( 272.10-11 ) says that it contains 12000 slokas, while the BhƒÅgavata (XII. 13 ), the Brabmavaivarta, the Padma (ƒÅdi. 62 ) say that it contains 15400 slokas and the Skanda (V. 3) and the Matsya 53 giver the extent of the Agni as 16000. The K≈´rma, according tortice the Bhagavata, contains 17000, according to the Matsya 18700 and only 8000 according to the Agni ( 272. 19). Though there is a remarkuble continuity in India as to religious thought

poor

FOUNC

191

handarkar

416

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

and practices, yet the popular religion of modern Hindus is pre-eminently paurƒ´nic. The Purƒ´vas contain thousands of slokas on dharina≈õƒÅstra matters, they are a rich mine awaiting exploration by careful students of social and religious questions and shed a flood of light on the deve

f light on the development of reli gious beliefs and practices in meilieval and modern India. Therefore, the re-constitution of the text of the purƒÅnas is a problem that will have to be tackled in the near future. Be sides the several MahƒÅpurƒ´nas, eighteen UpapurƒÉ≈Üas also are enumerated in some of the Puranas. Vide Garuda (223.17 ff),488 Skanda (V. 3. chap. 1. 45-62 and VII. I. char. 2), Padma (P√§tƒÅla-khanda chap. 111. 95-98 and Matsya ( 53. 59 ff) for UpapurƒÅnas. The Matsya-purana (chap. 53, verse 58 ) states that the 18 purinas reached in extent four lakho of verses and also states that there were upabhodus (i.e. UpapurƒÅvas ) and names some of them viz. NƒÅrasimha, NƒÅnda, (Nandam), Samba and Aditya. Besides the Mal√µpurƒÅnas and UpapurƒÅnas, there are other works of the purƒ´na class such as Ganesa, Maudgala, Devi, Kalki &c. The Padmapurana (Uttarakhanda chap. 263 ) divides the 18 PurƒÅnas into three groups, s√§ttvika, rƒÅjusa and tƒÅmesa and says that the Visuu, NƒÅradiya, Bh√° gavata, Garuda, Padma aud VarƒÅha are s√§ttvika. The Matsya ( 53 ) also speaks of this division. The Lingapurƒ´na (39. 63 66 ) speaks of the twenty expounders of dharma just as YƒÅj√±avalkya does and quotes the two verses in the form in which the Mit. presents them (and not Visvar≈´pa ), while the Padma (Uttarakhanda 263. 86-89 ) divides the eighteen gm·ªôtis into three groups of s√§ttvika, rƒÅjasa and tƒÅmasa. 480 It would be quite clear to any reader of the purƒÅnas and the smrtis that most of the former in their extant form are later than the smrtis of Manu, YƒÅj≈àavalkya, ParƒÅ≈õara, NƒÅrada &c. 458 3fotografa A: afirana OI 377F ARTTTH ARTHEAUT

‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶-( ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ ? )‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§‡•§ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡•ã‡§∂‡§®‡§∏‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§• ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§π‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•å‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Ç

Hrita1744 11 765, 223. 17-20. 459 ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§æ‡§•‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ

‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§® ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•à ‡§õ ‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•å‡§∂‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§É ‡•§‡•§.

The following table will give some idea as to how the eighteen principal purƒÅnas are rich in dharma≈õƒÅstra material. Besides the eighteen principal purƒÅnas, the KƒÅlikƒÅ-purƒÅ≈Üa (Venkate≈õvara press ed.) and the Saura-pura (Ananda srama ed.) have been drawn upon. The AnandƒÅsrama editions of the Agni, Pauma, Matsya and V√§yu and the Niruayasagara edition of the Bhagavata and the Venkatesvara Press editions of the other Purƒ´nas have generally been relied upon in the present edition of the 1st volume.

It may be stated here that the Smrti chapters in the Puranas are very much influenced by Manu, YƒÅj., NƒÅrada and mostly by the first.
