  1. The YƒÅjnavalkyasmrti This smrti has been published dozens of times. In the following the NirnayasƒÅgara edition edited by SƒÅstri Moghe ( 1892 A. D. ) has been used and the Trivandrum edition when speaking of Vi≈õvar≈´pa.

The name of YƒÅj√±a valkya is one of the most illustrious among Vedic sayes. He is credited with having promulgated the White Yajurveda. In the Suntiparva (chap. 312 ) we are told that there was a rupture between Vai≈°ampƒÅyana and his pupil YƒÅj≈àavalkya and that by worshipping the Sun the latter received the revelation of the White Yajurveda, the Satapatha etc. The accounts in the Visuu (3. 5 ), the Bhagen vata ( XII. 6. 61-74 ) and other purƒÅnas differ somewhat from the one in the Mahabharata, but all agree on the fact of them strained relations between YƒÅj√±a valkya and bis teacher. There

Bhandi

sec422

History of Dharmasastra

Satapatha BrƒÅhmana in several places alludes to the dialogues of YƒÅj√±avalkya and king Janaka of Videha on agnihotra (S. B. E. vol. 44 p. 46 ). Vide Sata patha ( ed. by Weber ) XI. 6.2. At the end of the Satapatha we are told that VƒÅjasaneya YƒÅj√±avalkya promulgated the bright Yajus formula received from the Sun.480 In the BrhadƒÅra·πáyaka Upani≈üad YƒÅj√±a valkya appears as a great philosopher teaching the recondite doctrines of Brahma and immortality to one of his two wives, the philosophically minded Maitreyi ( II. 4 and IV. 5). In the same Upani≈üad YƒÅj√±avalkya is represented as carrying away the one thousand cows set apart by Janaka for the most learned BrƒÅhmana (III. 1. 1-2) and YƒÅj√±a valkya is said to have imparted to Janaka the knowledge of the destiny of the soul after it is released from the bonds of flesh and worldly affec tions. KƒÅtyƒÅyana in his VƒÅrtika on P√§≈Üini (IV. 3. 105 )461 speaks of the BrƒÅhmania8 of YƒÅj√±avalkya and very heated controversies have raged round the correct interpretation of the VƒÅrtika apd the MahƒÅbhƒÅsya thereon ( vide Max M√ºller’s Ancient Sanskrit Literature p. 360, Goldsticker’s Panini, p. 132 ff and S. B. E. vol. 12 pp. XXXV-XXXVIII). The contro versies centre round the word ‘tulyak√°lƒÅni’ in the MahƒÅ bhƒÅsya. It may mean either ( 1 ) that the BrƒÅhma·πáa works by YƒÅj√±avalkya (mentioned as ‘Yaj√±avalkƒÅni BrƒÅhmanƒÅni’) are also ‘purƒÅna-prokta’ but in their case the affix ‘uini’ (in ) is not applied ; yet they are as old as those referred to in the S≈´tra, or (2) that the BrƒÅhmanas like those promul gated by YƒÅj≈°ƒÅvalkya are co-eval with PƒÅ·πáini and hence not

purƒÅna-prokta ' and the termination ‘≈Üini’ does not apply to them. Western scholars held that Panini made a distinc tion between old and later BrƒÅhmana works and regarded YƒÅj. BrƒÅhmanas as co-eval with himself.

It is to be noted that in the YƒÅj√ªa valkyasmrti itself488 (III. 110 ) the author, whoever he may be, claims the author ship of the Ara·πáyaka that he received from the Sun and the Yoga≈õƒÅstra composed by him. This is simply put in to glori fy the YƒÅj≈àavalkya-smrti as the work of a great and ancient 480 ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§∑‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§§‡§™‡§•

XIV, 9. 4. 33. 461 giorgiig awna 191, 1V.3. 106. 482 ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡•§

  1. III. 111.

1917

  1. The YƒÅj√±avalkyasmrti

423

sage, philosopher and yogin. From the style and the doct rines of the smrti it is impossible to believe that it was the work of the same band that gave to the world the Upanisad containing the boldest philosophical speculation couched in the simplest yet the most effective language. Even orthodox Indian opinion was not prepared to admit the unity of author ship in the case of the smrti and the Aranyaka. The MitƒÅk sarƒÅ says at the beginning that some pupil of Y√¢j. abridg. ed the dharma≈õƒÅstra in the form of a dialogue.463 It will be shown later on that, though the sage who promulgated the Aranyaka and the author of the smrti cannot be identical, yet the YƒÅjsavalkya-smrti is much more closely connected with the White Yajurveda and the literature particularly be longing to it than with any other Veda.

The YƒÅj√±avalkyasmrti contains in the NirnayasƒÅgara ed. of 1892 ) 1010 verses, while the Trivandrum edition with the commentary of Visvar≈´pa contains 1003 verses and Apa rƒÉrka gives 1006 ( AuandƒÅ≈õrama edition ). The difference in the number is mostly due to the fact that Visvar≈´pa in the first section on acƒÅra omits five verses that occur in the Mitak √üarƒÉ. *84 As regards one of them (the verse ‘rathyƒÅ kardama toyƒÅni’ I. 197 according to the Mit. ) Visvar≈´pa notices it and says that some read it after the verse ‚ÄúmukhajƒÅ vipru≈üƒÅ” and that it adds nothing to what precedes. AparƒÅrka ex plains that verse. In the second section on vyavahƒÅra Visvar≈´pa reads verses 465 which do not exist in the MitƒÅk ≈üarƒÅ nor in A parƒÅrka. Not only this but in some cases the arrangement of ver ses is not the same in both Visvar≈´pa and the Mit. For example, verses 14-29 of the prƒÅya≈õcitta section present very different sequences in both. What is verse 29 in the Trivan drum edition is verse 19 in the Mit. Besides, the Mit. reads one verse (III. 23 √¢ dantajanmanah &c. ) which is wanting in Visvar≈´pa and is also not commented upon by AparƒÅrka. Visvar≈´pa adds two half verses,467 which do not occur in the Mit. and AparƒÅrka. There is further a good deal of variance in the readings adopted by Visvar≈´pa and the Mit., though the meaning is not often affected. For example, the two verses enumerating the names of writers on dharma are differently worded in both.488 But MedhƒÉtithi favours the reading of Vi≈°var≈´pa. 480 Vi≈õvar≈´pa reails “asvattam loka vidvistam” ( I. 155 ) and notices a reading “asvantam,” while the Mit. reads “asvargyam loka &c. ‚Äù Both the Mit. and AparƒÅrka read ‚ÄúpitƒÅ pit√§maho bhrƒÅtƒ´ &c.‚Äù (I. 63 ), while Visvar≈´pa reads “pitƒÅ mƒÅtƒÅmaho bhrƒÅti,‚Äù remarks that “m√°t√°maha” is put in earlier as a guardian for marriage for metrical reasons and then notices ‚Äúpiti pit√§maho bhrƒÅtƒÅ” as √† various reading. Even in the days of Visvar≈´pa there were various readings in Yij. ( Vide com. on I. 1, 2, 51, II. 119,

179 etc.).

The AgnipurƒÅla affords an excellent check for the consi deration of the text of the YƒÅj√±avalkyasmrti. A good-sized monograph will be required to deal exhaustively with the questions raised by the comparison of the vyavahƒÅra portion of the AgnipurƒÅ≈Üu with Yij√±avalkya’s vyavahƒÅra-kƒÅnda.

I shall only briefly examine the inaterials and state the con clusions at which I have arrived. We know that Visvar≈´pa, the first extant commentator of Yaj., flourished about 800-825 A. D. The author of the Mit≈´ksarƒ´ flourished about 250 years later. Interesting results follow by a comparison of the text that these two commentators had before them with the Agni purƒÅ≈Üa. I shall select chap, 256 of the AgnipurƒÅna for a detailed examination. It contains 36 verses which all occur in Yaj. II. (verses 118-153 of Tri. ed. and verses 114-149 of the Mit.). It is found that the Agnipurƒ´na agrees with the text of 12 verges word for word as contained in Visvar≈´pa and 19 verses as contained in the Mit. Vi≈õvar≈´pa puts three verses between the two verses pit∆∞dravyƒÅvinƒÅ≈õena &c.' and ‘kramidablyƒÅgatam dravyam’, while the Mit. brings the two verses together. In several cases the readings of the Agripu r√§na agree with Visvar≈´pa’s text and not with that of the Mit. For example, Agni. reads ‘k√§ryƒÅh patnya·∏• samƒÅ·πÅsikƒÅ·∏•’ with Vis. (119), reads bh≈´ryƒÉ… dravyam. eva vƒÅ… putrasya cobhayoh' with Vi≈õ. (124), reads ‘pitrdravyƒÅvinƒÅ≈õena’ (and not ovyavirodhena' as Mit. does ) with Vi≈õ. ( 122 ), reads * dadyƒÅt-cƒÉpaharec-cƒÅmsan' with Vi≈õ. ( 142 b ), reads ‘Patitas -tatsuta·∏• klibah’ with Vi≈õ. ( 144 a ), reads ‘aprajƒÅyƒÅmatƒ´tƒÅ yƒÅm’ with Vi≈õ. ( 148 ). The AgnipurƒÅna, however, in a far larger number of cases agrees with the readings of the Mit. Ayni (256.8) reads with the Mit. (122) ‘vibhaktesu suto jƒÅtah gavarnƒÅyƒÅm vibhƒÅgabhƒÅk,’ Agni. reads mƒÅtƒÅpyamsam samun haret' with the Mit. ( 123 ), wbile Vi≈õ. ( 127 ) reads ‘mƒÉtƒÉpyamsam samƒÅrnuyƒÅt.’ Visvar≈´pa’s reading leaves it undecided as to what the share of the mother is to be, while the Mit. makes it definite by stating that it is equal ( to that of a son. ). Agni ( 256.12) reads ‘catustri-dvyeka-bhƒÅgƒÅh syuh’ and ‘vidj√§stu dvyekabhƒÅgi nah’ with the Mit. ( 125 ) ; Ayni ( 256.21 ) reads-‘rdhebhƒÅgi ka·πÅ’ with the Mit. (134). Agni. rogi ca.' The reading of the Mit. makes provision by the word ‘ƒÄdya’ for other persons like deaf-mutes mentioned in other smrtis as not entitled to inherit, while Vi≈õ. has to put forced interpretation on ‘cu’as including such persons. yautakaih’ with the Mit. (149), while Vis (153) reads

We find that the tendency of the readings of the Mit. is to smooth down harsh or involved constructions and that the AynipurƒÅna presents most of the changes in the text found in the Mit. but not found in Vis. In the same direction points the fact that Agni ( 256.35 ) reads ‘na dattam stridhanam yasyai’ with the Mit. ( 148 ) and not ‘yasyƒÅ’ as Vis. (152) does, as `yasyai ‚Äôis grammatically more regular than ‘yasyƒÅh’ with the form ‘dattam.’ But as against this we may note that both Vi≈õ. and Agni read ‘aprajƒÅyƒÅmati tƒÅyƒÅƒ±n’, while the Mit. reads ‘atƒ´tƒÅyƒÅmaprajasi .’ The reading ‘aprajasi’ is correct according to PƒÅnini (V. 4. 122 ) and not ‘aprajƒÅyƒÅm’. Therefore, the conclusion that follows is that the text of YƒÅj. preserved in the AgnipurƒÅna is intermediate between the text of Visvar≈´pa and that of the Mit≈´ksarƒÉ. As Visva r≈´pa flourished about 800-825 A. D., the AgnipurƒÅna repre sents a text of YƒÅjsavalkya current somewhat later i. e. about 900 A. D. In my ‘History of Sanskrit Poetics’ (pp. III-V) I established, from the fact that the extant AgnipurƒÅna quotes Dandin and Bh√§maha and knew the theory of dhvani, that it was composed about 900 A. D. That date is strikingly corro borated by the evidence derived from the chapters on vyava hƒÅra discussed above. It is no doubt true that the Agni pre. sents some readings that are found neither in Vi≈õ. nor in the Mit. For example, it reads ( 256.4 ) ‘tƒÅbhya »ôterpayet’, while both Vi≈õ. and Mit. read tƒÅbhya rtesnvyah.’ It is probable that this is an error of the copyists or the reading may be due to the difficulty of understanding the meaning of ‘anvaya·∏•’ there. Agni reads ( 256.5) ‘svayam-arjayet’ for ‘svayam arjitam’ (of Vi≈õ. and Mit. ) and jƒÅtopi dƒÅsyƒÅm s≈´drasya' (256.20 ) for og≈´drena' (of Vi≈õ, and Mit.). The total number of verses on vyavahƒÅra in AgnipurƒÅ≈Üa, chap. 253-258, is 315. Out of this the first 31 are not taken from YƒÅj. The GarudapurƒÅna affords, like the AgnipurƒÅ·πáa, material help towards examining the authoritativeness of the text of the first and third sections of Yiij. The Aguipurƒ´na does not expressly say that it drew upon Y√ºj., but the GurudapurƒÅ≈Üa is explicit on the point. In chup. 93.1. it is expressly said that the dhuria formerly promulgated by Yij√πavalkya is being narrated ‘YƒÅj√Æjavalkyena yat (yalƒ± ? ) purvam dharmam (dharmah ? ) proktam (‘tah?) katham Hare i tan me katlaya kesighna yathƒÅ tattvena Madhavall.’ Chapters 93-106 con tain dharma≈õƒÅstra material more or less taken from the Y√§j√±avalkyasƒ±n≈üti. There are 376 verses in these chapters. Considerations of space forbid any detailed examination of this material. A few salient facts only are brought out here. Chapters 93-102 deal with the several topics (prakaranas) of the first k√§nda in the same order, the only exception being the topics of rajadharmu (1. 309-308 ), which is omitted in the GarudapurƒÅna. Chapters 102-10.j treat of topics that occur in the third k√§nda of YƒÅj. and contain 121 verses only. In these chapters the order of the prakaranas in YƒÅj. is Dones observed at all, but Garuva speaks of them in the following order: vƒÅna prastha-prakarana, yati, karinavipƒÅka, prƒÅyascita ƒÅ≈õauca and a paddharma ( the last two being the first twirusa prakarauas in YƒÅj.). A feature which strikes one as regarda the Garudapurana (particularly chap. 102-106 ) is that a fer perche

verses only of YƒÅj. are repeated word for word, that very often the GarudapurƒÅ≈Üa gives only a summary by omitting and transposing the words and phrases of the original and that sometimes it adds verses of its own. This may be illug trated by what the Garuda says on vƒÅnaprastha and yati (chap. 102-103, 12 verses in all). Chap. 102 begins ‘vƒÅna prasthƒÅ≈õrama·πÅ vaksye tac-chravantu maharsaya·∏• putresu bhƒÅryƒÅm niksipya vana·πÅ gacchet sahaiva v√°ll.’ The latter half is a paraphrase of Yaj. III. 45a. Then III. 45b–46 (Mit.)= Garuda 102.2-3a ( with slight variations ), III.47 = Garuda 102-4 6-52 ; III. 18 = 3b-4a ; III. 49-50 = Garuda 5b (pak≈üe mƒÅsetha vƒÅ≈õniyƒÅd-dantol≈´khaliko bhavet’, which summarises and retains some words of the original), III. 71 - Garuda 102.6a (cƒÅndrƒÅyani svapedblumau karma kuryƒÅt phalƒÅdina, which includes a few words of 11 I. 49b also ), 111.52 = Garuda 6b-7a ( the last pƒÅda in Garuda is ‘yogabhyƒÅsƒÅt dinam nayet,’ while in YƒÅj. it is ‘≈õakty√± vƒÅpi tapas-caret’), 111.53 = Garuda 102.7. Chap. 203 contains only five verses. 111.56, 58-59 = Garuda 103. 1b-4a ( with variants ) and then Garuda adds 11 verses which are not found in YƒÅj. (viz. blavet-parama hamso v√£ ekadandi yamaditah Il siddhayogas-tyajan deham amptatvam-ihƒÅpnuyƒÅti dƒÅtƒÅtithipriyo j√±ƒÅni grhƒ´ sraddhepi mucyate li'). The mere fact that a prakarana is omitted in the Garuda purana should cast no doubt on the existence of that prakara·πáa in the original YƒÅj. We do not know on what principles the borrowing took place. Besides, we find that such prakaranas as VinƒÅyaka≈õƒÅnti and graha≈õƒÅnti are includ ed in the Garuda (chap. 100-101 ), while rƒÅjadharma prakarana is omitted. We know that rƒÅjadharma ‘figures in the s≈´tras aud Manu, but none of the ancient dharmas≈´tras, nor the Manusm·∫∑ti speaks of VivƒÅyaka. Hence conclusions must be drawn only froin what positively occurs in the Garuda purana and not from the absence of any topic in it. The GarudapurƒÅna sometimes follows the arrangement and form of the verses presented in Vis., sometimes it agrees with the Mit. and sometimes it is independent. For example, the two verses enumerating the authors of dharma≈õƒÅstras ( YƒÅj. 1. 4-5 = Garuda 93. 4-5 ) follow the readings of Vis., but not those of the Mit. In the 3rd k√ºnda, verses 14-19 of the lit. are differently arranged by Vis., and Vis. omits the dates Apar√°rka also ) one verse found in the Mit. (I11.23 Dus sit above, while the Mit. omits two half verses that are fouin Vis. ( vide note 313). The verse ‘ƒ´ danta &c.’ occurs in the

  1. The YƒÅj√±avalkyasm·ªôti

429

GarudapurƒÅna and the two half verses in Vis. omitted by the Mit. are also omitted in Garuda. So far the GarudapurƒÅna agrees with the arrangement preserved in the Mit. But it does not agree entirely with the Mit. The verse ‘ƒÅdanta &c’ is III. 23 in the Mit, and occurs before ‘ahastvadatta’ but in the Garuda it occurs before ‘triratram dasarƒÅtram vƒ´ (which is III. 18 in the Mit. ). Besides, verse 22 of the Mit. is read differently in the Garuda (da≈õa dv√§da≈õa varnƒÅnƒÅm tathƒÅ pancadasaiva ca 1 trimsad dinƒÉui ca tathƒÅ bhavati pretasuta. kam). It must, therefore, be said that the GarudapurƒÅna represents an intermediate stage of readings between Vi≈õ. and the Mit. As the Garudapurƒ´na was a popular work read by and recited for the benefit of slightly educated or illiterate people, it often introduces changes to suit their understanding. For example, the Mit. (1.296 ) reads ( us also Vis.) s√ºrya·∏• somo mahƒ´putra·∏• somaputro brhaspatih,’ while Garuda reads (chap. 101.2 ) ‘s√ºrya·∏• somo mangalus’ ca budhas caiva b≈ühaspatih,’ thus substituting the well-knowu words Mangala and Budha for Mahiputra and Somaputra. The verse

krt√°gnikƒÅryo bhunjite' (1.31 in the Mit. ) is placed by Vis. after ‘ekade≈õam - upadhyƒÅya,’ while the Mit. places it three verses earlier. The Gurudapurina here agrees with the Mit. In some cases Garula strikes an independent path. For exa mple, in YƒÅj. I. 11 Vi≈õ. reads ‘m≈´se’to j√§takarma ca,’ the Mit. reads ‘mƒÅsyete j√§takarma ca’, while Garuda ( chap. 93. 11 ) gives the easy reading presave jƒÉtakarma ca'. Mit. reads (Y√°j. I. 76 b) ‘tyajan dƒÉpyastrtiyƒÅ·πÅsam-adravyo bharanam striyah’; Vis. omits the whole verse, while Garuda omits 1.764 (of Mit.) and reads the other half as ‘sundhƒÅm tyaja≈Ñstrtƒ´. yƒÅm≈õam dadyadƒÅbharanam striyah’ ( 95. 23b ). Verses 1.91-92 of the Mit. on the offspring of inixed marriages are differently read by Vis. (1.90-91 ), while the Garuda ( 96. 1 b) has the same half verse as the Mit. I. 91 a and the same half verse (96. 3 2 ) as Vis. (91 b) and reads the two half verses between them as jƒÅto ‚Äôƒ±n basthastu s≈´drƒÅyƒÅm visƒÅdah p√£ra≈õavopi v√£ ll mƒÅhi≈üyal ksatriyajjƒÅto vai≈õyƒÅyƒÅm mlecchusu mjiita·∏•.

The foregoing makes it clear that the text that the Garudapurana had before it could not have been older than that commented upon by Visvar≈´pa and that it represents a stage intermediate between Vis, and the Mit.

The above gives rise to an important question whether one can detect several strata in the Y√ºj≈æavulkyasmrti. from

FOUNDED

430

History of Dharma≈õ√§stra

the fact that the s≈´tra of Sankha-Likhita cites YƒÅj√±avalkya among the promulgators of Jharma≈õƒÅstras ( vide note 137 ), while YƒÅj. himself includes Sankha-Likhita among the pro pounders of dharma (note 258 ), it may be plausibly said that Sankha-Likhita refer to an earlier YƒÅj√±avalkyasmrti than the extant one. Beyond this there is no evidence to establish that there was an earlier version of the present smrti. A comparison of the readings of Visvar≈´pa and the Mit. with those in the Agni and Garuda purƒÅnas has established that the text of the sin»ôti no doubt underwent slight verbal changes between 800 and 1100 A. D. and that a few verses were added and also omitted during these centuries. But the text remained in the main the game from 700 A. D. What the original smrti contained, whether it was in prose or verse or both and whether it dealt with only ƒÅcƒÅra and prƒÅyascitta sections are questions on which conjectures may be advanced, but there are no substantial materials for arriving at even tolerably certain conclusions.

YƒÅj√±avalkya’s work is more systematic than that of Manu. He divides the work into three sections and relegates all topics to their proper positions and avoids repetition. He treats of almost all subjects that we find in Manu, but his treatment is always concise and he makes very great and successful efforts at brevity. The result is that for the 2700 verses of Manu, he requires only a little over a thousand. He often compresses two verses of Manu into one, e. g. Manu II. 243, 247, 248 are equal to YƒÅj. I, 49, Manu III. 46-48 and 50 are concisely put in one verse by YƒÅj. (1. 79); vide also Manu IV. 7-8 and YƒÅj. I. 128 (contains alƒ±nost same words also ), Manu IV. 84-85 and YƒÇj. I. 141. Iu a few cases Manu and YƒÅj. convey the same meaning in one verse without compression, e. g. Manu III. 70 and YƒÅj. I. 102, Manu III. 119 and YƒÅj. I. 110. Mapu VII. 17 and YƒÅj. I. 348, Manu VII. 205 and Y√¢j. I. 349. The correspondence of YƒÅj≈°avalkya’s words with the text of Manu is in most cases very close, so much so that one cannot help feeling that Y√§j. had the Manusinsti before him and purposely made an attempt to abridge the somewhat loose expressions of Manu. The passages set forth above as examples of compressions will the serve as illustrations of this fact. The word Kaya ( from KA) is used by both in the sense of prƒÅjƒÅpatya form of marfage (Manu III. 38 and Y√•j. I. 60 ); vide also Manu II. 109 YƒÅj. 1. 28, Manu I11. 42-44 and YƒÅj. I. 62, Manu V. 28-07

STU

YAONA

BUNDEP

Qhondartarori

  1. The YƒÅj√±avalkyasmrti

431

and YƒÅj. I. 178–179, Manu VII. 56 and YƒÅj. I. 312 for further close agreement in phraseology. YƒÅj. adds some subjects which have either no counterpart in our Manu or which are only noticed in passing by Manu. The Manusmrti contains nothing corresponding to the Vinayaka≈õƒÅnti and Graba≈õƒÅnti of YƒÅj. (I. 271-308). YƒÅj. gives a detailed treatment of five kinds of ordeals (in II. 95-113 ), while Manu makes only a cursory reference to the ordeals of fire and water ( VIII. 114 ). YƒÅj. contains considerable anatomical and medical matter (III. 75‚Äì 108 ), which is wanting in Manu. On the other hand, there are some subjects on which YƒÅj. is silent though they are dealt with in detail by Manu. This is the case with the account of the origin of the world.

The whole of the YƒÅj√±a valkya-smrti is written in the classical Anustubh metre. Though the author’s great aim has been to be concise, his verses are hardly ever obscure. The style is flowing and direct. There are not many un-PƒÅ·πáinian expressions, though he employs ‘p≈´jya‚Äô in . 293 and ‘d√ºsya’ in II. 296. In the latter case both Visvar≈´pa and AparƒÅrka avoid the fault by reading differently. The verse ‚Äúkulani jƒÅtaya·∏• srenyo’ is ungramƒ±natical ( Tri. ed. II. 34 ), as jƒÅti' and' sre≈Üi' must be in the accusative case. According to the Mit. YƒÅj√±avalkya addressed his words to SƒÅma≈õravas and other sages (vide com. on I. 178 and III. 330-333). In this the Mit. is probably drawing upon the B·ªâ. Up. (III. 1. 2), where YƒÅj. asks S√°ma≈õravas to take away the 1000 cows. The sages interpose (vide III. 118, 129 ) as in Manu, while the great teacher is passing in review one topic after another. The teacher himself addresses his auditors (as in I. 178 srunudhvam' and nibodhata’in I. 272). YƒÅj. employs the first person about himself as in I. 56 ‘naitan-mama matam’ and in III. 126 sahasrƒÅtinƒÅ mayƒÅ yo va ƒÅdidera udƒÅhstah).

It is said that the sages approached YƒÅj√±avalkya in MithilƒÅ and requested him to impart to them the dharmas of the varnas, ƒÅ≈õramas and others. The contents of the work may be briefly summarised as follows:–KƒÅnda I: fourteen vidyae; twenty expounders of dharma, sources of dharma; constitution of a parisad, the samkƒÅras from GarbhƒÅithiina to marrage upanayana, its time and other details; every-day duties brahmacƒÅrin, persous fit to be taught, what things and actions & brahmacarin was to avoid, period of studenthood; marrinteresen

(

Hestaristu432

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

qualifications of girl to be married, limits of sapinda relation ship, intercaste marriages; the eight forms of marriage and the spiritual benefits therefrom, guardians for marriage, K»ôetraja son; grounds of supercession of wife, duties of wife; principal and intermediate castes; duties of householder and keeping sacred domestic fire, the five great daily yaj√±as; honouring a guest, machuparku, grounds of precedence, rule of the road, .privileges and duties of the four varnas; without ownership; invalidity of gift; rescission of gale; breach of contract of service; slavery by force ; violation of conven tions; non-payment of wages; gambling and prize-fighting ; abuse, defamation and slander; assault, hurt etc. ; sƒÅhasa ; theft; adultery ; miscellaneous wrongs ; review of judgment; KƒÅ≈Üda III-cremation and burial ; offering of water to various deceased persons; for whom no mourning was to be observed and no water to be offered; periods of mourning for various persons ; rules for mourners ; impurity on birth ; instances of immediate purification on death or birth; means of purifica. tion, such as time, fire, ritual, mud etc.; rules of conduct and livelihood in distress ; rules for forest hermit; rules for a yati ; how the individual soul is clothed in a body; various stages of the fatus, number of bones in the body, the various organs such as liver, spleen etc. ; the number of arteries and veins; reflection over ƒÅtman; use of music in the path of mokra; how the originally pure atinan 18 born among impure surroundings ; how some sinners are born as various kinds of animals or inanimate things; how yogin attains immortality ; three kinds of actions due to sattva, rajas and tamas; means of ƒÅtmaj√±ƒÅna; the two paths, one to immortality and the other to heaven; the various diseases from which sinners Buffer ; purpose of prƒÅyascittas; names of 21 hells ; the five mortal sins and other acts similar to them ; upapƒÅtakas ; prƒÅyascittas for brƒÅhmana murder or for killing other per sons ; prƒÅya≈õcittas for drinking wine, for other mortal and venial sins and for killing animals of various sorts ; greater or lesser expiation according to time, place, age, ability; ostra. cizing the non-conformist sinner ; secret expiations ; ten yamas and niyamas ; SƒÅnta pana, MahƒÅsƒÅnta pana, Tapta. krochra, ParƒÅka, C√¢ndrƒÅya·πáa and other expiations ; rewards of reading this sm·ªôti.

Besides the four Vedas, YƒÅj. refers to the VedƒÅngas as six and enumerates fourteen vidyƒÅs ( four Vedas, six angas, purƒÅ·πáa, nyƒÅya, mimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ, dharma≈õƒÅstra ). He refers to the Ara·πáyaka and Yoga≈õƒÅstra composed by himself. Ara·πáyakag in general are spoken of in I. 145 and Sukriya Ara·πáyaka in III. 309. The Upanisads are mentioned in III. 189, where PurƒÅ≈Üas are mentioned in the plural. ItihƒÅsas, PurƒÅ·πáa, Valio vƒÅkya, and NƒÅrƒÅsamsi gƒÅthƒÅs are mentioned in 1.45 ( also I 101 for PurƒÅna and ItibƒÅsa ). He enumerates at the comment cement nineteen authors on dharma, besides himself. But it

434

History of DharmadƒÅstra

is remarkable that in the body of the work not one individual author of a dharma-≈õƒÅstra is mentioned by name. He speaks of Anviksiki (Metaphysics ) and Dandanƒ´ti (I. 311). He lays down the dictum that where dharmagƒÅstra and artha sƒÅstra conflict, the former shall prevail (II. 21 ). He speaks of sm·ªôtis in general (II. 5 and 1.154 ). In III. 189 (III. 180 in Visvar≈´pa who reads. PurƒÅnam ca ), he names several sections of Sanskrit literature viz. Vedas, PurƒÅnas, VidyƒÅs ( Dharma sƒÅstra and others ), Upanisads, slokas, s≈´tras and bhƒÅsyas. This is an echo of B»ôhadƒÅranyakopanisad 11.4.10 and IV.5.11 quoted below.470 He speaks of s≈´tras and bhƒÅsyas. What works are intended it is most difficult to say ; the only extant bh√¢sya which can be said with certainty to be older than the extant YƒÅj. smrti is that of Pata√±jali. He refers to other writers on dharma in the word ‘eke’ (I. 36). The view re ferred to there occurs in Baud. Dh. S. 1. 2. 4.

YƒÅj. III. 185 refers to eight gu≈Üas, which appears to be a reference to Gautama Dharmas≈´tra 8. 23-24. Similarly, YƒÅj. III. 186 ( referring to 88 thousand sages who were house holders ) has in view Ap. Dh. S. II. 9. 21.3 (AstƒÅsƒ´tisahasrƒÅ≈Üi ye prajƒÅm-i≈üire rsaya·∏• &c ). It appears that the Matsya purƒÅna ( 53. 5-6 )471 quoted below copies the words of YƒÅj. I. 3 (PurƒÅna-nyƒÅya……… dharmasya ca caturda≈õa ) and thereby helps to some extent in arriving at the probable date of YƒÅj.

It is necessary to say a few words about the verses of the Yoga-YƒÅj√±a valkya which has 12 chapters and about 496 ver ses plus ten additional verses, in all 506 only.

Briefly the contents of the twelve chapters are as follows: Chap. I (70 verses ) - In an assembly of sages, in which Mai treyi ( the best of married women ) and Gargi ( the best among experts in knowledge of Brahma), were present, when GƒÅrgi prostrated herself on the ground and requested YƒÅj√±avalkya to impart to her the essence of Yoga. YƒÅj. agreed to impart to her the essence of Yoga together with its angas. He said

  1. The YƒÅj≈àavalkyasmrti

435

that he would impart to her the knowledge of Yoga which Brahm√£ communicated to him and requested the assembly of sages to listen to the Yoga that would be described by him. He dealt with knowledge and appropriate actions, as follows: actions are the way of knowledge which is twofold viz. pravar taka (i. e. inducing men to act) and nivartaka (i. e. making men to cease from ordinary acts). He said there are four asramas laid down by the Veda. Man owes debts to gods, ancestors and sages ( ?sis ) and pays off the debts (respectively) by sacrifices, by having sons and by brahmacarya as regards sages); there are four ƒÅ≈õramas, all four for a brƒÅhmana, three for a ksatriya, two for vaisyas and one for $≈´dras; men in the four ƒÅ≈õramas should perform the duties of those ƒÅ≈õramas out of the four that may be applicable to their cases respectively; there are different angas of Yoga applicable to the persons in the community. Yoga has eight angus viz. Yama, Niyama, Asana, PrƒÅƒºƒÅyƒÅma, PratyƒÅhƒÅra, DhƒÅra·πáƒÅ, Dhyana and SamƒÅdhi. Yamas are ten viz. AhimsƒÅ, truthfulness, asteya &c. and there are also ten niyamas viz. tapas, santo»ôa, √§stikya, dƒÅna, worship of god, listening to the fundamental principles of conduct, Hri, Mati, Japa ( vƒÅcika and manasa ) and vratas; (chap. 3 ) Asana ( bodily postures of eight sorts ); NƒÅdis ( 14 chief ones such as Ida, Pingalƒ´, Susum·ª•ƒÅ, &c.); ten vƒÅyus ( such as PrƒÅna, ApƒÅna &c.) and their special functions ); Nadƒ´suddhi ( described in chap. V); PrƒÅ·πáƒÅyƒÅma (description of ), Recaka, P≈´ralu, Kumbha, the mantra to be recited is to be Vedic, except for the s√ºdras and women ; (ten slokas at the end of chap. VI); seventh chap. deals with Pratya h√•ra ; this last and three more are called abhyantara angas of Yoga. DhƒÅranas are of five sorts (chap. VIII ): control of PrƒÅ≈Üa-vƒÅyu ; IX-deals with dhyƒÅna; chap. X-deals with SamƒÅdhi ( Samadhi·∏• samatƒÅ vasthƒÅ ); chap. XI (GƒÅrgi says that she had forgotten the Yoga with eight angas ); chap. XII-YƒÅj. teaches her briefly Yoga again when she said that she had forgotten the elaborate treatment that YƒÅj. indulged in and then YƒÅj. teaches her briefly the essence of Yoga ( chap. XII ).

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

7-10); 473 Gargi stated at the end that she had forgotten YƒÅjƒÅavalkya’s exposition of Yoga with its eight angas as the means leading to moksa and that he should explain briefly the Yoga with eight aiga8 ; Yajna¬∞ agrees ; XII brief description of a posture for control of VƒÅyu in which the right ankle is pressed against the anus (one among several items) and of practising this for two ghatikƒÅs for ten days one has certain experiences such as lightness of the body, hearing sounds and passing only a small quantity of urine and faeces &c. ; then contemplation on calermin (serpent that is lodged in the Kundalini); rousing of the Kundalini ; all ( Upanisad passages ) declare that one is to realize that brahman from which proceed all these beings &c.

The Yoga-YƒÅj√±avalkya is only a small work on Yoga, has little to do with Dharma≈õƒÅstra and it winds up its teachings by relying on Hathayoga in chap. XII, which is put forward by the work itself as a summary of the teachings of the first eleven chapters.473

( Continued on the next page)

POOHA

CMMAR

FOUNDED

1917

  1. The YƒÅjƒßavalkyasmrti

437

Mr. Divanji himself regards it as the earliest available work on Hathayoga for the common man (JBBRAS Vol. 29 for 1954 pp. 96-128 at p. 106 and in ABORI Vol. 34 for 1953 p. 23). The present author questions his assertions about its being the earliest.

AparƒÅrka ( about 1125-50 A. D. ) mentions YogayƒÅjsa. valkya about 25 times and quotes at least 63 verses therefrom (though the order of verses and some readings differ in a few cases). Reasons of space prevent a detailed statement of all verses quoted from YogayƒÅj√±avalkya. By way of sample, only some groups of verses from Yoga-YƒÅj. are cited here ; (.) about 18 verses ( though not in consecutive order ) on pp. 134-35 are quoted by AparƒÅrka from Br. Yoga. Yaj. , all except two from the 7th chapter (verses 39, 162-171 and from IV, 28 and 30 ); five verses are quoted from Br Y, Y. VII. This is not cited in the ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û. edited by Mr. Divanji. ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‘‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§Ü‡§™‡§É’ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‘‡§Ö‡§ò‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ' ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø, ‘‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§∞‡•Å p. 188. ‘‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç.’ is ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•¶ VII. 162 and ‘‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç’ is VII. 166 ( of the same ). None of these two is cited in ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ.. ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•å‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∂‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§æ ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡§æ ‡•• ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û. II. 312-313; ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡•• ‡§§‡§™‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∑ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ú‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§è‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•Å ‡•§‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û. I. 50-51 and ans 1-2; compare ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ-‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø-‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ø-‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•å‡§ö ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∑-‡§§‡§™‡§É-‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ II, 30 and In

verses and a half which are B»ô Y. Y. VII. 2 (latter half)-5. Mr. Divanji does not show that these verses occur in the

Yoga-YƒÅj√±avalkya that he edited.

The DƒÅnasƒÅgara of BallƒÅlasena (B. edition) mentions Yaj√±avalkya and YogiyƒÅj√±avalkya on p. 3 and it quotes about a dozen verses some of which are found in Yogi-YƒÅj√±a valky8,474 chap. VII. ( of Br. Y. Y.) via abhƒÅve ( D. S. p. 63=Br. VII. 139 ); na kuryƒÅt (D. S. p. 52-Br. VII. 37); na cankraman (D. S. p. 52-Br. VII. 131 ); na padƒÅ (D. S. p. 63-B·ªä VII. 132 ). . YƒÅj√±avalkya agrees very closely with the Visnudharma s≈´tra. What conclusions are to be drawn therefrom has been discussed above (see sec. 10). Similarly, there is close correspondence between the Kau»õiliya aud YƒÅj. If there is any borrowing at all, it must follow from the date above assigned to the Kau≈£iliya that it is YƒÅj. who borrows. There are numerous passages in YƒÅj. that show remarkable agreement with the text of Manu. But there are several points on which YƒÅj. differs from Manu and shows in general a more advanced state of thought and feeling than the Manusmrti. The follow ing are the principal points wherein YƒÅj. differs from Manu. Manu seems to allow a brƒÅhma·πáa to marry a s≈´dra girl ((III. 13 ), while YƒÅj. emphatically states it as his opinion that this is wrong (I. 56 ); Manu first describes the practice of niyoga and then severely condemns it (IX. 59-68 ), while YƒÅj. does not condemn it (I. 68-69). Manu enumerates eighteen vyavahƒÅrapadas; YƒÅj. does not expressly enumerate them in one place, though he defines vyavahƒÅra pada and adds verses of a miscellaneous character (prakƒ±rnaka ) in his section on vyavahƒÅra. Manu is silent about the rights of inheritance of

  1. The YƒÅj√±avalkyasmrti

489

the widow of a sonless man and gives only a vaguely expre seed order of succession, while YƒÅj. places the widow at the head of all heirs and enumerates several classes of heirs in e regular order. Manu condemns gambling outright (9. 224 228), while Yaj. brought it under State control and made its source of revenue to the king (II. 200-203). There are several other matters which YƒÅj. treats at much greater length and more systematically than Manu, e. g. ordeals (as indicated above), means of proof in courts ( Manu altogether ignoring documentary evidence, though he knew documents as in 8. 51-52), rules of procedure in courts ( compare Manu 8. 53-56 with Yaj. II. 5-11 and 16-21 ), the doctrine of possession and prescription (Yaj. II. 24-29 and Manu 9. 44 and 54 ). All these points tend to show that the YƒÅjnavalkya-smrti is much later than the extant Manusm≈üti.

The YƒÅj≈àavalkya-sm·ªôti seems to have taken the section on Vinayaka≈õƒÅnti from the MƒÅnavagƒºhya-s≈´tra (II. 14 ); verses 281-283 of YƒÅj. (I) occur in the M√§navagshya II. 14, but in a different order. 476 The M√§navagƒºhya takes the VinƒÅ yakas to be four, while YƒÅj. says that there is a single Vinayaka, whose appellations are Mita. &c.

The details of information about VinƒÅyaka in Y√•j. (I. 272-276) appear to have been versified from the prose478 of the M. Gr. S. The details of worship also and the mantra (Yaj. I. 291) are taken from the same work (vide M. Gr. S. II. 14. 30 for the mantra ). At one time the section on

475 ‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§ü‡§ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö

‘‡§ï‡§ü‡§ï‡§ü‡•å ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö’. 478 ‡§è‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§

‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ú‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡§É ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§â‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§® ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§≤‡§≠‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§≤‡§≠‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ … ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§´‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø II. 14. 3-21 (ed. by Knauer ),

440

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

VinƒÅyaka≈õƒÅnti was thought to be a gure indication of the late date of YƒÅj. Smrti. But since the discovery of the MƒÅnava gshya that position had to be given up. In the BaudhƒÅyana dharmas≈´tra (II. 5. 21 ) we have Vinayaka and his several appellations (in the tarpa≈Üa ). A parƒÅrka on YƒÅj. I. 275 quotes a long passage from the Baija vƒÅpa-gƒºhya which bears a very close correspondence in phraseology to the passage from the M. G»ô. S. quoted above and which gives the names of the four VinƒÅyakas as Mita, Sammita, Salakatan kata and K≈´smƒÅ≈ÜdarƒÅja putra.

The YƒÅj√±avalkya-smrti stands in a very intimate relation to the White Yajurveda and the literature that clusters round it. Most of the mantras quoted (in part) or referred to by YƒÅj. occur in the Rgveda as well as in the VƒÅjasaneya-sam hitƒÉ (e. g. in YƒÅj. I. 22, 24, 229, 230, 238, 239, 247 ). Yet there are a few mantras that do not occur in the Rgveda, but only in the VƒÅjasaneya-sa·πÅhitƒÅ or other sa·πÅhitƒÅs (e. g. ‘yavosi’ in YƒÅj. I.230, which is VƒÅj. S. 5. 26, ‘ye samƒÅna’ in Y√°j. 1. 254 which is VƒÅj. S. 19.45, ‘imam deva’ and ‘udbudhyanva’ in YƒÅj. I. 300, which are V√°j. S. 9. 40 and 15. 54, ‘annƒÅt pari ≈õrutah’ and ‘kand√°t‚Äôin YƒÅj. I. 301 which are VƒÅj. S. 19.75 and 13.20 ). Several verses ( Yaj. III. 191-197) are a para phrase of certain passages of the BrhadƒÅranyaka Upanisad, 80 much so that the very words of the latter are used through out in the former, as the quotations given below will show.477 Then again YƒÅj. very closely agrees with the PƒÅras karagƒºhya s≈´tra as was pointed out by Dr. Stenzler in his introduction to the edition of YƒÅj. (1849, Berlin ) and in the Journal of the German Oriental Society (VII. 527). Visvar≈´pa points out 477 ‡§∏ ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§• ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö

fastiant: ll 23. III. 191; compare EERVE II. 4. 5. and IV 5. 6

BEAT AT OP TET: njaati &c.'; I TAS Parceria #arma ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ATT eller 1 &c. 5.   1. The YƒÅj√±avalkyasmrti

441

that478 YƒÅj. I. 142‚Äì143 are based upon PƒÅraskara. The mantra ayam me vajrah’ in YƒÅj. I. 135 ( Trivandrum ed.) is given in PƒÅraskara-grhya 11.7.7. In the following also there is close verbal correspondence478 between YƒÅj. and the P. Gr. S; YƒÅj. III. 1-2 and P. Gr. S. III. 10. I, 5, 8-9 and 12: YƒÅj. III. 3 and P. Gr. S. III. IO. 16 and 19-20; YƒÅj. III. 4 and P. Gr. S. III. 10. 46-47 ; YƒÅj. III. 16 and P. Gr. S. III. 10. 26-27. Similarly, the verses of YƒÅj. on Sr√§ddha ( I. 217-270) offer many points of contact with the Sraddha-kalpa of KƒÅtyƒÅyana edited by Dr. Caland (pp. 127-130 of his work ‘Ahnencult &c.’ From these facts Dr. Jolly concludes that YƒÅj√±avalkya’s work goes back to a dharmas≈´tra of the White Yajurveda ( R. u. 8. p. 21 ). In another place Dr. Jolly hazards another conjecture based on the close correspondence between YƒÉj. and the Vi≈ünudbarmas≈´tra that he probably belonged to the K√§thaka school of the Black Yajurveda (Journal of Indian History, 1924, p. 7). YƒÅj. also shows great similarity to the Kau≈£iliya and borrows the VinƒÅyaka-≈õƒÅnti from the MƒÅnava grhyas≈´tra. From these facts one may argue at least with an much logic and force as underlies Dr. Jolly’s guess-work that YƒÅj. probably belonged to the MƒÅnava school of the Black Yajurveda or to the school of Kautilya. If YƒÅj. knew his business as a writer on Dharma≈õƒÅstra, he must have consul ted the works of his predecessors and his work is bound to show traces of that fact. One may conclude at the most tbat the author of the YƒÅj√±avalkyasmrti may have possibly been a student of the White Yajurveda and so the mantras of the White Yajurveda and the G»ôhyas≈´tra of PƒÅraskara were far more familiar to him than the other Vedas, s≈´tras, smrtis, and other works. No such conclusions that there was a dharma s≈´tra of the White Yajurveda and that the YƒÅj√±avalkyasmrti was based thereon are warranted by the facts so far discovered. 478 ‡§™‡•å‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§¶

1919442

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

For settling the date of YƒÅj. we need not consider the evidence after the 9th century A.D. For, in the first quarter of that century (as we shall see later on ) Vi≈õvar≈´pa wrote his extensive commentary on YƒÅj. - That he was separated from YƒÅj. by many centuries follows from several considerations. Not only had numerous various readings arisen in the text of YƒÅj. when he wrote, but various interpretations of the same words and verses of YƒÅj. had arisen. For example, he gives several meanings of the words ‘putronanyƒÅ≈õritadravyah’ (in YƒÅj. II. 47 ), of ‘sƒÅmudrƒÅh’ (II. 41 ); he gives different inter pretations of I. 265, II. 160, II. 173 &c. He refers to the interpretations of his predecessors in several places by the word ‘anye’ (I. 3, 25, 155, 169; II. 21, 119, 121 ; III, 201,209, 246 &c. ). In several places he appears to be referring to two other interpretations than his own ( vide on III.250, the words ‘kecittu’ and ‘anye tu’ and the same words on III.261 and 264). That Visvar≈´pa had before bim actual commentaries on YƒÅj. and was not merely giving scholastic interpretations started by himself is made very clear in several cases by his actually citing certain portions from those works. On 1.252 Visvar≈´pa says. others take from somewhere the following floke (then the sloka is quoted ), but this sloka is of no help, as its origin is not known !.480 Similar words occur in the comment on YƒÅj. III. 222. On II. 193 he styles some pre decessor as panditammanya' and on III. 257 he ridicules a predecessor who regards the verse of Manu IV. 222 as an arthavƒÅda by saying that that commentator wanted to show off that he knew the technical term arthavƒÅda.481 It is not unlikely that Vi≈õvar≈´pa in this last passage refers to some ancient commentator of Manu such as AsahƒÅya. In the PrƒÅyascittamay√ªkha, 48' Nilakantha ( Benares edition of 1879 )

1917

  1. The YƒÅj√±avalkyasmrti

443

says that Sankara in his BhƒÅsya on Brahmas≈´tra (III. 4.43) explained the application of YƒÅj. III. 226. Unfortunately in the printed editions of Sankara I could not find this. But from the BhƒÅmati where YƒÅj. III. 226 is explained, it is clear that the passage must have occurred in the text of Sankara used by the BhƒÅmati. Dr. Jolly lays great emphasis in assigning a late date to YƒÅj. on the fact that KumƒÅrila, who cites Manu, Gautama, ƒÄpastamba, BaudhƒÅyana frequently, ignores the YƒÅjsavalkya-smrti altogether. But this silence of the great mimƒÅ·πÅsaka can only mean that he did not assign the same pre-eminent and venerable position to YƒÅj. that he assigned to Manu, Gautama and others. Dr. Jolly himself is prepared to place YƒÅj. three or four centuries earlier than KuinƒÅrila. It will be shown hereafter that NƒÅrada and B»ôhaspati cannot be placed later than 500 A. D. and may have flourished two or three centuries earlier still. On a compa rison of their doctrines with those of YƒÅj. it will have to be conceded that they represent a far greater advance in juristic principles and exactitude than YƒÅj. So the latter cannot be placed later than the 3rd century A. D. As YƒÅj. is shown above to have followed the Manusmrti and the Kau≈£iliya his smrti cannot be placed earlier than the first century B.C. We shall not be therefore far from the truth if we place his smrti somewhere between the first century B. C and the third century of the Christian era. In the Lank√°vatƒÅras≈´tra ( ed. by B. Nanjio, 1923, Kyoto ) gathas 814‚Äì816 are ‘KƒÅtyƒÅyana·∏• s≈´trakartƒÅ YƒÅjsavalkastathaiva ca… Valmiko MasurƒÅk≈üasca Kautilya ƒÄsvalƒÅyana·∏• … From the context it appears that the author of the smrti is referred to as YƒÅj√±avalka.

Dr. Jolly (R. u. S. p. 21 ) following Dr. Jacobi (ZDMG 30, p. 306 ) thinks that YƒÅj. shows an acquaintance with Greek astrology. Dr. Jacobi’s position amounts to this that the naming of the week days after the planets was established among the Greeks towards the end of the 2nd century A. D. and as the names of the week days and the arrangement of the planets in correspondence with them was borrowed by the

( Continued from the previous page) FTTHIETTOarf#1919: 1 deportat i fant op 71. IIL 2008 ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ã‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ö‡•ã ‡§¨‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• afere… RE ‚Äì is a 97 III. 4. 43.

FOUNDED

1917

Bhandarkar o

444

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Indians from the Greeks, no Indian work which enumerates the week days or arranges the planets in the well-known sequence of Sun, Moon, Mars &c. ) could have been composed before the third century after Christ. As is very often the case with Western Sanskrit scholars in matters of Indian chronology, this grand generalization is based upon very slender data. The premises are mere assumptions without hardly any evidence worth the name to support them. No one knows exactly when the week-days were named and who were the people that first employed the current names of the week-days. It is well-known that as far back as the days of Herodotus the Egyptians had a presiding deity for each day and that in the times of Julius C√¶ser there were days of Saturn (vide I. A. vol. 14, p. I, General Cunningham’s article for the Indian origin of week-days ). At least from the third century B. C., as vouched for by the 13th edict of Asoka, India was in close touch with Syria and Egypt, where Bud dhist missionaries had been sent by Asoka while Antiochus and Ptolemy ruled in the two countries respectively. There fore, if Indians at all borrowed the week-days and the arrangement of planets from foreigners, there is nothing to prevent us from holding that they might have borrowed them from the Egyptians.

The present author has dealt at some length with the question of the origin of week days and their names in pp. 676-685 of Vol. V part I of the History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra. It is impossible to hold that such a brilliant planet as Venus whose rising precedes the dawn and setting follows the evening was not noticed by the ancient Indians. It is very likely that Vena praised in Rg. X.123.1,2 and 5 is the morning star and in X. 123.5 U≈üas the youthful (yosƒÅ ) Apsaras that greets with a smile in the highest heaven her lover i.e. the morning star that is a little high up in the sky when Usas smiles on the horizon. In a difficult verse ( Rg. 1.139.10) both B»ôhas pati and Vena are mentioned. Several Western scholars hold that Vena is Soma or S√ºrya according to the context. But this explanation would not suit Ry. X. 123. 1 and 5 at all. In Rg. X. 123.1 we have the words ' Ayam venas codayat…imam apƒÅm sangame s≈´ryasya’ and it is clear that ‘imam ‘restore to Vena (in the first half) and ‚Äús√ºryasya’ is separatet mend tioned from imam’ (i. e. Venam ). The earliest datending record ( so far known ) wherein a week-day is mentioned 18

  1. The YƒÅj√±avallyasmrti

445

the Era¬ª Inscription of 484 A. D. (Gupta Inscriptions p. 89) where we have” Suraguror divase.” It is to be noticed that YƒÅj. does not mention the week-days. Ip I. 296 he mentions the nine grahas in order as the Sun, the Moon, Mars (the son of the earth ), Mercury (the son of Soma ), Jupiter, Venus, Saturn, RƒÅhu, Ketu. No one can gainsay that at least the Sun, the Moon, Bphaspati and Venus were known to the Rgvedic India. B·ªãhaspati in the highest beaven is spoken of in the Rgveda483 and the conjunction of Jupiter and Tisya (constellation of Pusya ) is spoken of in the Tai. BrƒÅbmana. We know so very little of the ancient astronomical science in ancient India that one must think twice before dogmatising. YƒÅj. nowhere mentions the zodiacal signs (rƒÅ≈õis) and probably did not know them. Not only so, in his day the naksutras were still arranged from KrttikƒÅ to Bharani as was the case in the Tai. S. IV. 4.10. Vide YƒÅj. I. 268 (K»ôttikƒÅdi Bharanyantam ). We know from VarƒÅhamihira that in the 5th century A. D. the signs of the zodiac and the arrangement of Naksatras from Asvini to Revati were established facts in all parts of India. Therefore, Y√¢j. who uses the ancient arrangement of Nak≈üat ras cannot be placed so late as the 4th century A. D. When YƒÅj. (1. 80 ) speaks of ‚Äúsusthe Indau " we should not, follow ing such commentaries as the Mit., connect the words with the signs of the zodiac or the houses of the horoscope. Visvar≈´pa does not speak of rƒÅ≈õis in this connection, but of Naksatras only. From very ancient times certain Nak≈üatras had come to be regarded as auspicious or suitable for particular acts. The Tai. Br. 484 directs that one should not finish a thing or begin to sacrifice ou a naksatra with an evil name. The same BrƒÅhma·πáa says that ploughing was to be begun on the Maitra asterism (Anuradha ) and consecration of fire on the Aditya naksatra. Even the Rgveda speaks of auspicious day8486 and the Tai. Br. speaks of Deva-nak≈üatras and PunyƒÅhas, and says

483 Efafa’: 998 arhat Het Fatiaa: 9ch a 17 I IV, 60. 4;

pakta: qu√Ö HT99Tafea ei annaftalana i √•t. Al. 3. 1. 1. 6. 484 ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•á‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ó‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•à.

NSTITU

POONA

FOUNDE

1917

446

History of DharmasƒÅstra

that a daughter should be given away in marriage on the SvƒÅti naksatra if she was desired to be her husband’s favourite *86 Vide BaudhƒÅyana G»ôhya (I. 1 ) for the marriage nak·π£atras ; also ƒÄp. Gr. S. II. 15. 12-14, Gobhila Gphya 4.4. 28 and 2. 1.1.

There is nothing to show that YƒÅj. knew rƒÅfis ( zodiacal signs). He refers ( I. 80 ) to the MaghƒÅ and M√ºla nak≈üatras as forbidden for sexual intercourse between husband and wife. The presiding deity of both Magh√£ and Mula was pitara·∏• (deceased ancestors ); vide H. of Dh. Vol. V part 1 pp. 502-3 for both. Therefore, they are both inauspicious. Similarly, some of the tithia viz. AmƒÅvƒÅsyƒÅ, 8th and 14th tithis and Full Moon day were prohibited by Manu (IV. 128 ) for sexual intercourse between husband and wife. Hence times for many actions in early works were of three sorts viz. forbidden, recommended, or neutral (i. e. neither forbidden nor recom mended). When YƒÅj. speaks (in 1.80) of the moon being auspiciously placed, or when he speaks of a planet being badly placed ( du·∏•otha ) in 1.307, it is improper to jump to the conclusion that he refers to rƒÅsis, but he might have in mind nak≈üatras (like M≈´la and Mugha ) or tithis ( like Am√• vƒÅsyƒÅ or 8th ). The same remark applies to the words. Vyati pƒÅta andGajacchƒÅyƒÅ' that occur in YƒÅj. I.217. Both are times for srƒÅddha and variously defined (not necessarily depending on rƒÅdis ). Vide H. of Dh, vol. V. pp. 419 and 705 for VyatipƒÅta' and Vol. IV p. 371 n for GajacchƒÅyƒÅ and Vyatƒ´pƒÅta both.

In III. 171 and 172 YƒÅj. speaks of only the conjunction of planets and of the passage of them ) through tƒÅrƒÅs and maksatras. The Baud. Dh. S. II. 5.23 gpeaks of the nine grahas in the same order as that of YƒÅj. Therefore, there is hardly any evidence to show that YƒÅj. knew more astrology than was current in the days of the BrƒÅhmanas and the Grbyas≈´tras. YƒÅj. (in II. 240-241 ) speaks of the fine to be imposed on those who counterfeited “nƒÅ≈Üakas‚Äù (coins ) and on those examiners of ‚ÄúnƒÅnakas” who falsely declared a good coin to be counterfeited and vice versa. Mr. Jayaswal( Cal cutta Weekly Notes, vol. 17, P. CLIX ) says that nƒÅ≈Üaka is the

488 ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ

  2. The YƒÅj√±avalkyasmrti

447

gold coin of the Kushans bearing the picture of the Goddess Nanaia and that the Kushans did not rise to importance be fore 78 A. D. This would place YƒÅj. after 100 A. D. But it must be remembered that this connection between the Goddess Nanaia and the word “nƒÅnaka‚Äù is quite conjectural and that the chronology of the Kushans is far from being settled.

Yaj. speaks of the sight of yellow-robed people as an evil omen (1.273), which is probably a reference to the Buddhists; though it has to be remembered that he prescribes old yellow (kƒÅs√°ya ) robes for his seeker after moksa ( III. 157). He speaks of the founding of monasteries of BrƒÅhmanas learned in the Vedas (11.185). The philosophical doctrines contain ed in the third section ( verses 64-205 ) approach that phase of the VedƒÅnta that was taught by SankarƒÅcƒÅrya. Vide parti cularly III. 67, 69, 109, 119, 125, 140. He employs in elucidat ing the philosophy of Atman the well-known examples of gba≈£ƒÅkƒÅƒ£a and of the reflection of the Sun in water (III. 144 ), of the various ornaments made from gold, of the spider spinn ing webs out of his own body ( both in III.147 ), of the actor representing various parts (III. 162 ). All these illustrations frequently occur in Sarkara’s S√§rirakabhƒÅsya (e. g. ghatƒÉ kƒÅ≈õa on VedƒÅnta-s≈´tra II. I. 14, spider on II. 1.25). All these points, however, are of very little use in arriving at a definite age for the smrti of YƒÅj. The foregoing discussion has established that Dr. Jolly’s date (viz. 4th century A. D. in R. u. S., p. 21 ) is much later than the data warrant. There is nothing to prevent us from holding that the extant smrti was composed during the first two centuries of the Christian era or even a little earlier.

Prof. K. P. Jayaswel in his Tagore Law Lectures on ‘Manu and YƒÅj√±avalkya’ has given forceful expression to some novel views. A separate treatise would have to be written for ex posing the hollowness of some of his assertions. But one question concerns the text itself and cannot be altogether ignored here. On pp. 56 ff he asserts that verses 67-203 of the third adhyƒÅya of YƒÄj. are interpolations. The main reasons for this opinion are that these verses contain matters of anatomy and Yoga. This is a very bad example of foisthaga one’s own modern ideas about relevancy on writers who flourished about two thousand years ago. The N√°rada-small has a long disquisition on impotency ( vide SBE, vol. 33

pp. 166-168, XII. 9-14 ). Manusmrti contains a good deal of matter on Yoga e. g. vide Manu VI. 70-73; YƒÅj. 111.67 imitates Mundakopani≈üad II. 1.1 (in thought and words ), YƒÅj. 111.71 contains ideas common to Manu III. 76 and Santi parva 264.11 ; YƒÅj. VI. 2.16; YƒÅj. III. 200 re peats the very words of Gƒ´tƒÅ VI. 11 and XII. 4 in part.

Besides the YƒÅj√±avalkyasm»ôti we have to reckon with three other works connected with the name of YƒÅj√±avalkya, viz. Vrddha YƒÅj., Yoga-YƒÅj., and B»ôhad-YƒÅj. All these three works are comparatively ancient. Visvar≈´pa quotes ( vide note 219 above ) two verses of Vrddha-YƒÅj√±avalkya saying that many writers on dharma have been born and will be born and enumerating ten such writers.

The Mit. on YƒÄj. III. 1-2, 6, 19 quotes six verses of Vƒõddha-YƒÅj and AparƒÅrka quotes about eleven. The verse of V·ªáddha-YƒÅj. quoted as ‘c√¢ndƒÅla…P√§rasƒ´kƒÅdikam‚Äôin the note is quoted again by AparƒÅrka differently on p. 1196.

One quotation cited from Vrddha-YƒÅj. by Madhava refers to the means of proof in case of doubt whether there was . partition.487 So V·ªáddha–YƒÅj. wrote also on VyavabƒÉra. Most of the quotations occur in the prƒÅyascitta section. It is interesting to note that one of these quotations in AparƒÉrka488 regards the touch of Parasƒ´kas as on the game level with that of CandƒÅlas, Mlecchus and Bhillas. The DƒÅyabbƒÅga489 says that Jitendriya cited the words of Brhad-Yaj√µavalkya (viz. ‚Äúsodaro nƒÅnyamƒÅtrja·∏• ‚Äù). The Mit. cites Brhad YƒÅj√±avalkya on prƒÅya≈õcitta. So this also is a work that must be held to be earlier than 1000 A. D. YƒÅj. himself is styled

1917

  1. The YƒÅj√±avalkyasmrti

449

Yogisvara by the Mit. and other works, but Yoga-YƒÅjie valkya is a different work from the YƒÅj. Smrti. YƒÅj. (in III. 110) claims the Yoga≈õƒÅstra to be his own work.

The GarudapurƒÅna in chapters 93-106 contains about 376 verses, most of them borrowed from the YƒÅj. Smrti and adds a few verses of its own. It does not follow the order of verses in the Smrti. The Mit. on YƒÅj. III. 253 quotes a verse of B·ªãhad-Yaj√±avalkya stating that a Ksatriya or Vaisya even knowingly drinking madya does not become blamable, (but he incurs sin if he drinks liquor prepared from flour). The Mit, on YƒÅj. III. 253 quotes √† verse of Brhad-Visuu setting out ten kinds of madya, all forbidden to BrƒÅhmanas only but not to others.

Long after the first volume of the H. of Dh, was publi shed two works have been brought out, one called Brhadyogi YƒÅj√±avalkya edited and published in 1951 by Swami Kuva layananda of the Kaivalyadhama at Lonavla and Pandit Raghunath Shastri Kokje and the other by Mr. P. C. Divanji published at first in J. B. B. R. A. S. Vol. 28 (pp. 98-158 and pp. 215-268 ) and vol. 29 pp. 96-128 and later available in book form (in 1954 ). Mr. Divanji in J. B. B. R. A. S. vol. 29 pp. 96-128 deals with his mss., his method of collation, the work and its date, index of verses and glossary of words. In A. B. O. R. I. Vol. 34 pp. 1-29 Mr. Divanji tries to establish that the work he published is the Yoga≈õƒÅstra said to have been composed by the author of Yaj. Smrti (III. 110 ) before the smrti. The Lonavla editors replied in ABORI. Vol. 37 pp. 279-289 and in their Journal called Yogamƒ´mƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ Vol. VII. No. 2 ( also issued as a pamphlet in 1958 ). The present author cannot enter into lengthy criticism of what Mr. Divanji says, who does not keep an open mind as befits a scholar who is in search of truth. The Trivandrum Sanskrit Series also published (in 1938 ) the Yoga-Y√°j√±avalkya ( based on a single Ms. ) which generally agrees with the work edited by Mr. Divanji. The present author has to bring to the notice of scholars and readers the fact that the YogayƒÅj√±avalkya was published in the Trivandrum Series ( No. CXXXIV ) 80 fan back as 1938. The present author examined the question whether any one of these two works can be the YogasƒÅ to which the YƒÅj. Smrti (III. 110) says was composed by the sage YƒÅjsavalkya, a. of the Yƒ´j. Smrti, in H. of Dh. VoD

450

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

on each.

part 2, pp. 1404-1408. Those interested may read that dis cussion. The findings there are that none of the two works could have been the composition of the author of the YƒÅj. Smrti.

As both works are interesting ( particularly the one published at Lonavla ) the present author will say a few words on each.

The Brhad-YogiyƒÅj√±avalkya is a large work in twelve chapters and has about 930 verses. It begins just as the YƒÅj. Smrti does ( sages ask Yogi≈°vara who was in Mithila, ques tions). The twelve chapters deal with the following topics. I (verses 44 ); the essence of all Vedas, Smrtis and 14 vidyƒÅs; knowledge of ƒÄtman; five matters to be remembered at the time of performing japa of Mantras viz. the sage, the metre, the deity addressed, the application of mantras and (fifthly ) the explanation, origin, purpose and praise (i. e. the BrƒÅh mana of it); II ( verses 158 ) about OmkƒÅra (pranava ), it being a mantra by itself, eight different views about the mƒÅtrƒÅs of it ( YƒÅj√±avalkya’s view being that it is ‘amƒÅtra’); III (verses 32 ) On the VyƒÅb≈ôtis (either 3, 4, 5 or 7); IV (verses 82 ) on Gayatrƒ´, its sage, metre, deity and its employ ment; V. (12verses ) on NyƒÅsa of Om, VyƒÅh·ªãtis, Gayatri on the different parts of one’s body ; VI ( verses 31 ) on Sandhyo pƒÅsana (morning and evening worship ); VII (196 verses ) on bath, tarpana, sandhyƒÅ worship and japa (mutter ing of mantras); VIII (56 verses ) on PrƒÅnƒÅyƒÅma and PratyƒÅhƒÅra ; IX ( verses 198, the longest chap. in the work ) on Dhyana; definition of DhyƒÅna; ( dhyƒÅna being placed before dhƒÅra≈ÜƒÅ ); X ( verses 201 ) on S≈´ryopastbƒÉna ( worship of the Sun with mantras and GƒÅyatrijapa ); XI (56 verses ) practice of Yogadharma; XII (verses 49 )-All SƒÅstras originated from Veda, 14 vidyƒÅs means of knowing the proper dharma, greatness of Manu &c.

This work in its extensive remarks on Mantras, GƒÅyatri, SandhyopƒÅsana, bath, tarpa≈Üa, prƒÅnƒÅyƒÅma deals with Dharma dƒÅstra matters and combines with them the higher Yoga viz. pratyƒÅhƒÅra, dhyƒÅna and dhƒÅranƒÅ (as in VIII. 29, 30, 32 which are the same as Manu VI. 70-72). It quotes dozens of verses from the Manusmrti. It also contains many verses on the Bhagavadgit√£ and several passages of the Upanisads (All this will be shown in the table below. Therefore, the Dihan

The B»ôhad-yogiyƒÅj√±avalkya absorbs without acknowled gement Vedic, particularly Upani≈üad passages. For example, it cites (XI. 7) Rg. I. 164. 39 (Rco ak≈üare….samƒÅsate ). The B·ªáhadyogiyƒÅj√±avalkya contains about 930 verses, the YogayƒÅjsavalkya published by Mr. Divanji contains 496 verses and the Trivandrum edition of YogayƒÅj√±avalkya con tains about 465 verses. Therefore, the YogayƒÅj√±avalkya is in extent about half of the text of the Brhadyogi-yƒÅj√±avalkya. The references here are made to Mr. Divanji’s edition of Yoga yƒÅj√±avalkya (and not to the T. S. S. edition). The YogayƒÅj√±a valkya professes that in an assembly of sages (15 are named in XI.13-14 including Vasistha and Vi≈õvƒÅmitra ) both Maitreyi and GƒÅrgi were present and the latter (G√§rgi) fell at the feet of the sage and implored him to expound to her the principles of Yoga (1.8). The great sage promises to tell her the essence of Yoga with its angas, which was declared to him by BrahmƒÅ himself (1.10-15). He dilates on two paths, one stimulating (pravartaka ) a person to do acts laid down for varnas and asramus and the other called nivartaka ( which prevents rebirth ); he dilates on the four ƒÅ≈õramas for BrƒÅhma·πáa, three for Ksatriya, two for Vaisyas and one for S≈´dras and BrahmƒÅ directed YƒÅj√±avalkya to follow the paths of J√±ƒÅna and Karma (I. 39-40). The text (I. 43 ) tells us that GƒÅrgi was his wife (bhƒÅryayƒÅ tvevamuktastu Yuna valkyas-taponidhi·∏• ). In IV. 5 also GƒÅrgi is calleduynjak valkya’s wife, in IV. 40 she is addressed by YƒÅjnayake ya as priye’ and VarƒÅrohe (VI. 79, VII. 22 and 34 The

  1. The YƒÅj≈àavalkyasmrti

453

instruction imparted by BrahmƒÅ ends with the words in I. 39-40 as quoted below. J√±ana consists of Yoga, which has eight angas and Yoga means the union of the Individual soul with the Supreme Soul ( I. 44). The principal topics are: the eight angas, Yama &c.; ten Yamas (I. 50-51 ) and verses 1-19 their definitions ; II (chapter ) - ten niyamas and their definitions ; III the eight recommended ƒÅsanas (physical postures ); IV. on NƒÅdi-√°uddhi; on Susum≈ÜƒÅ, the best nadi (IV. 28 ); names of the 14 chief nƒÅdƒ´8 (IV. 26-28); ten v√°yus that circulate in the nƒÅdƒ´s, the five chief being PrƒÅna, ApƒÅna, SamƒÅna, vdƒÅna and VyƒÅna (IV. 47-48) and their spheres ; V. on means of NƒÅdi-√°uddhi and appropriate place and actions for securing it; Tantras are specially men tioned in V. 10; signs of having secured NƒÅdi-buddhi ; VI. ( longest chapter of the work ) on PrƒÅ≈ÜƒÅyƒÅma ; three aspects of prƒÅ≈ÜƒÅyƒÅma viz. recuku, p≈´raku and kumbhala ( VI. 2); explanations of these, results of practising these, such as removing diseases; VII. definition of pratyƒÅhƒÅra (1-2); VIII. on DhƒÅranƒÅ; definition of DhƒÅranƒ´, verbal close resem blances between the contents of the YogayƒÅjsavalkya and the Hathayoga-pradipika. The proper name of this last work is HathapradipikƒÅ ( vide H. of Dh Vol. V. p. 1427, n. 2344 ). This is a late work and mentions 35 siddhus such as MatsyendranƒÅtha, Gorak≈üanƒÅtha, GalininƒÅtha, Niv·ªãttinƒÅtha, and J√±anadeva, who wrote his famous commentary on the Gƒ´tƒÅ in 1290 A. D, and mentioned these as in the line of gurus before him. Vide H. of Dh. Vol. V. p. 1429.

There are great defects in the arguments of Mr. Divanji in favour of the work sponsored by him being the Yoga≈õƒÅstra referred to by YƒÅj√±avalkya (in YƒÅj. Smrti III. 110 ) as com posed by him before the Sm·ªôti itself. Both works (the B»ôhadyogiyƒÅj√±avalkya Smrti and the YogayƒÅj√±avalkya) claim that they contain what YƒÅj., a famous and very ancient sage, contemporary of ancient king Janaka (in the case of the B·ªô. Yogi-YƒÅj≈æiavalkya and also the recipient of Yajus from the Sun) and an ancient sage YƒÅj√±a valkya whose wife was GƒÅrgi and who received the Yogic knowledge from God Brahm√• himself (in the case of the Yoga-YƒÅjsavalkya ). Pent these days hardly any critical reader would admit these claims of both works. But the case of the author the Yoga-YƒÅi√±avalkya is much worse. This latter would be further charged either with being ignorant of aucient History

STUD

FOUNDED

454

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

and legends or with ignoring the Upanisad story and foisting a totally new one on YƒÅj√±avalkya. In the Br. Upanigad (II.4-5) it is said that YƒÅj. had two wives Maitreyi and KƒÅtyƒÅyanƒ´, the former wanted no wealth but was eager only to learn the means for securing immortality and then YƒÅj. expounded to her Brahma-vidyƒÅ. In B·ªâ. Up. III-1 it is said that Janaka offered to donate a thousand cows to that one among the persons assembled who was the best knower of brahman. YƒÅj. asked his pupil SƒÅmasravas to take away the cows. Then Asvala, Janaka’s hotr priest, and others viz. ArtabhƒÅga, Bhujyu, Usasta, Kahol& asked him questions, which Y√¢j. answered and silenced them. Then G√§rgi VƒÅcak navi asked him (in Br. Up. III.6) several questions one after another and lastly asked ‘kasmin nu Brahmaloka otƒÅ≈õca protƒÅsca’. YƒÅj. said to her' do not carry your question ing to the utmost limit, otherwise your head would fall down' (i. e. you will meet death). She remained silent. In the Yoga yƒÅj√±avalkya ( ed. by Divanji ) she is put forward as YƒÅj√±a valkya’s wife, a pure invention by the author of that work for the sake of palming it off as a very authoritative work.

Mr. Divanji on p. 25 of his paper in ABORI Vol. 34 on the two works ( having YƒÅj√±a valkya as part of their names) tries to make light of this circumstance by saying that a rose would smell as sweet even if called by some other name. This is trying to dodge the real issue, which is whether the work edited by him is that of the YƒÅj√±avalkya of the B·ªâ. Up. or is the work of the author of the YƒÅj. Smrti. The present author would have no quarrel with him if he admits that it is not a work of the ancient sage YƒÅj√±avalkya but of some one who suppresses his real name and the present author would admit that the work he edited is on Hathayoga (but not by the author of YƒÅj. Sm»ôti). On p. 29 he writes' the author had not forgotten the fact…but had meant to speak about another YƒÅj≈àavalkya’in I.6). One fails to understand what he means. The word Vadh≈´·∏• being in the singular would go with the nearest word Maitreyi and not with both Maitreyi and GƒÅrgi. The work, being a small one, deals only with Hathayoga, it does not dilate upon the daily religious rites to be performed, but harps constantly on the point that actions prescribed by SƒÅstric texts must be performed even by an adept for Hathayoga ( vide VI.79 nityam karƒ±na m√° caret,' XI. 7 ‘Vidhyuktam karma karta vyam brahmavidblica

1917

  1. The YƒÅj√±avalkyasmrti

455

nityasa·∏•) and the author says that GƒÅrgi was advised by YƒÅj√±avalkya (in X1.9 ) ‘tasmƒÅd-ƒÅ mara≈ÜƒÅd-vaidham kartav yam yogibhi·∏• sadƒÅ tvam caiva mƒÅtyƒÅya GƒÅrgi vaidham karma samƒÅcara il’.

As regards the Brhadyogi-YƒÅj√±avalkya matters stand as follows. VƒÅcaspatimisra in his commentary on the Yoga bhƒÅsya quotes a half verse from the YogiyƒÅjsavalkya-Smrti viz. ¬∑Hira·πáyagarbho yogasya vaktƒÅ nƒÅnya·∏• purƒÅtanah’, which occurs in the Brhad-Yogio (in Lonavala edition ) as X11.5, and not in YogayƒÅj√±avalkya ( ed. by Mr. Diwanji ). VƒÅcas pati wrote learned works on several sƒÅstras. His NyƒÅya s≈´cinibandha was composed in Vatsara 898 i. e. 841-41 A. D. (or even if the figures be taken as referring to Saka era before 976 A.D.). Therefore, the B»ôhad-Yogi-YƒÅj. would have to be placed at any rate before 800 A. D. or at least before 950 A. D. Prof. Keith in ‘Indian Logic and Atomism’ Oxford, 1921 ) pre fers 841 A. D. as the proper date (pp. 29-30 ) for VƒÅcaspati. AparƒÅrka in his voluminous commentary (on Yaj. ) mentions YogayƒÅj√±avalkya (Lonavala edition ) at least 25 times and quotes about 65 verses from it.

There are some special features in the Br. Yogi-YƒÅj. Most early and mediaeval works on Yoga do not dilate upon the prescribed daily duties ( such as bath, sandhyƒÅ, s≈´ryo pasthƒÅna ), while this work attaches importance to them and dilates upon them. Another outstanding feature is that it upholds the view called ‘I√±√°nakarmasamuccaya.’ One reaches the Highest Self by the union of knowledge and actions ; one would not secure perfection by treating the two as distinct from one another, therefore one should have recourse to both. J√±ƒÅna is predominant but not so when bereft of actions ; activity (actions ) is predominant, but not when devoid of knowledge. Therefore, perfection results from both only, just as a bird cannot fly on one wing. ( To hold ) that moksa ( re leage from bondage ) follows from knowledge is a sign of indolence. Unwise people desire no activities for fear of trouble to the body‚Äù ( B. Y. Y. IX. 28, 29, 34). Another noteworthy matter is that the Br. Y. Y. arranges the list of the eight angas of yoga as pratyƒÅhƒÅra, dbyƒÅna and dhƒÅraud and departs from the order stated in Yogas≈´tra II.28. The Br. Y. Y. holds that even a householder by performing the prescribed duties, by thoroughly understanding the nature of ƒÄtman and by the thorough knowledge of VedƒÅnta pa sta ges secures molsa.

456

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

The BrahmacƒÅri-kƒÅ≈Üda and Mok≈üa-kƒÅnda of the Kalpa taru (about 1125‚Äì1150 A. D.) quote respectively about sixteen and ten verses from YogiyƒÅj√±avalkya. A well-known verse about the meaning of rnƒÅtrƒÉ in prƒÅnƒÅyƒÅma has been quoted in vol. V. (of the H. of Dh.) p. 1438 n. 2361 from the Yogi-YƒÅj. which is Br. Y. Y. VIII.12. An interesting passage from the Brahmac√£rikƒÅnda of the Kalpataru is quoted in the foot-note which shows that the work was known as Yogi YƒÅj√±avalkya to the Kalpataru. 490

The Yoga-YƒÅj√±avalkya edited by Mr. Divanji is like an elementary treatise or handbook chiefly on Hathayoga of less than 500 verses. It is not possible to agree with Mr. Divanji that it was the Yoga≈õƒÅstra referred to by YƒÅj√±avalkya-Sin»ôti (II1.110 ) as already composed by him before the YƒÅj.Sm·ªôti. One circumstance against it (in putting forward G√§rgi as the wife of the sage YƒÅj√±ƒÅvalkya ) has already been stated above. Moreover, it differs from the YƒÅj√±avalk yasm·ªôti on some im portant matters. Some differences may be mentioned here. YƒÅj. enumerates ten Yamas and ten Niyamas (in II1.312-13). In Yoga-Yaj. also the number of both is the same (1.50-51 for yamas and 11.1-2 for niyamas ). But the details differ in both. Seven Yamas are the same in both viz. Brahmacarya, dayƒÅ, ksanti, satya, akalkatƒÅ (i. e. √§rjava ), ahims√£ and asteya. DƒÅna is a yama in YƒÅj ; but a niyama in Yogi-YƒÅj. Most niyamas are different. Both these works differ a good deal from the Yogas≈´tra 11.30 and 32 in the number of Yamas and Niyamas and their names.

YƒÅj. 1.10 states that BrƒÅhma·πáas, Ksatriyas and Vaisyas are dvijas and all rites for them from GarbhƒÅdhƒÅna to Ant yesti are to be performed with Vedic mantras. So a Vaisya could take to the order of forest hermits if he chose to do so. But the Yoga-YƒÅj. (11.30 and 35 ) expressly states that Ksatriya can resort to three √§gramas ( i. e. he cannot become a Sanyasin).

It may be noted that Sridatta ( about 1275‚Äì1310 A. D.) quotes from Yogi-YƒÅjsavalkya about 15 verses in his small work called ChandogƒÅhnika (only 63 pages in Nir. edition,

Even some learned and comparatively early commenta tors quote portions from the YƒÅj. Smrti as from Yogi-Yaj. For example, Kull≈´ka on Manu III.1 ( laying down various periods of time for Vedic studies ) quotes YƒÅj. From the above it is clear that Yoga-YƒÅj√±avalkya and B»ôhad-Yogi-YƒÅj√±avalkya are entirely different works and that the latter is comparatively an early work, as quotations from it are cited by VƒÅcaspatimisra ( 9th century ) and Apa r√§rka.

The Brhad-Yogi-YƒÅj√±avalkya contains numerous quote tions from the Manusmrti and the BhagavadgitƒÅ and a few from the YƒÅj. Smrti itself: YƒÅj. Smrti I. 3 is the same as B·ªábad-Yogi YƒÅj. XII. 3 ( which latter substitutes the word ‘tarka’ for nyƒÅya )'. Therefore the B»ôhad-Yogi-YƒÅj√±a valkya may be placed between 300 to 700 A. D.

There were probably many commentaries on the YƒÅj. Smrti. Out of these those of Visvar≈´pa, Vij√±ƒÅnesvara, Apa rƒÅrka, S≈´lapƒÅni and Mitramisra are the most famous. For these, vide sections 60, 70, 79, 95, 108 below. It has been shown above that Visvar≈´pa bad before him some commen tary or commentaries on YƒÅj. not now extant. For these see sections 60, 70, 79 and 95 below. On account of the para mount importance of the Mit. in modern Hindu Law administered by British Courts in the whole of India, the sm·ªôti of YƒÅj. has indirectly become the guiding work for De whole of India and this position it richly deserves by it is concise but clear statement of principles, its breadth of vision

and its comparative impartiality towards the claims of both sexes and the different var≈Üas.
