Mr. Divanji relies on quotations in the BhƒÅsya attributed to SankarƒÅcƒÅrya on the SvetƒÅ≈õvatara-upani≈üad. In A BORI Vol. 34 p. 23, Mr. Divanji admits that scholars question the claims of that BhƒÅsyakƒÅra to be the famous SarkarƒÅcƒÅrya, but argues that, even if a successor of the original SankarƒÅ cƒÅrya quotes them as YogayƒÅj√±avalkya, then that is positive proof that some verses of YogayƒÅj√±avalkya are quoted by some writer. But there is a snag in this argument. The BhƒÅ·π£yakƒÅra ( whoever he may be ) of the Sv. Up. quotes the YƒÅj. Smrti as YƒÅj√±avalkya (as on p. 5 YƒÅj. III. 62, 141 and 156-59 ) and as Bhagavan YƒÅj. ( verse III, 144 ) on Sv. Up. 1.7 p. 29. The same BhƒÅsyakƒÅra quotes on Sv. Up. 1.7 ( p. 28 ) four verses as those of YogiyƒÅj√±avalkya. This shows that the Bh√§syak√°ra of Sv. Up. regards the two as different. Mr. Divanji fails to show that these verses occur in the Yoga YƒÅj√±avalkya (that he edits). Mr. Divanji failed to recognize that YƒÅj. Smrti (III. 144) was quoted as that of BhagavƒÅn Y√°j. Again on the same page 23 ( of ABORI vol. 34 ) he remarks that out of 9 verses quoted on Sv. Up. I. 29 of the BhƒÅsya, 18 could be found with slight variations in the Yoga-YƒÉjo. There is a serious mistake here. The verses are not cited expressly as from YogayƒÅj. as the BhƒÅsya expressly cites four verses on Sv. Up. 17 as from Yogi-YƒÅj. The RhƒÅsya does not introduce them as from Yoga-YƒÅj. and therefore it is quite likely that those 29 verses occurred in some other work on Yogn from which the BhƒÅsyakƒÅra (on Sv. Up. II. 9 ) quoted and from which the Yoga-YƒÅj. copied some for its own purpose. Mr. Divanji’s conclusion is vitiated by this serious mistake that

  1. The YƒÅjnavalkyusmrti

IL IT

459

he commits. Eighteen whole verses out of 29 quoted on p. 9 are not found but mostly half verses are quoted which occur in YoyayƒÅj≈àavalkya edited by Mr. Divanji. Granting for argument that 18 out of 29 are found in YogayƒÅj√±avalkya whence do the other eleven come? The only possible conclu. sion is that all 29 are from one work, from which the present Yoga-YƒÅj. borrows its verses. There is another slip on Mr. Divanji’s part. These 29 verses are quoted in BhƒÅsya on Sv. Up. II. 9 and not on I. I. Besides, one of the 29 verses is ‘PrƒÅnƒÅyƒÅmair duhed-dosan &c.’ which is Manu VI. 7 and occurs also in Br. Y. Y. VIII. 32.

Mr. Divanji’s mentality is rather peculiar. On p. 113 of JBBRAS vol. 29, Mr. Divunji gives a list of eight items on quotations from and references to this work (i. e. to YogayƒÅj√±avalkya that be edits ) in other works. The first item (S√§nkara-bh√º≈üya on Sv. Up.) has been dealt with already. The third reference is to Sarvadar≈õanasangraha of MadhavƒÉ. cƒÅrya ( a work of the 14th century A. D.). That work, he says, contains four quotations of the work he edits. That work also quotes Brhad- Yoga - YƒÅj√±avalkya on p. 143 *Hirunyagarbho Yogasya &c. ( which is Br. Y. Y. XII.5). The 8th item ( and the last) on that page is above all, the author of the Yajnavalkya-Sinrti has in III. 110 referred to a ‘Yoga sƒÅstra promulgated by me,’ which can be none other than this (and refers to his own Introduction on p. 8). This is an extraordinary argument. He was a high judicial officer in the days of the British rule. He has written profusely on this one work but with great regret the present author has to say he has not kept an open and judicial mind. He assum es as indisputable what has to be proved to the satisfaction of the scholarly world. The uther items that he puts forward on p. 113 above cited are worth little.

  1. The ParƒÅsara Smrti

This work has been published several times, but the edi. tion of Jivananda (part II. pp. 1-52 ) and that in the Bombay Sanskrit Series with the voluminous gloss of the great MƒÅdhava are the best known. In the following pages Jika nanda’s edition has been used.

The sm»ôti of ParƒÅ≈õara must have been an ancient one as YƒÅj. (1.4 ) mentions him among the ancient writers on dha wim

19;

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

But it is doubtful whether we possess the ancient sm·ªôti of ParƒÅ≈õara. The extant smrti is probably a recast of it as it mentions YƒÅj. in the first chap. (p. 2 ). The Garudapurnya in chap. 107 gives a summary (in 39 verses ) of the ParƒÅ≈õara smrti. In doing so it takes parts of the latter and pieces them together. For example, verses 2-4 in the GarudapurƒÅ·ª•a (chap. 107 ) are' sruti·∏• smrti·∏• sadƒÅcƒÅro yah ka≈õcid vedakar t≈ôkah | vedƒÅ·∏• smitƒÅƒº brahma√±√£ƒ±lau dharmƒÅ ManvƒÅdibhi·∏• sadƒÅ Il d√¢nam kaliyuge dharma·∏• kartƒÅram ca kalau tyajet i pƒÅ pakrtyam tu tatraiva sƒÅpam phalati varsata·∏• Il ƒÅcƒÅrƒÅt prƒÅpnuyƒÅt sarvam sat karm≈´ni dine dine i sandhyƒÅ snƒÅnam japo homo devƒÅtithyƒÅdip≈´janam li' These are taken verbatim or with slight changes from the ParƒÅ≈õara-smrti; compare:‘na ka≈õcid veda kartƒÉ ca vedasmartƒÉ caturmukha·∏• i sruti·∏• smrti·∏• sadƒÅcƒÅrƒÅ nirnetavyƒÅ≈õca sarvadƒÅ i tathaiva dharmam smarati Manu·∏• kalpƒÅntarƒÅntare 1 tapa·∏• para·πÅ… dƒÅnameka·πÅ kalau yuge l… tyajet-de≈õam k≈ütayuge… kartƒÅram ca kalau yuge I…krte t≈´ tatk≈°anƒÅt sƒÅpa·∏•… kalau samvatsarena tu ll chap. I. verses 20, 21–23, 25, 27 and vide 39 for verse 4 of the Garuda-purƒÅna. This eastablishes that the GarudapurƒÅna regarded the ParƒÅ≈õara-smrti authoritative and ancient. There is another problem to be considered. Kautilya mentions six times the views of Par√§sara or the PƒÅrƒÅ≈õaras on various aspects of politics and state administration.

The ArthasƒÅstra mentions the views of the PƒÅrƒÅ≈õaras (School following ParƒÅ≈õara’s views ) in I. 8. 7, I. 15. 23, I. 17. 9, II. 7. 12, VIII. 1. 24, VIII. 3. 30 ( of Prof. Kangle’s edition). Therefore, it appears that there was a work of P√•rƒÅ≈õara on politics, in which it is possible that vyavahƒÅra also was dealt with.

The extant ParƒÅ≈õarasmrti is divided into twelve chapters and contains according to the last verse but only 592 verses. It deals only with ƒÅcƒÅra and prayascitta. MƒÅdhava intro duced his disquisition on vyuvah√ºrƒ±, which forms about a fourth of his extensive gloss, in an indirect way by regarding vyavahƒÅra as a part of the duties of Ksatriyas on which the ParƒÅsarasm·ªôti has something to say.491

  1. The ParƒÅ≈°arusmrti

The name ParƒÅ≈õara is an ancient one. In √¶g. VII. 18. 21 ParƒÅ≈õara is mentioned as a grandson of Vasistha Pra ye grhadamamadus-tvƒÅyƒÅ ParƒÅsarah-SatayƒÅtur-Vasi≈üthah.’ The plural ‘ye’ in the verse requires that SatayƒÅtu·∏•’ is an individual’s designation (literally meaning either one who possessed hundred magic tricks or one against whom one hundred magic tricks were practised ). In the Tai. Aranyaka ( I. 1. 3. 37 ) we have a VyƒÅsa PƒÅrƒÅsarya. In the Vamba that occurs in the B≈ühudƒÅranyaka II. 6.2 and IV. 6. 3 we have a PƒÅrƒÅ≈õarya. The Nirukta gives an etymology of PƒÅrƒÅbara. 492 PƒÅ·πáini attributes a bhiksus≈´tra to PƒÅrƒÅ≈õarya.s$3 ‘In the SƒÅntiparva ( Chapters 290-298 ) there is a lengthy dialogue between ParƒÅ≈õara and king Janaka.

The introductory verses of the smrti say that sages went to Vy√§sa and requested him to instruct them in the dharmas and conduct beneficial to mankind in the Kali age and that the great VyƒÅsa took them to his father ParƒÅ≈õara, son of Sakti, in the BadarikƒÅ≈õrama, who then propounded the dharmas of the four varnos. The first chapter recites the sm·ªôtis then known ( 19 in all) and lays down that in the four ages of Krta, TretƒÅ, DvƒÅpara, and Kali, the dharmas pro claimed by Manu, Gautama, Sarkha-Likhita and ParƒÅ≈õara were respectively to be the guiding ones. The following are briefly the contents of the ParƒÅ≈õarasƒ±n»ôti :

I. Introductory verses ; P√§rƒÅsara imparts to the sages knowledge of dharma ; the dharmas of the four yugas ; diffe rentiation of the four yugas from various points of view; six daily duties, viz. sandhyƒÅ, bath, jupa, homa, Vedic study, worship of yods, Vaisvadeva and honouring guests, eulogy of honouring guests, the proper means of livelihood for Ksatriya, Vaisya and S≈´dra ; II. duties of householder; agriculture ; the five unconscious acts of injury to animal life; III. purifi. cation from impurity due to birth and death; IV. concerning suicide; punishment for wife deserting her husband though poor, foolish or diseased ; definition and rules about Ku·ª•da, Golaka, Parivitti, and Parivitta; remarriage of women; re wards for chaste widows ; V. expiation for minor things (suoti as dog-bite ); about a BrƒÅhma·πáa who has consecrated fiber

dying on a journey or committing suicide ; VI. Expiation for killing various beasts and birds, for killing S≈´dras, artisans, women, Vaisyas, Ksatriyas, sinful BrƒÅhmanas; eulogy of BrƒÅhmanas; VII. purifications of various articles ( such as vessels of wood, metal &c); about a woman in her menses ; VIII. ParƒÅ≈õara contains several peculiar views. He speaks of only four sons (aurasu, k≈üetraja, datta and k≈ôtrima ) though he does not expressly negative a larger number (chap. 4 p. 14). He eulogises the practice of Satƒ´ (last two verses of chap. 4). The well-known verse of NƒÅrada ( Stripumsa-yoga 97) “naste m·ªôte &c. ‚Äù is read at the end as ‚Äúpatir-anyo na vidyate’ (p. 15). There are a few verses in the IndravajrƒÅ metre (e. g. on pp. 11-12 and 36). The Par√§≈õarasmrti quotes the views of several writers on dharma. Munu is frequently cited in the words ‚ÄúManur-abravid.‚Äù In the 7th chapter alone those words occur four times.484 None of them corres ponds exactly with any verse of the Manusm»ôti. Yet Manu V. 133 may be compared with the first two. Besides these, in the 9th chapter Manu’s view is quoted that on killing an ani mal tbe guilty party should restore a siinilar one to the owner

  1. The ParƒÅ≈õarasmrti

or its price. 495 In the 10th he says that according to Manu uncooked food, milk or oil brought from a s≈´dra’s house and used in cooking in a BrƒÅhmana’s house could be eaten by a BrƒÅhmana. This is similar to Manu IV. 223.406 In the 12th chapter ParƒÅ≈õara cites the view of Manu that a BrƒÅhmana fed on food (cooked) from s≈´dras would become a vulture for twelve births, a pig for ten and a dog for seven. There is nothing corresponding to this in Manu. In the 9th chap. Manu is spoken of as one who knows all ≈õƒÅstras.497 The first verse of the 6th chapter says that Manu deals at length with expia. tion for killing animals.498 This is probably a reference to Manu XI. 131-141. Numerous verses in the ParƒÅ≈õara-smrti are word for word the same as those of the Manusmrti. For example, Manu I. 85-86 occur in the first chapter of ParƒÉsara, Manu V. 160 ( about a widow remaining chaste ) occurs with slight variations in the 4th ; Manu XII. 114-115 ( about pari sad ) occur in the 8th chap. (p. 29); Manu XI. 212 ( about the definition of S√§ntapana ) is the same as ParƒÅ≈õara ( 10th chap. p. 40). Several verses are common to BaudhƒÅyana and ParƒÅƒ£ara, e. g. Baud. Dh. S. I. 1, 8, 11, 14 occur in the eighth chapter of ParƒÅ≈õara (pp. 29, 30). The verse “na DƒÅrikelair na ca sƒÅna bƒÅlair” occurring in ParƒÅ≈õara ( 9th chap. p. 35 ) is quoted as Vasistha’s by Haradatta on Gautama (22. 18). ParƒÅ≈õara is mentioned by name several times (chap. 111.2,p.8, chap. VI. I. p. 18 and p. 23, chap. VII. 1. p. 24, chap. X. 12. p. 38). Usanas is cited on p. 49 (chap. 12), PrajƒÅpati (in IV. 3. p. 13), Sarkha (chap. 4 p. 15). Veda, VedƒÅngas, dharma≈õƒÅstras and sm·ªôtis are spoken of on p. 23 ( 6th chap. ). In the 11th chap. ParƒÅ≈õara refers to several Vedic mantras, inost of which occur in the Rgveda, but two of them, " tejosi ≈õukram” and " devasya tvƒÅ” are not found in the Rgveda. but in the VƒÅj. S. (22, 1 and 1. 24 respectively ). ParƒÅ≈õara

464

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

appears to have been a practical man. He exhorts his readers to save their bodies first in invasions, journeys, diseases, calamities and then care for dharma. He recommends the non-observance of rules of purity in times of difficulty and adherence to the strict rules of dharma when one is at ease. 499

The Mit., A parƒÅrka, Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ, HemƒÅdri and other later works quote ParƒÅ≈õara very frequently. Most of these are found in the extant ParƒÅsarasmrti. For example, vide pp. 1169, 1177, 1180, 1191 &c. of AparƒÅrka, all of which are traced in ParƒÅ≈õara pp. 42, 43, 42 and 16 respectively. Vi√©va r≈´pa quotes ParƒÅ≈õara several times and these quotations can be verified; e. g. on YƒÅj. III. 16 the verge ‚ÄúanƒÅtham” ascrib ed to ParƒÅsara is found in ParƒÅ≈õara chap. III p. 10; on YƒÅj. III. 257 ten verses are cited by Visvar≈´pa from ParƒÅdara which occur in ParƒÅ≈õara with considerable variations (chap. VII. pp. 20-21 ) ; on YƒÅj. III. 262 the verse “gavƒÅm ban dhana"is cited from ParƒÅ≈õara, which is the first verse of the 8th chapter. Therefore, it is quite clear that in the first half of the 9th century the ParƒÅ≈õarasmrti that we have now was considered to be authoritative and the work of an ancient sage. It seems to have known a work of Manu, as seen above. Therefore, it must be assigned to some period between the first and the 5th century of the christian era. In the same direction points the fact that the GarudapurƒÅ≈Üa (chap. 107 ) seems to have known the introductory verses of ParƒÅ≈õara and as shown above (p. 191 ) combines passages of ParƒÅ≈õara in a summary of its teachings.600 The Vibnu-dharmottara which is fre quently quoted by AparƒÅrka and other later works cites verses that are borrowed from ParƒÅ≈õara. For example, chap. 75. 1 of the former is the same as a verse of ParƒÅ≈õara.51

Vi≈õvar≈´pa frequently quotes ParƒÅ≈õara e. g. on YƒÅj. II. 6 he quotes two verses of ParƒÅ≈õara by name that are ParƒÅ≈õara III. 45 and 47; on YƒÅj. III. 30 he cites verses of ParƒÅ≈õara viz. III. 5 (ekƒÅhƒÅt &c.), III. 6 (nƒÅmadhƒÅrakao), III. 8 Ubhaya tra &c.), III. 26 (Samparkesu &c. ), on YƒÅj. III. 250 (Patat yardham &c. ParƒÅ≈õara X. p. 40). MedhƒÉtithi on Manu V. 89 states that in the case of those who perform after-death religious rites for those who commit suicide ParƒÅ≈õara prescribes Taptakrcchra penance. The MitƒÅk·π£arƒÅ quotes about twenty-five verses on YƒÅj. III from ParƒÅ≈õara e g. on YƒÅj. III. 250, 41, on YƒÅj. III. 261 and 6) verses, on YƒÅj. III. 263-64. Apar≈´rka also quotes a few verses on ƒÅcƒÅra (about 9) and about 90 on YƒÅj. III. AparƒÉrka on YƒÉj. The Smrti-candrika (on ≈´hnika pp. 94-95) quotes two verses from VrddhaparƒÅ≈õara.

It is to be noted that AparƒÅrka (p. 1061 on YƒÅj. III. 250 ) quotes three verses from the BbavisyatpurƒÅna which mention that a brƒÅhmana who kills another brƒÅhmana (not learned in the Veda ) may perform the penance declared by ParƒÅ≈õara and cites ten verses from Par√§sara-smrti of which most are found in the printed ParƒÅ≈õara XII JivƒÅnanda pp. 50-51 ) though not all.

There is an extensive work called B»ôhat-ParƒÅ≈õara-san hitƒÉ ( published by Jivananda, part II. pp. 53-309). It is divided into 12 chapters and the last verse says that it con tains 3300 verses and that Suvrata proclaimed the sƒÅstra imparted by ParƒÅ≈õara. The introductory verses contain the same story as that in the ParƒÅ≈õara-smrti and many of the verses in the first chapter of the two works ( such as those about the 19 writers on dharma &c.) are almost the same in both. The total of verses in the printed work comes to about 3000 and not 3300. It appears that the work is a recast of the ParƒÅ≈õarasm·ªôti made by Suvrata. The subjects of the twelve chapters are :- 1. Introductory, the proper sphere of Aryas ; summary of contents; II. Disquisition on the 6 daily karmans, sandhyƒÅ, bath, japa, worship of gods, Vai≈°vadeva in honouring guests ; GƒÅyatr√≠; the dharmas of the Varnas; duties and manners of a householder; agriculture, honour toe COWB; IV. forms of marriage; duties of wives ; JƒÅtakarma ant

This B»ôhat-ParƒÅsara contains a considerable number of verses mostly in the IndravajrƒÅ metre and a few in the VasantatilakƒÅ (e. g. p. 134 ).

The B»ôhat-ParƒÅ≈õara appears to be a late work. It is a recast of the ParƒÅsara-smrti.   1. The NƒÅradasmrti

  1. The Naradasmrti

There are two versions of N√°rada on VyavahƒÅra, a smaller and a larger one. The smaller version was translated by Dr. Jolly in 1876 (Tr√ºbner & Co., London ). The text of the longer version was published by the same scholar in the Bib liotheca Indica series (1885 ) and was translated by him in the Sacred Books of the East Series ( vol. 33). The edition of the text is accompanied up to verse 21 of the 5th title abhyu petyƒÅ≈õusr≈´sƒÅ' by extracts from the commentary of AsabƒÅya as revised by KalyƒÅ·πáabhattu, who was encouraged in the task of revision by Kesavabhatta.

From verse 22 of the same title the printed text is the same as the smaller version. A verse quoted as NƒÅrada’s by KsirasvƒÅmin is not found in the larger version but is found in the smaller version.604 An ancient Ms. of NƒÅrada from Nepal dated 1407 A. D. contains two additional chapters on theft and ordeals. Dr. Jolly includes the first as an appendix and omits that on ordeals on the ground that it is not authentic. One of the colophons of the Nepalese Ms. describes it as ‘iti MƒÅnave-dharmasastre NƒÅradaproktƒÅyƒÅ·πÅ samhitƒÅyƒÅm &c.’ This corroborates what was said above (pp. 149, 156 ) as to the close connection between Manu and N√§rada.

NƒÅrada is not mentioned by YƒÅj√±avalkya in the list of ancient writers on dharma, nor does ParƒÅ≈õara mention him. Visvar≈´pa, however, quotes a verse of Vrddha-YƒÅj√±avalkya (on YƒÅj. I. 4-5), where N√§rada is the first among ten ex pounders of dharma enumerated therein. ‘NƒÅrada is a very ancient name. The Manusmrti ( I. 35 ) mentions NƒÅrada as one of the ten primeval Praj√°patis. In the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata sage N√§rada figures frequently. In Udyoga parva ( 49. 22 ) he is said to have told the Vronis to do their duties ( tasmƒÅt-kar maiva karta vyam-iti hov√°ca NƒÅrada·∏• I etad-hi sarvamƒÅcasta V≈Ü≈°≈Üicakrasya vedavit). SƒÅnti ( 30.6 ) says that N√§rada was the maternal uncle of Parvata. In SƒÅntiparva 29. 13 ff it is stated that NƒÅrada comforted Yudhisthira on the death of his many relatives and warriors by dilating upon the stories of sixteen ancient kings and heroes who had also similar

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

sorrows. In Salyaparva, N√§rada is said to have informed Balarama that his two disciples Bhima and Duryodhana were going to fight with maces. There NƒÅrada is described as holding a fine Vƒ´nƒÅ as an expert in dance and song and as stirring up feuds and always fond of quarrels (prakarta kalahƒÅnƒÉm ca nityam ca kalaha priyah) in chap. 54. 18-20. According to the MahƒÅbhƒÅsya on VƒÅrtika 15 on PƒÅ·πá. (VIII. 1. 15, Kielhorn ed. III. p. 371), NƒÅrada and Parvata may be spoken of as ‘dvandvam NƒÅrada parvatau as they are a famous pair that is ‘atyantasahacarita’ (not even Yudhisthira and Arjuna are so ).

The printed NƒÅrada contains three introductory chapters on the principles of judical procedure ( VyavahƒÅra-mƒÅt≈ÜkƒÅ ) and on the judicial assembly ( sabhƒÅ ). Then the following titles of law are dealt with one after another :- r≈ÜƒÅdƒÅna ( recovery of debts ), u panidhi (deposit, lending, bailment ), sambh≈´ya-samutthƒÅna (partnership ), dattƒÅpradƒÅnika (gifts and resumption thereof), abhyupetya-asu≈õr≈´ƒ∑ƒÅ (breach of contract of service ), vetanasya-anapƒÅkarma (non-payment of wages), asvƒÅmivikraya ( sale without ownership ), vikrƒ´yƒÅ sampradƒÉna (non-delivery after sale ), krƒ´tƒÅnusaya ( rescis sion of purchase ), samayasyƒÅna pƒÅkarma ( violation of conven tions of corporations, guilds &c.); simƒÅbandha ( settlement of boundaries ); strƒ´pumsayoga ( marital relation); dƒÅyabhƒÅga ( partition and inheritance ); sƒÅhasƒÅ·∏• (offences in which force is the principal element), such as homicide, robbery, rape &c.; vƒÅkpƒÅrusya ( defamation and abuse ) and dundapƒÅrusya (hurt of various kinds ); prakirnaka ( miscellaneous wrongs ). The appendix deals with theft ; a few remarks are made on that topic under the title of ‘sƒÅhasa ‘.

It will be noticed that NƒÅrada follows the Manusmrti to a considerable extent in the nomenclature and the arrange ment of the eighteen titles. Some of the titles are differently named by NƒÅrada, e. g. he speaks of upanidhi, while Manu employs the word niksepa. NƒÅrada seems to have included the ‘gvƒÅmipƒÅlavivƒÅda’ of Manu in vetanasya-ana p√§karma’. He makes one title of dy≈´ta and sum≈´hvaya. NƒÅrada includes strisamgrahana under sƒÅbasa and adds three titles, viz. abhyupetya-asusr≈´sƒÅ, vikrƒ´yƒÅsampradƒÅna and prakiraka. The Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ expressly 60s says that it follows the word

  1. The NƒÅradasmrti

469

of NƒÅrada in preference to that of Manu as regards the nomenclature and the sequence of the titles of law. NƒÅrada follows Manu in speaking of witnesses in the section on r·ª•ƒÅdƒÅna and in treating of theft after the eighteen titles have been dealt with ( vide Manu IX, 256 ff. ).

The printed NƒÅrada contains 1028 verses (including 61 on theft in the appendix ). About seven hundred of these verses occur in various nibandhas as quotations. Up to the 21st verse of the section ‘abhyuretyƒÅ≈õu≈õr≈´≈üƒÅ’ the commen tary of AsahƒÅya furnishes a valuable check for the authenti city of the text. For the remaining portion, there are important data as to its authenticity, sequence and readings. Visvar≈´pa, who belongs to the first half of the 9th century, quotes about fifty verses of Narada (generally by name ). The text that he had before him was essentially the same as vuat of the printed edition except in a very few cases. Out of the seven verses of Nirada on samayasya-ana pƒÅkarma’ Visvar≈´pa quotes five ( on YƒÅj. II. 190 and 196 ) and expressly states that N√°rada wound up his chapter on that topic with the verse dosavat karanam &c.’ as the printed text does. On YƒÅj. II. 226 Visvar≈´pa distinctly says that the verse ‘yameva hyativarteran’ &c. is followed immediately by ‘malƒÅ hyete manusyesu’. This is the case with the printed text also (dy≈´tasa mƒÅhvaya, verses 13-14). On YƒÅj. III.252 Visvar≈´pa quotes a verse of N√°rada about the three kinds of wealth, viz. sukla, sabala and krsna, which does not occur in that form in NƒÅrada, though the latter contains similar dicta.608 Visvar≈´pa contains no quotation from N√°rada on the topics of ƒÅcƒÅra or prƒÅya≈õcitta. The same is the case with Medh√† tithi and the MitƒÅksarƒÅ. MedhƒÉtithi somewhat inaccurately summarises the introductory words (in prose) of NƒÅrada ( vide note 269 above). MedhƒÉtithi frequently quotes NƒÅrada particularly from the sections on r≈ÜƒÅdƒÅna (vide on Manu 8. 47, 155, 149 ) and dƒÅyabhƒÅga (on Manu 8, 28, 29, and 207, 209 and 143). On Manu 8, 349 he quotes NƒÅrada on partnership (verse 10 ), ou 8. 216 he quotes NƒÅrada ( vetanasya-anapƒÉ. karma, verse 5). In some cases MedhƒÅtithi cites NƒÅrada’s verses without naming him e. g. on Manu 9. 76 he quotes the

well-known verse ‘naste mite pravrajite &c.’ ( NƒÅrada on marital relation, verse 97 ) as ‘smrtyantara’. I. 26-29a ); Agui 253. 13-30 are the verses defining the eighteen titles from ruƒÅdƒÅna to prakƒ´r·πáaka contained in N√§rada and occur in the game order in both. The readings preserved in the Agni purƒÅna deserve some discussion. Agni (253. 3-4 ) reads

dharma≈õca vyavabƒÅrasca…uttarah p≈´rvasƒÅdhakah,’ while NƒÅrada has p≈´rvabƒÅdhakah.’ Agni reads “caritram sam grahe pumsƒÅm rƒÅjƒÅj√±ƒÅyƒÅm tu sƒÅdhanam' (253.5), while NƒÅrada has ‘caritram pustakarane r√§jƒÅj√±ƒÅyƒÅm tu sƒÅsanam.’ Agni ( 253.15 ) reads ‘dattv√§dra vyam ca samyag-yah,’ while NƒÅrada (dattƒÅpradƒÅnika I) reads ‘dattv√§ dravyamasamyag yah.’ The Agni ( 253. 11 ) reads SarkƒÅ sadbhistu sa·πÅsary√•t tattvam soƒèhƒÅbhidar≈õanƒÅt' and avoids the rare word ‘hod hƒÅbhi-’ in NƒÅrada ¬∑ SankƒÅsatƒÅm tu sa·πÅsargƒÅt tattvam hodhƒÅ bhidarsap√°t' (VyavahƒÅramƒÅtskƒÅ I. 27). Aksavajra &c. ' ( 253. 29). The Mit. ( on YƒÅj. II. 199 ) and Vir. (p. 718 ) follow printed NƒÅrada in the last case and also in the other cases. The Mit. quotes more than 240 verses of NƒÅrada, sometimes in large groups. For example, it quotes over eleven verses in its Introduction to Y√°j. II. 182, nine verses more on YƒÅj. II. 182 itself and seven verses in introdu cing the topic of SƒÅhasa in YƒÅj. II. 230. In the Smrti-can drikƒÅ, HemƒÅdri, ParƒÅ≈õaramƒÅdhaviya and other later niban dhas numerous verses of NƒÅrada are quoted on topics of ƒÅcƒÅra SrƒÅddha, prƒÅyascitta. For example, HemƒÅdri (caturvargao, vol. III. part 2, pp. 159, 183, 185, 223, 235 ) quotes several verses of N√°rada on EkƒÅda≈õƒ´ and a verse of NƒÅrada about the astrological yoga called padmaka. The Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ (I. pp. 198-199 ) quotes 26 verses on the worship of NƒÅrƒÅyana, the last of which is the well-known verse dhyeyah sadƒÅ savit≈ümandala-madhyavarti &c.' and the same work (on srƒÅddha p. 354 ) quotes a verse of NƒÅrada in wbich Sunday and SamkrƒÅnti are mentioned. The question arises whether these quotations of NƒÅrada on ƒÅcƒÅra and prƒÅya≈õcitta amoralli ed topics are the work of the same N√§rada that wrote on

1917

  1. ‘The NƒÅradasmarthi

471

VyavahƒÅra. From the fact that early writers like Visvar≈´pa, MedhƒÉtithi and Vij√±ƒÅne≈õvara do not contain a single quota tion of NƒÅrada on topics other than that of vyavahƒÅra, it appears probable that the quotations on ƒÅcƒÅra and prƒÅyas citta belong to a later date than the NƒÅradasmrti on vyava hƒÅra and either did not exist in the days of Vi√∫var≈´pa and MedhƒÉtithi or had not attained canonical authority in those days. There is in the India Office Library a ms. of NƒÅrada sm·ªôti in three chapters and 322 verses dealing exclusively with ƒÅcƒÅra and prƒÅya≈õcitta (vide Jolly’s Introduction p. 5 to edition of text).

The NƒÅradasmrti, excluding the introductory passage in prose about the successive abridgments of the original work of Manu by NƒÅrada, MƒÅrkandeya and Sumati BhƒÅrgava, is written in the sloka metre except in the case of two verses (verse 38 of the 2nd chap. of vyavahƒÉra-mƒÅt≈ÜkƒÅ and the last verse of the chapter on sabha). N√§rada himself is mentioned by name in connection with the ordeals (r·∫°ƒÅdƒÅna verse 253 ).507 The first person also occurs in ‘ata·∏• param prava ksyƒÅmi’ (ruƒÅdƒÅna 343 ). AcƒÅryas are cited in dattƒÅprada nika’ (verse 5). Dharma≈õƒÅstra and Artha≈õƒÅstra are mentioned ( vyavahƒÅramƒÅtrka, chap. I, 37 and 39) and Narada lays down the rule as in YƒÅj. (II. 21 ) that in a conflict between the two the former should furnish the rule of conduct.608 N√§rada refers to Vasistha’s rule about interest (ruƒÅdƒÅna 99 ). Two verses are quoted from a PurƒÅna.508 Manu is named in several places (r≈ÜƒÅdƒÅna verses 250, 251, 326 ).610 The first

passage about Manu is quoted by Visvar≈´pa on YƒÅj. (II. 98 ) and corresponds closely with the teaching of Manu (8. 113). But the other passages crediting Manu with dividing ordeals into five kinds and giving his view about poison ordeal have no corresponding passage in the extant Manu. Therefore, NƒÅrada had a version of Manu before him that was somewhat different in certain respects from our Manu or NƒÅrada may be referring to Vrddha or B»ôhat Manu. Besides this, there is one remarkable fact to be noted about the relation of Manu and NƒÅrada. There are about 50 verses that are common to Manu and NƒÅrada. Manu 8. 12-14 and 18-19 are NƒÅrada (sabhƒÅ, verses 8-10 and 12-13 in a different order), Manu 8. 140-141 =N. (r≈ÜƒÅdƒÅna 99-100), Manu 8. 148-149=N. (r≈ÜƒÅdƒÅna 80-81), M. 8. 143=N. (mn. 129, M. 8. 64=N. (r. 177 ), M. 8. 72=N. ( ¬•. 189 ), M. 8. 93 and 113=N. (r. 199, 201 ), M.98-99 = N(r. 208, 209 and Udyoga parva 35. 33-34 ), M. 8. 89=N. (r. 225 ), M. 8. 186-187, 189 191=N. ( upanidhi 10-13), M. 8. 232-233, 235=N. ( vetanasya-anap√§karma 14-16 in a diffe rent order ), M. 9. 47=N. ( marital relation, verse 28 ), M. 8. 224-225=N. (marital-relation, 33-34), M, 9. 357-353=N. ( marital relation, 65-66 in reverse order ), M. 1.3=N. ( daya bhƒÅga 31 ), M. 9. 216 =N. (dƒÅyabhƒÅga 44), M. 8. 267-269=N. (vƒÅkpƒÅrusya 15-17 ), M. 9. 270-272=N. ( vƒÅk pƒÅrusya 22-24 ), M. 8. 281-284 =N. ( danda-pƒÅrusya ( 26-29), M. 4. 87=N (prakir≈Üaka 44 ).

NƒÅrada, mnƒÅdƒÅna 158, ‘srotriyƒÅs-tƒÅpasƒÅ v·ªâddhƒÅ ye ca pravrajitƒÅ narƒÅh I asƒÅksinas-te vacan≈´n nƒÅtra heturudƒÅhstah’ has probably Manu 8.65 in view where we read ‘na sƒÅk≈üi…na ≈õrotriyo na lingastho na sajigebhyo vinirgata·∏•’.

Besides these, there are several cases where NƒÅrada closely agrees with Manu though the verses are not identical, e. g. NƒÅrada ( sƒÅhasa 19 ) may be compared with Manu 9. 271 and N√°rada ( appendix on theft, verses 1-4 ) may be compared with Manu ( 9. 256-260 ). These facts establish that NƒÅrada is based on a version of Manu that was essentially the same as the extant text of Manu, though there was some difference here and there. NƒÅrada contains several verses that occur in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. For example, SƒÅnti III. 66=N. (vyavahƒÅra mƒÅt≈ÜkƒÅ 72 ),611 Udyoga 35.58=N. ( sabhƒÅ, verse 18 ), Ustega

51 ‡§§‡§≤‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ ‡§ñ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§§‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø

‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡§®‡§É ‡••

1917

  1. The NƒÅradasmrti

473

35.31-32=N. (r. 202–203). The well-known verse of the MahƒÉ bhƒÅrata on the greatness of speaking the truth (Santi, 162.26) occurs in NƒÅrada, verse 211 on p. 104 (SBE Vol. 33 p. 93 ). There are several cases where the text of Kautilya agrees with NƒÅrada.513 In some of these cases the agreement is almost word for word. 613 A half verse on poison-ordeal ( viz. Tvam visa…vyavasthitah ) is the same in both Y√£j. II. 110 and NƒÅrada IV. 325 p. 124 ( SBE. vol. 33 pp. 115-116 ).

Though NƒÅrada is based on Manu, he differs in several essential matters from Manu. We have seen the difference between them in the nomenclature of the titles of law. Manu only casually mentions the ordeals of fire and water ( 8.114 ), while NƒÅrada enumerates five kinds of ordeals, describes them at length and adds two more viz. tandula-bhaksana and taptumƒÅ≈Üu (inƒÅdina, verses 259-348 ). He allows Niyoga (marital relation, verses 80-88 ), while Manu strongly con demns it. He allows remarriage of women (NƒÅrada, marital relation, 97), while Manu is against it. Manu men tions seven kinds of slaves (8. 415 ), while N√§rada raises their number to fifteen ( abhyupetyƒÅ≈õusr≈´≈°ƒÅ, verses 26-28 ); Manu condemns gambling outright (9, 221-228 ), while NƒÅrada allows it under state control and as a source of re. venue ; N√§rada is further far more systematic than Manu and is full of divisions and sub-divisions; for example, he divides property into three kinds, each of which is again subdivided into seven varieties (mnƒÅdƒÅna 44-47 ); NƒÅrada divides the law of gifts into four sections, which are further subdivided into 32; he subdivides the eighteen titles into 132 (vyavahƒÅra mƒÅtrkƒÅ I. 25 ).

There are a few points which are almost peculiar to NƒÅrada such as the fourteen kinds of impotent persons (stri pumsayoga 11-13), the three kinds of punarbh≈´s and four kinds of svairi≈Üis (ibid. verses 45-52).

‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®

1974 11 FTTT, 549ER TELT I. 10-11; the first half in each porno is the same in ‡§ï‡•å‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø.

FOUNDED

1917

474

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

NƒÅrada is probably later than YƒÅj√±avalkya. YƒÅj. mentions only five kinds of ordeals, while NƒÅrada knows seven and the former’s treatment of them is not so exhaustive as NƒÅrada’s. The rules of judicial procedure in NƒÅrada are more systematic and exhaustive than those of YƒÅj. NƒÅrada is more conservative than YƒÅj. For example, NƒÅrada nowhere recognises the right of the widow to succeed to her deceased husband. NƒÅrada cites more definitions than YƒÅj. In some respects, however, NƒÅrada is more reticent than YƒÅj.; NƒÅrada gives no rules about the succession of gotrajas and bandhus as YƒÅj. does. In a few res pects NƒÅrada agrees with the views of Manu instead of with

YƒÅj., such as allowing a brƒÅhma·πáa to marry a s≈´dra woman. NƒÅrada regards sexual intercourse with a pravrajitƒÅ (female ascetic ) as a mortal sin ( strƒ´pu·πÅsayoga 74-75 ), while both Manu ( 8. 363 ) and YƒÅj. (II. 293 ) treat it lightly. Taking all these things into consideration it may be said that NƒÅrada flourished nearly at the same time as or somewhat later than YƒÅj.

It may be noted that in an Inscription from CampƒÅ dated about sake 1092 (i. e. 1170 A. D.) a king is described as

versed in all the Dharma≈õƒÅstras, notably the N√°radiya and Bhargaviya'; vide Dr. R. C. Majumdar’s ‘Ancient Indian Colonies’, vol. I at end p. 199 No. 81.

NƒÅrada contains several rare words such as “hodha” (in vyavahƒÅramƒÅt≈ôkƒÅ 1.27, meaning ‘one’s property when lost or stolen’). He gives expression to certain principles of law and politics, such as that a man is master of his own house, in other words, a man’s house is his castle ; 614 he highly eulo gises the office of the king, almost assigning it a divine origin and exhorts the people to obey and honour even a weak and undeserving king. 616 Mr. Jayasval sees in this and in the fact that NƒÅrada speaks of dinƒÅra while the Mrcchakatika speaks of nƒÅ≈Üaka indications that NƒÅrada belongs to the fourth cen tury, is later than the drama, is propping up the authority

stilu

19.17

  1. The NƒÅradasmrti

475

of a new dynasty and flourished under the Imperial Guptas (C. W. N. vol. 17, p. CCLXXXV). He regards a person as minor till the sixteenth year. 516 This limit was probably first fixed by NƒÅrada. NƒÅrada further boldly says that in case of conflict between dharma≈õƒÅstra and usages, the latter have to be followed, as they are directly observed. 517

As NƒÅrada‚Äôs is regarded as an authoritative sm·ªôti by Vis var≈´pa, MedhƒÅtithi and other later writers and as AsahƒÅya, who is mentioned by name in the commentary of Visvar≈´pa, wrote a comment on NƒÅrada, the NƒÅradasmrti must be older by some centurie : than the 8th century, the latest date to which AsahƒÅya can be assigned. Bana in his KƒÅdambari com pares the royal palace to NƒÅradiya.518 Ordinarily NƒÅradƒ´ya standing by itself would denote the NƒÅradapurana ( compare Vismu-purƒÅna 3.6. 21 where we have the form NƒÅradiya for the purƒÅƒºa ). The NƒÅrada-purana ( Venkatesvara Press edition, Bombay ) contains, however, no treatment of rƒÅjadharma. BƒÅna may have intended a violent pun, meaning the palace where the duties of kings were being expounded (Kvarnya mƒÅna ), like the N√°radiya in which rƒÅjadharma has not been set forth ( avarnyamƒÅna ).' European scholars like Dr. Jolly and B√ºhler hold that BƒÅna refers to the extant NƒÅradasmrti. But on this explanation also the difficulty is not entirely got over. The extant N√§rada can hardly be described as a treatise on rƒÅjadharma. It deals only in an indirect way with one aspect of the king’s duties and is rather concerned with vye vahƒÅra and the duties of the subjects towards each other from the strictly legal point of view. If we turn to the Mahabh√° rata and other works, we shall find that rƒÅjadharma meant something different from what is treated of in the NƒÅrada smrti. Therefore Bana’s reference to the NƒÅradiya is of a doubtful character. The RƒÅjanƒ´ti-ratnƒÅkara of Candesvara frequently quotes N√§rada on politics ( pp. 3, 13, 79 ). These quotations are not traced in the printed NƒÅrada. Therefore it is highly probable that Bana refers to a distinct work of NƒÅrada on politics which has not yet been recovered.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

:: From the RƒÅjanitiratnƒÅkara of Cande≈õvara published for the BORS of Patna ( 1924 ) by Mr. K. P. Jayaswal it appears that Cande≈õvara knew a work of N√°rada on RƒÅjadharma. On p. 3618 of that work NƒÅrada on RƒÅjaniti is cited for dilating upon three grades of rulers viz. Samr√°t (an emperor to whom other kings pay tribute ) also called ‘cakravartin’ and ‘Sakura’ and akara' rulers. On p. 75 Cande≈õvara quotes the words of HƒÅrita and NƒÅrada to the effect that a king should trans mit his kingdom to the eldest son after providing for the maintenance of other sons if he has several sons. The Vrddha

Harita-smrtisan in the Anandasrama collection of Smrtis (1905 A. D.) says that KƒÅtyƒÅyana, Manu, YƒÅj√±avalkya and NƒÅrada described at length the rƒÅjadharmas which he himself dealt with.

21

The VyavahƒÅramƒÅtrkƒÅ of Jim≈´tavƒÅhana and the ParƒÅ sara-Madhaviya (vol. III, part I, p. 203 ) quote a verse from N√°rada, the latter half of which is the same as the latter half of a verse in the Vikramorva≈°ƒ´ya.521 The doctrine attributed to NƒÅrada is found in YƒÅj. (II. 20 ) and the Visnudharina sutra (6. 22 ) but not in the same words. Unfortunately the date of KƒÅlidƒÅsa is far from being universally accepted, but the fourth or first half of the 5th century is often accepted 48 the probable date. There is further difficulty in the fact that the text of the Vikramorvasiya has been largely tampered with. If the verse is a genuine part of the drama, it seems natural to suppose that KƒÅlidƒÅsa turns a well-known legal maxim to a somewhat bumorous use. It is hard to suppose

‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡•• 520 ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®

‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡•• ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§ VII. 270-71. 521 ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§≠‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡••

FOUNDED U

1917

  1. The NƒÅradasmrti

477

UL

522

that NƒÅrada would borrow the words of a dramatist for sett ing forth a legal maxim. This would push back the date of N√°rada far beyond the 5th century. NƒÅrada in two places uses the word ‚ÄúdinƒÅra,” 522 once in the sense of a golden orna. ment and again as a coin or unit of value also called “suvarna.” In this last case he says that “dinƒÅra is equal to 48 kƒÅrsƒÅ panas or twelve dhƒÅnakas.” Jolly (R. u. S. p. 23 ) thinks that Indian dinƒÅras can scarcely be older than the 2nd century A. D., although in the times of the Indo-Scythian kings coins of the weight of din√§ra occur. Therefore Jolly is of opinion that NƒÅrada is later than 300 A. D. Winternitz ( History of Indian Literature, vol. II. p. 216 n. 4 ) follows him in this assumption that all Sanskrit works in which the word dinƒÅra occurs nust be later than the 2nd or 3rd century A. D. It may be that the golden dinƒÅras most numerously found in India belong to the 2nd and 3rd centuries A. D. But as Keith points out (J. R. A. S. 1915 p. 504 ) Jolly’s assumption is wrong and the introduction of vinurus into India need not be later than the beginning of the Christian era. Golden dinƒÅras were first coined in Rome in 207 B. C. and the oldest Indian pieces corresponding in weight to the Roman Denarius were struck by Indo-Scythian kings who reigned from the first century B. C. (W. B. p. 44). Therefore there is nothing to prevent us from holding that Narada flourished in the first centuries of the Christian era, i, e. between 100 and 300 A. D. Mr. Jayasval assigns him to the 4th century A. D. and after the M≈üccha katika. Most scholars would not be prepared to assign to the Mrcchakatika so early a date as the 3rd century A. D. Besides Mr. Jayasval builds his theory on very slend. er foundations. Because the drama employs the word nƒÅ≈Üaka and NƒÅrada speaks of dinƒÅra only, no chronological conclusion as to the priority of the one to the other can be drawn. After both words became current in the language, one author, though later, may employ one word, while another, though earlier, may employ the other.

While the first volume was in the Press, an edition of the NƒÅradiya Manu-sambitƒÅ with the bhƒÅsya of BhavasvƒÅmin

522 ‡§Æ‡§£‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø

478

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

was published in 1929 in the Trivandrum Sanskrit Series, edited by K. Sambasiva Sastri (based on four Mes). The work claims to be a version of the Manusmrti by N√§rada. Prof. T. R. Chintamani contributed a lengthy paper on this version of the NƒÅradasm»ôti to the Kunhan Raja Presentation volume, published by the Adyar Library, Madras ( in 1946 ) pp. 153-196. He points out that the main differences between the longer and shorter versions of N√§rada published by Prof, Jolly are these : the shorter text omits the section on thefts, does not cite the verses on ordeals in a separate chapter and omits the chapter on legal procedure. The longer version has 1028 verses including an appendix on thefts (of 61 verses ). The shorter version has 870 verses and the text on which BhavasvƒÅmin comments has 877 } verses. The edition with BhavasvƒÅmibhƒÅ≈üya has at the end a chapter on five ordeals dealt with in 46. verses ( the five being Dhata, Agni, Udaka, Visa and Kosa ). There are many variations between the Smrti as published by Dr. Jolly and that published with Bhavasvamin’s bhƒÅsya. On pp. 159-193 Prof. Chintamani sets out the numerous ( nearly a thousand ) differences ( small and also large ) in the Smrti as published by Dr. Jolly and as found in the NƒÅradiya ManusamhitƒÅ. And on pp. 193-196 Prof. Chintamani prints the text of the 2nd Appendix (on five ordeals with 46 verses ) in the Nepalese Ms held to be spurious by Jolly and contained in the version of BhavasvƒÅ min after the section called Prakƒ´r·πáaka.

The editor of Bhavasvamin’s bhƒÅsya surmises (on p. 4 of his English Introduction ) from the fact that all the Mss. of the bhƒÅsya were found only in the Kerala country and the fact that many of the brƒÅhma·πáas that officiate as sacrificial priests in central Kerala bear the name Bhavas v√°min, that the bhƒÅsyakƒÅra of NƒÅrada was a brƒÅhma·πáa from Kerala. North India suffered greatly from the ravages of foreign inva sions from the early centuries of the Christian era onwards by H≈´nas and others for several centuries, while South India was much better off during those centuries. Therefore the Mos. of the works of comparatively early writers of the North are often not found in North India but only in South Indie (BhƒÅnaha‚Äôs work on Poetics being a well-known instance

PEON.

1917

HM

480

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

and copper. In the Indische studien', vol. XVIII pp. 289-412 a ms. of LokaprakƒÅ≈õa of Ksemendra ( latter half of 11th century A.D.) is discussed in which the word dinƒÅra is frequently used (e. g. on pp. 339, 391 ) and we have a formula forward ing a dinƒÅra-hundikƒÅ' (on p. 342 ). HundikƒÅ stands for ‘Hundi used by travellers.

The time when BhavasvƒÅmin flourished is not free from doubt. Prof. Chintamani concludes (on p. 157 of Kunhan Raja volume) that BhavasvƒÅmin flourished in the early centu ries of the Christian era. I demur to this conclusion which is based mainly on Dr. Altekar’s view quoted in a note on p. 157 that it is very unlikely that gold dƒ´dƒÅras were in cir culation after 600 A. D. in the MathurƒÅ and Kanoj area.’ But it is clear that in the 11th century gold coins called DinƒÅras were current in Kashmir and if BhavasvƒÅmin was a Kashmir ian or had travelled and stayed there for some time he would easily have known them and referred to them. Therefore, Dr. Altekar’s opinion about BhavasvƒÅmin’s date is worth little.

BhavasvƒÅmin refers several times to other explanations of NƒÅrada’s verses with the words ‘anya aha’as on ‘inƒÅdana’ v. 195, ‚ÄúStrƒ´pu·πÅsayoga’ v. 30, DƒÅya vibhƒÅga verses 13, 14, prakirnaka v. 80. He refers here and there to different read ings in NƒÅrada as on RuƒÅdƒÅna verses 67, 153, Vikrƒ´yƒÅsampra dƒÅna, verse 12, Strƒ´pumsayoga, verses 2, 3, 15, 16, 29, 83. He quotes about two dozen verses of Manu. His commentary ex plains the words of NƒÉrada’s verges, is generally concise, and makes no show of learning. He cites a few s≈´tras of PƒÅ·πáini a few passages as ≈öruti (as on m√¨ƒÅdƒÅna 53, 97). It is re markable that he cites (on mnƒÅdƒÅna 190) ‘nƒÅputranya lokostƒ´ti’ as Sm»ôti, which is really Ait. Br. (VII.3). He quotes Vas. Dharmas≈´tra on mnƒÅdƒÅna verse 94 and on V√§g DandapƒÅrusya verse 20. It is noteworthy that he speaks of the present Manusmrti as Bhrgu-SamhitƒÅ$5 or BhƒÅrgavi

  1. The NƒÅrada–smrti

481

sambitƒÅ; for example, on Stripu√≠sayoga verse 111 he quotes Manu X. 19 as BhƒÅryavi-samhit√£ and on Manu VIII. 274 as Bhrgusamhit√£ on VƒÅguandapƒÅrusya' v. 20. He quotes VƒÅlmiki and Vy√§sa on RnƒÅdƒÅna' 628 verse 32. He quotes a S√°rd≈´lavikridita verse on krodha' (anger) and a verse on unmƒÅda'(delirium, or madness ) due to five causes on DattƒÅpradƒÅnika 8-10. Ou Rn√ºlƒÅna verse 31 he quotes an ƒÅryƒÅ on the importance of Ganita. On ‘R≈ÜƒÅdƒÅna verge 72 BhavasvƒÅmin quotes a verse of Vararuci explaining the meaning of the words ‘poganda, ku≈Üi’ and ' pangu ‘.527

As in Bhavasvƒ´min’s day various readings had already arisen in the N√§radasmrti and as he refers several times to the explanations of previous commentators, BhavasvƒÅmin would have to be placed (conjecturally ) some centuries after NƒÅrada i. e. between 700 and 1000 A. D.

The late Prof. Rangaswami Aiyangar in his Introduction to Brhaspati assigns BhavasvƒÅmin to the 8th century A. D. and in the footnote 4 on that page le asserts ‘Bhavasvamin, like M√§dhavasvƒÅmin and SkandasvƒÅmin, belongs to a period long anterior to Visvar≈´pa (circa A. D. 800 ) and refers in support to Journal of Oriental Research V. 325’. The reference to the journal appears to be wrong.

It may be noted that Visvar≈´pa quotes hardly any verses of NƒÅrada on two epics not pertaining to VyavahƒÅra except one verse on YƒÅj. I. 34 where he speaks of three kinds of »ôtviks’. But the same cannot be said about the MitƒÅk·π£arƒÅ. A few verses not strictly related to VyavahƒÅra topics are mentioned by it as occurring in NƒÅrada’s work. For example, on Yaj. III. 39 the Mit. quotes a verse of N√§rada that allows a brƒÅhuana to sell sesame in exchange of food-grains for securing medicine when he is ill or for the purpose of a Yaj√±a. This occurs in the section on RnƒÅdƒÅna ( 66 ). AparƒÅrka also quotes this verse (p. 933 ). Probably it was part of the king’s duty to remind a brƒÅhmana of the restrictions laid down on him by ≈õƒÅstra. AparƒÅrka ( p. 29 )

TRS

POONA

528 ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç ‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ó‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§æ

a 37TAT: ll on FETT V. 32. 527 afar11 TERETFOTarpuffastur greiRUT: 1 Pact:

atrogafor-aga: il fat i on FSUTATA 72. aue h√∏re seems to be som a lexicographer,

482

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

cites 24 verses on the actions that are comprehended under ista and pƒÅrtu. But the Sm·ªôticandrik≈´ quotes from NƒÅrada at least 50 verses on ƒÅhnika and at least 16 on ≈õrƒÅddha-kƒÅnda, one of which refers to Sunday and Sankranti and on the selection of EkƒÅda≈õƒ´ for & fast when joined to the 10th or 12th tithi.

It is likely that non-VyavahƒÅra topics came to be added as NƒÅrada’s a century or two before 1000 A. D., since the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ (1150-1225 ) A. D. contains numerous verses of NƒÅrada on nop-VyavahƒÅra matters. 528

It is difficult to say anything as to the home of NƒÅrada. In the appendix on theft NƒÅrada in one place says that in the south a silver kƒÅr≈°ƒÅpana is current, that in the east it is equal to twenty panas and that he does not follow the standard of kƒÅrsƒÅpana current in the land of the five rivers.628 From these data and from the fact that the oldest mss. of NƒÅrada come from Nepal and that an old commentary on N√§rada in NewƒÅri was composed in Nepal, Dr. Jolly conjectures that NƒÅrada’s home was to be sought in Nepal. This is all pure guess-work. There is no reason why NƒÅrada could not have hailed from Central India. The places where the oldest and best mss. of a work are found car bardly ever be indications of the original home of an ancient author. BhƒÅmaba is by common consent a Kashmirian writer on Poetics, but most of the mss. of his work so far found come from Southern India.

Prof. D. R. Bhandarkar (Carmichael Lectures 1918, p. 90), probably following the NayacandrikƒÅ, hazards the conjecture that the writer called Piguna cited in the Kau≈£iliya is another name of NƒÅrada. Beyond the bare fact that NƒÅrada is often credited in the PurƒÅnas with the role of instigating feuds and quarrels and that the word pi≈õuna means “wicked, back biter‚Äù, there is nothing to support this identification.

A Jyotir-NƒÅrada is quoted by Bhattoji in his commentary on the Caturvimsatimata ( p. 11 ). A B»ôhan-NƒÅrada is quoted

528 ‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ã‡§™‡•ã‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡•Ä ‡••

maart ( 764TVS p. 364 ). 529 ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§™‡§£‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø ‡§∞‡•å‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§™‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞

‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Å ‡••… ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§™‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç , PHCTAE ATA 11 luna 9460 57 and 59.

1-

  1. The NƒÅrada-smrti

488 by Raghunandana and a Laghu-Narada by the Nirnaya sindbu and the SamskƒÅra-Kaustubha.

In the MahƒÅbh√§rata several opinions are attributed to Narada. One of them condemns the eating of flesh.530 The first half of the last verse is the same as Manu 5.52. Narada is credited with having divided utp√§tas (portents ) into three varieties.581 NƒÅrada is said to have held the view that one must always be active.533 It appears that all these views are taken from some work or works from NƒÅrada. The first is probably taken from NƒÅrada’s version of the Manusmrti of which the Puranas speak as stated above ( note 270).

The Introductory prose passages of the NƒÅradasmrti (I. 1-5) are interesting and are therefore set out in the note below.533 ___For AsahƒÅya, the commentator of Narada, vide section 59 below. 530 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ã‡§µ‡§∏‡•Ä

‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® 115. 14. 531 ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•É‡§∑‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö

‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§É ‡•• ‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ 46. 8-9. 532 ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•ã‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§É ‡•§ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ 49.

‡§á‡§π ‡§π‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§É ‚Äò‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç’ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§ø‡§ò‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡•ã ‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ! ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡•• ‡•ß‡•• ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ß‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§® ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•® ‡•• ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ß‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•© ‡•• ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ß‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™ ‡•• ‡•™ ‡•• ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∂‡§§‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§® ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä

Titute

ROML-1

PROHIT

SOUNDED

1927

484

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

  1. Brhaspati Brbaspati as a s≈´tra writer on politics has been dealt with above ( section 26 ). In this section Brhaspati the jurist will be spoken of. The complete smrti of B»ôhaspati on law has not yet been discovered. It will be, when discovered, a very precious monument of ancient India, exhibiting the high water mark of Indian acumen in strictly legal principles and definitions. Dr. F√ºbrer collected together 84 verses ascribed to Brhaspati in the legal treatises of AparƒÅrka and others with German translation and notes ( Leipzig, 1879 ) and Dr. Jolly collected about 711 verses of Brhaspati on law and translated them in the Sacred Books of the East (vol. 33 ).

YƒÅj. (I. 4-5 ) enumerates Brhaspati among the writers on dharma, but he is probably referring to Brlaspati’s work on politics. The com. on the Nitiv√°kyrimpta (p. 7) quotes the first verse of Brhaspati’s Niti≈°astra.

We saw above how Bihaspati closely follows the extant Manusmrti, how he pointedly refers to the text of Manu ( notes 345-349) and therefore might by analogy be styled a vƒÅrtikakƒÅra of Manu. In many places Brhaspati explains and illustrates the laconic treatment of Manu. Manu (8. 153 ) speaks of four varieties of interest (Cakra, KƒÅla, K√§rita, and KƒÅyika ), but does not explain these terms. Brhaspati ex plains them clearly.534 Manu (8.49 ) enumerates five modes of recovering a debt (dharma, vyavahira, chala, ƒÅcarita, bala ) but leaves them unexplained ; Brhaspati devotes several verses to the explanation of these terms ( vide Kull√ºka on Manu 8. 49). B»ôhaspati gives elaborate rules regarding partnership. Brhaspati enumerates nine ordeals ( of fire, water, poison, balance, kosa, taptamƒÅsa, tundulas, dharmadharma, phala ); while Manu barely alludes to two. Manu devotes only three verses to samvidvyatikrama (8. 219-221 ), but Brhaspati must have devoted at least a score of verses to this topic, as AparƒÅrka alone quotes 17 verses of Bphaspati on this title.

The order in which the topics of law appeard in Brhaspati can be settled with tolerable certainty from the quotations in Apar√°rka, VivƒÅdaratnƒÅkara, Viramitrodaya and other works.

..

.

.

V

POON4

834

17

Vide $on #9 8. 153 : giet FAETATE Letla: 1 after ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ã‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ

  1. Brhaspati

485

It was as follows:–the four stages of a law-suit, proof (kriyƒÅ, human of three sorts and divine ), witnesses (of 12 kinds ), documents ( ten kinds ), bhukti ( possession ), ordeals (nine), 18 titles, rnadana, niksepa, asvamivikraya, sambhuya-samu tthƒÅna, dattƒÅpradƒÅnika, abbyupetyƒÅ-su≈õr≈´≈üƒÅ, vetanasya anapakarma, svƒÅmipalavivada, samvid-vyatikrama, vikriya sampradƒÅna, sƒ´mƒÅvivƒÅda, pƒÅrusya ( of two kinds ), sƒÅhasa ( of three kinds), strisamgrahana, stripumdharma, vibhaya, dyuta samƒÅhvaya, prakirnaka ( otherwise called ‘nrpasraya vyava hƒÉra’, wrongs for which proceedings are set on foot by the king).

B·ªãhaspati was probably the first jurist to make a clear distinction between civil and criminal justice.636 He divided the eighteen titles into two groups, those springing from wealth ( 14 titles ) and those springing from injury to beings (4 titles). This distinction was probably dimly perceived by even Gautama, when he says that in disputes based on injury there is no hard and fast rule about witnesses (i. e. about their interest in the subject of dispute ).538 Bihaspati, like Narada lays down the rule that a legal decision should not be arrived at merely on the basis of ≈õƒÅstra and that when a decision is devoid of reasoning, there is loss of dharma, for even a good man may be held to be a bad one or what is good may be held to be sinful iv a judicial proceeding, just as MƒÅndavya was held to be a thief on a decision without thoughtful reasoning. 637

535 ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§π ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ß‡§®‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ

‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§É ‡•• ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§æ of ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§§. p. 277; vide also ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ (‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø. p.9) ‘‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø

‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É’. 538 ‡§® ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•å. ‡§ß. ‡§∏‡•Ç. 13.9 on which ‡§π‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ says ‘‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á

‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§•‡•á‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç

‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø.‡•§’ 637 ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§É

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡§ö‡•å‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡•ã ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•å‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡•• quoted by ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï on ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û. II. 1 ; compare ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶ ( ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§æ chap. 1. 42 ) : ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•å‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•å‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•å‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•å‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•å‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§É ‡•• For the story of ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø who kept silent, vide ƒÄdiparva 107.

( Continued on the next page)

FOUNI

191

Hary

486

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Bphaspati gives such elaborate definitions and rules about procedure from the filing of the plaint to the passing of the decree that he can very well stand comparison with modern legislators on the same subjects.

NƒÅrada and B»ôhaspati agree very closely in several res pects. For example, both speak of three kinds of proof, four parts of a judicial proceeding, almost the same defects of plaints, four kinds of answer, four divisions of the law of gift and their sub-divisions, five modes of recovering debts, four kinds of sƒÅhasa.

We have seen that NƒÅrada departs from Manu in several essential matters. On the other hand B»ôhaspati follows Manu very closely. But he too differs on some points from Manu, for example, we saw above how Brbaspati dissents from Manu on the question of the divisibility of clothes &c. (uote 348 ). He appears to differ from Manu as to the maximum interest allowed on corn, fruit, wool and beasts of burden.588 Manu and NƒÅrada are both silent as to the widow’s right to succeed to her deceased husband’s estate. But Bphaspati agreeing with YƒÅj√±avalkya makes her the first heir of her sonless

( Continued from the previous page ) The story of MƒÅnda vya occurs also in Adiparva 63. 92‚Äì93 aod is also mentioned in the ArthasƒÅstra of Kautilya, IV. 8. 12. The story in the epic differs from that stated in ArthasƒÅstra which says: ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§É ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§É ‘akit sa gator: 1 In the epic, there is no mention of the fear of torture as in the Kau»õiliya. “Ani’ means ‘g√ºlƒÅgra’.   1. 46-50. 538 ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á ‡•§ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡•ã ‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å

1917

  1. Brhaspati

487

husband.580 Br. says ‘those who say that clothes and the like are not liable to partition have not bestowed proper thought (on that matter), as rich people might, have wealth largely consisting of clothes and ornaments. This is really a criticism of the Manusmrti but out of deference for Manu, the reference is impersonal. AparƒÅrka p. 726 (five verses ) explains from Bphaspati how to partition these.

These considerations make it clear that B·ªãhaspati is cer tainly later than Manu and YƒÅj. It is difficult to state his exact relationship to NƒÅrada. He agrees more closely with Manu than NƒÅrada does, but in some respects such as defini tions and the rights of women he shows great advance over NƒÅrada. So he is probably a contemporary of or not much later than N√§rada. He employs the word nƒÅ≈Üaka 640 He de fines a dƒ´nƒÅra, also called “suvarna”, as equal to twelve dhƒÅnakas and says that a JhƒÅnaka was equal to four andikƒÅs, an andikƒÅ being a copper pa≈Üa weighing a kar≈üa and bearing a stamp.541 This agrees with what NƒÅrada says about dinƒÅra. Dr. Jolly (S. B. E. vol. 33 p. 276 ) assigns Brhaspati to the 6th or 7th century A. D. But this is much later by several centuries than the evidence warrants. KƒÅtyƒÅyana was looked upon as an authoritative writer along with NƒÅrada and Brhas pati by Visvar≈´pa and MedhƒÉtithi. This position he could not have attained in a century or two. So he cannot be plac ed later than the 6th century. KƒÅtyƒÅyana in several places quotes B·ªãhaspati as an authority. AparƒÅrka quotes KƒÅtya yana as saying that, according to B»ôhaspati, pastures, ways,

‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§æ ‡•• ‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§™‡§∞

Ahond

488

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

clothes that are worn on the body, debts, (or books for use, according to others ) and what is set apart for religious pur poses should not be partitioned.642 KƒÅtyƒÅyana says that, according to Brhaspati, that wealth which a man acquires by means of his learning after refuting an opponent in a contest with a stake for the winner is styled “vidyƒÅdhana” and is not liable to partition 543; and what is acquired through valour &c. by persons that were taught in the family or learnt under their father should be partitioned among the brothers, accord ing to B·ªãhaspati. If a man falsely denies his liability and if only a part of the claim is brought home to him, then he should be made to pay the whole.544 That the statement of a witness may be relied upon on a matter under his direct per ception owing to his being near the plaintiff and the defendant and not otherwise; so says Bphaspati.645 The foregoing exa mples show that KƒÅtyƒÅyana looked upon Brhaspati as an authority who must therefore have flourished several centu ries before. Therefore B»ôhaspati cannot be placed later than the 4th century A. D. As he knew the extant Manusmrti, was later than YƒÅj. and probably than N≈´rada, Bphaspati must have flourished between 200 and 400 A. D. This conclusion is strengthened by the fact that Visvar≈´pa quotes, without making any difference, prose and verse passages of B»ôhaspati and thereby shows that in his opinion the jurist Brhaspati (in verse ) was identical with the political writer B»ôhaspati and was a very ancient writer in his day. MedhƒÅtithi (on Manu 9. 153 ) quotes the verse‚Äú na pratigrahabh≈´r” (ascrib ed to Brhaspati by others ) as Sm·ªôtyantara. B·ªãhaspati is

FOUNDED

  1. Brhaspati

489

cited in a few cases as referring to his own views in the third person 848 ; sometimes he uses the first person also.547 Nothing can be said about his country at present. In a well-known passage Byhaspati refers to the usages of the southern people, of the people in the Madhyade≈õa, of the eastern and northern people.648 In a striking and beautiful passage Brhaspati compares vyavahare with yajna,549_the king with Visnu, the successful party with the sacrificer and the defeated party with the victim, the plaint and the reply to food and the pratijna to the sacrificial offering (prepared from food ), the sƒÅstras to the three Vedas and the subhyas to the priests in a sacrifice. Brhaspati seems to have been very fond of such long-drawn metaphors.sh0

The Sm·ªôticandrika quotes about seventy verses of Bƒôbas pati in the Ahnika portion and about forty on SrƒÅddha. In the later works like the Parisara-Madhaviya, the Nirnaye. sindhu and Sarnskara-Kaustubha, the number of verses quot ed from Brhaspati is much larger than even those quoted by the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ. Those verses are quoted on such sams karas as pumsa.vana, namakarana, caula, upanayana. vivaha. and also ou √°sauca and purification of dravyas. Even the MitƒÅk≈üarƒ´ quotes several verses of Bphaspati on matters

548 ‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡§®‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•ã

‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ. ‡§Æ‡§æ. III. 1. p. 212 ; ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡•ß‡•¶. 547 ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ quoted by ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï on ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂.

II. 211. 548 ‡§â‡§¶‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö

‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ (‡§Ü‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ï p. 10, Gharpure ),

‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø p. 16 ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞. p. 29, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø. ‡§Æ. &c. 549 ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡••

‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ã

‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•á | quoted in ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø. ‡§Æ‡§æ. p. 284. 550 8. g. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§´‡§≥

‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã ‡§≠‡•å‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ñ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•¶ p. 14. Compare ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶ (‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø. ‡§Æ‡§æ. in for the second v

37 ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó

490

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

other than those of vyavahiirit. For example, the Mit. on YƒÅj. I. 210 quotes a verse of Brhaspati that a nivartana ( of land ) is equal to 30 dandas in area (danda being seven cubits in length) and ten nivartanas are equal to a gocarma.851 On YƒÅj. III. 17 the Mit. quotes two verses of B·ªãhaspati about impurity on birth or death &c. On YƒÅj. III. 21 the Mit. cites the definition of le≈õƒÅntara given by Brhaspati.562 On YƒÅj. III. 24 the Mit quotes Brhaspati’s opinion that the period of mourning on the death of one’s maternal grandfather, ƒÅcƒÅrya or srctriya is three days. On YƒÅj. III. 253 the Mit. quotes Brhaspati’s rule as to prƒÅya≈õcitta for consciously drinking wine.868 Vide also Mit. on YƒÅj. III. 30, 250, 254, 260, 290 for other quotations from Brhaspati

The foregoing, therefore, establishes, that Bphaspati was known at least to the Mit. and later writers as an expounder in verge not only of vyavahƒÅra but also of other topics of dbarma as well. As over a thousand verses of B»ôhaspati (including about 800 on VyavahƒÅra ) are quoted it appears that his work must have been an extensive one comprising several thousand verses. Such a work of Bphaspati has yet to be recovered.

The Mit. on YƒÅj. III. 261 quotes a Vrddha-Bphaspati on the nine varieties of sa·πÅkara.664 Kulluka on Manu (9. 181 ) cites a verse of V»ôddha-Bphaspati about the eleven subsidiary

561 ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á

part I. p. 645 where the reading is careata ). 52 ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞

‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡•á ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á

nga 711 563 ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É

‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• 564 ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§π ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡§§‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡•á

‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§π ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§®‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ß‡§Æ‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§π ‡•• * These are ascribed to Vrddha-Brhaspati by Mit, on Yaj. 14. BOR by AparƒÅrka on p. 1086 ( with slight variations ) and batin candrikƒÅ (ƒÄhnika p. 10, Gbarpure ) and Gr. R. p. 687 ( 13 Beiden pati’s ).

  1. Brhaspati

491

sons ( vide note 346 above, where the verse is ascribed to B·ªãhaspati ). HemƒÅdri ( Caturvarga, vol. III, part 2, p. 472 ) quotes a Jyotir-B»ôhaspati on the prohibition of a sraddha on the thirteenth tithi of the dark half. A parƒÅrka on Y√°j. II. 3-4 quotes three verses from Vrddha–Brhasiati about the deriva tion of the word “prƒÅ≈≥-vivƒÉka' and one on the punishment for sabhyas who take bribes. Three of these verses are ascrib ed to Brhaspati in the Par√§sara-MƒÅdhaviya and other work. and one of them to Katyayana in the Vyavahira-mƒ´trkƒÅ.

After the publication of the first volume of the History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra in 1930' and the publication in 1933 by the present author in a book-form of the verses of KatyƒÅyana (with English translation and notes ) on law and judicial procedure (originally contributed to a Journal on Hindu Law ), the late Prof. K. V. Rangaswami Aiyangar came to me in 1934, when I gave him a copy of the reconstruction of KƒÅtyƒÅyana. He asked me to attempt a similar reconstruction of Bfhaspati As I had by that time decided to bring out a large history of Dharma≈õƒÅstra, I refused to undertake what he suggested and asked him to make the attempt himself. He undertook the work of reconstructing B·ªãhaspati’s Smrti and published it in 1941 in the well-known Gaekwad’s Oriental Series ( Baroda ). That is a bulky volume in 732 pages. He not only collected the verses attributed to B»ôhaspati on law and judicial procedure but also on other subjects. He arranged them in seven parts:(1) on Vyavahara in pp. 1-228 arranged in 29 chapters, ( 2 )on SamskƒÅra (pp. 231-308 ), (3) AcƒÅra (pp. 309-325), ( 4 ) SrƒÅddha (pp. 326-351 ); ( 5 ) Asa uca (pp. 352-364 ); ( 6 ) ƒÄpad-dharma pp. 365-372 ), ; (7) PrƒÅyascitta (pp. 373-386). Besides a Preface, a list of Sans krit works drawn upon or referred to in the footnotes, an Index in Sanskrit of the topics dealt with (pp. 17-69 ), he contributed a learned and exhaustive Euglish Introduction (pp. 71-186 ) and an alphabetical (Sanskrit ) Index of quarters of the verses included in the section on VyavahƒÅra (pp. 387-459 ) and another Index of half-verses on sections other than VyavahƒÅra (pp. 460-492); he also gives a list of additional texts found after the work was sent to the Press Up. 493-499 ), a list of authors and works cited if the text of Brhaspati), additions to footnotes (pp. 502-536 and lastly a comparative statement of verses translated from Dr. Jolly (in SBE Vol. 33, 1889 ) and in the work that he

492

History of Dharmasastra

collected and edited. This work is a laborious performance. It should have been accompanied by an English translation and notes on difficult passages. I have, however, to differ from it in some places and am further obliged to say that, in spite of all the labour he bestows, he some how failed to notice some verges and prose passages of Byhaspati as having been men tioned by Visvar≈´pa and others. Dr. Jolly (in S. B. E. vol. 33 ) collected and translated 717 verses of Brhaspati on

VyavahƒÅra'.

Prof. Aiyangar on p. 73 of his Introduction states that Dr. Jolly published an English rendering of 697 Slokas on VyavahƒÅra attributed to Brhaspati. To me it is not clear how he arrived at the smaller figure of 097. Probably there is some mistake in making the total of the verses in the 27 Bections of the translation. Prof. Aiyangar further says (on p. 73 of the Introduction) that the number of Slokas (includ. ing under the term a few passages in prose) dealing with VyavahƒÅra is 1372, nearly double the number collected by Dr. Jolly,

Dr. Jolly rightly says at the beginning of his Introduc tion to the translation of Brhaspati’s verses ‘the fragments of Bphaspati’ are among the most precious relics of the early legal literature of India.

AparƒÅrka (on YƒÅj. II. 151 pp. 761-62), Kalpataru (on VyavahƒÅra on pp. 450-51 ) and Smrticandrika ( VyavahƒÅra, p. 234, Gharpure) contain 8 or 9 verses of B·ªãhaspati about the loss or gain of lands by the change in the courses of rivers or when a king grants lands from one village as situated in another.

The VyavahƒÉranirnaya of VaradarƒÅja cites a verse (on p. 132 ) as Bphaspati’s in the work called PancƒÅdhyƒÅyi' and again ( on p. 357 ) simply a verse in ‘PascƒÉdhyƒÅyƒ´.’ It is possible that PascadhyƒÅyi is an independent work in which Bphaspati was quoted or it may be that Pa√±c√ºdhyƒÅyi is the name of the work of Brhaspati himself. 666

FOUNDED

  1. Brhaspati

498

Prof. Aiyangar says ( on p. 493 of his reconstructed Brhaspati) that certain passages ( both nir. prose and verse ) attributed to B»ôhaspati in different Nibandbas were noticed by him after the text had been sent to the press and then gets out only two passages in prose from Visvar≈´pa’s BƒÅlakrida The commentary of Visvar≈´pa was published at Trivandrum in two parts, the first in 1922 ( on YƒÅj. I and II, ƒÅcƒÅra and vyavahara) and the 2nd in 1924 (on Prayascitta). He began to collect materials for the reconstruction of Brhaspati after 1934. Therefore, he could have secured many more prose passages attributed to Brhaspati by Visvar≈´pa. I set out a few more prose passages of Brhaspati from Visvar≈´pa’s com mentary alone. They are ten in all, most of which refer to VyavahƒÅra.b58 Visvaripa also quotes five verses of Brhaspati,

.

.
