‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ. ‡§®‡§ø. p. 357. 556 (1) ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§¶‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞

‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• on ‡§Ø‡§æ. II. 38 ; (2) ‡§ß‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§•‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ on ‡§Ø‡§æ. II. 47: (3) ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§™‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§£‡•á‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ on ‡§Ø‡§æ II. 39 ; ( 4 ) ‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ on ‡§Ø‡§æ. II. 55; (5) ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ω ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ú ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡•á ‡•§ on ‡§Ø‡§æ. II. 138 ; (8) ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§ø ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• on ‡§Ø‡§æ. II. 139 ; (7) ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§Ø‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§£‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§§ ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ on ‡§Ø‡§æ. II. 154 ; (8) ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ..

( Continued on the neat page)

494

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

which have been noticed by Prof. Aiyangar. He, it appears, regards the quotations in prose and verse as belonging to the same author. In one proge quotation Brhaspati is mentioned by name as stating a certain proposition. It is possible that Visvar√ºpa regarded that all quotations (both prose and in verse) are to be attributed to oue author. One cannot dogma tise on such a point. But it is quite likely that the author of the verses was different from the author of the S≈´tras quoted by Visvar≈´pa.

Prof. Louis Renou of Paris contributed to volume VI (1962) of the Indo-Iranian Journal ( Publishers, Moulton and Co., the Hague ) pp. 81-102 a learned paper (in French ) on the edition of the fragments of Brhaspati (collected ) by Prof. K. V. Rangaswami Aiyangar. It is not possible to mention here for reasons of space even the most salient points of his criticisms against Prof. Aiyangar’s edition of B»ôhas pati. On p. 83 note 2 he observes that Prof. Aiyangar has not made use of P. V. Kane’s learned edition of the fragments of K√§tyƒÅyana with translations and points out that the word ‘nƒÅs≈£ika’ which is explained in H. of Dh. Vol. III pp. 464-5 and the incidents of the sale by a finder of an article lost by the owner (in KƒÅtyƒÅyana 622-623 ) are not set out by Prof. Aiyangar. It is unnecessary for the present author to dwell on the omissions pointed out by Prof. Reuou in Prof. Aiyangar’s work, which latter simply collects passages with enormous details about the works and pages where the verses of B·ªãhaspati occur with hardly a word of explanation anywhere.

An interesting point, with reference to the collections of verses quoted as from Brhaspati or KƒÅtyƒÅyana, the original Sm·ªôtis of which are not now available, is the confusion

  1. Brhaspati

caused by the same verse being cited as from Brhaspati or KƒÅtyƒÅyana or N√§rada or Manu ( both the latter Smrtis beiug available in printed editions ). A few striking examples are cited (in the footnote). Some verses are attributed to both

(8) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•á‡•§ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•å ‡§ö ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•• ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§∞‡•Å (‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ. p. 67) ascribes to both ‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ. and ‡§¨‡•É‡§π., and ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ. ‡§Æ‡§æ. III p. 17t ascribes to ‡§¨‡•É‡§π. (9) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§ã‡§£‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡§É ‡•• ‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ. act. to ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï. p. 650 ‡§µ‡§ø. ‡§∞. p. 51, ‡§µ‡§ø. ‡§ö‡§ø, p. 18, ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ. ‡§Æ‡§æ. III. p. 263. In the Introduction to my edition of ENT reconstruction of KatyƒÅyana I have (on pp. VIII-X) pointed out many verses that are common to KatyƒÅyana, Brhaspati, NƒÅrada. and Manu.

496

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

  1. Katyayana NƒÅrada, B»ôhaspati and KƒÅtyƒÅyana form a triumvirate in the realm of the ancient Hindu Law and procedure. The work of K√§tyƒÅyana on VyavahƒÅra, like that of Bphaspati, has yet to be recovered. After the first volume of H. of Dh. was published in 1930, I contributed to a Law Journal in Bombay & collec tion of KƒÅty√§yana’s verses gathered from quotations in 21 works and later (in 1933 ) published in a book form 973 verses of KƒÅtyƒÅyana with English translation, two Appendices and a General Index (in all 372 pages). Later on Prof. K. V. Rangaswami Aiyangar contributed a paper to the Kane Fest schrift (pp 7-17) embodying 121 additional verses of KƒÅtyƒÅyana from the work called VyavahƒÅranirnaya of Vara darƒÅja ( which he published in 1942 48 No. 29 of the Adyar Library series ).

KƒÅtyƒÅyana is enumerated as one of the expounders of dhurma by Sarkha-Likhita, Y√°j≈àavalkya ( I. 4-5 ) and ParƒÅ Sara. A K√¢tya is quoted as an authority in the BaudhƒÅyana dharmas≈´tra (I. 2. 37). A Srautas≈´tra and Sraddhakalpa of the white Yajurveda are ascribed to K√§tyƒÅyana.

KƒÅtyƒÅyana appears to have taken N√§rada and Bphaspati as his models in the order and treatment of the subjects to be dealt with on vyavahƒÅra. He closely follows both the writers in terminology and technique. On several points he presu pposes N√§rada and expounds and elucidates the latter’s dicta. For example, NƒÅrada ( Intro, chap. I. 10-11 ) lays down that VyavahƒÉra has four pƒÅdas, each later one prevailing, viz. dharma, vyavahƒÅra, caritra, rƒÅjas√°sana (note 361 ) and then NƒÅrada very briefly in one verse explains these four terms; K√§tyƒÅyana, on the other hand, devotes at least nine verses to the elucidation of the rule as to each succeeding one prevailing over its predecessor. 568 NƒÅrada contains very little on the topic of strƒ´dhana (dƒÅyabhƒÅga chap. verses 8-9). He merely enumerates the six kinds of strƒ´dhana and then lays down the rule of succession. KƒÅtyƒÅyana’s treatment of stridhana has attained classical rank. It appears that he was probably the first to carefully define the several kinds of stridhana (such as adhyagni, adhyƒÅvahanika, prƒ´tidatta, sulka, anya dheya, saud√£yika), to lay down woman’s power of different

siru

658

Vide RI. AT. vol. III, part I, pp. 16-17, and airo p. 9-10, 120, 1910

  1. K√§tyƒÅyana

497

over the several varieties of stridhana and to prescribe lines of devolution as to stridhana. The verses on this topic occu rring in the nibandhas number ubout thirty. The leading nibandhas contain only a few quotations from Brhasrati on strƒ´dhana. Hence it may be surmised that Kƒ´tyƒÅyana proba bly was the first sm·ªôti writer to give elaborate rules on this topic.

It has been already shown how KƒÅtyƒÅyana often quotes the views of B·ªãhaspati. A few more examples may be added here. According to Brhaspati, says KƒÅtyƒÅ yana, when a man who stands surety with others on a joint liability goes abroad, his son would have to pay the whole debt, but if the man dies then the son would be liable for his father’s share only.” Wheu cattle stray into fields, gardens, houses or cowpens, they may be, according to Brhas pati, caught hold of ( by the ear &c. ) or beaten.580 According to B»ôhaspati, a man of the ksatriya, vaisya or s≈´dra caste may employ one of his own caste to do the work of a dƒÅsa (slave or serf ), but even a Br√•lana could never employ another BrƒÅhmana in the same way.561

1

More than 21 nibandhas on VyavahƒÅra quote about 1100 verses of Katyayana on vyavahara, the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ alone citing about 600 of them. In these verses KatyƒÅyana refers at least a score of times to the views of Burgu. It is remarka ble that only a few of the views ascribed to Bhrgu are found in the extant Manusmrti. Katyayana says, according to Bhrgu, whatever ( ancestral) wealth was concealed by one coparcener from others, whatever was badly divided should be divided in equal shares when afterwards discovered ( ParƒÅ. Sara-M√ºlhaviya III, p. 566). This may well be compared with Manu 9. 215. KƒÅtyƒÅyanu says, according to Bhrgu, it is not BrƒÅhmana-murder to kill an ƒÅtatayin who is foremost by his austerities, learning and caste. This has in view Manu

559 ‡§è‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§ø ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§®

qarafa: 11 927. #1. III, p. 251. 580 ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§

fa. T. p. 241. 581 ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§µ‡§£‡•á ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§® ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É

fa. 5. p. 152.

498

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

    1. KullƒÅka distinctly says that Katyayana simply ex. plains the verse of Manu by referring to it as Bhrgu’s. On the other hand, there are several places where the views ascribed to Bhrgu find no counterpart in the extant Manu. Bhrgu seems to have been a predecessor of the author of the extant Manusmrti since it mentions ( III. 16) the view of Bhrgu. The Mit. on Yaj. III. 292 quotes a verse of Bhrgu. Visvarupa also quotes a verse of Bhrgu on Yaj. I.79 and ano ther on Yaj. I.187, both of which are not found in the Manu smrti. AparƒÅrka quotes in all four verses of Bhrgu (on pp. 58, 461, 547, 696 ). The Sin»ôticandrikƒÅ,561a after dilating upon the two superior places cited by Manu ( viz, the king or a judge appointed by the king where disputes are decided ) quotes three verses of Bhrgu which refer to 15 inferior tribu nals for decision in some special matters. The Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ also quotes several verses of Blƒ±rgu on SrƒÅddha, two of which are interesting and indicate that the Bhrgu it quotes is : much later writer than Manu, as they refer to the position of the Sun in rƒÅfis ( signs of the zodiac ).

According to Bhrgu in all sƒÅhasas of the worst type the truth should be found out by means of divine proof (ordeals &c. ) even though there may be witnesses.Sea There is nothing in the Manusmrti corresponding with this. According to Bhrgu the ordeals of balance &c. are prescribed for those who are suspected to be in league with marauders and who have

561a ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§É ‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø

‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§•‡§ø‡§ï‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•à‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•à‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É || ( and two more verses ) quoted by ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ (‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•¶ ) p. 18. ‡§è‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§π‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω ‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§É ‡•• ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§® ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≤‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ ‡•¶n ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß p. 370. ‡§≠‡•É‡§ó‡•Å‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø

incurred popular censure, but in such cases there is no under taking (by the complainant to pay fine ).583 The Manusmrti has not a word on this point. Household para phernalia, beasts of burden, cattle, ornaments, slaves should be divided when discovered ; if they are ( alleged to be ) concealed, the ordeal of ko≈õa should be resorted to; 80 says Bhrgu.864 Another important circumstance that deserves to be noted is that KƒÅtyƒÅyana several times refers to the views of Manu. KƒÅtya yana says that the view of Manu was ‘In those disputes (or crimes ) for which ordeals are forbidden (to be administered to perpetrators ) the king should make efforts to have them performed by good men on their behalf (if available); he should not abandon the person charged (without testing his guilt by proxy )': this is the view of Manu.686 According to Manu, if a woman deserted her son, though he may be able (to pay ), her stridhana should be seized and the paternal debt should be paid thereout. 686 Manu declared, says KƒÅtyƒÅyana, that if animals be killed, the offender should offer (to the owner) another similar animal or its proper price. All these views attributed to Manu by K√¢tyƒÅyana are not found in the extant Manusmrti. In certain places K√§tyƒÅyana refers to the views of the M√§navas; e. g. according to the G√§rgiyas and M√§navas if a bribe had already been paid, the person receiving it should be made to repay it and should be fined eleven times as much ; 567 according to the MƒÅnavas thieves caught red

amanti 1

.

handed with their booty should be at once banished.568 As regards both these references, the teaching of the Manusmrti seems to be different; vide Manu I. 231 and 270 respectively. These facts about Katyayana’s references to Bhrgu and Manu raise several difficult questions, whether Bhrgu and Manu stand for two entirely different works or for the same work and whether he refers to some other version of the Manusmrti ascribed to Bhrgu. In my opinion he is not referring to two separate works, and that he had before him a version of the Manu

but somewhat different from and probably larger than the present Manusmrti.

In the nibandhas several.verses are ascribed to KƒÅtya yana along with Manu, YƒÅj√Æavalkya and Brhaspati. For example, the well-known verse about the sixtold division of stridhana (adhyaynyadhyƒÅvahanikam &c. ) is ascribed by the DƒÅyabhƒÅga to Manu and K√§tyƒÅyana. The half-verse “var≈ÜƒÅ nƒÅmƒÅnulomyena dƒÅsyam na pratilomatah” is the same in both YƒÅj√±avalkya (11. 183 ) and KatyƒÅyana. The Viramitrodaya (p. 140 ) ascribes a verse to Brhaspati and K√§tyƒÅyana, in which the opinion of Brhaspati is cited. There is very close agreement between the definitions proposed by the two last writers of dharma, vyavahƒÅra, caritra, and rƒÉja≈õƒÅsana. Besides Manu (or MƒÅnavas ), Byhaspati and Bhrgu, KƒÅtyƒÅyana cites the views of several other writers on dharma. For GƒÅrgyas and Gautama vide uotes 567 and 568. He says, accord ing to Kausika, powerful robbers were to be guarded by chains of iron, were to be low-fed and were to undergo hard labour for the state till death ( AparƒÉrka p. 849). He quotes the view of Likhita that where a woman is deprived of food, raiment and dwelling (by her husband’s coparceners ) she would be entitled to demand her own ( stridhana ) and a share from the coparceners. In one case ( AparƒÅrka p. 755 ), a verse is cited as K√§tyƒÅyana’s in which KatyƒÅyana himself is named (ParƒÅ≈õaramadhaviya III. p. 235).

KƒÅtyƒÅyana contains the same advanced views about law and rules of procedure as are found in N√§rada and B»ôhaspati.

568 ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§¢‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø

steagul fat. T. 332. It is not unlikely that the correot reathing is ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§£‡§Ç for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç, as the immediately following view ta‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ suggests. The words of ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å are ‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§¢‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®

  1. KƒÅty√§yuna

501

He is even in advance of these two writers in certain matters, such as detinitions in general and the elaboration of rules about stridhana. He gives numerous definitions, such as those of vyavahara, pridviv√°ka, stobhaka, dharmƒÉdhikarana, tirita anii anusista, samanta &c. He seems to have been the first to invent some new terins. For example, he defines pascƒÅtkƒÅra as a judgment given in favour of the plaintiff after a hot coutest between the plaintiff and the defendant, while the term jyapatra is restricted by him to the judgment given on admission by the defendant or a judgment dismissing the suit on various grounds.509 He lays down a stringent rule that if a man abandons a ground of defence or attack and puts forward a less cogent one, he would not be allowed to put forward again the stronger ground after a decisive judg ment of the court.970 This resembles the 4th explanation to section 11 of the Indian Civil Procedure Code (1908 ) about res judicuta. The verses about k√§rpapana and dinƒÅra quoted above (note 368 ) from N√§rada (parisista verses 58-60) are ascribed to KƒÅtyƒÅyana by the Sm·ªôticaudrikƒÅ.

The date of KƒÅtyƒÅyana can be settled only approxi mately. He is certainly much later than Manu and YƒÅj√±a valkya. As shown above he presupposes NƒÅrada and regarded B»ôhaspati as a very leading authority on vyavabƒÅra. Hence his upper limit is the 3rd or 4th century A. D. Vi≈õvar≈´pa quotes eight verses as KƒÅtyƒÅyana’s by naine ( vide on YƒÅj. II. 5, 6, 47, 63, 281 ) on such topics of VyavahƒÅra as the defects of the plaint, the contents of the plaint, the liability for the debts of a deceased person, payments of debts of honour (satyamkƒÅra ), punishment for abortion, grievous hurt and homicide of a brƒÅhmana woman. MedhƒÉtithi (on Manu 7. 1 ) ascribes to KatyƒÅyana the rule that in case of conflict between the dictates of dharma≈õƒÅstra and artha≈õƒÅstra the king should prefer the forener. MedlƒÉtithi on Manu ( VIII 216 ) speaks of KityƒÅyana-sutra, appears to quote a portion

569 ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å

FUIFFT9944 Farao, 213172a, ako. 370 ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§µ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§

PUTA ll fiato on 13. 11. 80 ; 27. Al. p. 281 ; Ifto p, 108,

‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Æ

Bhandark Research

502

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

of it in prose and explains it. 571 MedhƒÅtithi says that KƒÅtya yana extended the maxim of the trader carrying merchandise (bhƒÅndavƒÅha-vanik maxim ) to all similar transactions. All known quotations of KƒÅtyƒÅyana are in verse. When MedhƒÅ tithi speaks of a sutra and quotes a portion of it (as “vƒÅ” and “iti” after ‚Äúnivarteta " indicate ) in prose, we must either suppose that he is referring to some other work of K√§tyƒÅyana than the one in verge from which hundreds of verses are cited by other writers or that KƒÅtyƒÅyana’s work on vyavahƒÅra also contained some proge passages. As hardly any other writer quotes a prose passage of K√§tyƒÅyana on vyavahƒÅra, the second alternative appears somewhat unlikely. Visvar≈´pa and Medb√¢tithi regarded KatyƒÅyana as an authoritative smrtikƒÅra along with N√§rada and B»ôhaspati. This position he could not have attained in less than a few hundred years. Therefore, the lowest limit to which KƒÅtyƒÅyana can be assign ed is the 6th century. Hence it may be said that K√§tyƒÅyana flourished between the 4th and 6th century A. D.

The VyavahƒÅramƒÅt≈ükƒÅ (p. 307 ) quotes a Brhat-KƒÅtya yana on the question of proof. The DƒÅyabhƒÅga mentions & V»õddha-KƒÅtyƒÅyana. The Sarasvatƒ´vilƒÅsa also quotes verses of Vrddha-KƒÅtyƒÅyana on rescission of purchase and other topics (p. 320). In the present state of our knowledge it is very difficult to say whether these two are different works, The Caturvarga-cintƒÅma≈Üi (vol. III, part 2, p. 657) speaks of UpakƒÅtyƒÅyana. AparƒÅrka on p. 485 quotes a verse from sloka-KƒÅtyƒÅyana which is not found in the Karmapradipa (Jivananda’s ed. ), but appears to be a summary of a prose passage quoted as KƒÅtyƒÅyana’s immediately before by AparƒÅrka.

In Jivananda’s collection of smrtis ( part I, pp. 603-644 ) there is one of KƒÅtyƒÅyana in three prapƒÅthakas and 29 khandas and about five hundred verses. The same work is printed as Gobhilasm·ªôti in the AnandƒÅ≈õrama collection (pp. 49‚Äì71). It contains also a few prose passages in the 12th, 13th and 14th khandas. The prevailing metre is Anustubh, a few verses being in the Indra vajrƒÅ and other metres. The

671 ‘‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¨‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á”

  1. K≈´tyƒÅyana

503

work is styled the Karmapradipa of KƒÅtyƒÅyana. The opening verse justifies this name when it states that like a lamp the work will clearly show the mode of performing certain rites treated by Gobhila and other rites which are not clearly elucidated.572 The contents of this work are briefly as follows:- how to wear the sacred thread; sipping water and touching various limbs with water; the worship of Ganesa and fourteen mƒÅtrs in every rite; kusas; ≈õrƒÅddha details; consecration of sacred fires; details about aranƒ´s, sruc, sruva; rules about cleansing the teeth and bathing; sandhyƒÅ; prƒÅ·πáƒÅ. yƒÅma, muttering of Vedic mantras ; tarpana of gods and manes; the great daily yaj√±as; who is to offer srƒÅddha; rules about periods of impurity due to death; duties of wife; GrƒÅddhas of various kinds.

The Karma prudƒ´pa mentions by name several authorg. It very frequently cites the views of Gobhila (pp. 603, 626, 638 ) and Gautama (pp. 619, 620, 626, 630, 636, 639 ). The Karmapradipa as the opening verse says is intimately related to the Gobhila G»ôhyas≈´tra. It distinctly says that as Gobhila did not dilate upon the details as to time and procedure of goyaj√±a and vajiyaj√±a, K√§tyƒÅyana dilates upon them. This is borne out by the Gobhila grhya-s≈´tru673 Another passage of KƒÅtyƒÅyana574 about the AstakƒÅs is based upon the very words of the Gobhila-grhya. Frequent reference is made to the views of Vasistha on the worship of MƒÅtrs (p. 605), on GrƒÅddha (pp. 608, 625). Vide also p. 642 ( 28. 16). Among the other authors named are NƒÅrada on the sticks for danta dhƒÅvana ( p. 615), BhƒÅrgava (probably U≈°anas ) on p. 640,

SƒÅndilya and SandilyƒÅyana on p. 626. KƒÅtyƒÅyana is named in several places (pp. 624, 627, 638 ) and once the first person is used ( as in “mamƒÅpyetad hrdi sthitam‚Äù p. 643). The KƒÅtyƒÅyanasmrti quotes the verse of Manu (111.70 ) on the five great yaj√±as. On p. 633 four verses forming the conso lation to be offered to the relatives of a person departed are the same as Y√°j. The question is:-what is the date of this KatyƒÅyana om»ôti ( Karmapradipa ) and whether it is the work of Katya yana the great jurist. The Mit. (on YƒÅj. I. 254 ) quotes a verse as K√§tyƒÅyana’s which occurs in Jivananda’s text (P. 624 verse 20 ); similarly the Mit. quotes two verses as Katya yana’s (on YƒÅj. III. 247) which have a place in the Karmapradipa (Jivananda p. 634 verses 4-5). Scores of verses cited as KatyƒÅyana’s by AparƒÉrka (on ƒÅcƒÅra and prƒÅya≈õcitta ) are found in the Karmapradipa. For example, vide A parƒÅrka p. 43 (three verses ) and Karmapradipa (1.605, 1110-12), AparƒÅrka p. 51 ( three verses abont samull) and Karmapr. (p. 613, 8. 17-19), AparƒÅrka p. 135 ( four verses about bathing in rivers ) and Karma. (p. 615, 10.5-7 and 14), AparƒÉrka p. 532 ( fuur verses on sraddha in which K√§tyƒÅyana himself is cited as an authority ) and Karma. (p. 624, 16. 16-19), AparƒÅrka p. 872 ( six verses ) and Karma. (21. 2-7 p. 632 ), AparƒÅrka p. 1066 (three verses about an nihutrin being guilty of mahƒÅpƒÉtaka ) and Karma. (23. 4-6 p. 634 ). The Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ also quotes profusely from KƒÅtyƒÅyana on ƒÅcƒÅra, srƒÅddha etc. and cites from the Karmapradipa by name passages which occur in Jivananda’s edition. The above re ferences show that in the eyes of the MitƒÉksar√£ and AparƒÅrka the Karmapradipa was an authoritative work. Therefore, it follows that it must have been composed long before the 11th century A. D. It is, however, remarkable that several quotations ascribed to KatyƒÅyana in the Mit≈´ksarƒ´, AparƒÅrka and other works are not found in the Karmajiradipa. For example, the Mit√§ksarƒÉ (on Y√±j.   1. KƒÅtyƒÅyana

505

verge about five varieties of lapses in conduct viz. mahƒÅp√• taka, atipƒÅtaka, pataka, prƒÅsaigika, upapƒÉtaka and on YƒÅj. III. 260 quotes a verse of KƒÅtyƒÅyana about what are ati pƒÅtakas. These are not to be traced in the Karmapradƒ´pa printed by Jivananda. Similarly, AparƒÅrka (pp. 94-95) quotes three verses of KƒÅtyƒÅyana that are very interesting but are not found in Jivananda’s edition.676 Later works like the Nirnaya≈üindhu, the Sa·πÅskƒÅramayukha, the MadanapƒÉri jƒÅta quote numerous verses of KityƒÅyana on upanayana, marriage and other sa·πÅskƒÅras which we vainly seek to find in the Karmapradipa. It is better to hold with Dr. R. C. Hazra that several works were ascribed to KƒÅtyƒÅyana, though they were composed by different persons. Vide New I. A, vol. VII at pp. 64-65.

The next question is whether KƒÄtyƒÅyana the jurist and the author of the Karmapradipa are identical. There are not sufficient data to identify the two. The only fact that points to the identity is that such eminent and early writers as Vij√±ƒÅnesvara and AparƒÅrka appear to make no distinction between the two. Besides, the Karmapradipa is also an early work. Against this it has to be remembered that Visvar≈´pa, probably the most ancient of all extant commentators, no where quotes KƒÅtyƒÅyana ou acƒÉra and prayascitta. This absence of quotations is not a very cogent argument; still it raises a doubt in one’s mind whether a work of KatyƒÅyana on ƒÅcƒÅra and other non-jural topics was known to Visvar≈´pa.

A few words must be said about the additional 121 verses collected and published in Kane Festschrift by Prof. Aiyangar as ascribed to KƒÅtyƒÅyana. Many verses are ascribed to B·ªãhaspati in some Dharma≈õƒÅstra works which are attributed to KatyƒÅyana by others. The number of Sm·ªôtis or Smrtik√°ras quoted or referred to by themselves or mentioned in commentaries and digeste is very large, particularly if one takes into account Sin»ôtik√§ras or Sm·∫∑tis with the words ‘bphat'‘madhyama,’ ‘laghu’ and ‘vrddha’ prefixed to many of them. The important versi fied Smrtis in the Sanskrit alphabetical order will now be briefly dealt with one after another.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Angiras laying down prƒÅya≈õcitta for killing certain beasts and birds, wherein Angiras himself is men tioned with honour (bhagavƒÅn ). AparƒÅrka (pp. 22-23 ) quotes thirteen verses from Arigiras on the constitution of pari≈üad, wherein such terms as c√£turvilya, vitarkƒ´, angavid, dharmapƒÅthaka are explained and the last of which says that

pari≈ücƒ±d sitting in judgment over those who are guilty of mahƒÅpƒÅta kas may consist of hundreds. The MitƒÅksarƒÅ ( on YƒÅj. I. 86 ) quotes several verses on the practice of satƒ´ and escribes them to both Sankha and Angiras.579 AparƒÅrka (pp. 109, 112 ) quotes four other verses on the same practice, one of which is in the IndravajrƒÅ metre and another prohibits & brƒÅhmana wife from following that practice. MedhƒÅtithi (on Manu. V. 157 ) quotes the view of Angiras on satƒ´ and disapproves of it. The Mitak≈üara, Haradatta and others quote numerous verses of Angiras on √•sauca and priya≈õcitta. Haradatta on Gautama (20. I) quotes a verse of Angiras about the seven antyajas, 580 Visvar≈´pa (on YƒÅj. III. 237 ) quotes a sutra of Sumantu in which Angirasa is cited as an authority. The Suddhi-may≈´kha quotes a verse of Angiras which relies upon S√§tƒÅtapa.681 The Sm·ªôticandrik√§ quotes Angiras on the enumeration of Upasm·ªôtis ( vide note 260 above). The Sm»ôticandrikƒÅ also contains a few proge quota tions from Angiras; the same work cites √† verse of Arigiras holding the dharma≈õƒÅstra of Manu as the supreme guide.882

The Angiras-smrti (in Jivananda part I, pp. 554-560 ) in 72 verses is probably an abridgment. It lays down prayas cittas for various occasions, such as taking food and drink from antyajus, for cruelly beating or causing various injuries to cows. It also lays down various rules for the wearing of the dark cloth (nƒ´livastra ) by women. It cites Angiras and Apastamba by name. The penultimate verse condemns those who rob women of their wealth.

679 One of them is the well-known verse faet: TEILT aga

‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡•• 680 GUE[∆°: 4 : I am a fewGut | HI T√å·∫£i ƒëa nh√† Ita

HRT: 11 681 ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶ 582 ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§®‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡•§‡•§

FOUNDED

FOUNDED

1917

  1. Angiras

50g

In the AnandƒÅ≈õrama collection of Sm·ªôtis (published in 1905 ) there is an Angiras-Smrti in 168 verses. At the begin ning it is said that, when asked by BharadvƒÅja and others, Angiras declared the Smrti dealing with rules of prƒÅyascitta. It names the following SmrtikƒÅras, viz. Sankhalikhita ( in v. 15), Sumantu ( in v. 26 ), Apastamba ( v. 76 ), Manu ( v. 86 ), Angiras ( 147 and 155 ). In 1953 Mr. A. N. Krishna Aiyan. gar published an Angirasasmrti at Adyar. This is different from the preceding two works and contains over 1200 ≈õlokas. Pandit Manoranjan Sastri (of Gauhati) claims that he has found the insg. of a different Argirasasmrti compiled before 14th century A. D. (p. 100 of the Pragjyotisa Souvenir pub lished by him at the time of the All India Oriental Conference at Gauhati in January 1965). As the text is not yet available to scholars, and no reasons are given except the learned Pandit’s opinion on reading the K√§mar≈´pa Ms., other scholars have to suspend their judgment. The Kalpataru (on Suddhi p. 18 ) states that Vasistha and Angiras have certain passages in common ( vide note below ).583

There are several mss. in the Govt. Mss. Library at the Bhandarkar Institute ( Pooua ) wbich contain a varying number of verses on prƒÅyascitta agreeing more or less with Jivananda’s text. For example, No. 53 of 1879-80 contains about one hundred verses, No. 205 of 1882-83 contains 54 verges, while No. 65 of VisrƒÅm bƒÅg collection and No. 83 of 1895-1902 contain only 32 ; No. 81 of 1884-86 is styled B»ôhad–Argiras and contains 151 verses, many of which are identical with those in the Calcutta text.

1

The Mit√¢ksarƒÅ (on Y√°j. 111. 277 ) and the Sm≈ütiratn√°vali of VedƒÅcƒÅrya (I. O. cat. No. 1552 p. 475 ) quote & B»ôhad Angiras and the MitƒÉksarƒÅ also quotes a Madhyama Angiras several times (on Yaj. III. 243, 247, 258 and 260 ).

583 ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø

‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó ‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡§ø… ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ Compare ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ IV. 20-23.

ilistory of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

  1. Rsyasrnga This is a writer who is frequently quoted on ƒÅcƒÅra, ƒÅ≈õauca, srƒÅddha, and prƒÅya≈õcittu by the Mit., AparƒÉrka, Sm·ªãticand rikƒÅ and other works. A parƒÅrka (p. 724 ) quotes as Rsyas roga’s a verse ascribed to Sarkha in the MitƒÅksarƒÅ ( on YƒÅj. II. 119 ) and other works, which states that when one copar cener recovers with his own efforts family property that was lost to the family, he gets a fourth share of it and the others become sharers in the rest.684 The SmrticandrikƒÅ (I. p. 32 ) quotes ‘api vƒÅsasi yaj√±opavitƒÅrth√¢n kuryƒÅt tadabhƒÅve trivstƒÅ s√ºtrena’, which is in prose,

Rsya≈õ·∫°nga is frequently quoted by AparƒÅrka on the PrƒÅya≈õcitta section of YƒÅj. (about 13 verses ) on PrƒÅya≈õcitta. The Vy. N. of Varadaraja ( p. 26 ) ascribes the verse of YƒÅj. II. 32 ( MattonmattƒÅrta &c) to Rsya≈õ≈ünga also. AparƒÅrka (p. 724 ) quotes one verse of Rsya’, on VyavahƒÅra viz. ‘If one coparcener in a joint family recovers by his efforts pro perty lost to the fumily, he should be awarded one-fourth of it and the remaining portion should be distributed among the remaining coparceners according to their proper shares. This verse is ascribed to Saikha by the SmrticandrikƒÅ ( on p. 276 ). Kalpataru (on Vy. 622 ) quotes two verses on a wife’s duties.

  1. Karsnajini This writer is quoted by the Mit. (YƒÄj. III. 265 three verses ), AparƒÉrka, Sm·ªôticandrikƒ´ and other works mostly op srƒÅddha. A parƒÅrka (p. 138 ) quotes a verse from him which enumerates the seven sons of BralmƒÉ, viz. Sanaka, Sanandana, SanƒÅtana, Kapila, Asuri, Vodha (?) and Panca sikha. A par≈´rka (p. 424 ) quotes a verse of KƒÅrsnƒÅjini which refers to the two signs of the Zodiac, KanyƒÅ, and Vr≈õcikƒÅ.

  2. Caturvimsatimata There are two Mgs. of this work in the Bhandarkar Institute, Poona (No. 244 of A. 1881-1882 and 111 of 1895-1902). It contains 525 verses. The work is so called because it embodies the essence of the teachings of 24 sages, Manu, YƒÅj√±a valkya, Atri, Vis≈Üu, Vasistha, VyƒÅsa, Usanas, Apaskambe, 584 ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§≠‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§∂‡§ø‡§§

  1. Caturvi√±satimata

511

Vatsa, Harita, Guru ( Brhaspati), Narada, ParƒÅsara, Gautama, Yama, BaudhƒÅyana, Daksa, Saikha, Aigiras, SƒÅtƒÅtapa, SƒÅrkhya (SƒÅrkhyƒÅyana? ), Sa·πÅvarta. The subjects treated of are :– The usages of the varmas and iframas, sauca, acamana, cleansing the teeth, bath, pranayama, repeating the GƒÅyatri, study of the Vedas, marriage, agnihotra, five great daily yaj√±as, means of livelihood, forest hermits, sam nyƒÅsins, duties of Ksatriyas and the other two varnas, prƒÅya≈õcittas for the deadly sins and other lesser misdeeds, means of livelihood, srƒÅddha, ƒÅ≈õauca (on birth and death ).

In the Govt. Mss. library at the B. O. R. Institute (Poona), there is a Ms. bearing No. 111 of 1895-1902 of Caturvimsati mata which contains 526 verses and another No. 244 of A. 1881-82 which has 525 verses.

The work often quotes the views of U≈õanas, Manu, PƒÅrƒÅ≈õarya, Angiras, Yama, HƒÅrita. It quotes Manu III. 5 ( ' asapindi. ca ya.’ etc.) and Manu XII. 95 (ya vedabahyah sm·ªôtayah). Two other verges which it contains are indicated as interpolated in several editions of Manu.586 It says that the teachings of Arhat, CƒÅrvƒÅka and Buddha delude people. 588 Its position is that whatever is not found in the Veda or the Puranas, the RƒÅmƒÅyana, or MahƒÅbhƒÅrata or in the sƒÅstras of Manu and others is as good as non-existent. 687

The Caturvi≈Üsatimata is frequently quoted by the Mit., A parƒÅrka and later work8,688 but not by Visvar≈´pa and

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

MedhƒÅtithi. It was probably compiled about the time when the latter two writers flourished. AparƒÅrka 589 (p. 1121 ) quotes a prose passage from the work on the prayascitta for a dvijƒÅti procreating children on a S≈´dra wife. This passage could not be traced in the two mss. referred to above.

The Mit. on YƒÅj. III. 58 quotes the Caturo for the proposition that a person resorting to the 4th ƒÅ≈õrama (i.e. SannyƒÅsa ) may be ‘ekada≈Üdin’ or ‘tridandin’. The Mit. quotes several verses from the Caturo on penances (prayas cittas ) for serious and light sins or offences. It suggests alternative penances for even very heinous sins, e. g. on YƒÅj. III. 308 it provides that if a person performs the Japa of GƒÅyatrƒ´ (Rg. III. 62. 10 tat-savitur-varenya·πÅ ) a crore of times he atones for the sin of brƒÅhmana murder, becomes free from the sin of drinking liquor by japa of GƒÅyatrƒ´ 80 lakhs of times, from the sin of the theft of gold by repeat ing 70 lakhs of times the GƒÅyatri. The Smrti-candrikƒÅ quotes Caturo many times on Ahnika and on Sraddha. It quotes the opinion of BaudhƒÅyana in a verse and goes so far as to say that a man becomes free from sins by the japa of BrƒÅhma·πáa works, the six angas, the ƒÅkhyƒÅnas ( legends ), ItihƒÅsa, PurƒÅlas and praises of gods and expositions on Dharma. AparƒÅrka also quotes about 60 verses of Caturvimsatimata and one proge passage on p. 1121 ( quoted below ).

Anothor somewhat remarkable point is that A parƒÅrka in several cases places Caturvimsatimata passages immediate ly near ≈ûat-trimsatmata passages (vide AparƒÅrka pp. 1081, 1172‚Äì74, 1182, 1248 ).

The portions of the works on sa≈ÜskƒÅra and sraddha together with the commentary of Bhattoji, son of Lak≈ümidhara, have been published in the Benares Sanskrit

!!43. Dak≈üa

513

Series ( Nos. 137 and 139 ). The commentary is a very learned one and refers to a host of writers. This commentary is in some mss. ascribed to Ramacandra ( vide I. O. Cat. No. 1554, p. 473).

  1. Daksa

Dak≈üa is one of the writers on dharma enumerated by YƒÅj. Vigvar≈´pa quotes verses of Daksa several times, viz. on YƒÅj. 1. 17 (on clods of earth for purifying the body ), on YƒÅj. III. 30 (two verses on ƒÅ≈õauca ), on YƒÅj. III. 66 ( about & parivrƒÅjaka ), on Y√°j. III. 191 (about padmƒÅsada ). The Mit. (on YƒÅj. I. 89) quotes a half verse of Daksa to the effect that a dvija should not remain unattached to an asrama (i. e. without a wife in the context ) even for a moment; on YƒÅj. III. 58 two verses about bhik·π£us; on YƒÅj. III. 243 (one verse ). AparƒÅrka cites numerous verses of Dak≈üa on ƒÅcƒÅra, ƒÅ≈õauca, srƒÅddha and similar topics. In one case (p. 368 ) be attributes a prose passage to Dak≈üa about the gift of gold.500 Two of Daksa’s verses most frequently quoted by writers on vyavahƒÉra are those that lay down wbat nine things cannot be the subjects of gift.601

In Jivananda’s collection there is a Daksasm·ªôti (part II, pp. 383-402 ) in seven chapters and 220 verses (vide also AnandƒÅsrama collection pp. 72–84), M. N. Dutt’s collection Vol. I. pp. 291-309. The principal subjects treated of are : Four asramas, two kinds of brahmac≈´rins; the daily round of duties for dvijas; various subdivisions of actions, nine karnans vine vikarmang nine actions that should be concealed, nine acts that should be made public, nine things that should not be gifted; gifts; eulogy of a good housewife; sauca of two kinds; impurity due to birth and death ; Yoga and its six angas viz. pr√§·ª•ƒÅyƒÅma, dhyƒÅna, pratyƒÅhƒÅra, dhƒÅranƒÉ, tarka and gam√°dbi; maithuna of eight kinds to be avoided by ascetics ; duties of bhik·π£u, dvaita, and advaita.

590 ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§´‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï. 51 ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ,

514

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Dak≈üasmrti contains the name of Daksa himself and shows that he was a thorough-going Advaitin (as the note shows ).582

This smrti is certainly a very old one. All the quota tions from Daksa cited by Visvar≈´pa occur in the printed Daksa (vide pp. 395, 396, 384, 397 which reads ‘na pathyƒÅ sanƒÅd yogo’). Similarly all the quotations in the Mit. from Daksa are found in the Calcutta text. AparƒÅrka contains over forty verses from the printed Dak≈üa, though there are a few verses cited by him as Dak≈üa‚Äôs which are not found therein. The Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ quotes about ten verses of Dak≈°a on woman which are all found in the 4th chap. of the Calcutta text.

In the Govt. Mos. library at the B. O. R. Institute Poona, there is a ms. of Daksa (No. 120 of 1895‚Äì1902), which contains 197 verses on the same topics as above, many of which are identical with the Calcutta text. The Bombay University has also a similar ms. Vide I. O. Cat. No. 1320 p. 385 for a similar ms. in 197 verses.

  1. PitƒÅmaha

PitƒÅmaba is enumerated among writers on dharma in a verse of V·ªäddha-YƒÅjsavalkya quoted by Visvar≈´pa. The Smrti of PitƒÅmaha (part I p. 10) is drawn upon mostly on VyavabƒÅra. Visvar≈´pa cites (on Yaj. I. 17 ) & verse from him on sauca.603 The MitƒÅk·π£arƒÅ and AparƒÅrka respective ly quote about 45 and 75 verses from PitƒÅmaba only on VyavabƒÅra and specially on ordeals and the Kalpataru on VyavahƒÅra quotes about 90 verses on the same topics from PitƒÅmaha. Some verses are ascribed to both PitƒÅmaha and NƒÅrada (as in Kalpataru Vy. pp. 238, 239) and in a few cases to B»ôhaspati and PitƒÅmaba (as in Kalpataru, Vy. p. 251 ). The Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ quotes about ten verses (of Pito ) on ƒÅhnika, 130 on VyavahƒÅra and only a few on srƒÅddha. PitƒÅmaha regards the Vedas with the angas, MimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ, the

  1. Pit≈´maha

515

Smrtis, Purana and Nyaya system as dharmasastras.584 PitƒÅmaha, like B»ôhaspati, enumerates nine kinds of ordeals,886 while YƒÅj. and NƒÅrada name only five, though the latter seems to have known two more, viz. tandula and taptamƒÅsa. The SmsticandrikƒÅ quotes a dozen verges about 50 chalas on which a king took action without any complaint.588 PitƒÅmaha seems to have followed VyƒÅsa in defining documents called krayapatra, sthitipatra, samdhipatra, visuddhipatra.sor The Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ cites PitƒÅmaha for an enumeration of the 18 pralertis viz. washerman, leather worker, etc.be8 The same work states that according to PitƒÅmaha the titles of law to be taken cognisance by the king himself were twenty-two. In the hall of justice, he says, there should be eight consti tuents viz. the scribe, the accountant, astra, the sadhya. pƒÅla, the assessors, gold, fire and water. 888 Some of the other noteworthy dicta of PitƒÅmaha are :- a suit should beooo first tried before the village ( pancƒÅyat), then before the town (court of appeal ), then before the king ; between litigants of the same country, town, societies, cities and villages, the decision should be arrived at according to their own peculiar conventions and usages, but when there is a dispute between these and strangers, the decision must be

‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ ( ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø.); compare ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶ ( Intro. chap. verse 15 ). ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•á ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§É ‡•• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶; ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§ó‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡•• ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§π ‡•• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶,

‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø

516

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

according to the ≈õƒÅstru; possession in order to be recognised by the courts as decisive must have five characteristics,sol it must have title, long duration, it must be uninterrupted, it must not have been impeached and it must be before the eyes of the opponent; & private document602 under one’s own hand is inferior to a jƒÅnapada (a publicly written and attested ) deed, the latter is inferior to a royal edict, this last is inferior to possession continued for three generations.

PitƒÅmaha is later than Bphaspati,603 as he cites the latter’s view that a litigation between members of the same village, society, town, guild, caravan or army must be decided according to their peculiar usages. Therefore, PitƒÅmaha must be assigned to some date between the 4th and 7th century A. D.

  1. Pulastya Pulastya’s name is among the ten primordial sages men tioned in the Manusmrti I. 34–35.

Pulastya is one of the expounders of dharma enumerated by Vrddha-YƒÅj√±avalkya. Vi≈°var≈´pa quotes a verse from him on sƒÅrƒ´ra≈õauca.604 The Mit. (on YƒÅj. I. 261 ) cites & verse from Pulastya that a BrƒÅhma·πáa should principally use asce tic’s food (i. e. vegetable food ) in sr√•ddha, that ksatriyas and vaisyas should use meat and b≈´dras madhu.606 The Mit. (YƒÅj. III. 253 ) quotes two verses of Pulastya who enumerates eleven intoxicating drinks together with surƒÅ as the twelfth.806 AparƒÅrka quotes several verses from Pulastya on sa·πÅdhyƒÅ, Sraddha, asauca, duties of yatis, prayascitta. AparƒÅrka quotes two verses from Pulastya propounding the view that a

‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ

  1. Pulastya

514

combination of j√±ƒÅna and karma is the correct view.807 The first of these verses is ascribed by him to Yoga-YƒÅj√±avalkya elsewhere (note 336 ). The Sm·ªôticandrika quotes about forty verses from Pulastya on √§hnika and srƒÅddha. In one place it quotes Pulastya on the efficacy of bathing on Sunday, Tuesday, and Saturday. AparƒÅrka (on p. 1136 ) quotes eight verses from Pulastya that provide various religious rites or actions for dog-bite in the case of brƒÅhmana men and women.

The DƒÅnaratnƒÅkara of Cande≈õvara cites a prose text from Pulastya on the gift of deer-skin.gog

The Pulastya-smrti must have been composed between 4th and 7th century A. D.

  1. Paithƒ´nasi

Paithƒ´nasi, though not named among the Sm·ªôtikƒÅras enu merated in YƒÅj. I. 4-5, is mentioned among the 36 Sm·ªôtis quoted by Apar√°rka (p. 7) from the BhavisyapurƒÅua and also in the quotation from Paithinasi about the thirty-six names of the expounders of Dharma≈õƒÅstra in the Smi≈üti-CandrikƒÅ (p. 1). Another reason is that he appears to have dealt in his work with all three branches of Dharma≈õƒÅstra, viz. ƒÅcƒÅra, vyavahƒÅra and prayascitta. Another important matter is that quotations in prose from him far outnumber quotations in verse in the comparatively early digests like the Mit., AparƒÅrka, Kalpataru. Visvar≈´pa on YƒÅj. III. 262 cites a prose

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§‡•§ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç I camera 77 Pares: ma il 37927 on IT. 111. 57, d. 961 These verses occur in the Bihad-Yogi-YƒÅj√±o (chap. 8-29),

which probably borrows from Pulastya. 808 ‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡§®‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•à ‡§® ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡•à‡§É

‡§ï‡•á‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡•• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶. 609 ‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

"

passage of Paithƒ´nasi about the prƒÅya≈õcitta for killing a cow.610 The Mit. quotes prose passages from Paithƒ´nasi on YƒÅj. III. 17, 19, 253, 265 &c. AparƒÅrka quotes several prose passages from Paithinasi on pp. 58, 60, 105 174, 189 (three Astakas in Pausa and the following two months), 239, 248. Two intere sting prose passages 610a on VyavahƒÅra also occur, one being that the wealth of a man dying sopless goes to his brother, in default of brother, to parents or to the senior one among his wives. On p. 1175 Apararka quotes a long prose passage mentioning 18 persons at whose house one should not dine, nor sit for dinner in the same row with them and who are unfit to be invited at a ≈õrƒÅddha. An interesting passage cited by AparƒÅrka about marriage is as follows: A man should choose a girl whose ( father’s ) gotra is not the same as his. He should avoid girls who are within the fifth degree in descent from a common ancestor on the mother’s side and 7th in descent from the father’s side ; or three on the mother’s side and five on the father’s side. 8100 This latter portion about three and five degrees has now been accepted by the Indian Parliament (excepting customs to the contrary) in the Hindu Marriage Act No. 25 of 1955, Section 3 (f).

Kalpataru on VyavahƒÅra quotes 22 prose passages of Paithinasi and 7 verses. On p. 627 it sayss10c women are the 610 ‡§™‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø-‡§ó‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§≤‡§∂‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§®‡•ã ‡§ó‡•ã‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§É

‡§∂‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•¶ on ‡§Ø‡§æ. III. 262, part II p. 141; also in ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ. on ‡§Ø‡§æ. 11. 263-84; ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•å ‡§ö‡•à‡§ï‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ. on III. 17; ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ú‡§® ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•à‡§†‡•Ä. in ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ. on ‡§Ø‡§æ. III. 19 ; and ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§∞‡•Å (‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ) p. 20 ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§™ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡•á‡§§‡•ç - ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•à‡§†‡•Ä‡§®‡§∏‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ. on ‡§Ø‡§æ.

III. 253. 810a ‡§Ö‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•å ‡§≤‡§≠‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡•§

‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•à‡§†‡•Ä‡§®‡§∏‡§ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç etc. ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï p. 744 ; ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡§® ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∑‡§°‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Ç

‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•à‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§™‡•à‡§†‡•Ä. in ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï p. 748. 810b ‡§™‡•à‡§†‡•Ä‡§®‡§∏‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§

quotes this s≈´tra of Paiƒºhinasi. 810c ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§

  1. Paithanasi

519

presiding deities of the bome; (strict) rules about purifica tion are pot demanded of them, nor the observance of vratas nor fasting; they reach the highest world if they properly look after their husbands. When an appointed daughter dies her husband does not succeed to her wealth; if she dies sonless, her wealth should be taken by her unmarried daughter or sister. On pp. 818 and 819, there are two prose passages, the first providing for the status of the children of a brƒÅhmana, ksatriya or Vaisya woman born from a person of a lower varna and the second providing for the status of children born in unions (which are not bad on the ground of illicit inter course ). The Brahmac√°rikƒÅnda of the Kalpataru quotes 22 prose pasgages and seven verses from Paithƒ´nasi. Kalpataru ( MoksakƒÅnda pp. 21-22 ) has a long sutra of Paithƒ´nasi about the daily life of a forest hermit (vƒÅnaprastha ). Kalpataru (on SrƒÅddha ) adduces prose passages of Paithƒ´nasi fifteen times and only two verses. Kalpataru (on Suddhi) adduces from Paithinasi only prose passages ( 15 times ), some (as op pp. 105 and 140 ) being very long. Kalpataru (NaiyatakƒÅlika, quotes Paithƒ´nasi 24 times; one prose passage ( about one pago in extent) deals with honouring a guest (on pp. 188‚Äì89) and there is another very long prose passage on rajasvalƒÅ occupy. ing one page and a half on pp. 352-3.

  1. Pracetas

Pracetas fiuds a place among the sages enumerated by PerƒÅsara (though not in YƒÅj√±avalkya), in the list of 36 Smrti k√§ras by PaithinƒÅsi in Sm·ªôticandrikƒÉ p. 1). In both Mit. and AparƒÅrka there are passages in prose and verse ascribed to Pracetas on daily duties, srƒÅddha, ƒÅ≈õauca, prƒÅyascitta. The Mit. (on YƒÅj. III. 27 ) quotes & verse from Pracetas saying that workmen, artisans, physicians, male and female slaves, kings, royal officers have not to observe periods of impurity 811 (on death). This verse is cited as a smrti by MedhƒÅtithi on Manu V. 60 without ascribing it to Pracetas. So Medh√§tithi looked upon Pracetas as equally authoritative with Manu, Vi≈°≈Üu and others.

81 ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ‡§É

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

It appears from the quotations in the Mit., AparƒÅrka and SmrticandrikƒÅ that they had before them a large work of Pracetas containing s≈´tras and verses and that Pracetas did not deal with VyavahƒÅra. An example of a long prose passage is cited below.613

The Mit. on YƒÅj. (III. 20, 263, 264 and 265 ), Haradatta on Gautama (22.18 ) and AparƒÅrka (on pp. 910, 1125, 1171 ) quote several verses of Brhat-Pracetas on ƒÅ≈õauca and prƒÅyas citta and the Mit. on YƒÅj. III. 265 and AparƒÉrka (on pp.888,) 897 and 1098 ) quote several verses of Vƒ©ddha-Pracetas on the same topics.

A few prose quotations from Pracetas are noted in the SmrticandrikƒÅ and by Haradatta (on Gautama 23. 1).

  1. Prajapati PrajƒÅpati is cited as an authority by the BaudhƒÅyana dharinas≈´tra (II. 4. 15 and II. 10. 71 ). Vasistha several times quotes PrƒÅjƒÅpatya blokas (viz. III. 47, XIV. 16-19, 24-27, 30-32). It has been shown above that most of these Verses are found in the Manusmrti or have close correspon dence with verses of Manu. So it is not unlikely that both the writers of dharmas≈´tras mean Manu by PrajƒÅpati.

In the AnandƒÅ≈õrama collection (p. 90-98 ) there is a smrti of PrajƒÅpati in 198 verses on the various details of frƒÅddha, such as the time, place, the persons authorised to perform, proper food, BrƒÅhmanas to be invited etc. The pre vailing metre is Auustubh, but there are nine verses in the IndravajrƒÅ, Upaj√§ti, VasantatilakƒÅ (verse 137 ) and SragdharƒÉ (verse 96 ). It speaks of Kalpa≈õƒÅstra, smrtis, dharma≈õƒÅstra, purƒÅnas. It contains a verse referring to the Kanya and Vr≈õcika ( scorpion ) signs of the Zodiac, which is almost the same as a verse of KƒÅr≈°≈ÜƒÅjini.

812 ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã

‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§ú‡§∞‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§É ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§ï‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§É ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∂‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§µ‡§£‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∂‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ kranti 1 fat i tata in 34921p. 1155,

FOUNDED

1917

  1. PrajƒÅpati

521

The Mit. (on YƒÅj. III. 25 and 260 ) quotes verses of PrajƒÅ pati on ƒÅ≈õauca and prƒÅya≈õcittu. AparƒÅrka cites verses of PrajƒÅpati on purification of various substances, on √©rƒÅddha, witnesses, ordeals and ƒÅ≈õauca. None of these is traced to the printed text of PrajƒÅpati. A parƒÅrka (p. 952 ) gives a long prose text of PrajƒÅpati on the four orders of parivrƒÅjakas, viz. kuticaka, bahudaka, hamsa, paramahamsa. AparƒÅrka (p. 542) cites a verge of LaugƒÅk·π£i which refers to the view of PrajƒÅ pati that the son of a putrika was to offer pindas to his mother by the gotra of his maternal grand-father.s13 AparƒÅrka, Smrti. candrikƒÅ, ParƒÅ≈õara-MƒÉdhaviya and other works quote several verses of PrajƒÅpati on vyavahƒÅra. Wituesses are of two kinds, krta and akrta.814 In this he seems to have followed Narada (rnadana, verse 149). Prajapati lays down the characteri stics of valid reply ( uttara ) of the defendant and defines 818 the four varieties of uttara. The ParƒÅ≈õara-Madhaviya cites several verses of PrajƒÅpati on ordeals. PrajƒÅpati recognised the right of the sonless widow to succeed to her husband’s wealth018 and enjoined on her the duty of offering frƒÅddha every month and year to her husband’s manes and to honour his relatives.817

  1. Marici

The name Marici is very ancient. In Manusm·ªôti II. 34-35 Marici is mentioned first among the ten PrajƒÅpatis.

This sage is relied upon as an authority by the Mit., AparƒÅrka, Smrticandrika on Ahnika, Asauca, Sraddha, PrƒÅyascitta and VyavahƒÅra. Apar√§rka quotes several verses on

‡§π‡•à ‡§Ü‡§™‡§ï‡•á

813 ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•ã‡§¶‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï. 814 ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§è‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω.

‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï p. 666, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ (‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø. p. 80 reads ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•¶). 815 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ (‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø. p. 42-43 ), ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ. ‡§Æ‡§æ. vol. III, p. 69-73. 618 ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§≤‡§≠‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§è‡§∑

‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§É ‡•• 817 ‡§ú‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§

‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¶‡•å‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•§‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ (p. 291), ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ. ‡§Æ‡§æ. vol, III. p. 536,

‡•§

522

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

turpana, one of which speaks of Sunday.618 Marici disallows bathing in the rivers in the months of SrƒÅvana and BhƒÉdra pada.618 Marici made a very near approach to the modern conceptions underlying the Transfer of Property Act. Com pleteness is not attained without writing in the transactions of Aale, mortgage, partition and gift of immoveable property. 820 If a buyer purchases a chattel before a row of merchants and to the knowledge of the king’s officers and in broad daylight, he is free from blame and gets back his money (if the thing turns out to be another’s property ), while if the price (paid by a buyer for a chattel) cannot be recovered (from the veodor who sells without title) owing to the vendor’s address being not known, the loss should be apportioned between the buyer and the original owner of the chattel.081 Marici divides adhi into four varieties bhogya, gopya, pratyaya, ƒÅj√±ƒÅdbi.

Prose passage of Marƒ´ci is ‘KanyƒÅnƒÅm prƒÅk-c≈´ƒºƒÅkara·∏•ƒÅt sadya·∏• saucam | PrƒÅgdƒÅnƒÅd-ekƒÅha·∏• | DattƒÅnƒÅm prƒÅk-pari≈Üa yanƒÅt-tryaham | AparƒÅrka p. 938.

It is to be noted that AparƒÅrka ( p. 908 ) quotes a prose passage of Marici on ƒÅ≈õauca.

  1. Yama

The Vasistha-dharmasutra (18. 13-15 and 19. 48 ) cites four slokas of Yama and quotes (11. 20 ) one verse in which Yama is spoken of as an authority. All the slokas except one

  1. Yama

528

are found in Manu.622 Vasistha quotes a bloka of Prajapati wherein Yama’s view is set forth. Yama is one of the sages enumerated in the list of YƒÅj√±avalkya. GovinderƒÅja (on

Manu 5. 16) and AparƒÅrka quote a verse of Sankha wherein Yama’s view that the flesh of certain birds could be eaten is referred to.613 Apar√°rka (p. 1231 ) also cites & verse of Sankba in which the view of BhagavƒÅn Yama that one should save one’s life in all ways (even by incurring sin ) is relied upon.

___ In Jivananda’s collection (part I. pp. 560-568) there is a smrti of Yama in seventyeight verses on prƒÅya≈õcitta and purification ( buddhi). In the sm·ªôti Yama himself is cited in the third person ( verse 65 ). One verse ( 33 ) refers to the view of BhƒÅsvati (son of the Sun, by which may be meant either Manu or Yama himself ).84 Some of the verses are identical with those of Manu (e. g. verses 26, 28 are the same as Manu 11. 178 and 3. 19). Verse 44 is in the UpajƒÅti metre. In the Anandasrama collection there is a Yamasmrti in 99 verses on prƒÅya≈õcitta, ≈õrƒÅddha and purification. Most of the topics of this smrti are the same as those of the Calcutta text, but most of the verses are not identical. A few

verses are found in both, e. g. the verses about the seven lowest casteg625 ( antyajas ). Verse 11 quotes the view of SƒÅtƒÅtapa. This Sm·ªôti contains the well-known text that * woman passes on marriage into the gotra of her husband, which is cited by the Mit. (on Yaj. I. 254 ).828 In the same collection there is a sm·ªôti of B·ªãhad-Yama (pp. 99-107 ). It is divided into five chapters and contains 182 verses. It deals with prƒÅya≈õcittas for various lapses, purification from various kinds of contacts (suddhi), srƒÅddha, partition and a few matters of medical procedure. In this su»ôti Yama is frequently cited by name. S√§tƒÅtapa is cited on partition ( V. 20). Many of the verses of this text are identical with those of Yama in Jivananda’s text. For example, Jivananda (p. 561 ) verses 15-17 are the same as Brbad-Yama III. 1-3, Jivananda p. 563 verses 29-33 are the same as Brhad-Yama III. 34-38, Jivananda verses 35-36 are the same as Brhad-Yama III. 16‚Äì17. The verse in the UpajƒÅti metre, Jivananda 44 ) is Brhad-Yama III. 61. Two of the verses at the end of chap. V. are the same as YƒÅj. II. 17 and 23.

The pumerous m88. of Yama contain either one or other of the above three texts or different texts bearing on the same topics. For example, the Govt. Mos. Collection at the Bhandarkar Institute, Nos. 209-211 of A 1881-82 and No. 153 of 1895-1902 are the same as the Yamasmrti in the AnandƒÅ srama collection. No. 401 of 1891-95 seems to be the same as Brhad-Yama in the Anand√°srama collection. But the I. O. Cat. No. 1334 p. 390 contains 37 slokas, the last 20 of which are in the IndravajrƒÅ metre.

Visvar≈´pa, Vij√±ƒÅne≈õvara, AparƒÅrka, the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ and other later works quote over three hundred verses of Yama on all topics of dharma≈õƒÅstra including vyavahƒÅra. This establishes that they had an extensive work of Yama before them from which it is probable that various abridgments corresponding with the printed works were made. Visvar≈´pa quotes about ten verses of Yama on water as purifier (on YƒÅj.

  1. Yama

525

1, 187 ), on srƒÅddha ( on YƒÅj. I 225 and 252 ) and on prƒÅya. scitta for killing a cow (on Yaj. III. 262). The identical verses are not found in the printed texts. Some of the verses quoted from Yama in AparƒÅrka and the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ can be traced in the printed text. For example, AparƒÅrka (p. 42 ) quotes a verse of Yama in which Yama himself is referred to as an authority.sa7 It occurs in Jivananda’s text (verse 65 ). The two verses in Jivananda’s text ( verses 26, 28) that are identical with Manu are cited in the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ 88 Yama’s. AparƒÅrka p. 1135 quotes a prose passage of Yama, ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§É- ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Æ‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ï‡§É ‡§´‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç :- Two verses of Brhad-Yama ( III. 20-21 ) about the proper age of marriage in the case of girls are quoted as Yama’s in the Smrti. candrik√°.628 In some of the verses quoted by AparƒÅrka from Yama, the opinions of Manu are cited which can be identified with the views of the Manusmrti. For example, according to Yama food polluted by the touch of hair, moths and insects, or seen by sinners and women in their courses is purified by water, holy ashes etc.628 This refers to Manu V, 125. Similarly, the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ quotes a verse of Yama which says that according to Manu those who administer poison, who are incendiaries and robbers and those guilty of homicide and abetment thereof should pay the extreme penalty of death.630 AparƒÅrka (p. 988 on Yaj. III. 109) quotes five verses of Yama which refer to the 26 tattvas well-known in the Sankhya system, regard Purusottama as a 26th tuttva and propound that he who correctly understands the 25 tattvas, in whatever a≈õrama he may be, reaches the highest abode of Vi≈Ü≈Üu. AparƒÅrka quotes a few prose passages from Yama on the garments to be worn by brahmac√£rins,831 on prƒÅyascitta

827 ‡§Ö‡§™‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§ñ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç

‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡•• This is attributed to ‡§Ø‡§Æ in the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö. also. 628 ‡§Ö‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§®‡§µ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§∂‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ

‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ ‡•• ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ã‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ (‡§Ü‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ï p. 79 ).

‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§™‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡•à‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•à‡§É

‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§π ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï p. 267. 680 ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ ; ride ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å. 9. 278. 631 ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•å‡§∞‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ß‡•ã‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§® ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï D. 58.

for killing various kind of birds and insects, for cutting trees and bushes, for drinking wine, for stealing gold and for the other deadly sins etc. 632

The Anulisanaparva of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata (Chap. 104 verse 72 ) states that those who are conversant with ancient times recited verses (g≈´th≈´s ) of Yama and then follow 84 verses which are more or less like verses found in several smrtis e. g. the verse ‘√ºrdhyam prƒÅnƒÅ… pratipadyate’ occurs as Anu≈°ƒÅsana 104. 64-65 (and is Manu II. 120 ); so also

D≈´rƒÅdƒÅvasathƒÅn ..d√ºre kƒÅryam hitaisinƒÅ’. This is Apu≈°ƒÅsana 104.82 (Manu IV. 151). The verge AcƒÅrƒÅllabhate hyƒÅyur-ƒÅcƒÉro hantyalaksanam’ ( Anu. 104. 155 ) occurs in Manu IV. 156. It is possible that the final redactor of the MahabhƒÅrata had before him a Smrti ascribed to Yama or it is likely that a few verses ascribed to Yama were first cited and the author of the Epic added a few more from other sources. Yams is pro fusely quoted in the various K√§ndas of Kalpataru.

The Sm·ªôticandrik√° quotes a verse of Yama which speaks of the Sun being in the zodiacal sign Virgo.638

Yama required the king to look into the disputes of liti gants carefully and impartially.834 Yama cites the authority of Manu for the proposition that everything brought about by coercion such as a gift or a deed was liable to be set aside.685 This is almost identical with Manu 8. 168. Yama lays down that a BrƒÅhmana was never to be awarded corporal punish ment, but that a BrƒÅhmana guilty of crimes was to be impri soned and made638 to work. Yama like Yaj. (II. 145 ), pre scribed that the stridhana of a woman married in the Asura

AparƒÅrka (p. 822 ) quotes two verses of Yama that prescribed the first ammercement for him who, though forbidden, wrongfully takes the water of a lake or disturbs a water-courge and the highest ommercement for him who breaks a lake. AparƒÅrka (p. 860 ) also cites Yama for the fine of five krsnalas in the case of adultery with another’s wife of the same caste as that of the paramour and twelve panjas in case the wife is of a lower caste. The Smrticandrika and the Vyavaharamay≈´kba on the other hand direct that the king should punish the BrƒÅhmana woman guilty of adultery with a S≈´dra by throwing her to dogs and by forcible tonsure and riding on an ass in case of adultery with a Kiatriya or Vaibya. The SmrticandrikƒÅ, ParƒÅsara-MƒÉdhaviya and VyavahƒÅramayukha quote a verse of Yome about a debtor, who, being able to pay, does not want only pay, being punished by taking twice the amount. Yama remarks that the order of Sa·πÅny√•sa is not allowed to women in the Vedas or in the sƒÅstra 38 (dharmadƒÅstra ) and that her real dharma is to be the mother of children from one of her own caste.

Verses of B»ôhadyama are cited 098 by the Mit. on YƒÅj. III. 255, 260, 289 and by AparƒÅrka, who, on p. 496, quotes also from Laghuyama a verse and a half.

Yama is cited 46 times in the Kalpataru (BrahmacƒÉri K√§nda ) and 13 times in the MoksakƒÅnda (in which it quotes 70 verses ).   1. Laugaksi

LaugƒÅk≈üi is mentioned among the 36 expounders of Dharma≈õƒÅstra set out by Paithƒ´nasi (on p. 1 of Sm·ªô. Ch.) and Angiras quoted on the same page includes LaugƒÅk≈üi among Upasm·ªôtis.

The Mit. (on YƒÅj. III, 1-2, 260, 289 ) quotes verses of LaugƒÅksi on ƒÅ≈õauca and prƒÅyascitta. AparƒÅrka quotes nine proge passages (pp. 28‚Äì29, 33, 122, 145, 166, 176 and 530) on ƒÄcƒÅra including SrƒÅddha and ten verses on ten pages on AcƒÅra, ƒÄ≈õauca and the order of forest hermits and one very long prose passage on p. 1227 (covering half a page ). On p. 542 AparƒÅrka quotes a verse of LaugƒÅksi in which PrajƒÅpati is mentioned as an authority. The Mit. on YƒÅj. II. 118-119 quotes the definitions of Yoga’and Ksema given by LaugƒÅk≈üi and which are declared to be not liable to partition by coparceners ( acc. to Mapu IX. 219 ), even if they be acqui red by detriment to the parental estate. Those definitions of Yoga and K≈üema are quoted by many works and writers on VyavahƒÅra such as the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ (on Vy. p. 277 ), Par. M. Vol. III. p. 563. Vide H. of Dh. Vol. III. pp. 588-589 for different meanings of the two words.

It is remarkable that AparƒÅrka quotes from LauvƒÅk≈°i prose and verse passages ten times each. On pp. 1821938, a long prose passage of LaugƒÅk≈üi is quoted about K≈´do mandar homa ( for which see H, of Dh. vol. IV p. 43 n. 102). FOUNDED

  1. VisvƒÅmitra

  1. Visvamitra VievƒÅmitra is one of the writers on dharma enumerated by Vrddha-YƒÅjƒ´javalkya as quoted by Visvar≈´pa. Apar√°rka, the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ, the KƒÅlaviveka of Jim≈´tavƒÅhana and other works quote verses of Vi≈õvƒÅmitra on almost all topics of dharma except vyavahƒÅra, such as on the five deadly sins, on srƒÅddhas, prƒÅya≈õcitta etc. Vi≈õvƒÅmitra defines dharma as that which is esteemed by Aryas ( respectable people who know the Vedas. 640 Apar√°rka quotes 18 verses from VisvƒÅ. mitra on Prayascitta and the SinrticandrikƒÅ also quotes several verses of his Kalpataru ( on Brahmacario), cites YƒÅj. I. 14 (GarbhƒÅstame &c.) as occurring in Vi≈õvƒÅmitra also. Similarly Kalpataru (on NaiyatakƒÅla p. 314 ) states that YƒÅj. I. 179 (prƒÅnƒÅtyaye &c. ) also occurs in VisvƒÅmitra’s Sm·ªôti. His verses on the mahƒÉpƒÉtakas are frequently quoted.641 The Madras (Govt. ) Mss. cat. (p. 1985 No. 2717 ; notices a Sm·ªôti of VisvƒÅmitra in verse in nine chapters.

RA

  1. VyƒÅsa In Jivananda (part II, pp. 321-342 ) and in the Anand√° srama collection of sm·ªôtis there is a smrti ascribed to Vyasa (pp. 357-371 ). The two texts are the same with a few variations. It is in four chapters and contains about 250 verses. VyƒÅsa is said to have declared the Smrti in Benares.

640 ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§Æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ

FOUNI

530

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstro

The contents briefly are :– the dharmas herein laid down prevail only in that region where the black deer roam about; the authoritativeness of sruti, smrti and purƒÅnas; mixed castes; sixteen sa·πÅskƒÅras ; duties of brahmucƒÅrƒ´; marriage; a BrƒÅhmana may marry Ksatriya or Vaisy& girl but not S≈´dra ; duties of a wife; the nitya, naimittila and k√§mya acts of householders, eulogy of the householder stage and of gifts.

Visvar≈´pa quotes a few verses of VyƒÅsa. They are mostly taken from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and are concerned with topics of marriage, daily duties (such as washing the teeth and bathing ), srƒÅddha and prƒÅyascitta. Similarly MedhƒÉtithi quotes several verses from the MahƒÅbharata as Vyasa’s. Kalpataru quotes VyƒÅga about 80 times ou VyavahƒÅra, 16 times in Grhastha, 3 times on RƒÅjadharma. Vi≈°var≈´pa on Yaj. II. 121 ( part 2, p. 121 ) quotes three verses of Vyasa on theft, the 2nd and 3rd of which say ‘on acquiring by theft one suvarna, one cow or even one fingerbreadth of land from the best of brƒÅhma·πáas (the thief ) certainly receives bodily punishment’ (or death sentence ); and ‘by gift or theft the reward ( or result ) is middling or lowest or highest, depend ing on the extent of the thing donated and the worth of the donee’. Maskarin on Gaut. 23. 2 quotes VyƒÅsa’s verse842 (i. e. MahƒÅbhƒÅrata, Udyoga parva, 59. 5, that both Ke≈õava ( Krona) and Arjuna were seen drunk (having drunk sweet liquor ), who had applied sandalwood paste to their bodies and who lay down on the same bed. Kalpntaru ( GrhasthakƒÅ≈Üda p. 302 )048 speaks of only five Yamas and five Niyamas ( as quoted below ), while the Yogasutra also names five Yamas and five Niyamas, but YƒÅj. III. 312-313 and Vaik. SmƒÅrtas√∫tra IX. 4 enumerate ten yamas and ten niyamas; vide H. of Dh. Vol. V.

.

842 ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡•ç quotes ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‘‡§â‡§≠‡•å ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§¨‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§≠‡•å’ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•å ‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï

  1. Vyasa

631

p. 946 n. 1525 and pp. 1419-21 for these. VyƒÅsa say8644 nobody is a friend or foe of anybody; friends and enemies arise on account of power'. VyƒÅsa refers to the opinion of some that one should not marry a girl of the same gotra as that of one’s mother (in her maiden state ). Yy√§sa and B»ôhaspati provide that aged parents, a virtuous wife and a son who is e child must be given maintenance even by taking to conde mned means of livelihood. A brƒÅhmana should not hanker after gifts; he may collect them only for his livelihood; a brƒÅh mana taking more than what is required for his maintenance incurs degradation. In AparƒÉrka, the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ and other works about two hundred verses of VyƒÅsa are cited on vyavahƒÅra. From these it appears that VyƒÅsa dealt with rules of procedure and the several titles of law ( vyavahƒÅra-padas ) and that his doctrines closely agreed in most respects with those of NƒÅrada, KƒÅtya yana and B»ôhaspati. He gives rules on the four kinds of uttara (mithyƒÅ, sampratipatti, kƒÅrana and prƒÅn-nyaya ), divides documents into three varieties ( svahasta, janapada, rƒÅja≈õƒÅsana ), divides laukiku documents into eight sub varieties ( just as KƒÅtyƒÅyana seems to have done ); YƒÅj. (1. 316-318 ) provides that when a king makes a grant of land or of a permanent right to receive a certain sum of money or a certain part of goods, he should inscribe on a piece of cloth or on a copper plate the details of the grant with his seal. Byhaspati (four verses quoted by Apar√§rka on pp. 579-580 ) deals more elaborately with the same matter and AparƒÅrka quotes about eight verses of VyƒÅsa, one of which prescribes that the grant should record in it the merit for the grantor and his successors who continue the grant, and heaven for 60000 years, and hell for the same length

History of Dharmasastra

of time for him who resumes it.646 VyƒÅsa lays down that if & stranger enjoys a person’s land for twenty years when the king i is there (i. e. when there is no revolution or anarchy) and when the owner is able (to resist) the latter loses his property.848 He speaks of adverse possession as having five characteristics.s47 He mentions seven kinds of sureties, wbile Harita and K√§tyƒÅyana speak of only five and B»ôhaspati of four. He speaks of only five kinds of ordeals. He defines a niska as equal to 14 suvarnas, a suvarna being equal to eight palas.843 Vyasa seems to represent a middle stage in the evolution of the rights of the widow to succeed to her deceased husband. He says that a woman was to get a maximum of two thousand (kƒÅrsƒÅpanas) from the estate of her deceased husband.648 (besides what he gave her when living ). Vyasa gave to the father and sons equal share in ancestral property and allowed partition even against the wish of the father.660 From these important characteristics of VyƒÅsa it may safely be concluded that Vyasa flourished about the same time as Yaj≈àavalkya and B»ôhaspati, i. e. between the second and the fifth century (A. D. ).
