1917 1153. VyƒÅsa

533

In AparƒÅrka and other works there are numerous verses attributed to Vyasa which are certainly not taken from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata or from the VyƒÅsa-empti in the AnandƒÅ≈õrama collection (pp. 357‚Äì371 ). For example, on YƒÅj. I, 12 he cites e verge of VyƒÅsa in the VasantatilakƒÅ metre about the auspicious asterism for caula and another verse laying down Saturday, Sunday and Friday as not suitable for caula. Similarly, VyƒÅsa’s verses dealing with the merit of bathing on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday in conjunction with certain tithis are cited by Apar√•rka (p. 213). VyƒÅsa a peuks of srƒÅdthas when the Sun is in the sign of Viryo ( A pararka p. 424). These indications are sufficient to assign Vy√°sa to a comparatively later date. But, as AparƒÅrka evidently makes no distinction between Vyasa the jurist, VyƒÅsa, the reputed compiler of the Mahabharata (e. g. he quotes on p. 961 six verses of the Bhagavadgiti as Vyasa’s) and Vy√§sa who wrote on the sams kƒÅras, fr√§ddha and other topics, it appears that the jurist and the writer on other topics of dharma were separated from him by several centuries. Whether the jurist and the writer on other topics of dharma are identical is a difficult problem. The Mit. also appears to identify VyƒÅsa of the Maha bbƒÅrata with the jurist. For example, on Y√ªj. III. 253 it refers to ‘Ublau MadhvƒÅsa’s ( Udyoya parva 58. 5 ) applied to Krona and Arjuna and explains that all intoxicants were not forbidden to Ksatriyas but only wine prepared from tour. The Mit. on YƒÅj. II. 283 ( on ‘Strisangrahaya’) quotes three verses and a half on the three kinds of that juridical topic. No one has so far identified these verses in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. The Mit. appears to make no distinction between the two. The Kalpataru (on Vy. pp. 577-579 ) quotes with slight vari. ations the same verses and also sets forth similar verses of Bphaspati. AparƒÅrka (pp. 854-55 ) and Sm·ªôticandrik√• (Vy. p. 8) also quote the same verses as Vy√§sa’s (with slight variations. ). All that can be said is that the two may probably be identical. The Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ quotes a Gadya Vy√°ga 661 and quotes about 450 verses of Vy√§sa on √¢hnika, vyavabƒÉra and prayascitta.

861

It adds in Yamatarpa!a the following: 4719 √Årtata ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡•• ‡§è‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

The Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ652 quotes several interesting verses of Laghu-VyƒÅsa that condemn somewhat severely and unchari tably the memorizing of the Veda without understanding the meaning. A few verses are quoted below. It may be noted that the Nirukta I. 18 ( several centuries before Christ ), by quoting a verse ‘a man who memorizes the Veda but does not know the meaning is like a stump of a tree, a mere carrier of a burden’condemned mere learning of the Veda by heart in very similar words (SthƒÅ≈Üur-ayam bhƒÅrahƒÅra·∏• kilƒÅbh≈´t &c.) Daksa (in II. 34 ) states that the study of Veda has five aspects viz. first to commit it to memory, then to think over its meaning, then to repeat it often, its japa and to pass it on to pupils.

AparƒÅrka quotes a verge of V»õddha-VyƒÅsa on SaudƒÅyika, a kind of strƒ´dhana. The Mit., the PrƒÅya≈õcitta–may≈´kha and other works cite verses of a Brhad-VyƒÅsa. BallƒÉlasena in his DƒÅnasƒÅgara quotes MabƒÅ- VyƒÅsa and Lagbu-VyƒÅsa as authorities and also DƒÅna-VyƒÅsa, which probably means the dƒÅna-dharma portions of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata.

Dr. Batakrishua Ghosh collected from fourteen works (such as AparƒÅrka’s commentary, MitƒÅk·π£arƒÅ, DƒÅyabhƒÅga, ParƒÅ≈õaramadhaviya, Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ, VyavahƒÅramƒÅt≈ÜkƒÅ, Vya vahƒÅramayukha &c.) 268 verses of VyƒÅsa on judicial procedure and the substantive law and published them in Indian Culture’ Vol. IX. pp. 65-98 ( with references at the bottom of the pages). They relate to the king as judge, the qualifi catious of the Judge and the members of the Court, the plaint,

VAS

FOUNDED

1917

  1. Vy√ºsa

535

the reply, proof and burden of proof, documents; the judge ment, eight different kinds of documents such as cƒÅraka, adhipatra, kraya patra; examination of documents ; posses sion and title; witnesses and pointing out their faults ; ordeals; interest; mortgage and pledge; debts and persons liable to pay debts ; sureties; several titles of law; abuse and defamation; crimes of violence; thieves and robbers; adultery and other wrongful acts about women; punish ments ; duties of women and wives ; partition of family property; stridhana (woman’s property ).

Some of the verses quoted as VyƒÅsa’s occur elsewhere e. g. verse 11 ( of the above collection ‘na si sabhƒÅ…viddham occurs in NƒÅrada III. 18 and is quoted as Vyasa’s in AparƒÅrka ( p. 604). Similarly, the verse’ na narmayuktam vacanam hinasti ( No. 111 in the list of Dr. Batakrishna Ghosh ) quoted by the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ ( Vy. p. 89 ) as VyƒÅsa’s occurs in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata ( Adi. 82, 16 and S√§ntiparva 165. 30 ). Verse 129 (AdityacandrƒÅvanilo which is the mantra to be employed in ordeals ) occurs in Adiparva 74. 30. No. 140 of the collection by Dr. Ghosh defines niska as equal to fourteen suvarnas.688 The Mit. on YƒÅj. I. 72 provides that a wife who drinks wine, who is guilty of adultery with the husband’s pupil or guru, who kills her husband and particularly one who has inter course with a man of a degraded caste (such as a shoemaker) should be abandoned.864 So, whoever might have been the author of the VyƒÅsasm·ªôti he incorporates some verses from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata therein.

  1. Sat-trimsan-mata The title literally means ‘the doctrines of thirty-six (Sm·ªôtis )’. This appears to have been a work like the Catur vim≈õatimata. It has been stated above that Paithinasi enumerated thirtysix propounders of Dharma (vide Smrtican drik√° p. 1). Quotations from »òat-trimsan-mata cited in the

653 ‡§™‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂ ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡••

quoted by plago (jo ) p. 99, 97. AT. ( 200 ) p. 158. 864 ‡§ö‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ó‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§ú‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡•ã.

536

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

MitƒÅk·π£arƒÅ are prose passages on YƒÅj. III. 265 and about 23 verses on the third section of YƒÅj. Smrti and AparƒÅrka also has one prose passage on p. 1196 and about 37 verses on two sections viz. ƒÅcƒÅra and prƒÅycscitta. Both these digests cite no passage of the Sat-trimsan-mata on VyavahƒÅra. It appears that the Kalpataru was aware of the existence of this work but regarded it as unauthoritative, since it was accepted only by a few and was contradicted by others, as stated in the Brahmac√°rikƒÅnda of Kalpataru (p. 26).666 The prose quotation in the Mit. on YƒÅj. III. 265 from the »òat-trimsan-mata is a long one and provides the penances for adultery by a woman of the four varnas with a male of a varna different from each of them. AparƒÅrka quotes a prose passage (on p. 1196 ) from this work which provides a penance for touching the corpse of a cƒÅ≈ÜdƒÅla or for occupying the same vehicle, seat or bed with the latter.

The fact that Visvar≈´pa and MedhƒÉtithi do not mention this work, taken along with the above statement of Mitramisra may be relied upon for holding that this compilation must have been among the latest products of the age of sm·ªôtis and was probably compilerl some time between 790-909 A. D. Almost all the quotations from this compilation are concerned with the topics of purification of substances (buddhi), srƒÅddha and prayascittas for sins and pollutions of various sorts. No verse of this compilation dealing with vyavahƒÅra could he discovered. One verse quoted from it prescribes a bath on touching Bauddhas, PƒÅ≈õupatas, Jainas, atheists and followers of Kapila.666 Another verse quoted by AparƒÅrka cites the

view of B·ªãhaspati.667 In another verse the view of Vaivasvata is referred to.668 The Vyavaharanirnaya quotes (on p. 13 ) two verses from Sat-trimsan-mata defining those that may be called Pasandas.968 The Prthvicaudra ( in VyavahƒÅra prakƒÅka p. 19) quotes two verses ( from Sat-trinsan-mata. which state that the words of a sudra even if he be a learned man should not be accepted ( as authoritative ).660

The Mit. on Yij. ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï p. 1249. 658 ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ

‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•á p. 1174. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á ‡§® ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ) ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç (‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á?) ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•à‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§. 660 ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§¨‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§®‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç

‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ( ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞. p. 19 ). 861 ‡§∏‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡•á ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ö ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä

‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É ‡•• ‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Æ‡§§ g. by ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ (‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß) p. 303. A

538

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

portant for the history of Hindu Law. A few of the important views of the SamgrabakƒÅra are set out below. He gives the requisite characteristics of a plaint in five verses.662 Accord ing to him documents are of two kinds, rƒÅjakiya and jƒÅna pada. The ordeals from dhata (balance) to poison (i. e, four) are prescribed in cases where the subject matter is of great value (i. e. above 500 panas ), while ko≈õa and the other ) ordeals (in all three ) are prescribed in disputes for lesser sums.868 This is slightly opposed to NƒÅrada (rnƒÅdƒÅna, verse 336 ), according to whom the five ordeals from tula to kosa were prescribed in substantial disputes. The Samgrahak√§ra has in view the seven ordeals spoken of by N√§rada (r≈ÜƒÅdƒÅna verses 252, 337, 343 ), while B»ôhaspati and PitƒÅmala enumerate nine. He defines dƒÅya as the wealth that is handed down through father and mother. 864 He held that ownership arose from the dictates of ≈õƒÅstra and was not an affair of the world (laukika) and puts forward two reasons in support of his theory, viz. if ownership were laukika, then it would not be possible to make such assertions as his wealth has been wrong-fully seized by another and the texts (vide Gautama X. 49 ) laying down the means of acquisition of wealth for the several varyas would be meaningless.686 Dbire≈õvara held the same view. These views were elaborately criticized by the Mit. According to the Samgrahak√§ra, 666 partition creates ownership in the son as regards paterual wealth ( in which he has no rights by birth ). DhƒÅre≈õvara entertained the game opinion, which was vehemently controverted by the Mit. holding that partition takes place of that in which one has already ownership.

862 Vide fato on AST. II. 6, plato ( 24. p. 36 ), HETTATE

(p. 12), alco (p. 62 ). 863 ‡§ò‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§ø ‡§≤‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ

‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç ‡•§‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ (‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø. p. 668 ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•à‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ

POOHA

FOUNDED I

1917 A

A

  1. Sangraha or Smrtisangraha

539

1

According to the Samgraha,867 ownership does not consist in being able to dispose of a thing at one’s sweet will, since it is the sƒÅstra that prescribes the proper disposal or application of all things. The Samgraba$68 laid down that the special share given to the eldest son, the practice of niyoga and the offering of a cow are all forbidden in the present age. DhƒÅre svara also held the same view about the eldest son’s rights and the Mit. also approves of it and quotes anonymously the same verse (on Yaj. II. 117 ). The Sa·πÅgraha in two verses appa rently following Manu 9. 182-183, lays down that, if of several full brothers one has a son, all thereby have issue and that, if one out of the several wives of a person has a son, all the co-wives may be regarded as putruvati. The Sm·ªôti candrikƒÅ says that Devasvami explained this dictum of the Samgrahak√§ra (Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ, Vy. p. 289). The Samgraha says that the widow of a separated coparcener dying childless would inberit his whole estate if she submitted to Niyoga at the behests of her elders.968 This was also the opinion of Dhare svara and was refuted according to the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ by Visva. r≈´pa. The Mit. also criticizes this view. He names Manu in con nection with the succession of a person dying without leaving any one out of the twelve kinds of sons.670 He has in view Manu 9. 185. According to the SangrahakƒÅra the order of succession to a sonless man is :– widow, the daughter who is a putrikƒÅ, mother, paternal grandmother, father, full brothers, half-brothers, the line of the father (pitssantati ), the grandfather’s line, the great-grand-father’s line, other sapindas, sakulyas, the preceptor, the pupil, a fellow-student,

687 ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ

‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• 688 ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø

ad√† il 20 ( 34. p. 268 ) ; 901. AT. III. p. 492. 889 ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡••

  1. AI. 111. p. 633. ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§

wrazo ( 49. p. 294 ). 870 BRAICA FETAH yang uha PTAHL I Warat naraaz

f aqat vyrazo ( 04. p. 290 ).

540

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

a learned BrƒÅhma·πáa. The Mit. notes that relying on Mann (9.217) DhƒÅre≈õvara placed the paternal grandmother after the mother and before the father (tbus agreeing with the Samgraha). The Sangraha says that homicide and other offences when committed with force are called s≈´hasa. 871

It will be seen from the above that the views of the Sam grahakƒÅra closely agreed with those of DhƒÅre≈õvara in many respects and were not approved of by the Mit. and other later writers. In vyuvahƒÅra the Samgraha certainly marks a far more advanced stage than YƒÅj√±avalkyal and NƒÅrada, whose works do not contain the controversial questions about ownership, partition etc. As Dh√•re≈õvara agrees very closely with the Smrtisamgraha it may be argued that they were not separated by a long interval of time. It has to be also noted that Visvar≈´pa and Medhitithi do not refer to the Samgraba. It is not unlikely that the Sangraha was in vogue in the territory ruled over by Bhoja of Dhir≈´ und was therefore followed by Bhoja Dh√§re≈õvaris. Taking all things into con sideration the Sangraha was probably compiled between the 8th and 10th centuries of the Christian era. The Smrti candrikƒÅ no doubt says in one place that the SamgrahakƒÅra follows the views of Dh√ºre≈õvara.978 But this statement should not be einphasized and interpreted too literally. All that it means is that both held the same opinion. There is no intention to state that Dh√•re≈õvari preceded the Samyraha kƒÅra. Chronology was never the strong point of Indian commentators, particularly when the writers whose opinions were referred to flourished several centuries earlier. We know that Bharuci and Dh√ºre≈õvara preceded the MitƒÅksarƒÅ which names both; but the SarasvativilƒÉsa in several places (e. g. pp. 347, 361, 383 ) says that Bharuci cannot tolerate the view of Vij√±ƒÅne≈õvara and also says that DhƒÅre≈õvara and Devas vƒÅmi follow the view of Vij√±ƒÅnayogin (1) 395 ).

The Smrticanlrika quotes several verses from the Sam graha on topics of ≈õr≈´ddha in which Gautama, KƒÅtyƒÅyana,

  1. Saivarta

541

ParƒÅ≈õara, Manu, YƒÅj≈àavalkya, Yama and Saunaka are cited by naine.673

The Samgraha or Sm·ªôtisamgraha inust have contained a very large number of verses, since the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ alone quotes several hundred verses, from it on ‘ƒÅhnika, VyavahƒÅra and SrƒÅddha’. The VyavahƒÅra-nir∆∞aya of Varadaraja states ion p. 324 ) that the view of SangrahakƒÅra is relied upon by DhƒÅre≈õvarabhatta !

  1. Samvarta Sa·πÅvarta occurs as a SmrtikƒÅra in the list of YƒÅj√±a valkya. He is cited on all topics of dharma by Visvar≈´pa, MedhƒÅtithi, the Mit., Haradatta, Aparirka, the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ and a host of other writers. Visvar≈´pa quotes either wholly or in part about twenty verses of Samvarta on evening sandhyƒÅ vandana, on the duties of a yuti and on the prƒÅya≈õcittas for theft, adultery of various kinds, deadly sius. MedhƒÅtithi quotes verses of Surivarta on Manu V. 88 and XI. 116. The Mit. quotes him on prayascitta and a≈õauca ( YƒÅj. III. 6. 17 19 etc. ). Apararka had a large work before him and quotes about 200 verses almost all on ƒ´cƒ´ra and priyuscitta.

A few of the views of Samvartu on topics of vyavahƒÅra may be noted here. According to him oral testimony when in opposition to writing was to be discarded. 674 This is in striking agreement with section 92 of the Indian Evidence Act. He says that if houses and fields are being enjoyed ( by one person us against another ) when the king is there (i. e. when the central government is strong and there is no

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

anarchy ), then it is possession that counts and not mere writing (i. e. possession will be protected and not mere paper title without possession ).075 He lays down that no interest was to be allowed if not stipulated for in certain cases, viz., on stridhana ( when used by the husband ), on interest, on deposit ( as long as it is not lost or deteriorated ) and in suretyship.s78_He enumerates ten wrongs ( aparƒÅdhas ) of which the king was to take cognisance suo motu without any private person’s complaint, viz., restraint of the defendant ( before judgment ), obstruction of the public road, women conceiving in adultery, becoming rich without any ostensible means, destruction of a meeting hall and of trees and crops, kidnapping of maidens, sinning BrƒÅhma·πáas, champerty and maintenance, destruction of the roads where tolls are to be paid, the danger of robbers, rape, injury to cows and BrƒÅh manas.077 He prescribed that disputes were not to be investi gated on the full moon and new moon day, and on the 14th and 8th tithis. ( Vide Par. M. Vol. II. p. 23 ).

In Jivananda’s collection ( part I, pp. 584-603 ) and in the Anandasrama collection (pp. 411-424) there is a smrti of Samvarta in 227 and 230 verses respectively. It purports to have been declared to VƒÅmadeva and other sages by Sa·πÅvarta. Its main contents are:– that is the religious country where the black deer roam about, rules of conduct for a Brahma cƒÉrin, prƒÅyascittag for various lapses on the part of a student,

‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•• ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø (‡•ß) ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø…‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•• ‡§∏‡§≠‡§æ‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ… ‡•• ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§ï‡§∞‡§∂‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§ó‡•ã‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§∂‡•à‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡§§‡§ø‡§ö (‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ. p. 28), ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ. ‡§Æ‡§æ.   1. Sanivarta

543

duties of householder, eulogy of liberality, duties of forest hermit and sampy√§sin, prayascittas for various sins and actions, Sa·πÅvarta is sometimes cited as an authority ( verses 38,123 ). He recommends the marriages of girls at the age of eight ( verse 67 ) and condemns marriage with a maternal uncle’s daughter ( verse 157 ).

In a few M83. (e. g. I. O. cat. No. 1367 ) the Sam varta smrti comprised is different from the printed Sa·πÅvarta.

The printed sin»ôti appears to be an epitome of a portion of the original surti of Sa·πÅvartu. Many of the verses in the printed texts are found in AparƒÅrka. For example, AparƒÅrka p. 14=Sasvarta verse 6; Apar√°rka p. 693 = Samvarta verses 107-108; AparƒÅrka p. 1053 = Samvarta verses 111-113; AparƒÉrka p. 1094 ( eight verses out of which five ) =Sa·πÅvarta verses 130-34. The pƒÅda of Sa·πÅvarta which Visvar≈´pa quotes (ardhƒÅstamitabhƒÅskarƒÅm) on YƒÅj. I. 25 occurs in verse 6 of the printed text. This shows that the printed sm·ªôti preserves very ancient material, the authenticity of which is vouched for by so early a writer as Visvar≈´pa.

ADU

The Mit. quotes a Bphat-Sa·πÅvarta (on YƒÅj. III. 265 288 ).

A Svalpa-Sarvarta is quoted in HarinƒÅtha’s SmrtisƒÅra.

  1. Harƒ´ta The verse quotations from HƒÅrƒ´ta on topics of vyavahƒÅra deserve some treatment. He defines vyavahƒÅra as that where by the recovery of one’s own wealth and the avoidance of (doing ) the duties peculiar to another (caste or class ) are effected in due course of law.878 He further says that that judicial proceeding is proper which is based on the dictates of dharma≈õƒÅstra and arthasƒÅstra, which is in conformity with the usages of respectable people and which is free from fraud.978 HƒÅrita calls upon the king to know the sƒÅstras, the

078 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏.

gazd il fafaa.. 679 ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§É ‡•§ ‡§õ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∏

fi ll tafaqa.

FOUN

19:

544

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

duties of the varnas and of the lowest castes.880 He, like NƒÅrada, said that vynvahƒÅru had four aspects, each succeeding one prevailing against the preceding one,ssl viz., dharma, vyavahƒÅra, caritra, n·∫°pƒÅj√≠a. He attached the greatest im portance to writing and said that a transaction cousigned to writing is effective even after great lapse of time and that he who bas a writing in his hands is entitled to possession (pro bably in cases of mortgages and pledges ).882 He lays down very elaborate rules about the requisites and defects of plaints, about summoning the defendant, about the contents, faults and kinds of the defendant’s reply, and about the bur den of proof.683 He protects long possession of property even if it originated without title provided it had lasted for three generations.084 He says that the title is the decisive factor as to various kinds of possession, viz., when possession is for cibly taken by soldiers and freebooters, when a thing is stolen or kept concealed, when it was delivered through affection and friendship or when it was lent on hire, or when it was handed over for wearing or safe custody or was borrowed through friendship.085 To illustrate the relation of title and possession he uses a very apt figure, viz. just as a branch cannot be seen expanding in the sky unless it is supported by the roots, so title is the root and possession is its offshoot.

882

II. 6 and 7. 884 ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å

‡§™‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶; ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ. ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ. on ‡§Ø‡§æ. II. 27. ‡§≠‡§ü‡§ö‡§æ‡§ü‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§π‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ü‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡•§‡•§ ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤ ‡§≠‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡•§‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶,

985

POONA

  1. Commentaries and Nibandhas ( digests )

545

According to him sureties are of five kinds,686 abhaya (for keeping the peace), pratyaya ( for confidence ), dƒÅna ( return of money or carrying out one’s obligations ), upast bƒÉna ( return of money lent on pledge ) and dar≈õana ( for appearance ). He prescribed an absolute tutelage for women as regards the giving a way of the husband’s wealth and allow. ed only maintenance to a young window of improper conduct.887 But HƒÅrƒ´ta was humane in his treatment of even erring wives. He does not allow a husband to cast adrift an adulterous wife and prescribes that she should be given food to keep body and soul together and bare clothes.688

It appears from the above that Harita the jurist must have flourished nearly at the same time as Brhasrati and KƒÅtyƒÅyana, i. e. between 400 and 700 A. D.

  1. Commentaries and Nibandhas ( digests )

The literature on Dharma≈õƒÅstra falls into three well marked but somewhat over-lapping periods. The first period is that of the ancient dharmas≈´tras and of the Manusmrti. It is a period dating from at least the 6th century B. C. to the beginnings of the Christian era. Next comes the period when most of the versified smrtis were composed and it ranges from the first centuries of the Christian era to about 800 A. D. The third period is that of the commentators and the writers of digests. This covers over a thousand years from about the 7th century to 1800 A. D. The first part of this last period was the golden era of famous commentators. Commentaries on smrti works continued to be written almost to the end of this period, e. g. Nandapandita wrote the commentary called Vaijayanti on the Visnudharmas≈´tra in the 17th century. But the general tendency from the 12th century onwards was

G

.

688 ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§• ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•á ‡•§ ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§É ‡••

Palao. 887 ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä

‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ ; ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•å‡§µ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§∂‡§æ ‡•§

314: TUTTE g Trai Titazi aar li facto on 9. II. 135. 688 ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ö‡•á‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

to write works not professing to be commentaries on a parti cular sm·ªôti, but works that were in the nature of digests containing a synthesis of all the dicta of smrti writers on topics of dharma. Examples of this class of works are the Kalpataru, the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ, the CaturvargacintƒÅma≈Üi, the RatnƒÅkaras of Cande≈õvara. Even when in the earlier part of this period writers professed to compose only commentaries on particular works, they adopted the style of digests trying to introduce order out of a chaotic mass of Smrti dicta and explaining away apparent contradictions. For example, Visvar≈´pa’s commentary (in the ƒÅcƒÅra and prƒÅya≈õcitta sec tions ), the MitƒÅksarƒÅ and AparƒÅrka’s work, though professing to be commentaries on YƒÅj≈°avalkya, are really in the nature of digests. In fact there is no hard and fast line of demarca tion between a tikƒÅ and a nibandha ( digest). Vij√±ƒÅnesvara is described by the Dvaitanirnaya of Sankara bhatta as the most eminent of all writers of ribandha8.. Therefore, though it is usual to speak of the third period as one of commenta tors and nibandhakƒÅras, there is no necessity in this work to observe any sharp line of distinction between the two. In the following pages a few prominent and typical commentators and nibandhakƒÅras who have written on all or most of the branches of dharma≈õƒÅstra and whose works have attained classical rank will be dealt with in chronological order as far as that can be done with any accuracy.

  1. AsahƒÅya

Dr. Jolly in his edition of the NƒÅradasmrti (B. I. series ) bas incorporated a portion of the bhƒÅsya of AsahƒÅya as re vised by KalyƒÅnabhatta. Even this revised version comes up to only verse 21 of the fifth title abhyupetya-asu≈õr≈´≈üƒÅ. The exact relation of KalyƒÅnabhatta’s labours to the original bhƒÅsya cannot be accurately gauged from the opening888 words ' finding that the N√°radath√§sya composed by AsahƒÅya was spoilt (bhrasta ) by bad scribes, KalyƒÅ·πáa composes this after revising the ancient one’. The colophon at the end of the first chapter of the VyavahƒÅramƒÅt√Ωk√§ says that KalyƒÅnabhatta

  1. AsahƒÅya

547

revised the bhƒÅsya of AsahƒÅya at the encouragement of Ke≈õava bhatta.890 KalyƒÅna bhatta seems to have takeu great liberties with the text of the original bhƒÅsya. On p. 9 verse 15.( rƒÅjƒÅ satpurusa·∏• sabhyah sƒÅstram gana kalekhakau ), the comment on sastra is ¬∑ Manu-Narada - Visvar≈´pƒÅtmakam'. If Visvar≈´pa named here be identical with the Visvar≈´pa who commented on YƒÅj. (as is alunost certain ), this passage could not have occurred in AsahƒÅya’s bhƒÅsya. Vi≈°var≈´pa, in commenting on YƒÅj. III. 263-64, mevtions AsahƒÅya by name and cites his explanation of a s√∫tra of Gautama (22. 13). The name Kalyanabhatta frequently occurs in the printed commentary itself (p. 81, 86, 89 ).801

In the I. 0. ms, there is a salutation to ≈õiva and Ganesa at the beginning. There is a ns. of the N√°radiyabhƒÅsya as printed by Dr. Jolly in the Govt. Mss. Library at the B. O. R. Institute, Poona, ( No. 72 of 1874-75). It does not contain the first folio and curiously enough it ends just where the printed text stops. Dr. Jolly omits a few lengthy passages occurring in the ms. and generally indicates such omissions by dots. In a few cases Dr. Jolly omits only a word or two for no apparent reason, e. g. on p. 8 ( folio 7b of No. 27 of 1874-75 ) he omits the word ‘paramasamrudhyƒÅ’ after

vyavahƒÅrah' and before ‘catur≈ÜƒÅm-api var·πáƒÅnƒÅm’.

The Kalpataru (on Moksa pp. 48-49 ) quotes Gautama Dh. S. III. 10-24 from ‘Anicayo bhiksuh’ to ¬∑ AnƒÅrambhi' and cites the explanations of Bhartryaj√±a, AsahƒÅya and Maskarin on some words occurring in them. Maskarin is a well-known commentator on Gautama ( the com. is printed ). It seems that Bhatryaj√±a and AsahƒÅya also composed com mentaries ; vide ABORI Vol. 18 p. 205 where Prof. Raghavan draws attention to Asahaya’s commentary on Sankba-Likhita mentioned by Anandagiri. On p. 544 the VivƒÅdaratnƒÅkara quotes Manu IX. 165 ( Aurasuksetrajau ) and AsahƒÅcƒÅrya’s explanation thereon.

690 ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§-‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§§-‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É

VSTITUT

uion

548

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

The HƒÅralatƒÅ of Aniruddha who was the guru of king BallƒÅlasena of Bengal, the author of AdbhutasƒÅgara ( about 1168 A. D.), tells us that AsahƒÅya composed a bhƒÅsya on the Gautamadharmasutra.se Visvarupa also cites, as said above, AsahƒÅya‚Äôs explanation of a s≈´tra of Gautama.

It appears that AsahƒÅya probably wrote a commentary on the Manusmrti also. A passage of the SarasvativilƒÅsadis says that partition of dharma was approved of by smrtikƒÅras like Manu, YƒÅj≈°avalkya, by their commentators, viz. AsahƒÅya, MedhƒÅtithi, Vij√±ƒÅnesvara and AparƒÅrka and by writers of nibandh¬´18, viz. the author of the Candrik≈´ and others. Here the order in which the commentators are named requires that AsahƒÅya like Medhitithi was known to be a commentator of Manu. This conclusion is to some extent corroborated by the fact that the VivƒÅdaratnƒÅkaragot quotes with reference to

‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ( ‡§ó‡•å. ‡§ß. ‡§∏‡•Ç. 14. 44 ) ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§® ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§'; ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§≤‡§§‡§æ p. 97 ‚Äò‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•á ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡•§’ ( ‡§ó‡•å. ‡§ß. ‡§∏‡•Ç. 14. 12 )‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ

‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ … ‡§á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§' 693 ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•Ñ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§æ

‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏ paru. 83 and p. 348 ( Mysore ed.). ___ The ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏ ofton refers to a writer called ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞. He is likely to be ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø. Vide ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏ p. 457 ' ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ( ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•å) ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§É ‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§∂‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡•§… ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡•§'; ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß

‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£' p. 468. 694_The verse of ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å is ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§. The words

of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø are ‘‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ú‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§’ ‡§µ‡§ø. ‡§∞. p. 583.

FOUNDE M 1917

  1. AsahƒÅya

549

Manu 9. 182 the words of AsahƒÅya thereon. On Manu 8. 156 MedhƒÅtithi quotes the opinion of AsahƒÅya.695 Manu VIII. 155 in in Mandlik’s edition.

The foregoing establishes that AsahƒÅya composed bhƒÅsyas on the Gautamadharmas≈´tra, on the Manusmrti and on NƒÅrada. When the SmrticandrikƒÅ898 refers to a bhƒÅsya of NƒÅrada it is most probably referring to Asahaya. In the Mit. (on YƒÅj. II. 124 ) the opinion of AsahƒÅya and MedhƒÉtithi on the right of an unmarried sister to receive one-fourth as pro vision for her marriuge from her brothers is preferred to that of BhƒÅruci.097 This seems to be rather a reference to AsahƒÅya’s commentary on Manu (9. 118 ) which contains a rule similar to YƒÅj. (II. 12+ ), while NƒÅrada contains no such rule about a fourth share. It is a strange irony of fate that the very name of Asahiya who is profusely quoted by the Sarasvatƒ´vilƒÅsa in the first half of the sixteenth century was forgotten by later writers, so much so that the BƒÅlambhatti understands the word Asahaya ( in note 515 above ) as an attribute of MedhƒÅ tithi in the sense of peerless'.

As Visvar≈´pa and Medh√§tithi both name AsahƒÅya, his lowest limit is about 750 A. D. How much earlier he flourish ed it is difficult to say. He can hardly be earlier than the 6th century. In the com. on NƒÅrada (p. 48 ) there is a story from Pataliputra about the repayment of a debt by sons, grandsons and great-grandsons. It has been argued ( Calcutta Law Journal, vol. 17 p. 59 ) that, as Pataliputra was a desert ed city in the middle of the 7th century and as the reference shows that P≈´taliputra was a living and flourishing city, AsabƒÅya must have lived long before the 7th century. But as the very authenticity of the text of the bhƒÅsya is doubtful owing to the drastic ‘revision’ of KalyƒÅnabhatta, such a con clusion is extremely hazardous. In the ms. of the bbƒÅsya

895 ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§ø

ET: I on the verse 3atiforcat ea. 896 Fazo ( 34. p. 36 ) on matalafo says ‘ga naima TEOTTI’

‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§…‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂. ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡•ã ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§Æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§ß

‡§Æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§® ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ 897 3HATAET√Äfafenatat eqreqraha 7 Hirth: i foran

550

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

other places such as Vatapadraka ( probably modern Baroda ), AvƒÅvadu and SamvƒÅduka are mentioned. There is nothing to show that the author was either a native of or had a first hand knowledge of Pataliputra. He might have been relying on traditions when he gave the story. Dr. Jolly not being aware of the express mention of AsahƒÅya by MedhƒÉtithi argued that he flourished earlier than MedhƒÅtithi ( Tagore Law Lectures p. 5; S. B. E. vol. 25 p. VII) on the ground that the Mit. and the SarasvativilƒÅsa always place AsahƒÅya before MedhƒÉtithi whenever authorities on vyavahƒÅra are enumerat ed. Dr. Jolly’s conclusion is right as shown above, but his reasoning is faulty. There is hardly anything of chronology in the order in which authors are named, since we find that the Sarasvativil√°sa 688 names Vij√±ƒÅne≈õvara even before AsahƒÅya though the former flourished centuries after the latter.

Some of the views attributed to AsahƒÅya may be quoted here. The definition of d≈´ya ( heritage ) given by the Mit. was identical with AsahƒÅya’s.689 AsahƒÅya explained the dic tum of U≈õanas that fields were impartible by taking it to refer to the son of a brƒÅhmana from a ksatriya wife, who does not participate in land gifted to a BrƒÅhmana.700 The Mit. on Yaj. II. 119 takes the same view. AsahƒÅya held that as regards succession to the sullca of a woman even step-brothers should be given something, though the major portion would go to the full brothers.701 According to AsahƒÅya, the wealth of a child less brƒÅhmana went to the teacher, then to the teacher’s son, then to the teacher’s widow, the pupil, pupil’s son, pupil’s widow (oue after another) and then to the fellow-student.“02

  1. Betraya ma

561

The VivƒÅdaratnƒÅkara 03 (p. 578 ) quotes the PrakƒÅ≈õa as refer ring to the views of AsahƒÅya and MedhƒÅtithi on Manu IX. 198 that the special rule of Manu applies to all the stridhana belonging to a Ksatriya woman who has a brƒÅhmani co-wife. The VivƒÅdaratnƒÅkara704 quotes a verse of NƒÅrada about mƒÅsa and a verse of the blƒÅsyakƒÅra thereon. It probably refers to AsahƒÅya’s bhƒÅsya.

| √°o. Bharteyajƒ©a This seems to have been a very ancient commentator. Medhatithiros in his bhƒÅsya on Manu 8. 3 says ‘other explana tions have been well brought out by Bhartƒºyaj√±a and they should be understood from his work’. TrikƒÅnda-mandana (who flourished before 1100 A. D.) in his ƒÄpastambas≈´tra dhvanitƒÅrtha-kƒÅriki708 (I. 41) refers to the views of Bhartr yaj√±a that one who had committed to memory the text of the Veda had the privilege ( the adhikƒÅra ) of consecrating the sacred fires, though he may be innocent of the meaning of the Vedic texts. From Ananta’s bh√¢sya it appears that Bhartryaj√±a composed a bhƒÅsya on the KƒÄtyƒÅyana≈õrautas≈´tra which had been lost (autsanna) in the former’s day. From Gad≈´dhara’s comments on the Paraskaragrhyas≈´tra it appears that Bhartryaj√±a commented on P√§raskara,707 The Grhastha ratnƒÅkara of Cande≈õvara quotes Bhartsyaj√±a‚Äôs explanation of

703 ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø (‡§•‡•Ä ‡§á‡§§‡§ø?)

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ 704 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§®-‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∑‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§™‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§§‡•ã

‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∑‡§ï‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§

‡§™‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡•• ‡§µ‡§ø. ‡§∞. p. 234. 705 ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§•‡§æ

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡•§ 708 ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø

‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§® ( B. I. series ). 707 on ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø I. 1. 2 ‘‡§è‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ü‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ

‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É’; on ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞ I. 2. 1, the ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø of ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û on the word ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á is quoted ; on the ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‚Äò‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ &0. (‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞ II. 5. 28 ) ‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞ says ‘‡§á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á’.

552

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

the word sa mvibhƒÅga occurring in Gautamadharmas≈´tra (10. 39 svƒÅmi riktha….samvibhƒÅga-parigrahƒÅdhigamesu ).708 The NityƒÅcƒÅrapradƒ´pa ( B. I. series ) after quoting Gautamadharma s≈´tra (11. 29 varnƒÅ≈°ramƒÅh svadharmanisthƒÅh &c. ) cites the comment of Bhartryaj√±a700 on the word tac-chesenu occurring in that s≈´tra. Therefore it appears probable that Bhartr. yaj√±a like AsahƒÅya was an ancient commentator of the Gautamadharmas≈´tra. The GrhastharatnƒÅkara, after quoting from Vasistha (17. 1 ) and Visnu the well-known verse of the Aitareya-brƒÅhmana (mnam-asmin sam-nayati) cites the ex planation of Bhartryaj≈æia as to the word ‚ÄújƒÅtasya' occurring therein. 710

The Kalpataru (on BrahmacƒÅrio p. 15 ) quotes the expla nation of the words ‘tata·∏• se»ôena’ and also on p. 144 quotes the explanation of Manu V. 143 (ucchistena tu &c. ) given by Visvarƒ´pa and Bhartsyaj√±a. Kalpao (SuddhikƒÅnda p. 101 ) quotes Gaut. XIV. 35-40 and Bhartryaj√±a’s explanation of ‘ante tvantyƒÅnƒÅnn’ as ‘navamƒÅ≈õauc√¢nte’. Kalpataru (G»ôhastha kƒÅnda p. 5) cites the explanation of Vas. Dh. S. VIII. 1 (Grhasthu…vindeta ) by Bhartryaj√±a. Similarly, Kalpao (Gr. p. 259) quotes Gaut. X. 39 (SvƒÅmƒ´ riktha-kraya”) and cites the explanation of samvibhƒÅya' as ‘mitradƒÅyu’ by Bhartryaj√±a. Kalpao (NiyatakƒÅla p. 256 ) cites YƒÅj. I. 166 (s√ºdre≈°u dƒÅsa gopƒÅlao) and its explanation by Bhartryaj√±a as ‘yasya gƒÅ·∏• pƒÅlayati tasyaiva bhojyƒÅnnah’. Kalpao on Niyata p. 203 quotes Gaut. Dho. S. V. 41 and the explanation of the word ‘adhivƒôksas√ºrya’ by both Maskarin and Bhartryaj√±a as meaning’sƒÅyamkƒÅla' (evening). Vide an interesting paper by Prof. Baladera Upadhyaya in I. H. Q. vol. XII p. 494-503, where he advances some grounds for holding that Bhartr. yaj√±a commented on the Paraskaragrhya and preceded even Karka. The VyavahƒÅranirnaya of VaradarƒÅja (on p. 135) cites the view of DhƒÅre≈õvara, AsahƒÅya and Srikara about the effect of not asserting one’s right against an interloper for a long time and of AsahƒÅya on pp. 230, 455 also.

Since Bhartryaj√±a is quoted by MedhƒÉtithi who also men tions AsahƒÅya but not Vi≈õvar≈´pa, it follows that Bhartryajia must have flourished before 800 A. 1), and was probably & contemporary of or slightly later than AsahƒÅya.

  1. Vi≈õvarupa The commentary of Vi≈õvar≈´pia called BƒÅlakrƒ´dƒÅ on the YƒÅjsavalkya-smrti has been recently published in two parts by M. M. T. Ganapati SƒÅstri in the Trivandrum Sanskrit Series. The Mit. states in the introductory verses that the dicta of Yij. were expanded by the voluminous or ample (vikata ) explanations of Visvar√ºsra. In commenting on YƒÅj. 1. 81 the Mit. tells us that Visvar≈´jia looked upon the words of YƒÅj. I. 79 ( tasmin yugmƒÅsu sa·πÅviset ) as a niyama. In Visvar≈´pa’s commentary on YƒÅj. I. 80 (evam gacchan &c. ) we do find that the verse of YƒÅj. and similar passages of Manu (3. 45 ), Vasistha and Gautama ( 5. 1 ) are understood to contain a niyam and not a prescinkhyu.?!! On YƒÅj. III. 24 the Mit, inforins us that Visvar≈´pa, Medhatithi and DhƒÅre svara looked upon certain texts of Rsyasriiga on ƒÅ≈õciucu as in conflict with well-known sinitis and discarded them. Mr. S. Sitaram S√∫stri published (in 1900 at Madras ) the text and translation of Vi≈õvar≈´pia’s comment ou inheritance and Mr. Setlur also published the wavah√ºrco section. In the following pages the Trivandrum edition is relied on.

The printed com. of Visvar≈´pa on the vyavaharu section is extreinely meagre and scarcely merits the epithet vikata applied to it by the Mit. But the commentary of Vi≈õvar≈´pa on the ƒÅcƒÅra and grƒ´yascitta sections is truly voluminous and coinpares favourably with the Mit. The style of Visvar√ºpa is simple and forcible and resembles that of the great SankarƒÅ. cƒÅrya. He quotes profusely from Vedic works, mentions the Carakas and VƒÅjasaneyins (on Yaj 1. 32 ), the Kathaka (on Yaj. III. 237 and 243 ) and very often supports his position by quotatious from the Rgveda (e.g. on Y√¢j. 11. 121 and 206 ), the BrƒÅhmanas (e. g. the Sata patha on YƒÅj. 1. 53 and III. 257 ) and from the Upanisads (e. g. on YƒÅj. 11. 117, the well-known

Chandogya passage about the ordeal for theft and on YƒÅj. I. 50 Chandogya II. 23. 10 about the three branches of dharma). He speaks of the pada-rƒÅtha and the kramapƒÅtha as due to human agency (on YƒÅj. III. 242). He frequently quotes the Grhya s≈´trus of PƒÅraskara and less frequently those of BhƒÅradvƒÅja and AsvalƒÅyana. lle cites a host of smrtikƒÅras.712 Most of the quotations attributed to Svayambh≈´ are found in the extant Manusmrti, but this is not the case with the quotations ascribed to Bhrgu (vide pp. 309, 310 above). Most of the quota tions from Brhaspati (even on such topics as repayment of debts, sureties, the rights of s≈´drƒÅputra ) are in prose, only a few being in verse ( e. g. & verse about ordeals on YƒÅj. II. 117, a verse about the method of partition on YƒÅj. II. 153 ). Ou YƒÅj. I. 307 Vi≈õvar≈´pa quotes a long prose passage from Brbaspati in which the qualities required in a SenƒÅpati, PratihƒÅra, Hastyadhyaksti, AsvƒÅdhyalist, D≈´ta, Mantrin and Uparika are set out at length. It appears, therefore, that Visvar≈´pa either knew a work of Brhaspati in prose on artha≈õƒÅstra in which occurred a few verses or he had before him a prose work of B·ªãhaspati and a versified smrti of B·ªãhaspati, both of which he regarded as the compositions of the same author. He quotes a verse (on YƒÅj. I. 328 ) from VisƒÅ lƒÅksa, a well-known writer on politics quoted even by Kautilya. He refers to the artha≈õƒÅstra of U≈õanas along with that of B»ôhaspati. Kautilya is nowhere quoted by name. The learned editor of Visvar≈´pa thinks (Intro. p. V) that Vi√üve r√∫pa took B·ªãhaspati and Vi≈õƒÅlƒÅk·π£a as ƒÅrsa writers long anterior to YƒÅj. and therefore used their dictu to elucidate and support YƒÅj., while he omits Kautilya because he thought Kautilya to be posterior to YƒÅj. This argument contains several fallacies. In the first place it is wrong because Visva r≈´pa quotes verses from NƒÅrada and K√§tyƒÅyana to supple ment YƒÅj. There is nothing to show that Visvar≈´pa regarded NƒÅrada and KƒÅtyƒÅyana also as anterior to YƒÅj. and we have

  1. Visvar≈´pa

655

seen above that they are several centuries later than the smrti of YƒÅj. Moreover Kautilya himself looked upon both Bphaspati and Vi≈õƒÅlƒÅksa as high authorities and so Visvar≈´pa might have quoted them rather than Kautilya. Even taking the latest date assigned to Kautilya (about 3rd century A.D.) he flourished several centuries before Visvar≈´pa. It is im possible to believe that Visvar√ºpa was in possession of the exact chronological relation of YƒÅj. and Kautilya. Many scholars, besides, place Kautilya’s work centuries before YƒÅj. It appears, however, that Vi≈õvar≈´pa had the work of Kautilya before him. On YƒÅj. I. 307 he speaks of ministers tested by the four allurements (upachii) of dharma, artha, k≈´ma and bhaya. This is an echo of Kautilya ( I. 10). On YƒÅj I. 343 Vi≈õ. refers to the view of some that a march should be made when neighbouring chiefs are overwhelmed in calamities.713 This is the view of Kautilya almost in the same words. On YƒÅj. I. 341 Vis. speaks of the inanifold aspects of the work of a minister, some words of his comment being almost identical with Kautilya’s.

Some of the verses on pp. 25-27, for example, the first verse ( govadham &c.) relers to Yaj. III. 234 ( where (govadha' is mentioned as the first among UpapƒÅtikas (51 in number ). vedam-eva tvad:starthe…pramƒÅnam paramam dharme Srutir' embodies a part of Manu III. 13. The Karik≈´ at the top of p. 27 quotes some words of Manu II. 10.

he applies the term ny≈±ya to MimƒÅ·πÅs√¢. He takes ‘nyƒÅya mimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ’ in Yƒ´j. I. 3 as one vidyƒÅ, while he notes that others explain nyayu as the system of logic propounded by Aksa pƒÅda.   1. Visvar√ºpa

‘Though Vi≈°var≈´pa was a past master in P≈´rvamƒ´mƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ lore, his philosophical views seem to have been identical with those of the great Sajikara. According to him moksu results from correct knowledge alone and the whole samsƒÅra is due to avidyu il? He quotes anonymously one of GaudlapƒÅda’s kƒÅrikƒÅsiis (III. 5 ) on YƒÅj. III, 134.

He speaks on YƒÅj. III. 103 of Narada who knew the Veda of music ( gitivedavid ), of purƒÅna ( on III. 175 ), and quotes verses (on Y√±j. III. 85 ) from an abhidh≈´nuko≈°u ( lexicon ) and from a N√§maratnamila (on III. 266). He speaks of the sloka of BhiksƒÅtana (on III. 60.). He is in this probably referring to the Bhikrƒ´tanakivya,719 which is mentioned by the Sahityavarpani. Amony commentators he mentions Asahaya’s bh√¢sya on Gautama by name ( on YƒÅj. III. 263 ). On YƒÅj. III. 256 he explains Mleccha as pulindas and

TƒÅjikus ( i. e. Arabs ).

It has been shown above ( $34 pp. 423-425 ) how Visva r≈´pa’s text of Y√§j. varied in some respects from that of the Mit.; how he frequently refers to the views of commentators of YƒÅj. earlier than himself (in the words ‘apare,‘‘anye’), how he proposes several explanations of the same words in several cases.

Dr. Jolly (Journal of Iulian History, 1924, pp. 7-8) says that the citations of Vis in the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ about his having refuted the views of Dhire≈õvara cannot be traced in the printed Balakrida, as also the reference to Vis, in the Mit.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

on Yaj. I. 81 and II. 135. It has been shown above ( note 529) that the printed Vis on Yaj. I. 80 does contain the view attributed to it by the Mit. As regards the Mit. un YƒÅj. II. 135 it has to be noted that the Mit. - does not mention Vis. by name there, but only speaks of bhagavƒÅn ƒÅcƒÅrya, ‘720 which words are interpreted by the Subodhinƒ´ and the B≈´lambhatti as referring to Visvar≈´pa. It is true that the printed Vi≈õ. does not contain in so many words the explana tion attributed by the Mit. to ‘bhagavƒÅn ƒÅcƒÅrya.’ But it is worth considering that in the printed Vis. the two quotations from Manu and Sankha do occur and are put in the mouth of an objector and are explained away in a way somewhat similar to that put forth in the Mit.721 As regards the passages of the SmrticandrikƒÅ, the matter requires careful examination. The Smrticandrika, (II. p. 294 Gharpure’s ed.) says that according to the SamgrahakƒÅra a widow was allowed to succeed to her souless husband’s wealth if she submitted to niyoga, that the same was the view of Dh√§re≈õvara and that Vi≈õvar≈´pa refuted the view of DhƒÅre≈õvara. In no place does the printed Vis. name Dharesvara. The words of the Smrti candrika are uot to be taken literally. It will be shown below that the author, Devanmabhatta, flourished about 1200 A. D. while DhƒÅre≈õvara flourished between 1000-1050 A. D. Devanna had no correct idea of their relative chronological position. It has been shown above (p. 249 ) how though

.

720 The words of the Mit. are : ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§∞

‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ ( ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å 9. 185 ) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç , ‡§§‡§•‡§æ-‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•å ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ö‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§≤‡§≠‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§ß‡§®‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§â‡§§ ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‚Ä¢ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø…‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ß‡§®‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡•á‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡§£‡•á ‡§ò‡§ü‡§§‡•á ‡§á‡§§‡§ø

‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡•§ 721 ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‘‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á … ‡§µ‡§æ’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§

‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‘‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø … ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§á‡§§‡§ø’ ‡•§ ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§¶‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡•ã‡§π‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™.

  1. Vi≈°var≈´pa

569

AsahƒÅya is named by the Mit., the SarasvativilƒÅsa very often says that AsahƒÅya does not like ( or tolerate ) the views of Vijnanesvara. Similarly, the same work ( para 392 ) says that DhƒÅre≈õvara and DevasvƒÅmiu do not tolerate the view of Vij√±ƒÅnesvara, but Dhire≈õvara is one of the predecessors of Vij. actually named by him. So all that the Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ means is that DhƒÅre≈õvara and Visvar≈´pa differed in their views on the particular points mentioned by it. The word patni is taken by Vi≈õ. to mean a widow who is pregnant at the time of her husband’s death and quotes the sutras of Vasistha and Gautama in support of his view as j√±ƒÅpokas. So this view entirely differs from the view of Dh√§re≈õvara that the widow of a sonless person succeeds if she submits to niyoga. The Sm·ªôticandrikƒÅ (II. p. 300 ) says that the SamgrahakƒÅra placed the father’s mother immediately after the mother and before the father, that the SamgrahakƒÅra relied on the same arguments that were employed by DhƒÅre≈õvara and that Visvar≈´pa and others refuted those arguments. The passage in the printed Vi≈õ. is somewhat corrupt in this place. Vis. does place the mother before the father on the ground of the word n√§tƒÅ occurring first when the word ‘pitarau’ or the compound mƒÅtƒÉpitruritu’ is expanded. The comment does mention the verse of Man (9. 217 ) about the grandmother, but it makes no clear sense, as it stands.722 For the reason given above Rai Bahadur M. M. Chakravarti ( JASB for 1922, p. 345 and for 1915, p. 322 ) is not right when he places Vi√üvar≈´pa later than Bhojadeva because of the remarks of the Sm·∫∑ticandrikƒÅ.

In the works of Jim≈´tavƒÅhana ( viz. the DƒÅyabhƒÅga and the Y yavahƒÅram√±trkƒÅ ), in the SmrticandrikƒÅ, the HƒÅralatƒÅ, and other later works like the SarasvativilƒÅsa, the views of Visvarƒ´pa are frequently cited and discussed. Several such citations have been already examined by me (JBBRAS for 1926, pp. 200-204 ). From considerations of space I do not repeat here the discussion of those passages. In the Grhastha. ratnƒÅkara728 of Candesvara (No. 44 of 1883-4, in the Govt.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Mss. Lib at the B. 0. R. Institute Poona, folio 133a ) the explanation of Visvar≈´pƒÅcƒÅrya on YƒÅj. 1. 135 is cited, which does not exactly tally with the printed Vis. HemƒÅdri724 refers to Visvar≈´pa’s: explanation given in his section on partition which does not occur in the printed text. The result of the examination of these citations is that the printed text of Vis. is in the main genuine, but that in a few cases (parti cularly in the vyavahƒÉra section ) it is corrupt or deficient.

Though Vis. holds the same view as the Mit. that owner ship does not for the first time arise on partition but that partition takes place of what is already (jointly ) owned, yet on numerous points the two disagree. A few of them may be set out here.

(1) Vis allows ( on YƒÅj. II. 118 ) the father unrest rictd freedom of distribution of property among his sons during his lifetime, while the Mit. expressly says that this power of unequal distribution is restricted to self acquired property.

( 2 ) Vis. ( on YƒÅj. II. 119 ) allows a share of property to the widows of predeceased sons and grandsons of a man when a partition takes place during his lifetime. The Mit. restricts the word ‘patnyab’ to the father’s own wives when he effects a partition during his lifetime.

(3) Vi≈õ. connects the words without detriment to the paternal estate’( in YƒÅj. II. 122 ) with the words ‘whatever else is acquired by himself’ and not with ‘maitra’ (gifts from a friend ) und udvihika’ (gifts on inarriage ), while the Mit. connects the half verse whatever else is acquired by the man himself without detriment to the paternal estate as a

( 4 ) Vis allows niyog only to s≈´rus in general and to knatriya kings in case of danger of extinction of line ( vide com. on YƒÅj. I. 69 and II. 131 ), while Mit. forbids niyoga in general and holils the texts speaking of it is applicable to a girl who is only betrothed and not married.

( 7 ) Vi≈õ. allows a widow to succeed to her husband if she is pregnant at his death, while Mit. allows a widow to succeed without any restriction except that of chastity.

(8) Vis restricts the word ‘duhitarah‚Äôin ‘patni duhitarascaiva’ ( Yaj. II, 138 ) to putrilƒÉ only and so does not allow all daughters whatever to succeed, while Mit. does not introduce any such qualification

(10) Vis. reads “ƒÄdhivedanikam caiva ‘for “ƒÅdhiveda nikadyam ca’ of Mit, and holds that bandhudatta, sulku and anv√§llheyaku strƒ´lhana of a childless woman goes on her death to her full brother; while Mit. connects these three with the preceding verse and takes the half verse ‘atƒ´tƒÅyam &c.’ 88 laying down a general rule of succession to strƒ´dhand of all kinds and interprets biudhav√§h’ us meaning ‘husband and the rest’.

( 11 ) Vi≈õ. takes the verse adhiviuna-striyai’ &c. con Yaj. II. 152 ) as applicable to a wife superseded without arm ground of supercession allowed by the texts; while Middies! not introduce any such qualification.

FOUNDED

1917

562

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

As Visvar≈´pa quotes KumƒÉrila’s SlokavƒÅrtika and is mentioned by the Mit. as an authoritative commentator it follows that he flourished between 750 A. D. and 1000 A. D. A greater approximation as to the date of Visvar≈´pa can be made, if the identity of Visvar≈´pa with Sure≈õvara be held established. Sure≈õvara, as he himself tells us in the Naiskarmyasiddhi, the Taittiriyopani≈üad bhƒÅsya vƒÅrtika and other works, was √† pupil of the great SankarƒÅcƒÅrya whose generally accepted period is 788-820 A. D. MƒÅdhavƒÅcƒÅrya in several works of his quotes as Visvar≈´pa’s passages from the the well-known works of Sure≈õvara. For example, the ParƒÅ≈õara-MƒÅdhaviya ( vol. I, part I, p. 57 ) quotes a karikƒÅ of Sure≈õvara as that of Visvar≈´pƒÅcƒÅrya.726 In the Vivarana prameyasa·πÅgraba ( Vizianagaram series p. 92 ) also Madhava quotes & verse from the B»ôhadƒÅranyakopanisad bhƒÅsya vƒÅrtika as Visvar≈´pa’s.726 In the PurusƒÅrthaprabodha7a7 of BrahmƒÅnanda-bhƒÅrati (ms. in Bhau Daji collection, Bombay) composed in 1476 (probably of the Saka era ) the author speaks of the Naiskarmyasiddhi as a work of Vi≈°var≈´pa. In the Sa·πÅksepa-Sarkara-jaya, Visvar≈´pa is said to be the author of the two vƒÅrtikas on Sarkara‚Äôs bhƒÅsya.738 According to tradition embodied in the various lives of Sarkara, the latter had four pupils, Sure≈õvara, PadmapƒÅda, Totaka and HastƒÅmalaka. Several works mention Visvar≈´pa as one of the four pupils and omit the name Sure≈õvara. For example, in the DvƒÅda≈õa-vƒÅkya-vivarana of GopƒÅla (Aufrecht’s Oxf. Cat. No. 557, p. 227 b) the four pupils of Sankara are named as Visvar≈´pa, PadmanƒÅbha, Totaka and HastƒÅmalaka. In the MƒÅnasollƒÅsa-v»ôttƒÅnta-vilƒÅsa of RƒÅmatƒ´rtba we are expressly

fou61. Visvar≈´pa

568

told that Sure≈õvara is another name of Visvar≈´pa, a pupil of Sankara (vide Mitra’s Notices vol. V, No. 1763,p. 82). In the Saptas≈´tra-sanƒ±yƒÅsa paddhati (Mitra’s Notices, vol. VI, p. 296 ) the four pupils are said to be Svar≈´pƒÅcƒÅrya, PadmƒÅ cƒÅrya, Totaka and Prthvidhara. The Guruva·πÅsakƒÅvya (Vanivilas ed. ) identifies Suresvara and VisvarƒÅpa ( II.59) and makes him a pupil of Kum√§rila and Sankara. It may therefore be held as fairly established that Visvar≈´pa and Sure≈õvara are identical. Some corroboration is afforded by the fact that Vi≈õvar≈´pa quotes Gauda pƒÅda the ‘paramaguru’ of Sankara and holds the same philosophical views as those of Sarkara. Just as Visvar≈´pa quotes KumƒÅrila’s Sloka vƒÅrtika, Suresvara also in his TaittiriyopanisadbhƒÅsya-vƒÅrtika quotes a kƒÅrikƒÅ of Kumirila and styles the latter MimƒÅ·πÅ sakam-manya.729 This shows that Suresvara treated Kumarila with scant respect, which seems unlikely if he was at any time Kumarila’s pupil. Visvar≈´pa, in his introduction,730 performs an obeisance to the Sun, the great serpent (Sesa ), Tilakasvamin and Vinayaka. The Bhamati of VƒÅcaspati–misra has a similar salutation. VƒÅcaspati–misra wrote his NyƒÅyas≈´ci-nibandha in 841-42 A. D. i. e. he was almost a contemporary of Sankara and his pupils. The learn ed editor of Vi≈õ. tells us that in a commentary on Vi√ü. called Vacanam√°lƒÅ Sure≈õvara is bracketed with Maru and Yogisvara (Yajnavalkya ) as an expounder of Sastra (i. e. dharma sastra ).8l Therefore that commentator looked upon Vis. aud 729 ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•à‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø.

‡§ú‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ï‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•à. ‡§â. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï I. 9-10. verse 110). 730 ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á

The ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä has - ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§£‡•ç‡§° ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ó‡§£‡§™‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡••. ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä would mean ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä. History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Sure≈õvara as identical. From all these several considerations it follows that Visvar≈´pa flourished about 800-825 A. D. But this problem presents further difficulties. The mutual rela tions of Sure≈õvara, Bhavabh≈´ti, Umbeka and Mandana are a great puzzle. I have dealt with this question in JBBRAS for 1928, pp. 289-293. The conclusions arrived at there are that Mandana’s literary activity lies between 690-710, that of Umbeka between 700-730 and Sure≈õvara’s between 810-840

A. D. and that Umbeka and Bhavabhuti are identical, but that Mandana and Sure≈õvara are separated by about 100 years,

In the H. of Dh. Vol. V pp. 1188-1198 the present author has discussed at some length the relative chronological posi tion of KumƒÅrila, PrabhƒÅkara, S√§likanƒÅtha, Mandanami≈õra, Umbeka, Bhavabh≈´ti, Vi≈°var≈´pa and Sure≈õvara and the conclusions relevant to Visvar≈´pa are that Mandanamisra is not identical with Vi≈õvar≈´pa, that Visvarapa and Sure≈õvara are identical and that Sure≈õvara is the name of Visvar≈´pa after the latter became a sunny√§sin. The grounds in favour of the identity of Visvar√ºpa and Sure≈õvara are overwhelming as evidenced by the writings of great scholars like M√§dhavƒÅcƒÅrya.

An interesting matter about Visvar≈´pa may be mentioned here. On YƒÅj. I. 162 / which is one of tbe verses that state the persons whose food should not be partaken of ), ‘grƒÉmayƒÅjin’ is one ( who is abhojy≈´nnu ) and Vi≈õ. remarks that among the M√§lavas a grƒÅmay√§jaki is known as Vai≈°va devika'. It is possible that Visvar≈´pa was an inhabitant of MƒÅlava ( roughly present Malwa ) or that he had stayed there for some years.

Dr. Jolly has brought together in the Journal of Indian History ( vol. III. pp. 1-27 ) some valuable information about Visvar≈´pa.

In several later works a digest called Vi≈õvar≈´pa-uibandha is frequently cited. That appears to be the composition of another Visvar√ºpa altogether. For example, the ≈üan-·ª•avant sr√§ddhanirnaya of Sivablatta (which is later than 160 A, D.) tells us that Vi≈°var≈´pƒÅcirya composed a vivurder

  1. Vi≈°var≈´pa

585

(commentary) on the SraddhakalikƒÅ.732 The KrtyacintƒÅinani of Sivarima ( No. 221 of 1879-80 in the Govt. Mss. Lib. at the B. O. R. Institute, Poona 4 ) quotes several 33 verses from Visvara panibandha on supinda relationship in marriage, which are not found in the BalakridƒÅ. but which agree

remarkably with the words of the Mit. on YƒÅj. I. 53. The Varsakriyakaumudi (pp. 378, 380) mentions Visvarupa nibandha and quotes two verses cited therein. The Tithi nirnaya-sarvasamuccaya ( later than 1450 A. D.) quotes certain lcarileti.s of Visvarupa on the 18 varieties of Ekadasi.734 The Kalanirnayasiddhantavyakhya ( composed in 1653 A. D.) quotes certain verses of Vi≈õvar≈´pa on the question of the disposal of food prepared for a marriage when a period of impurity on death supervenes.135 The Nirnayasindhu also quotes verses of Visvar≈´jia. From these data it follows that a Visvar≈´pa composed a commentary on SrƒÅddhakalik√° and also wrote a digest on matters of acara and other topics of dharma in prose and verse. Raghunandana in his UdvƒÅha-. tattva (ed. by Jivananda, p. 116) names a Visvarupa samuccaya. It is likely that it is the same as Visvarapa nibundlhn.

proper one and not that of BhƒÅruci. The ParƒÅ≈õaramadhaviya736 and the SarasvativilƒÅsa ( para 133 ) inform us that Bharuci was of opinion that unmarried sisters were only entitled to a provision for their marriage and were not entitled to a fourth share.

The SmrticandrikƒÅ ( on VyavahƒÅra p. 268 ) holds that the Visuudharmas≈´tra (chap. 18 ) and YƒÅj. II. 124 ( bhagi nyusca…dattvamsam tu turƒ´yakam ) not to be taken literally but all that is meant is that provision has to be made for the marriage expenses of the unmarried sisters of the sons taking the paternal wealth. The Par. M. (III. p. 510 ) notes that this was the view of BhƒÅruci (as against MedhƒÅtithi and Vij√±ƒÅnesvara and also of the SmrticandrikƒÅ ).

Vide Dr. T. R. Chintamani’s paper on ‘BhƒÅruci’ (in the Pro. of All India Or. Conf. ut Benares in 1943-44, vol. II, pp. 352-360, where he first collects 50 passages of BhƒÅruci found in the SarasvativilƒÉsa, then puts together passages where Medhatithi refers to the views of UpadhyƒÅya and then refers to a fragment of Manusmrti commentary (on chapters VI to XII) where some colophons read RjuvimalƒÅ and others BhƒÅruci.

BhƒÅruci, being mentioned by the Mit., is certainly older than 1050 A. D. RƒÅmƒÅnujƒÉcƒÉrya, in his VedƒÅrthasamgraba ( reprint from the Pandit, ed. of 1924, p. 154 ), mentions six ƒÅcƒÅryas that preceded him as expounders of the VisistƒÅdvaita system, viz. BodhƒÅyana, Tanka, Dramida, Guhadeva, Ka pardin and BhƒÅruci. Similarly, the YatindramatadipikƒÅ787 of SrinivƒÅsadƒÅsa (AnandƒÅ≈õrama ed.) enumerates (p. 2) a host of teachers as the predecessors of RƒÅmƒÅnujƒÅcƒÅrya in propound ing the VisistƒÅdvaita system. VyƒÅsa is the reputed author of the VedƒÅntas≈´tras, BodhƒÅyana is said to have composed a vrtti on the VedƒÅnta-s≈´tras called K»ôtako≈£i according to the

736 ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç, ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã

  1. BhƒÅruci

567

rit

Prapanca-hrdaya ( p. 39, Trivandrum ed.). Tanka and Bra hmƒÅnandin are identical. Dramida is credited with the author ship of a bhƒÅsya on the VedƒÅnta-s≈´tras ( which is quoted by RƒÅmƒÅnuja in his bhƒÅ≈üya on II. 2. 3). NƒÅthamuni is said to have been the grand-father of YƒÅmunamuni, who was born about 916 A. D. RƒÅmƒÅnuja refers to him with great reverence as his teacher’s teacher (parama-quru), vide VedƒÅrtha samgraha, (p. 149 ) and is said to have been young when Yamuna died ( vide J. R. A S. for 1915, p. 147 and I. A. for 1909, p. 129). It is therefore obvious that the teachers are arranged by the YatindramatadipikƒÅ in chronological order. Hence BhƒÅruci, being placed earlier than even Dramida and NƒÅthamuni, was comparatively an ancient author and could not have flourished later than the first half of the 9th century. BhƒÅruci, the jurist, also flourished before 1050. It is difficult to believe that there were two famous writers of the same name nearly about the same time. Hence it may provisionally be held that BhƒÅruci the writer on dharma≈õƒÅstra and BhƒÅruci the Vi≈°istƒÅdvaita philosopher are identical. If this identity be accepted, then BhƒÅruci the writer on dharma≈õƒÅstra becomes comparatively an early writer, being at least as old as Visva r≈©pa. His views agree on several points with those of Visva r≈´pa, which is a circumstance that lends some corroboration to the date proposed for him.

One interesting point about BhƒÅruci deserves mention here. From pumerous notices contained in the SarasvativilƒÅga it appears that BhƒÅruci either commented upon the Vis≈Üu dharmas≈´tra or wrote some work in which he took great pains to incorporate explanations of several s≈´tras of Vis≈Üu. For example, para 637 tells us that Bharuci explained the word' bija' occurring in a sutra of Vi≈ü≈Üu as `pinda ‘.738 In para 674 we are told that BhƒÅruci explained the word

niskƒÅrana’ in a sutra of Visnu and that he held that a daughter’s son has not to perform the sraddha of his maternal grandfather if the latter has a son. SudarsanƒÅcƒÅrya in his comment upon Apastam bagshya ( 8. 21. 2 ) ascribes the same

738 ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§π ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§∞‡•á ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§ø

para 637 ( pp. 422‚Äì23 of Mysore ed.). The s≈´tra of fasor is TEMITTAUTIH Tatar' a. la. para 636.

FOUNO

1911

568

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

view to Bharuci and quotes the very words of BhƒÅruci.739 Vide J BBRAS for 1925 pp. 210-211 for further examples. There is nothing unnatural in Bharuci, the VisistƒÅdvaita philosopher, having composed a commentary on the Visnu dharmas√∫tra. The extant Visnulharmasƒ´tra contains doctri nes peculiar to the Vi≈°istƒÅdvaita system such as the worship of NƒÅrƒÅyana or V√°sudeva, the four Vyuhas of Vasudeva &c. If BhƒÅruci was a Vi≈°ist√±ilvaitin he would naturally turn to the s≈´tra of Visnu as having the greatest claim on his atten tion. Many of the sutras of Vislu quoted in the Sarasvati vil√°sa with the explanations of Bharuci are not found in the printed text of Visnu, on which Nandapandita commented in the first half of the 17th century. It appears that the SarasvativilƒÅsa haid before it a larger version of Visnu current in the South ( vide note 118 p. 127 above ).

On several points there is divergence between the views of BhƒÅruci and those of the Mit. Bh√§ruci differed from the Mit. as to the definition of d√ºyco and vibhƒÅgu, he allowed niyoga to childless widows, while the Mit. condemned it in the case of all widows; Bharuci, like Visvar≈´pa, did not men tion supratibundlove and apratibuƒ±ndar dayco; BhƒÅruci, like Visvar≈´pa, held that a coparcener who concealed some joint property was not guilty of theft, while the Mit. held that he was. Vide J BBRA S for 1925 pp. 211-13 for more examples and details.

Prof. T. R. Chintamani submitted an important paper at the Benares Session of the All India 0. Conf. (in 1943-4) which is published in the proceedings, Vol. II pp. 352-360, wherein he informed scholars that at Trivandrum exists a ms. containiny a fragment of BhƒÅruci’s commentary on Manu called ( Manu≈õƒÅstra-vivarana ) on AdhyƒÅya VI ( almost from the beginning ), on adhyƒÅyas VII-XI and on a portion of
