  1. Bl√∂ruci

569

6

adhyƒÅya XII. Dr. J. D. M. Derrett740 ( recently contributed a paper to the Journal of the American Oriental Society (Vol. 84 for 1964 pp. 392-395) on ¬∑ Blauci on royal regulative power in India', based on Bharuci’s explanation of Manu VII. 13; and another paper in 2. 1), M. G. Vol 115 pp. 134‚Äì152 ( where on pp. 141-151 he arranges in three parallel columns parts of Bharuci’s commentary and Melh√§tithi’s BhƒÅsya on Manu VII. 50, 54, 147, 153, 154, with parallel passages from Kautilya’s Artha≈õƒÅstra and on p. 144 of his paper compares only Bharuci aud MedhƒÉtithi on Manu VII. 52. Dr, Derrett holds (pp. 139-40 of his paper ) that Bharuci is nearer A. D. 700 than the period 800-850 which was assigned to BhƒÅruci in the H. of Dh. Vol. I. 1930 ) p. 265. Dr. Derrett holds (p. 138 of the paper ) that the passages which MedhƒÉtithi takes without acknowledgement froin Kautilya are not obtained from the Artha≈õƒÅstra direct, but from Bharucin, who is quoting from Kautilya with occasional udjustments, that MedhƒÅtithi did not know that he was reproducing the Artha≈õƒÅstra, that the Ms. used by MedhƒÉtithi was lefective, that in some places he could not read it.

What Manu VII. 13741 means is: there are several desirable matters ( istenu ), but the king might decide (or resolve ) to strictly enforce one of them. In that case that matter becomes a rule of Dharma. The same applies to cther matters that are undesirable (anistenu) but the king may resolve to put down with a strong hand one undesirable matter out of many. That would then become the rule of the realm and it has to be obeyed by all. Bh≈´ruci’s exegesis comes to this that the king is not the source of the rules of Dlarƒ±na, but it is SƒÅstra that defines the rules binding on the different varnas (classes) and

741

Probably the Trivandrum My, omploys that form of the name. A VII. 13 is : JHIGH JAZT ARTATIETY: 1 af afrait faag * 7 faretraset 11 HIETA’s comment is : 7 PE TAT ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É, ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§µ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç , ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

√°≈õramas ( stages of man’s life ). If the king were held to be the source of Dharma and adharma there would be great con fusion; one king may make certain rules, while his successor might abrogate them and promulgate other and different rules. He further says that the kivg often times repeats what the Sastra states ( bizhuk≈ôtvas-taduktih ) and that opposing the dicta of SƒÅstra would be wrong and moreover one should hold that this text only extols the king’s office as the context shows.

In the edition of Mandlik on Manu VIII. 150, Medh√£tithi explains that that verse, according to some great ones was explained (iti mahattarair-vyƒÅkhyƒÅtam ) and immediately afterwards sets out the differing view of Yajvan and on Manu VIII. 151, MedhƒÉtithi mentions the explanation of Rju. Dr. Derrett (in footnote 20 on p. 141 of his paper in 2. D. M. G. ) puts forward the suggestion that Yajvan ought to be taken as standing for Rju and that BhƒÅruci is Rju. In the present state of our knowledge I cannot agree to this sugges tion. From MedhƒÉtithi’s bh√¢sya on Manu II. 6743 ( which is a very long one, occupying more than seven printed pages ) it appears that there were many persons designated by MedhƒÅ tithi as ‘Sm·ªôtivivarana karah’ as the quotation cited below will show. On Manu II. 25 he refers to the exegesis of VivaranakƒÅras that Dharma has five aspects (pa√±caprakƒÅro dharma iti VivaranakarƒÅh prapancayanti). It is clear from the parallel passages cited by Dr. Derrett on pp. 141-151 that there is remarkable agreement between the explanation of BhƒÅruci and of MedhƒÅtithi and that probably it is MedhƒÉtithi that borrows. But one’s judgment may be suspended till the

  1. Srikura

whole of Bharuci’s available text is printed and carefully studied. Vide remarks under SarasvativilƒÅsa of Prataparudra deva for various passages of Bharuci referred to and Manu, particularly VII. 13.

  1. Srikara The Mit. on YƒÅj. II. 135 alludes to the view of Srikara and others that the widow succeeded is heir to her deceased husband’s estate if it was small.743 The Smytis√§ra744 of HarinƒÅtha attributes the same view to Srikara and disappro ves of it. On YƒÅj. II. 169 the Mit.746 cites the view of Srikara about that topic and disapproves of it. Visvar≈´pa also gives two explanations of that verse of YƒÅj., the first of which agrees with that of the Mit, and the second is akin to Srikara’s.

The works of Jim√ºtavƒÅhana (viz. the DayabhƒÅga and the VyavahƒÅramƒÅt≈ôkƒÅ ), the SmrticandrikƒÅ and the Sarasvati vilƒÅsa contain very interesting notices of Srikara’s views. Many of them were brought together by ne in JBBRAS for 1925, pp. 213-215. Srikara like Visvar≈´pa held the view that ‘duhitarah in Y√ºj. refers to the putriku, he allowed the parents of a chililless person to succeed together at the same time. The DiyabhƒÅga very severely criticizes the views of Srikara on the succession to re-united members, on vidyƒÅ dhana and on Yaj. II. 24 ( about enjoyment for 20 years ). 148 Most of the views attributed to Srikara were also entertained by Visvar≈´pa ur are more antiquated than Vi≈õvar≈´pa’s.

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

Srikara was probably a writer from Mithila and seems to have propounded the view of spiritual benefit as the criterion for judging superior rights of succession. The Smrtis√§ra747 of HarinƒÅtha ascribes such a view to a Srikara-nibandha.

Whether Srikara wrote a commentary on a smrti or a general digest ( nibandha ) it is difficult to say. The Smrti candrikƒÅ748 says that Sambhu, Srikara and DevasvƒÅmin com piled digests of smitis and allded their own explanations of them. The SmrtyarthasƒÅra?!9 of Sridhara asserts in the in troductory verses that Srikantha and SrikaricƒÅrya filled up the gaps in the smrtis that were scattered about ( by intro ducing order out of chaos ). Srikara’s explanations of Yajina valkya are frequently cited by the Mit., the DƒÅyabhƒÅga and others. But the Mit. does not connect Srikara’s name with YƒÅj√±avalkya as a commentator, though Visvar≈´pe is express ly so connected. It appears therefore inore likely that Srikara

( Continued from the previous page ) ‘‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡§∂‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§… ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞-‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï-‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï-‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü- ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø-‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Ç‡§ï‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü-‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡§®‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ó‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡•§'; ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø of ‡§µ‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú p. 135 refers to this topic. Eambhu is quoted by Apar√§rku (p. 475 on icirn ) and by VyavabƒÅra prakƒÅ≈õa (of Pithvivandru) p. 176 as having the same vorse on

ordeals with Nirada. 747 Vide ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞ ( I. 1). ent. No. 301, folio 1470 ) ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§

‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á‡§É … ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ

‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ 748 ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ

‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç

‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•¶ ( ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•¶ soction p. 266 ). 749 ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ó‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•á‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§ß‡§æ‡•§

‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞ ( Ms. No. 44 of 1870-71 in the Govt. Mas. Library at the B. O. R. Institute, Poona 4, copiod in ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç 194b, has these verses ). 164. MedhƒÅtithi

573

wrote a digest of sm√®tis in which he paid particular attention to the explanation of the words of YƒÅjsavalkya. The RƒÅja nitiratnƒÅkara750 of Candesvara quotes the views of Srikara on RƒÅjaniti, one of which is that the poor and helpless are entitled to a share of the royal wealth.

Hem√•lrist quotes the view of Srikara on Visnu and dis approves of the faults found therein by the author of the Pa·ª•uita-paritosa.

As Srikara is quoted by the Mit., he is certainly earlier than 1050 A. I). As his views agree largely with Visvar≈´pa’s he may provisionally be regarded as nearly of the same period as Visvar≈´pia’s. He cannot be earlier than Asahiya who is named both by Vi≈õvar≈´pa and Medhatithi, though both of them are silent about Srikara. Hence Srikara must be placed somewhere between 800 and 1050 A. D. and probably flourish ed in the 9th century.

This Srikara must be distinguished from another Srikara, the father of SrinƒÅtha.

1

  1. Medhatithi Medhatithi is the author of an extensive and erudite commentary ( bhusyu ) on the Manusmrti. It is the oldest extant commentary on that smrti. The bh√¢sya of MedhƒÉtithi was first published about forty years ago by Rao Saheb V. N. Mandlik in Bombay and recently Mr. J. R. Gharpure of Bombay brought out an edition of MedhƒÅtithi which closely follows Mandlik’s edition. A critical edition of the bhƒÅsya based upon all the available Msg. is a great clesideratum. A new edition in two volumes based on several mss. edited by M. M. Dr. Ganganath Jha was published in the G. O. I. Series in 1932 and 1939. In this edition also ten verses in the 3rd adhyƒÅya are wanting and in adhyƒÅya nine there

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

are substantial lacunas in the commentary on verses 1, 4-6 as in Mandlik’s edition. An English translation of the bhƒÅsya by M, M. Dr. Ganganath Jha is in progress and several parts have been published so far. In the following, Mr. Gharpure’s edition has been used. The bhƒÅsyu as printed is corrupt in many places, particularly in the 8th, 9th and 12th adhyƒÅyus. In Mr. Gharpure’s edition there is no bhlisya on verses 182-202 of the 9th chapter.

B√ºhler in his learned and exhaustive Introductiou to the Manusmrti (S. B. E. vol. 25 ) brings together a good deal of information about MedhƒÅtithi ( pp. CXVIII-CXXVI ). In JBBRA S for 1925, pp. 217-221, I have offered criticisms on some of B√ºhler’s views and have given some additional information.

In several M88. of the bh≈´syu at the end of several adhyƒÅyas occurs a verse782 which says that a king nained Madana, son of SahƒÅrana, brought copies of MedhƒÅtithi’s commentary from another country and effected a restoration (j≈´rnoddh≈´ru ). This does not refer to the restoration of the text of MedbƒÉtithi, but to the completion of the library of the king, who was MadanapƒÅla, son of S√§dhƒÅrana and flourished, as we shall see later on, in the latter half of the 14th century.

Dr. Jolly (Tagore Law Lectures p. 6 ) holds MedhƒÉtithi to be a southerner on account of the fact that his father’s name was Virasvainin and on account of the attention paid to his blƒÅsya by southern writers. It cannot be said that names ending in ‘svƒÅmin’ were a monopoly of the south. The RƒÅjatara rigi≈Üi gives literary celebrities whose names ended in ‘svƒÅrniu’ (e. g. V. 34 mentions a SivasvƒÅmi). K≈°ƒ´rasvƒÅmin was a Kashmirian. The south has always been famed for preserving Mss. of valuable works from the north. M88. of the KƒÅvyƒÅlamkƒÅra of Bhimaha, a K√§shmiriau, are very rare and have been found only in the south. B√ºhler (p. CXX III)

752 ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§≤‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç

  1. Medhitithi

575

seems to be right in holding that MedhƒÅtithi was a Kashmi rinn (or at least an inhabitant of Northern India ). In explain ing such words as ‘svarƒÅ tre‚Äôand janapadah’( Manu VII. 32 and VIII. 42 ) MedhƒÉtithi introduces Kashmir. He gives ( on Manu VIII. 400 ) the monopoly of the sale of elephants as a privilege of the kings of Kashmir where saffron abounds.763 He says that the rainbow is called vijnana-chƒÅyƒÅ’ in Kashmir ( on Manu IV. 59). He very frequently refers to northerners i. e. on Manu III. 234 he says ‘kutapa’ is the word for what is well-known as ‘kambala’ among northern people and on III. 238 he says ‘northern people’wrap their heads with s≈´taukaus (garments ). He says on Manu II. 24 that in the Himalayas in Kashmir it is not possible to perform the daily sundhy≈´ in the open por is it possible to bathe every day in & river in Hemanta ‘and Sisira’. On Manu II. 18 he says in other countries, some say, people marry one’s maternal uncle’s daughter ; but that is opposed to the words of Gautama’ (4.3) and proceeds ‘even in that country taking food in the same plate with (or in the company of ) one whose thread ceremony is not performed is not at all re garded as dharma (but as improper conduct). This is clearly a reference to BaudhƒÅyana Dh. S. (1. 1. 19 ) according to which ‘mƒÅtulasuti-parinayana’ and taking food in the same plate with one whose upanayana is not performed are two of the five usages peculiar to the south. It is fair to add that later writers like Kamalakarabhatta (Nirnayasindhu, 3rd pariccheda on sƒÅpindya ) regard MedhƒÅtithi as a southerner.

MedhƒÅtithi quotes from or names numerous smrti writers, such as Gautama, BaudhƒÅyana, Avasta mba, Vasistha Visuu, Sankba, Manu, Y√°j., NƒÅruda, ParƒÅ≈õara, Brhaspati, KƒÅtyƒÅyana And others. He refers to B»ôhaspati as a writer ou’vƒÅrtƒÅ’ (Manu VII. 43 and IX, 326 ) and to Brhaspati and Ufonas √†s writers on politics and government ( Manu VIII. 283, VII. 2 and 155 ). On Manu VII. 43 he refers to Canakya as a writer on dandaniti'. In numerous places he seems to have

drawn upon Kautilya‚Äôs work. For example, on Manu VII. 155 in interpreting pancavarga' as ‘kupa≈£ika, udƒÅsthita, g·∫∑ha patika, vaidehika and tƒÅpasavya√±jana’ he explains them almost in the words of Kautilya (1. 2 ). On VII, 148 he quotes the five angas of mantra in the very words of Kautilya.784 Vide also his remarks on Manu VII. 54 ( testing of ministers by upalhƒÅs ). He names AsahƒÅya ( on 8. 156 ) and certain writers as Sm·ªôtivivaranakƒÅrƒÅ·∏• ( on II. 25 ). B√ºhler is not quite accurate (p. cxx, n. 1) when he states that MedhƒÅtithi gives only once the name of an early commentator'. On VIII. 3 he refers to the interpretations of Bhartryaj√±a He refers to the interpretations of Yajvan (on VIII. 151 and 156 ). Yajvan is only the last part of a name (as in DevarƒÅja yajvan). He quotes the interpretation of Manu by UpadhyƒÅya (on II. 109, IV. 162, V. 43, IX. 141 and 147 ). B√ºhler holds that MedhƒÅtithi refers to his own teacher. It is more likely that UpadhyƒÅya, like Yajvan, is the name or part of the name of a previous commentator of Manu. On VIII. 152 the explanations of Rju are twice cited. On IX. 253 MedhƒÉtithi cites the view of one VisnusvƒÅmin.765 From the tenor of the quotation it appears that VisnusvƒÅmin was a writer on MimƒÅinga and not a commentator of Manu us B√ºhler thought (p. cxx, n. 1). Some M88. read the word preceding VisnusvƒÅmi as ‘kovara’, others as ‘k√µvara! It is probably ‘kƒÅvera’ (residing on the KƒÅveri river ).

He quotes ( on Manu I. 19 ) a verse from the Sarikhyaka rikƒÅ (prakrter mal≈´n &c ). On Manu I. 5 MedhƒÉtithi remarks that the evolution set out (in Manu I. 5 ff’) is in some parts based on the PurƒÅnas and in some other parts based on the Sankhya system and that it does not matter much as regards dharma' and ‘adharma’ whetber it (i. e. evolution ) is well understood or not. He further states that *MahƒÅn' occurring in Manu I. 15 is the S√£jkhya Mahat tattva' and that in Manu I. 16 ‘ahankƒÅra’ and the five ‘tanmƒÅtrƒÅs ‚Äô of the SƒÅn khya system are mentioned. On Manu

  1. Medhatithi

577

  1. 17 he quotes a part of SankhyakurikƒÅ 22 (pancabhyah pa√±ca bh≈´tƒÅni ) and on I. 19 quotes the first half of the same kƒÅrikƒÅ. He further remarks that the Pauranic procedure of evolution is mentioned by Manu in I. 21.11. He speaks of VindhyavƒÅsa756 as a SƒÉnkhya and says that he does not admit a subtle interim body ( antarabhavadeha ). This is probably taken froun KumƒÅrila’s words.167 He repeatedly refers to the purƒÅ≈Üus, tells us (on 11I. 232) that they were composed by VyƒÅsa and contained accounts of creation. He quotes (on XII. 118) a verse from the VƒÅkyapradipa.168

He tells us ( on II. 6 ) that the Pancarƒ´tras, Nirgranthus (Jains ) and Pasupatas were outside the pale of Vedic orthodoxy.169

MedhƒÉtithi had drunk deep at the fountain of the Parva mimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅ. His bhƒÅsya is full of the terms virthi and artha vƒÅda. On Manu III. 45 (rtu-kƒÅlƒÅbhigƒÅmi syƒÅt ) Medhatithi discusses whether this is a niyamu or parisunkhyƒÅ just as the Mit. on YƒÅj. 1. 79 and 81 discusses the same question and MedhƒÅtitbi quotes the well-known verse vidhir-atyantama prƒÅptau niyamah pƒÅksike sati'&c. MedhƒÉtithi (at the end of his commentary on Manu I. 11 ) remarks that these are arthavƒÅdus and are to be explained some-how in a metaphorical sense, and not literally (ArthavƒÅdƒÅ… yathƒÅ kathƒÅ√±cidgunavƒÅdena niyante ). For Arthavƒ´da and its three varieties, vide H. of Dh. Vol. V. part 2 pp. 1240-1. On Mapu II. 1 he remarks in the first adhyƒÅya five or six verses are meant to set out the purpose of this s√§stra, the rest are artha vƒÅdas and it does not matter much if they are not well understood ; instruction is directly given here (in II. 1 and the following verses on What Dharma is ‘. Even in Chap. II he remarks that II, 83, 87, 233 are mere arthavƒÅdas, Vide, for example, remarks on Manu III. 17, 19, 37, 50, 56, V. 53-54, VIII. 21, 22, 98 &c. He quotes Jaimini’s S≈´tras frequently and applies them to the interpretation of smrti texts at every step. Vide J BBRAS for 1925 p. 219 for 78 ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡§ø on ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å

(S. B. E. vol. 25, CXXIII. n. 1). 759 ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å‡§™‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

examples. He cites passages from Sabara’s bh≈´sya (e. g. on III. 1). He mentions KumƒÅrila by name (on I.3) and as BhattapƒÅda ( on Manu II. 18 ).

MedhƒÅtithi mentions several nyƒÅyas for explaining the Manusmrti. On II. 29 he extends the MimƒÅ·πÅsƒÅnyƒÅya (sarva sƒÅkh√£pratyayam-ekam karma’ P. M. S. II. 4. 8-33 which applies to Vedic passages ) to Sm·ªôtis also and states that where the smrtis differ, there is either an option or all pro visions of the Sm·ªôtis on a certain point are to be added up; vide H. of Dh. Vol. V. p. 1350 for this nyƒÅya. On Manu II.101 he mentions the nyƒÅya ‘Gunalope ca mukhyasya’ for an explanation of which, vide H. of Dh. Vol. V. p. 1343 (where it is shown that it is based on P. M. S. X. 2. 63 ). On Manu II. 102 he quotes the verse ‘arke cet madhu vindeta kimartham parvatam vrajet’( quoted by Sabara on I. 2. 4 ). Vide H. Dh. Vol. V. p. 1340 for references. On Manu X. 127 Medb√•tithi relies on ‘Y√§vad-vacanam vƒÅcanikam’, for which vide H. Dh. V. p. 1348. Another nyƒÅya that M. mentions is nimittƒÅv≈ü. ttau naimittikƒÅv»ôtti·∏•' on Manu X1. 220, which is explained in H. of Dh. Vol. V. p. 1345.

Some common nyƒÅyas mentioned by M. are ¬∑ BrƒÅhma·πáa parivrƒÅja kanyƒÅya (on Manu I. 22 ), KƒÅkatƒÉliya-nyƒÅya (on Manu I. 12 ), Visvajit-nyƒÅya ( on Manu II. 2).

B√ºhler at first took the remark on Manu XII. 19 ) about SƒÅrƒ´raka' as780 referring to Sankara‚Äôs bhƒÅsya on the VedƒÅnta sutra, but later on changed his opinion (SBE vol. 25, p. CXXII) and held that it probably implies a reference to the SƒÅrƒ´raka s≈´tras. B√ºhler’s considered opinion does not seem to be right. The words ‘yatheha rƒÅjƒÅ … apaiti’ are a summary of Sankara‚Äôs bhƒÅsya on VedƒÅntas≈´tra II. 1. 34 and II. 3. 42. and I. 2. 11-12. On Manu II. 83 he refers to the Upanisad bhƒÅsya761 on ChƒÅndogya II. 23. 4 and says that that passage

780 ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§ö ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ê‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç

‡§Ø‡§•‡•á‡§π ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡•à‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•å ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§

The gyfater passage is 7291 771 affor qafo di quota ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•É‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ'. ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡§ø explains ‘‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã

19

  1. MedhƒÅtithi

579

has been differently explained in the bhƒÅsya. Sankara does explain that passage of the Ch√°ndogya differently. But this is not all. In various other places MedhƒÅtithi seems to have in view the SƒÉrirakabhƒÅsya of Sarkara. For example, he makes an obeisance to Parabrahma like an advaitin vedƒÅnta vedya-tattvaya…parasmui Brahmane namah’. On I. 80 he ha8782 before himn Sankara’s bhƒÅsya on the s≈´tra ‘lokavat tu Tilakaivalyam’ ( Vedantasutra II. 1. 33 ). He, however, seems to have favoured the position that the attainment of noksa is due763 not to mere correct knowledge but to the combina tion ( samuccurya) of knowledge and learma ( vide remarks on Manu VI. 32, 74-75 and XII. 87-90 ). This was probably due, as Kullika remarks784 ( on I. 3), to his being a profound studeut of MimamsƒÅ.

Froin MedhƒÅtithi‚Äôs bhƒÅsya it is perfectly clear that the text of Manu on which he commented was practically the same that we have now. He refers to ancient (cirantana) expositors of Manu (on V. 127 ) and to former ( p≈´rva ) ex positors (IV. 176, II. 134, X. 21 ). He discusses various read ings in several places ( vide III. 119, IV, 99, 185, 229,

VIII. 53 ). On VIII, 182-183 he notes?05 that the order of the verses was traditionally different. Kull≈´ka also notices that those two verses and the next two were read in one order by MedlƒÅtithi and Bhojadeva and in another by GovindarƒÅja. In numerous places he refers (in the words ‘auye’, ‘kecit’’ pirval’) to the explanations of the Manusmrti that ditfer from his own; vide for example, on I. 28, 84, II. 5 ( bahavascƒÅtra vyƒÅkhyƒÅvikalpƒÅh, asƒÉratvat tu na pradarsitƒÅ·∏• ), II. 28, 8+; III. 109; VIII. 1, 2, 20, 30, 43, 359, 375, 410; IX. 18, 64, 76; X. 21, 188. On several verses his bhƒÅsya extends to three, four or even five printed pages as on II. 105, 189, III. I(five pages ), 238, V. 2, VIII. 104, 148, X. 5.

One remarkable fact about MedhƒÅtithi may be mentionell here. Vij√±ƒÅnesvara flourished about two hundred years after Medhatithi and names 80 Smrtis and Sm·ªôtik≈´ras. Yajna valkya (1. 4-5) names twenty authors that propounded Dharma. This leads one to presume that most of the works with those prefixes were either not composed before MedhƒÅtithi or ( more probably ) were recent works in Medhatithi’s day or that, even th some of them were composed sometime before MedhƒÉtithi, they had not penetrated to distant Kashmir in MedhƒÉ tithi’s day.

MedhƒÅtithi’s bh≈´sya is full of very interesting information. But for want of space it cannot be analysed in detail. The Mit. (on YƒÅj. TarcaFT: 1 √Ä 110 00 #7 VI. 32. 788 ‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§É, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡•ã

yggd i 10 ON H9 9. 188,

582

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

adopt even a ksatriya boy. He explains away the well-known verse ‘naste mrte…patiranyo vidhiyate’ by taking the word ‘pati’ in its etymological sense and says769 that the verse suggests that in order to maintain herself in such calamities the woman may take service with another person as her protector.

MedhƒÅtithi quotes several verses from his own work called Smrtiviveka on Manu II. 6 ( in all 24 verses ) and on X. 5 he says that he has dealt with the topic of mixed castes in Smrtiviveka. That work, therefore, was either entirely in verse or contained numerous verses. The ParƒÅ≈õara-Madhaviya ( vol. I, part 2, pp. 183-186 ) has a long quotation in verse on the duties of yatis from & work called Smrtiviveka and the game work several times quotes verses attributed to MedbƒÉtithi ( vol. I, part I, p. 276 and part 2, p. 172). Hence the Smrti viveka cited by the ParƒÅ≈õara-MƒÉdhavƒ´ya most probably is MedhƒÅtithi’s work. Lollata, o an early writer quotes several verses of MedhƒÅtithi in his work on srƒÅddha'. In the Tithi niruaya-sarvasamuccaya ( Bhadkamkar collection ) several verses of MedhƒÉtithi on obstacles to marriage such as death are quoted.771 In the Yatidharmasangraha of Visvesvara– sarasvati ( AnandƒÅ≈õrama ed. p. 27 ) two well-known verses about ‘costƒÅngamaithuna’ ( viz. smara≈Üam kƒÅrtanai keli·∏•

769 ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§∏‡•à‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§æ. on ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å.

    1. 770 ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§∏‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É, ‡§§‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø

‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ( folio 4h of the ms. of ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ by ‡§≤‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ü‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø in the ‡§Ü‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ library at Poona ) ; ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ã‡§§‡•å ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•å

‡§ö‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ( ibid. folio 10a ). 771 ‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§• ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø

‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§( ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§? )‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ( folio 45b ) ; ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§¶‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ( folio 46 a ); ‡§ö‡•å‡§≤‡•á ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ( ‡§® ? ) ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• (folio 47a ); ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ó‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ú‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•á ‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§™‡•á ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•• ( folio bla ). The first two verses occur in ‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞’s commentary on the ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø and the last three are cited in the ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø of ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡•§

Ms. No. 221 of 1879-80, folios 54 b, bba, 56 b. in the Govt. Mss. at the B.O. R. Institute, Poona 4.64. MedhƒÅtithi

583

etc.) are ascribed to MedhƒÉtithi and another verse72 is cited (on the same page ) about the six duties of yatis. These quotations show that MedhƒÅtithi wrote an extensive work in verse on several topics of dharma. It is to be fervently hoped that this work of MedhƒÉtithi would be brought to light some day or other. Coming as it does from such an erudite and ancient writer, it would throw a flood of light on the development of dharma≈õƒÅstra.

As MedhƒÅtithi names AsahƒÅya and KumƒÅrila and most probably quotes the views of SankarƒÅcƒÅrya, he is later than 820 A. D. As the Mit looked upon him as an authoritative writer, he must be earlier than 1050 A. D. Most probably be flourished between 825 and 900 A. D. Kull≈´ka"73 on Manu III. 127 says that MedhƒÉtithi is much earlier than GovindarƒÅja ( 1050-1100 A. D. ). Lollata is mentioned as a predecessor in the Smrtyartha-s√§ra of Sridhara, which was composed between 1150–1200 A. D. So Lollata is much earlier than 1150 A. D. He looked upon Medhatithi as a writer whose work was as authoritative as a smrti. A work called PrakƒÅ≈õa774 which is quoted in the Kalpataru appears to have mentioned Medha tithi. HemƒÅdri quotes at great length MedhƒÉtithi’s comments in several places. 776 Hence the above date is amply corrobo rated. This conclusion is further strengthened by the fact that, though he names AsahƒÅya, he does not mention Vi√üve r√ºpa, BhƒÅruci or Srƒ´kara. If by Migra,778 in his comment on Manu XII. 118 he refers to VƒÅcaspati-migra, the author of the BhƒÅmati aud other works, then he will have to be placed after 850 A. D.

772 ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ü‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§™‡•ã ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∑‡§°‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ

‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π. 773 ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡§®‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ 774 Vide note 222. 775_Vide ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó III. 1. 1082-83 where ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡§ø's comment on ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å

III. 265 is cited. 776 ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§è‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§
